Name: だ
Meaning: To be, Is
About: For the most part, だ is the equivalent of 'is' in English. Its role is to strongly express determination or assertion. It is a casual grammar structure, which means that you won't see it in polite sentences. Technically, だ is an auxiliary verb, a group of words that attach themselves to other words to give them meaning. です has the same role as だ, but です is the one that will be used in polite sentences, and is also one of the first Japanese grammar patterns many people are exposed to. だ will always follow nouns, or words that behave like nouns, such as な-Adjectives.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アイスクリームだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is ice cream.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お寺だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is a temple.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 危険だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is dangerous.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大切だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is important.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大きいだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is big. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大きいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is big. (Natural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 本だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is a book.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 猫だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (It) is a cat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 学生だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (I) am a student.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 綺麗だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is beautiful.

Name: です
Meaning: To be, Is
About: Similarly to だ, です is an auxiliary verb that is an expression of determination or assertion. It states that something 'is' a certain way. です is considered to be the polite variation of だ. Keep in mind though that although their roles are similar, both だ and です are standalone structures. です connects to words in exactly the same way as だ, but is also regularly seen attached to the end of い-Adjectives.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大学生です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am a college student.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 店です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is a store.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 綺麗です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is beautiful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 面白いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is funny.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 暑いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is hot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ペンです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is a pen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: さくらです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (I) am Sakura.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (He/she) is a friend.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暑いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is hot.

Name: は
Meaning: As for... (Highlights sentence topic)
About: は (pronounced わ) is often considered to be one of the most difficult particles to master in Japanese, alongside が. は marks the topic of the sentence, and describes the whole sentence broadly. However, が primarily marks single actions or statements. We will explore this distinction in more detail when covering が. In many sentences (especially short ones), either は or が would be considered perfectly natural. This depends on whether someone is simply stating something (は), or highlighting it especially (が). In the first sentence, は broadly describes what the sentence is about (curry). In the second sentence, は again describes the whole sentence being about 'me', but が highlights one specific piece of information (wine being the thing that is hated).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんは先生です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san is a teacher. (Broadly speaking, not compared to anything)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はトムです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am Tom. (Broadly speaking, not compared to anything)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カレーは辛い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Curry is spicy. (Broadly speaking, not compared to anything)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は、ワインが嫌い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I (as the topic of this sentence) dislike wine. (Specifically wine)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今はテスト。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have a test now. (Slightly unnatural, as the test is happening 'right now')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は、雨。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It will rain today. (Natural, as rain is a fairly broad event)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は、金曜日が好き。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like Fridays. (Focus is on Friday)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は、金曜日は好き。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like Fridays. (Focus is on the comparison to other days)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私はトムです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I (as the topic of this sentence) am Tom.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたはジムです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You (as the topic of this sentence) are Jim.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムは先生です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tom [as the topic of this sentence] is a teacher.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: カバンは汚い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The bag (as the topic of this sentence) is dirty.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: カレンダーは必要です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A calendar (as the topic of this sentence) is necessary.

Name: も
Meaning: Also, Too, As well, Even, Either, Neither
About: も can mean 'too/also', or 'even', or 'neither/either', depending on if the sentence is affirmative or negative. Multiple meanings like this are quite common for Japanese particles, as there is no need to use different words simply to agree with other statements in the sentence (unlike English). As you can see here, English requires 'either/neither (when negative)', or 'too/also', but Japanese only requires も. You can think of it as simply meaning 'Whatever is true for (A), is also true for (B)'. も is part of many other compound grammar structures in which it keeps its original meaning, but shifts the nuance a little bit. Some of these include でも, にも～ない, とも. As we can see, it is frequently paired with other particles! Here, も can be seen pairing with で. This suggests that 'With (A), (B) also'. This is regularly translated simply as 'but' in English, despite the nuance being closer to 'and also'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は、先生です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am a teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私も先生です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm also a teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車は早い、でも危ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Cars are fast, and also dangerous.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたもトムです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You are also Tom.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私も。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Me too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼も先生です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is also a teacher.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 服も古い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The clothes, too, are old.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君も、忙しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You are also busy.

Name: これ
Meaning: This
About: これ is often thought to be equal to 'this' in English, which is basically correct. これ will always be used to highlight something that is close to the speaker either emotionally, or physically. Despite being translated as a 'pronoun' in English, it might be easier to think of これ as a substitute noun (the literal meaning in Japanese), as this is always its function. これ substitutes for something that has its own name, but is not required in the context of the sentence, or is simply unknown by the speaker.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 健康。これは大切だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Health. This is important. (Emotionally close)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これも？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This too? (Physically close)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはお菓子です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is candy. (Physically close)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはステーキです。これはいいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is a steak. It is good. (これ acts like 'it' in English, in the second sentence)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これはペンです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a pen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは本です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a book.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは寿司です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is sushi.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これも寿司です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is also sushi.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは、海です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is the sea.

Name: それ
Meaning: That
About: Just like これ, それ is considered to be a pronoun in Japanese (more accurately it is a substitute noun). それ translates roughly to 'that' and highlights something that is closer to the listener (physically or emotionally) than the speaker. In these sentences, we can see それ highlighting things that the speaker is identifying as being closer to the listener, or about the listener. それ is also used to point back to things that have been mentioned previously in the conversation. This can be something that was said earlier within the same sentence, or something that someone else said.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それだ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is that! (That's it!)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは大変だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That's tough.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それも高い？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is that expensive too? (About something mentioned earlier)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは…
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That's hmmm... (About something mentioned earlier. This statement could be translated as 'I'm not sure about that...')

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それもエアコンです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That is also an air conditioner.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは本です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That is a book.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それも本です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That is also a book.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは、水です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That is water.

Name: あれ
Meaning: That (over there)
About: あれ, just like これ and それ, is one of several 'pronoun-like' words in Japanese (substitute nouns). あれ translates roughly to 'that' in English. However, unlike それ, あれ is used to highlight things that are away from both the speaker and the listener. Due to this, it is also often translated as 'that over there'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あれは、病院です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is a hospital. (Away from the speaker and listener)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あれは、バス停です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That over there is a bus stop.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あれは何？
Questions.EnglishHTML: What is that over there?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あれはコンビニです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That over there is a convenience store.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あれはホテルです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That over there is a hotel.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あれは、電車です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That over there is a train.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あれは、兄です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That over there is my older brother.

Name: の
Meaning: Indicates possession
About: From the perspective of English, の has several different meanings. It can indicate possession, like putting (A)'s on the end of a word. In Japanese, however, the meaning is a bit broader, and shows that (B) is an attribute/possession of (A). In the first sentence, we can see that の is showing ownership, however in the second sentence, it is simply showing a relationship between (A) and (B). の is also often used in the same way as が, to highlight the subject of a statement. Our lesson for が will be covered separately.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは妹の車です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is my younger sister's car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日の夜。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today's night. (Not very natural in English, but 'tonight' is an attribute of 'today' in Japanese, so it works)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が好きなお酒はビールです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My preferred drink is beer. (Alcoholic drink)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の好きなお酒はビールです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My preferred drink is beer. (Alcoholic drink)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あれは私のペンです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That over there is my pen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これも私のペンです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is also my pen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは私の猫です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is my cat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生の傘です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (It) is the teacher's umbrella.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたの名前は？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Your name is?

Name: 良(い)い
Meaning: い-Adjective meaning 'good'
About: いい is an adjective that means 'good' in Japanese. It can be a little bit difficult to use at first, as it conjugates differently to other い-Adjectives. In these sentences, we can see that the first い in いい changes to よ, depending on the form. This is unique to いい, and does not happen with other adjectives. いい can sometimes be seen as 良(よ)い, in these cases, the kanji is likely to be read as よい, and not いい. There is technically no difference between these two meanings, but よい does sound more formal/old-fashioned.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはいい映画だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is a good movie.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは良くない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is not good.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日の天気はよかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Yesterday's weather was good.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日の天気はよくなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Yesterday's weather was not good.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはいい車だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is a good car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これも良い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is also splendid. ('Splendid' is similar to the nuance that よい gives いい)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (It is) good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これはいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これはいい本です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a good book.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これもいい本です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is also a good book.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これはいい音だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a good sound.

Name: い-Adjective
Meaning: Adjectives ending in い
About: In Japanese, い-Adjectives are known as 'form containing words', and are used to describe nouns. All い-Adjectives end in い in their base form. As mentioned, all い-Adjectives end in い in their base form. However, not all words ending in い are い-Adjectives. Let's take a look at some of the words that are commonly mistaken for い-Adjectives. In addition to きらい above, there is also きれい. きれい actually comes from the kanji structure 綺麗(きれい), with い being part of the kanji itself. This is never the case with い-Adjectives, where the い will always be outside of the kanji. Due to the kanji for 綺麗(きれい) being somewhat difficult, this word is often written in hiragana or katakana, which leads to confusion for learners. Unfortunately there is no rule for distinguishing which words ending in い are not い-Adjectives, but thankfully, there are not very many of them, so it won't be long before you become familiar with them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 温い水。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Lukewarm water.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 狭い道。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Narrow road.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: バナナも嫌い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I also don't like bananas.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 水はきれい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The water is clear.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本の道は、狭いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Japan's roads are narrow. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 温泉の風呂は熱いだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The onsen's baths are hot. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暑いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is hot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は暑いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is hot today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寒いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is cold.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは楽しいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is fun.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新しい車。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A new car.

Name: な-Adjective
Meaning: Adjectives that are also nouns
About: In Japanese, the vast majority of な-Adjectives are originally nouns, and differ from nouns only in that they have their own set of conjugation rules. The dictionary form of a な-Adjective will always be followed by だ. な is only attached when describing another noun. As we can see from these examples, だ or です is required at the end of a sentence, but な will be required when using a な-Adjective to describe a noun. な-Adjectives are mostly words of foreign (Chinese/English) origin. This is why they have evolved to require unique conjugation rules.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 魚は大好きだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I love fish. (Fish are loved by me)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大好きな野菜です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A vegetable that I love.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: とても綺麗。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Very pretty. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: とても外。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Very outside. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 綺麗な絵。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A pretty painting.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 綺麗な女の人。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A pretty woman.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暇な一日。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A free day.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 静かな部屋。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A quiet room.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あれは綺麗です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That over there is beautiful.

Name: か
Meaning: Question marking particle
About: か is a particle that frequently comes at the end of sentences in Japanese, and carries the same meaning as a question mark in English. (It is not limited to appearing at the end of sentences, however). In addition to questions, か can also express uncertainty about something, without strictly being a question. か regularly comes after the polite form of words, such as ～ですか, ～ますか. However, in casual conversation, か can be used directly after the word that the speaker is showing uncertainty about. Both examples are grammatically correct, but the sentence without です may be considered rude by some people (as it sounds too familiar/direct).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはコップですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is this a cup? (Plain question)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたのアパートは大きいですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is your apartment big? (Plain question)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 美味しいか分からない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't know if this is delicious or not. (Expressing uncertainty, but not a question)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは何か分からない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't know what this is. (Expressing uncertainty, but not a question)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大丈夫ですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are you okay? (Standard pattern)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大丈夫か？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are you okay? (Very casual pattern)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは本ですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is this a book?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これはあなたの本ですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is this your book?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これもあなたの本ですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is this also your book?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これはペンですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is this a pen?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これはいいですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is this good?

Name: が
Meaning: Subject marking particle, Identification particle
About: が is considered to be the subject marker in Japanese. This means that it marks someone or something that is performing an action, or it identifies someone or something as having a specific feature (this is usually a feature that the listener is not aware of). In both of these sentences, が puts focus on the thing performing an action/existing in some way (as opposed to any other thing). Because of this, が is usually said to highlight what comes before it, while は highlights what comes after it. が always shows the 'target' of a statement, when other targets also exist. This is why が is used to describe situations that are happening either 'in the moment', or 'individually of other things'. Because the group in this sentence is only one group out of many possible 'groups of people' that could be described, が will be used.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 父が働く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My father works. (My father is the one who does work)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 父は背が高い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My father is tall. (My father's stature is the thing that is tall)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コーヒーが好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like coffee. (I specifically like coffee)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: テストは嫌いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I dislike tests. (In general, I don't like tests)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 近所の子供たちが走る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The neighborhood kids will run. (As opposed to some other group of people)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お茶が冷たいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The tea is cold.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何がいい？
Questions.EnglishHTML: What is good? (What would you like?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それがいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That is good. (That is what I would like)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: カレーが辛い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The curry is spicy. (The curry is the thing that is spicy)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 木が高い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The tree is tall. (The tree is the thing that is tall)

Name: よ
Meaning: Emphasis (Sentence ending particle)
About: よ is classified as a sentence ending particle in Japanese. In most cases, it is used to convey new information to the listener, or just to add a bit of emphasis. Like most sentence ending particles, it is simply added to the end of almost any sentence. Despite the standard use of よ being to convey new information, it is also very regularly paired with ね, to convey the meaning of 'right?!'. This more literally means something closer to 'I think (A), and I bet you think (A) too!'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは熱いよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is hot!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は雨だよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's going to rain tomorrow!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あれは先生だよね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That over there is a teacher, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車は高いよね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't you think cars are expensive?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムは足が速いよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tom has fast feet. (Tom is a fast runner)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は背が高いよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am tall.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 野球は楽しいよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Baseball is fun.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これはケーキだよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a cake.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それはいいよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That is good.

Name: ね
Meaning: Isn't it?, Right? (Sentence ending particle)
About: ね is classified as a sentence ending particle in Japanese. It may also be pronounced as ねえ. ね is used when the speaker is looking for agreement from someone, or wants confirmation about something. Due to this, it is often translated as 'right?', or 'isn't it?'. To use ね, simply add it to the end of almost any sentence. As we will cover in our lesson about the sentence ending particle な, ね can almost be thought of as the opposite. ね is used when expressing a shared opinion, a shared thought, or generally something you think will be agreed with by the listener. However, な focuses almost exclusively on the speaker, and their own thoughts.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事は疲れるね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Work is tiring, isn't it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日も暑いね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's hot today too, isn't it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あれは綺麗だね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is pretty, isn't it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は寒いですね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's cold today, isn't it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは辛いね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is spicy, don't you think? (You and your friend are at a curry restaurant. After taking your first mouthful, you turn to your friend and say this, because you think they would agree)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは辛いな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is spicy, yeah? (You and your friend are at a curry restaurant. After taking your first mouthful, you notice that it is spicier than usual. You turn to your friend and say this, because you want them to know that you feel this way)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 松下さんはかわいいよね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Matsushita-san is cute, isn't she?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いいですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That's good right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 美味しいね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's delicious, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寒いね！
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is cold, isn't it!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いい質問ですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That is a good question, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自転車はいいね。︎
Questions.EnglishHTML: Bicycles are nice, aren't they?

Name: る-Verb (Dictionary)
Meaning: る + ます (Ichidan Verbs)
About: る-Verbs are verbs that have only one possible conjugation pattern. This pattern simply involves the replacement of る with another construction, depending on the tense of the verb (past, negative, etc). This conjugation pattern that only includes る is where the Japanese name Ichidan (一段(いちだん)) 'one-level' comes from. In these examples, we can see that る is removed from the verb to create the polite ます form. The る form of the verb is often called 'plain form', 'casual form', or 'short form', depending on the source/book.All る-Verbs end in the kana る, there are no exceptions to this rule.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 生徒が答える。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The student answers.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 生徒が答えます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The student answers.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が閉める。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will close it. ('It' is implied, despite no object being stated)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が閉めます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will close it. ('It' is implied, despite no object being stated)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それも取る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will take that too.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それも取ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will take that too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 見る → 見ます
Questions.EnglishHTML: To look

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寝る → 寝ます
Questions.EnglishHTML: To go to sleep

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 覚える → 覚えます
Questions.EnglishHTML: To memorize/remember

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食べる → 食べます
Questions.EnglishHTML: To eat

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 浴びる → 浴びます
Questions.EnglishHTML: To wash/shower

Name: う-Verb (Dictionary)
Meaning: う + ます (Godan Verbs)
About: う-Verbs include all of the verbs in Japanese that end in う sounds (including some of the verbs that end in る). These verbs are called Godan (五段(ごだん)) 'five-level' verbs in Japanese, due to their conjugations using all 5 of the different sounds in the same column (段(だん)) that their base form comes from. As we can see here, the く in 聞(き)く changes to き when conjugated to the polite form. All of the other sounds the K-column will be used with 聞(き)く, depending on the conjugation. This is the same for all of the う-Verbs. 聞(き)かない, 聞(き)きたい, 聞(き)く, 聞(き)ける, 聞(き)こう Here we can see the う-Verb 聞(き)く using all of the different K-column sounds in various conjugations.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はパンクも聞く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I also listen to punk music.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 学生たちは先生の話も聞きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The students listen to the teachers also.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 聞く → 聞きます
Questions.EnglishHTML: To listen/hear

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 座る → 座ります
Questions.EnglishHTML: To sit down

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 飲む→ 飲みます
Questions.EnglishHTML: To drink

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 打つ → 打ちます
Questions.EnglishHTML: To hit

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会う → 会います
Questions.EnglishHTML: To meet

Name: を
Meaning: Object marking particle
About: In Japanese, を is a particle that marks the object of an action. This means that the subject (the person or thing performing an action) is performing that action with the object being the goal/target of the action. In most cases, whatever を is attached to will not actually be 'doing' anything, but will instead have something being done to it. In these sentences, を is marking the thing that is having an action performed 'on' it. This is how the Japanese language views the 'object'. However, unlike English, an object can also be a place in which an action is performed 'through', if the goal of that action is based in that location itself. In these sentences, を is marking the place 'through' which the action is taking place. This use of を highlights that the place itself is what is being interacted with (running/walking requires interaction with the ground, so the ground/place is the object).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ラーメンを食べる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To eat ramen. (Object marker)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 歌を歌います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To sing a song. (Object marker)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 公園を歩く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To walk through a park. (The park is the object that 'walking' is being performed through) (Object marker)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 建物の中を走る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To run through a building. (The inside of the building is the object that 'running' is being performed through) (Object marker)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 漢字を覚える。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To memorize kanji. (object marker)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何を食べますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: What will you have to eat? (object marker)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: バターを食べる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To eat butter. (object marker)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スポーツを見る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To watch sports. (object marker)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 時計を見る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To look at the clock. (object marker)

Name: ます
Meaning: Polite Verb Endings
About:
In traditional Japanese teaching, ます is introduced as something placed on the verbs to create the 'polite form'. While this is true, taking a bit of a closer look at what ます is by itself will help us understand the concept more clearly. ます is an auxiliary verb, which means it is a word that connects to other words in order to change the meaning. For ます, this change occurs on verbs, and creates the polite form.
To use ます, attach it to the conjunctive form of the verb. Because most students see ます so early in their learning, the 'conjunctive form' is often simply called the 'ます form', or the 'ます stem'  in many resources, as it may be easier to remember what to do with the verb that way. Basically, ます is to verbs what です is to nouns and adjectives. They are both auxiliary verbs, and together they form the basis of polite language in Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が食べます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will eat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 猫が寝ます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The cat will sleep.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 猫は走ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The cat will run.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 飛行機が飛びます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The airplane will fly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは私ですが…
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is me, but…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は飲みますが…
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He drinks, but…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたが運転します車はどれですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Which car is the one you drive? (Unnatural Japanese, as ます cannot be used when creating a noun phrase)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は毎日運転します。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I drive every day. (Natural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は寝ます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will sleep.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕も遊びます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will hang out too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このマッサージは効きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This massage is effective.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 母は映画を見ます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mum will watch a movie.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 桜の花が咲きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The cherry blossom’s flowers will bloom.

Name: る-Verb (Negative)
Meaning: Will/Does/Do (not)
About: The negative form of る-Verbs are conjugated based on the same set of rules used for other forms of る-Verb conjugation (removal of る, followed by the addition of something else). In the case of negation, the additional component will be ない (casual), or ません (polite). While the common translation of ない and ません is simply 'not', they actually have several possible nuances. These nuances are 'don't' (usually not), 'won't' (intentionally not), or 'can't' (unintentionally not). Both ない and ません are auxiliary verbs (ません is a conjugation of ます), meaning that they have their own set of conjugation rules.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は、肉を食べない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't eat meat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は黒板が見えません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't see the black board.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は人の名前を覚えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't remember people's names. (Unintentionally not)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はプレゼントを開けません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I won't open the present. (Intentionally not)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
寿司を食べない。
寿司を食べないです。
寿司を食べません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't eat sushi.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
テレビを見ない。
テレビを見ないです。
テレビを見ません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't watch TV.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
お金を借りない。
お金を借りないです。
お金を借りません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will not borrow money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
パンを食べない 。
パンを食べないです。
パンを食べません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't eat bread.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
ホラー映画は見ない。
ホラー映画は見ないです。
ホラー映画は見ません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't watch horror movies.

Name: う-Verb (Negative)
Meaning: Will/Does/Do (not)
About: The negative form of う-Verbs are conjugated based on the same set of rules used for other forms of う-Verb conjugation (changing the last kana, followed by the addition of something else). In the case of negation, the additional component will be  ない (casual), or ません (polite). As can be seen here, the kana change differs depending on whether ない or ません is being used. If ない will be used, the last kana will always change from the kana ending with a う sound, to the kana ending with an あ sound within the same row. If ません will be used, the change will be from the う sound kana to the い sound kana. The only exception to this rule are verbs that end in the kana う. Instead of changing to あ (the あ sound kana in the same row), う will become わ, when used with ない. While the common translation of ない and ません is simply 'not', they actually have several possible nuances. These nuances are 'don't' (usually not), 'won't' (intentionally not), or 'can't' (unintentionally not). Both ない and ません are auxiliary verbs (ません is a conjugation of ます), meaning that they have their own set of conjugation rules.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は川で泳がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She does not swim in rivers.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は川で泳ぎません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She does not swim in rivers.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はカラオケで歌を歌あない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't sing songs at karaoke. (Incorrect conjugation using あ)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はカラオケで歌を歌わない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't sing songs at karaoke. (Correct conjugation using わ)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は泳ぎません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't swim. (Unintentionally not)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日はお酒を飲まない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today, I won't drink. (Intentionally not)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
お金はない。
お金はないです。
お金はありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't have money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
車は持たない。
車は持たないです。
車は持ちません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I won't have a car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
木は歩かない。
木は歩かないです。
木は歩きません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Trees do not walk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
トミーは話さない。
トミーは話さないです。
トミーは話しません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tommy does not talk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
ボールを打たない。
ボールを打たないです。
ボールを打ちません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: to not hit a ball

Name: と
Meaning: And
About: と is a particle that is often thought of as meaning 'and' in English, which is usually how it can be translated. In a broader sense, と simply shows that there is a relationship of 'compilation' between (A) and (B). That relationship could be existing together (translated as 'and'), or performing an action together (translated as 'with'). In this case, we will focus on the 'and' translation. A full description of と as 'with' can be found here. と is required after every noun that it is grouped with. However, the last と in a sentence will often be omitted, if there are several. In this example, we can see that the last noun in the group (pencil) does not require the particle と, although it is considered more correct to have it. In conversation, the last と will almost always be omitted.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ピーナッツとビール。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Peanuts and beer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女と食べる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I eat with my girlfriend.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 消しゴムとペンと鉛筆もある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is an eraser, pen, and a pencil too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 魚とバナナ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Fish and bananas.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムとジェリー。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tom and Jerry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コーヒーと牛乳。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Coffee and milk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 川と滝。
Questions.EnglishHTML: River and waterfall.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これとそれは私のものです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This and that are mine.

Name: ここ
Meaning: Here, This place
About: ここ is one of the forms of the これ family of words used to identify things close to the speaker. In this case it demonstrates a place. In the same way that これ represents 'this', ここ represents 'this place', or simply 'here'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここのパンは美味しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The bread here is good.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生、こことここが痛いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Doctor, I have pain here and here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こっちに来ますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Will you come here? (Focus on the movement)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここに来ますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Will you come to this place? (Focus on the place)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Here is good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここもいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Here is also good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここがいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Here is good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここがいいですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is here good?

Name: そこ
Meaning: There, That place
About: そこ is one of the forms of the それ family of words used to identify things close to the listener. In this case it demonstrates a place. Just like それ represents 'that', そこ represents 'that place', or simply 'there'. In the same way that それ can be used to point back to something that was mentioned previously, そこ can be used to point back to a place that was mentioned previously.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこの犬は危ないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That dog is dangerous. (The dog from that place)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前のそこが悪い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That right there is one bad thing about you. (That personality trait there, within you)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこは綺麗？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is that place beautiful? (That place you mentioned earlier)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そっちです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is there. (Focus on the direction)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこに置く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Put it there. (Focused on the place)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そこがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That place is good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そこのパソコン。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That PC there.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たぶん、そこ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Maybe, there.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そこのレストランは美味しいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The restaurant that is there is delicious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こことそこも明るい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is bright here and there too.

Name: あそこ
Meaning: Over there
About: Like ここ and そこ, あそこ is a word that is used to identify a place in Japanese. The place that あそこ will be used to identify is somewhere that is separated from both the speaker and the listener. This translates roughly to 'that place over there' in English. あそこ can be used to identify both physical locations, and emotional ones. In the same way that あれ can be used to point back to something that was mentioned previously, あそこ can be used to point back to a place that was mentioned previously. However, unlike それ or そこ, あれ and あそこ will only be used this way when both the speaker and listener have intimate knowledge of the topic.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あそこの店はいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That store over there is good. (Not near the speaker or listener)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あそこは嫌だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't like that place. (Not near the speaker or listener)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あそこも暑い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That place over there is hot too. (That place mentioned earlier, for a place that both the speaker and listener have been)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あそこがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That place over there is good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あそこも楽しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That place over there is also fun.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そことあそこ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That place and that place over there.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あそこが広い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That place over there is spacious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あそこの店。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The store over there.

Name: で
Meaning: At, In
About: で is a particle that has several different uses in Japanese. At its core, it is always used to highlight something that is 'required' to perform some sort of action. One of these uses relates to places, and translates roughly as 'at', or 'in' in English. In these sentences, the place is considered essential for the action to be performed, or the result of the action to be achieved. This is unlike the particle に, which marks the location itself as being the destination or target of an action. Basically, で means (A) 'place' allows (B) 'action' to occur. While に means (A) 'place' is the target for (B) 'action' occurring. In the first example, we can see that に marks the place that the person exists during an action, but the action itself is not dependent on the place. In the second example, the action is considered dependent on being at that place, as there are possibly no barbeques in other areas.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はここでピザを食べる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I eat pizza here. (At this place)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は部屋で寝る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I sleep in my room.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は公園にいます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is at the park. (He is at the park, but the park isn't 'allowing' him to be there)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は公園でバーベキューをする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He BBQs at the park. (Because there are barbecues at the park, it is allowing him to cook)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そこで寝る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I sleep (at) there.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ホテルで寝る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To sleep at the hotel.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここで曲がります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To turn (at) here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私はここでサッカーをする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I play soccer (at) here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そこで泳ぎますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Will you swim (at) there?

Name: に
Meaning: In, At, To, For, On
About: に can be a very difficult particle to master in Japanese, as it has many different translations in English. These translations are usually 'in', 'at', 'to', 'for', or 'on'. Let's look at an example of each meaning. While these examples may seem quite confusing at first, it will be easier to think of に as always having one 'basic' meaning. That meaning is to be the 'end-point' of an action. This means that whatever action is being described, can only be considered complete/able to be completed once you're at/while you're at the location/time described in the sentence. Verbs like 住(す)む (to live/dwell) often confuse learners, as they use に instead of で. This is also due to the fact that 住(す)む is a verb that can only be 'completed' at the destination. (You can only complete the act of living/dwelling in the place that you live, so to speak).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は部屋にいますよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is in his room. (に as 'in')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は家にいます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm at home. (に as 'at')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 公園に行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To go to the park. (に as 'to')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は誕生日にケーキを食べる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will eat cake for my birthday. (に as 'for')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: バスに乗る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To ride on the bus. (に as 'on')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: マンションに住む。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To live in an apartment.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 旅館に泊まる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To stay at a hostel.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はあそこにいます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is at that place over there.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここに本を置く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To place a book on this place (here).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この机の上に座る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To sit on this desk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 駅に行く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To go to the station.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 病院に行く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To go to the hospital.

Name: か
Meaning: Or
About: One of the common uses of the particle か is often translated to 'or' in English. While this translation is accurate, it is not actually any different from か's regular usage as a question marker. From these examples, we can see that, in Japanese, か is performing the same role that a question mark would, or that a change in tone of voice would in spoken language. 'Would you like tea? coffee?' (said with a rising tone). This nuance of か can be used after the dictionary form of almost any word in Japanese. However, using です or ます will change the nuance from 'presenting possibilities', to 'asking a formal question', so should be avoided.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それはお母さんの靴かお父さんの靴。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are those mom's shoes, or dad's shoes?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それはお母さんの靴か。お父さんの靴か。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are those mom's shoes? Dad's shoes?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日か明日休むか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today or tomorrow, when will I take a break? (The speaker is thinking this to themselves)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日か明日は休みますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Will you take a break today or tomorrow? (The speaker is asking another person)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここかそこ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Here or there?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 赤か青。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Red or blue.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寝るか遊ぶ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To sleep or to play.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日か明日。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Today or tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは私のペンかあなたのペンですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is this my pen or your pen?

Name: と
Meaning: With
About: In our second lesson about と, we will look at the common translation of 'with' that is associated with this particle. と shows that there is a relationship between (A) and (B), regardless of if that relationship is translated as 'and', or 'with'. In either case, the nouns that are marked with と are usually all performing some mutual action (that mutual action may simply be existing). When と is used as 'with', it means that both/all people or objects are equally involved in the action. However, に highlights that one person is the target (destination) of an action, so will result in something sounding a lot more one sided. Here we can see that both people are talking when と is used. It is a mutual conversation. When に is used, however, the person marked by に is being talked 'to', and is usually not actively participating in the conversation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カレーはご飯と食べるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I eat curry with rice. (I eat rice 'and' curry)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コーヒーを妻と飲む。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I drink coffee with my wife. (I 'and' my wife drink coffee)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生と話す。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will talk with my teacher. (Focus on both people talking)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生に話す。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will talk to my teacher. (Focus on only one person talking)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムと話す。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I talk with Tom.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕は友達とごはんを食べる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will eat food with my friend.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ゆうこさんはみおさんとコーヒーを飲む。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Yuko-san drinks coffee with Mio-san.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: タキはミツハと走る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Taki runs with Mitsuha.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんは山田さんと話す。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san talks with Yamada-san.

Name: でしょう
Meaning: Right?, Probably, Isn't it?
About: でしょう is a conjugated form of です, and can also be seen in the contracted form でしょ (more casual). でしょう is regularly translated to 'right?', or 'probably' in English. In a broader sense it just expresses an assertion about something (like です), that the speaker assumes the listener would probably agree with. In the above, we can see that, in both examples, the speaker is looking for confirmation that/affirming that the listener agrees with them. As でしょう is a conjugation of です (the polite form of だ), it usually follows the plain form of words, rather than words using ～ます. However, in very formal situations, or older literature ～ますでしょう may be seen.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: イタリアは良かったでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Italy was nice, right? (Has the nuance of 'I bet!')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日の昼ごはんはハンバーガーでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today's lunch is probably hamburgers, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼も踊るでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He will probably dance too.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼も踊りますでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He will probably dance too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これはあなたの本でしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is your book, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いいでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is probably good. (right?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日は寒いでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It will probably be cold tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたはトムでしょう？
Questions.EnglishHTML: You are Tom, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは、いい車でしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a good car, right?

Name: だろう
Meaning: Right?, Probably, Isn't it?
About: だろう is a conjugated form of だ, and can also be seen in the contracted form だろ (more casual). だろう expresses that the speaker thinks that something is true (assertion/expectation), and also that the listener would probably agree with them. This comes across like 'right?', or 'probably' in English. だろう carries exactly the same meaning as でしょう (the polite equivalent). However, due to だ being more casual than です, だろう is also considered to be more casual/masculine than でしょう.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前、明日パーティーに行くだろ？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are going to the party tomorrow, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は晴れるだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It will probably be clear tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは、お菓子だろう？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is candy, isn't it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここがいいだろう？
Questions.EnglishHTML: This place here is good (right?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなただろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's you (right?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これはペンだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a pen. (right?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今夜は、忙しいだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tonight is busy (right?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは、水だろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is water, right?

Name: が有(あ)る
Meaning: To be, There is
About: がある is a common construction that is simply a combination of the が particle, and the う-Verb, ある. This expression means 'to exist', or 'there is', and is used in relation to non-living/inanimate things. Because the things being described in these examples are not considered to be 'alive', ある is the verb that will be used. いる is used for living things. The polite form of ある conjugates as あります. Due to the る changing to り, we can determine that ある is a う-Verb (Godan verb). However, ある is irregular in that the plain negative form is ない, not あらない. The kanji form of 有(あ)る is quite common, and should be learned as early as possible, to save any confusion while reading. There is no difference in nuance between this expression being used with, or without kanji, and is up to the preference of the writer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日、テストがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is a test tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部屋に椅子がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have a chair in my room.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: キッチンにケーキがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is a cake in the kitchen. (Correct example)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: キッチンにケーキがあります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is a cake in the kitchen. (Correct example)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お金がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have no money. (Correct example)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トイレがありません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no toilet. (Correct example)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: にんじんがあらない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Theren't carrots. (Incorrect example, with incorrect English to match!)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は時間が有る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have time today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫の中には何ある？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What's in the refrigerator?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 本がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is a book.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ペンがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't have a pen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 時間があります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仕事がない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't have work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: エレベータがあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is an elevator.

Name: が居(い)る
Meaning: To be, There is,  To remain (in a state)
About: がいる is a common construction that is simply a combination of the が particle, and the verb いる. This expression means 'to exist', or 'there is', and is used in relation to living/animate things. Because the things being described in these examples are considered to be alive (or operated by something that is alive), いる is the verb that will be used. ある is used for non-living things. The polite form of いる conjugates as います. Due to the る being removed, we can determine that いる is a る-Verb (Ichidan verb). The kanji form of 居(い)る is quite common, and should be learned as early as possible to save any confusion while reading. There is no nuance difference between this expression being used with or without kanji, and is up to the preference of the writer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 警察がいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is a police officer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 猫がいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is a cat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パトカーがいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is a police car. (Operated by police)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は、彼女が居る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have a girlfriend.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこに警察居るよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is a cop over there.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私がいる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am (here). (exist)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムがいます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tom is (here). (exists)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんとトムがいます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mr. Tanaka and Tom are (there). (exist)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生がいます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is a teacher. (exists)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私と友達がいます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A friend and I are (here). (exist)

Name: この
Meaning: This
About: この is classified as a 'pre-noun adjectival' in Japanese. These are a special type of word that do not conjugate. This means that they will always appear in the same form. この comes from the same family of words as これ and ここ, and is used to identify a 'thing' that is near the speaker. As the name 'pre-noun adjectival' suggests, these words will always appear before a noun, and describe that noun in some way.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このスーツはあなたのですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is this suit yours?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この仕事は大変だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This work is difficult.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この本がいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This book is good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このケーキは大きいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This cake is big.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この写真は私のです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This picture is mine.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この犬は私の犬です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This dog is my dog.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この動物は、猫です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This animal is a cat.

Name: その
Meaning: That
About: その is classified as a 'pre-noun adjectival' in Japanese. These are a special type of word that do not conjugate. This means that they will always appear in the same form. その comes from the same family of words as それ and そこ, and is used to identify a 'thing' that is near the listener. As the name 'pre-noun adjectival' suggests, these words will always appear before a noun, and describe that noun in some way.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そのパズルは難しい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is that puzzle hard? (If a sentence finishes in a rising tone, questions markers like ですか may be dropped in casual speech)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その話は絶対嘘でしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That story is definitely a lie.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その本がいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That book is good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その映画を見る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will watch that movie.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その店は安いですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is that store cheap?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その動物は猿です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That animal is a monkey.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その時計は高いでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That clock is expensive, isn't it.

Name: あの
Meaning: That (over there)
About: あの is classified as a 'pre-noun adjectival' in Japanese. These are a special type of word that do not conjugate. This means that they will always appear in the same form. あの comes from the same family of words as あれ and あそこ, and is used to identify a 'thing' that is away from both the listener, and the speaker. It is usually translated as 'that' (thing over there). As the name 'pre-noun adjectival' suggests, these words will always appear before a noun, and describe that noun in some way.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの子は可愛いね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person is cute, don't you think? (子（こ） is often used to refer to any person in an affectionate way, regardless of their age. Primarily women)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの話はウソ？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is that thing you said a lie? (That story that we both know about)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人はトムです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person over there is Tom.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの犬が可愛いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That dog over there is cute.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのラーメン屋は美味しいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That ramen shop over there is good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの綺麗な人は、田中さん。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That beautiful person over there is Tanaka-san.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの店でもいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That store over there is also okay.

Name: んだ・んです
Meaning: Explanatory, Emphasis, The fact is
About: のです is a construction with several different forms, each meaning roughly the same thing. This expression behaves similarly to だ and です by themselves (asserting that something is true). However, the addition of の strengthens the relationship being highlighted. Due to this, it will come across a bit like 'it is a fact that (A)' in English. In these sentences, we can think of the ん, or の as simply adding emphasis to the statement. Due to の adding emphasis, this expression will be heard very frequently in explanations. While both the だ and です forms are equally as natural, only the です form will be used if adding か to the end ～んですか. This construction shows that the speaker is looking for an explanation about something.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここのコーヒーが美味しいんです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The coffee here is really good. (Strong assertion)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が悪いのです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am the one to blame. (Strong assertion)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたはこれが欲しいんですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is this what you want?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お腹が空いたのですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Have you become hungry? (Are you hungry?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いいんですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is it good?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 赤がいいんですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is red good?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いいのですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is it good?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これがいいのですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is this good?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 川があるんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is a river.

Name: い-Adjective (Past)
Meaning: Was, Were (Past tense)
About: In order to create the past form of い-Adjectives, you must add the auxiliary verb た to the 'past' conjunction form of the い-Adjective. The past conjunction form is created by removing the い and replacing it with かっ. This structure is equivalent to 'was' in English. 面白(おもしろ)い - 'Interesting' in its base (dictionary form). 面白(おもしろ)かっ - The conjugation form used with た (and several other auxiliary verbs). From these examples, we can see how the casual past form is constructed. In modern Japanese, simply adding です after た is considered to be the standard polite past form.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お風呂が温かかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The bath was warm.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日の夜は寒かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Last night was cold. (Literally 'yesterday's night')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 京都は涼しかったです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Kyoto was cool. (In relation to temperature)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このケーキは甘かったです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This cake was sweet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寒かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was cold.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは、高かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That was expensive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんは強かったです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san was strong.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の姉の家が古かったです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My (older) sister's house was old.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 動物園は楽しかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The zoo was fun.

Name: のは・のが
Meaning: Verb nominalizer, The one who..., That which...
About: In Japanese, のは and のが behave in a very similar way to the words 'that' and 'which' in English. This means that they perform a task called nominalization. Nominalization is when a phrase is treated in the same way as a single noun. Rather than a single noun, we can see from these examples that the phrases 沢山(たくさん)食(た)べるのは and バスに乗(の)るのが are behaving in the same way that a single noun would. In English, this can either mean 'that which', or 'the one who/that'. This construction can be used after verbs in any tense, except for the polite ます or ません, which are only used at the end of a sentence, or certain clauses.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 沢山食べるのは彼です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is the one that eats a lot. (Literally 'the one that eats a lot, he is')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はバスに乗るのが嫌いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't like riding the bus. (Literally 'that which is riding a bus, I hate')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は走るのが好き。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He likes running. (That which is)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お菓子を全部食べたのは、娘だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My daughter is the one that ate all of the candy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 山を登っているのは、今田さんだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The one who is climbing the mountain is Imada-San.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 読むのは私です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am the one who reads.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君を愛するのは、私だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am the one who loves you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この仕事をするのは私だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am the one who does this job.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寿司を食べるのは、彼だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is the one who eats sushi.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 漢字を覚えるのは、彼女です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She is the one who memorizes kanji.

Name: い-Adjective + (Noun)
Meaning: Describing a noun
About: In Japanese, almost any type of word can be attached to the beginning of a noun to modify the meaning, or describe the qualities of that noun. However, depending on the type of word used, conjugation rules will differ slightly. For い-Adjectives, they are simply attached to the front of the noun in their standard (dictionary) form.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 速い車。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A fast car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 怖い先生。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A scary teacher.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新しい車。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A new car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 可愛い女の子がいる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is a cute girl.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: かっこいい先輩。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Cool senpai.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寒い夜。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Cold night.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 面白いゲームを買います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To buy an interesting game.

Name: な-Adjective + (Noun)
Meaning: Describing a noun
About: In Japanese, almost any type of word can be attached to the beginning of a noun to modify the meaning, or describe the qualities of that noun. However, depending on the type of word used, conjugation rules will differ slightly. For な-Adjectives, they will always need to be followed by な, when used before a noun. This means that adjective (A) is describing qualities/features of noun (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カーテンオタク：これは綺麗なカーテンです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A curtain enthusiast : This is a pretty curtain.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 元気な赤ちゃん。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A healthy baby. ('Energetic' or 'spirited' would also be accurate translations)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 幸せな日。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A happy day. (A 'quality' of this day is that it is 'happy')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 幸せの匂い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The smell of happiness. (The 'type' of smell is that of 'happiness')

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暇な一日。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A free day.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 旭が丘は静かな街です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Asahigaoka is a quiet town.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たなかさんは親切な人だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san is a kind person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは便利なツールです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a convenient tool.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 綺麗なタオルはトイレにある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are clean towels in the bathroom.

Name: へ行(い)く
Meaning: To go to, To head toward
About: へ行(い)く is a common construction used when describing a place that someone/something is 'heading'. The particles に and へ are mostly interchangeable, but there is a slight difference in meaning. に has the nuance of 'going to', while へ has the nuance of 'heading to'. In these examples, while they may seem the same at first glance, へ focuses much more on the journey, while に puts more emphasis on the destination. This is true for other uses of に and へ as well. に will always put more focus on the destination of an action, where へ will put more emphasis on the distance traveled/between the origin and destination.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ジョンは学校へ行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: John is heading to school.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: エルサは病院に行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Elsa is going to the hospital.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生へ電話をする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To make a call to the teacher. (Focuses more on the distance between the caller and receiver)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生に電話をする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To make a call to the teacher. (Focuses more on the destination of the call)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 学校へいく。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To head to school.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 駅へいく
Questions.EnglishHTML: To head to the station.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 東京へいく。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will head to Tokyo.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 教室へいく。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will head to the classroom.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 道へいきます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To head toward a road.

Name: する
Meaning: To do, To make into
About: する verbs are one of only two main verbs in Japanese that do not follow the standard rules of conjugation for Godan and Ichidan verbs. The other primary verb being 来(く)る. する means to do something, or to make something a certain way. する will almost always have the particle を attached to the thing that is being done (depending on the form of the verb). The reason that する verbs are called さ-column irregular conjugation verbs in Japanese is because the る in する does not conjugate, but is dropped. This will leave す to be the part that conjugates. Because of this, する has qualities of both る-Verbs (the る being dropped), and う-Verbs (the remaining す changing, depending on the conjugation). Here are some examples of how する changes. （さ）せる, （し）ます, （す）る, （せ）よ. We will learn more about each of these conjugations of する, and their individual meanings at a later stage. For now, let's take a look at the polite します conjugation. In a broader sense, する can be thought of as meaning 'to do something that has an external effect'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 洗濯をする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To do laundry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 料理をする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To cook. (Literally 'to do food')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電話をします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To make a call.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勉強をします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To study.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サッカーをする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To play soccer. (to do)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サッカーをします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To play soccer. (to do)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何をしますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: What will you do?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は勉強をする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I ((will) do) study.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 掃除をする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To clean. (to do)

Name: 来(く)る
Meaning: To come
About: 来(く)る is one of only two main verbs in Japanese that do not follow the standard rules of conjugation for Godan and Ichidan verbs. The other primary verb being する. 来(く)る means 'to come', or 'to be coming'. 来(く)る will always have the particle に or へ attached to the location that someone 'will come', or 'has come'. The reason that 来(く)る is called a か-column irregular conjugation verb in Japanese is because the る in 来(く)る does not conjugate, but is dropped. This leaves the く being the part that conjugates. Because of this, 来る has qualities of both る-Verbs (the る being dropped), and う-Verbs (the remaining く changing depending on the conjugation). Here are some examples of how 来(く)る changes. （き）た, （く）る, （こ）ない. 来(く)る will often be seen as 来(き)ている when someone has come to a place and remains there. This is due to ている meaning 'to exist in the state of an action', rather than being exactly the same as '(A)~ing' in English. Because of this, 来(き)ている can mean either 'to be somewhere that one has come', or 'to be coming'. Sometimes the difference between these two will not be clear unless there is further context.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前もパーティーに来る？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Will you come to the party too?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サヤの家に来ている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have come to Saya's house. (I'm at Saya's house now)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今、駅に来ている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have come to the station. (I am at the station now)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カナは駅に来ている？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is Kana coming to the station? (Is Kana on her way to the station now?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムはここにくる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tom will come here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: バスがくる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The bus will come.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はバスできます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He will come by bus.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達もきますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Will your friend come too?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will come tomorrow.

Name: る-Verb (Past)
Meaning: る - Verbs (Past tense)
About: To make the past form of a る-Verb in Japanese, just like all other conjugations of る-Verbs, you will need to remove the る first. After this, all you need to do is add the auxiliary verb た (casual), or ました (polite).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ドアを開ける。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I open the door.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ドアを開けた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I opened the door.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ドアを開けました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I opened the door.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たかしは１９９４年に生まれた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takashi was born in 1994. (An example of past)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今朝、テストを受けた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I took the test this morning. (An example of completion)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の名前を忘れた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I forgot his name, and still can't remember. (An example of continuation)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
疲れた。
疲れました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was tired.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
早く起きた。
早く起きました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I woke up early.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
シャワーを浴びた。
シャワーを浴びました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I took a shower.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
昨日、テレビを見た。
昨日、テレビを見ました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I watched TV yesterday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
日本で寿司を食べた。
日本で寿司を食べました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I ate sushi in Japan.

Name: う-Verb (Past)
Meaning: う - Verbs (Past tense)
About: To make the past form of a う-Verb in Japanese, just like all other conjugations of う-Verbs, you will need to change the last kana, before adding the auxiliary verb た (casual), or ました (polite). This change in kana is a bit different to other conjugations of う-Verbs, so let's take a look at them for the casual form. As can be seen in these examples, the changes consist of った, いた, いだ, んだ, した (the same as the changes for て form, but using た instead). For the conjugations using だ in place of た, this is simply a sound change in the language that happened over the course of history, to make words easier/smoother to say. It is not the auxiliary verb だ. For the polite past form of う-Verbs, the change in sound is far more consistent. This only requires a change from the う sound, to the い sound within the same column (from う to い, or from く to き, for example). When た is added to verbs (or any other word), it can have one of three possible meanings. Past: 過去(かこ) - Happened at some point in the past. (Did/Was) Completion: 完了(かんりょう) - An action that has finished 'happening'. (Done) Continuation: 存続(そんぞく) - A new state of something that is continuing. (Has been done)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ５キロ走った。５キロ走りました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I ran 5 kilometers. (Example of a verb ending in る)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しいペンを買った。新しいペンを買いました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bought a new pen. (Example of a verb ending in う)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日は駅で５分待った。昨日は駅で５分待ちました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I waited for 5 minutes at the station yesterday. (Example of a verb ending in つ)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ノートに名前を書いた。ノートに名前を書きました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wrote my name on the notebook. (Example of a verb ending in く)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: テイラーは池で泳いだ。テイラーは池で泳ぎました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Taylor swam in the pond. (Example of a verb ending in ぐ)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 去年、ペットの金魚が死んだ。去年、ペットの金魚が死にました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My pet goldfish died last year. (Example of a verb ending in ぬ)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫を台所に運んだ。冷蔵庫を台所に運びました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I carried the refrigerator to the kitchen. (Example of a verb ending in ぶ)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 庭をフェンスで囲んだ。庭をフェンスで囲みました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I surrounded my yard with a fence. (Example of a verb ending in む)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電気を消した。電気を消しました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I turned off the lights. (Example of a verb ending in す)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しい漢字を習いました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I learned a new kanji.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車が動きました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The car moved.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日、カラオケで歌を歌った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I sang a song at karaoke yesterday. (An example of past)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今、コーヒーを頼んだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I ordered coffee (just) now. (An example of completion)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 乗った自転車が壊れた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The bike I rode broke, and is still broken. (An example of continuation)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
昨日、本を読んだ。
昨日、本を読みました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I read a book yesterday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
牛乳を飲んだ。
牛乳を飲みました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I drank milk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
ロンドンへ飛んだ。
ロンドンへ飛びました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I flew to London.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
私たちのチームは勝った！
私たちのチームは勝ちました！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Our team won!

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
メアリーは日本に帰った。
メアリーは日本に帰りました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mary returned to Japan.

Name: 好(す)き
Meaning: Like, Fond of
About: 好(す)き, meaning 'to like', is one of the very common な-Adjectives in Japanese that is used in many different expressions. All な-Adjectives behave similarly to verbs, in that their form changes depending on what comes after them. For 好(す)き, it will be followed by な when acting as an adjective, or one of either だ or the more polite です when acting as a noun. This distinction is made depending on whether it is linked to another noun, or is independent. In the example with だ, 好(す)き is expressing that the thing is 'likable' (assertion). However, in the example with な, 好(す)き is expressing 'likability' as a quality of the noun it is attached to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はコンビニが好きだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like convenience stores. (They are likable, to me)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はサーフィンが好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He likes surfing. (It has likability, to him)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が好きなピザを食べる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I eat the pizza that I like. (The pizza that is likable, to me)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大好きだよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I love you!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 好き？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Do you like (it)?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うん、好きだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Yeah, I like (it).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 好きな人がいますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is there someone that you like?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: はい、山田さんが好きです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Yes, I like Yamada-san.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の家が好きですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Do you like my house?

Name: 嫌(きら)い
Meaning: Dislike, Not fond of
About: For 嫌(きら)い, it will be followed by either な, when acting as an adjective, だ, or the more polite です, when acting as a noun. This distinction is made depending on whether it is linked to another noun, or is independent. In the example with だ, 嫌(きら)い is expressing that the thing is 'dislikable' (assertion). However, in the example with な, 嫌(きら)い is expressing 'being disliked' as a quality of the noun it is attached to. In the same way that 好(す)き can often be partnered with 大(だい) to mean 'love', 嫌(きら)い can often be partnered with 大(だい) to mean 'hate'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは嫌いだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't like that. (That is dislikable)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はスポーツが嫌いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't like sports. (They are dislikable, to me)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の嫌いな食べ物はピザです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The food he doesn't like is pizza. (The food that is disliked, by him)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大嫌いな先輩が来る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The senpai I hate is coming.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パイナップルが嫌い？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Do you dislike pineapple?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うん、大嫌いだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Yeah, I hate it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嫌いな食べ物がありますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is there a food that you dislike?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: はい、納豆が嫌いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Yes, I dislike natto.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嫌いな色はありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no color that I dislike.

Name: のが好(す)き
Meaning: Like doing, Love doing
About: ～のが好(す)き is a common construction that is used in Japanese to express that you like/love doing something. This particular expression is used with the plain (dictionary) form of verbs only. In these examples, we can see that there is no difference between Ichidan verbs and Godan verbs. Both will be used in their plain forms. In this expression, のが is performing the same function as in the regular のは or のが construction. This function is nominalization (turning a phrase into a noun). This construction can also be used to ask questions about what other people like. This is done through the addition of か.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は映画を見るのが好き。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like watching movies.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はプレゼントを貰うのが好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like to receive gifts.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は野球をするのが好きだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He liked to play baseball.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子は漢字を書くのが好きでした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My son used to like to write kanji.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何をするのが好きですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What do you like to do?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 映画を見るのが好きですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you like watching movies?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私はサッカーをするのが好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like playing soccer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は本を読むのが好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like reading books.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私はラーメンを食べるのが好きです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like eating ramen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 犬と遊ぶのが好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like playing with dogs.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 旅行に行くのが好きでしょう？
Questions.EnglishHTML: You like going on trips, don't you?

Name: がある + (Noun)
Meaning: Noun (B) that has Noun (A), Noun (B) with Noun (A)
