About: In this expression, がある has the role of describing the noun that follows it. The description that it is giving is '(A) がある (B)' = '(B) has/with (A)'. This type of phrase is called a relative clause (something that describes a noun), and behaves similarly to an adjective. In English, a relative clause would require a pronoun such as 'who' 誰(だれ), 'which' どれ, 'that' それ・あれ, 'where' どこ. However, these types of words are not required in Japanese, and the noun will follow がある directly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ピアノがあるレストラン。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A restaurant with a piano.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コンビニがあるビル。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A building that has a convenience store.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 漫画はある本屋。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A book store that... well... it has manga. (Unnatural Japanese, unless you're making the point that there is something else that this bookstore doesn't have. This is an advanced use of は)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 綺麗な川のある山。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A mountain with a beautiful river. (Natural Japanese, but less common than が)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ベッドがある部屋。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A room that has a bed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たくさん休みがある５月が好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like the month of May with its many holidays.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 綺麗な池がある公園。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A park with a beautiful pond.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 家がある人。
Questions.EnglishHTML: People who have a house.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫がある台所。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A kitchen with a refrigerator.

Name: くない
Meaning: Not (Adjective)
About: The negative form of い-Adjectives in Japanese is created by using the conjunctive form of the adjective, followed by ない. conjunctive form just means 'agglutinative', or 'conjunctive' in Japanese. For い-Adjectives, this conjunctive form is created by removing い, and replacing it with く. The ない used with い-Adjectives is considered to be a different word to the ない used with verbs. When used with い-Adjectives, ない itself is also an い-Adjective. This means that it follows the same rules as regular い-Adjectives. Due to ません (the polite negative form) being an auxiliary verb,  it cannot be conjugated with い-Adjectives in the same way as verbs. As can be seen here, you must first add the verb ある, and then conjugate it into its negative form using the auxiliary verb ません. This is how the polite negative is created.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたは悪くない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are not to blame. (Translates directly to, you are not bad.)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は暑くない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not hot today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このお茶は、温くません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This tea don't lukewarm. (Incorrect example, with incorrect English to match!)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このお茶は、温くありません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This tea is not lukewarm. (Natural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暑くないです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not hot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は寒くない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not cold today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは楽しくないです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is not fun.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新しくないコンピューター。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A computer that is not new.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは安くないです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That is not cheap.

Name: で
Meaning: With, By (using)
About: で is a particle that has several different uses in Japanese. At its core, it is always used to highlight something that is 'required' to perform some sort of action/reach some kind of goal. One of these uses relates to 'things'. This comes across as 'by' or 'with' in English. In these sentences, the item is considered essential for the action to be performed. While other items may be used, で simply highlights the one that was chosen. で is also used when groups of people perform actions together, this is something that many people learning Japanese have trouble with initially (because と may also be used as 'with' for people). However, the use of で is actually the same as this by/with, meaning that the speaker considers the group as the tool used for performing the action. The difference between と and で as 'with', is that で is used when everyone in the group has the same objective/end goal. と is used when each person is performing the action toward each other, not toward an external objective.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車で空港へ行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go to the airport by car. (Required to reach a goal)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電車で行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go by train. (Required to reach a goal)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: みんなでレストランに行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go to the restaurant with everyone. (Being with everyone is what allows/gives purpose to the action)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来年は皆でハワイに行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will go to Hawaii with everyone next year. (Being with everyone is what allows/gives purpose to the action)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家族全員で沖縄へ行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will go to Okinawa with everyone in my family. (Being with everyone is what allows/gives purpose to the action)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お母さんとご飯を食べる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I eat with my mom. (Being together is the objective, eating is just what is happening while being together)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: バスで行く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I go by bus.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: バスで学校に行く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I go to school by bus.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自転車でいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: By bicycle is good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自転車で。
Questions.EnglishHTML: By bicycle.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電車で来ますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Are you coming by train?

Name: ので
Meaning: Because, So, Since, The reason being
About: ので is a Japanese grammar structure called a conjunction particle. This means that it connects two parts of a sentence 'logically'. The connection that ので makes between (A), and (B), is similar to から, meaning that it is often translated as 'because', or 'since'. When used after な-Adjectives or nouns, な must precede ので. When used as 'since', ので puts emphasis on the sentence as a whole, or on the effects caused. It then examines those reasons objectively (in a way that is based on facts, rather than feelings or opinions). から tends to be more subjective, and can sound much more vague when used as 'because'. We can see here that から is not quite as strong as ので. This relates back to the base meaning of から being 'from', rather than 'because'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は日曜日なので休みです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since it's Sunday today, It's a day off.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達が家に来るので、部屋の掃除をする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since my friend is coming to my house, I will clean my room.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 景色が綺麗なので、写真を撮ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since the scenery is beautiful, I will take a picture.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は寒いので、コートを着ます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since it is cold today, I will wear a coat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は弱いので、ジムへ行きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go to the gym because I am weak. (Being that I am weak)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 野菜が嫌いだから、食べません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't eat vegetables because I don't like them. (From that vegetables are disliked)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今テストがあるんで、後で電話します。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I have a test now, I will call you later.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日はお客が来ますので、掃除をします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since a guest is coming tomorrow, I am going to clean.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は寿司が好きではないので、食べない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't like sushi, so I don't eat it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は時間がないので、明日に漢字を教えます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because we don't have time today, I will teach you kanji tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は先生が休みなので、授業がなくなった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since the teacher has the day off today, classes were cancelled.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 土曜日なので、旅行に行きたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because it is Saturday, I want to go on a trip.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は一月二十日なので、彼の誕生日です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since today is January 20th, it is his birthday.

Name: から
Meaning: Because, Since
About: から can have several different meanings in Japanese, depending on which part of the sentence it is in, and what comes before/after it. It is often translated as 'because', or 'since'. In these cases, it just means 'Because of (A), (B)'. から may be used with almost any type of word, but when the nuance is 'because', it will require だ before it when following a noun or な-Adjective. Despite having several different nuances, it may be easier to think of から as meaning 'from' in all situations, as that is the base nuance. From (A as a reason), (B) = Because/Since. From (A as a location), (B) = From.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日、アイスクリームを沢山食べたから、お腹が痛いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I ate so much ice cream yesterday, my stomach hurts. (From that I ate so much ice cream)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は優しいから、好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because she is nice, I like her. (From that she is nice)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大きい会社だから、人が沢山いる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because it is a big company, there are a lot of workers. (From that it is a big company)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: スマホは便利だから、人気がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since smartphones are useful, they are popular. (From that they are useful)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は犬が好きですから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I like dogs.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お菓子だから、甘い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because it is candy, it is sweet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 辛いから、カレーが好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because it's spicy, I like curry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 楽しいから、スポーツを見る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because it is fun, I watch sports.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 学生がいるから、学校があるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because there are students, there is a school, right?

Name: から
Meaning: From
About: から can have several different meanings in Japanese, depending on which part of the sentence it is in, and what comes before/after it. It is often translated as 'from'. In these cases, it just means 'with (A) as a starting location, (B)'. In this grammar construction, から comes directly after the place that is considered the starting point. This form of から is the closest to the 'base' meaning of the word in Japanese, as the nuance of から can almost always be thought of as meaning 'from' in some way.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はモロッコから来ました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She came from Morocco.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 空港から車で来ました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I came from the airport by car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 駅からバスで来た。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I came from the station by bus.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アメリカから来ました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I came from America.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この靴はお母さんからです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: These shoes are from my mom.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 学校から、パーティに行く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To go to the party from school.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仕事から帰る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To return home from work.

Name: けど
Meaning: But, However
About: けど is one of the common conjunction particles in Japanese. These are particles that function by connecting the (A) and (B) parts of a sentence. けど works very similarly to が, in that it highlights 'while thinking about (A), (B)'. This means that けど will often come across as 'but' in English. As can be seen from these examples, just like many other grammatical constructions, だ will be required when using けど after a な-Adjective, or a noun. けど is just a modern (casual) version of けれども. Please see below for a list of the most casual, to the most formal variations. Casual - けど - けども - けれど - けれども - が - Formal.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日泳ぐけど、今日は泳がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I swim everyday, but I will not swim today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 北海道は寒いけど、綺麗。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hokkaido is cold, but pretty.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田舎は静かだけど、不便だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The countryside is quiet, but inconvenient.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはステーキだけど、冷たい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is a steak, but it is cold.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は肉を食べるけども、野菜も好き。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I eat meat, but I also like vegetables.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は水が怖いけれど、泳ぐのが好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am afraid of the water, but I like to swim.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お酒は飲むけれども、ワインは飲まないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I drink alcoholic beverages, but I don't drink wine.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 沖縄は綺麗ですが、暑いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Okinawa is beautiful, but hot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パソコンはないけど。（大丈夫？）
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't have a computer… (but is that okay?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 便利だけど、高い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is convenient, but expensive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その赤いＴシャツが好きだけど、青いＴシャツを買う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like that red T-shirt, but I will buy the blue one.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お金があるけど、買いません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have money, but I won't buy (it).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 豚肉は嫌いだけど、鶏肉は食べます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't like pork, but I eat chicken.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その店は高いけど、美味しいでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That restaurant is expensive, but it is delicious, isn't it.

Name: が
Meaning: But, However
About: As a particle, が has several different uses in Japanese. However, each of these different uses share a common theme. That theme expresses 'highlighting (A) as important, (B)'. In this use, が comes across as 'but', or 'however' in English. This nuance of が is used directly after any form of verb or い-Adjective, but requires one of the conjugations of だ or です before it when used with a noun or な-Adjective. From these examples, we can see that が is simply highlighting that 'while (A) is important, there is extra information'. が with the meaning of 'but' is considered to be very formal, this is due to it sounding quite direct in asserting that there is extra information.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日走るが、運動はきらい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I run everyday, but I don't like exercise.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このカレーは辛いが、美味しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This curry is spicy, but delicious.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車は便利だが、危ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Cars are convenient, but dangerous.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お金は大切だが、時間も大切だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Money is important, but time is also important.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まあ、綺麗ですが。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well, it is pretty, but… (I still don't like it)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 早いですが、起きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is early, but I will wake up.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 難しいですが、頑張ります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is difficult, but I will do my best.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寒いですが、外へ行きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's cold, but I will go outside.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ロイさんの携帯は古いですが、速いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Roy's cellphone is old, but it is fast.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 綺麗ですが、危ないです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is beautiful but dangerous.

Name: る-Verb (Negative-Past)
Meaning: る - Verbs (Negative-past tense)
About: In order to form the negative past form of  る-Verbs, you will need to remove the る, and then follow it with the auxiliary verb ない (or ます), conjugated into their past forms. This will either be なかった (casual), or ませんでした (polite). A semi-polite form may also be used. This is constructed by using なかった, and then simply adding です. This form is not grammatically correct, but is so common that most sources (and native speakers) would consider it correct.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今朝ニュースを見なかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I didn't see the news this morning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ゴミを捨てませんでした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I did not throw the trash away.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ライトが消えなかったです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The light did not turn off.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
寿司を食べなかった。
寿司を食べなかったです。
寿司を食べませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I didn't eat sushi.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
テレビを見なかった。
テレビを見なかったです。
テレビを見ませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I didn't watch TV.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
お金を借りなかった。
お金を借りなかったです。
お金を借りませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I did not borrow money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
早く起きなかった。
早く起きなかったです。
早く起きませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I didn't wake up early.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
これは教えなかった。
これは教えなかったです。
これは教えませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I didn't tell you this.

Name: う-Verb (Negative-Past)
Meaning: う - Verbs (Negative-past tense)
About: In order to make the negative past form of  う-Verbs, you will need to change the last kana of the verb into the あ sound kana from the same column (or わ if the original kana was う). After this, the あ sound kana will be followed by ない (or ます), conjugated into their past forms. This will either be なかった (casual), or ませんでした (polite). For the ませんでした (polite) form, rather than the final kana changing to the あ sound kana from the same column, it will change to the い sound kana from the same column. The negative past form is used to convey that something 'did not happen', or 'was not'. A semi-polite form may also be used. This is constructed by using なかった, and then simply adding です. This form is not grammatically correct, but is so common that most sources (and native speakers) would consider it correct. ある is an exception to the regular conjugation rules of う-Verbs. The casual past-negative is not あらなかった, but simply なかった. However, the polite past-negative form conjugates in the same way as would be expected for う-Verbs. ありませんでした.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は公園で遊ばなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I did not play at the park.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたの車は洗わなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I did not wash your car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこに置きませんでした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I did not place it there.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこには本がありませんでした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The book was not over there.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼とは話さなかったです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I did not talk with him. (Notice the use of と and は together. Double particle usage is common when presenting a topic in Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 紙がなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There was no paper. (Casual Japanese past tense)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 紙がありませんでした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There was no paper. (Formal Japanese past tense)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
昨日、行かなかった。
昨日、行かなかったです。
昨日、行きませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I didn't go yesterday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
遊ばなかった。
遊ばなかったです。
遊びませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I didn't hang out.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
はなこさんは話さなかった。
はなこさんは話さなかったです。
はなこさんは話しませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Hanako didn't talk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
彼女は事故で死ななかった！
彼女は事故で死ななかったです！
彼女は事故で死にませんでした！
Questions.EnglishHTML: She didn't die in the accident!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それも知らなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I didn’t know that either.

Name: ～て (Conjunction)
Meaning: And, Then (Linking events)
About: In Japanese, て is a very important conjunction particle that can be used with many different structures. When it is partnered with a verb, it has special conjugation rules, depending on whether it is being added to a る-Verb or a う-Verb. In the case of う-Verbs, it also depends on what the preceding kana is. The most common translation in any situation is just 'and' or 'then', due to (B) being highlighted as something that happens/happened after (A). In these examples, we can see that て basically means '(A) て (B)' = '(A) happened, then (B)'. However, this is only when it is linked to another verb. Sometimes the て form appears as で. This is a change that happened throughout the course of history, in order to make sentences flow more smoothly. Despite this, there is no difference in meaning between て and で as a vocal change. The easiest way to identify whether to use て or で is by looking at the preceding kana. If the plain (dictionary) form of the verb finishes in ぐ, ぬ, ぶ, or む, then で will be used. る-Verbs never use で.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 山を登って休む。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To climb a mountain, then rest. (To climb a mountain, and rest)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 食べて寝る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To eat, then sleep. (To eat, and sleep)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 本を読んで返す。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To read a book, then return it. (て appearing as で)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遊んで帰る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To play, then go home. (て appearing as で)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 学校に行って勉強をする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go to school, then study.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ダイエットをして痩せる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To go on a diet, then lose weight.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 公園に来て遊ぶ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To come to the park, then play.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 答えを問うて書く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To enquire about the answer, then write it down.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 許可を請うて実行する。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To get permission, then act out.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: （食べる）→ 食べて
Questions.EnglishHTML: To eat → To eat and then.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: （洗う）→ 洗って
Questions.EnglishHTML: To wash → To wash and then.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: （返す）→ 返して
Questions.EnglishHTML: To return (an object) → To return (an object) and then.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: （歩く）→ 歩いて
Questions.EnglishHTML: To walk → To walk and then.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: （泳ぐ）→ 泳いで
Questions.EnglishHTML: To swim → To swim and then.

Name: ～ている ①
Meaning: Is, Am, Are (~ing)
About: ている is a construction used in Japanese to convey that someone or something is existing in a constant state of 'doing' the verb that comes before て. In English, depending on the verb, this can be translated as 'is (A)', 'am (A), or 'are (A)~ing'. The expression is made by adding いる to the て form of either る-Verbs, or う-Verbs. Due to いる being one of the verbs for 'existing' in Japanese, the ている form means something closer to 'continuing to exist in a specific state', rather than (A)~ing in English. This is why verbs like 死(し)ぬ, and 知(し)る, appear as the ている form in Japanese, when they would appear as the past form in English.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: シャンプーは何を使っているの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What shampoo are you using?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今ラーメンを食べています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am eating ramen now.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前はもう死んでいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are already dead.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この人誰か知っている？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you know who this is?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何をしている？
Questions.EnglishHTML: What are you doing?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寿司を食べている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am eating sushi.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今、勉強していないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am not studying now.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今、兄は寝ていません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My older brother is not sleeping now.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は図書館で日本語を勉強しているだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is studying Japanese at the library, right?

Name: へ
Meaning: To, Toward
About: へ is a particle used when describing a place that someone or something is 'moving toward', or 'in contact with'. In many cases, the particles に and へ are interchangeable, but there is a slight difference in meaning. へ focuses more on the distance/effort required to get between (A) and (B), while に focuses more on the connection between (A) and (B). へ always comes after the noun signifying the destination. In these examples, while they may seem the same at first glance, へ shows that there is a space between (A) and (B), while に puts the emphasis solely on the destination. This is why common expressions such as 'city/country name へようこそ' sound very polite. It is like saying 'Welcome, and we acknowledge your journey/effort to get here'. In the TV-show example, this commonly means 'thank you for your effort to watch this particular show, out of all the ones you could have chosen'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はフランスへ行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will go to France.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日東京に行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will go to Tokyo tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大阪へようこそ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Welcome to Osaka!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ＢＰＲニュースへようこそ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Welcome to BPR News.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大阪へようこそ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Welcome to Osaka.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここへ？
Questions.EnglishHTML: To here?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 神戸へ行く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To go to Kobe.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 家へ帰る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To return to one's house.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 道へ走る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To run toward the road.

Name: ～に行(い)く
Meaning: To go ~, To go in order to ~
About: に行(い)く is a grammar construction that is used when someone is going somewhere for the purpose of doing (A). (A) representing the verb that comes before に行(い)く. As with other uses of に, this particle is highlighting an end point or goal of 'going'. When using this structure, it will be important to remember that (A) will appear in its stem form, before に行(い)く gets attached to the end. This grammar point is regularly translated as 'to go in order to (A)'. If you have already 'gone' somewhere for the purpose of doing something, then you would use '(A) に来(き)た', while at the location.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 釣りに行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To go fishing. (Fishing is the purpose/goal of going)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今からトレーニングをしに行きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am going to go workout now. (Working out is the purpose/goal of going)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さっきあなたの友達が宿題を渡しに来たよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Your friend came to hand in their homework earlier.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ラーメンを食べにいく。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To go eat ramen. (to go in order to eat)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サッカーをしにいく。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To go play soccer. (to go in order to play)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語を勉強しにいきます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will go study Japanese. (to go in order to study)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 公園へ遊びにいった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I went to play at the park. (to go in order to play)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 本を買いにいきます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will go buy a book. (to go in order to buy)

Name: 誰(だれ)
Meaning: Who
About: 誰(だれ) is a substitute noun that is used in Japanese to describe unknown people. Due to Japanese particles behaving in very specific ways, 誰(だれ) will be translated differently depending on the particle that follows it. 誰(だれ)が・誰(だれ)で・誰(だれ)に・誰(だれ)を (who), 誰(だれ)の (whose), 誰(だれ)か (somebody), 誰(だれ)も (any/everybody).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰がくる？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Who is coming?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前は誰と行く？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Who are you going with?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは誰のノートですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whose notebook is this?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部屋に誰かがいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Somebody is in my room.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは誰に送る？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To whom are you going to send this?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰を連れて来ますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Who will you bring with you?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰もいない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There's nobody.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰ですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Who is it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰がいますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Who is there?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰がしますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Who will do it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは誰のパソコンですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whose computer is this?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は誰でしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder who he is.

Name: い-Adjective + です (Predicate)
Meaning: い-Adjective (Predicate)
About: A predicate is a word that describes the topic/subject of a sentence. The Japanese equivalent of this is a 述語(じゅつご), which literally means 'statement word'. As a predicate, い-Adjectives can appear by themselves (when the word they are describing does not need to be stated), or they may be used at the end of a sentence. When there are no other words apart from the adjective itself, it comes across similar to 'It's cute', or 'It's hot', and similar expressions in English. We just have to guess what the 'it' is from context. In many sentences, either は or が could be used to mark the word/words that the predicate is describing. However, which one sounds more natural will depend on many factors. In general, if you are specifically pointing out something as being different from other things in the same category, が will be used. In this example, が is distinguishing this specific bath as having a unique level of hotness compared to others (maybe the water system is broken and only boiling water comes out). は would sound unnatural in this type of sentence, as it is not the 'normal' state of the bath.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 丸い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's round.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 地球は丸い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The earth is round.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このお風呂は熱い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This bath is hot. (In general, it is hot)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このお風呂が熱い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This bath is hot. (Compared to other cooler baths)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
暑い。
暑いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is hot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
寒い。
寒いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is cold.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
これは楽しい。
これは楽しいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is fun.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
猫はかわいい。
猫はかわいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Cats are cute.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
私の家は近い。
私の家は近いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My house is near (by).

Name: な-Adjective + だ (Predicate)
Meaning: な-Adjective (Predicate)
About: A predicate is a word that describes the topic/subject of a sentence. The Japanese equivalent of this is a 述語(じゅつご), which literally means 'statement word'. As a predicate, な-Adjectives can appear by themselves (when the word they are describing does not need to be stated), or they may be used at the end of a sentence. It is important to remember that all な-Adjectives can also function as nouns, and therefore tend to sound more like a noun than an adjective, when used as a predicate. When there are no other words apart from the adjective itself, it comes across similarly to 'It's pretty', or 'It's hated', and similar expressions in English. We just have to guess what the 'it' is from context.  In this example, が is distinguishing a specific station as having a unique level of dirtiness compared to others. は would sound unnatural in this type of sentence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 素敵。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's wonderful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼氏は素敵です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My boyfriend is lovely.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 有名な駅は汚いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Popular stations are dirty. (In general)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この有名な駅が汚いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This popular station is dirty. (Compared to other popular stations)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
夜の海は静かだ。
夜の海は静かです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The night sea is quiet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
さいきさんは親切だ。
さいきさんは親切です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Saiki is kind.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
彼は静かだ。
彼は静かです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is quiet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
私は暇だ。
私は暇です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am free.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
海が綺麗だ。
海が綺麗です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The sea is beautiful.

Name: だった・でした
Meaning: Was, Were (Past tense)
About: In order to say that something 'was' a certain way in Japanese, you will need to use だった (casual) or でした (polite) attached to the end of a noun or な-Adjective. This is simply a combination of two auxiliary verbs, だ (or です when polite) with た. For だった, we will need to add った to the base form of だ. For です, す will change to し before adding た.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの電車は静かだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That train was quiet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 富士山は綺麗でした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Mt. Fuji was beautiful.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 綺麗だった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was beautiful.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was Tom.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは、昨日でした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That was yesterday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 猫が大好きだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I really liked cats. (Cats were loved by me)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大変だった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was terrible.

Name: じゃない
Meaning: Is not, Isn't
About: じゃない is the casual form of ではない. では is regularly contracted to じゃ in Japanese, so is worth remembering as its own structure. じゃない (casual), or ではない (semi-polite) are the structures used for creating the negative form of nouns and な-Adjectives. These structures are simply added to the base form of the noun or な-Adjective. じゃ and では can also be used with the negative ます form of ある, to create the polite variant. ない is sometimes said/written as ね or ねえ. However, this is considered very casual, or even a bit rough. Accordingly, it is best avoided in most conversations.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは食べ物じゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This isn't food.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この携帯は便利じゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This cell phone is not useful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは飲み物ではありません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is not a drink.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたの部屋は綺麗ではありません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Your room is not clean.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺は馬鹿じゃねえよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm not stupid.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは無理じゃない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is impossible, isn't it? (More direct statement)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは無理じゃないか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't you think this is impossible? (More direct question)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 犬じゃない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not a dog.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生じゃない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am not a teacher.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 牛肉じゃないです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not beef.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この絵は、綺麗じゃありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This painting is not beautiful.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 好きなスポーツは、サッカーではありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The sport that I like is not soccer.

Name: じゃなかった
Meaning: Was not, Wasn't
About: じゃなかった is the casual form of ではなかった. では itself is regularly contracted to じゃ in Japanese, so is worth remembering as its own structure. じゃなかった (casual), or ではなかった (semi-polite) are the structures used for creating the negative-past form of nouns and な-Adjectives. Either じゃなかった or ではなかった will simply be added to the base form of a noun or な-Adjective. じゃ and では may also be used with the negative-past ます form of ある, to create the polite variant.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あそこは病院じゃなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That place over there wasn't a hospital.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この車は便利じゃなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This car wasn't useful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あれは猫ではありませんでした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That over there was not a cat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は綺麗ではありませんでした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person was not pretty.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: りんごじゃなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was not an apple.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生じゃなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They were not a teacher.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 晩ごはんが好きではなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Dinner was not liked by me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その動物は、牛じゃなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That animal was not a cow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 宿題は大変ではありませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The homework was not terrible/hard.

Name: くなかった
Meaning: Was not, Wasn't (Adjective)
About: In order to create the negative past form of い-Adjectives, we will need to use the conjugation form. The conjugation form of an い-Adjective is simply created by removing the い, and replacing it with く. く is then followed by ない (conjugated into its past form なかった), or あります (conjugated into its past negative form ありませんでした). The polite negative (past) form requires use of the う - Verb, ある. This is not a unique rule for the negative past, but actually the correct way that all く-form conjugations of い-Adjectives should be constructed. However, in modern Japanese, it is not considered necessary. Instead, the semi-polite form is often used. The semi-polite form is constructed by using なかった, and then simply adding です.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は太くなかったよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was not fat!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 北海道（に）は、暑くありませんでした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hokkaido was not hot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この車は、高くなかったです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This car was not expensive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コーヒーは熱くなかったです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The coffee was not hot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは、安くありませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That was not cheap.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の犬は強くなかったです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My dog was not strong.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の姉の家が高くなかったです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My (older) sister's house was not expensive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 漫画を読むのは難しくなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Reading manga was not difficult.

Name: と
Meaning: Quotation
About: One of the regular functions of と in Japanese is as a quotation particle. This use is called 引用(いんよう) in Japanese, which basically translates as 'reference', or 'citation'. This way of using と can appear after almost any type of word (or phrase), but requires だ when used after nouns or な-Adjectives. と as a quotation marker will almost always be followed by a verb that shows what type of 'quote' it is. This can be words like 言(い)う, 思(おも)う, 考(かんが)える, 聞(き)く, etc. However, at the end of a sentence, the verb will often be omitted. As with other instances of the particle と being used, this use simply expresses the relationship between (A) 'what was communicated', and (B) 'how it was communicated'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生が「危ない！」と叫んだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The teacher yelled, 'Watch out!'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 木村さんが「３キロ歩いた」と言った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Kimura san said, 'I walked 3 km.'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あれは猫だと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think that is a cat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 富士山は綺麗だと思う？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you think that Mt. Fuji is beautiful?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 生徒が先生に「何で？」と。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The students asked the teacher, 'Why?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はとても親切だと聞きました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that he is very friendly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「彼はここに来ますか」と聞いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I asked, 'Is he coming here?' (asked)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「晩ごはんを作った」と言った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I said, 'I made dinner'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「重いですか」と聞きました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He asked, 'Is it heavy?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生が「危ない」と書いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The teacher wrote, 'It is dangerous'.

Name: って
Meaning: Casual quotation
About: って is a casual variation of the と particle that is used for quoting something. This use is called 引用(いんよう) in Japanese, which basically translates to 'reference', or 'citation'. って is almost exclusively used after direct quotations, and will be followed by a verb indicating what type of communication was used. 言(い)った, 思(おも)った, 聞(き)いた, for example. Just like with と, the verb that comes after って is frequently omitted. This is even more true for って, as many things are omitted in casual language.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 「行ってきます」ってママが言った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Mom said, 'I'll be back soon'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 「それは危ないよ」って先生が言った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The teacher said, 'That is dangerous'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムは「今日休む」って。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tom said he was going to take the day off today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「乾杯！」って言いたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to say, 'Kanpai!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生は「おはよう！」って言った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The teacher said, 'Good morning!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「明日は雨が降りますか」って聞いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I asked, 'Is it going to rain tomorrow?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は「晩ごはんを捨てた」って言った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He said, 'I threw away my dinner'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「何時からですか」って聞いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I asked, 'What time is it from?'

Name: Verb (Non-Past)
Meaning: (Non-past)
About: In Japanese, the non-past form of verbs is identical to the dictionary form/casual form. Unlike English, this form of verbs is able to be used in several cases where conjugation/different constructions would be required in English. In these examples, we can see the three forms of English verbs that are covered by the single non-past form of Japanese verbs. These are verbs ending with -s (sees, hears, goes), verbs requiring will (will see, will hear, will go), and verbs that do not require conjugation (see, hear, go). Due to this one form of verbs covering several different nuances, it is often important to use expressions of time in the sentence, so that the meaning becomes clear. If there is no word distinguishing 'time' in the sentence, the nuance will be that of stating a general fact about something that is true at any time. From all of these examples, we can see that the non-past form can be thought of as expressing one of three basic ideas. General facts, habits, or future events.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 嫁は毎晩映画を見ます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My wife watches movies every night.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺は明日の昼にピザを食べます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will eat pizza tomorrow during lunch.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供は遊ぶ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Kids play.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: テイラーは毎朝走る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Taylor runs every morning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カホは８時に寝る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Kaho will sleep at 8 p.m.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 赤ちゃんは泣きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Babies cry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
鳥は飛ぶ。
鳥は飛びます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Birds fly. (the verb is used as a general truth)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
ロックを時々聞く。
ロックを時々聞きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I listen to rock sometimes. (habit)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
私は九時にバナナを食べる。
私は九時にバナナを食べます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will eat a banana at 9 o'clock. (future event)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
ヴァンパイアは血を飲む。
ヴァンパイアは血を飲みます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Vampires drink blood. (general truth)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
たなかさんは毎週車を洗う。
たなかさんは毎週車を洗います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san washes the car every week. (habit)

Name: ～た + (Noun)
Meaning: Verb modified noun, Relative clause
About: In Japanese, if you want to describe something or someone that is performing an action, one of the ways you can do this is through a relative clause. A relative clause is when two phrases are joined into one sentence, rather than two individual sentences. The た (plain-past), or ている (continuous) form of verbs are usually used. る-Verbs and う-Verbs follow their regular conjugation rules when making a relative clause. In the first example, we can see that 'Takashi-san is a man that lived in Tokyo', is one sentence, rather than 'Takashi-san is a man. He lived in Tokyo'. In English, words like 'that', and 'which' are used to create a relative clause. However, seeing as though these words do not exist in Japanese, the first phrase is simply attached to the noun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たかしさんは東京に住んだ男。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takashi-san is a man that lived in Tokyo.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 貴方が食べたハンバーガー。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The hamburger that you ate.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんが飲んでいるコーヒー。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The coffee that Tanaka-san is drinking.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 道で寝ている犬。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A dog that is sleeping on the road.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たかしさんは東京に住んでいました男。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takashi-san is a man who lived in Tokyo. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 洗った服。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Washed clothes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たくさん勉強をした生徒。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A student who studied a lot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本に住んでいる外国人。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A foreigner living in Japan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達から借りたペン。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A pen borrowed from a friend.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私が作った椅子。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A chair I made.

Name: の
Meaning: Possessive use (Noun omission)
About: A common pattern in Japanese is referring back to a noun that has already been mentioned, without actually repeating it.  This is achieved through the use of the particle の, in a similar way to its standard possessive use. The noun that would usually follow の is dropped, as it has either been said earlier in the sentence, or is understood clearly from context. In these examples, it would also be grammatically correct to use the same noun following の, but as can be seen in the English translation, it results in unnecessary repetition. This is called word stacking/redundant words (重(かさ)ね言葉(ことば)) in Japanese, and is considered a poor writing/speech habit. Despite this, it is important to know that this の is exactly the same as the possessive の (with the following word simply being left out).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この本はたけしさんのです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This book is Takeshi-san's (book).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そのペンは誰の？あなたの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That pen, whose (pen) is it? Is it your (pen)?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの車、あなたが乗っているのですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That car, is it the car (one) you drive? (の is used here instead of repeating 'car'.)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その帽子は娘の(帽子)です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That hat is my daughter's (hat).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのパソコンは君の(パソコン)でしょう？
Questions.EnglishHTML: That computer is your (computer) right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 木綿のスカーフは私の(スカーフ)です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The cotton scarf is my (scarf).

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「この本は誰の(本)？」
「先週に来たお客さんの(本)。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Whose book is this (book)?'
'It's the customer's (who came in last week) (book).'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この駐車場もあなたの会社の(駐車場)ですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This parking lot is also your company's (parking lot)?

Name: な (Prohibitive)
Meaning: Do not, Don't (Prohibitive)
About: な is classified as a sentence ending particle in Japanese. When attached to the base (dictionary) form of a verb, it has the nuance of strongly demanding that someone 'not' do something.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 危険！触るな!
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Danger! Don't touch!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 「家の中で走るな！」とお母さんが言った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My mother said, “Don't run in the house!”

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 行くな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Don't go.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここでサッカーをするな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Don't play soccer here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 泣くな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Don't cry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一人でするな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Don't do it alone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「これは不味い！」って言うな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Don't say, 'This tastes bad!'

Name: だけ
Meaning: Only, Just
About: だけ is used in Japanese in a similar way to 'only' or 'just' in English. The basic meaning of this word is that 'while there are/were several possibilities, only (A) is true/was chosen'. だけ is used by attaching it to the base (dictionary) form of any word, except for な-Adjectives, which require な when being used adjectivally. Due to な-Adjectives being able to be used as either a noun or an adjective, the meaning of a sentence will be different depending on whether だけ is used with the noun form, or the adjective form. Basically this difference just highlights whether something is being discussed in a measurable way (an adjective), or an immeasurable way (a noun).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今夜は食べるだけ、何も飲まない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tonight I'm only going to eat, I won't drink anything.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はブロッコリーだけがきらい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I only dislike broccoli.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は有名なだけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person is just famous. (Fame is all they have)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このスープは辛いだけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This soup is just spicy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の彼女は綺麗なだけです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My girlfriend is just beautiful. (There are no other distinguishing features)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 富士山は綺麗だけじゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As for Mt. Fuji, beauty is not all there is. (There are other distinguishing features)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一人だけです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only one person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それだけです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サッカーだけが好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I only like soccer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私だけ行きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only I am going.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その映画は長いだけ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That movie is just long.

Name: どれ
Meaning: Which (of three or more)
About: どれ is from the same family of words as これ, それ, and あれ. These words are called こそあど言葉(ことば) in Japanese. Unlike the other 3, which all point to a specific thing, words starting with ど are designed for enquiring about something unknown. どれ can roughly be translated as 'which' in English, and is used for enquiring about a group (of 3 or more things). From these examples, we can see that the particle が is often used with どれ, especially when preceding questions. However, when どれ follows a noun, は will be used. When there are only two choices to select between, どちら + の,  or どっち + の will be used instead of どれ. This is a habit that has become part of the language over time, and was not originally how these words were used.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どれが飛びますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Which one of these flies?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どれが新しいですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Which one is new?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どれが綺麗ですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Which one is beautiful?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どれが弟ですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Which one is your younger brother?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたの車はどれ？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Which one is your car?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どちらのケーキを食べますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Which cake would you like to eat? (Out of these two choices)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どっちのテストが難しい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Which test is hard? (Out of these two choices)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どれがいいですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Which is good?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どれでもいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whichever is fine.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どれを選びますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Which will you choose?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どれが好きですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Which do you like?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どれでも好きだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like whichever。

Name: どこ
Meaning: Where
About: どこ is one of the forms of the どれ family of words used to enquire about unknown things. In this case it asks about a place. Just like どれ represents 'which', どこ represents 'which place', or simply 'where'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日はどこに行く？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Where do you want to go tomorrow?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 牛乳はどこにありますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Where is the milk located?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どっち？右？左？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Which way? Right? Left? (Focuses on the direction of movement)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここはどこですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Where is this place? (Focuses on the location)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どこに行きますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Where are you going?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: すみませんが、この本はどこにありますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Excuse me, but where can I find this book?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここはどこ？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Where is here?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どこがいい？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Where is good?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 美味しいレストランはどこですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Where is a delicious restaurant?

Name: どの
Meaning: Which (of three or more), What (kind)
About: どの is classified as a 'pre-noun adjectival' in Japanese. These are a special type of word that do not conjugate, which means that they will always appear in the same form. どの comes from the same family of words as どれ and どこ, and is used for asking about 'which' thing someone will choose. In these examples, we can see that どの may be used to ask a question, or it may also be used in a similar way to 'whatever', or 'whichever' in English.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どの飲み物がいい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Which drink would you like?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どの色でもいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whatever color is okay. (Literally 'even any of whichever color is good')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 赤か青、どっちがいい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you prefer red or blue?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どの色が好き？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What color do you like?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どの寿司屋がいいですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Which sushi restaurant is good?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どのレストランに行く？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Which restaurant will you go to?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どのブランドを選びますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Which brand will you choose?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どのパソコンが好きですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Which computer do you like?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どのお茶を飲みますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Which tea will you drink?

Name: ～ている ②
Meaning: State of being, Has (have) done
About: As mentioned in our first ている lesson, this construction is used to convey that someone or something is existing in a constant state of 'doing' the verb that comes before て. Here we will take a closer look at several of the verbs that will be used with ている, to express 'existing in a state of (A) having been done'. All of these verbs would appear as the past form in English, after the initial thing has 'started', 'come', 'died', or 'gotten angry'. However, this is not the case in Japanese. In Japanese, once something is angry, it exists in the state of being angry, once something has started, it exists in the state of being ongoing, once something dies, it exists in the state of being dead, and so on.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: クラスは始まっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The class has already started. (Existing in the state of having started)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お母さんは今買い物に行っています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My mom went out to go shopping. (Existing in the state of having gone)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの犬は死んでいるだろう、悲しいね 。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That dog over there is probably dead… How upsetting. (Existing in the state of having died)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生がめちゃ怒っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My teacher is very angry. (Existing in the state of having gotten angry)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ピアノが落ちている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The piano has fallen. (Existing in the state of having fallen)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのカバは太っていない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That hippopotamus over there isn't fat. (The hippopotamus is in the state of not being fat)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: バスは今大阪に来ています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The bus is in Osaka now. (The bus has come to Osaka and is there now)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パーティーは始まっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The party has begun. (The party has begun and is still going on)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電車は東京に行っています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The train is in Tokyo. (The train has gone to Tokyo and is there)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ななさんのバナナは腐っています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Nana's banana is rotten. (Nana's banana is in a state of being rotten)

Name: ～てから
Meaning: Once...is done, Once...happens, After doing
About: In order to specifically express that one thing happens/begins to happen after another thing, てから will be used. This expression is regularly translated as 'once (A) happens, (B)', or 'after doing (A), (B)'. The difference between てから, and the regular て form followed by another verb, is that てから puts more emphasis on the (A) action 'enabling' the (B) action.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: おやつを食べてから、勉強を始める。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will start studying once I eat some snacks.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 洗濯をしてから、出かける。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After doing the laundry, I will go out.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今夜は勉強をするから、遊ばない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I won't hang out tonight, because I will be studying.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 牛丼の大盛を食べたから、お腹いっぱい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am full because I ate a large serving of gyudon. (After having eaten a large serving of gyudon)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 晩ご飯を食べてから、洗い物をする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After I eat, I will do the dishes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語の勉強をしてから、日本に行きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once I study Japanese, I will go to Japan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本に行ってから、日本語の勉強をします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After going to Japan, I will study Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この本を読んでから、返す。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once I've read this book, I will return it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暇になってから、ゆっくり旅行に行きたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After becoming free, I want to take a nice, long trip.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 雪が降ってから、スキーに行く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once it snows, I will go skiing.

Name: ～て (Sequence)
Meaning: And, And then, After that (sequence)
About: The て form of a verb, followed by another verb phrase is often translated to 'then', or 'and then', and is how Japanese lists sequences of events that happen one after another.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ショッピングセンターに行って、買い物をします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To go to the mall and then shop.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パンを買って、食べた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bought some bread, (and) then ate it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 晩ご飯を食べて歯を磨いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I ate dinner and brushed my teeth.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ともこは鍵をかけて出かけました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tomoko locked up the house and left.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日は９時に起きて、朝ごはんを食べて買い物に行きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tomorrow I will wake up at 9 (and), eat breakfast, and go shopping.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「東京に行って何をしたの？」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'What did you do after you went to Tokyo?'
（'You went to Tokyo, and then what did you do?')

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ひとみさんのお母さんに会って一緒に戻りました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I met Hitomi's mother, and we went back together.

Name: もう
Meaning: Already, Anymore
About: In English, もう is regularly translated to 'already', or 'anymore', depending on if it is used in a positive-past (already), or negative (anymore) sentence. The reason that Japanese only requires one word for both of these nuances is due to もう literally meaning 'something has unexpectedly ended'. From these sentences we can see that もう can be translated in each case as the following. (Past) - Although expected to not be done, it is. 'Already', in English. (Negative) - Although expected to still be going, it isn't. 'Anymore', in English. This is the opposite of まだ, which means 'something is unexpectedly still going'. もう may also be used to ask questions. This is when the speaker thinks that something 'might' have ended, but wants to confirm.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 朝ごはんはもう食べた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I already ate breakfast. (Although you probably didn't expect it, I have already eaten breakfast)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もうお金がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't have money anymore. (Although you probably didn't expect it, I have no money)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もうデザートを食べた？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Did you already eat dessert?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あ～もう無理。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ugh, that's enough. (I've had enough, I'm done arguing/continuing)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう学校に行きましたか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Did you already go to school?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もうその本を読んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have already read that book.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もうコーヒーを作りました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I already made coffee.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もうしました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I already did it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう帰った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They already went home.

Name: まだ
Meaning: Still, Not yet
About: In English, まだ is regularly translated as 'still', or 'not yet', depending on if it is used in a positive non-past, or negative sentence. The reason that Japanese only requires one word for both of these nuances is due to まだ literally meaning 'something is unexpectedly still going'. From these sentences, we can see that まだ may be translated in each case as the following. (Non-past) - Although (A) is expected to not be there/happening, it is. 'Still' in English. (ている) - Although (A) is expected to not still be going, it is. 'Not yet' in English. The negative form of this will be discussed more in まだ～ていません. This is the opposite of もう, which means 'something is unexpectedly finished'. まだ may also be used to ask questions. This is when the speaker thinks that something 'might' be continuing, but wants or needs to confirm.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まだ走っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am still running. (Although you probably didn't expect it, I am still running)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まだ親がいるからゲームできない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My parents are still here, so I can't play games. (Although you probably didn't expect it, my parents are still here)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まだ宿題があるから、遊ばない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I still have homework, so I can't hang out yet. (Although you probably didn't expect it, I still have homework)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まだ日本語の勉強しているの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are you still studying Japanese?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まだまだだねー。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are not ready for this. (You still STILL are not ready)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫にケーキがまだあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is still cake in the fridge.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まだ食べていますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Are you still eating!?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「お前にはまだ早いよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: ''It is still too early for you.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まだ雨が降っているの？
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's still raining?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まだ足が痛い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My foot still hurts.

Name: まだ～ていません
Meaning: Still haven't done (something)
About: まだ～ていません is a regular expression that combines the adverb まだ, with the conjunction particle て. The て form will be followed by the verb いる in its negative いません (polite), or いない (casual) form. This expression has the meaning of 'to still not have done (A)'. From these examples, it can be seen that this grammatical structure follows the regular rules of conjugation for the て form.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その映画はまだ見ていません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I still haven't watched that movie. (I continue to not have seen that movie)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それはまだ生徒に教えていません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have not taught my student that yet. (I continue to 'not' have taught that to my student)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まだ食べていません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I still haven't eaten.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その本をまだ読んでいません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I still haven't read that book.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まだ勉強していません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I still haven't studied.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この漢字をまだ習っていません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I still haven't learned this kanji.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 学校にまだ行っていません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I still haven't gone to school.

Name: ～てもいい
Meaning: It is alright/fine/okay even if, Can/may, ~ is also okay
About: Noun, い-Adjective, or な-Adjective + てもいい is a construction in Japanese that is used to express that something is 'okay', or 'alright'. It is also frequently used as a question to ask if you 'can', or 'may' do something. As can be seen, with い-Adjectives, we will need to use the conjugation form. This is created by removing the い and then replacing it with く. This phrase is also regularly used without the も, but is considered a bit more direct/casual in those cases. It is best to remove the も only when talking to people that you know well. てもいい is an expression that literally means て (noun, etc) も (also) いい (is good). Similarly to the てもいい grammar point that is used with verbs, this variant may also be used as a question. To do this, you simply need to follow てもいい with ですか, or the more casual の.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電車でもいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am fine even if it is by train. (It does not need to be by car)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お茶冷たくてもいい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is it okay even if the tea is cold? (Would you prefer I heat it?)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 肉が好きでもいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is okay even if you like meat. (I won't force you to eat something vegetarian)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 焼きそばでもいいですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is it okay even if it is yakisoba?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これ食べてもいいの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is it okay if we eat this? (Is this one that is okay to eat?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 高くてもいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is fine (even) if it's expensive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何でもいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Anything is fine.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰でもいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Anyone is fine.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 水曜日でもいいですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is it fine (even) if it is (on) Wednesday?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 冷たくてもいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is fine (even) if it is chilled.

Name: たい
Meaning: Want to do
About: たい is an auxiliary verb that is used to express things that you would like to do (want). To use たい, it needs to be added to the same conjugation base form of a verb that ます would be attached to. When using たい, the thing that is 'wanted' can either be marked with を, or が. The difference in nuance is that something marked with が is considered to be wanted more. たい is conjugated in the same way as い-Adjectives, meaning that the negative, past, or past-negative forms may also be used. たい is only used for expressing things that 'you' want, or repeating information/asking questions about what other people want. It may not be used to make guesses about what other people 'may' want, unless asking them directly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今夜はピザが食べたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tonight, I want to eat pizza.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: プロの歌手と歌いたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to sing with a professional singer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 虫は食べたくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't want to eat insects.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 警察官になりたかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wanted to become a police officer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昔は先生になりたくなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In the past, I did not want to become a teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何が食べたい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What do you want to eat?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: オレンジジュースを飲みたかったの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Did you want to drink orange juice?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたはご飯を作りたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As for you, I want to make dinner. (This can never mean 'I want you to make dinner for me', and is a fairly unnatural sentence)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アカネも行きたい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Akane, do you want to go too? (Sounds more like a question than an invitation)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本に行きたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to go to Japan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 来年日本に行きたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Next year, I want to go to Japan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 早く食べたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to eat soon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サッカーをしたいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to play soccer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 文法を勉強したいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to study grammar.

Name: たり～たりする
Meaning: Things like ~ and ~
About: In Japanese, たり is a 'conjunction particle' that is used in exactly the same way as て. However, instead of having the nuance of 'then', or 'and', it has the nuance of 'and things like'. Basically, it is used for listing sequences of events that do not happen in a specific order. The last たり in any sequence should be followed by a form of する (for example, した for past tense). From these examples we can see that たり will sometimes be said as だり. This happens with the same verbs that usually use だ for past tense (like 読(よ)んだ), or で for the て form ( like 泳(およ)いで). This will not change the meaning at all, and is only to help make the words easier to say. To summarize, the difference between て form, and たり is as follows. Events in order - I did (A) て, (B) て, (C) て, (D) た. Events in no specific order - I did (D) たり, (B) たり, (A) たり, (C) たりした. たり is frequently used when there is only one verb in the sentence. This just means that the speaker did 'things like (A)', without specifically listing anything else.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 休みの日は家でテレビを見たり、寝たりする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On my days off, I do things like watch tv and sleep at home.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 飲み会で食べたり、飲んだりした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At the party, I did things like eat and drink.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昔あそこの池で泳いだりした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In the past, I used to swim in that lake over there. (Among other things)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勉強をしたり、おやつを食べたり、掃除もします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I do things like study, eat snacks, and also clean. (In no specific order)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな夜遅くに上司から電話だ、なんか問題発生してたりして。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's a phone call from my boss, at such a late time. I wonder if something happened.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなこと言って、実はお前もそいつのこと好きだったりして。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You say that, but I bet in reality you like her too. (Joking)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 家でゲームをしたり、食べたりした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At home, I did things like play video games and eat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 音楽を聞いたり、本を読んだりしました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I did things like listen to music and read books.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 掃除をしたり、洗濯をしたりした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I did things like cleaning and doing the laundry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 雨が降ったり、止んだりするね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It keeps doing things like raining and stopping, doesn't it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は、勉強したり、練習したりする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Today I will do things like study and practice.

Name: 結構(けっこう)
Meaning: Quite, A lot, Fairly, Rather
About: 結構(けっこう) is a な-Adjective that is actually used more frequently as a sentence altering adverb, than it is as a な-Adjective. What this means is that it is regularly used before an entire phrase (without な or だ), and it will modify the entire sentence. The most common meaning that 結構(けっこう) has is 'quite' (a bit/a lot).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 結構走ったね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We ran quite a lot, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 結構高いですよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's quite expensive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 袋は結構です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't need a bag, thank you. (I'm fine without a bag)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いいえ、けっこうです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No thank you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このカバンはけっこう高いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This bag is quite expensive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それはけっこう面白いですね
Questions.EnglishHTML: That is quite interesting, isn't it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は、けっこうです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No thank you. (I'm fine)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この公園はけっこう広いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This park is quite spacious.

Name: 沢山(たくさん)
Meaning: Many, A lot of, Plenty, Enough
About: There are many cases in Japanese where a noun will appear as an adverb, particularly with words that are describing amounts. たくさん, or 沢山(たくさん) as it is regularly seen, is one of those words. たくさん means 'a lot', or 'many' in Japanese, and can be used before a phrase, or directly before a noun, when separated via の.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 沢山食べてよ!
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Eat a lot! (Eat to your heart's content!)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この島には沢山の猫がいます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On this island, there are a lot of cats. (Unrelated to the sentence, there is actually an island like this in Japan!)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの店の前に沢山人が集まっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are a lot of people gathering in front of that store. (Focuses on the store. I wonder why there are so many people in front of that store)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの店の前に沢山の人が集まっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are a lot of people gathering in front of that store. (Focuses on the people. The amount of people gathering up in front of that store is unbelievable)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たくさんありますから。食べてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is plenty. So, please eat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たくさん雪が降りました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A lot of snow fell.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たくさん仕事をします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will do a lot of work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語の勉強をたくさんしました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I did a lot of Japanese studying.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はたくさんの本を読む。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He reads a lot of books.

Name: 前(まえ)に
Meaning: Before, In front of
About: 前(まえ)に is used when describing something that is either 'before something' (in time), or 'in front of something' (a location). It is used with verbs (in their non-past form), or nouns. When used with nouns, の is required before 前(まえ)に.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 病院の前にあるコンビニ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A convenience store in front of the hospital.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家に入る前に靴を脱ぐ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I take off my shoes before I enter the house.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 銀行の前にあるラーメン屋。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The ramen shop in front of the bank.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の手前にある着物は高いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The kimono right in front of me is expensive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食べるまえに「いただきます」と言う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Before eating we say 'いただきます'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 帰るまえに勉強をする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Before going home I will study.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まえにここに来ました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I've been here before.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食べるまえに手を洗います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will wash my hands before I eat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テレビのまえに、机があります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is a desk in front of the TV.

Name: くらい ①
Meaning: About, Approximately
About: くらい or ぐらい (more common in spoken language) has several different uses in Japanese, but is often translated as 'about', or 'approximately'. It comes from the kanji 位(くらい), which literally means a 'rank', or 'grade' of something. This use of くらい comes after numbers, or counter words. As can be seen in the last example, くらい may also be used after question words such as どの, when asking about the extent (grade) of something. Due to the original meaning of くらい being 'rank', or 'extent', it may not be used when referring to broad periods of time. ころ will be used in these situations. However, くらい and ころ may be used interchangeably when referring to a specific time (due to a specific time being able to be thought of as an extent).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 後３分くらいで着く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'll arrive in about 3 minutes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ４個ぐらい欲しいな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want about 4.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どのくらいで着きますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: About how long will it take for you to arrive?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ８時くらいでもいい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is about 8 okay?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ８時ごろでもいい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is about 8 okay?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供のくらいにディズニーランドに行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: About when I was a kid, I went to Disneyland. (Incorrect example, with unnatural English to match!)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供のころにディズニーに行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I went to Disney when I was a kid.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何時ぐらいに来ますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Approximately when will you come?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あと３０分ぐらいで行きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will go/leave in approximately 30 minutes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 毎週コーヒーはどのくらい飲む？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Approximately how much coffee do you drink per week?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は１０歳くらいだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He's about 10 years old.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一週間に、五時間ぐらいスポーツをする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I play sports for about five hours in one week.

Name: Noun + まで
Meaning: Until, Till,  To (but no further than)
About: まで is a particle that roughly means 'as far as'. Due to this, when used with regular nouns, or words that signify some kind of end point (a time or day), it is often translated as 'until', 'till', or 'to'. When used in relation to a place, まで functions similarly to に. This means that someone or something will go 'to' the place, but not any further. まで may also be used about points in time in the past, where 'up until' would usually be used in English.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 空港まで行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go to the airport. (To 'go' until the airport, and then be finished)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ９時まで勉強する。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I always study until 9.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 駅まで送るよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'll take you to the station. (Until the station is reached)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車で駅に行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will go to the station by car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日のパーティーは１１時まで続いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The party last night continued up until 11.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どこまで行く？
Questions.EnglishHTML: How far will you go? (Until)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ７時までです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Until seven o'clock.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このセールは金曜日までです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This sale lasts until Friday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 朝まで寝ました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I slept until morning.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ８時まで、テレビを見る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To watch TV until eight o'clock.

Name: Verb + まで
Meaning: Until (something) happens
About: まで is a particle that roughly means 'as far as (A)', or 'until the point of (A)'. When used with verbs, it is often translated as 'until (A) happens'. Because まで means 'as far as/until the point of', it cannot be used with verbs in past tense, as would usually be the case in English. Due to this, past tense will be made clear by the context of the story, or verbs that come later in the sentence. When used with a place, まで functions similarly to に. This means that someone or something will go 'to' the place, but not go any further.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達が来るまで、駅をウロウロした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Until my friend came, I wandered around the station. (した gives the whole sentence the meaning of past tense)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 携帯は壊れるまで、使います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Until my phone breaks, I will use it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 授業が始まるまで、先生が来なかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The teacher didn't come until the class started.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 映画が始まるまで、友達と話した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Until the movie started, I talked with my friend.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼が来るまで、日本語を勉強します。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Until he comes, I will study Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: カタカナを覚えるまで、私は寝ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Until I memorize katakana, I won't sleep.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その漢字を覚えるまで、辞書を使う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Until I remember that kanji, I will use a dictionary.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お風呂に入るまで、ゆっくりしたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Until I get in the bath, I want to relax.

Name: 過(す)ぎる
Meaning: Too much, Very
About: すぎる is a verb that is used in Japanese to mean 'to exceed', or 'to go past'. It keeps this meaning when it is attached to other words, and creates the Japanese equivalent of saying that something is 'too much'. すぎる can be joined to the ます stem of verbs, the stem form of い-Adjectives (simply remove the い), or the stem form of な-Adjectives (simply remove the な). With すぎる, the る is regularly omitted, with すぎ being used by itself. This is a casual language pattern, and something you will hear all the time. This variation may be used with any word that すぎる would usually be used with. There are a few rules that you will need to be careful about when using すぎる. The first of these unique rules is using すぎる with ない. When linked to ない, the い-Adjective, the い changes to さ, creating the structure なさすぎる. This means 'too much not (A)', or more naturally in English 'not enough (A)'. However, when the auxiliary verb version of ない follows verbs, the さ is not used, resulting in なすぎる. Despite this, さ may sometimes be included following verbs in slangy Japanese. As with regular ない forms, では or じゃ will be required when used after な-Adjectives. In the third example here, we can see that the さ has been omitted. This is not correct Japanese, as the さ will always be required when ない is functioning as an い-Adjective. The second unique rule is when using すぎる with いい to mean 'too good'. Because すぎる is used with the stem form of い-Adjectives, you will need to remember that the stem form of いい is not actually い, but よ. This means that よすぎる would be correct, while いすぎる is not.
