AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 頑張りすぎるのは身体に良くない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Working too hard is not good for your health.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは熱すぎるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is way too hot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺には田舎は静かすぎる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For me, the countryside is way too quiet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この犬、可愛すぎ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This dog is too cute!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は私のタイプじゃなさすぎる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person is DEFINITELY not my type. (Literally 'they are too much not my type')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はお金がなさすぎる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't have enough money. (Literally 'I have too much of no money')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この店は商品がなすぎる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This store does not have enough goods. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この歌は良すぎる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This song is too good.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 学校に行かなさすぎるから成績が落ちた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I don't go to school enough, my grades are going down. (Literally, I don't go too much)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はトイレに行かなさすぎない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He doesn't not go to the toilet enough. (A double negative that becomes positive)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ゲームセンターには行きすぎないでね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't go to the arcade too often. (The negative focus is on 'too much', and sounds more like a request)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここはゴミが多すぎる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is too much garbage here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この寿司は美味しすぎる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This sushi is too delicious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その冗談は面白くなさすぎた。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
That joke was not funny at all.
(Literally - Was too much not funny)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつも週末に寝すぎます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I always sleep too much on the weekends.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 漢字を書きすぎたから、手が痛い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I wrote too much kanji, my hand hurts.

Name: にする
Meaning: To decide on, To choose, To make something into, To view something as
About: にする is a structure that combines the に particle (a location/target), with the verb する. It means to 'make/decide' something in a certain way. The nuance with にする is that the speaker has direct control over the outcome. This is where the strong feeling of 'choice' comes from. The noun that comes before にする is the thing that is being decided. In this example, although the common translation is 'to decide', it is actually much closer to the slang expression 'to do (A)' in English. This means that the literal translation is actually 'I'll do a beer', or 'I'll make it a beer'. Sometimes the particle と is used instead of に. Although this has the same meaning, it changes the nuance slightly. When と is used, it takes away the feeling of being a direct decision. とする tends to be used in more formal situations, but this is only because と is less 'definite', so results in the phrase sounding less pushy. If you were going to compare these two to an English equivalent, it would be similar to the difference between the following sentences. に - I'll buy a burger. (A burger is the direct target of 'buy') と - I'll go with a burger. (You aren't 'going' anywhere, it just sounds softer) This grammar point may be used for more abstract nouns, and does not specifically need to be 'items'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺はビールにする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm going to decide on this beer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日はここまでとする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today, I will decide to make this the end. (Why don't we call it a day, if that's ok)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日はここまでにする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today, I will decide to end it here. (I'm going to call it a day)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ハイキングへ行くの日曜日にする？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is Sunday ok for hiking? (Literally, 'as for heading hiking, will you make it Sunday?')

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何にする？
Questions.EnglishHTML: What will you decide on?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日の晩ごはんは何にする？
Questions.EnglishHTML: What have you decided on for today's dinner?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このかばんにします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To decide on this bag.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日の朝ごはんは魚にします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To decide on fish for breakfast tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このレストランにします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To decide on this restaurant.

Name: になる・くなる
Meaning: To become (Adjective)
About: になる (with な-Adjectives), or くなる (with い-Adjectives) is an expression used in Japanese to show that something is 'becoming (A)'. It can be used with any form of なる, to highlight that something will become (non-past), is becoming (continuous), or has become (past). It can even be used with negative forms, to show that something 'will not become (A)'. In the example with the tea getting cold, we can see how ている sometimes highlights something that exists in an ongoing state, rather than changing any further. In other words, 'the tea has gotten cold, and remains to be cold'. Additionally, the adjective いい 'good' is an exception to the regular conjugation rules for い-Adjectives, and will conjugate as よくなる, not いくなる.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 早く食べて、冷たくなるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hurry up and eat, it will get cold.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お茶が冷たくなっているよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The tea has gotten cold.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コーヒーが温くなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The coffee has become lukewarm.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は医者にならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I won't become a doctor.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勉強をしているから、頭が良くなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I study, I will become smart. (Literally, 'my head will get good')

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 難しくなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To become difficult.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嬉しくなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To become happy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 早くなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To become fast.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: よくなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To become better.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 綺麗になる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To become pretty/clean.

Name: の中(なか)で～が一番(いちばん)
Meaning: Out of ~, ~ is the best/most ~
About: In Japanese '(A) の中(なか)で (B) が一番(いちばん) (C)', is a regular expression that is used for showing that something is 'the most (C)', usually an adjective. This structure can be used with almost any adjective, whether it is positive or negative. Each part of this grammar point represents the following: (A) - A group. (B) - A single thing/person within that group. (C) - An adjective, or general description of that thing/person. This expression is also frequently used with demonstratives such as この and その. The construction '(A) の中(なか)で' is regularly translated by itself as 'among (A)', and may be used in many different expressions. This will be covered in a separate grammar point.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 食べ物の中で寿司が一番好き。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Out of all foods, I like sushi best. (Sushi is the number 1 liked food)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 授業の中で理科が一番嫌いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Out of all classes, I don't like science the most. (Science is the number 1 hated class)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この中でどれが一番好き？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Out of all of this, which one do you like best?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その中ではクッキーが一番美味しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Out of those, the cookie is the most delicious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この中で一番好きな 食べ物は何？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Among these, what is your number one favorite food?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 中華料理の中で何が一番好きですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Out of all Chinese dishes, what is your number one favorite dish?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 飲み物の中で一番好きなのは何ですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Out of all drinks, what is your number one favorite drink?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お茶の中で一番美味しいのは何ですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Out of all teas, what is the number one most delicious tea?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 国の中で一番人口が多いのはどれですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Out of all countries, which country has the number one largest population?

Name: より～の方(ほう)が
Meaning: To be more ~ than ~
About: より～のほうが can be thought of as similar to the grammar points たほうがいい, and ないほうがいい, in that it expresses that one thing is the 'better (A)', or 'more (A)'. However, unlike ほうがいい based expressions, any pair of adjectives, verbs, or nouns may be compared in this construction, so long as のほうが is followed by an adjective. より translates roughly to 'than', or 'rather than' in this phrase. From the examples listed here, we can see that より will always appear after the word that has the lower extent of (A), when used together with のほうが.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田舎に住むより、都会の方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Living in the city is better than living in the countryside.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女より、私の方が背が高い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am taller than my girlfriend.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 映画は怖いより、面白い方が好き。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like funny movies more than scary movies.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これがより高い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is more expensive. (Compared to other things in general)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 給料がいい仕事より、楽しい仕事の方をしたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to do a job that is fun, more than a job that pays better. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この小さいテレビより、その大きいテレビの方を欲しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want that big TV rather than this small TV. (Natural Japanese, but が is more common)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このパンよりそのパンのほうが美味しいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That bread is more delicious than this bread.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: バスケットボールよりサッカーのほうが好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like soccer more than basketball.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ユキよりリュウトのほうが賢い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Ryuto is smarter than Yuki.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 月曜日より、日曜日のほうが好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like Sunday more than Monday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あそこの 公園より、家に近い公園のほうが広い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The park near my house is more spacious than that park over there.

Name: 何(なに) + か
Meaning: Something, Nothing, Anything, Not anything, Some kind of, Not any kind of
About: 何(なに)か and 何(なに)も are constructions that are used in Japanese for expressing 'something', 'anything', or 'nothing'. The main difference between the two being that 何(なに)も is used with negative phrases (phrases that use ない or ありません), while 何(なに)か is used in other cases. To use this expression, we simply need to put 何(なに)か or 何(なに)も before the desired phrase.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何か食べますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you want to eat something?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫の中には何もないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is nothing inside the refrigerator.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なにか食べる？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Do you want to eat something?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私がなにか嫌なことをしましたか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Did I do something you didn't like?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いいえ、なにもしていませんよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No, I didn't do anything (wrong).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本に行って、なにか食べたいものがありますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When you go to Japan, is there something that you want to eat?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 頑張って勉強したけどなにもわからない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I studied diligently, but I don't understand anything.

Name: 誰(だれ)か
Meaning: Someone, Somewhere, Not anyone, Not anywhere
About: The constructions 誰(だれ)か, and どこか are used when you want to ask, or answer questions about 'someone', or 'somewhere' (positive sentences). Alternatively, 'no one', or 'nowhere' based statements are made with 誰(だれ)も, and どこも (negative sentences). Structures like this that use 誰(だれ) were briefly discussed in the 誰(だれ) grammar point. Using 誰(だれ), or どこ is not limited to the か and も particles. へ, に, or と may also be partnered with か or も, to give a more specific meaning. As can be seen with these examples, か will always precede any other particle in a positive sentence. However, the opposite is true for も. も will always follow any other particles in negative sentences. This is because か will always attach directly to the noun (when altering the meaning of that noun), but も alters the whole phrase, not just the noun. However, It should be noted that も is not limited to appearing in negative sentences, as can be seen with the final example.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰かがいますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is anyone here?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来月はどこかへ行きますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are you going somewhere next month?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺の誕生日パーティーには誰も来なかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No one came to my birthday party.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ９時だからどこも開いていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since it is 9pm, nowhere is open.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 休みの日はどこかへ行きましたか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Did you go anywhere during your break?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰かに言った？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Did you tell anyone? (Literally, 'did you tell it to anyone?')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰かと電話をしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is on the phone with someone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日はどこへも行かない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I won't go anywhere today. (Not even anywhere)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は誰にも会わない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will not meet anyone tomorrow. (Not even anyone)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は誰にも話す。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I talk to anyone. (Even anyone, but less common than でも)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「どこかに友達がいるのですか。」
「どこにもいません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Do you have friends somewhere?'
'I don't have friends anywhere.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「誰かにそのことを言いましたか。」
「いいえ、誰にも言っていません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Did you tell someone about that?'
'No, I didn't tell anyone.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「どこかにあるでしょう。」
「どこにもありませんよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'It is probably somewhere.'
'It is not anywhere (I'm telling you).'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「紙を誰かに渡しましたか。」
「誰にも渡していません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Did you hand off the paper to someone?'
'I did not hand off the paper to anyone.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「どこかへ出かけますか。」
「どこへも行きたくないよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Do you want to go somewhere?'
'I don't want to go anywhere, man.'

Name: ましょう
Meaning: Let's, Shall we (Polite volitional)
About: ましょう is one of the conjugations of the auxiliary verb ます, and is a common (polite) way to suggest that something be done 'together' (when used with a verb). It is often translated as 'let's (A)', or 'shall we (A)?'. To use ましょう, we will simply need to change ます to ましょう, when conjugating the verb. Despite regularly being translated as 'shall we (A)?', ましょう does not specifically target another person, and can also be used as a declaration that (A) will be done/needs to be done. This use reflects the base meaning of ましょう, which is the polite volitional form (deliberately/purposefully doing something). In this example, the speaker is expressing to themselves that they 'will' do something, and are strongly resolved to make it happen (similar to 'I shall' in English).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: モールに行きましょう！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let's go to the mall!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 踊りましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Shall we dance? (Said with a rising tone to indicate that it is a question)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ５キロ痩せましょう！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will lose 5 kg! (I shall do it!)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サッカーをしましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's play soccer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このレストランで寿司を食べましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's eat sushi at this restaurant.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ごはんを食べましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's eat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: バスで行きましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's go by bus.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 難しい漢字を覚えましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's memorize difficult kanji.

Name: ましょうか
Meaning: Shall we, Shall I
About: As covered in our ましょう lesson, ましょう is one of the conjugations of the auxiliary verb ます, and is a common (polite) way to suggest that something be done 'together'. Adding the particle か to this expression simply changes the nuance from 'let's', to 'shall we?', and is more of a direct question than ましょう by itself. Like ましょう, this expression can be added to the ます stem form of any verb. One thing to note with these examples is that they are 'suggestions', not 'invitations'. In Japanese there is a slight difference between the two, in the same way that there is in English. If you want to invite someone to do something, the most natural way would be to use ませんか, a phrase that is similar to ましょうか. The difference here is that 'won't you do (A)?' has a stronger nuance of being a direct invitation, while ましょうか is closer to just 'let's do (A)!'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: レストランまで車で行きましょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Shall we go to the restaurant by car?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今夜走りましょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Shall we run tonight?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一緒にイタリアに行きませんか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Won't you go to Italy with me?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一緒にイタリアに行きましょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Shall we go to Italy?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語で話しましょうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Shall we speak in Japanese?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日ビーチに行きましょうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Shall we go to the beach tomorrow?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: インド料理を食べにいきましょうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Shall we go and eat Indian food?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ９時前に帰りましょうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Shall we go home before nine o'clock?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 図書館で勉強しましょうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Shall we study at the library?

Name: ませんか
Meaning: Won't you, Would you not, Why don't we
About: ませんか (or ないか more casually) is an expression that is used after verbs as an invitation. It basically translates to 'won't you do (A) with me?'. This expression is a little bit different to ましょうか, in that it sounds directly like an invitation to do (A). ましょうか tends to sound more like a suggestion that (A) should be done. It is recommended to use the ませんか version, as ないか would be a bit too casual to use with someone that you are not very close with (and is also technically not correct Japanese). To make it clearer that the speaker wants to do (A) 'with' someone, expressions like 一緒(いっしょ)に 'together' are often added, for clarification. To examine the difference between ましょうか and ませんか, let's have a look at how the nuance changes in the same type of sentence. Here, ませんか will come across as an invitation due to the fact that you are asking the person if they 'wouldn't mind doing (A)' with you. This is the main reason that it is considered a more polite option when inviting someone to do something, than ましょうか.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は温泉に行きませんか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Won't you go to the onsen with me tomorrow? (Polite)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来週は釣りをしに行かないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Won't you go fishing with me next week? (Casual)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一緒にお祭りへ行きませんか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Won't you go to the festival with me?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ラーメンを食べに行きましょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Shall we go eat ramen?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ラーメンを食べに行きませんか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Won't you go eat ramen with me?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寿司を食べに行きませんか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Won't you go eat sushi (with me)?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サッカーをしませんか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Won't you play soccer (with me)?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一緒に文法を勉強しませんか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Won't you study grammar with me?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お風呂に一緒に入りませんか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Won't you take a bath with me?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 金曜日に、買い物に行きませんか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Won't you go shopping (with me) on Friday?

Name: ～てもいい (Verb)
Meaning: It's okay to, It's alright to, Can/may
About: Verb + てもいい is a construction in Japanese used to express that something is 'okay', or 'alright'. It can also be used as a question to ask if you 'can', or 'may' do something. This phrase is also regularly used without the も, but is considered a bit more direct/casual. It is best to remove the も only when talking to people that you know well. This expression is simply a construction that literally means て (verb) も (also) いい (is good).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その靴を買ってもいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's alright if you buy those shoes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この肉は食べてもいいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is okay to eat this meat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は家に行ってもいいですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is it okay if I go to your house tomorrow?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ペンを借りてもいいですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: May I borrow your pen?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これを見てもいい？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is it alright if I look at this?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 質問をしてもいい？
Questions.EnglishHTML: May I ask a question?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暑いです。水を飲んでもいいですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's hot. Is it alright to drink some water?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あそこで遊んでもいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You may play over there.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あそこでスポーツをしてもいいですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: May I play sports over there?

Name: ～て下(くだ)さい
Meaning: Please do (Polite request)
About: てください is a polite expression that is used for asking people to do something. It is most often translated as 'please do (A)'. ください is actually classified as honorific language, a type of polite speech that is used to refer to the actions of other people. くださる itself is the base form of this verb. While ください is exclusively used for making requests. くださる is the honorific language equivalent of くれる. In friendly conversation, ください can be omitted from this expression, and the て form itself can be used as a very casual way of saying 'please do (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 手を洗ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please wash your hands.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これを見てください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please look at this.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ちょっとテレビを消して。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hey, can you turn off the TV? (ちょっと is often used simply to get the attention of the listener)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: クッキーを作ったから食べて。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I made cookies, you can eat them.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この本を読んでください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please read this book.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食べてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please eat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: やめてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please stop.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このえんぴつを使ってください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please use this pencil.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここから、写真を撮ってください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please take the photo from here.

Name: ～ないで下(くだ)さい
Meaning: Please don't (Polite request)
About: ないでください is an expression that is used to politely ask someone 'not' to do something. It is a combination of the casual negative form of a verb, the で particle, and ください (the conjunctive form of くださる). ください is classified as honorific language, a type of polite speech that is used to refer to the actions of other people. The ください form of くださる is used almost exclusively for making requests. くださる is the honorific language equivalent of くれる. In friendly conversation, ください may be omitted from this expression, and the で form itself can be used as a very casual way of saying 'please don't do (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは誰にも言わないでください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please don't tell this to anyone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこには座らないでください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please don't sit there.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それ、お兄ちゃんのだから、食べないで。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because that's my older brother's, please don't eat it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 後で電話するから寝ないでよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I'm going to call you later, please don't sleep.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 行かないでください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please don't go.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここでサッカーをしないでください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please don't play soccer here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 泣かないでください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please don't cry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一人にしないでください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please don't leave me alone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それを食べないでください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please don't eat that.

Name: ～てはいけない
Meaning: Must not, May not
About: てはいけない is used in Japanese to express that (A) 'cannot', or 'must not' be done. It is the combination of a verb in て form, the は particle, and the negative potential form of 行(い)く (to be able to go). In this way, it literally means '(A) cannot/is not able to go'. Although は can be dropped from many phrases and expressions, the は in this particular grammar point is usually not. This is because いけない would then become the second action in a sequence of events (the usual function of て form). However, to make this more casual, ては is often changed to ちゃ (ては becomes ちゃ), or じゃ (では becomes じゃ), as this is easier to say.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タクシーの扉を自分で開けてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must not open the taxi door by yourself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供の前でタバコを吸ってはいけません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must not smoke cigarettes in front of children.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 危ない場所に行っちゃいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must not go to dangerous places.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 旗を踏んじゃいけないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must not step on a flag.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そこに入ってはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You must not go in there.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: クジラを食べてはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We must not eat whale.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このビルに入ってはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You must not go into this building.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 晩ごはんの前に、お菓子を食べてはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You must not eat candy before dinner.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この池で泳いではいけません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You must not swim in this pond.

Name: なくてはいけない
Meaning: Must do, Have to do
About: Much like てはいけない, なくてはいけない states that something 'must not' be done. However, this is where the similarities end. なくてはいけない is an example of a double negative in Japanese, and actually has the meaning '(A) must be done', or 'must do (A)'. While this grammar point is usually translated as 'must do', the literal translation is 'must not, not do (A)'. This double 'not' is where many learners have difficulties. いけない simply means 'cannot go', and comes from the negative potential form of 行(い)く. To use this structure, simply create the negative form of a verb, and then convert ない to なく (the conjunctive form of an い-Adjective), followed by て. After this, は is added, and then finally いけない. いけない is considered to be the most common structure used with the 'must', and 'must not' grammar points, and is natural in both speech, and written Japanese. Alternatively, ならない may be used in formal speech, but is much better suited to writing. だめ is also acceptable, but much more casual than either いけない or ならない.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は９時に寝なくてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today, I must sleep at 9. (I must not, not do it)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は彼女の誕生日プレゼントを買わなくてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I must buy my girlfriend's birthday present tomorrow. (I must not, not do it)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は友達が来るから、家の掃除をしなくてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since my friend is coming tomorrow, I must clean my house. (I must not, not do it)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 朝食後に薬を飲まなくてはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After breakfast, I must drink my medicine.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 野菜も食べなくてはダメだよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must also eat vegetables.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 土曜日も会社に行かなくちゃいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I gotta go to the company on Saturdays too.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日はスーパーに行かなくちゃ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today, I gotta go to the supermarket.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テストの前に、よく寝なくてはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Before a test, you must sleep well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １２月になってから、暖房をつけなくてはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once December comes, you have to turn on the heating.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 来週は試合があるので、たくさん練習しなくてはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I have a game next week, I must train a lot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日はいい天気だから、外で遊ばなくてはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because the weather is nice today, I have to play outside.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まだやりたいことがあるけど、もう寝なくてはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are still things that I want to do, but I have to sleep already.

Name: なくてはならない
Meaning: Must do, Have to do
About: Much like てはならない, なくてはならない states that something 'must not' be done. However, this is where the similarities end. なくてはならない is an example of a double negative in Japanese, and actually has the meaning '(A) must be done', or 'must do (A)'. While this grammar point is usually translated as 'must do', the literal translation is 'must not, not do (A)'. This double 'not' is where many learners have difficulties. ならない simply means 'cannot become', and comes from the negative form of なる. To use this structure, simply create the negative form of a verb, and then convert ない to なく (the conjunctive form of an い-Adjective), followed by て. After this, は is added, and then finally ならない. ならない is considered to be the most formal structure out of ならない, いけない, and だめ. It is regularly used in formal writing, or semi-formal/formal speech. いけない (the most common variation) and だめ (the most casual variation) are also acceptable in many situations.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は次のバス停で降りなくてはならないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have to get off at the next bus stop. (I must not, not do it)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムはタカにお金を返さなくてはならないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tom must give back money to Taka. (He must not, not do it)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は漢字の勉強をしなくてはならないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have to study kanji today. (I must not, not do it)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: レポートを書かなくてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I must write a paper.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 食べる前に手を洗わなくてはダメ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must wash your hands before you eat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は沢山走ったからシャワーを浴びなくちゃならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I ran a lot today, I must take a shower.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: バーベキューに肉を持って行かなくちゃいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I gotta bring meat to the barbeque.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冬になる前にキャンプに行かなくちゃだめだね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We gotta go camping before it becomes winter, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 毎日勉強をしなくてはならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You must do your studies every day.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ３時半までに、銀行に行かなくてはならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: By 3:30, I have to go to the bank.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう二時ですか！まだお弁当食べてないです。食べなくてはならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's already two?! I haven't eaten my bento yet. I have to eat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 京都で電車を降りなくてはならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I must get off the train in Kyoto.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君が決めなくてはならないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You have to decide.

Name: ～た方(ほう)がいい
Meaning: It'd be better to, Should do
About: In Japanese, there are several ways to express that something 'should' be done. たほうがいい is one of the most common, especially when giving advice. This expression uses the past tense of a verb grouped with 方(ほう), the particle が, and the い-Adjective, いい. As 方(ほう) can be translated closely to 'way', or 'direction', this expression is suggesting that one specific choice is simply the better 'way'. This expression is quite direct, and can imply that there may be some sort of negative consequence if (A) is not done. In that respect, this phrase could also be translated as 'It would be better if you did (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 食べる前に手を洗った方がいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would be better if you washed your hands before you eat. (You should wash your hands)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 警察に言った方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would be better if you told the police. (You should tell the police)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高いけど、美味しいお肉を食べる方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though it is expensive, it is better to eat delicious meat. (This is a general opinion)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 食器はすぐ片付ける方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is better to put away the dishes as soon as possible. (This is a general opinion)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お医者さんに聞いたほうがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be better to ask a doctor.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 帰ったほうがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It'd be better to go home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 朝ごはんを食べたほうがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be better to eat breakfast.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自分の皿を洗ったほうがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be better to wash your own dishes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは返したほうがいいだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be better to return that, wouldn't it.

Name: ない方(ほう)がいい
Meaning: It'd be better not to, Shouldn't do
About: Like たほうがいい, ないほうがいい is used in Japanese for giving advice. However, this expression suggests that it is better 'not' to do something. This phrase is constructed by using the negative form of a verb grouped with 方(ほう), the particle が, and the い-Adjective, いい. As 方(ほう) can be translated closely to 'way', or 'direction', this expression is suggesting that one specific choice is simply the better 'way'. This expression is quite direct, and can imply that there may be some sort of negative consequence if the (A) verb is done.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あそこは危ないから、行かない方がいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because that place over there is dangerous, it would be better not to go there.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは触らない方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would be better not to mess with that. (触（さわ）る has the nuance of 'mess around with', whereas 触（ふ）れる is closer to simply 'touch')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 虫が入ってくるから、窓を開けない方がいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because bugs will come in, it would be better not to open the window. (The negative consequence is that bugs will come inside)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その肉を食べないほうがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It'd be better not to eat that meat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: タバコを吸わないほうがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be better not to smoke cigarettes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 汚れないほうがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be better not to get dirty.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一人で行かないほうがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be better not to go alone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 毎日肉を食べないほうがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be better not to eat meat every day.

Name: なくちゃ・なきゃ
Meaning: Must do, Have to do
About: なくちゃ (short for なくては), and なきゃ (short for なければ) are the most common colloquial abbreviations used to convey that something 'must', or 'has to' be done. Like てはいけない (must not), なくてはいけない (must), and なくてはならない (must), these abbreviation forms can be followed by いけない, ならない, or だめ. However, they are usually omitted, without changing the meaning. Structures like this are referred to as spoken/colloquial language. These casual variations can come across in a very similar way to words like 'gotta' in English. In these examples, a variety of forms have been used naturally. There is no 'most natural' form, and it will often depend on the speaker as to which they choose. As with almost all grammatical structures, the shortest variations (not including いけない, etc.) are the most casual/used the most often. There are several other ways that these common abbreviations can appear based on region, or even an individual speaker's preference. An example of this is なけりゃ, which is a (very) casual form of なければ. In this example, we can see that some of these less common variations are used specifically by certain genders (in general). なけりゃ itself tends to be used by male speakers, and may be considered a bit rougher than なきゃ, or なくちゃ, which can be used by anybody.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は家の掃除をしなきゃだめだから、遊ばない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I must tidy up the house today, I won't hang out.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 野菜を食べなくちゃいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I must eat vegetables.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あっ、洗濯をしなきゃ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Oops, I gotta do laundry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 宿題をしなくちゃ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I gotta do my homework.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前がやらなけりゃだめだろ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must do it! (Why aren't you doing what you must do?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語を勉強しなくちゃいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You must study Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暑いので水を飲まなきゃいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since it is hot, you must drink water.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もっと文法を勉強しなくちゃいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I must study more grammar.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 買いに行かなきゃいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I must go shopping.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日テストだから、もっと勉強しなくちゃいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since there is a test tomorrow I must study more.

Name: や
Meaning: Things like, And the like
About: や is a particle that has several different roles in Japanese, with the most common being as an adverbial particle. や is used similarly to と as 'and', but rather than listing specific things in a group, it lists 'things like (A)'. や is always used to group nouns, and simply comes directly after them. To compare how と and や are different, imagine that there is a bowl of fruit. In this bowl there are apples, oranges, and peaches. If と is used to list the apples and oranges, it would give the listener the impression that there are no peaches. This is called an 'exhaustive' list, meaning that all possibilities should be listed. However, if や is used, the listener would know that there are other things in the bowl apart from the apples and oranges. In this way, や is a better choice when you want to say 'and', but don't want to limit the group that you are listing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このスーパーには果物や弁当がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This super market has things like fruit and bentos.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 飛行機や船は大きいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Things like planes and ships are big.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日の飲み会でビールとワインを飲んだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Last night at the party, I drank beer and wine. (Only beer and wine)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日の飲み会でビールやワインを飲んだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Last night at the party, I drank things like beer and wine. (There were other things, but it was mainly beer and wine)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コンビニでお水やおかしを買った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I bought things like water and snacks at the convenience store.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ひらがなやカタカナや漢字があります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are things like Hiragana and Katakana and Kanji.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 京都や東京や大阪に行きました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I went to places like Kyoto and Tokyo and Osaka.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サッカーやテニスをするのが好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like playing sports like soccer and tennis.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 果物や野菜を食べてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please eat things like fruits and vegetables.

Name: ～たことがある
Meaning: Have done before
About: たことがある is a set expression in Japanese that is used for saying that 'there has been a time that I have done (A)'. The auxiliary verb た will be added to the verb indicating what you have done, followed by こと - が - ある. Like の, こと is regularly used for nominalization (creating a noun-like phrase). However, の cannot replace こと in this particular grammar pattern. From these examples, we can see that ない (the negative equivalent of ある) may also be used, when you want to express that you have 'never' done something.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 富士山へ行ったことがある？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Have you ever been to Mt. Fuji before?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はお菓子を買ったことが無い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have never bought snacks.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は踊ることができる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He can do things like dance.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来週は休みだから旅行へ行くことにする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I have no work next week, I have decided to go traveling.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は帰るのが遅くなることになる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today, I will end up coming home late.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここでサッカーをしたことがありますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Have you ever played soccer here before?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本に行ったことがありますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Have you ever been to Japan before?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この本を読んだことがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have read this book before.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の家を見たことがありますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Have you ever seen my house before?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ６時前に起きたことがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have never woken up before six o'clock.

Name: ～ている ③
Meaning: Has/have done, Is ~ing (Repetition)
About: The 3rd most common meaning (in no specific order) that ている is used for in Japanese, is the repetition of common activities. This is for things that are not 'continuing', but happen so often that they are considered to be continuous (like going to work, having a hobby, and similar things). Due to いる being one of the verbs for 'existing' in Japanese, the ている form is closer to 'continuing to exist in a specific state', rather than (A)~ing in English. In this construction, it can be thought of as 'to be existing in the state of performing a regular activity'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は毎日ギターを弾いている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I play my guitar everyday. (This is a hobby of the speaker)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎晩９時に寝ている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I sleep at 9 every night. (This is a habit of the speaker)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は学校で働いている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He works at a school. (This is a regular activity for him)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺、毎日勉強しとる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I study every day.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 俺は毎週金曜日の夜にスーパーに行っているのだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I go to the supermarket every Friday night. (I am going...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ふうたろうさんは毎日みくさんと一緒に歴史を勉強している。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Fuutarou-san studies history every day with Miku. (Fuutarou-san is studying...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 魔王さまはバーガークイーンで働いています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The Demon Lord works at Burger Queen. (The Demon Lord is working...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この公園では毎週末多くの人が走っています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Many people run in this park every weekend. (Many people are running...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうしてスティーブンはいつも黒いタートルネックを着ているのですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Why does Steven always wear a black turtleneck? (is wearing)

Name: ～て (Adjectives and Nouns)
Meaning: And... (Conjunctive)
About: The て form of an い-Adjective, or で form of a noun (or な-Adjective) is exactly the same as the て form of a verb, in that it carries the meaning of 'and', and is used for linking. It will allow us to list multiple qualities/traits of something. For い-Adjectives, we will need to change the last い to く (the form used for conjugation), and then simply add て. For nouns and な-Adjectives, we will need to add で to the base form (not な or だ). It should be noted that て and で are different structures here. て is the same conjunction particle that is used with verbs (meaning that い-Adjectives are similar to verbs), while で is actually a form of だ that is used for conjugation. It is the same で as the one that is used in the formal version of だ, である. Which we will learn later.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このパソコンは新しくて早い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This computer is new and fast.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの自転車は便利で軽い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That bicycle is useful and light.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 音楽を作るのは仕事で趣味だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Making music is both work, and my hobby.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は綺麗で優しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person is beautiful and nice.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大雨でバスが止まりました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The bus stopped with rain. (With rain as the reason)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はご飯を急いで食べる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I eat food in a hurry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新しい → 新しくて
Questions.EnglishHTML: New → New and...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大きい → 大きくて
Questions.EnglishHTML: Big → Big and...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嫌い → 嫌いで
Questions.EnglishHTML: Dislike → Dislike and...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 静か → 静かで
Questions.EnglishHTML: Quiet → Quiet and...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 病気 → 病気で
Questions.EnglishHTML: Disease → Disease and...

Name: ～て (Qualities and States)
Meaning: And..., Both and (Conjunctive)
About: The て form of an い-Adjective, or で form of a noun (or な-Adjective) is exactly the same as the て form of a verb, in that it carries the meaning of 'and', and is used for linking. Building on from the adjective +て, noun + で grammar point, instead of linking adjectives, adjective + て + (B) is used for linking an adjective to an entire phrase. With this construction, the phrase is simply added after て (with い-Adjectives), or で (with nouns and な-Adjectives), without any extra consideration for the phrase following it (this means that the (B) phrase will behave as if it was its own sentence). As with adjective +て, noun + で, it should be noted that て and で are different structures here. て is the same conjunction particle that is used with verbs (meaning that い-Adjectives are similar to verbs), while で is actually a form of だ that is used for conjugation. It is the same で as the one that is used in the formal version of だ, である. Which we will learn later.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんの犬は大きくて遊ぶのが好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san's dog is big and likes playing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: マサミは綺麗で水泳が趣味です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Masami is beautiful, and swimming is her hobby.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トミーは漫画家でたまに学校で国語を教えている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tommy is a cartoonist, and occasionally teaches the national language at school.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このスマホは新しくて速い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This phone is new and fast. (Linking)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このアイスクリームは甘くて美味しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This ice cream is delicious because it is sweet. (Reasons)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 声を出して話してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please project when you speak. (Manner)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: りさは背が高くてかわいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Risa is tall and cute.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 静かで平和なところに住みたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to live in a quiet and peaceful place.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ほろさんは親切で優しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Holo is kind and gentle.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「ルフィさんは明るくていい人ですよね。」
「そうですよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Luffy is a bright and good-natured person, isn't he?'
'That's right.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新田さんは悲しくて寂しかったんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Nitta was (used to be) sad and lonely.

Name: のが下手(へた)
Meaning: To be bad at, Poor at, Unskillful
About: ～のが下手(へた) is a phrase that behaves in almost exactly the same way as ～のが上手(じょうず), but rather than meaning 'to be good at (A)', it means 'to be bad at (A)', (which is a much more handy expression, if you are like me!). This particular expression is used with the plain (dictionary) form of verbs only. In these examples, we can see that there is no difference between Ichidan verbs and Godan verbs. Both will appear in their plain form. In this expression, のが is performing the same function as in the regular のは, and のが constructions. This function is nominalization (turning a phrase into a noun).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は漢字を教えるのが下手。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am bad at teaching kanji.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は運転するのが下手です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is bad at driving.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 去年まで料理をするのが下手だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Until last year, I was bad at cooking.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私はチェスをするのがへただ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm bad at chess. (unskillful)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: カタカナを覚えるのがへた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm poor at remembering Katakana. (unskillful)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サッカーをするのがへたです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm bad at playing soccer. (unskillful)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は勉強するのがへた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She is bad at studying. (unskillful)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は漢字を書くのがへた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is bad at writing kanji. (unskillful)

Name: のが上手(じょうず)
Meaning: To be good at, Proficient
About: ～のが上手(じょうず) is a phrase that behaves in almost exactly the same way as ～のが好(す)き, but rather than meaning 'to like' something, it means 'to be good at' something. This particular expression is used with the plain (dictionary) form of verbs only. In these examples, we can see that there is no difference between Ichidan verbs and Godan   verbs. Both will appear in their plain form. In this expression, のが is performing the same function as in the regular のは・のが construction. This function is nominalization (turning a phrase into a noun).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は漢字を覚えるのが上手です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She is good at memorizing kanji.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は歌うのが上手です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is good at singing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お母さんは若い頃、踊るのが上手だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When my mother was young, she was good at dancing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 歌うのが上手です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am good at singing. (Like, how am I not famous)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 歌うのが得意です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am good at singing. (I have confidence in my singing)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムはサッカーをするのが上手です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tom is good at playing soccer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 漢字を覚えるのが上手。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (He) is good at remembering Kanji.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は漢字を書くのが上手でしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is good at writing kanji, isn't he?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は、料理をするのが上手です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She is good at cooking.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は歌うのが上手。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She is good at singing.

Name: (Adjective) + のは
Meaning: The 'one' that... (Indefinite pronoun, Adjective nominalization)
About: One of the roles that the particle の can take in Japanese is replacing a noun that has already been mentioned, or one that has not been mentioned yet. In this way, it is similar to 'the one that (A)' in English. When using this expression, we will need to use な before の, when a な-Adjective is being used. When using this expression, の will be followed by は, が, or も, depending on what the speaker/writer wants to express.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 可愛いのは私の犬です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The one that is cute is my dog.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 心配なのはあなたです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The one that is to be worried about is you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 安いのはあのペンだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The one that is cheap is that pen. (Without much consideration for other things)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 熱いのがこれです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is the one that is hot. (Specifically highlighting one thing out of several)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冷たいのも好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I also like the one that is cold.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここにある車の中で好きなのはあの赤いの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Out of the cars that are here, the one that I like is that red one over there.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新しいのは彼の車だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The one that is new is his car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 元気なのは社長です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The one that is energetic is the manager.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 難しいのは歴史だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The one that is difficult is history.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女が素敵なのは服だけだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The only (one) thing that is great about her is her clothes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暑いのも好きだから、エアコンがなくてもいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I also like the heat, so it's alright if I don't have an air conditioner.

Name: あげる
Meaning: To give (away), To present, To provide
About: あげる is a verb with many uses in Japanese. It's original meaning is 'to raise', but is also used as a polite speech way of saying 'to give'. In this way it can be thought of as similar to 'to offer up' in English. As polite speech has the same basic subject and object rules as standard speech, the giver will be marked with は or が, while the recipient will be marked with に. As usual, the 'object' that is being given will be marked with を. From these three examples, we can see that the order of 'giver', 'recipient', and 'object' does not matter, so long as the correct particles are used.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムがタカにプレゼントをあげる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tom will give Taka a present.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タカにトムがプレゼントをあげる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tom will give Taka a present.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムがプレゼントをタカにあげる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tom will give Taka a present.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このペンをお前にやるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will give you this pen. (This pen is all yours)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このペンをお前にあげるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will give you this pen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その傘をあげます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will give you that umbrella. (away)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は弟に飲み物をあげた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I gave my little brother a drink. (away)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 宝箱の鍵をあげます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will give you a key to a treasure chest. (away)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 紙をあげるのでメモして。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since I will give you some paper, take some notes. (away)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼にスマホをあげましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's give him a smartphone! (away)

Name: くれる
Meaning: To give (me), To be given
About: くれる is generally taught as part of a set of 3 verbs that are regularly used for giving and receiving in Japanese. These verbs are くれる, あげる, and もらう. くれる means 'to give' (to you, or someone that is part of your 'in' group). With くれる and あげる, they both function in the regular way you would expect (regarding particles). This means that が will always mark the giver (the person performing the action), and に will mark the recipient (the person that is the 'destination' of the thing that is given). This means that を will be used to mark the 'object' that is given, as is usually the case. The giver/recipient are often omitted from sentences with くれる, as one/both are usually obvious from context, or the sentence may be focusing on the object. As can be seen here, the same nuance is kept, even when things are omitted.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: おばあちゃんはいつもお菓子をくれる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My grandmother always gives me candy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎年、彼女が手紙をくれる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every year, my girlfriend gives me a letter.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 母は毎日私にクッキーをくれる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My mother gives me cookies everyday.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 嫁がプレゼントをくれた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My wife gave me a present.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私にプレゼントをくれた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A present was given to me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 近所の人が旅行から帰って来て、父にお土産をくれた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When the neighbors return home from traveling, they give my father souvenirs.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生がクラブ仲間のとしこちゃんに花をくれた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The teacher gave flowers to my club member, Toshiko-chan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 母は僕にかっこいいペンをくれた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My mom gave me a cool pen. (I was given)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 兄は(私に)便利な箱をくれた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My brother gave me a convenient box. (I was given)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: おじいちゃんは(私に)古い自転車をくれた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My grandpa gave me an old bicycle. (I was given)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼が(私に)かわいい靴をくれて、嬉しいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He gave me some cute shoes, so I am happy. (I was given)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達は毎週土曜日に私の母にクッキーをくれる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My friend gives my mom cookies every Saturday. (My mom is given)

Name: 貰(もら)う
Meaning: To receive, To get, To obtain
About: もらう is the 3rd verb that is regularly taught together with くれる, and あげる. It is used to highlight that (A) is 'received' by someone. However, unlike くれる and あげる (which are used to highlight that something is 'given'), もらう requires the に particle (or から) to mark the giver, not the recipient. が or は may be used to mark the recipient, as they are the one performing the action of receiving. を will mark the object that is being given. In the second sentence we can see that the recipient has been omitted, while in the third example, the giver was omitted. This is a regular occurrence when using もらう, as the receiver is usually obvious, or the 'giver' may not be important to the overall meaning of the sentence. In this example, the thing that was given is the focus, while the speaker does not consider the 'giver' something that needs to be mentioned. Sometimes, for very simple sentences with clear context, neither the 'giver', nor the 'receiver' needs to be mentioned.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はお正月におばあちゃんからお金をもらいました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For New Years, I received money from my grandmother.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女に手作りのケーキをもらった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: (I) received a homemade cake from my girlfriend.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: (私は)今日は学校でチョコレートをもらった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I received chocolate at school today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 駅でティッシュをもらったけど欲しい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I received some tissues at the station, but do you want them?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これをもらった！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I got this!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私はお祖母さんからおはしとコップをもらった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I received chopsticks and a glass from my grandmother.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女に(私は)青い花をもらいます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (I) receive blue flowers from her (my girlfriend).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: (私は)友達に暖かいセーターをもらった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (I) received a warm sweater from (my) friend.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 父から(私は)お金をもらった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (I) received money from my father.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: (私は)明後日給料をもらいます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (I) receive (my) salary the day after next.

Name: けれども
Meaning: But, Although
About: けれども is the more formal (full version) of the conjunction particle けど. Like けど, it usually carries the meaning of 'but', but because of its formality, sounds a bit more like 'although', or 'provided that'. It simply highlights that 'while thinking about (A), (B)'. Meaning that the (B) phrase is important, or needs to be considered. As can be seen from these examples, だ will be required when using this conjunction after a な-Adjective, or a noun. As a reminder, please see below for a list of the most casual form of 'but', to the most formal. Casual - けど - けども - けれど - けれども - が - Formal.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は１０キロ走ったけれども、疲れていません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I ran 10km, but I am not tired.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 温泉は熱いけれども、気持ちいいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Onsens are hot, but they feel good.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は綺麗だけれども、怖いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person is beautiful, but scary.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはゲームだけれども、面白くないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is a game, but it is not fun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このパソコンは古いけども、便利だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This computer is old, but useful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 薬を飲んだけれど、まだ頭が痛い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I took medicine, but my head still hurts.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 走るのは疲れるけれども、楽しいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Running is tiring, but it is fun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田舎は静かだが、やる事が無い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The countryside is quiet, but there is nothing to do.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もう晩ご飯食べたけれども。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I already ate dinner, but… (There's always room for dessert!)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私はこの本が好きではないけれども、あなたは好きでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't like this book, but you do, don't you?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムに言ったけれども、トムは忘れました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I told that to Tom, but he forgot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 掃除をしたけれども、まだ汚い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cleaned, but it is still dirty.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 映画を見るのは楽しいけれども、チケットが高い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Watching movies is fun, but tickets are expensive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電車は便利だけれども、いつも人が多い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The train is convenient, but there are always a lot of people.

Name: つもりだ
Meaning: To plan to, To intend to
About: つもりだ (or です) is a grammar point that can have several meanings in Japanese, but is often translated simply as 'intend to (A)', or 'plan to (A)'. It can be used after the plain (dictionary) form of verbs, or after the ない form. In the last two sentences, there is quite a large difference in nuance, and can be thought of as similar to the difference between 'to intend not to' ないつもり, and 'to have no intention of' つもりはない in English. The former will mean that (A) is being actively avoided, while the latter will indicate that one simply has no plans to (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そのピザは今日の昼に食べるつもりです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I intend to eat that pizza for lunch today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は学校に行かないつもりだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't intend to go to school today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は休みだから、早く起きるつもりはない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I have the day off tomorrow, I have no intention of waking up early.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは謝ってるつもり？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is that intended to be an apology? (Do you really think that is an apology?)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は先生と話すつもりがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't have any intention to talk to the teacher today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は何も買うつもりじゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't intend on buying anything today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本に行くつもりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I intend to go to Japan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語を勉強するつもりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I intend to study Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日早く起きるつもりです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I intend to wake up early tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 車で行くつもりです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I intend to go by car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スポーツが上手になるつもりだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I intended to become good at sports.

Name: でも
Meaning: Or something,  Any... (with question words), No matter (who)
About: でも is one of many adverbial particles in Japanese. These are particles that behave like a regular 助詞(じょし) (in that they appear after the words that they are referencing), but their role is a little bit more specific. でも itself has several uses, and the use that we will examine in this grammar point is called 例示(れいじ). Basically this means 'presenting examples'. In English, this results in a translation similar to 'even', or 'or something'. To use this structure, simply attach でも to the end of any noun, or  pronoun. When grouped with a standard noun as above, でも is just showing that the noun is an example/suggestion, and that there are other choices/possibilities available. However, when the noun is a word like 誰(だれ), どこ, 何(なん), or いつ, the translation becomes much closer to English words like 'anyone', 'anywhere', 'anything', or 'anytime'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お茶でも飲みましょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Shall we drink some tea, or something?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大丈夫だよ、お前でも出来るよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's okay, even someone like you can do it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この簡単な漢字は誰でも分かるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Everyone knows this easy kanji.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 「明日はどこに行きたい？」「どこでもいいよ。」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: 'Where do you want to go tomorrow?' 'Anywhere is fine.'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前は本当に何でも食べるね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You really do eat anything.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いつでも電話してね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please, call me anytime.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: スプーンでも缶詰が開く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A can will open, even with a spoon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どこでもいいよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Anywhere is good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつでも家に来てください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please come to my house anytime.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつでも電話に出るから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will answer the phone anytime.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつでも洗濯できますよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can do laundry anytime.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お茶でもどう？
Questions.EnglishHTML: How about tea or something?

Name: ～易(やす)い
Meaning: Easy to, Likely to
About: 易(やす)い is an い-Adjective that is regularly seen attached to the ます stem of verbs (the form of a verb that can be used as a noun). When attached in this way, it carries the meaning of 'easy to (A)', where (A) is the verb that comes before やすい. Sometimes, やすい has a translation that is a bit closer to 'prone to (A)', or 'likely to (A)' in English. This nuance is regularly seen when the verb is related to emotions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は食べやすいサイズにステーキを切る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will cut the steak into a size that's easy to eat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この漫画にはフリガナがついているから読みやすいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since this manga has furigana included, it's easy to read.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの先輩は怒りやすいからめんどくさい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That senpai is prone to getting angry, so he's annoying.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カスミちゃんは泣きやすいから優しくしてね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Kasumi is likely to cry, so please be nice to her. (Kasumi cries easily)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日やすいゲームを買った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Yesterday, I bought a cheap game. (安（やす）い meaning cheap, not 易（やす）い meaning easy)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は簡単なゲームが好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I enjoy easy games. (易（やす）い would not work here, as it is not usually used without a verb)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ケーキは作りやすい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Cake is easy to make.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この魚は食べやすいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This fish is easy to eat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昨日の練習はしやすかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Yesterday's practice was easy to do.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この白い服は、汚れやすいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: These white clothes are easy to get dirty.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この音楽が好きだから、踊りやすい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I like this music, it is easy to dance.

Name: にくい
Meaning: Difficult to, Hard to
About: Like 易(やす)い, にくい is an い-Adjective that is regularly attached to the ます stem of verbs. However, instead of meaning 'easy to (A)', it means 'difficult to (A)'. (A) will always represent the verb that comes before にくい. The nuance of にくい is that (A) is a task that is difficult to do, because of the required skill level, or similar factors. This is different from づらい, which focuses more on a task that is difficult due to being unbearable/hard to endure for some reason.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この駐車場は狭いから止めにくい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This parking lot is very cramped, so it is difficult to park.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は具合が悪いから呼吸がしにくい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I am not feeling well today, it is hard to breathe.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私には英語の「Literally」という単語がとても言いにくい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For me, the English word 'literally' is very hard to say. (Hard due to the individual's skill level)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前には本当に言いづらいけど、お前のギターを壊した。ごめん。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is very difficult for me to say to you, but I broke your guitar. I'm sorry. (Hard because the speaker knows that telling the listener will cause a negative response)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 甘くないケーキは、食べにくいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Cakes that aren't sweet are hard to eat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アフリカには行きにくいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is hard to go to Africa.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 怖いことはしにくいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is difficult to do scary things.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人とは話しにくいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person is hard to talk to. (Unapproachable)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このコップ、形が変だから飲みにくい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because this cup has a strange shape, it is hard to drink out of.

Name: 段々(だんだん)
Meaning: Gradually, Little by little, Step by step
About: だんだん is an adverb that is used to express the slight, but constant, progression of something. Originally, it comes from the kanji construction 段々(だんだん), which can be thought of as meaning 'step by step', 'stepwise', or even 'steadily'. だんだん is similar to ほとんど, in that it can modify the meaning of entire phrases, rather than just single words. To use だんだん, simply put it before the phrase that you want to express as '(A) that is increasing steadily'. While だんだん can take the particle と, it is not required. In fact, と is very often omitted from adverbs/onomatopoeic words (words that represent a sound or motion) in Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １２月になってからだんだん寒くなってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since December, it has gotten colder steadily.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: だんだん仕事の環境に慣れてきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have steadily gotten used to work's environment.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近はだんだんと暑くなってきたね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently it has progressively gotten hotter, right? (Slow progression)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: だんだん雨が降ってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is starting to rain. (Slow progression, does not imply great speed or severity)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんどん雨が降ってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is starting to rain. (Rapid progression, may imply great speed and/or severity)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先輩が後輩に話している：「大丈夫、だんだん上手になるよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A senpai speaking to their kouhai: 'Don't worry, you will become better gradually.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達が話している：「秋になったからこれからだんだん寒くなるよね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Friends talking: 'Autumn is here, so it will gradually become cooler, don't you think?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 英語の教師が生徒の親と話している、教師：「娘さんはだんだん英語がうまくなってきました。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: An English teacher talking with a student's parents, teacher: 'Your daughter has been gradually improving in speaking English.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達が話している：「だんだんとあのやつの事が嫌いになってきていて、今は避けるようにしている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between friends: 'I gradually came to dislike that guy, and now I do my best to avoid him.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お母さんが子供と話している：「あなたはだんだんおかしを食べたくなくなる。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A mother speaking with a child: 'You will gradually lose interest in sweets.'

Name: どんどん
Meaning: Progressively, Rapidly increasing, More and more
About: どんどん (or ドンドン) is one of the countless words in Japanese that represent a particular sound or sensation. These words are known as onomatopoeia (オノマトペ in Japanese). どんどん represents the sound of banging (like on a drum), or the pounding of feet. In this way, it is regularly translated as 'rapidly', or 'quickly'. Like だんだん, どんどん may be used before almost any phrase. While どんどん can take the particle と, it is not required. In fact, と is very often omitted from adverbs/onomatopoeic words in Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女が出来てからどんどんお金が減っていく。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I got a girlfriend, my cash has been rapidly decreasing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんどん頼んでね！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Quickly order! (Literally means 'more and more' in a sentence like this, with the nuance of 'don't hold back, order in rapid succession')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: バスの運転手がどんどんと減っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The number of bus drivers is rapidly decreasing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日ピアノを練習しているから、だんだんピアノが上手になってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I practice the piano everyday, I have steadily gotten better at playing. (Slow progression)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日ピアノを練習しているから、どんどんピアノが上手になってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I practice the piano everyday, I have rapidly gotten better at playing. (Rapid progression)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんどん暑くなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It will rapidly get warmer and warmer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんどん日本語が上手になりたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to progressively get better at Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本の人口がどんどん減る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The Japanese population will rapidly decrease.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 音がどんどん大きくなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The sound will get louder and louder.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女がどんどん綺麗になる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She will progressively get prettier.

Name: 等(ら)
Meaning: We, Them, They, These, Those
About: There are many prefixes and suffixes in Japanese that are used depending on what the speaker wants to highlight. ら is a suffix (component used after the main part of a word) that implies that there is 'more than one' of something. Due to this, ら is often called a 'pluralizing suffix'. ら comes from the same kanji as 等(など), and the literal meaning is closer to '(A) etc'. This 'etc' is where the implication of 'more than one' originates. To use ら, attach it to the end of any pronoun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼らは日本語を勉強しにきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They came in order to study Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前ら、アニメを見ないの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You guys don't watch anime?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼らは十分に勉強をしたから、試験が簡単だった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They studied sufficiently, so the test was easy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これらを捨ててください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Could you please toss these?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それらの畳はいい匂いがしている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Those tatami mats smell good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君ら池に入るつもり？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Do you all intend to go swimming in the pond?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 奴らはプロだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They are pros.

Name: ～ていく
Meaning: To ~ and go, To go on, To start
About: This grammar construction is a mix of the conjunction particle て, and the verb 行(い)く 'to go'. To use this grammar point, you will need to attach て to any verb, and then follow it with いく. This nuance is usually that '(A) happened and then went', or 'will happen, and then go'. In other words, it will depend on whether いく is in present, or past tense. ていく can be used when representing time, or when representing a physical place. When representing a physical place, it is more likely that the kanji structure, 行(い)く will be used. However, this is not a set rule, and depends on the writer. When used in relation to time, the nuance is usually that something has already started/is about to start, and then will continue to progress in the same way. This is the opposite of てくる, which indicates that something has finally reached a certain state, after progressing in that way for some time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日はうちで食べていく？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you want to go and eat at my place tonight? (Literally 'will you', but comes across more as an invitation in casual Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今晩は雨が降ると聞いたから、傘を持って行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I heard that it was going to rain tonight, I took an umbrella.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日ゴルフの練習をしたらだんだんと上手くなっていく。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When you practice golf everyday, you will gradually get better.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大きい音で、鳥が飛んでいく。
Questions.EnglishHTML: With a loud noise, the birds will fly away. (fly and go)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これを先生に持っていってください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please take this to the teacher. (hold and go)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達にプレゼントを買っていく。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am going to buy a present and take it to my friend. (buy and go)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大丈夫！お弁当を持っていくから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's okay! Because I will take a lunch (bento) with me. (hold and go)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日はテストを受けるから鉛筆を持っていく。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I am going to take a test today, I will take a pencil. (hold and go)

Name: ～てくる
Meaning: To come to, To become, To continue, To be starting to, Has been ~ing
About: This grammar point is a combination of the conjunction particle て, and the verb 来(く)る 'to come'. To use this grammar point, you will need to attach て to any verb, and then follow it with くる. This nuance is usually that '(A) happened, and then came', or 'will happen, and then come'. In other words, it will depend on whether くる is in present, or past tense. てくる can be used when representing time, or when representing a physical place. When representing a physical place, it is more likely that the kanji structure, 来(く)る will be used. However, this is not a set rule, and depends on the writer. When used in relation to time, the nuance is usually that something has already come to pass, or will start to happen from now. This is the opposite of ていく, which indicates that something will change from the way that it is now, or will continue progressing in a certain way.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日も宿題を持ってくるのを忘れた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I forgot to bring my homework today too. (To 'come with' homework was forgotten)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パパ〜、じゃが芋を買ってきたよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Dad, I bought the potatoes. (Bought and 'came with')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近、日本語が上手くなってきた感じがする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently I feel like I have come to be better at Japanese. (Very similar to 'gotten' in English)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: すぐ帰ってくるね？
Questions.EnglishHTML: You will come back home soon, right? (Literally - Return and come)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お金がなくなってきた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have started to lose money. (has become)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トイレに行ってきます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will go to the bathroom and come back.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お母さんに似てきたね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You have come to look like your mother.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お弁当を持ってきてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please bring a bento with you. (hold and come)

Name: 方(かた)
Meaning: Way of ~ing, How to ~, Manner of ~ing
About: When 方(かた) is attached to the ます stem of a verb, it carries the nuance of the 'way of doing (A)'. This is identical to 方(かた)'s standard meaning of 'way', or 'direction'. When used with する verbs, sometimes the construction 仕方(しかた) is seen. This has exactly the same meaning as the form without kanji, and may be thought of as meaning 'way of dealing/attending to (A)', as 仕(し)'s original meaning is 'to attend to (A)'. In these cases, the する verb is followed by の, and then 仕方(しかた).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何その食べ方、口を閉じてよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What is that way of eating? Please close your mouth.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ネクタイの結び方を弟に教える。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will teach my brother the way to tie a necktie. (How to do it)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 外国語の勉強の仕方が分からない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I do not know how to study a foreign language. (The way to do it)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩、ファックスの仕方を教えてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Senpai, can you teach me how to fax?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は高校の時に母から貯金の仕方を教わりました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I learned how to save money from my mother, when I was in highschool.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 引っ越し屋さんの家具の運び方を見て、彼らの体力にビックリした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After seeing the way the removalists were carrying the furniture, I was surprised by their strength.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の泳ぎかたは変だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: His way of swimming is strange.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お菓子の作りかたを学ぶ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will learn how to make sweets.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 文法の勉強のしかたを教えてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please teach me how to study grammar.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 妻はリモコンの使いかたが分からない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My wife doesn't know how to use the remote.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼のスパゲッティの食べかたは良くない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: His way of eating spaghetti is not good.

Name: だけで
Meaning: Just by, Just with
About: だけで is a combination of the adverbial particle だけ, and the case marking particleで. This expression is regularly thought of as meaning 'just by (A), (B)'. However, the literal translation is a bit closer to 'with only (A), (B)'. This reflects the で particle's standard usage of showing a 'tool' that is being used to achieve a certain result. To use だけで, simply attach it to the end of any (non ます) form of verb, or noun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女と話すだけで楽しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just talking with my girlfriend is fun. (We don't need to do anything else, because talking is fun enough)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは電子レンジだけでオーブンの機能はついていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is just a microwave, an oven function is not included.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パーティーに行くだけで楽しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just (by) going to a party is fun.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 顔を見ただけで、彼はいい人だと分かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I could tell he was a good person just by his face.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一緒に時間を過ごすだけで、仲良くなりました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We became good friends just by spending time together.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼を見ただけで性格が悪いと分かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just by looking at him I determined that he had a bad personality.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 家族と一緒に居るだけで、幸せ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just by being with my family I am happy.

Name: だが
