Meaning: But, Still, However, Nevertheless
About: While だが (or ですが as a polite equivalent) are classified as their own words, they are actually just combinations of だ, or です, and が. だが is usually used as a formal way of saying 'but', or 'nevertheless'. Due to this, we can see that だ is being used to 'determine' that a statement is true, while が simply shows that there is other important information to follow. In this way, だが is very similar to the expression 'that may be, but…' in English. だが may be used at the beginning of any phrase, or between sentences. To make だが sound a little bit softer, sometimes ね is added. However, this is not so common in modern-day Japanese, and is more limited to the older generation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は弁護士だが、頭が良くない、不思議だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is a lawyer, but he is not very smart… How odd.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 宝くじを１００枚買った。だが、当たらなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bought 100 lottery tickets. However, I didn't win.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 美容室に行ったのですが、高かったので帰りました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I went to the hair salon, but since it was expensive, I came home.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 君はいい人だと聞いた。だがね、まだ君を信用できない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have heard that you are a good person. However, I can't trust you yet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大統領が言いました。ですが、私は信じません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The president said that. However, I don't believe it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 毎日運動をしました。ですが、痩せていません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I exercised everyday. However, I haven't lost any weight.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 本当は私がしなくてはならない。だがね、君にしてほしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Really, it is I who has to do it. However, I want you to do it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これが基本ルールだ。だが、例外もある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a basic rule. However, there are also exceptions.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日から、旅行に行きます。ですが、まだチケットを買っていません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am going on a trip tomorrow. However, I still haven't bought my ticket.

Name: なくて (Sequence)
Meaning: To not ~ and ~, Not ~ and ~ (Conjugations)
About: In Japanese, なくて is a construction that combines ない (in its conjugation form, なく), with the conjunction particle て. This results in the same 'and' meaning as the standard て form, but with the negative meaning of ない. なくて can be translated as 'to not (A), and…', or 'not (A), and…', depending on what type of word it is used with. As discussed in our initial lesson about ない, there are two forms of this particular word. One form is an auxiliary verb, and is used with verbs. The other form of ない is an い-Adjective (形容詞(けいようし)), and is used with nouns, な-Adjectives, and い-Adjectives. The difference between these two, is that the い-Adjective form may have は in between it and the word it is connected to (では in the case of nouns and な-Adjectives). With verbs, due to ない being an auxiliary verb, this is not possible.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お金がなくて車が買えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't have money, and I can't buy a car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのケーキは甘くはなくてまずいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That cake is not sweet, and tastes bad. (は is frequently added between the stem form of adjectives and ない. Often, this is just for emphasis)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の車は静かではなくてガソリンの減りも早い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My car is not quiet, and runs out of gas quickly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あれは犬ではなくて猫でもないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is not a dog, and not a cat either.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この風呂は汚れはなくて、いつもいい匂いがする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This bath is not dirty, so it always smells good. (Unnatural Japanese, as は will never come between a verb and ない)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この風呂は汚れなくて、いつもいい匂いがする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This bath doesn't get dirty, and it always smells good. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トーマスにはまだプレゼントをあげないでね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please don't give Thomas his present yet. (No particular reason, simply implies 'without doing')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もらったクッキーを弟にあげなくて、妹にあげた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I did not give the cookie I got to my brother, but to my sister. (Implies a specific reason for not giving it to the brother)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なる → ならなくて
Questions.EnglishHTML: to become → to not become and...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嫌い → 嫌いではなくて
Questions.EnglishHTML: dislike → not dislike and...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 病気 → 病気じゃなくて
Questions.EnglishHTML: illness → not an illness and...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 高い → 高くなくて
Questions.EnglishHTML: expensive/tall → not expensive/tall and...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いい → よくなくて
Questions.EnglishHTML: good → not good and...

Name: なくて (Reasons and Causes)
Meaning: Not ~ and, Not so, Because not (Examples)
About: In Japanese, なくて is a construction that combines ない (in its conjugation form, なく), with the conjunction particle て. This results in the same 'and' meaning as the standard て form, but with the negative meaning of ない. なくて is often used when the phrase that comes before it is being highlighted as an example/reason for a specific result. In these situations, the translation is usually 'because not (A), (B)', or 'because I didn't (A), (B)'. When なくて is used in this way, it is often followed by the speaker's feelings (in the form of an adjective), verbs in the potential form, or something that is generally beyond the control of the speaker. It is due to this fact that the result is 'beyond control' that the translation becomes 'because'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたが来れなくて残念です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is unfortunate that you were not able to come. (Not being able to come is the reason that it was unfortunate)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は寒くはなくて暖かいから、今日はジャケットを着なくてもいいね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because it is not cold today, but warm, we don't have to wear our jackets, right? (Not being cold is the reason that it was hot)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このスマホは便利ではなくて残念だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since this smartphone is not useful, it's a letdown.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 虫歯ではなくて安心した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am relieved because it was not a cavity.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日は良く寝れなくて、疲れている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am tired because I did not sleep well yesterday.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は仕事がなくて嬉しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am happy because I don't have work tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 重病じゃなくてホッとした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was relieved because it wasn't a serious illness.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「お茶しか出さなくてすみません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I am sorry because I cannot serve you anything but tea.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「試験に合格したか分からなくて不安だね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I don't know if I passed the exam, and I am anxious.' ('I am anxious because I don't know if I passed the exam')

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「孫がまだきていなくて心配です。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'My grandchild hasn't come yet and I am worried.' ('I am worried because my grandchild hasn't come yet')

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼氏が子猫が好きじゃなくて、がっかりした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My boyfriend doesn't like kittens and I was let down. (I was let down because my boyfriend doesn't like kittens)

Name: ないで
Meaning: Without doing, Not ~ and ~
About: There are two primary ways in which ないで is used with verbs in Japanese. The first is to express 'without doing (A), (B)'. The second is to request that someone 'not do (A)'. We will examine the first in this write-up. ないで is a combination of the auxiliary verb ない, and the particle で. Due to this, で keeps its standard meaning of 'with/by', in relation to 'not' doing something. When ないで is used to express that '(A) has not been done before doing (B)', this is usually contrary to some kind of expectation. Because of this, ないで is often used to express something that may be surprising to the listener.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 魚を焼かないで食べたから、お腹を壊した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I ate fish without cooking it, I got a stomach ache. (Literally, to break one's stomach)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アミはドアのカギをかけないで寝るの？危ないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ami, you sleep without locking your doors? That's dangerous.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 上司に伝えないで休んだの！？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You took the day off without notifying your boss!?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昼ご飯を温めないで食べた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I ate my lunch without heating it up. (Event 2 happened without event 1)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: インターネットが繋がらなくて困ってる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am bothered because the internet isn't connecting. (Event 2 happened because of event 1)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 休まないで仕事をする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To work without taking a break.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「後悔しないで生きたい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I want to live without regret.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「あの人は便所から手を洗わないで出てきたんだよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'That person left the toilet without washing their hands!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夕食を食べないで、寝る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To go to bed without eating dinner.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「昨日、うちの娘は頭をぶつけたけど、泣かないで『大丈夫だよ』とだけ言ったんだ。本当に驚いた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Yesterday, my daughter hit her head, but without crying, she just said 'I'm fine.' I was really surprised.'

Name: れる・られる (Passive)
Meaning: Was done to ~ by ~, Done without consent, Done to one's dismay
About: In Japanese, there are several ways to express that something 'passively' happens. All of these are done with the auxiliary verbs れる and られる. Japanese verbs in the passive form behave in a slightly different way than they do in English, so we will examine this difference more closely later. For now, let's focus on れる, られる, and される (the form used with する verbs). Passivity in Japanese means that the person (or thing) that is the target of the action will be the subject of the sentence, rather than the person that is 'doing' whatever verb is being used. You can conjugate any Japanese verb into the passive form in the following way. For う-Verbs (godan verbs), simply replace the last kana with the equivalent あ sound kana from the same row (す becomes さ, つ becomes た, ぶ becomes ば, う becomes わ, like with ない, and so on), then add れる. For る-Verbs (ichidan verbs), just replace the る with られる. する and くる behave slightly differently than most other verbs. For する, it will become される, while くる will become こられる. As can be seen in these examples, the 'doer' of the verb will be marked with に, but から can also be used in cases where there is no physical contact with the subject.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犬に噛まれるのが怖いから、犬には近づけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I am afraid of getting bitten by a dog, I can't approach them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はいつも彼と比べられる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I always get compared to him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 知らない人からいたずらをされるのがきらい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't like being pranked by strangers.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 急に義理の母に来られると困る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I feel troubled when my mother in law visits unannounced.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はどこでも寝れます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can sleep anywhere. (I have the potential to sleep anywhere)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はどこでも寝られる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can sleep anywhere. (I have the potential to sleep anywhere)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私のアイスクリームを兄に食べられた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My ice cream was eaten by my brother.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 変な話を親に聞かれた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My strange conversation was overheard by my parents.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は部屋をきれいにして、褒められた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was praised for cleaning my room.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 宿題をしたけど、持って来るのを忘れた。何と言われるかな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though I did my homework, I forgot to bring it with me. I wonder what will be said to me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私はあいつらに何をされてもいいけど、あいつらには絶対に君の名前を教えない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It doesn't matter what is done to me by them, I won't give up your name to them.

Name: 他動詞(たどうし)・自動詞(じどうし)
Meaning: Done through action vs. occurring on its own
About: The two most fundamental divisions that can be made with Japanese verbs are transitive verbs - the subject is moving/acting upon something else, and intransitive verbs - the subject themself is moving/acting. Sometimes these terms are simplified even further to 'other-move' (transitive), and 'self-move' (intransitive). Basically, this is the difference between verbs that require an object marked with を (transitive verbs), and those that only require が, to show that the subject itself is moving (intransitive). In Japanese, there are many transitive/intransitive pairs of verbs, and these will need to be memorized.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ローソクを消す。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To put out a candle.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 風でローソクが消える。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For a candle to be put out by the wind.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 木からバナナ​​が落ちる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The banana fell from the tree.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 木からバナナを落とす。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To drop a banana from a tree.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来年からアメリカに住むことにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From next year I am going to live in America. (I have decided to live in America starting next year)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来年からアメリカに住むことになる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From next year I am going to live in America. (I will be living in America starting next year due to work/school/family matters beyond my direct control)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 虫を集めた・虫が集まった
Questions.EnglishHTML: I gathered bugs. The bugs gathered.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 探していたカバンを見つけた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I found the bag that I had been looking for.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 犯人が見つかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The criminal has been found.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ケーキの上に乗っていたロウソクを消した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I blew out (extinguished) the candles on the cake.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 台所のライトが消えた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The light in the kitchen went out.

Name: 直(なお)す
Meaning: To do over, To redo
About: 直(なお)す is a verb that means 'to fix', or 'to redo'. It is used when saying that something needs to be done a second time (usually due to the result/quality being insufficient the first time). To use 直(なお)す, it will need to be attached to the ます stem form of any verb. With する verbs, the conjugation rules are slightly different. する will become し, and then 直(なお)す will be connected in the regular fashion. In some situations, する may be replaced with やる (a very casual equivalent of する). As やる is a う-Verb, it will be conjugated as やり直(なお)す.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 髪がちゃんと染まってなかったので染め直します。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because my hair wasn't properly dyed, I will redo it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: フェンスを塗りなおす。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To repaint the fence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客様に挨拶をし直す。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To re-greet the customer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: プロポーズはやり直す事が出来ないから、緊張している。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because you can't redo proposals, I am nervous.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この文章を書き直した方がいいよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You should rewrite this sentence.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「お前」って言うな。言い直してください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Don't say 'おまえ'. Please rephrase what you said!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お客さんに電話を掛け直してください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please call the client again.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女のことを見直しました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I renewed my view of her.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: はい！急いでやり直します。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Yes, sir! I will quickly redo it.

Name: と言(い)う事(こと)
Meaning: ~ing, The ~ that ~ (Nominalization)
About: One of the ways to perform nominalization (turning a phrase into a noun) in Japanese is through the use of the expression ということ. This grammar point is a combination of と (the particle), 言(い)う (the verb), and こと (the noun). Together, the literal translation is close to 'that (A) is said to be'. However, in reality, it sounds far less formal than this. To use ということ, attach it to the end of any phrase (without です, or ます). In most cases it will be written using hiragana. In conversation, という is regularly shortened to simply って. This form will be heard/seen much more frequently in conversation/manga and similar things. ということ is also frequently used when clarifying what someone else has said. In these cases, it translates very similarly to 'you mean that (A)?', or 'you mean to say that (A)?'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 宇宙人はいるということですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Does that mean aliens exist?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一緒に住んでいるけど付き合ってはいないの？ルームメイトだということだよね？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are living together, but not dating? So that means they're your roommate, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの先生の教え方が酷いということを聞いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that the way that teacher teaches is harsh.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これが正しいってことですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Does that mean that this is correct?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車が壊れたの？電車でくるってこと？遅れないで来てね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Your car broke? Does that mean you are coming by train? Please don't be late.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは人工ってこと？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You mean that this is man made?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう別れたいという事？
Questions.EnglishHTML: It means that you want to break up? (Phrase to noun)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この店は美味しいという事をよく聞きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I often hear that this restaurant is delicious. (Phrase to noun)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私がみんなの分を払うという事ですか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Do you mean I should pay for everyone? (Phrase to noun)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 真面目になるという事ですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You mean that you will get serious? (Phrase to noun)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私が、一人でお皿を洗わなくてはいけないという事ですか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Do you mean that I have to wash the dishes all by myself? (Phrase to noun)

Name: 時(とき)
Meaning: When, At the time of
About: とき, or 時(とき) in kanji, is a noun that is regularly used to signify 'when' something happened (a verb). However, unlike some other time expressions, とき is mainly used to express things that happen at regular intervals (habits, hobbies, etc.), or at broad times/individual events (when it rains, when there is a sale at the shop, etc.) Using とき is quite easy! You just need to attach it to the end of any independent word (verbs, nouns, or adjectives). As with most cases where a noun will be attached to another word in Japanese, we will also be required to use な after な-Adjectives, and の after nouns. The case-marking particle に will generally come directly after 時(とき), signifying that another verb is about to follow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 狭い駐車場で車のドアを開けたときにドアを壁にぶつけた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I opened my car door in a small parking lot, I slammed it on the wall. (Individual event)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 暑い時はエアコンを点けましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When it is hot, let's turn on the air conditioner. (Broad time)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は暇なときに本を読みます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He reads books when he is bored. (Hobby)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 雨の時は家でゴロゴロしています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When it rains, I laze around in my house. (Habit)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 学校から家に帰った時に火曜日だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The time when I was going home from school was Tuesday. (Tuesday is a state, rather than an action, so とき will not be used to express something like this) (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺は高校生の時に俺が好きな女の子に告白して、「え、無理...」って言われた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I was in highschool I asked out a girl I liked, and she said 'umm, no way…' (時（とき） is describing the broad event of 'being a highschool student', while て goes on to describe another single event that happened during that time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 散歩をするときに音楽を聴く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I listen to music when I take a walk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 授業のときは静かにしなくてはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When you are having class, you have to be quiet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの映画を見たとき、泣いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When I watched that movie, I cried.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大変なときに彼の親は亡くなった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: His parents died when he was going through a difficult time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寒いときは、お風呂に入りたくなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When it is cold, I want to take a bath.

Name: まず
Meaning: To start with, Firstly
About: Like many other adverbs in Japanese, まず can be used to modify a whole phrase/sentence. This means that it will regularly appear at the beginning of a statement. まず is associated with kanji 先(まず) and therefore carries the meaning of 'first', or 'starting with'. まず is regularly used when you want to convey that something 'should' be done before anything else/discussed first, and not when something is first in rank.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まず宿題をしたほうがいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: First, it would be best for me to do my homework.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まずエンジンをかけて。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: First, please turn on the engine.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 赤い車がまず、ゴールをしました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The red car finished to start with. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まず別れた方がいいと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think you should break up first.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まず踊りに行きましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: First let's go dancing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まず壁を塗ってください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To start with, please paint the walls.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まずこれだよね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This one first right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まずこの部分を仕上げてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To start, finish this portion. (First)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まず買い物して、その後食べに行きましょうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: First let's go shopping then after that, shall we go out to eat?

Name: まで
Meaning: Even, To even, To the extent of
About: The adverbial particle まで is used in the same way as many other adverbial particles, in that it is highlighting that the statement that comes after it as important in some way. However, unlike our first look at まで, which discussed its use as 'until', this use of まで has the nuance of 'even', or 'to the extent'. Although using まで as 'even' may seem different to 'until', they are essentially the same thing in Japanese. This is because まで always means '(A) まで, (B)', where (A) is the 'limitation/extent', and (B) is the 'noteworthy factor'. This 'noteworthy factor' will usually be a descriptive word/phrase, such as a verb, adjective, or explanation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 隣街の店舗まで行ったけど、そこでもお目当てのグッズは売っていなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I went even to the store in the next town, but even there, the merchandise I was looking for wasn't being sold.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お腹が空きすぎて、大嫌いなバナナまで食べた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I was so hungry, I even ate a banana, which I hate.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: バイクまで持っているの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You even have a bike?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一回笑ったら、面白くない話までおかしくなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Once you start laughing, even uninteresting topics become funny.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はスポーツカーまでも持っています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I even have a sports car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こっちまでイライラしてきた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even I am starting to get annoyed. (to the extent・until)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それまでやらなくてはいけないの？
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have to even do that? (to the extent・until)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 頭まで痛くなってきた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even my head is starting to hurt. (to the extent・until)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夜中まで日本語の文法を勉強している。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm studying Japanese grammar until the middle of the night. (to the extent・until)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お腹が空いているとき、熊は果実まで食べる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Bears will even go as far as to eat berries when they are hungry. (to the extent・until)

Name: までに
Meaning: By ~, By the time that ~, Before ~
About: までに is a combination of two different types of particles. The adverbial particle まで, and the case marking particle に. までに is very similar to まで when it means 'until'. However, there is one very important distinction. This distinction is that までに means 'by', not 'until'. To use までに, we will need to attach it to the end of a noun, or verb in the non-past form. To understand the difference between まで, and までに, we need to remember that に usually marks a 'target', or a 'destination' for where something will happen. In this case, まで is the 'target' that に is marking. This is due to the fact that まで means 'as far as' (まで is sometimes written using kanji 迄(まで), especially in older/formal texts, and newspapers). In this way, までに more literally means '(A) as far as (に marks the target), (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ５時までに駅に来てください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please come to the station by 5 o'clock.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遊びに行くまでに片付けてね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please tidy up by the time you go out to play.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来月までにレポートを書く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will write a report by next month. (Focus is on 'next month' being the deadline)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来月までレポートを書く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am writing a report until next month. (Focus is on 'next month' being the end point for something that will continue until that point)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冬が終わるまでにスキーをしたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to go skiing by the end of winter. (Not just 'by winter', but specifically 'by the end of winter')

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日までに電話をください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please call by tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お昼までには着きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will arrive by noon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １０時までに帰ってきてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Could you please come back home by 10?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 来週までには終わります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will be done by next week.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ８時までに学校につかなくてはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have to arrive at school by 8 o'clock.

Name: また
Meaning: Also, As well, Moreover, Again, Additionally
About: また, or 又(また) in its kanji form, is an expression which means 'again', 'additionally', 'also', or 'moreover'. This may seem confusing at first, but it may be easier to think of また as meaning 'repetition of (A)', where (A) is any particular course of action. This repetition is a bit different to English, in that it can express the same action, or an alternative option. また can be used as an adverb, or as a conjunction. In this lesson, we will focus on its use as a conjunction. As with many other conjunctions in Japanese, a phrase/sentence can begin with また, so long as that sentence expresses a complete thought. Due to また being quite different to any single word that we have in English, let's try to make the meaning a bit clearer. Imagine that '(A) action always has (B) result'. However, the action which leads to the (B) result could be many different things. Because of this, また can have the following meanings. The same (A) action is taken - Has the nuance of 'again', or 'moreover'. A different (A) action is taken - Has the nuance of 'also', and 'additionally'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: また遊ぼうね！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let's hang out again!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: また行こうね！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let's go again!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: またカンニングしたの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You cheated again?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は宇宙飛行士であり、またアナウンサーでもある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is an astronaut, and also an announcer!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: また寝坊したの？
Questions.EnglishHTML: You overslept again?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: またその夢を見たい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to dream that dream again.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: また、彼からチョコをもらった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Moreover, I received chocolate from him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は、また旅行に行くつもりです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I intend to go on another trip. (again)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日から、また授業が始まります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Class will start again from tomorrow.

Name: 始(はじ)める
Meaning: To start, To begin to
About: To express that actions are beginning or ending in Japanese, the verbs 始(はじ)める (to commence), or 終(お)わる (to end) will need to be used. In this lesson, we will focus on actions that are 'beginning'. To say that (A) is starting/beginning, we will need to attach はじめる to the ます stem of almost any verb. Whether you use the hiragana form, or the kanji form does not matter, as there will be no change in nuance. Due to はじめる being a verb itself, the tense can be changed, to show that something will start, is starting, or has started.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来月からお金をため始めます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will start saving money from next month.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 歌を歌い始める。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To start singing a song.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日から日本語を習い始める。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will start learning Japanese from tomorrow. (Will start)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 雨が降り始めてきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is starting to rain. (Is starting)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高校生の時にお金を貯め始めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I started saving up money when I was in high school. (Has started)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今朝、雪が降りはじめた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It started to snow this morning.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日から、日本語を習いはじめます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will start learning Japanese from tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 練習しはじめてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please begin to (do) practice.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ９時になってから、働きはじめた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I started working from nine.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼が話し始めてから１時間経った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It has been an hour since he started talking.

Name: 終(お)わる
Meaning: To finish, To end
About: To express that actions are beginning, or ending in Japanese, the verbs 始(はじ)める (to commence), or 終(お)わる (to end) will need to be used. In this lesson, we will focus on actions that are 'ending'. To say that (A) is ending/finishing, we will need to attach おわる to the ます stem of almost any verb. Whether you use the hiragana form, or the kanji form does not matter, as there will be no change in nuance. Due to おわる being a verb itself, the tense can be changed to show that something will end, is ending, or has ended.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 荷物は全部届け終わりました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have finished delivering all the packages.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この車のローンは明日払い終わる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will finish paying the loan for this car tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ご飯を食べ終わるまで、デザートは禁止だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You're not allowed to have dessert until you finish eating your food.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そのコーヒー、まだ飲み終わってないの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Have you not finished drinking that coffee?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 長いレポートでしたが、今日やっと読み終わりました！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It was a long report, but today I finally finished reading it!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ２時間もかかったけど、食べおわりました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It took two hours but I finished eating.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ３時ごろに作りおわる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will finish making it around three o'clock.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この番組は見おわった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I finished watching this program.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 走りおわったのは何時ぐらいでしたか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Around what time did you finish running?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 宿題を直しおわった人は教えてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Those who have finished fixing the homework, let me know.

Name: 頃(ころ)
Meaning: Around, About
About: ころ, or ごろ (the colloquial pronunciation) is a word which carries the meaning of 'around', or 'about'. It is utilized in a similar way to くらい, but has a few differences. When ごろ is used, it will need to be attached to the end of a noun, or a noun followed by の. The main difference between ころ and くらい is that ころ can be (and often is) used to express a broad point in time, while くらい is limited to expressing timeframes that are more specific. Conversely, ころ will not be used when expressing approximate distances/lengths. The primary reason for this is that ころ expresses a span of something, while くらい expresses an extent. In this way, ころ could also be translated as 'within the span of (A)', while くらい is closer to 'at the point of (A)'. As an easier way to think about it, if we have a one meter ruler, ころ could express anywhere between 1 to 100 centimeters (the span), but くらい can only express somewhere between 90 and 100 centimeters (the extent). Just like with English, if the 'time' expressed is very specific, then either くらい or ころ could be used naturally. This is due to the 'span', and the 'extent' already being something that is a 'precise point' in these cases.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １１時頃に帰ってくる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will be home around 11.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は大学生の頃に富士山を登りました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I climbed Mount Fuji around when I was a college student.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供のくらいはよく親と動物園へ行きました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I was approximately a child, I often went to the zoo with my parents. (Unnatural Japanese, as being a child is a broad time frame)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供のころはよく親と動物園へ行きました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Around when I was a child, I often went to the zoo with my parents. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 二メートルくらいの所に印をつけてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please make a mark around the 2 meter point. (Natural Japanese, as an approximation is being discussed)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 二メートルごろの所に印をつけてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please make a mark within the span of 2 meters. (Unnatural Japanese, as the listener would think that marking a line anywhere within the two meter space is fine)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は１２時くらいに帰る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will be home around 12.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は１２時頃に帰る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will be home around 12.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ８時頃に帰りました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I went home around eight o'clock.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 東京に行った友達は今頃着いているでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My friend who went to Tokyo is probably arriving around now...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 月曜日の夜頃に、雨が降ります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It will rain around Monday night.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何時頃帰って来る？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Around what time will you come home?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １１時頃に帰って来るから、ご飯はいらないです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will get home about 11, so I don't need dinner.

Name: 後(あと)で
Meaning: After, Later
About: In Japanese, あとで is a combination of the noun 後(あと) (behind), and the particle で (with). When these words are linked, they form an adverbial phrase which is used to express 'after', or 'later'. As with で's standard meaning of 'with', あとで is simply highlighting that something will happen, 'with' the 'after/behind' part of something. To use あとで, attach it to the end of any past-tense verb, noun followed by の, or verb followed by のは (nominalization).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勉強するのは食べた後でいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You can study after you finish eating. (With the time after eating)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事の後で、飲み会に行きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will go to the party after work. (With the time after work)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コピーを取るのは後でいいから、今は上司に電話して。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since it's fine to make the copies later, please call the boss right now. (With the time after calling the boss)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 後で洗濯もの干してね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please hang the laundry later.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: またあとで、会いましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's meet again later.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強したあとで、遊んでもいいよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is ok to play after you study.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あとで買い物に行きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will go shopping later.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あとで話がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We will talk later.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食事のあとで、お皿を洗わなくてはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have to wash dishes after a meal.

Name: ～ていた
Meaning: Was doing ~
About: To convey that '(A) was happening', or that somebody 'was doing (A)' in Japanese, ていた (or ていました) will be used. ていた is a construction which uses the conjunction particle て, and the ichidan verb いる (to exist), in its past tense form いた. Sometimes ていた is used to express things that are still ongoing, but the speaker is not sure about, or would like to politely advise the listener about. This is very similar to the way in which English uses '(A) was doing (B)'. In this example, although the action of 'sitting' is not finished, we can imagine that the speaker is suggesting that 'dad was sitting here, and he still is, but he just went to get a drink'. The same kind of sentence could be used when the speaker has walked away from where their dad was sitting, and doesn't actually know if he is still sitting there or not.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: シャワーが壊れていたから二日間もシャワーを浴びれなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because the shower was broken, I was not able to take a shower for 2 days. (Was in the state of being broken)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日は夜遅くまでカラオケで歌っていたので、のどが痛いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was singing until late last night at karaoke, so my throat hurts. (Was doing karaoke)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昔はパーマをかけていました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In the past, I used to have my hair permed. (Was getting perms)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 窓が割れていました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The window was smashed. (Was in the state of being smashed)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お父さんがその椅子に座っていたから、こっちに座りな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Dad was sitting there, so sit here please.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強をしていたけど、今は休んでいる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was studying but am taking a break right now.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 音楽を聴いていたから、電話が聞こえなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I was listening to music I couldn't hear the phone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昨日１時ごろに寝ていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Yesterday around one o'clock I was sleeping.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ４時間も椅子に座っていたから、お尻が痛い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was sitting for as much as four hours, so my butt hurts.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お母さんが帰って来た時私はご飯を作っていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When my mom came home I was making food.

Name: に (Frequency)
Meaning: Times (In each time period), Every, Frequency of
About: When the case marking particle に is used, sometimes it has the nuance of 'frequency'. This means that it can be utilized to describe how often something happens/is done. In this grammatical construction, the 'time frame' is followed by に, then followed by the number of times that you would like to say that something happens. In this way, に keeps its regular nuance of being a 'goal', or 'destination', within which something else takes place.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は一ヶ月に一回友達と遊園地に行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go to the amusement park with my friend every month. (One time per month)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は一週間に２回しか歯を磨かないから、口が臭い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because he only brushes his teeth twice every week, his mouth stinks.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ２年間で５０万円も貯めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In two years, I saved up ￥500,000. (Natural Japanese, as this expresses the amount of time that something took)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一年に三回ぐらい海外旅行に行く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I take trips abroad about three times in a year. (frequency)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一日に六時間は寝る必要がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is necessary to sleep for six hours every day. (frequency)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一時間に十本の電車がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are ten trains every hour. (frequency)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 公務員は一年に一回ボーナスをもらう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Public servants get a bonus every year. (Once each year) (Frequency)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はタバコを１日に４０本ぐらい吸う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He smokes about 40 cigarettes every day. (40 each day)

Name: 到頭(とうとう)
Meaning: Finally, After all
About: とうとう is an adverb that is used to express that something 'finally' happens. In Japanese, there are a few ways to do this, but とうとう is one of the more common. Coming from the kanji 到頭(とうとう), this structure literally means 到 (to arrive at), 頭 (the head of/crux of) something. Due to this, 'finally', and 'after all' are the two most common translations of とうとう. Like many other adverbs in Japanese, とうとう is often used at the beginning of a phrase/sentence. While とうとう is written in hiragana the majority of the time, knowing the kanji will help when trying to remember the expression's nuance. That nuance is that something has 'ended', usually after some sort of long journey/effort. This adverb may be used to express either positive or negative outcomes, as it focuses more on the time required to achieve the result, rather than the result being good or bad.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: とうとうお前が大学生か...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: So you're finally a college student... (After all this time, have you finally become a college student?)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: とうとうロシアに行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will finally go to Russia. (After all this time, I can finally go to Russia)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: とうとう夏休みだ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's finally summer break! (Good result)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: とうとう夏休みが終わる日が来た。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The day that summer break ends has finally arrived. (Bad result)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いよいよ夏が来た。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Finally, summer has come. (Natural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 到頭休みだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Finally it is my day off.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 到頭タバコをやめた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I finally quit smoking.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それを到頭捨てた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I finally threw that away. (I threw that away after all)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日痛みが到頭なくなった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Today the pain finally went away.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 到頭漢字の勉強ができる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can finally study kanji.

Name: より
Meaning: More than, Over
About: In N5, we learned about the use of より that is seen when making comparisons in より～のほうが. However, in this lesson, we will take a look at how this case marking particle can be used by itself. When used alone, this particle expresses that (A) (a noun or verb) is being compared to (B) (a noun or verb that is regularly paired with an adjective). The word that より is directly attached to will always be 'less than' the comparison being made. However, the overall expression is used to describe that (B) is 'more' (something) than (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パンダはバナナより重い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Pandas are heavier than bananas.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 太陽はロウソクより明るい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The sun is brighter than a candle.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これがより高いものになります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is the thing that would be more expensive. (Compared to everything else that is here)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたの絵は私の絵より上手。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Your paintings are better than mine.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 月曜日より日曜日がいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Sunday is better than Monday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語は英語より話しにくい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Japanese is harder to speak than English.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつも飲んでいる水より好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like this (drink) more than the water that I usually drink.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スポーツをするより、ゲームの方が楽しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Video games are more exciting than sports.

Name: 毎(ごと)に
Meaning: Each, Every
About: ごとに is a combination of the noun ごと, and the particle に. Together, they are used adverbially to express that something happens 'every (A)', or 'at intervals of (A)'. ごとに may be used after any verb (usually in non-past form), or noun. Although ごとに may be used after verbs, the most common use is with nouns, or phrases that finish with nouns.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 失敗をする経験は無駄ではありません。失敗をするごとに上達します。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Failing is not a pointless experience. Every time you fail, you improve.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は３時間ごとにお菓子を食べます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I eat snacks every 3 hours.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は一週間ごとに実家に帰ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go to my parents' home every week. (Every single one)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は一週間おきに実家に帰ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go to my parents' home every other week. (With 'spaces' or 'gaps' of 1 week)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのチームは、試合をする毎に強くなっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That team is getting stronger with every match.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夏毎にアメリカに帰ります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Every summer I go back to America.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 生徒毎に紙を渡した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I gave a paper to every student. (Each)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 二日毎に友達とサッカーをする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I play soccer with my friend every two days. (at two day intervals)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人は会う人毎に笑顔で握手します。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person greets every person they meet with a smile and a handshake.

Name: なるべく
Meaning: As ~ as possible, Wherever practicable
About: Combining 成(な)る (to become), and 可(べ)く (to be permissible), なるべく is an expression that literally means 'as each opportunity becomes permissible/presents itself'. This is often simply translated as 'as much as possible', or 'whenever possible'. なるべく (usually written in hiragana) is regularly used before an entire phrase, to express that (A) should happen as much as possible. Due to なるべく expressing the 'possibility', or 'having the opportunity' to do something, it will sound considerably softer/more polite than できるだけ. できるだけ is a similar expression which more directly states that something will be done 'to the full extent possible'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 外に出かけるときはなるべくドアのカギをかけてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When you go out, lock your doors as often as possible.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事で疲れていても、なるべく夕食は食べてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if you are tired from work, please eat dinner whenever possible.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日はできるだけ早く来てね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tomorrow, please make sure to come as early as possible.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日はなるべく早く来てね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tomorrow, please come as early as possible.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なるべく速く行きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will go as fast as possible.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なるべく早めに連絡してください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please contact me as soon as possible.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なるべく正直に話してください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please speak as honestly as possible.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なるべく早めに犯人を捕まえるつもりです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We intend to catch the criminal as soon as possible.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なるべく沢山の人気な場所へ行きたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to go to as many famous places as possible.

Name: ～る所(ところ)だ
Meaning: About to, On the verge of
About: The noun ところ (sometimes shortened to とこ) is often used to describe the 'place' or 'situation' in which something happens. The primary determining factor for the nuance of ところ, is the tense of the verb it follows. When it is in the non-past form, ところ means 'about to (A)', or 'on the verge of (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は手紙を書くところだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is about to write a letter.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今から友達と会うところです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm about to meet my friend.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いまの所...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This current place…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いまのところ...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This current situation…

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今から帰るところです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am just about to go home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ちょうど出かけるところだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am about to leave right now.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 髪の毛を切るところでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was on the verge of cutting my hair. (just about to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 出かけるところなので洗い物ができない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am just about to go out, so I cannot do the dishes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 宿題をするところで、友達から電話が入った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just when I was about to do my homework I got a call from a friend.

Name: のに
Meaning: Despite, Although, Even though
About: Although のに is often thought of as a simple combination of the particles の and に, it is actually its own particle, with the meaning of 'despite', or 'in order to'. In this lesson, we will focus primarily on the 'despite' nuance. Due to のに being a conjunction particle, it can be linked to almost any word type, to show that 'despite (A), (B)'. As with many conjunction particles, な will be required after a noun/な-Adjective, but before のに. It is also possible to see だのに, instead of なのに, but this is something that is only seen in certain dialects, and would be considered incorrect by the vast majority of native speakers.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日テストがあるのに彼は勉強をしないでゲームをしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Despite having a test tomorrow, he is playing games without studying.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何で納豆は臭いのに美味しいの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why does natto taste good, despite smelling bad?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はイケメンなのにいつも汗臭い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though he is a good looking guy, he always smells like sweat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この車はスポーツカーなのに遅い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Despite being a sports car, this car is slow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 虫歯だのに、チョコレートを食べたから歯が痛い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My tooth hurts because I ate chocolate, despite having a cavity.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 無理って言ったのにまだやるの？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though I said it was impossible, you're still going to do it? (despite)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は忙しいのに、ゲームをしている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite being busy, he is playing video games. (even though)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 天気予報は悪かったのに、晴れた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite the weather forecast being bad, it was sunny. (even though)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの女の人はきれいなのに、彼氏がいない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite being pretty, that woman doesn't have a boyfriend. (even though)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あまり牛乳がないのにスーパーに行った時買わなかったの？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though we are running low on milk, you didn't buy any when you went to the store? (despite)

Name: と思(おも)う
Meaning: I think
About: To express that you 'think' something in Japanese, the common expression と思(おも)う is regularly used. As you can probably guess, this is just a combination of the particle と, plus the う-Verb 思(おも)う. とおもう can be used after any verb, い-Adjective, な-Adjective, or noun, but will require だ after a noun or な-Adjective. Although this structure usually requires だ after nouns and な-Adjectives, it is often omitted in casual speech.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ごめん、ちょっと遅れると思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sorry, I think I'm going to be a little late.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その言い方は酷いと思うよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think the way you said that was harsh.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺はあの人が綺麗だと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think that person looks pretty.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはフランス語だと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think this is French.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は日本が安全と思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think Japan is safe. (Ungrammatical Japanese, but quite common)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ジェームスは自分が賢いと思っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: James thinks he is smart.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来年に新しいオートバイを買いたいと思っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am thinking that I want to buy a new motorcycle next year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このズボンはいいと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think these pants are good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日、雨が降ると思った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I thought that it was going to rain today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そうだと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think so.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは凄いと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think that is amazing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ダメだと思いますよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think it is no good. (Not allowed)

Name: 等(など)
Meaning: Such as, Things like, Etc., And so on
About: など is an adverbial particle that is used to express that something is being presented as an example, but that other things in the same category also exist. In this way, it is regularly translated as 'such as', 'things like', or 'and so on'. など may be used after nouns, to describe that (A) is being presented as an example from within a group. Alternatively, など can be followed by の (B), to show that (A) is only one example from within a broader category related to (B). など is regularly seen in its kanji form, 等(など). This kanji itself has a similar meaning to 'etc' in English.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この公園では石などを投げないでください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do not throw rocks and so on in this park.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はいつもルームメイトなどの悪口を言っています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is always badmouthing people, like his roommates.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 鞄や靴等を川に捨ててはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You mustn't discard things such as bags and shoes into the river.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あいつ等本当にうるさいね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Those people are very noisy, don't you think.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: イタリアやアメリカなどに行きたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to go to places such as America and Italy. (etc. / and so on)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: フルーツはぶどうなどが好きです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As for fruits, I like grapes and such. (etc. / and so on)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 趣味などを教えてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please tell me things like your hobbies. (etc. / and so on)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日から、準備などをするつもりです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From tomorrow, I plan on doing things like preparing. (etc. / and so on)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 数学などを勉強します。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I study things like math. (etc. / and so on)

Name: みたい
Meaning: Like, Similar to, Resembling
About: In Japanese, there are many ways to express that something happens in a way that is 'like' something else, or 'resembles' something else. One of these ways is through the use of the な-Adjective, みたい. みたい can be used after any word that a な-Adjective would usually follow, to express that something is 'like (A)', or 'similar to (A)'. In the above examples, we can see that みたい should always be followed by だ (or です) when it is at the end of a statement, however, this is frequently omitted. みたい is also often used to describe another noun, but needs to be followed by な in these cases. In this type of sentence, it is just expressing that something is '(B), but resembles (A)'. みたい is used most often in conversational situations, and is based on direct, reliable information. It is far less formal than its counterpart, ようだ.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は雪が降るみたいだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems like it will snow tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこのプールは浅いみたいだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That pool over there seems shallow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は地下鉄が嫌いみたいだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems like he does not like subways.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その携帯はパソコンみたいだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That cellphone looks like a computer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩は今日は来ないみたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems like senpai is not coming today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はスポーツ選手みたいな体をしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He has a body like an athlete.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この犬は熊みたいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This dog looks like a bear.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人は有名人みたいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person looks like a famous person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日の昼から雨が降るみたいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It looks like it will rain this afternoon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの雲は馬みたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That cloud resembles a horse. (Looks like)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのビルは会社じゃなくて病院みたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It seems like that building is a hospital, and not a company.

Name: こと
Meaning: Converting a verb into a noun
About: In a very similar way to のは, こと is used in Japanese for nominalization (creating a noun-like phrase). However, unlike のは, which is a combination of two particles, こと is a noun. To use こと, just add it to the end of a verb in its dictionary form. こと (or 事(こと) in its kanji form) is a noun that is often translated as 'thing', and in this way, literally means 'the thing that is (A)' when used for nominalization. As we can see from these examples, ない can also be used between the verb and こと, to form a 'not' statement. There are other auxiliary verbs that may be used with こと in this way, but ない is the most common. Although this lesson discusses こと pairing with the dictionary form of verbs, it can actually pair with any standard verb form. Standard form just means anything that does not finish with the polite ます.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 近所の迷惑になることをしてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You should not do things that will cause annoyance to your neighbors. (That which is 'causing a problem in the neighborhood')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ファックスをすることが嫌い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I dislike things like faxing. (That which is 'faxing')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お金を使い過ぎないことが大事です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is important to not use too much money. (That which is 'not using too much money')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 1．クラスメイトをいじめないこと。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: 1. Do not bully your classmates.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語を話すことは難しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Speaking Japanese is difficult.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スポーツをすることが好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like playing sports.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ダンスをすることは楽しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Dancing is fun!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大きい声で喋らないこと。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not talking loudly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: フォークじゃなくて、お箸を使うこと。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not using a fork, using chopsticks.

Name: そう
Meaning: Look like, Appear, Seem, Have a feeling that
About: そうだ is one of the 18 primary auxiliary verbs in Japanese, and can be used in two (2) different ways. The broad meaning in each of its applications is that something 'seems' to be a certain way. Due to this, そう is regularly translated as 'seems like', 'looks like', or 'appears as though'. In this lesson, we will focus on the form that is used with the conjunctive (stem) form of words. Please examine the structure guide to see these forms.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は毎日走っていそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She seems like she runs everyday.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは正しそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This seems correct.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの店員は丁寧そうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That clerk seems like he is attentive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の部屋は汚くなさそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: His room doesn't seem messy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの車は小さくて便利じゃなさそう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That car is small and seems inconvenient.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はもうイギリスに帰らなそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It appears that he is not going back to England.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は朝から雨が降るみたいだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It looks like it is going to start raining tomorrow morning. (Higher confidence)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は朝から雨が降りそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems like it is going to start raining tomorrow morning. (Lower confidence)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 雪が降りそうです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It looks like it is going to snow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生の仕事は難しそうです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The job of being a teacher looks difficult.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日の宿題は簡単そうだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Today's homework looks easy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その食べ物は食べやすそう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That food looks easy to eat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この教科書はとても難しそうです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This textbook seems very difficult.

Name: さ
Meaning: Converting adjectives to nouns
About: さ is a suffix in Japanese that can be attached to the stem form of い-Adjectives and な-Adjectives. When this happens, it transforms the target adjective into a noun that illustrates the 'amount' of that particular adjective. This commonly translates as '-ness' in English (sweetness, tallness, spiciness, etc), but is referred to as degree in Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が道の長さを測ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will measure the length of the road. (The road's lengthiness)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大人になってから家族の大切さが分かってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After becoming an adult, I came to understand the importance of family. (Family's importantness)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 学校からの帰るさにお金を拾った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the way back from school, I picked up some money. (At the 'point' of returning home)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 行くさで家に忘れ物をしたことを思い出した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I was on my way there, I remembered that I had left something at home. (At the 'point' of going somewhere)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この美しさは初めてです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This beauty is a first for me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の元気さは子供みたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: His energy is like that of a child.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この甘さは美味しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This sweetness is delicious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 箱の重さを測ってください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please weigh the heaviness of the box for me?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この寒さだけで死ぬよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just by this coldness you will die.

Name: とか
Meaning: Among other things, For example, Such as
About: とか is a word that belongs to a unique family of particles in Japanese called listing particles. As the name suggests, these particles are used for listing groups of items that share similarities. とか can be used after verbs, or nouns, to express 'among other things, (A)'. When multiple things are listed, the last item in the list can (and often does) have とか omitted.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 健康のために野菜を食べるとか水を飲むとかをしています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For my health, I do things like eat vegetables and drink water.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 亀とかすっぽんとかは美味しいんですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are things like turtles and softshell turtles delicious?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: かぼちゃとかサツマイモとか白菜とかシイタケが入っている鍋が好き。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like hot pots that include things like pumpkin, sweet potato, cabbage, and shiitake.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫の中にあるものを食べるとかしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Eat what's in the refrigerator or something. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫の中にあるものを食べるやしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Eat things in the refrigerator or something. (Unnatural Japanese, as や cannot be used with verbs)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 青とか水色が好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like colors such as blue and light blue. (among others)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日とか今週末とか、暇なら、映画を見に行こう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you are free tomorrow or, for example this weekend, let's go watch a movie. (among others)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トム・クルーズとかブラッド・ピットとかがかっこいいと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think people like Tom Cruise for example, or Brad Pitt are cool. (among others)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本とか、韓国とかに行ってみたいですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to go to places such as Japan and Korea. (among others)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語で「th」の音とかはないです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Japanese doesn't have a 'th' sound (among other things).

Name: そういう
Meaning: Like that, Kind of
About: Coming from the こそあど言葉(ことば) family of words, こう, そう, ああ, or どう may be used with the verb 言(い)う to form an expression which literally means 'in the way of (A)'. (A) being 'this' これ, 'that' それ, 'that over there' あれ, or 'what' どれ (in questions). As with all pre-noun adjectival words, this expression will be used directly before a noun. Although こう, そう, ああ, and どう share a relationship with これ, それ, あれ, and どれ, they are their own individual words, which each have a meaning similar to 'as such'. These words are all adverb when used by themselves.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こういう映画は初めて見る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is my first time watching a movie like this. (This 'kind' of movie)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そういう人は嫌い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't like people like that. (That 'kind' of people)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ああいう車に乗ってみたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to try to drive a car like that one. (That 'kind' of car)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたはどういう音楽を聴きますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What kind of music do you listen to?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そういう人もいるよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are also people like that (you know).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どういう意味ですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: What do you mean? (Literally - What kind of meaning?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ああいう消しゴムが好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like erasers like that one over there.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こういう人形がほしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want a doll like this.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こういう仕事をしなくちゃいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have to do this kind of job.

Name: う・よう (Volitional)
Meaning: Let's, I shall (Casual volitional)
About: よう (and う) are grammar constructions that function in a similar way to ましょう, or to be more precise, ましょう is the polite (conjugated) form of these auxiliary verbs. They are used as a casual way of expressing 'let's' when making suggestions, or 'I shall' when making statements. よう is only one of the potential forms of this grammar point, and can actually be divided into two separate auxiliary verbs, う (used with う-Verbs), and よう (used with る-Verbs, する, and くる). When attaching う to う-Verbs, simply replace the last kana with the equivalent お sound kana from within the same column (く becomes こ, う becomes お, す becomes そ, etc.), before adding う. For る-Verbs, replace る with よう. As with many other verb conjugations, する and くる behave in a slightly different way to regular う-Verbs and る-Verbs. する will become しよう, while くる will become こよう. The type of statements that う, and よう can be used for in Japanese are usually divided into three categories. 推量(すいりょう) - Expresses guesses (has a similar meaning to だろう, which itself is the よう form of だ) 意志(いし) - Expresses intentions (has a similar meaning to ～するつもりだ) 勧誘(かんゆう) - Expresses invitations or encouragement (has a similar meaning to 誘(さそ)う 'to invite')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今夜は先輩の試合を見に行こう！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tonight, let's go watch the senpai's tournament!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 早く食べよう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let's eat already!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が運転しようか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Shall I drive?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日はお金が無いから明日こよう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't have money today, so let's come tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたが好きなケーキを買ってあげよう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'll buy you a cake that you like.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 毎日スポーツをしよう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's play sports every day.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 朝ご飯を食べに行こう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's go out to eat for breakfast.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここにはあまりいいものがないから帰ろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is not really anything good here, so let's go home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は早く帰ろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's go home early today.

Name: 様(よう)だ
Meaning: It seems that, It appears that, It looks like
About: In a similar way to みたい, ようだ is used when making observations about something in Japanese. This auxiliary verb is used to express three primary things. たとえ - Using (A) as an example to highlight the way that (B) looks/is acting. 推定(すいてい) - Using (A) as a reason for an assumption made about (B). 例示(れいじ) - Presenting (A) as an example of what (B) is. ようだ is usually based on direct information/experience, and shows that the speaker has high confidence in what they are saying. It may also frequently appear in its kanji form, 様(よう)だ. ようだ can be used with any verb, い-Adjective, な-Adjective, or noun. However, it requires な before it when used with な-Adjectives, or の when used with nouns. Although ようだ and そうだ are often used in similar situations, そうだ shows that the speaker has a lot less confidence in their statement than ようだ. Because of this, ようだ is a much better choice when stating things that are obvious/observable by anyone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここに大きなビルが出来るようだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems like a big building will be made here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あそこのプールは深い様だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems like the pool over there is deep.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は明日のテストに自信があると皆に言っているが、本当は不安なようだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is telling everyone that he is confident about the test tomorrow, but it seems like he is actually worried.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ヨーダは宇宙人のようだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Yoda appears to be an alien.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ほとんど無くなっているようだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It seems that most of it is gone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はここに来ないようだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It seems like he won't come here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日の天気は台風のようだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Today's weather looks like a typhoon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の話し方は歌っているようだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: His way of speaking seems like singing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人はお金を持っていないようだが、本当はお金持ち。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person seems like he doesn't have any money, but he really is rich.

Name: 全然(ぜんぜん)
Meaning: (Not) at all
About: In Japanese, there are several adverbs that are traditionally used exclusively with negative expressions (containing ない). 全然(ぜんぜん) is one of them. When used at the beginning of a ない (or ません) containing phrase, 全然（ぜんぜん) has the meaning of 'completely not (A)', or 'not (A) at all'. In writing, it is equally as natural to use either 全然(ぜんぜん) as kanji, or hiragana only, so both forms may be used confidently. ぜんぜん is more flexible (and friendly sounding) in casual conversation than 全(まった)く, a similar expression which has a formal (often negative) nuance. While both of these sentences have the meaning of 'not (A) at all', まったく could give the listener the impression that you are not pleased with the situation. This will depend quite a bit on tone of voice, though.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やばい、トイレットペーパーが全然ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Oh shoot, I don't have any toilet paper at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は家事の手伝いを全然しなかったので別れました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I broke up with her because she didn't help out at all with house chores.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今月もお金が全然無いからパンだけを食べる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't have any money this month either, so I am only eating bread.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日後輩からもらったお土産は全く美味しくありませんでしたね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The souvenir we got from our junior member yesterday was not tasty at all, don't you think?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日？全然いいよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tomorrow? That's completely fine!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 着物が全然似合わない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Kimonos don't look good on me at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 全然頑張りたいと思わない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't feel like trying at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は全然英語を話せないです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't speak English at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたは全然理解が出来ていないね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You don't understand at all do you?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今、機嫌が悪くて、全然嬉しくならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm in a bad mood right now and there's no way at all I'll become happy.

Name: かな
Meaning: I wonder
About: Originally a mixture of the sentence ending particles か, and な, かな evolved over time to become its own (singular) sentence ending particle, which roughly translates as 'I wonder if (A)?'. As it is a sentence ending particle, かな can be added to the end of almost any sentence. However, in the case of な-adjectives, both だ and です will usually be omitted, with かな simply following the word stem itself. Combining the meanings か and な, we can see where かな gets its original meaning. か presents questions (usually to other people), while な shows that a statement is related purely to the speaker's own thoughts/opinions. In this way, かな expresses that the speaker's own thoughts are being questioned.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人が道の真ん中で倒れてるけど、大丈夫かな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person over there is laying collapsed in the middle of the street, but I wonder if they are okay.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このコンロにこの魚が入るかな？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if the fish will fit in this stove.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この通帳はお母さんのだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if this is my mother's checkbook. (Slightly masculine)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は本当に弁護士なのかな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if that person is really a lawyer. (Commonly used by anybody)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もうすぐ食べに行くかな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder if we will go eat soon...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日は運動をした方がいいかな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder, if I should exercise tomorrow...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今週末に友達と会えるかな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder if I can meet my friends this weekend...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫にケーキまだあるかな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder if there is still cake in the fridge.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お母さんは何をくれるかな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder what my mom will give me.

Name: 余(あま)り～ない
Meaning: Not very, Not much, Not really, Hardly
About: あまり is a very flexible word in Japanese, that is used in several different grammar points. When paired with the ない form of a word, it translates to 'not very (A)', or 'hardly (A)'. To pair あまり (or the casual form, あんまり) with another word, we just need to place it at the beginning of a phrase, or directly before the ない statement.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今の時間だったらあまり並ばないと思うよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At this time, I think we would not have to stand in line for very long.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私には犬がいるからあまり寂しくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have a dog, so I don't feel lonely very much.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近はどこもあまり平和ではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, nowhere has been very peaceful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこの肉屋の肉はあまりいい肉ではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Meat from that butcher over there is hardly good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このケーキはあまり美味しくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This cake isn't very delicious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あまり肉を食べない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't eat very much meat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あまり大変なことではないから、心配いらないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not really a big deal, so you don't have to worry. (isn't that)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寿司をあまり食べたいと思わない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't really think I want to eat sushi.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この漢字の意味があまり分かりません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't really understand the meaning of this kanji.

Name: ば
Meaning: If… then, (Conditional)
About: There are several different ways to express 'if' in Japanese. One of these is through using the conjunction particle ば. ば presents hypothetical situations (possibilities), and pairs with verbs using an う to え sound-change conjugation method on the terminal (last) kana. Let's examine this with a few verbs first. As we can see with these verbs, the final kana will change to an え sound, from its original う (る to れ, う to え, く to け, す to せ, etc.) before adding ば. It is important to practice these, to not get them mixed up with verbs that use れる, and られる. Unlike with these verbs, the base form of する and くる will not change when using ば. To conjugate い-Adjectives with ば, the い will be replaced with けれ, one of the standard い-Adjective conjugation forms. After this, just add ば. For な-Adjectives, and nouns, なら (another standard conjugation form of these words) will be added, before attaching ば. In the negative form (using ない), both the auxiliary verb ない, and the い-Adjective ない will conjugate in the same way. Simply replace い with けれ, and then add ば.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事を辞めれば自由時間が増えるけど、お金が無くなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I quit work, I will have more free time, but I will have no money.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 雨が止めば、今日も釣りに行くつもりです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it stops raining, I intend to go fishing today also.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこの信号で右に曲がれば病院に着きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you turn right at the light just there, you will get to the hospital.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 店に電話をすれば、すぐに予約ができるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you call the store, you will be able to make a reservation immediately.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あいつがくればパーティーが楽しくなると思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If he comes to the party, I think it will be more fun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 頭が痛ければ、薬を飲んで寝た方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If your head hurts, it would be better if you take some medicine and then sleep.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ラーメン屋のチャーハンが不味ければ、そこのラーメンも不味いだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If a ramen shop's fried rice tastes bad, then the ramen probably tastes bad too, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 刺身が嫌いならば 、寿司も嫌いでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you do not like sashimi, then you probably don't like sushi either, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: バイクならば、バイク専用の駐輪場に止めてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it's a motorcycle, please park it in the designated bike parking lot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が作ったクッキーを食べたくなければ、捨ててもいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you don't want to eat the cookie that I made, you can throw it away.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カレーが辛くなければ、いっぱい食べれる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If the curry isn't spicy, I can eat a lot of it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トラックの運転手でなければ、この仕事の辛さが分からない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you aren't a truck driver, then you wouldn't understand the hardships of this job.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運動をすれば痩せるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you exercise, you will lose weight.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夜遅くに電話をされると迷惑です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is very inconsiderate of you to call this late at night.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ヘルメットを被らなければ、バイクに乗れない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If (you) do not wear a helmet, then (you) cannot ride a motorbike.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日雨が降れば、映画を見に行くつもり。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it rains tomorrow, then I will go watch a movie.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 毎日サッカーの練習に行けば、プロのサッカー選手になれる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you go to soccer practice every day, then you can become a professional soccer player.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今週の金曜日までに出来なければ、来週末に終わらせなくてはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If (you) cannot do it by this Friday, then (you) have to finish it next weekend.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 展覧会に行けば、色々なことを学べる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If (you) go to an exhibit, then (you) can learn a variety of things.

Name: なら
Meaning: Were it, If, If it's the case, As for (Conditional)
About: As mentioned in our lesson about ば, なら is often used by itself to mean 'if'. This is considered to be an abbreviation of ならば, the hypothetical form of なり, a classical auxiliary verb that is not used much in modern Japanese. Because なり originally meant 'to be', it functions in a similar way to the auxiliary verb だ. This means that it regularly pairs with nouns, or phrases that have been nominalized (become noun-like), through the use of の. However, unlike だ (or です), なら is also regularly used without the extra help of の for nominalization, and can be attached directly to verbs or い-Adjectives.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田舎に住むのならば、車を買ったほうがいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are going to live in the countryside, it would be better to buy a car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 寒いのならば、ジャケットを着るといいだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it is cold, you should wear a jacket.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 無理ならいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it is not possible, it's okay.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: デザートなら何でも食べられます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it is a dessert, I can eat anything. (If it is dessert, I like anything)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の車を使うなら、いつ使うか教えてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are going to use my car, please let me know when.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 暑いなら、その上着を脱いでください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are hot, please take off that jacket.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 練習をするなら、漢字を書くのが上手になる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are going to practice, you will get good at writing kanji. (Unnatural Japanese, as becoming 'good' is a natural result of practicing)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君なら、できる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it's you, you can do it. (if it is the case)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そういうことなら、聞かなくていい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it's something like that, you don't have to ask. (in the case of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 宿題が難しいなら、一緒にしよう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If the homework is hard, let's do it together. (if it is the case)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: また行くなら、帰って来ないでください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you are going to go again, please don't come back. (in the case of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暑いなら、扇風機を点けてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it's the case that it is hot, please turn on the fan.

Name: がる
