Meaning: To feel, To think, To act as if, To want, To desire
About: がる is a う-Verb that is primarily used as a suffix in Japanese. When used in this way, it means 'to act like (A)', or 'to show signs of being (A)', where (A) is the word that it is attached to. To use がる, you will need to link it to the stem form of an い-Adjective (simply remove the い), or to the stem form of a な-Adjective (do not include the な). がる is a verb which means 'to give the impression of (A)', or 'to act like (A)'. This is very important in Japanese, as you would not usually say how somebody else feels, unless they told you directly and you are simply repeating what you heard (in which case you would use the quotation particle と). When you want to express the way you 'think' that someone else feels, but don't have any direct information about it, that is when がる would be natural to use. For example, if you see someone shivering in the cold, you would say something like the following. The main difference between がる, and がっている, is that がる will be used when a person usually/always acts a certain way, whereas がっている is more about the way someone/something is acting in any specific moment.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はいつも女の子の前では強がるけど友達の中では彼は一番の怖がりだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He always acts tough in front of girls, but amongst our friends he is the biggest scaredy-cat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犬が嫌がる事をしてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must not do anything that the dog would not like.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムはこの新しいゲームを欲しいと思うよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think Tom would want this new game.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人、寒がっている。ジャケット着ればいいのに。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person seems like they feel cold. It would be better if he wore his jacket. (Natural Japanese, as がる shows how he 'appears to be acting', rather than what he is actually feeling)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この子はいつも新しいおもちゃを欲しがる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This kid always wants new toys.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: キムは新しいパソコンをほしがっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Kim is wanting a new computer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺はいつも人の前では強がる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I always act tough in front of people. (I probably always appear to act tough)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は今、犬をほしがっているけど、マンションに住んでいるからまだ飼えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Right now, I am wanting a dog, but since I live in an apartment, I can't get one yet. (I am currently acting like I want a dog)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人、暑がっているね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person looks like they are hot, don't you think. (They're acting like they're hot)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人、暑そうだね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person looks like they are hot, don't you think. (They seem hot)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の猫は怖がる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My cat is jumpy. (Acts scared)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の弟は強がる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My younger brother acts tough.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの子はゲームをほしがる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That kid (always) wants games.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 映画を見て、面白がっています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Watching a movie and showing signs of interest.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君の車を欲しがる人はいないと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't think that anyone feels like they want your car.

Name: がする
Meaning: To give off, Smell, Sound, Taste, Sensation
About: In Japanese, describing things that can be experienced with the senses (excluding visual), is a little bit different to the way that we would convey it in English. Traditionally, we would use unique verbs for each of these situations, such as 'smells like (A)', 'tastes like (A)', 'feels like (A)', etc. While this is still possible in Japanese, it is not the most common way. がする is a grammar construction that focuses on the source of the smell, sound, taste, or feeling, and makes the sensory experience itself the subject of the sentence. To use がする, simply attach it to the end of any phrase that expresses which type of 'sense' is being created/given off by the subject.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この石鹸はバラの匂いがするから好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like this soap because it smells like roses. (Literally, 'it gives off a rose smell')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰かが階段を上がっている音がする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hear someone coming up the stairs. (Literally, 'the sound of someone coming up the stairs is being made')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このバナナが変な味がする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This banana tastes weird. (Literally, 'it gives off a strange flavor')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰かに見られている感じがする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It feels like I'm being watched by someone. (Literally, 'the feeling of being watched is happening')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ヤバい、鍵をかけるのを忘れた気がする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Shoot, I feel like I forgot to lock my door. (Literally, 'my attention is being drawn to that I may have forgotten to lock the door')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なんか忘れた気がする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I feel like I forgot something. (Literally, 'my attention is being drawn to that something was forgotten')

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 車の音がする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A car is making a sound.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この部屋はコーヒーの匂いがします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This room is giving off a coffee smell.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この料理は塩の味がします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This food gives off a salty taste.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 変な味がするのでこれを捨てます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This gives off an odd flavor, so I will throw it away.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お砂糖を入れ過ぎたから、甘い味がする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I put too much sugar in, so it gives off a sweet taste.

Name: たがる
Meaning: To want to (Third person)
About: As we explored in our lesson about がる, this verb can be used with adjectives, to express the way in which people are acting. However, it can also be partnered with the auxiliary verb たい, to form たがる. This grammar construction is used when expressing that someone is acting like they 'want' to do something. To use this structure, attach たい to the ます stem form of any verb, then replace the い in たい with がる.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ジョンはなんでいつも悪口を言いたがるんだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder why John always wants to talk badly about people.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 皆は彼が作ったケーキを食べたがる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Everyone always wants to eat the cakes that he makes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はこのステーキを食べたがる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He wants to eat this steak. (He acts like he wants to)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼にこのステーキを食べてほしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want him to eat this steak. (I want him to)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中君は新しいゲームを見つけると、そのゲームをほしがる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When Tanaka-kun sees a new game, he always wants it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は動物園に行きたがる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is acting like he wants to go to the zoo.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 娘はいつもスポーツをしたがる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My daughter always wants to play sports.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は最近の映画を見たがる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My girlfriend wants to see a recently released movie.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの子が帰りたがるならいいんじゃない？
Questions.EnglishHTML: If that kid wants to go home, that's alright, isn't it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はパソコンを買いたがって、週末も働いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He wanted to buy a PC, so (and) he even worked weekends.

Name: かもしれない
Meaning: Might, Maybe, Probably
About: かもしれない is an expression in Japanese that is often treated as a single word, but is actually the combination of the particle かも, and the potential form of the う-Verb 知(し)る (to know) with the auxiliary verb ない attached. かもしれない is regularly translated simply as 'might', or 'maybe', but the literal translation is much closer to 'even (A), we cannot know'. To use かもしれない, attach it to the end of any verb, noun, な-Adjective or い-Adjective, in their non-polite (keigo) forms. As the う-Verb 知(し)る is part of this construction, it may also be altered to its polite-potential form, creating かもしれません. Due to かもしれない being such a common grammar pattern in daily speech for expressing uncertainty about various things, several colloquial forms also exist. These are かも, かもしらん, and かもしれん. かも is by far the most common of these colloquial forms, with かもしらん potentially sounding a little bit rough/boyish.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来年から観光客が増えるかもしれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From next year, the number of tourists might increase.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの建物は教会かもしれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That building might be a church.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は無理かもしれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It might not be possible today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこの池は深いかもしれないから気を付けてね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That lake over there might be deep, so please be careful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は休むかもしれません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I might take the day off tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は休みだからドライブするかも。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have a day off tomorrow, so I might go for a drive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 財布を家に忘れてきたかもしらん。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I might have left my wallet at home.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は夜遅くまで仕事があるから、行かないかもしれん。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have to work late tomorrow night, so I probably won’t go.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そうかもね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That might be right.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女がまた遅れるかもしれません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She might be late again.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 来年アメリカに行くかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I might go to America next year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このいい服を買えば、人気になるかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I buy these nice clothes, then I might become popular.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そういうことを言わないほうがいいかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is maybe better to not say such things.

Name: みたいに
Meaning: Like, Similar to, Resembling
About: As learned in our previous lesson about みたい, it is a な-Adjective. This means that it can be used in conjunction with nouns, or with verbs. In each of these cases, it will carry the meaning of 'like (A)', or 'resembling (A)'. The difference between みたい describing a verb or a noun can be identified by whether it is followed by な (describes a noun), or に (describes a verb). Let's take a look at some examples. This difference is important to know, as (B), the thing that みたい is describing, does not always come directly after みたい. In the second example sentence, we can see that 泳(およ)ぐ (the verb that に is linked to), does not actually come until later in the sentence. This is quite a regular occurrence, especially in longer passages.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: プロみたいに泳ぎたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to swim like a professional.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生みたいになりたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to be like my teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生みたいな人になりたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to become someone like my teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 関西みたいな所に住みたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to live in a place like the Kansai region.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はイルカみたいに泳ぎたいと言っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is saying that he wants to swim like a dolphin.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はイルカみたいに、早く泳ぎたいと言っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is saying that he wants to swim fast like a dolphin.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私はあの女の人みたいになりたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to become like that woman.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは城みたいな家です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That is a castle-like house.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 魚みたいに泳ぎたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to swim like a fish.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サンダルみたいに履きやすい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They are easy to put on, just like sandals. (similar to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お金持ちの人みたいな生活をしたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to live a life similar to a rich person.

Name: そうに
Meaning: Seem, Look like, Sound
About: そうだ is one of the 18 auxiliary verbs in Japanese, and can be used in the same way as な-Adjectives (may be followed by な when acting as an adjective, or に when acting as an adverb). This is a unique characteristic of そうだ and ようだ. It is not something that can be done with all auxiliary verbs. As with そうだ, そうに and そうな carry the meaning of 'seeming like (A)', or 'looking like (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さっき、先輩が怒りそうになってた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Earlier, it seemed like senpai was going to get angry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は忙しそうに仕事をしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is working like he is busy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はどんな仕事でも簡単そうにやるからうらやましいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She does all her work like it is easy, so I am very jealous of her.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: つまらなそうなパーティーには行きません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't go to parties that seem like they would be boring.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: すごい！辛くなさそうに食べるね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Wow! You eat it like it's not spicy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大事じゃなさそうな物は捨ててもいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You can throw away anything that does not look important.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は怒らなそうな顔をしているけどいつも怒っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He does not look like he gets angry a lot, but actually he is always angry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は美味しくなさそうにご飯を食べている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is eating his food like it does not taste good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これが入りそうな箱ってある？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is there a box that looks like it might fit this?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 優しそうに犬を撫でた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She pet the dog in a way that seemed affectionate.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は雨が降りそうな日ですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It looks like today is going to be a rainy day doesn't it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: つまらなそうな話は聞きたくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't want to hear a story that sounds boring.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は分かりやすそうな説明をしたが、まだ理解ができない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He gave an explanation that seemed easy to understand, but I still don't get it.

Name: の様(よう)に
Meaning: Like (Noun), Similar to (Noun)
About: The auxiliary verb ようだ is used for making observations. It states that something is 'in the manner/way of (A)'. Like the auxiliary verb そうだ, ようだ may be used in a similar way to な-Adjectives (can be followed by な when acting as an adjective, or に when acting as an adverb). の is required before these constructions when it is describing a noun. Because よう (coming from the kanji 様(よう)) usually expresses the 'manner' in which something is existing/happening, it is regularly used when the speaker has direct personal experience from which they are drawing a comparison. This means that よう will sound far more confident than みたい, or そう.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ナオミはプロの歌手のように歌う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Naomi sings like a professional singer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この先生は鬼のように怖い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This teacher is as scary as a demon. (Literally, 'scary like a demon')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は鳥のように自由だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am free as a bird. (Literally, 'free like a bird')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近はタブレットのようなスマホが売られています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, tablet-like smartphones are being sold.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スープのようなカレー。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Soup-like curry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そのように使ってはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You cannot use it like that. (in that way)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そのようにお箸を使わないで下さい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please don't use chopsticks like that. (In that way)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このような洋服を探しています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am looking for some clothes like these.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お箸はこのように使います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chopsticks are used like this.

Name: う・よう + と思(おも)う
Meaning: I think I will, I think I shall, Going to, Gonna (Volitional + と思う)
About: The combination of a verb with the auxiliary verb う, or よう, followed by the う-Verb 思(おも)う gives us the common expression ようと思(おも)う. This expression is often translated as 'I think I will (A)', or 'I shall (A)'. It is also close to the casual expression 'I'm gonna (A)'. Remembering that う and よう can have one of three possible meanings in Japanese (as discussed in the よう grammar point), ようと思(おも)う is usually only used to express one of those three. That 'one' is as follows: 意志(いし) - Expresses intentions (has a similar meaning to ～するつもりだ）. This expression is also often used with 思(おも)っている. In these cases, it highlights that the intention of the speaker is something that they regularly think, or have been thinking about for some time. 思(おも)っている may also be used when describing the intentions of another person, as discussed in our lesson about と思(おも)う.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このゲームはもうあきらめようと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think I will give up on this game already. (I have arrived at the conclusion that I will give it up)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は明日から電車で通おうと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think I shall commute by train from tomorrow. (I have arrived at the conclusion that I will do it)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来月、バイクを買おうと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think I will buy a bike next month. (I have arrived at the conclusion that I will buy one)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今晩はレストランで美味しいものを食べようと思っているけど、ナオミも来る？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am thinking of eating something delicious at a restaurant tonight, but do you want to come too, Naomi?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タケル、お前は絶対サチコと別れようと思っているでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takeru, you are definitely thinking of breaking up with Sachiko, aren't you?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日、勉強をしようと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think I will study tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 来年、家を買おうと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think I will buy a house next year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 帰ってから、お菓子を食べようと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think I will eat candy after returning home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日から文法の勉強を始めようと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think I will start studying grammar from today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 息子はレゴを欲しがっているから、買ってあげようと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My son wants lego, so I think I will buy him some.

Name: く・に
Meaning: ～ly (Describing verbs), Adverbs
About:
Adverbs can be used before verbs to indicate the way in which an action is being done. This is translated in a similar way to '~ly' in English, where the adjective 'quick' would become 'quickly' when describing a verb. Both い-Adjectives and な-Adjectives have different rules for being used adverbially.
For い-Adjectives, remove the い and replace it with く. This is also known as the conjunctive form. For な-Adjectives, に will be added directly after. In most cases, adverbs that are modifications of an い-Adjective or a な-Adjective should come directly before the verb they are modifying.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 強く引く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To pull strongly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: きつく閉める。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To close tightly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しく買う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To buy new.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 丁寧に書く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To write neatly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 適当に話す。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To talk irresponsibly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 上手に歌う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To sing well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は彼女に甘く話しかけた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He spoke to her sweetly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 料理を軽く味見した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I lightly tasted the food.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はいつも前向きに考える。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She always thinks positively.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 姉は丁寧にプレゼントを作った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My older sister carefully made the present.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 試験前の夜は早めに寝たほうがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You should go to bed early the night before an exam.

Name: にする・くする
Meaning: Adjective + する, To make something/someone (more)
About: When combined with a な-Adjective, にする (or くする in the case of い-Adjectives) carries the meaning of 'to make more (A)'. Just like the にする grammar point that is used for highlighting decisions, this にする construction implies that the speaker has a high level of control over the action. Basically, this changes the adjective into an adverb, and then uses する to show that the adjective itself is the thing that is being done.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この建物をもっと丈夫にする方法がありますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is there any way to make this building more durable?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 汚い部屋を綺麗にするのは大変だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is difficult to make a dirty room clean.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 風呂を熱くするよ。いい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm going to make the bath hot. Is that okay?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このコーヒーを甘くするために、砂糖をください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please give me sugar to make this coffee more sweet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 頑張って部品を小さくしてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please try your best to make the parts smaller.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 布団を新しくしたから気持ちいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I got a new futon, so it is comfortable. (Literally - I did it new)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 歯医者さんで歯を白くしてもらった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I had the dentist make my teeth whiter. (Literally - Do white)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お花見には温かくして行った方がいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You should make yourself warm when going to a flower-viewing party. (Literally - Do warm)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この部屋を大きくしたいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to make this room bigger. (Literally - Do big)

Name: といい
Meaning: I hope, I wish, You should, It would be good
About: One of the regular uses of the と particle is to express 'if'. However, unlike some other structures (like なら, たら, and ば), と implies that the 'if' result of と is something that will definitely happen, or is a natural consequence of (A) happening. When combined with the い-Adjective いい, it means 'if (A), it would be good'. This construction may be used with any phrase ending in a word in its standard form. Because と expresses a 'certain' outcome, the 'good' in this grammar construction often sounds quite strong, leading to といい regularly being translated closer to 'I hope (A)', or 'I wish (A)'. There are several situations in which this grammar point can be used to express that you are hoping something for yourself, or hoping something for someone else. This is primarily determined by the use of な, or んだけど (hoping for yourself), or ね (hoping for others/mutual benefit).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は学校に行きたくないな～、雪が降るといいな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't want to go to school tomorrow. It would be great if it snows.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今夜のパーティーは楽しいといいね！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hope your party tonight is fun! (Hoping for someone else's sake)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩が言っていることが本当だといいね！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If what senpai is saying is true, it would be good!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 「今夜の夕食は魚だといいな～」と弟が言っていました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My little brother was saying 'I hope dinner tonight is fish'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は晴れるといいな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hope it clears up tomorrow. (Hoping for your own benefit)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日の試合で勝つといいんだけど相手が強いから自信がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hope to win the tournament tomorrow, but since my opponent is formidable, I am not confident. (Hoping for your own benefit)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来週は彼氏が来るといいね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hope your boyfriend comes next week. (Hoping for another's benefit)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日の朝に荷物が届くといいんだけど。（今夜から雪が降るから配達が大変そう）
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hope my package arrives tomorrow morning. (However, it is going to start snowing tonight, so delivery seems like an issue)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 宝くじに当たるといいんだが。（一枚しか買っていないから当たらないと思う）
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hope I win the lottery. (But since I only bought one ticket, I don't think I will)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 試合で勝つといいですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I hope that you can win the game.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたはもっと果物を食べるといいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You should eat more fruit.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 楽しいといいんですが。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I hope it is fun.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの選手が世界一になるといい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I hope that athlete becomes the world's best.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これからもどんどん強くなるといいね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I hope that you can rapidly get stronger (from now).

Name: 様(よう)になる
Meaning: To reach the point that, To come to be that, To turn into
About: When combined with the particle に, and the う-Verb なる, よう expresses that a particular action has reached the point of being completed/able to be completed. Because of this, ようになる is regularly translated as 'to reach the point that (A)', or 'to turn into (A)'. To use ようになる, it will need to be added to the plain-potential, non-past form of a verb. However, ようになる is not limited to being used in affirmative sentences, and may also be used after a verb with ない. This shows that something has reached the point of 'not' being able to be completed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日、漢字の練習をすれば綺麗に漢字を書けるようになります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you practice kanji everyday, you will reach the point where you can write them neatly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 早く走れるようになりたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to reach the point where I can run faster.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 髪を綺麗にカット出来るようになるのが夢です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is my dream to reach the point where I can cut my hair nicely.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自分から行動が出来るようになってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please turn into someone who can act on their own. (Please become more self sufficient)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来年から現金が使えないようになる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From next year, it will reach the point where you will not be able to use cash.(Starting next year, you will not be able to use cash)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来月から会社で喫煙できないようになります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Starting next month, it will reach the point where you will not be able to smoke at the company. (Starting next month, smoking will be banned)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ちゃんと英語を勉強すれば、話せるようになる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you study English diligently, then you will reach a point where you can speak it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 泳げるようになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I reached the point that I was able to swim.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 理解出来るようになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I reached the point that I could understand.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 料理ができるようになりたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to reach a point where I can cook.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １００メートルを１０秒で走れるようになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I reached the point that I could run 100 meters in 10 seconds.

Name: 毎(まい)～の様(よう)に
Meaning: Almost every ~, Nearly every ~, On a ~ basis
About: In a similar way to のように, まい～のように states that something is happening 'in the manner/way of (A)'. まい means 'every' (coming from the kanji 毎(まい)), and will always be followed by (A). (A) being a word that expresses some kind of measurement (usually time). まい～のように is often translated as 'almost every (A)', 'nearly every (A)', or 'on an (A) basis'. Because よう (from the kanji 様(よう)) usually expresses the 'manner' in which something is existing/happening, this phrase literally highlights that something occurs 'in the manner of every (A)', and is therefore up to the interpretation of the listener as to whether the speaker means 'every', or 'almost every'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日のようにポテトチップス食べてるから太ってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I eat potato chips almost everyday, I am starting to gain weight.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 渋谷には毎週のように行っているよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go to Shibuya almost every week.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は８月になると毎年のように平和記念資料館へ行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When August comes, he goes to the peace memorial museum almost every year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ともきさんは仕事前に毎日のように釣りに行った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tomoki-san went fishing almost every day before work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仕事を終わったときは毎晩のようにジムに行く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I go to the gym nearly every night when I finish work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は彼に出会う前は、毎日のように高校をサボっていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Before she met him, she used to skip school almost every day.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はその後、故郷に 毎月のように帰った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After that, he returned to his hometown almost every month.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本では 毎年のように少なくとも１回は地震が起こる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is at least 1 earthquake in Japan nearly every year.

Name: じゃないか
Meaning: Isn't it?, Is it not?
About: When learning じゃない and ではない, we briefly mentioned that these constructions are regularly partnered with the particle か, in order to form a (usually casual) question. In this lesson, we will further explore this usage. Unlike じゃない and ではない (which need to come after a noun or な-Adjective), じゃないか is able to be attached to the end of almost any phrase, to indicate a question. This is very similar to finishing a sentence with 'isn't it?' in English. When じゃないか is too casual, ではないか will be used instead. Despite being more formal, this may sound a bit stiff at times, so is best only used when politeness is expected.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: キヨコはもうすぐ来るんじゃないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Isn't Kiyoko coming soon?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そのカメラは高いんじゃないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That camera is expensive, isn't it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この着物は綺麗じゃないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This kimono is beautiful, isn't it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたの車は私の車より速いじゃないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Your car is faster than my car, isn't it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは台風の影響ではないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is the typhoon's effect, isn't it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遊んでないで明日のテストの勉強をした方がいいんではないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Without mucking around, wouldn't it be better if you studied for the test tomorrow?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そのことじゃなかったか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was about that, wasn't it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう終わるんじゃないか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is already over, isn't it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あれカメラじゃないか！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Isn't that a camera!?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 次の駅で降りるんじゃないか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: The next station is the one we get off at, isn't it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この橋を渡るのが怖いんじゃないか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is scary crossing this bridge, isn't it?

Name: らしい ①
Meaning: Seems like, Apparently, I heard
About: The auxiliary verb らしい is very similar to the auxiliary verbs そうだ and ようだ, in that it expresses something that the speaker 'thinks' is true. This use is known as 推定(すいてい) (presumption) in Japanese. However, despite being a presumption/assumption, らしい usually sounds relatively confident. らしい is regularly translated as 'it seems like (A)', or 'I heard that (A)'. To use らしい, attach it to end of any (non-polite) verb, adjective, or noun. In these examples, らしい indicates that the speaker has some reason to believe that (A) is true. This could be that they heard, saw, or read something, but are still not 100% sure whether their understanding is correct or not. In this way, it sounds very similar to 'it appears as though (A)' in English.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ねえ、聞いた？タケシ君がキヨミちゃんにプロポーズするらしいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hey, did you hear? It seems that Takeshi-kun is proposing to Kiyomi-chan.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カシキさんの彼氏はカッコいいらしいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that Kashiki-san's boyfriend is handsome.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タカギ先輩がさっき言っていた事は本当らしいですよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Apparently the thing that Takagi senpai was talking about earlier is true.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人はフランス人らしいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that person is French.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今朝、新聞で読んだんだけど、明日から雪が降るらしいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I read this in the newspaper this morning, but it appears as though it is going to start snowing tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたは本当に男らしいね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are really manly, aren't you. (You exhibit the typical qualities of a man)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やっと１１月らしい天気になったね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The weather is finally becoming November-like, don't you think? (Weather that is typical of November)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はダイエットを続けるらしいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He seems likely to continue his diet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は姉のタイプじゃないらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It appears that he is not my older sister's type.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたの元彼女が婚約したらしいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that your ex-girlfriend got engaged.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人は会社の社長らしいよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that he is a president of a company.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語を話せなくても、日本に行けるらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that you can go to Japan even if you cannot speak Japanese. (It seems like you can)

Name: ～ておく
Meaning: To do something in advance
About: When the conjunction particle て is followed by the う-Verb 置(お)く in Japanese, it regularly has the meaning of 'to do (A) in advance'. 置(お)く as a verb itself means 'to place something' (down), but also has the nuance 'to leave something alone', or to 'drop something' (like a topic). In this way, ておく can be thought of as meaning 'to do (A) and leave it (until later)'. When using ておく, the 'future event' that the (A) action is being done for may be something that is coming soon, or may be something that the speaker doesn't want to ever come. Due to this, ておく is also regularly used when the speaker is doing something specifically to prevent another thing from happening.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 寝る前に食器を洗っておく。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Before sleeping, I will wash the dishes in advance. (So that it does not need to be done later)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたの財布を鞄に入れておきます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am going to put your wallet in your bag. (So that you won't forget it later)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 予約しておくね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am going to make a reservation in advance. (So that the bookings don't fill up while we wait)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日歯を磨いておくと、虫歯が防ぎます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you brush your teeth everyday (in advance), you will be able to prevent cavities. (That may or may not come in the future)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 机の上に明日の旅行に必要なパスポートを置い とくね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am going to leave the passport we need for the trip tomorrow on top of the table in advance. (So that I won't forget it later)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 水筒に水を汲んどくね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am going to fill this thermos up with water in advance. (So that it is available when I am thirsty)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここにリモコンを置いておくね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will put the remote here (in advance for future use).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ちょっと調べておきます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will do a little research in advance.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 帰ってくるのが遅くなるから、ご飯を作っておいた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I won't get home until late, so I made food in advance.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日のパーティーのためにジュースを買っておきました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I bought juice (in advance) for the party tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今夜明日のお弁当を作っておいてくれますか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Will you make tomorrow's bento (in advance) for me tonight?

Name: が欲(ほ)しい
Meaning: To want something, To be in need of
About: To say that you want something in Japanese, the が particle will be combined with the い-Adjective 欲(ほ)しい 'to want (A)', or 'to desire (A)'. This is exactly the same way as other い-Adjectives behave when describing nouns.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しい車が欲しいけど、今はお金が無いから買えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want a new car, but I don't have any money right now, so I can't buy one.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犬が欲しいけどスペースが無い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want a dog, but I don't have space.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あそこのラーメン屋の餃子を食べたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to eat gyoza from that ramen shop over there.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は彼氏に大事にしてほしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want my boyfriend to treat me like I am important.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 機会がほしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want a chance.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君がほしい！
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want you!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 猫が欲しくないです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't want a cat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私はいい服などがほしいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want things such as nice clothes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 使いやすい箸がほしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want chopsticks that are easy to use.

Name: ～て欲(ほ)しい
Meaning: I want you to
About: As mentioned in our lesson about 'saying that you want something' with がほしい, sometimes ほしい can be used as auxiliary adjective (an adjective that needs to be connected to another word in order to have meaning). In these cases, it will follow the conjunction particle, て. When used this way, てほしい expresses that the speaker 'wants somebody to do something'. To use てほしい, simply change the verb that you 'want someone to do' into its て-form, and then add ほしい.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もう一回説明してほしいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want you to explain it one more time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 皆に俺が書いた漫画を読んでほしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want everyone to read the manga that I wrote.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 手伝ってほしいの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You want me to help you?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: キヨミがタケルに家事を手伝ってほしいと言っていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Kiyomi told Takeru that she wants him to help with chores.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 車で来てほしかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wanted you to come by car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コーラを買ってほしいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want you to buy (me) a cola.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一緒にサッカーをしてほしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want you to play soccer with me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一緒に食べに行ってほしいんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want you to go out to eat with me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 毎日お弁当を作ってほしいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want you to make me a bento every day.

Name: と聞(き)いた
Meaning: I heard that
About: When the particle と is used for citation in Japanese, it is regularly partnered with other verbs, to form set phrases. One of these set expressions is と聞(き)いた, which means 'I heard that (A)'. と聞(き)いた may be used after any phrase expressing the thing that was heard.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来年から先輩が私と同じマンションに住むと聞いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that starting next year, my senpai is going to live in the same apartment that I do.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 北海道の冬は、沖縄の冬より寒いと聞いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that winter in Hokkaido is colder than winter in Okinawa.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達からあなたは歌うのが上手だと聞いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard from a friend that you are good at singing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社長の息子がもう大学生だと聞いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that the son of the company president is already a college student.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたは泳ぐのが下手と聞いたけど、本当なの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that you are bad at swimming, but is that true?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あれが世界一高い山と聞いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that that mountain over there is the tallest in the world.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日はテストがあると聞いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that there is a test tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは無理だと聞いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that this is impossible.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムは旅館に行ったことがないと聞いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that Tom has never been to a ryokan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 市内にあるスーツ屋が安いと聞いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that suit shops in the city are cheap.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 近くの映画館のスクリーンが一番大きいと聞いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that the screens at the movie theater nearby are the biggest.

Name: 聞(き)こえる
Meaning: To be audible, To sound (like), (Can) hear, To be heard
About: 聞(き)こえる is a verb that is often used to describe things that can be heard, or the way in which something is heard. Because of this, the most common translations of this verb are 'to be audible', or 'to sound like (A)'. 聞(き)こえる is an intransitive verb, and literally means 'to give off sound'. When using 聞(き)こえる, (A) will always be followed by が. (A) is considered to be the 'source' of the sound (a noun). However, the 'way that something sounds' will be marked adverbially. This means that an い-Adjective will be changed to its く form, and な-Adjectives/nouns will be followed by に.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車の音が聞こえる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can hear the sound of a car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アニメに出てくる女の子の声は可愛く聞こえるけど、声優はいつもおばさんだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Voices of girls that appear in anime sound cute, but the voice actor is always an old lady.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こう歌うと上手に聞こえる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you sing like this, you will sound good.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電車の音のように聞こえるけどあれは隣の人のいびきだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It sounds like the noise from a train, but it's the neighbor's snoring.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 静かな部屋にいると聞こえるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You can hear it if you are in a quiet room. (Without effort)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 静かな部屋にいると聞けるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are in a quiet room, you can hear it. (If you focus and try to hear the sound)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「今のノック聞こえた？」
「ううん、聞こえなかったよ。空耳じゃない？」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Did you hear a knock just now?'
'Nope, I didn't hear it. Aren't you hearing things?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「西山さんは生まれつき耳が聞こえないんです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Nishiyama has been deaf since birth.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 隣のせきくんはうるさすぎるわよ。彼が音楽を聴くときいつもあたしのアパートに聞こえるわ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: My neighbor Seki is too loud! Whenever he listens to music, I can hear it in my flat!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「教師の声が小さすぎるから何も聞こえないんだよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'The teacher is too quiet, so I cannot hear anything.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「外がうるさいからテレビの音がよく聞こえない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Since it is loud outside, I cannot hear the TV very well.'

Name: 見(み)える
Meaning: To be visible, To seem, To be in sight
About: In the same way that 聞(き)こえる is used to describe things that are 'audible', 見(み)える can be used to describe things that are 'visible'. 見(み)える itself is an intransitive verb, meaning that the object that is 'visible' will be marked with が. When using 見(み)える, (A) will always be followed by が. However, the 'way that something looks' will be marked adverbially. This means that an い-Adjective will be changed to its く form, and な-Adjectives/nouns will be followed by に. This usage of 見(み)える will be covered more in our focused lesson on this particular grammar structure.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この部屋からは富士山が見えます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Mount Fuji can be seen from this room.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遠くに建物が見えるけどあれは何？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can see a building in the distance, but what is it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パンツが見えるくらいズボンを下げて、先生に怒られた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My pants were sagging to the point where my underwear was visible, and I got scolded by my teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここからだと小さく見えるけど、あのビルは１３０メートルもある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From here, the building looks small, but it is 130 meters tall.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの仕事は大変に見えるけど、簡単らしいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That job looks difficult, but I heard that it is easy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部屋を暗くして外を見たら、星が見えるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you make your room dark and look outside, you will see the stars. (Even without trying, you will see them)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部屋を暗くして外を見たら、星が見られるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you make your room dark and look outside, you will see the stars. (If you focus past the clouds, and give your eyes some time to adjust)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 若い時に大きな怪我をしたからなにも見えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because of a big injury when I was young, I cannot see anything at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「遠すぎるから書かれていることが見えないよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Because it is too far, I cannot see what is written there.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「あの看板は大きいので、どこからでもよく見える。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Since that signboard is big, it can be seen from anywhere.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「富士山はとても大きいから遠くからでもよく見える！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Mount Fuji is very big, so it can be clearly seen even from afar!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 雨がやんで、今でははっきりと見えるよ♪
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can see clearly now, the rain is gone♪

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田舎は都会より明かりが少ないから星がよく見える。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is less light in the countryside than in cities, so stars are clearly visible.

Name: 出(だ)す
Meaning: To suddenly begin, To start doing
About: だす, or 出(だ)す in its kanji form is a verb that is regularly attached to the conjunctive form of other verbs. When it is connected in this way, it has the meaning of 'to suddenly do (A)', or 'to burst into (A)'. To use this construction, simply add だす to the ます stem (conjunctive form) of the verb that you want to highlight as happening 'suddenly'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最初から速く走りだすのは体に良くない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not good for your body if you suddenly start running fast.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 転んだ息子が泣きだす前に、あめをあげる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I give my son candy before he bursts into tears after falling.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コンサートで歌手が歌を歌い始める。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At the concert, the singer will start singing. (Something that has been planned to be started)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近、友達が授業中に歌いだした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, my friend suddenly burst into song during class. (Something that happened without any prior plan/expectation)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの子は急に泣き出した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That child suddenly started crying.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 面白いことを今思い出した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I suddenly remembered something funny.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 晴れていたのに、雨が急に降り出した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although it was clear, it suddenly began raining.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夜中に夫が急に餃子を作りだした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My husband suddenly started to make dumplings in the middle of the night.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何も言わないで走り出した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Without saying a word, he suddenly began running.

Name: 代(だい)
Meaning: Teens, Twenties, Thirties, 1910s, 20s/30s
About: The suffix ～代(だい) is used for several different things. One of the most common uses is for highlighting someone's decade of age. In the same way that English says teens, twenties, and thirties. All that is required is adding 代(だい) after the age (in tens), in Japanese. In addition to someone's decade of age, ～代(だい) can be used to express a chronological decade, such as the 1960's, 70's, or 80's. In these cases, 年(ねん)代(だい) will be used after the decade.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １０代の頃によく怒られたよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was scolded often when I was in my teens.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は２０代の頃に沢山旅行をしました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I traveled a lot in my twenties.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 六十代の方はこちらにお並びください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: People in their sixties, please line up over here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ７０年代の音楽が好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like music from the 70s.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ８０年代のファッションはかっこいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Fashion from the 80s is cool.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新生代は哺乳類時代とも言われています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The Cenozoic era is also known as the era of mammals.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 第５代将軍徳川綱吉はとても有名な将軍です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The fifth shogun, Tokugawa Tsunayoshi, is a very famous shogun.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 街頭インタビュー、通行人：「１９８０年代ころからここに住んでいます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Street interview, passerby: 'I have been living here since (around) the 1980s.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 証人が警察官に言う：「泥棒は３０代半ばだったと思います。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A witness speaks to a policeman: 'I think that the thief was in their mid-thirties.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新聞記事：「Ｘさんは昭和５０年代の終わりごろにお金持ちになった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Newspaper article: 'Mr. X became rich toward the end of the 50s of the Showa era.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 漫画のナレーター：「イラめぐみは３０代前半で次長になった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Manga narrator: 'Megumi Ira became vice-director in her early thirties. '

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新聞記事：「２０１０年代の終わりからハイエンドスマホの値段が上がり始めた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Newspaper article: 'High-end smartphone prices started growing since the late 2010s.'

Name: Number + も
Meaning: Emphasis, As ~ as, Not even
About: The adverbial particle も is often used for labeling (A) as part of a category, when it would not usually be considered part of that group. In this way, it emphasizes that (A)'s inclusion is something that is surprising/unexpected in some way. When も is used after a specific number + counter, it shows that the number itself is surprising. This can be when the actual number is lower, or higher than what was expected. Due to this, も can translate as 'as much as (A)', or 'not even (A)', and other similar phrases in this expression. At first glance, this may seem different than も's translation as 'too' or 'also', but in those cases, も is also just pointing out that the something unexpected is part of whatever group was initially highlighted. The above sentence just shows that the (B) speaker is unexpectedly putting themselves in the group that the (A) speaker initially only considered themselves to be a part of.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １２時間も仕事をしたから疲れた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I worked as long as 12 hours, so I am tired.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その携帯２０万円もしたの？！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That cellphone cost you as much as 200,000 yen?!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は一回も地下鉄に乗ったことが無い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have never taken the subway, not even once.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私も行きたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to go too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １０万円も払わなくてはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have to pay as much as 100,000 yen!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １０回もやったけど、できなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I tried to do it as many as 10 times but couldn't do it!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アメリカまで１５時間もかかりました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It took as long as 15 hours to get to America!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １０時間も運転したけど、あまり疲れていない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I did as much as 10 hours of driving, but I am not really that tired.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「掃除をして」って何回も言ったでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I told you to clean many times, right? (as many as)

Name: 殆(ほとん)ど
Meaning: Almost all, Most, Hardly any, Few (Adverbial noun)
About: The adverb ほとんど is used in many situations in Japanese, and often translates as 'most', 'hardly any', 'almost all', and similar expressions. The nuance will always depend on the rest of the sentence. The most accurate translation for the word ほとんど itself is simply 'almost', where the thing that it is describing is always considered to be a full group, rather than a single thing. As with many other adverbs that highlight an 'amount' in Japanese, ほとんど can modify a whole phrase, or can be used before の, to further specify a single noun. In negative sentences, ほとんど translates as 'hardly any'. This is mainly due to the 'full group' that ほとんど is describing being highlighted as almost 'not' existing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 宿題はほとんど終わっているよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Most of my homework is done.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 弁当はほとんど食べてないけど、おやつは全部食べた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I didn't eat most of my lunch, but I ate all the snacks.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ほとんどの人は私の名前を読めません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Most people can't read my name.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ほとんどの大学生は親と住んでいます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Most college students live with their parents.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年は屋台がほとんどないね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are hardly any food stalls this year.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 週末に出かけることはほとんどないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hardly go out during the weekends.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: みんなは、ほとんど帰りました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Almost everyone has gone home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ハンドバッグがほとんど売り切れでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The handbags were almost all sold out.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は宿題がほとんどない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is hardly any homework today. (almost/mostly none)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この湖はほとんど浅いと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This lake is mostly shallow, I think.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: えっ！この魚ほとんど匂いがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Huh?! This fish hardly has any smell. (almost/mostly none)

Name: そんな
Meaning: Such a・Kind of, Something like ~
About: One of the most common ways to convey that something is 'like' something else in casual conversation, is through the use of そんな, こんな, あんな, or どんな (when asking a question). These are not officially words themselves, but are abbreviations that come from そのような, このような, あのような, and どのような. To use this casual expression, simply say it directly before the noun that you are describing, or enquiring about. Because these abbreviations originally come from a longer (more formal) variation, that form may also be used in situations where you would like to sound a little bit more polite.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんな言い方してはいけません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You should not phrase it like that.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな高いものはもらえないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't accept a gift this expensive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんな大人にはなりたくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't want to become an adult like that.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんな靴が欲しい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What kind of shoes do you want?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そのような商品はないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We don't have a product like that.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このような場合にはどうすればいいですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What should we do in a situation like this?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのような運転をしないでください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please do not drive like that.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どのような商品をお探しですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What kind of product are you looking for?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんな車がいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: What kind of car is good?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんな技術は珍しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A skill such as that is rare. (close to listener)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんな高いのは必要ですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is such an expensive one necessary? (close to speaker)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんな畳が大体寝やすい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tatami mats like these are generally easy to sleep on. (close to speaker)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あんな駐車場は使いにくい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A parking lot like that (over there) is hard to use. (far from both speaker and listener)

Name: 各(かく)
Meaning: Each, Every, Respective, Various
About: One of the slightly more formal ways to say that something is happening 'each', or 'every' (A) in Japanese, is by using the prefix 各(かく). While there is no strict rule for when this prefix can be used, it is almost always seen before words of Chinese origin (kanji compounds), or katakana words. Although this kanji is used to mark 'each', it is very rarely used to mark units of time. The most common/natural usage of 各(かく) is for identifying things that are part of a sequence. For example: Each/Every stop, on a train line that has many stops. Each/Every page, in a book that has many pages. Each/Every floor, in a building that has many floors. Each/Every house, in a street of many houses.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このエレベーターは各階で止まります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This elevator will stop at each floor.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このホテルは各部屋に洗濯機がついている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This hotel has a washing machine in every room.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここは正月になると日本各地からの観光客でいっぱいになる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When it becomes New Year's, this place is filled with tourists from each and every place in Japan.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 弁当は各々で用意してきてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please come prepared with your own lunch. (Each person should bring their own lunch)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 各ファイルを各自アップロードする必要がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is necessary to upload each file individually.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このバスは各バス停に止まります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This bus stops at each station.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 各自で弁当を持ってきてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please bring your own respective bento (individually).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この書類の各ページをプリントアウトしてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please print each page of this document.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 各部屋に冷房がついている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Each room is equipped with air conditioning.

Name: 以上(いじょう) ①
Meaning: More than (or equal to), Over・(and) above, Any more・Greater, Exceeding
About: In order to mark something as 'equal to, or more than (A)', 以上(いじょう) will be used. This is simply a combination of the kanji 以(い) which means 'by means of', and 上(じょう) 'above'. This expression may also be translated as 'greater than (A)', or 'exceeding (A)'. To use 以上(いじょう), attach it to the amount that you want to highlight as the 'minimum' amount. 以上(いじょう) is also regularly used as a statement that translates roughly as 'the end', or 'that's it', and is a very common way to say that something has finished. Although saying 'the end' would sound a bit rude in English in this situation, it is completely natural in Japanese, and literally means 'the above (list of things I said) is all'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 七十歳以上の人は運転をしない方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would be better if people over the age of 70 didn't drive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コンサートには５００人以上のファンが集まった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: More than 500 fans gathered at the concert.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: え～っと、ビッグマックのセットとクォーターパウンダーの単品とナゲットの３０ピースを下さい。以上です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Uhhh, Can I have a Big Mac meal, a quarter pounder, and 30 nuggets? That's all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その時に１００人以上も参加した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At that time, more than 100 people attended.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 六歳以上。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Ages 6 and over. (and older)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これ以上はもう聞きたくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't want to listen to this any more (than this).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これ以上運動をしたくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't want to exercise more than this.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それ以上私のお金を使わないで。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please don't use any more of my money over that amount.

Name: 以下(いか)
Meaning: Less than (or equal to), Under・(and) below, Any less・fewer, Not exceeding
About: In order to mark something as 'equal to, or less than (A)', 以下(いか) will be used. This is simply a combination of the kanji 以(い) which means 'by means of', and 下(か) 'below'. This expression may also be translated as 'under (A)', or 'fewer than (A)'. To use 以下(いか), attach it to the amount that you want to highlight as the 'maximum' amount. Similarly to the way that 以上(いじょう) can be used to mark 'everything up until now', 以下(いか) can and often is used to highlight 'everything after now', 'the rest', or 'the following'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １７歳以下の方は保護者の方と来てください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For those of the ages 17 and under, please come with a guardian.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この車は３０万円以下だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This car was under 300,000 yen.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 以下同文。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The rest is the same. (Usually seen in documents to notify the reader that the rest of the document basically repeats what has already been said)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 空港には以下のものを持って来てください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please bring the following to the airport.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この家は２０００万円以下です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This house costs less than 20 million yen. (or equal to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 五千円以下のコーヒーメーカーがないんですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Are there no coffee makers below 5000 yen? (not exceeding)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 残っているジュースは十本以下だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are fewer than 10 juices left. (under・not more than)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これ以下の値段がありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are none under this price. (less than or equal to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コンサートに行ったのは１００人以下。
Questions.EnglishHTML: 100 or less people went to the concert.

Name: 以外(いがい)
Meaning: Except・besides, Other than, With the exception of
About: In order to mark something as 'except (A)', or 'besides (A)', 以外(いがい) will be used. This construction is a combination of the kanji 以(い) which means 'by means of', and 外(がい) 'outside'. This expression can most accurately be translated as 'with the exception of (A)', or 'everything outside of (A)'. To use 以外(いがい), attach it to the thing that you want to highlight as being the 'all inclusive' amount/area.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は和食以外のものが食べたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today I want to eat something other than Japanese food.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タロウはゲーム以外に趣味はあるの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Taro, do you have any other interests besides gaming?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たかし君もアニメ好きなの？ちょっと意外だね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takashi-kun, do you like anime too? I'm a little surprised.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺こう見えても意外に肉を食べないの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It may come off as a surprise based on how I look, but I don't eat meat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: メアリー以外、誰も来なかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No one except Mary came.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それ以外、聞いてないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I haven't heard anything other than that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 納豆以外何でも食べられる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can eat anything other than natto.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は言われたこと以外何もしないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He will not do anything other than what he is told.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それ以外に好きなことないの？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Don't you have anything you like besides that?

Name: ずっと ①
Meaning: Continuously, All throughout, Entire time, Ever (since), The whole time, All the way
About: The adverb ずっと has two primary meanings in Japanese. The first is that something keeps going in a constant state, without ever stopping/resting, and the second is to emphasize an amount of something. We will examine the first meaning in this lesson. To use ずっと, add it to the beginning of the phrase that you want to highlight as being ongoing. Alternatively, ずっと can be used after から, to express that something has been continuing 'ever since' some specific event/point in time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ずっとゲームをしないでたまには勉強もする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Instead of continuously gaming, I occasionally also study.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ずっと立ってたから足が痛い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was standing the whole time, so my feet hurt.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日からずっと寝てないからメチャ眠い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I haven't slept at all since yesterday, so I am extremely tired.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 朝からずっと何も食べていないからお腹が空いたよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I haven't eaten anything at all since morning, so I am hungry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「ずっと前から日本に行きたかったです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I have wanted to go to Japan for a long time.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 朝からずっと忙しいですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have been continuously busy since morning.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は子供の頃から彼にずっと会っていません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have not met him ever since I was a child.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私達は結婚してからずっとここに住んでいます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Ever since we got married, we have always lived here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 冬休みはノートパソコンを買えるようにずっと働いていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I worked all throughout winter vacation in order to be able to buy a new laptop.

Name: 大体(だいたい)
Meaning: Most・mostly, Adequately・generally, For the most part, Roughly・approximately, In the first place
About: 大体(だいたい) is an adverb that is used to highlight the 'main point' of something in Japanese, and therefore has several different nuances. 大体(だいたい) will regularly be translated as 'mostly', 'generally', or 'for the most part'. As with other adverbs that highlight amounts, 大体(だいたい) can be used to modify entire phrases, or can be used directly before a noun as 大体(だいたい)の + noun. In a similar way to そもそも, a noun/adverb which means 'in the first place', 大体(だいたい) can also have this meaning. This nuance is frequently quite obvious, as the rest of the sentence will highlight a desired outcome that unfortunately did not happen.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: だいたいでいいから何時くらいに着くか教えて。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since a general time is okay, can you let me know around when you will arrive?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 水曜日はだいたい５時に起きています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On Wednesdays, I generally wake up at 5 am.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: だいたいの人たちが薔薇という漢字を書けません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Most people do not know how to write the kanji 'bara'. (薔薇（ばら） is the kanji for 'rose')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: だいたいなんでお前がここにいるの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why are you here in the first place? (No one wants you here)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: と言うことは私たちが言っていることはだいたい一緒なのね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In that case, what we are both saying is the same in essence.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「日本語が大体わかる。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I roughly understand Japanese.' (for the most part)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「大体３時間くらいでできます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'It will be ready in approximately 3 hours.' (roughly)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「彼女は大体の状況を知っています。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'She has the general idea of the situation.' (adequate・mostly)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
焼きたてパンについて話しているカップル、
彼女：「どう？」
彼氏：「大体いいと思うんだけど、」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Couple talking about freshly baked bread:
Girlfriend: 'How is it?'
Boyfriend: 'I think it is mostly good, but…'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電話にでている子供：「父は大体５時ごろ帰ります。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Child answering the phone: 'Dad usually comes home around 5.'

Name: の中(なか)で
Meaning: In, Among, Within
About: Just like the grammar point の中(なか)で～が一番(いちばん)～, this grammar point may be used when marking one thing from within a group, and then further describing it. The only difference is that の中(なか)で by itself simply marks something as being 'among (A)', or 'within (A)', rather than being the 'most (A)'. の中(なか)で is also frequently used to describe things that are happening within a place, and will translate simply as 'in (A)', in these cases.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ラーメンの中では味噌ラーメンが好き。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Among ramen, I like the miso type.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このバンドの中では誰が好き？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Who do you like in this band?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車の中で夕食を食べました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I ate dinner in my car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この三つの中では、赤色が好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Among these three, I like the red one. (within)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: フルーツの中で、イチゴとかパインが好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Among all fruits, I like strawberries and pineapple. (within)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この中で一つを選んでください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please choose one from among these. (within)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 公園の中で子供達が遊んでいた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The children were playing in the park. (Within)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 全部の国の中で、一番行ってみたいのはどこ？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Among all countries, which one do you want to go to the most? (within)

Name: 様(よう) + に・な
Meaning: As・like, Just like
About: We have seen many cases now where the auxiliary verb ようだ may be modified slightly to show that something is being done 'in a way' that will bring about a specific outcome. In this lesson, we will look at how ような (when used with nouns), or ように (when used with verbs) may be used with almost any noun/verb, to show that they are being done/existing in a particular manner. Sometimes, this structure is used purely to express the speaker's uncertainty about whether (B) really is being done/existing in the way of (A). In these cases, ように (or ような) will be translated as 'as if', or 'as though'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は亀のように走る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He runs like a turtle.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: バケツをひっくり返したように雨が降っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is raining like a bucket was flipped over. (It's pouring rain)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の車は工場のような臭いがする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: His car smells like a factory. (His car has an industrial smell)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: キトウ先生は鬼のような怒り方をする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The way Kito-sensei gets mad is like a demon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は今、人を殺すような目をしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Right now, his eyes look as if he is about to kill someone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は食べすぎたような顔をしている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He looks like he ate too much.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたが言ったように、事故が起こった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: An accident happened just like you said.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 十代に戻ったように楽しかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was fun, just like being in my teens again.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君が言うように綺麗ですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is beautiful, just like you say.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 驚くような景色を見た。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I saw mind-blowing-like scenery.

Name: (Amount) + は
Meaning: At least, Sort of, Or so
About: The は particle has two primary functions. The first is to mark the topic of a sentence, as learned very early in our Japanese language journey. However, the second common usage of は is to highlight contrast (making a comparison). When は is used after a number/counter, it regularly has this comparison meaning. This can be translated as 'or so', or 'at least'. Before は, the counter is regularly followed by くらい (or ぐらい). This just softens the statement, and further highlights the 'or so' meaning. Despite being translated as 'at least', the comparative meaning of は itself is what creates the nuance of this grammar structure. The thing before は is being highlighted as an amount, while also implying that there are other amounts. This implication of another amount makes は sound as if it could mean 'as opposed to (B)'. So in essence, this grammar structure sounds like 'As for (A), as opposed to (B)', where (B) is not usually mentioned.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ディズニーランドには年に５回は行っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go to Disneyland at least 5 times a year.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は毎日、テレビを５時間は見ている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every day, I watch TV for 5 hours or so.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ２キロくらいはあると思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think it is at least 2 kilograms.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 倉敷には１回ぐらいは行った方がいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You should go to Kurashiki at least once.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: クリスマスぐらいは家に帰って来てね？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Won't you come home for Christmas, at least?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 少なくともこれぐらいは持って行ってください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At the very least, at least bring this with you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 囚人のうち少なくとも６人は逃げたらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that at least 6 prisoners have escaped.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この食べ物は少なくとも床に３秒は落ちていたから食べられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This food was on the floor for at least 3 seconds, so I can't eat it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 付き合っているんだから手ぐらいはつないだでしょうね？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since you are going out, you were at least holding hands, right?

Name: 何(なん) + (Counter) + か
Meaning: Some, Several, A few
About: The expression なん + counter + か in Japanese is a way of highlighting an uncertain number of something, and comes across similarly to 'some', 'several', or 'a few' in English. Literally, the meaning is much closer to 'what + counter + I wonder?', as it shows the speaker's uncertainty about the number. In addition to なん; いく, from the kanji 幾(いく) (how many/much) may be used as part of this construction. While both are fairly common, 幾(いく) is more common as part of set expressions, like 幾(いく)ら (how much) and 幾(いく)つ (how many/old), while なん is more common for counting specific things, like people. Both 何(なん) and 幾(いく) are regularly seen in plain hiragana and their kanji forms, so it is worth remembering both.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこには何回か行ったことがあると思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think I have been there several times.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ごめん、紙を何枚かちょうだい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sorry, may I have some paper?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この車はいくらですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: How much is this car?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: マリちゃんは幾つになったの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: How old did Mari-chan turn?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いらない本を何冊か妹にあげた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I gave several books that I didn't need to my sister.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前は何者だ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Who are you! (What kind of person are you)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このアニメのなん話かを見たと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think I have seen a few episodes of this anime.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昨日なん台かの車が盗まれたらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that several (some) cars were stolen yesterday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 選手のなん人かが負傷した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Some athletes were wounded.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なん冊かの本が山のように床に積まれていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Some books were piled on the floor like a mountain.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なん本かの高級な木の幹を製材所に届けた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I sent some high grade tree trunks to the sawmill.

Name: 真(ま)っ
Meaning: Completely, Exactly, Right
About: The prefix ま, coming from the kanji 真(ま) (true), is attached to words in Japanese to express that something is 'completely', 'exactly', 'genuinely' (A). Depending on the word that follows 真(ま), several different conjugation patterns will be used. This conjugation depends on which column the first kana of the word after 真(ま)comes from. ま comes from the ま, み, む, め, も column, for example. When linked with a ま column, or な column word, 真(ま) will become 真(ま)ん. When linked with a か column, さ column, or しゃ sound word, 真(ま) will become 真(ま)っ. When linked with a は column, 真(ま) will become 真(ま)っ, and the first kana of the following word will change to a 'P' sound.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この猫は真ん丸でかわいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This cat is completely circular and cute. (This cat is so fat that it is cute)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 真ん中にある本をとってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please take the book in the middle.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 体が真っ赤になるくらい お風呂が熱かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The bath was so hot that my body went completely red.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サルが木から真っ逆さまに落ちた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The monkey fell completely upside down from the tree.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 道が雪で真っ白になった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The road turned completely white with snow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ちょっと、何で真っ裸なの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Wait, why are you completely naked?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 真っ昼間からこんな話をするの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are going to talk about this in the middle of the day? (Are you seriously going to talk about something like this in the middle of the day?)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 空が真っ青できれいだね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The sky is completely blue and beautiful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 顔が真っ赤になってるよ、大丈夫？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Your face is completely red, are you okay?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 道の真ん中に鹿がいた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There was a deer right in the middle of the road.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 真ん丸の円を描ける人がいますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is there anyone who can draw an exact circle? (perfectly circular)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この道路を真っ直ぐ行ってください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please go (exactly) straight down this street.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は竹を刀で真っ二つに切った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He cut the bamboo right in two with a sword.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 急に立ったから、目の前 が真っ暗になってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I stood up suddenly, everything went completely black.

Name: (Number) + しか〜ない
Meaning: No more than, Not exceeding, As few as・as little as, Only
About: The adverbial particle しか is often compared to だけ, in that it also expresses 'only'. However, unlike だけ, しか can only be used in negative statements. Due to this, しか～ない is regularly translated as 'there's only (A)', or 'there's nothing but (A)'. しか～ない may be used to express numbers, or nouns. In this lesson we will examine numbers. To use this construction, the number that you want to express as being 'all that exists' will go before しか, then しか will be followed by a verb in its ない, or ありません form.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は五キロしか走れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can only run 5 km today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は１００円しか持っていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have nothing but 100 yen on me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日はたくさんの宿題があるから２時間しか遊べない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have a lot of homework today, so I can only hang out for 2 hours.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫の中には色々な物が入っていたけど、リンゴだけを取り出した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There were a lot of things in the refrigerator, but I just took out an apple.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫の中にはリンゴしかなかったから、リンゴを食べた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Apples were all that was in the refrigerator, so I ate an apple.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女にはまだ１回しか会っていない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have met her no more than once.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 計画書は１枚しか提出出来ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You can submit only one plan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 髪の毛が３本しか生えていない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He has no more than three hairs on his head.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一ヶ月しか期間がないのに、あなたは変われるの？
Questions.EnglishHTML: You only have (the period of) one month. Can you change?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼には１度しか勝っていない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He has won no more than once.

Name: は～の一(ひと)つだ
Meaning: 〜 is one of (many) 〜
About: In order to express that something is only one thing from within a larger category, the construction ～は～の一(ひと)つだ will be used. In this expression, (A), the thing that there is one of, will be followed by は. After this, (B) + の一(ひと)つだ will highlight the broader category to which (A) belongs. In this grammar point, の一(ひと)つ is a standard counter. This means that other counters can and will be used, when they are more appropriate than 一(ひと)つ.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アンドロイドはスマートフォンのＯＳの一つだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Android is one of (many) smartphone operating systems.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電車は乗り物の一つです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Trains are one of (many) vehicles.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼も家族の一人だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is also one member of my family.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トマトはフルーツの一種だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tomatoes are one of many types of fruits.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このクレヨンはこのセットの一本だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This crayon is part of this set.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ホンダは車のメーカーの一つだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Honda is one of (many) car makers.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アイフォンはスマートフォンの一つだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: iPhone is one of (many) smartphones.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: マクドナルドはファストフードの一つだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: McDonald's is one of many fast food chains.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コカコーラはコーラの一つだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Coca-cola is one of many colas.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: キリスト教は宗教の一つだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Christianity is one of many religions.

Name: ない～はない
Meaning: There is not ~ that is not/does not
About: ～ない～はない is an example of a double negative in Japanese, and is a grammar construction that requires careful attention in order not to incorrectly interpret. Both the い-Adjective (形容詞(けいようし)), and auxiliary verb forms of ない may be used in this construction, depending on what type of word is being negated. Let's take a look at a few examples. Literally, this grammar pattern is very similar to 'there isn't an (A) that doesn't (B)' in English.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼にはピアノで弾けない曲はない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no song that he can't play on the piano.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は美味しくない食べ物は食べない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't eat food that does not taste good.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は安くない靴は買わない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He doesn't buy shoes that aren't cheap.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私に書けない漢字はない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no kanji that I cannot write.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は漢字を書けなくはないけど...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that I can't write kanji, but…

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 本当に書けない漢字はないの？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is there really not a single kanji that you cannot write?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夢を見ない人はいないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is not a single person who doesn't dream, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 紙を使わない会社は一つもありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is not a single company that does not use paper.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あそこのカフェで美味しくないコーヒーは絶対ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no coffee at that cafe that is not delicious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強していない文法はなかったから、テストには合格しました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There was not a single grammar point that I did not study, so I passed the test.

Name: 少(すこ)しも～ない
Meaning: Not even a little, Not at all, Not in the least, Never
