About: Coming from the word 少(すこ)し (a little bit), すこしも～ない is an expression which translates almost exactly to 'not even a little bit (A)' in English. Due to this, it indicates that there is 'no (A)', '(A) never happens', or 'not (A) at all', depending on whether a verb or an adjective is the word that is being negated. すこしも can come at the beginning of the sentence, or directly before the word/statement it is referring to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は人が多いからすこしも離れないでね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are a lot of people today, so don't stray off. Not even a little bit.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何このケーキ、すこしもおいしくない！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What is this cake, it's not even a little good!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女の彼氏はすこしもイケメンではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Her boyfriend is not even a little handsome.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今月もお金がすこしもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't have any money this month either.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この景色は少しも綺麗ではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This scenery is not pretty at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの店のケーキは少しも美味しくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That store's cake is not delicious in the least.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 少しも暑くないのに、汗をかいている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not in the least bit hot, but I am sweating.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ガソリンの値段が少しも下がらないね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The price of gasoline has not dropped in the least.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今の話が少しも理解出来なかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I did not understand the conversation in the least.

Name: 少(すく)なくない
Meaning: Quite a few, Quite a lot, Many, Not a few, Not a little
About: Another expression that utilizes the 少(すく) kanji (meaning 'few'), in its い-Adjective form, is 少(すく)なくない. This is an example of a double negative in Japanese, as 少(すく)ない 'a few' is being negated in 少(すく)なくない. Therefore, the meaning is 'not a few', and translates more closely to 'quite a few', or 'quite a lot'. To use this expression, simply pair a noun with は, が, or も, and then follow it with 少(すく)なくない (or 少(すく)なくありません).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 漢字を書くのが嫌いな子は少なくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are quite a few children that dislike writing kanji.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は好き嫌いが少なくないんです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have many things that I like and dislike.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 寝る前にお菓子を食べる人も少なくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are also many people that eat snacks before they sleep.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年は去年よりも雨が降る日が少ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Compared to last year, there are fewer days with rain this year.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 天気が悪い時に釣りに行くのは危ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is dangerous to go fishing when the weather's bad.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 手が汚いから手を洗う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My hands are dirty so I will wash them.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アニメと漫画が好きな人は少なくないですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are quite a few people that like anime and manga.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ハセガワ：「僕は友達が少なくないよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Hasegawa: 'I have quite a few friends.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 朝ごはんを食べない人も少なくないです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are quite a few people who do not eat breakfast.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そう思っている人も少なくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Quite a few people think like that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女の欲しがっているものが少なくないんだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are many things that she wants.

Name: 場合(ばあい)は
Meaning: In the event of, In the case of
About: 場合(ばあい)は is a phrase in Japanese that is often translated to 'in the event of (A)', or 'in the case of (A)'. It can be used with almost any type of word, but will require な when following a な-Adjective, or の when following a noun. 場合(ばあい) by itself is usually translated as 'case', or 'situation'. It is frequently used to highlight a hypothetical situation, or a viewpoint/characteristic of another person. When 場合(ばあい)は is highlighting a viewpoint/characteristic of another person, this is almost always in contrast/comparison to something that is already being discussed. This is an example of the contrastive nuance of the は particle.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: オートバイに乗る場合はヘルメットをかぶってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In the event that you will ride a motorbike, please wear a helmet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 咳がひどい場合はマスクをしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In the case that you have a bad cough, please wear a mask.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事が大変な場合は私に電話をしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In the case that your work is difficult, call me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の場合は冬が好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In my case, I like winter. (Personally I like winter)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 浅草駅に行く場合はどの電車で行った方がいいですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I were to go to Asakusa station, which train would be the best to take?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたの場合、こういう時はどうする？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In a situation like this, what would you do?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 学校に行く場合は早く起きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I were to go to school, I would wake up early. (Unnatural Japanese, unless going to school is an unusual thing for this person)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 学校に行くときは早く起きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I go to school, I wake up early. (Natural Japanese, if going to school is a regular thing for this person)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あしたのパーティーに来る場合は飲み物を持って来てください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In the event that you will come to tomorrow's party, please bring some drinks. (Focuses on the possibility of coming)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あしたのパーティーに来るときに飲み物を持って来てください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When you come to the party, bring some drinks with you. (Focuses on the request)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 危険な場合はここに電話をしてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In the event that it is dangerous, please call me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の犬の場合は家族と一緒です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In the case of my dog, he is like family.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遊んでいる場合は、危ないことをしないで。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In the case that you are playing, don't do anything dangerous.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この商品が売り切れの場合は買えないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You cannot buy this product in the event that it is out of stock.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 山が崩れている場合は運転をしないでください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In the event of the mountain crumbling, please do not drive. (In the event of a landslide)

Name: ～て (Casual Request)
Meaning: Please do for me (Casual request)
About: In casual speech, てください is often shortened to て. This usually comes across as being a friendly way to say 'please do (A)', but may sound like a very soft order, so is best used with friends/toward people of lower status. This nuance of て is usually able to be identified by appearing at the end of a sentence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 午後からお客さんが来るから部屋を片付けて。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We have guests coming over during the afternoon so please clean up your room. (Said by a parent to a child)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ペン貸して。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Can you please lend me a pen?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 駅まで走っていって...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I ran to the station and…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 約束を守れなくてすみません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am sorry that I wasn't able to keep my promise.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タケシのジャケットに水をこぼしちゃってごめん。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takeshi, I am sorry that I spilled water on your jacket.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「頼むよ。落ち着いて。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I beg you! (Please) calm down!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「こしょうを取って。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: '(Please) pass me the pepper.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「誰か助けて！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: '(Please) somebody help me!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
母親：「部屋を片付けてね。」
子供：「うん。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Mother: '(Please) tidy up your room, okay?'
Child: 'Okay.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「このポスターを貼っておいて。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: '(Please) put up this poster.'

Name: ～てよかった
Meaning: I'm glad that
About: When て (or で when following ない) is paired with the past form of the い-Adjective, いい; てよかった, なくてよかった, or ないでよかった will have the meaning of 'I'm glad that (A)' (when positive), or 'I'm glad that I didn't (A)' (when negative). The primary difference between なくてよかった and ないでよかった in this expression, is that ないでよかった will be used far more frequently in casual speech. Comparatively, なくてよかった tends to be reserved for books, and may even be considered old-fashioned by some people.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やっぱり今日来てよかったね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Actually, I'm glad that we came today, don't you think?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの携帯を買わなくて良かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm glad that I didn't buy that cellphone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの時にお前と別れないで良かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm glad that we didn't break up that one time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩、今日の会議で余計なことを言わなくて良かったですね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Senpai, aren't you glad that you didn't say anything more at the meeting today? (A bit more formal, focuses on expressing reasons or results)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 行った人皆が風邪引いたの？昨日のパーティーへ行かないでよかった！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Everyone that went caught a cold? I'm glad that I didn't go to last night's party! (A bit more casual, focus more on 'not doing' something)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ダイエットを諦めなくてよかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm glad that I didn't give up on my diet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このレストランにまた来てよかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm glad that we came to this restaurant again.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強をしてよかったです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am glad that I studied.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日はデザートを食べなくてよかったです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am glad that I didn't eat dessert today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このバスに間に合ってよかったです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am glad that I made it in time for this bus.

Name: せる・させる (Causative)
Meaning: To make/let/have (somebody do something)
About: In order to express that someone was 'made to do', or 'let do' something, the auxiliary verbs せる and させる will be used. The meaning that せる and させる will convey (when attached to a verb) is called 使役(しえき) (causative, employment, or using) in Japanese. A common misconception is that せる and させる are standard conjugations of each verb. However, these auxiliary verbs should be thought of as having their own meaning, in a similar way to how たい, ない, だ, です, and other auxiliaries each have their own meanings. In order to use these grammar structures, remove the る from る-Verbs, and then add させる. For う-Verbs, change the last kana to the あ sound kana from within the same column (except for う, which becomes わ), and then add せる (る becomes ら, む becomes ま, く becomes か, etc.). As usual, する and 来(く)る have special conjugation rules. する will be replaced completely by させる (in a similar way to how できる completely replaces する in the 'potential' form). 来(く)る will become 来(こ)させる.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子に野菜を食べさせる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I make my son eat vegetables.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達にトマトを育てさせる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I make my friend grow tomatoes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 忘年会で先輩たちが後輩に歌を歌わせた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At the end of year party, the seniors made the juniors sing a song.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達が私の携帯を壊したので、新しいのを買わせます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since my friend broke my phone, I will make them buy me a new one.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 嫌な仕事は後輩にさせる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I let my juniors do the work that I don't want to do.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 親を心配させることは、してはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You should not do anything that would make your parents worry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夜遅くに会社に来させるのはよくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not good to make people come to the company late at night.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犬を呼んで、こっちに来させる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To call the dog and make it come to you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰かに心配をさせる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To let someone worry about you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰かを心配させる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To make someone worry about you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お兄ちゃんが妹を泣かせた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My older brother made my younger sister cry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 学校に行きたくない子を行かせる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Someone) makes the kid who doesn't want to go to school go.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達を朝４時に起こして、帰らせた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I woke my friend up at four in the morning and made him go home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は生徒に勉強することを楽しませます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I make/let students enjoy studying.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達を無理やりお化け屋敷に行かせたから、怒られた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was yelled at because I insistently made my friend go to a haunted house.

Name: と言(い)ってもいい
Meaning: You could say, You might say
About: と言(い)ってもいい is a common expression in Japanese which literally means 'even if you say (A), it is good/ok'. This is translated more naturally as 'you could say (A)', or 'you might say (A)'. As the と at the beginning of the phrase is the 'quotation' use of the と particle, と言(い)ってもいい may be used after almost any statement that the speaker wants to quote.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は一日に七食も食べているから、一日中食べていると言ってもいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person eats 7 meals a day, so you could say that he is eating all day.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そのスポーツは危ないと言ってもいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You could say that sport is dangerous.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人の仕事のやり方は丁寧だと言ってもいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You could say that how that person works is careful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はすごい優しい人だと言ってもいいでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is safe to say that she is a very nice person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このワインは飲みやすいといってもいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: One might say that this is a palatable wine.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はとてもいい人だといってもいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You might say that he is a very good person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの子は、魚のように泳げるといってもいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You might say that that kid can swim like a fish.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は全然日本語が出来ないといってもいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You could say that he can't speak a word of Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの二人が付き合っているといってもいいだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You might say that they are together. (Dating)

Name: ～ても・でも
Meaning: Even if, Even though
About: The combination of the conjunction particle て (or the case-marking particle で), with the adverbial particle も, often has the nuance of 'even if (A)', or 'even though (A)'. To use this structure, simply conjugate a verb or い-Adjective into its て-form, and then add も. For nouns and な-Adjectives, でも will be used instead. This grammar pattern may also be used for highlighting negative sentences, and will translate similarly to 'even if not (A)', or 'even though not (A)' in these cases.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人に言っても何も変わりません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Nothing will change even if you talk to him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お茶は冷たくても美味しいから好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like tea because it tastes good even if it is cold.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は仕事が大変でも諦めません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She will not give up on work even if it is difficult.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 安い電子レンジでも弁当は温められます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even with a cheap microwave you can warm up bentos.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは明日までに終わらなくてもいいから。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's okay even if you don't finish this by tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 頭が痛くなくてもこの薬を飲んでください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please take this medicine, even if your head doesn't hurt.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 野菜は好きじゃなくても食べた方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if you don't like vegetables, you should eat them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運転手じゃなくてもシートベルトをしなくてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if you're not the driver, you need to wear your seatbelt.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 試合に負けても、諦めません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if I lose the game, I won't quit.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トレーニングをしても、痩せない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if I work out, I don't lose weight.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 靴下を履いても、足が冷たいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if I wear socks, my feet get cold.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たくさんサラダを食べても、お腹いっぱいにならないんですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if I eat a lot of salad, I don't get full.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供に何回も起きてと言っても、起きなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though I told the kid to wake up multiple times, he didn't get up.

Name: ～てしまう
Meaning: To do something by accident, To finish completely・totally, Unfortunately
About: By combining the conjunction particle て, with the verb しまう (sometimes written as 終(しま)う), you are able to express that something was done 'by accident', 'completely', or 'unfortunately'. These meanings may seem quite different, but we will discuss their similarities in a moment. Let's look at a few examples of てしまう first.  Sometimes, てしまう or でしまう will be shortened to a more casual form, which are often used in speech. These forms are as follows: てしまう will become ちゃう でしまう will become じゃう

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はすぐに道に迷ってしまう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Unfortunately, I easily get lost.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家にお菓子がいっぱいあると全部食べてしまうのでお菓子を買わないようにしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When there are a lot of snacks in my house, I completely eat them all, so I try not to buy them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: メニューにアイスクリームがあると頼んでしまう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When there is ice-cream on the menu, I unfortunately order it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はよく舌を噛んでしまう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I accidentally bite my tongue often.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近運動をしてないから太っちゃう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, I haven't been exercising, so I'm totally going to get fat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 花が死んじゃうから、花を踏むな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since the flowers will unfortunately die, don't step on them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ゲームを始める前に宿題を終わらせてしまおう！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let's completely finish my homework before I start playing video games! (I'm going to completely finish my homework before I start playing video games)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 青木先輩、定時までに社長に頼まれたレポートを完成させてしまいましょうよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Aoki senpai, let's completely finish the report that our boss has asked us to do before work is over.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 傘を忘れてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I unfortunately forgot my umbrella. (I totally forgot my umbrella)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達は私のケーキを食べてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My friend finished off my cake. (eaten completely)・(totally)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お皿が割れてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Someone) accidentally broke a plate. (unfortunately・totally)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今出ないと遅れてしまうよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you don't leave now, you will unfortunately be late. (totally)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ごめん！卵を全部使ってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Sorry! I completely used all the eggs. (Sorry! I totally used all the eggs)

Name: ～て (Reasons and Causes)
Meaning: And・and so, Due to, Because of, Since, Conjunctive
About: One of the functions that the conjunction particle て performs in Japanese is very similar to 'since', or 'due to', in English. Phrases that use this particular (A) て (B) nuance of the て-form primarily express something that is beyond the control of the speaker in the (B) statement. To use this grammar construction, pair the て-form of a verb or い-Adjective with the (B) phrase. In the case of nouns and な-Adjectives, で (the particle) will be used instead.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犯人が捕まって安心です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I feel safe because the criminal got caught.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は宿題が多くて行けなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I couldn't go today because I had a lot of homework.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田舎は静かで落ち着きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can relax in the countryside because it is quiet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 虫歯で歯が痛い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My tooth hurts because of a cavity.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 文字も小さすぎて読めないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The characters are too small and I cannot read them. (I cannot read the characters because they are too small)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 部屋が綺麗でのんびりできます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can relax because the room is clean. (The room is clean and I can relax)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: メアリーがアメリカに帰って悲しいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mary returned to the USA and I am sad. (I am sad because Mary returned to the USA)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: おとなしさんは病気で参加できませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mr. Otonashi was sick and could not participate. (Mr. Otonashi was unable to participate due to being ill)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: おっちゃんのコンサートは雨で中止になった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: O-chan's concert has been canceled due to the rain.

Name: させられる (Causative-Passive)
Meaning: Verbs (Causative-passive voice), To be made to do something, To be forced to do
About: When the auxiliary verb せる (or させる) 'to make/let do' is combined with the auxiliary verb られる 'to be the receiver of', it creates the causative-passive form of verbs in Japanese. These sentences will be from the perspective of the person who has 'been made to do' something, and are very often negative (against the will of the speaker). First, verbs must be conjugated in the same way that they would be with せる, or させる. After that simply remove the る, and then add られる. This will create the verb form させられる (linked with る-Verbs), or せられる (linked with う-Verbs). As with the causative form, する and 来(く)る have special conjugation rules. する will be replaced completely by させられる, while 来(く)る will become 来(こ)させられる.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: おばあちゃんの家に行くとお腹がいっぱいでもいっぱい食べさせられる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I go to my grandma's house, she makes me eat a lot, even if I am full.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんな事させられるとは思わなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I didn't think that I would be forced to do something like that.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩に色んなお酒を飲ませられたから頭が痛い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because my senpai made me drink all sorts of alcohol, my head hurts.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達に冷たい水を浴びさせられるのが嫌いだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't like it when my friend douses me with cold water.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 上司に力仕事をさせられる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My boss forces me to do physical labor.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達に知らないバンドのコンサートに連れてこさせられる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My friend forces me to go to the concert of bands that I do not know.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供の頃は兄が勉強をさせられていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When we were still kids, my older brother was forced to study.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供の頃は兄に勉強をさせられていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When we were still children, my older brother forced me to study.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お腹がいっぱいなのに、ケーキを食べさせられた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was forced to eat the cake even though I was full.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は兄に宿題をさせられた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was forced to do homework by my older brother.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんなことをさせられたの？
Questions.EnglishHTML: What kind of things were you forced to do?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嫌なことをさせられた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was made to do awful things.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あまり見たくない動画を見させられたのです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was forced to watch a video I didn't really want to watch.

Name: ～て (Means and Manner)
Meaning: By, With, On, By means of, ~ing with
About: The conjunction particle て, or the case marking particle で are often used to highlight when something is being 'used'. The thing being used does not necessarily need to indicate a tool, but can also indicate a circumstance/situation. In these cases, '(A) で (B)' translates as 'with/by means of (A), (B)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 寝坊をしたので慌てて準備をした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I overslept, I got ready in a flurry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日泳いでトレーニングをしています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I train by swimming every day.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 父は車で仕事に行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My father goes to work by car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はハサミで野菜を切ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I cut my vegetables using scissors.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: フライパンを使って、料理をします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am making a meal with a frying pan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 歩いて帰るつもりだよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I plan to come home on (by) foot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: けいまくんは自転車に乗って学校に行っています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Keima goes to school by (riding a) bike.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 総理大臣は新幹線を利用して東京に戻りました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The prime minister returned to Tokyo by (using the) shinkansen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はあの船に乗ってアメリカに来た。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He came to the USA on that/by riding that ship.

Name: ～てある
Meaning: Something is done, Has been done, Remaining state
About: Like 'verb + ている', 'verb + てある ' is a structure that will convey an ongoing state. However, that is where the similarities stop. てある may only be used with transitive verbs, and highlights the object itself as being the subject of the sentence (rather than the initial person/thing that performed the action). Because ある is being used, it highlights the object as being inanimate (or unable to undo the action that was performed on it). Due to this, てある is regularly translated as 'to be left (A)', or 'to remain (A)', where (A) is the original verb that somebody performed on the object. が may mark the object in these sentences when the action itself involves some kind of preparation. Examples are as follows: 予約(よやく) - Reservation (requires time investment to reserve). 準備(じゅんび) - Preparation (requires time investment to prepare). 録音(ろくおん) - Recording (requires time investment to make the recording). In situations that involve no real preparation (opening a door, for example), を will be preferred when marking the object.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたの弁当は机の上に置いてあるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have left your lunch on the desk. (Literally 'your lunch is in the state of having been left on the desk')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車は駐車場の真ん中に止めてある 。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I parked the car in the middle of the parking lot. (Literally 'your car is in the state of having been stopped in the carpark')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 庭にトウモロコシが植えてある から気を付けてね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Corn has been planted in the yard, so please be careful. (Literally 'corn is in the state of having been planted')

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このドアは開けてある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This door has been left open.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テレビ台の上に置いてあるよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It has been placed on top of the TV stand.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日の準備してあるんですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Have tomorrow's preparations been done?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日の準備をしてあるので、もう寝ます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have done my preparation for tomorrow so I am going to bed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １０００年前に建てられたビルがまだ残してある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The building that was built 1000 years ago is still standing.

Name: 様(よう)に～て欲(ほ)しい
Meaning: Want ~ to ~ like ~, Want ~ to be able to ~, Want ~ to ~ in the way of ~
About: (A) ように～てほしい is an expression in Japanese which combines the auxiliary verb,  ようだ, with the てほしい structure (indicating that you/someone else wants someone to do something). As ようだ is being linked to a verb which comes later in the sentence, it will take on the adverbial form ように. This expression is used to highlight that you (or someone else) want someone to do something 'in the way of (A)'. Note that when ように follows a noun, の will be required. Either に or が may mark the thing that the speaker 'wants' to do. It is more common for に to be used to mark people, while が will often mark events/objects.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 弁護士になれるように頑張ってほしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want you to work your hardest, so that you can become a lawyer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このチームが大会で勝てるようになってほしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want this team to be able to win a tournament.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前にはスポーツ選手のように走ってほしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want you to run like an athlete.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もっとアナウンサーのように話してほしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want you to talk more like an announcer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたに漢字を書けるようになってほしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want you to be able to write kanji.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 事故が無くなるように運転をしてほしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want people to drive in a way that will reduce accidents.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムに友達ができるようになってほしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want Tom to be able to make some friends.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ブラジルのように負けて欲しくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't want (you) to lose like Brazil.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どのように書いて欲しいですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In what way do (you) want me to write this?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ウサイン・ボルトのように走って欲しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want (you) to run like Usain Bolt.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 頭がよくなるように勉強して欲しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want (you) to study in a way that allows you to become smart.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私たちの子供には君のようになって欲しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want our children to become like you.

Name: ～ている間(あいだ)に
Meaning: While, During the time that ~
About: When (A) ている is paired with 間(あいだ)に (B), it expresses that '(B) is happening/happened within the timeframe of (A)'. These events do not need to be related in any specific way, but the (B) action must happen somewhere within the duration of (A). This construction translates naturally as 'during the time that (A), (B)'. ている間(あいだ)に will often be used when the (B) action is somehow beyond the control of the speaker. However, this is not always the case.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ねえ、数えている間には話しかけないで。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hey, don't talk to me while I'm counting.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 荷物を運んでいる間に転んで怪我をした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I tripped and hurt myself when I was carrying luggage.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 旅行に行っている間に家に泥棒が入った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While I was on a trip, a burglar came into my house.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 妻が寝ている間に、私は好きなことができる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While my wife is sleeping, I can do what I like.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サッカーをしている間に電話がかかってきました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I got a phone call while playing soccer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強をしている間にお腹が空いてきた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I became hungry while studying.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 料理をしている間に子ども達が帰って来た。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While I was cooking, my kids came home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パンを焼いている間にお皿を出した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While I was toasting some bread, I took out a plate.

Name: なくてもいい
Meaning: Don't have to
About: なくてもいい is simply the opposite of てもいい, and highlights that it is 'ok even if (A) is not done'. This usually comes across as being quite polite, and sounds like 'don't worry about doing (A)' in English. なくてもいい is a combination of the auxiliary verb ない in its conjunction form, with てもいい. In order to make this phrase sound even more casual, the adverbial particle も may be omitted. This does not change the nuance at all, but will sound a bit more friendly (when used with people that you know well).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ミカは悪くないから謝らなくてもいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Mika, you are not in the wrong, so you don't have to apologize.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その手紙はもう届けなくてもいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's okay if you don't deliver that letter anymore.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は会社に来なくていいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is fine if you don't come to the office today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 忙しいなら、行かなくてもいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you are busy, you do not have to go.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 掃除をしなくてもいいですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is alright even if I don't clean?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その青いセーターを着なくてもいいですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is alright even if you do not wear that blue sweater.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんなに怒らなくてもいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You don't have to be that angry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これ以上飲まなくてもいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You don't have to drink more than this.

Name: ～てみる
Meaning: To try to
About: In order to express that you will (or someone else should) try something, the conjunction particle て will be paired with 見(み)る (almost always without kanji). While this is translated as 'to try to (A)', the actual meaning is closer to 'to do (A), and see (whether the result is good or not)'. This grammar construction is usually only used when someone tries something for the first time. As mentioned above, this phrase is also used when suggesting that someone else should try something. In these situations, (A) + てみて, or more formally, (A) + てみてください will be used. Sometimes, in very casual situations, even the て will be dropped, and (A) + てみ will be used by itself. This usually has the nuance of 'come on, just give it a go!'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 本当においしいの？今度食べてみるよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is it really delicious? Next time I'll try it!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これ飲んでみる？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you want to try this drink?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: だまされたと思って食べてみてよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Try and eat it as if I tricked you into eating it. (Believe it or not, this tastes good)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もう一度電源を切ってみてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please try to turn it off once more.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このボール投げてみ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Try and throw this ball.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの新しいショッピングモールに行ってみたよ！すごい良かった！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I tried going to that new shopping mall! It was so good!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タケルにもらった靴を履いてみたけど、俺の足がデカすぎるから入らなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I tried to wear the shoes that Takeru gave me, but my feet were too big so they didn't fit.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: イルカと泳いでみたいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to try swimming with dolphins.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まず、食べてみてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: First, please try to eat it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 柔道をしてみたいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to try to do Judo.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 図書館で、調べてみるつもりです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I intend to try to look it up at the library.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先週末、スキーをしてみた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I tried skiing last weekend.

Name: ～てすみません
Meaning: I'm sorry for
About: てすみません is a grammar construction that expresses the speaker's regret about (A). It is often translated directly to 'I'm sorry for (A)'. As discussed in one of our previous lessons on て, we examined the 'since', or 'due to' meaning that it can have. Let's look at a few examples. Phrases that use this particular (A) て (B) nuance of the て-form primarily express something that is beyond the control of the speaker in the (B) statement. Coming from the verb 済(す)む (to finish), すみません (the negated form) means 'to be unfinished'. In this way, てすみません literally means that the speaker feels that something is 'unfinished due to (A)'. This is very similar to phrases like 'having unfinished business' in English. Although the translation is 'I'm sorry', perhaps it would be easier to remember this grammar structure as highlighting someone's regret/unfinished feelings about (A), and simply showing that to the person that is being apologized to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 待ち合わせの時間に遅れてすみません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am sorry for coming later than the arranged meeting time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子さんの髪をピンクに染めてすみません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am sorry for dyeing your son's hair pink.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ご飯を残してすみません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am sorry that I didn't eat all the food. (It unfortunately resulted in that I did not finish eating all the food)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたのケーキを食べてすみません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm sorry for eating your cake.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遅くなってすみません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am sorry that I am late.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 約束を破ってすみません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm sorry for breaking my promise.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 怒ってすみません。怒りたくなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm sorry for getting angry. I didn't want to be angry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 喋りすぎてすみません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm sorry for talking too much.

Name: ～てあげる
Meaning: To do something for someone, As a favor for
About: The receiver of the てあげる action will be marked with に, while the doer will be marked with が (if mentioned).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 父が妹にお菓子を買ってあげる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My father buys snacks for my sister.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いいよ、俺がやってあげるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's okay, I'll do it for you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は私が送ってあげるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tomorrow, (as a favor) I will send you off.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部長、今夜は俺がおごってあげるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Boss, I'll pay for the food tonight (as a favor). (Natural Japanese, but may be considered rude by the boss)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犬に餌をやる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To feed the dog. (To give food to the dog because they need it to live)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犬に餌をあげる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To feed the dog. (To give food to the dog because you want it to have the best life)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前が食いたいものは何でも作ってやるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will make anything you want to eat for you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 母に花を買ってあげた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I bought flowers (as a favor) for my mother.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あそこのおばあさんを手伝ってあげましょうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Shall we give assistance to (as a favor for) that lady?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このプレゼントをお父さんに渡してあげてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please hand over this present to your dad. (Give to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ユカに消しゴムを貸してあげてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please lend your eraser to Yuka. (For Yuka)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寂しそうにしているから、ハグしてあげましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because they look lonely let's give them a hug. (For them)

Name: ～てくれる
Meaning: To do something for someone (usually you)
About: The verb 呉(く)れる in Japanese, is very similar to 与(あた)える (to bestow). The primary difference is that 呉(く)れる (primarily written in hiragana) means to 'bestow to the speaker' (or someone in the speakers inner circle). In this way, てくれる is the opposite of てあげる, which conveys that someone (usually the speaker) gives (an action) to another person that is outside of their inner circle. てくれる is commonly translated as 'would you do (A) for me', as a question, or 'someone did (A) for me', as a statement. When asking for a favor, てくれる can be shortened to てくれ. However, this is very casual, and should not be used with strangers (or anyone that you do not know well). As an English equivalent, てくれ sounds similar to phrases like 'would ya do (A)', or 'could ya do (A)?'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: おばあちゃんはいつも美味しいご飯を作ってくれる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Grandma always makes delicious food for us!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達が旅行から帰ってくるとお土産を持って来てくれる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When my friend comes back from vacation, they bring me souvenirs.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パパ、電気を消してくれる？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Dad, can you turn the lights off for me?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お願いだから急いでくれ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm begging you, could ya hurry it up (for me)?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遊園地に連れて行ってくれる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Someone will take me to the amusement park. (They are taking me for my benefit)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遊園地に連れて行ってもらう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Someone is taking me to the amusement park. (I am having someone take me)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遊園地に連れて行って頂く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Someone is taking me to the amusement park. (I am being bestowed the act of being taken)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのグラスをここに持ってきてくれる？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Would you bring me that glass?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この漢字の意味を教えてくれますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Would you teach me the meaning of this kanji? (for me)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私を愛してくれますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Will you love me? (do me the favor of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ママが書きやすいペンをかってくれた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My mom bought a pen that is easy to write with. (For me)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 喋らないで黙って行ってくれますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Could you not talk, shut up and go? (for me)

Name: ～てもらう
Meaning: To get someone to do, To have someone do
About: Being slightly more direct than てくれる, てもらう removes the meaning of 'to bestow' (to the speaker), and focuses on the meaning of 'to receive' (from the giver). With てもらう, に will mark the person that 'did something' for the subject, while が (or は) will highlight the receiver themselves. In English, this grammar structure is regularly translated as 'to have (someone) do (A) for you', or 'to get (someone) to do (A) for you'. Literally, it means 'to receive the action of (A)'. てもらう is also regularly used when receiving a service from someone, as てくれる would imply that the action was a favor.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語が話せないから友達に行き方を聞いてもらう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I can't speak Japanese, I'm going to have my friend ask for directions on my behalf.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は虫が嫌いなので妻に虫を捕ってもらう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I hate bugs, I get my wife to catch them (for me).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日は朝から頭が痛かったから医者に見てもらった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because my head hurt since the morning yesterday, I had a doctor look at it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 朝から頭が痛かったから病院に行って、医者が見てくれた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I had a headache since this morning, I went to the doctor and he checked it out for me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は母に宿題をしてもらった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I had my mom do my homework (for me).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: クリスマスに犬を買ってもらうかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I might have (someone) buy me a dog for Christmas.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: (誰かに)この仕事を手伝ってもらう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will get someone to help with this work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ユカは誰かに手伝ってもらったかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Yuka might have gotten someone to help her.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まず掃除をしてもらうと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: First I think I will have you clean (for me).

Name: なさい
Meaning: Command to do
About: なさい is the imperative form of なさる, an honorific language verb which specifically highlights and respects the actions of another person (never the speaker). Despite being respectful, the fact that this is a 'command' means that it would never be used toward a superior. Due to this, なさい is most frequently used toward peers, or people of lower status, like children. To use なさい, simply connect it to the ます stem of any verb. なさい may be shortened further to な, which becomes an even more casual form that is used most frequently toward peers.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 早く寝なさい！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hurry up and sleep!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遊んでいないで勉強しなさい！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Stop playing and study!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勉強しな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You should study.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前も悪いから謝りな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are also at fault, so you should apologize.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このクッキーを食べな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You should eat this cookie.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このクッキーを食べるな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do not eat this cookie.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強しなさい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Study!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 早く帰りなさい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Hurry up and go home!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 野菜を食べなさい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Eat your vegetables!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これをパパに渡しなさい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Hand this to your dad.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 注意しなさい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Be careful.

Name: ～て (Non-Sequence)
Meaning: Non-sequence, And, But (Contrast), Parallel action/state
About: One of the common functions that the conjunction particle て has, is that it can contrast things that share some sort of relationship. This is similar to the contrastive use of は. In order to identify this nuance of て, we will need to think about whether the things being described are happening one after the other, or are simply describing '(A), and then (B)'. Let's look at some examples. Due to this 'contrast' that is shown with て, sometimes it is translated as 'while (A), also (B)'. The primary difference between this nuance of て, and other 'while' or 'but' grammar points, is that (A) and (B) will always have equal weight/importance in a て sentence. Comparatively, structures like けど, のに, だが and similar points will usually imply that either (A) or (B) is more important in some way.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お姉ちゃんは毎晩勉強をして弟は毎晩ゲームをしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My older sister studies every night, and my younger brother plays games.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 妻は買い物に行って、私はごみを捨てに行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My wife went shopping, while I went to throw away the trash.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タケルはご飯を食べてナオミはパンを食べる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takeru eats rice, and Naomi eats bread.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 朝は雨が降って夕方は晴れた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It rained this morning, and then it cleared up in the afternoon. (There is no particular emphasis on either event)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 朝は雨が降ったけど夕方は晴れた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It rained this morning, but then it cleared up in the afternoon. (There is emphasis on that it stopped raining)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昨日は曇っていて寒かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Yesterday was cloudy and cold.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: チトゲさんは歌ってオノデラさんは踊っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chitoge is singing and Onodera is dancing. (but・contrast)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 雨が降って雷が鳴る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It rains and thunders.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: おばあさんはいつもラジオを聴いておじいさんはいつもテレビを観る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My grandma always listens to the radio, and my grandfather always watches tv. (but・contrast)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はピアノを弾けてドラムも上手に叩ける。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She can play the piano, and also she can play drums well.

Name: ないで (Casual Request)
Meaning: (Please) do not (for me), Casual request
About: ないでください is a polite way to express 'please don't do (A)'. However, such politeness is often not required, like in conversations between close friends. In these cases, ないで by itself may be used for the same purpose. Although grammatically the same as the ないで with the meaning of 'without doing (A), (B)', rather having a part (A) and a part (B) to the sentence, this ないで acts more like a simple statement. ないで combines the auxiliary verb ない, with the case marking particle, で. To use this structure, simply attach it to the negative stem of the verb that you wish to request someone not to do. The sentence itself usually finishes with ないで.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生：「そこの生徒、授業中に寝ないで！」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Teacher: 'The student there, please don't sleep during class!'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 母が娘に：「知らない人についていかないで！約束よ。」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Mother to her daughter: 'Please don't go with people you don't know! That's a promise.'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 妻が夫に：「貯金をしたいから、無駄な物にお金を使わないで。」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Wife to her husband: 'I want to save up, so please don't use money recklessly.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あそこの公園は危ないので、遊ばないで。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since that park is dangerous, (please) don't play there.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫にあるケーキはまだ食べないでね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Please) don't eat the cake in the refrigerator yet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食べてからジェットコースターに乗らないで。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Please) don't ride a rollercoaster after eating.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「バカにしないでよ！はんだくん。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: '(Please) don't make a fool out of me! Handa.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここは病院なので、走ったり、騒いだりしないで。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since this is a hospital, (please) don't do things like run or be boisterous.

Name: ～てくれてありがとう
Meaning: Thank you for ~ ing
About: As an extension of てくれる, which expresses that something was done for the speaker, or someone within their immediate circle, てくれてありがとう thanks someone for that action.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いつもゴキブリを捕まえてくれてありがとう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thank you for always catching the cockroaches.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ケーキを買って来てくれてありがとう！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thank you for buying the cake for me!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 弁当を袋に入れてくれてありがとう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thank you for putting my bento in a bag! (Slightly unnatural Japanese, if just plainly thanking someone for doing their job)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 手伝ってくれてありがとうございました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Thank you so much for helping (me).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつも一緒にいてくれてありがとう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Thanks for always being with me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 駅までおくってくれてありがとうございます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Thank you so much for taking me to the station.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 晩御飯を作ってくれてありがとう！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Thanks for making dinner (for me)!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遅くなってごめん！待っていてくれてありがとう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am sorry that I am late! Thank you so much for waiting (for me).

Name: ～て + くれない
Meaning: Won't you?, Will you?, Could you?, Can you?, Would you?
About: When used in the negative, てくれない (coming from てくれる),  and てもらえない (coming from てもらえる), are similar to the negative question form of じゃないか. They express the following: てくれない - Would you not do (A) for me? てもらえない - Could I not have you do (A) for me? In both of these constructions, か (the question particle) may be omitted. However, they do sound slightly more polite when か is used. Let's examine the following list, for a scale of the level of politeness. てくれ, てくれる, てもらえる, てくれない (か), てもらえない (か)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私に漢字を教えてくれない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Would you not teach me kanji? (Would you please teach me kanji?)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 道を調べてもらえない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Could I get you to look up the way?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日だけ自転車を貸してくれないか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just for today, would you not let me borrow your bike?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: テレビを点けてもらえないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Could I get you to turn the TV on for me, please?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スマホを使わせてくれないか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Won't you let me use your phone?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お茶を入れてくれない？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Won't you make some tea for me?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うちでも働いてくれない？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Won't you work at my place (for me) too?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こっちに醤油を取ってもらえない？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Won't you pass (take) the soy sauce (for me)?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 米を炊いておいてくれない？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Won't you cook some rice (in advance) for me?

Name: のだろうか
Meaning: I wonder...
About: When だろう (the conjugated auxiliary verb) is grouped with か (the question particle), it presents the statement before it as something that the speaker is unsure about. In this way, it sounds similar to 'I wonder if (A)' in English. To use this construction, the statement before だろうか must be nominalized (turned into a noun-phrase). This is done through the use of の, or なの (in the case of な-Adjectives and nouns). Despite the grammatical rule relating to nominalization using の (or なの), this part of the phrase is often omitted. だろうか is quite masculine, so in order to sound more polite/ladylike, でしょうか may also be used instead.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私たちのチームは勝てるのだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if our team can win.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は本当に彼氏が欲しいのだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if she actually wants a boyfriend.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は大丈夫なのだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if that person is okay.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あれは本当に食べ物なのだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if that is really food.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムは私を誘うだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if Tom will invite me. (の omitted)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は本当に弁護士だろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if that person is actually a lawyer. (なの omitted)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんな高い鉛筆をトムが買うのでしょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if Tom will buy a pencil that expensive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの車はキムの車なのでしょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if that car belongs to Kim.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この人が言っていることは本当なのだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if what this person is saying is true. (Said while talking to oneself)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこに息子を連れて行っていいのだろうか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if I can take my son there. (Said while talking to oneself)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の都合が悪いだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder if it is bad timing for him?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もうすぐ時間だろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder if it is about time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 練習したら、うまくなるだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder if I will get better at it if I practice.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 犯人が見つかるだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder if the criminal will be found.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この小屋に虫が居るのだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder if there are any bugs in this storehouse.

Name: お～になる
Meaning: To do (Honorific)
About: お～になる (or ご～になる) is an honorific language expression which is used to pay respect to the actions of the person that is being spoken to/another person (never the speaker). In this expression, になる is used in exactly the same way that する would be, except that it will be attached to the ます stem of the verb that it is referring to. The primary difference between お and ご, is that お will be used with words/readings of Japanese origin (kun-yomi), and ご will be used with words/readings of Chinese origin (on-yomi). In fact, お and ご are both represented by the same kanji. For this kanji, 御(お) is one of the kun-yomi, and 御(ご) is one of the on-yomi.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客様がお見えになるのは３時頃です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The time that the customers will come will be around 3 o'clock.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 皆様、お立ちになってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We request that everyone stand up.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この資料がご参考になれば幸いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would bring me great happiness if this document could be a useful reference for you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部長はどういう番組をご覧になるのですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Boss, what kind of TV shows do you watch?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生はお帰りになりました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The teacher has gone home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ハリーポッターをお読みになりましたか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Did you read Harry Potter?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 父上はもうお帰りになったんですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Father has already gone home, hasn't he.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 歯医者がお見えになるのは３時です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The dentist will arrive at 3 o'clock.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お父さんは何時頃お帰りになります？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Around what time will father return home?

Name: なさる
Meaning: To do (Honorific)
About: なさる is an honorific language verb which acknowledges and respects the actions of another (never the speaker). Like お～になる, なさる has exactly the same meaning as する. なさる can be utilized in any situation where する would be used, as a direct replacement. It is a special-class verb, which means that it has some unique conjugation rules. In its casual form, it will conjugate in exactly the same way as a う-Verb. However, in the polite form, instead of る changing to り (as would be expected of a う-Verb), it will change to い instead.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 週末もお仕事をなさるのですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are you going to work over the weekend also?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勘違いなさらないでください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please don't take this the wrong way.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社長は先週どちらでゴルフをなさったのですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Boss, where did you go to play golf last week?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 納得なさらないなら私に言ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are not with me on this, please let me know.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お飲み物はどうなさいますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What would you like to drink?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 忘れ物はなさいませんか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Did you forget anything?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客様、どうなさいましたか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Valued guest, what seems to be the issue?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は計画を変えることはなさいませんでした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He did not do anything to change the plan.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社長は今、ゴルフをなさっていらっしゃる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The CEO is currently playing golf quite playingly. (Unnatural Japanese, with unnatural English to match!)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社長は今ゴルフをなさっています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The CEO is currently playing golf. (Natural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お飲み物はどうなさいますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: What will you have to drink?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今朝、彼は家を留守になさいました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He was away from home this morning.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供のころスポーツをなさっていたんですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I hear that you played sports when you were younger.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今何を勉強なさっていますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: What are you studying now?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何をなさろうとするのですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: What will you attempt to do?

Name: お～ください
Meaning: Please do (Honorific)
About: お～ください is an honorific language expression in Japanese which is used in a similar way to なさい.  It is the imperative form of くださる, which itself is the honorific language equivalent of くれる. In this way, it conveys 'please do (A) for me'. お～ください is more polite than なさい, and may be used when making requests to almost anybody, regardless of if they are higher, or lower status than you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こちらのサービスを使うにはインターネットでお申込みください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To use this service, please register via the internet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こちらのスリッパをお使いください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please use these slippers over here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 後ろの扉をお閉めください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please close the door behind you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうぞ、こちらにお掛けください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Go ahead, please sit right here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 少しお待ちください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please wait just a minute.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうぞお召し上がりください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please go ahead and eat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: しばらくお休みください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please take a short break.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうぞ、お掛けください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please, have a seat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日までにお支払いください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please complete the payment by tomorrow.

Name: いらっしゃる
Meaning: To be (Honorific), To come (Honorific), To go (Honorific)
About: いらっしゃる is another of the common honorific language expressions in Japanese. This means that it elevates the status of another person, in order to pay them respect. It will never be used when referring to the speaker themselves, or their own actions. いらっしゃる can be used to replace 居(い)る 'to be', 来(く)る 'to come', or 行(い)く 'to go'. This is due to the unique perspective that honorific language places the speaker in, in relation to the person that is being respected. This is a slightly advanced concept that we will discuss more later. To use いらっしゃる, simply replace いる, くる, or いく with いらっしゃる. Alternatively, いらっしゃる may also be used to replace いる, くる, or いく when they are attached to the て-form of another verb.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたの隣にいらっしゃるのはお嫁さんですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is the person (existing) next to you your wife?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あと３０分で社長がいらっしゃるので準備をしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The CEO is coming in 30 minutes, so please get ready.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩は明日の忘年会にはいらっしゃいますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Senpai, are you coming to the end-of-year party tomorrow?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中様が来ていらっしゃったので案内をお願いします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Mr. Tanaka is here, so please see to his needs.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: マユミさんはタクシーに乗っていらっしゃるのでもうすぐ着きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Mayumi-san is coming by taxi, so she will be here soon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は歩いていらっしゃいそうです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It appears as though he will come by foot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社長は忘年会においでになると聞きました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that the CEO will be at the end of year party.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社長は忘年会にいらっしゃると聞きました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that the CEO will be at the end of year party.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 分からない人はいらっしゃいますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is there anyone who doesn't understand?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お客さんがいらっしゃいました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A customer came.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いらっしゃい(ませ)！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Welcome!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先にいらっしゃったんですが。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He was here first, but...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 鈴木様はもういらっしゃらないですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is Suzuki-sama no longer here?

Name: 御座(ござ)います
Meaning: To be, To exist (Polite)
About: ございます is a combination of the (special-class) verb, ござる (御座(ござ)る in its kanji form), and the auxiliary verb ます. It is considered polite speech, and is directly equivalent to ある (or いる). ござる itself is almost never used in daily conversation in modern Japanese, due to the preference of the polite form, ございます. However, ござる is regularly used in dramas, manga, and other forms of media (especially historical dramas).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ありがとうございます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thank you very much. (Polite expression)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 質問はございますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you have any questions?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここは私の家でござる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is my humble abode.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が担当者でございます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am the representative.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカ様でございますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are you Mr. Tanaka?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカ様でいらっしゃいますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are you Mr. Tanaka?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: おはよう御座います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Good morning. (Polite greeting)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お水が御座います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is water. (exists)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 鶴の折り紙が御座います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is an origami crane. (exists)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 駅があちらに御座います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The station is over there. (exists)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明けましておめでとう御座います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Happy New Year! (polite expression)

Name: で御座(ござ)います
Meaning: To be, Polite copula
About: As mentioned briefly in the ございます lesson, でございます is a structure which can be used as a replacement for であります, the polite form of である (which itself is the formal equivalent of だ). Both です and でございます are considered polite speech. However, でございます is the more polite of the two. Let's take a look at a few examples. でござる may also be seen, as it is the base form of で + ございます a (special-class) verb. However, in modern Japanese, this is primarily restricted to historical dramas, or characters that have a somewhat 'quirky' personality.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 郵便局は隣でございます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The post office is next door.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運転手のタナカでございます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am Tanaka, the driver.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 拙者がハットリでござる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am Hattori. (拙者 is a very common word that was used by samurai, and simply means 'I')

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この方は田中さんで御座います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is Mr. Tanaka.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こちらが先生の机で御座います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is the teacher's desk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こちらは図書館で御座います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is the library.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 英語担当の浜田で御座います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (I am) head of English, Hamada.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 本日のスペシャルはホットケーキで御座います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Today's special is pancakes.

Name: お〜する
Meaning: I humbly do, I am obliged to do, Humble speech
About: お〜する comes from a form of polite speech in Japanese called humble speech. This type of speech is used to refer to the speaker and their actions. This is opposed to honorific language, which refers exclusively to the listener and their actions. お〜する is almost exactly the same as お～になる, as in it simply means する. お〜する is regularly used with words of Japanese origin, while ご～する will be used with words of Chinese origin. The する in this compound will attach directly to the ます stem of almost any verb.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 僕がお守りします！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am going to protect you!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今すぐにご確認します。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will check right now.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ご登録する方はこちらをクリックしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For those who want to register, please click here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ご注文する時はこちらのベルを押してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When you are going to order, please press this bell.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩にお電話するのがすきです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like to call my senpai.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達とお勉強するのは楽しいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is fun to study with my friends.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ５分後にお電話します。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After 5 minutes, I will call you. (I will call you in five minutes)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ５分後にお電話いたします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After 5 minutes, I will call you. (I will call you in five minutes)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ドアをお閉めします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I (will) humbly close the door.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お任せします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will humbly leave it up to you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生の分もお取りします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will humbly take the teacher's share.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたの分もお作りします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will also humbly make your share.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これを彼にお渡ししてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please humbly hand over this to him.

Name: 致(いた)す
Meaning: To do (Humble)
About: いたす, or 致(いた)す as it is often written, is a humble speech う-Verb, which refers to the actions of the speaker (or people within the speakers inner circle, like their company). Similarly to お〜する, いたす means 'to do'. In the case of する verbs themselves, simply replace する with いたす. For other verbs, add いたす to the ます stem of the verb, while attaching お, or ご to the beginning (depending on whether it is a word of Japanese or Chinese origin).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私たちが用意いたします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We will do the preparation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コートはこちらでお預かりいたします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We will look after your coats here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こちらからご連絡いたします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We will contact you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は親戚のお寺を拝観する。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will look at my relatives' temple. (With utmost respect)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩からお金を拝借する。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will borrow money from my senpai. (With utmost respect)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ご案内いたします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will guide you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 拝借してもよろしいですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: May I borrow it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 駅の前でお待ちいたします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will wait in front of the station.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 品物は明日お送りいたします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We will send the merchandise tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お荷物をお持ちいたしましょうか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Shall I take your baggage?

Name: ～ていただけませんか
Meaning: Won't you, Could you please (Humble request)
About: ていただけませんか is the humble speech form of てもらえませんか, which itself is the negative potential form of てもらう 'to have (A) done by someone else'. This structure is a combination of て (the conjunction particle), the う-Verb いただく 'to be topped with', the polite-negative auxiliary verb ません, and the question particle, か. Generally, it is translated in a similar way as てもらえませんか 'won't you (A)', or 'could you please (A)'. This construction and いただく itself can regularly be seen as 頂(いただ)く, its kanji form. Due to this kanji literally meaning 'to be topped with', it is just acknowledging that the person that is doing the action for you (or someone in your group), is doing so from 'above' (sounds more respectful). Here we can see how the 'to be topped/capped with' meaning is used in a standard sentence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: すみませんが、後ろに乗っていただけませんか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am sorry but, could you please sit in the back.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 危ないので少しだけ下がってもらえませんか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because it is dangerous, could you please back up just a little.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 雪を頂いた山はとてもきれいだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A snow-capped mountain is very beautiful.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 犬を散歩していただけませんか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Could you please walk the dog?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夜９時までに帰っていただけませんか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Could you please return home by nine o'clock? (go home)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もしよかったら、明日もしていただけませんか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it is ok, could you please do it for me tomorrow too?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 駅まで送っていただけませんか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Could you please take me to the station?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ３時ぐらいに来ていただけませんか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Could you please come around three o'clock?

Name: たら
Meaning: When, From when, Just when, If
About: The conjunction particle たら is used as a kind of 'halfway point' between 'if' and 'when' in Japanese. It expresses the completion of an (A) action, and then a (B) action that is considered to be the result of (A). It may be hypothetical, or it may be presenting a one-time result of something that happened in the past. To use たら, it will replace た in the simple past form of verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives, and nouns.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今度遅れたら、許さないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Next time, when/if you are late, I will not let it slide.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 寒かったら、エアコンつけてね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When/if you are cold, turn on the air conditioner.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の事が好きだったら、彼に言った方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When/if you like him, you should tell him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日だったら、遊べるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When/if it is tomorrow, I can hang out.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来週だったら、いけるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it is next week, I can go. (Highlighting a future event)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先週だったら行けたのに。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it was last week, I could have gone. (Highlighting a past event)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 買い物に行ったら、クッキーを買ってきて。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When/if you go shopping, please get me some cookies.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたがその本を読まないなら、私が読みます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are not going to read that book, I will read it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強したら、テストは簡単になる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When you study, the test will become easy. (if・from when)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お茶の味が薄かったら、言ってください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please let me know if the tea is weak. (if・just when)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もし食べに行きたかったら、行こう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If/when you want to go out to eat, let's go! (from when)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 週末だったら、時間ありますよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If/when it is the weekend, I have time. (from when・just when)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 辛かったら、牛乳を飲んでください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it is spicy, please drink some milk. (from when・just when)

Name: 他(ほか)に
Meaning: Other, Another, Any other, Anything else, As well as, Besides, In addition
About: 他(ほか)に is regularly considered to be one of the more difficult structures to master in Japanese, so let's take a thorough look at it. Basically, 他(ほか) by itself just means 'another', or 'other'. に highlights 他(ほか) 'another thing' as being the target of what comes next in any particular sentence. The possibilities are as follows: 他(ほか)に - Another thing. 他(ほか)に（も） - Even another thing (sounds less certain). 他(ほか)に（は） - Was there another thing (focuses on something pre-existing, which someone may have forgotten). 他(ほか)に（は） may be used in either positive or negative sentences, but it tends to appear in negative sentences more often.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 他に、欲しいものはある？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is there anything else you want?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 動物園の他にもどこかへ行きますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is there anywhere else you want to go, other than the zoo?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 他にはない物が食べたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to eat something that isn't anywhere else. (Something unique to this place)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この電子レンジは壊れているので他の電子レンジをお使いになってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This microwave is broken so please use a different one.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お金の他には何が欲しいですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Other than money, what do you want?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の他にはフランス語を話せる人はいません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Other than him, there isn't anyone else that can speak French.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 欲しいものは、その他にもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is also nothing else besides what I want. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その他にも何か質問がありませんか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Besides that, are there no other questions? (Natural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 他は？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Anything else?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いいえ、他はいりません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No, I don't need anything else.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 他の国に行ったことがありますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Have you ever been to any other countries?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 他の方法がないかな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder if there is no other way. (another)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この箸の他には使えないんだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't use anything but these chopsticks. (other than)

Name: が必要(ひつよう)
Meaning: Need, Necessary
About: が必要(ひつよう) is a common expression in Japanese which is used to highlight the 'need' or 'necessity' of something. It is a structure that may only be used with nouns, which means that verbs will need to be nominalized (turned into noun-phrases) in order to use this construction. Both が and だ may sometimes be omitted from this expression in casual speech. However, it is a good idea to at least use が,   to clarify the thing that is 'necessary'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: プールで泳ぐときは水着が必要だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When swimming in a pool, a swimsuit is necessary.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: バスを運転するには特別な免許が必要だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You need a special license to drive a bus.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は車を持っていないから迎えに行くことが必要だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because he doesn't have a car, it is necessary to go pick him up.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここは泥棒が多いから出かける前に鍵をかけることが必要だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because there are a lot of burglars here, it is necessary to lock your door before you go out.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は運転するときは眼鏡が必要。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I need glasses when I drive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田舎に住むには車が必要。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To live in the countryside, a car is necessary.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テストをする時はえんぴつが必要です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A pencil is necessary when you take a test.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ケーキを作るなら、砂糖が必要です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you are going to make a cake, sugar is necessary.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田舎に住んだら、車が必要です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you live in the countryside, a car is necessary.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スノーボードに行くなら、手袋が必要です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you are going snowboarding, you need gloves.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何が必要かな〜。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder what I need...

Name: そんなに
Meaning: So (much), That much, Like that
About: そんなに, like そんな, is one of the most common ways to express that one thing is 'like' something else in casual conversation. The addition of the particle に just highlights そんな as being the 'destination' of the 'like' amount. This construction is regularly translated as 'so much', 'that much', or simply 'like that'. As a word, そんなに is used adverbially. This means that it may come before any verb, い-Adjective, or な-Adjective. Almost any そんなに based sentence can be translated literally as 'to an extent like (A)', where (A) is the word that comes after そんなに, and に indicates 'to'. As そんなに is another example of こそあど言葉(ことば) (words like これ, それ, あれ, and どれ), it means that こんなに, あんなに, and どんなに may also be used. Despite this, そんなに is almost considered a set phrase, and is therefore the most common out of all of the possibilities (except for どんなに, which is often used when explaining/giving reasons for something).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなに食べたらお腹を壊 すよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you eat that much, you are going to break your stomach. (Natural Japanese for 'stomach ache')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなに暑いと思うならエアコンをつければいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you think it's that hot, you should turn on the air conditioner.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなに嫌いなら、無理して食べなくてもいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you dislike it that much, you don't have to force yourself to eat it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんなにもらってもいいんですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is it okay to receive this much? (Are you really giving me all of this?)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんなに食べたのにまだお腹が空いているの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are still hungry, even after eating that much?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんなに頑張っても、私は先輩みたいにはなれないと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how hard I try, I don't think that I can become like my senpai.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このケーキはそんなに甘いんですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is this cake really that sweet?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんなに痛いなら、病院に行ったほうがいいんじゃないですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it hurts that much, shouldn't you go to the hospital?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんなに頑張っても、彼みたいに出来ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if I tried that hard, I couldn't do it like he can. (that much)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんなに日本に行きたいなら、行って来たら？
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you want to go to Japan that much, why don't you?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんなに水泳が嫌いなら、泳がなくていいんじゃない？
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you hate swimming so much, why don't you just not swim? (that much)

Name: 必要(ひつよう)がある
Meaning: It is necessary to
About: Like が必要(ひつよう), 必要(ひつよう)がある is an expression which is used to highlight the 'need' or 'necessity' of something. The primary difference being that 必要(ひつよう)がある highlights the need to 'do (A)', and will therefore be used with verbs (without the need for nominalization). To use 必要(ひつよう)がある, just attach it after the plain form of the verb that you want to highlight the 'need' for. As we can see, this construction is simply the combination of a verb + 必要(ひつよう) (creating a verb modified noun), the case marking particle が, and the う-Verb ある. In this way, it just means 'the need of doing (A) exists'. Naturally, this grammar pattern may also be used negatively, to highlight that there is 'no need to do (A)', or that 'doing (A) is not necessary'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日はテストがあるから、勉強をする必要がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I have a test tomorrow, it is necessary to study.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子はまだ小さいので、いつも一緒にいる必要がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since my son is still little, it is necessary for me to be with him at all times.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カイルは日本語が分かるので、書類を英語に訳す必要がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since Kyle understands Japanese, there is no need to translate the documents into English.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 娘は元気になったので、病院に行く必要がありません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since my daughter got well, there is no need to go to the hospital.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 朝ご飯を食べる必要がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is necessary to eat breakfast.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それを明日までに終える必要がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is necessary to finish that by tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この板が厚すぎて、切る必要がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This board is too thick, so it is necessary that it is cut.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 痩せたいなら、運動する必要がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you want to lose weight, then it is necessary to exercise.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ホテルに泊まるならカミソリを持って行く必要がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you are going to stay at a hotel, it is necessary to bring a razor.

Name: 例(たと)えば
Meaning: For example
About: たとえば (or 例(たと)えば in its kanji form) is an adverb in Japanese that is used at the beginning of a sentence, or an individual statement, in order to present an example. It can be translated almost directly as 'for example'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たとえば、ドイツとかは？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For example, how about Germany, or something?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たとえば、冷たい物を食べたときに歯が痛いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For example, my teeth hurt when I eat cold things.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 詳しく言うと、トマトのように種がいっぱいある食べ物が嫌いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: More specifically, I don't like foods that have a lot of seeds, like tomatoes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たとえば、「英語が好きですか。」と聞いてみたら？
