Questions.EnglishHTML: For example, why don't you ask 'Do you like English?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たとえば、翻訳者になったら日本に住むことが出来る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For example, if you become a translator, you will be able to live in Japan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 漢字を覚えるサイトがたくさんあります。たとえば、ワニカニだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are a number of sites you can use to learn kanji. For example, Wanikani.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たとえば毎日日本語を話すなら、日本語のレベルが上がる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For example, if you speak Japanese every day, your Japanese level will rise.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は、たとえばあそこにあるイタリアンレストランのような店を作りたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For example, I want to make a restaurant like that Italian restaurant over there.

Name: れる・られる (Potential)
Meaning: To be able, Can (Potential)
About: In addition to 'passive' verbs, れる and られる (the auxiliary verbs) are used when expressing possibility '可能(かのう)'. られる will be attached to the base form of る-Verbs (the form after る has been removed). Note also that れる and られる themselves behave like standard る-Verbs, so can be conjugated into a variety of different tenses in the same way as a standard verb. A common sight in modern Japanese is words where the ら may be removed, 'ラ抜(ぬ)き言葉(ことば)', and れる may be used by itself. However, this is not technically correct Japanese, and may cause confusion in cases where ら is required (with る-Verbs and くる, when られる is expressing 'passivity', 'respect', or 'spontaneous occurrence'). For う-Verbs, they will behave a little differently. Instead of the final kana of the verb changing to an あ sound, and then adding れる (as would be the case with passive verbs), the final kana of the verb will change to an え sound (る will become れ, う will become え, す will become せ, etc.) before adding る. Interestingly, する verbs do not have a 'potential' form, and the verb できる will be used in its place.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日までに届けられる？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Can you deliver it by tomorrow? (Natural Japanese, and may express 'potential', 'passivity', 'respect', or 'spontaneous occurrence')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一人で全部食べられる？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Can you eat all of this on your own? (Natural Japanese, and may express 'potential', 'passivity', 'respect', or 'spontaneous occurrence')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムはすぐに新しい文法を覚えれる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tom is able to remember new grammar immediately. (Natural Japanese only when expressing 'potential', not 'passivity', 'respect', or 'spontaneous occurrence')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はなんでも食べれる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He can eat anything. (Natural Japanese only when expressing 'potential', not 'passivity', 'respect', or 'spontaneous occurrence')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この歌は弾けますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are you able to play this song?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この池では色々な魚が釣れます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You can catch many kinds of fish in this lake.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サリーはほとんどの漢字を書くことができる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sally is able to write most kanji.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やっとシャワーを浴びられる！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can finally take a shower!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたは何が食べられるの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What can you eat?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムは日本語とフランス語と英語を話すことができる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tom is able to speak Japanese, French, and English.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの山が見られますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Can you see that mountain over there?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女の話は信じられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot believe her story.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 十分待てますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Can you wait 10 minutes?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の好きな映画が見られたらいいね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I hope that you can see the movie I like.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 見つけられなくてすみませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am sorry that I was unable to find it.

Name: んだけど
Meaning: But..., And...
About: んだけど is an expression that combines んだ (explaining/giving cause), with けど (but). Together they translate simply as 'but...', although the nuance is actually closer to 'but with (A) as the reason… (B)', while (B) is sometimes left unsaid. This implies that the speaker is looking for a reply, or does not want to say the (B) part of the sentence out of politeness/awkwardness. There are several different forms of this construction that are mostly interchangeable with each other. From most casual, to most formal, they are as follows: んだけど、んだけれど、んだけれども、んだが、んですが ん may be replaced with の in any of the above expressions. However, it will again make it slightly more formal.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 助かるんだけど一人でできるから帰ってもいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I feel like you are being helpful, but I can handle it by myself, so you can go home.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は明日釣りに行くのですが先輩も行きませんか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am going to go fishing tomorrow, but senpai, do you also want to go?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しいパソコンを買いたいのだけど...どれを買えばいいか分からない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to buy a new computer, but… I don't know which one to buy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 顔はいいのだけど...性格は悪い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He has a good looking face, but… his personality is bad.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「昨日の告白はどうなったの？」
「こくはくしたんだけど (ふられた)。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'How did yesterday's confession go?'
'I confessed but… (I was rejected).'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これほしいんだけど (たかい)。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want this, but… (it is expensive).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: やせられたらいいんだけど (難しいね)。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be great if I could lose some weight, but… (it is hard).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新しい時計を買いたいのですが (どちらがいいでしょうか)。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I would like to buy a new watch (and…) (which one would be good?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 窓が開いているからちょっと寒いんですが (どうか窓を閉めていただけませんか？)。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since the window is open, it is a bit cold (and…) (I wonder if you wouldn't mind closing it?).

Name: 筈(はず)だ
Meaning: Bound to (be), Expected to (be), Should be (able)
About: はず, coming from the kanji 筈(はず), is a word in Japanese that is very similar to 'bound' in English. This means that it expresses something that the speaker is 'quite sure is true', but cannot confirm. The most common translations of はず are 'bound to be (A)', and 'should be (A)'. As はず is a noun, it may be used in any place that a noun would usually be used. It will often be followed by だ, or です.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は雨が降るはずだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is supposed to rain today. (But I am not 100% sure if it will)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新幹線で行った方が速いはずだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is bound to be faster if we go by shinkansen. (But I am not 100% sure if it will)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は魚が嫌いだから寿司は嫌いなはずだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He does not like fish, so he is sure to dislike sushi. (But I am not 100% sure if he will)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 頼んだのはコーヒーのはずだったけどお茶が来た。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was sure that I ordered coffee, but tea came. (But I am not 100% sure if I did)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ハリーも今日のパーティーに行く…はず。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Harry will go to the party today… Probably.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 出かける前に家の中の電気は全部消した… はず。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I turned off all the lights in my house before I left… I'm pretty sure.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は借りたペンを返す筈だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is bound to return the pen he borrowed. (expected to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夏だから、暑い筈だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because it is summer, it is expected to be hot. (bound to be)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここから富士山が見える筈だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: One should be able to see Mt. Fuji from here. (bound to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この港には船がある筈だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are bound to be boats in this harbor. (expected to be)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 脱出した犯人が見つかる筈だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The escaped convict is bound to be found. (expected to be)

Name: かどうか
Meaning: Whether or not, If...or not
About: かどうか is an expression in Japanese which combines the 'or' meaning of か, with the 'how' meaning of どう. (A) かどうか (B) is regularly translated as 'whether or not (A), (B)'. To use かどうか, simply attach it to the end of any phrase that you want to express the 'or' use of か about, then add the (B) phrase. Although 'whether or not' is the standard translation, the more literal translation of かどうか is 'if it's (A), or however it is, (B)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サチコと付き合うかどうか分からない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't know whether or not I will go out with Sachiko.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 水が汚いからこの川が深いかどうか分からない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since the water is dirty, I don't know whether or not this river is deep.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この携帯が便利かどうか分からない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't know whether or not this cell phone is useful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 目が悪いからあそこにいるのが父親かどうかわからない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I have bad eyes, I don't know whether or not the person over there is my father.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 旅行に行けるかどうかわからない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't know whether or not I can go on a trip.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サンタさんがいるかどうか探しています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We're searching for clues as to whether or not Santa's here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まだ日本に行けるかどうか、分からない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't know whether or not I still can go to Japan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スピーチがうまくできるかどうか心配している。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am worried whether or not my speech will go well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今の動物は犬かどうか分からないけど、怖かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't know whether or not the animal I just saw was a dog, but it was frightening.

Name: と
Meaning: If, When, Whenever, And, [Conditional]
About: In the same way as the case marking particleと means 'and', sometimes it is translated as 'if'. In these cases, it is considered to be far stronger than ば, なら, or たら (which express hypothetical outcomes). This is because one of the primary uses of と is highlighting a result. In these cases, と is actually a conjunction particle, and shows one of three things. 仮定(かてい)の順接(じゅんせつ) - A result that is assumed to be true, and obvious. 確定(かくてい)の順接(じゅんせつ) - A result that is known to be true. 仮定(かてい)の逆接(ぎゃくせつ) - The opposite of a result that is assumed to be true. Due to this, the (B) part of a phrase using と as 'if', will always occur when (A) happens, as it is considered to be the result of (A). と may not be used in situations where the (B) result 'might' happen. It must be definite (or close to definite). In this particular nuance of と, despite being translated as 'if', the actual meaning is much closer to 'and', as と is expressing that (A) and (B) will always go together.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 甘いものをいっぱい食べると、太る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you eat a lot of sweet things, you will gain weight.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部屋が汚いと、お母さんに怒られる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If my room is messy, my mother will yell at me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部屋が静かだと、眠れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If my room is quiet, I can't sleep.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 地下鉄だと、五分早く着く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it's the subway, you will arrive 5 minutes faster.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 走るとけがをする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I run, I will injure myself. (Unnatural Japanese, unless this person always injures themselves while running for some reason)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 目を閉じると、何も見えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I close my eyes, and I can't see.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強をすると、テストは簡単になる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you study, tests become easy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この石を磨くと、綺麗になる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you polish this rock, it will become beautiful.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そうすると絶対に失敗するよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you do it that way, you will definitely make a mistake.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここから見ると、富士山が全然見えない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you look from here, you can't see Mt. Fuji at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 週に３回トレーニングをするとだんだん強くなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whenever you workout three times a week, you gradually get stronger. (if...)

Name: ないと
Meaning: Must, Have to
About: As an extension of the 'if' meaning of と, attaching the auxiliary verb ない to the verb before it will express 'if (A) is not done, (B)'. (B) is most frequently いけない 'cannot go', which makes ないといけない a double negative phrase, which translates to 'must do (A)', or 'have to do (A)'. いけない may be replaced with だめ, to make the phrase more casual, but ならない is generally not used with ないと.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ライト君が悪いんだから、リュウ君に謝らないといけないでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Raito-kun, you are in the wrong, so you have to apologize to Ryu-kun, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は勉強しないとだめだから、明日は？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have to study today, so how about tomorrow?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日はテストがあるの？！勉強しないと。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is a test tomorrow!? I have to study.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もう７時じゃん？準備しないと。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Oh, it's already 7? I need to get ready.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 歩行者も信号機を守らないといけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even pedestrians have to obey traffic lights.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「約束を守らないといけません！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'You have to keep your promise!' (must)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「なぜ、税金を払わないといけないのですか？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Why do I have to pay taxes?' (must)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「子沢山だから、一週間に三十回は洗濯しないとだめ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'There are lots of children, so I have to do laundry thirty times a week.' (must)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「合格したらまず両親や先生に伝えないと。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'If I pass, I have to tell my parents and teacher first!' (must)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「ピーナッツにアレルギーがあると言っておかないといけないんだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I have to tell (you) in advance that I am allergic to peanuts.' (must)

Name: 筈(はず)がない
Meaning: Hardly possible, Cannot be, Highly unlikely, Improbable
About: Like はず, coming from the kanji 筈(はず), which suggests that something is 'bound' to be true, はずがない suggests that something is 'not bound' to be true. This expression is usually translated as 'hardly possible', 'improbable', or 'unlikely', but in reality, it is a bit weaker than these, and translates more literally to '(A) is not the only possibility'. As はずがない (a combination of 筈(はず), the case-marking particle が, and the い-Adjective  ない) is a phrase that starts with a noun, it may be used after any word that could usually connect with a noun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一時間も早く家を出たから遅れるはずがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I left the house an hour early, it is improbable that I will be late. (That I am bound to be late is not true)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この箱は重いはずがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is hardly possible that this box is heavy. (It is not the case that this box is bound to be heavy)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サリーの家は立派なはずがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is highly unlikely that Sally's house is splendid. (That Sally's house is sure to be splendid is not the case)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あそこにいる人はトムのはずがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is highly unlikely that the person over there is Tom.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の車は高くないはずだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: His car would not be expensive. (His car is bound to not be that expensive)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の車は高いはずがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is hardly possible that his car is expensive. (That his car is bound to be expensive is not true)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これだけの筈がない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is highly unlikely that it is just this.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それはあなたのカバンの筈がない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is highly unlikely that that is your bag.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夏に雪が降る筈がない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is hardly possible for it to snow in the summer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのビルは古すぎなので、病院の筈がない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because that building is so old, it is hardly possible that it is a hospital.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんな量を一気に食べられる筈がないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is hardly possible to eat this amount of food at once.

Name: しか～ない
Meaning: There's only, Nothing but
About: The adverbial particle しか is often compared to だけ, in that it also expresses 'only'. However, unlike だけ, しか can only be used in negative statements. Due to this, しか～ない is regularly translated as 'there's only (A)', or 'there's nothing but (A)'. しか～ない may be used to express numbers, or nouns. In this lesson we will examine nouns. Like しか～ない, the construction used for expressing numbers, when used before a noun, this expression will mean that nothing apart from that one 'thing' exists. Any verb may be used after しか, but it must be in its ない (or ありません) form.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犯人はまだ３人しか捕まっていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Only 3 of the criminals have been caught so far.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この店は牛丼しか置いていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This store only has gyudon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 釣りに行って、一匹しか釣れないと悲しくなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I get sad when I go fishing and only catch one fish.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日から雨が降るから、今日行くしかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since it will start raining tomorrow, we have no choice but to go today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 座るところがここしかありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is nowhere else to sit but here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遠いので、車で行くことしか出来ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because it is far away, you can only go by car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「はい」と「いいえ」しか言わない人とは話しにくい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is difficult to talk to people who only respond with 'yes' and 'no'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: すみませんが、午後しか空いていないみたいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am sorry, but it looks like there is only space open in the afternoon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫に牛乳しか残っていない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is nothing but milk in the fridge.

Name: だけでなく
Meaning: Not only… but also
About: だけでなく (an abbreviation of だけではなく) is a common construction in Japanese which translates to 'not only (A), but also (B)'. Sometimes the (B) statement may be left unsaid. This expression may connect to any (A) phrase that だけ would usually be able to connect to. The conjunction particle て should follow なく, as it is the conjunctive form of the い-Adjective ない. However, the て in this particular construction is very often omitted.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 痩せるためには運動をするだけでなく、食べるものにも気を付けなくてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To lose weight, not only should you exercise, but you must also be careful of what you eat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 名古屋の夏は暑いだけでなく、湿気もひどい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Summer in Nagoya is not only hot, but the humidity is terrible too.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田舎は静かなだけでなく、空気もきれいだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The countryside is not only quiet, but the air is also clean.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トーマスは車だけでなく、バイクとボートも持っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not only does Thomas own a car, but he also has a bike, and a boat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タケルはピアノだけじゃなく、ギターも弾けると聞いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that Takeru can not only play the piano, but also the guitar.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムは日本語だけでなくて、中国語も話せる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not only can Tom speak Japanese, but also Chinese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 角にあるラーメン屋はおいしいだけでなくて量も多い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The ramen shop on the corner is not only delicious, but the portions are large too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ぶどうは甘いだけでなく、みずみずしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Grapes are not only sweet, but also juicy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私だけでなく、私の友達も日本語が喋れる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not only me, but also my friends can speak Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人は日本語だけでなく、韓国語、中国語とタイ語も話せる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person can speak not only Japanese, but also Korean, Chinese, and Thai.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ジョニー・デップはカナダだけでなく、日本も訪れたことがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Johnny Depp has not only visited Canada, but has visited Japan as well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女だけでなく、私もこの映画が好きだよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not only does she like this movie but I do too.

Name: ことが出来(でき)る
Meaning: Can, Be able to
About: Like ことがある, ことができる is an expression that nominalizes what comes before it (turns it into a noun-phrase), and then highlights something about that (A) phrase. In the case of ことができる, the thing being highlighted about (A) is that it is 'possible'. This translates as 'can do (A)', or 'to be able to do (A)'. However, こと is only required when the (A) phrase needs nominalization (is not a noun to begin with). Due to this, ができる may be used by itself when following a noun, without changing the meaning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 魚のように泳ぐことができるように毎日練習する。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I practice everyday so that I will be able to swim like a fish.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は料理をすることができる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is able to cook.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運転ができる彼氏が欲しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want a boyfriend that can drive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 力仕事ができる人を探しています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We are looking for a person that is able to do physical labor.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 馬に乗る事が出来る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can ride a horse.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 泳ぐ事が出来ますか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Can you swim?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 初めて、漢字を書く事が出来た。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was able to write kanji for the first time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の姉は歌う事が出来る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My older sister can sing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 約束を守る事が出来なくてすみません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am sorry that I am unable to keep my promise.

Name: かい
Meaning: Question marker
About: The sentence ending particle かい is a grammar structure that is used in Japanese to highlight a question. Despite commonly being thought of as one word, it is actually the combination of か (the sentence-ending particle) and い, another sentence-ending particle that is primarily used by men (in a similar way to ね and よ). かい will usually be used directly after the word or phrase that it is highlighting. In the case of verbs and い-Adjectives, の may be inserted before かい. For な-Adjectives and nouns, なの may be inserted directly before it. However, の (or なの) are frequently omitted, due to how casual かい is. When it is not omitted, の (or なの) may be shortened to ん (or なん）. This is in the same way that の and なの would behave in the のです and なのです grammar structures. Although there are some exceptions, かい will almost always be used to ask simple yes/no questions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このドーナッツを食べたいのかい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you want to eat this donut?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このおもちゃが欲しいのかい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you want this toy?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は綺麗なのかい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is your girlfriend pretty?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はいい人なのかい?
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is he a good person?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前も一緒に行きたいんかい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you also want to come with me?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大学生なんかい。中学生だと思った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are a college student? I thought you were a middle schooler.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勉強してるのかい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are you studying?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: また鍵をなくしたんかい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You lost your keys again, didn't you?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 本当に行きたいのかい？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Do you really want to go?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これだけで十分なのかい？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is just this enough?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その帽子を被って行くのかい？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Are you really going to go wearing that hat?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうしたの？恥ずかしいのかい？
Questions.EnglishHTML: What's wrong? Are you embarrassed?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この番組を見たくないのかい？
Questions.EnglishHTML: You don't want to watch this TV program?

Name: もし
Meaning: If (For emphasis)
About: もし is an adverb used to emphasize the nuance of 'if', with expressions like と, ば, なら, たら, and ても. Literally, the meaning of もし is close to 'while slight', or 'while small'. To use もし, simply add it to the beginning of any phrase that uses one of the conditional expressions listed above.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もし彼を動物に例えると、猫に似ています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If we were to compare him to an animal, he resembles a cat. (Even if you only slightly compared him)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もし今日来れれば来てね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you can come today, please do. (If, on the slight chance you can come)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もしまだ頭が痛いなら、医者に行った方がいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If your head still hurts, you should go to the doctors. (If, on the slight chance it does hurt)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もし買い物に行ったら、お菓子を買って来て。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you go shopping, can you buy some snacks? (If, on the slight chance you do go)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もし雨が降っても遊園地に行きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if it rains, we will still go to the amusement park. (If, on the slight chance it does rain)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もし雨が降ったら、車で行く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it rains, I will go by car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もし辛いものだったら、食べられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it is spicy, I can't eat it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もしコーヒーを買ってくれたら、嬉しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you bought coffee for me, I would be happy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もしこのパソコンを彼女にあげるなら、説明書も渡してね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you are going to give this computer to her, (make sure to) give her the manual too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もし君が文法を勉強したら、日本語を喋れるようになるでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you study grammar, you will become able to speak Japanese, right?

Name: し (Reasons)
Meaning: And, Giving reasons
About: Like て, し is a conjunction particle. This means that it is used for linking the (A) and (B) parts of a sentence, and describing that link in some way. The 'description' that し will highlight is 'reasons'. Regularly it is translated simply as 'and'. し may be connected to the end of almost any word, but will require a だ before it when it comes after nouns or な-Adjectives. し will follow every 'reason' that is being listed in a sentence. However, the last し may be replaced with から or ので, before the 'result' is stated. Using し will indicate that each 'reason' being listed is of equal weight/importance. Because of this, it would not be appropriate to use in sentences where one of the reasons clearly far outweighs everything else.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はピアノが弾けるし、スポーツができるし、彼女に出来ないことはないと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She can play the piano and she can do sports. I think there isn't anything she can't do.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このレストランは高いし、まずいし、何もいいところがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This restaurant is expensive and doesn't taste good. There are no good parts.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は真面目だし、親切だし、彼と友達でよかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is serious and nice. I am glad that he is my friend.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は休みだし、晴れだし、今日は公園に行こう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today is my day off, and it's sunny, so let's go to the park.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日は雨が降ってたし、おばあちゃんも亡くなったし、悲しいな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It was raining yesterday and my grandmother also passed away, so I'm sad. (Unnatural Japanese, as the level of sadness between losing your grandmother, and it being a rainy day would be completely different)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は掃除ができるし、料理も作れるし、結婚してよかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He can clean and cook (among other things). I am glad that I married him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この赤が可愛いし、デザインがいいし、この帽子を買いたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This red is cute and the design is good (among other things). I want to buy this hat!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は親切だし、綺麗だし、本当に大好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She is kind and beautiful (among other things). I really love her.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この近所は治安がいいし、スーパーが近いし、人が優しいからここに住んでみたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This neighborhood is safe and the store is close and the people are nice, so I wouldn't mind living here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕は全然やりたくないし、やることが多すぎるし、諦めようと思っています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have absolutely no desire to do it and there are too many things to do (among other things), (so) I am thinking about giving up.

Name: でできる
Meaning: Made of, Made from, Produced from, Come from
About: でできる, or からできる are two structures that share very similar meanings. Basically, they both mean '(B) was made from/out of (A)'. These constructions highlight the 'ingredients', or 'materials' that something is/was made out of. Let's look at some examples. から and で are both case marking particles in this grammar point, and while they express much the same thing when translated into English, there is a slight nuance difference. These differences are as follows: から - Literally 'prepared from'. Tends to be used more frequently when the material is not obvious at first glance. May also put focus on the ingredients/materials before there was any alteration. で - Literally 'prepared with'. Tends to be used more frequently when the materials are more obvious. Despite this, recent generations use で in most situations, regardless of if the material is visible at first glance or not. As a result, でできる and からできる are almost indistinguishable in modern Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は卵と鶏肉でできる料理を紹介します。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today we will introduce a food that is made from eggs and chicken.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 味噌は大豆からできると職人さんが教えてくれた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A craftsman told me that miso is made from soybeans.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近はコンクリートでできる家が人気だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, houses made of concrete are popular. (Houses in general)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この箸は竹でできている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: These chopsticks are made from bamboo. (This specific pair of chopsticks)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 裏面がガラスでできているスマホは最近売行きがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Recently there has been demand for smartphones with the back made of glass.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このワインはトップクラスのブドウからできています。どうぞ飲んでください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This wine is made from top-class grapes. Please, try it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スーパーは木曜日にミルクからできている製品のセールをするよ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: The supermarket is having a sale of products made from milk on Thursday! (come from)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 飛行機は軽い素材でできている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Airplanes are made from light materials.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: プラスチックやアスファルトは石油からできます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Things like plastic and asphalt are made from oil. (come from)

Name: ながら
Meaning: While ~ing, During, As
About: ながら is another conjunction particle in Japanese that has two primary different meanings. These meanings are as follows: 同時(どうじ)の動(うご)き - Two things that are existing/happening simultaneously. 確定(かくてい)の逆説(ぎゃくせつ) - Two things that are unexpectedly existing/happening simultaneously. We will focus purely on the 同時(どうじ)の動(うご)き meaning in this grammar point. To use ながら, simply add it to the ます stem of verb (A), and then highlight verb (B) as part of the following clause. This may be translated simply as 'while' in English. Grammatically, the (B) action is considered to be the 'important' action, while the (A) action expresses the timeline within which (B) takes place.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は毎日、音楽を聴きながら走ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I run every day, while listening to music.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運転しながら携帯を使っていたら、前の車にぶつかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I was using my phone while driving, I crashed into the car in front of me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高校の頃はサッカーの練習をしながら漢字の勉強もした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I was in high school, I studied kanji while also practicing soccer. (Natural Japanese, as the overall timeline of the sentence is 'while in high school')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 漢字の勉強をしながらアニメを見る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I watch anime while studying kanji. (Natural Japanese, as the speaker is doing both things at the same time)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大学に通いながら、トランプ氏がアメリカの大統領だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Trump was the president of America while I was going to university. (Unnatural Japanese. Although the events happen at the same time, they share no common subject/place)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あそこの病院は古いながらも中は綺麗だと聞いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that that hospital looks nice inside, even though it is old.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: シャワーを浴びながらいいアイディアを思いついた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While showering, I thought of a good idea.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 赤ちゃんが寝ながら、おならをした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The baby farted while sleeping.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: バスに乗りながら、スマホでゲームをしている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am playing games on my phone, while riding the bus.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達を待ちながら、コーヒーを飲もう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's get coffee while waiting for our friends.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 運転しながら携帯を使ってはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You must not use a cellphone while driving.

Name: ～た所(ところ)だ
Meaning: Just finished doing, Was just doing
About: In a similar way to how ところ (sometimes shortened to とこ) means 'about to (A)', or 'on the verge of (A)', when following the non-past form of a verb, when following the auxiliary verb た, ところ will mean 'just did (A)'. To use this structure, make the past tense of any verb, and then add ところ. While this expresses 'just did (A)', ていた may be used when you would like to express that you were 'just doing (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今、先生に聞いたところ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I just asked the teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事は今終わったところ。もうすぐ帰る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I just finished work. So I'll head home soon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 休みを楽しんでいたところで上司から電話が来た。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I got a call from my boss just as I was enjoying my day off.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今食べ終わったところです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I just (now) finished eating.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 服を脱いでいたところに、母が部屋に入ってきた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My mom came into the room just as I was taking my clothes off.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新しいおもちゃを渡したところで壊れた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just after I gave the new toy (to someone), it broke.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達はたまたま友達に会う：「君に会いたいと今思っていたところだわ！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Friend meets a friend by accident: 'I was just thinking that I want to see you!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 改札に入ったところで電車の扉が閉まった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just as I (had) entered the ticket gate, the train doors closed.

Name: ～ている所(ところ)だ
Meaning: In the process of doing ~ right now/at this moment
About: In the previous grammar point, we learned that たところ (or ていたところ) will mean 'just did (A)', or 'was just doing (A)'. ているところ works in a similar way, but expresses that someone is right in the middle of doing something. It is regularly translated as 'doing (A) right now', or 'in the process of (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事をしているところだから後で電話するね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am in the middle of work right now, so I will call you later, okay?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日は近所で泥棒が警察から逃げているところを見た。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Yesterday, I saw a burglar running away from the police in my neighborhood.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 映画を見ているところだったから電話に出れなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was in the middle of watching a movie, so I couldn't answer the phone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ギターを弾いているところだったからメッセージに気付かなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was in the middle of playing my guitar, so I didn't notice your message.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今、映画を見ているところです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am in the process of watching a movie right now.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今、お父さんは富士山を登っているところです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My dad is in the process of climbing Mt. Fuji right now.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 警察官がパトロールをしているところです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The police officer is in the process of doing her patrol at this moment.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今、先生に聞いているところです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am in the process of asking the teacher right now.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕は今日本語を勉強しているところだけど。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am in the process of studying Japanese right now. (Annoyed that he is being interrupted)

Name: と～と、どちらが
Meaning: Between ~ which one
About: と～と、どちらが is an expression in Japanese that is made from the following parts: と - The particle (x2) in its meaning of 'and'. どちら - The polite speech form of 誰(だれ) 'who', and a slightly newer form of どっち that basically means 'which'. が - The case marking particle. This structure is used when the speaker is asking a question about whether someone will choose (A) or (B). It is only used when there are no more than two possible choices. As can be seen above, verbs may be used as part of this structure if they are nominalized with こと, or の. Additionally, the polite form does not specifically need to be used, and どっち may be used instead. The second と itself is quite often omitted, as どちら (or どっち) implies that both (A) and (B) are part of the same structure.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ピザとラーメンとどちらが好きですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Between pizza and ramen, which do you prefer?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 漢字を書くことと漢字を読むこととどちらが得意ですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Between writing and reading kanji, which are you more confident with?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遊園地に行くのと動物園に行くのとどちらがいいですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Between going to the amusement park, and going to the zoo, which is better?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 辛い物と甘い物とどっちが好き？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Between something spicy and something sweet, which do you like more?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私と彼女どっちが好き？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Between me and her, who do you like?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: すみません、どちら様ですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm sorry, who are you?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ワインとビールとどちらの方が飲みたいですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Between wine and beer, which would you want to drink more?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コーヒーとお茶とどちらがほしいですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Between coffee and tea, which do you want?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スポーツすることと、ゲームすること、どちらが上手ですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Between playing sports and playing video games, which are you better at?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ひらがなとカタカナとどちらが覚えにくいですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Between hiragana and katakana, which one is more difficult to remember?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: エベレストとＫ２とどちらが高い？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Between Everest and K2, which one is taller?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電車で行くのと車で行くのとどちらが早いんですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Between going by train and going by car, which one is faster?

Name: 様(よう)にする
Meaning: To try to, To make sure to, To endeavor to
About: (A) ようにする is an expression in Japanese which combines the auxiliary verb ようだ, with する (indicating that you will 'try' to do something). As ようだ is being linked to the verb する, it will take on its adverbial form, ように. This structure emphasizes that the (A) action (always a verb) is something that the speaker is going out of their way to do, and implies effort. Naturally, this structure may also be used with a negative verb, to imply that (A) being done is something that is actively being avoided. This translates as 'to make sure not to do (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近太ってきたので、毎日走るようにしています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, I have been gaining weight, so I try to run everyday.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 次の試合で勝てるようにする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will try to be able to win the next tournament.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 「空気が汚れるので乗り物に乗らないようにする」と弟が言いました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My brother said 'I try not to ride vehicles, because it pollutes the air'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 成績が悪いから学校を休まないようにする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because my grades are bad, I will try not to miss school.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 妻にばれないようにしてくれ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Try not to let my wife find out about it!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 予約に間に合うようにしましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's try to be on time for the reservation.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そのコップを落とさないようにしてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please try not to drop that cup.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あまり音が出ないようにしてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please try not to make much noise.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 綺麗に包むようにします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will try to wrap it beautifully.

Name: なければいけない
Meaning: Must do, Have to do
About: Like なくてはいけない, なければいけない is a structure that implies that something 'must be done'. However, it is important to remember that this is actually a double negative, and therefore means 'If (A) is not done, it cannot go', or more simply '(A) cannot not be done'. To make this construction, the auxiliary verb ない will need to be conjugated with ば, creating なければ (if not). After this, いけない (to not be able to go) will be added to the end. As learned in the なきゃ lesson, なければ may be shortened to なきゃ. This structure is frequently used either with or without the added いけない.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来月に友達の結婚式に行かなければいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Next month, I have to go to my friend's wedding. (Not going to the wedding is not going to work)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車は駐車場に止めなければいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Cars have to be parked in parking lots. (Not being parked in a parking lot is unacceptable)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここで話している場合じゃない。息子を迎えに行かなきゃ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is not the time to talk here, I have to go pick up my son.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 宿題で、調べなきゃいけない事があるから、パソコン貸して。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I need to look up something for my homework, would you please lend me your computer?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仕事に行かなければいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have to go to work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 冬になったら、暖房をつけなければいけません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When winter comes, I will have to turn on the heater.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 覚えにくいけど、覚えなければいけません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is difficult to remember, but I must remember.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: すごく汚れたから洗わなければいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because it is very dirty, I must wash it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼に会いたくないけど、会わなければいけません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't want to see him, but I must (meet him).

Name: なければならない
Meaning: Must do, Have to do
About: Like なければいけない, なければならない is a structure that implies that something 'must be done'. However, it is important to remember that this is actually a double negative, and therefore means 'If (A) is not done, it cannot become', or more simply '(A) cannot not be done'. To make this construction, the auxiliary verb ない will need to be conjugated with ば, creating なければ (if not). After this, ならない (to not become) will be added to the end. As we learned in the なきゃ lesson, なければ may be shortened to なきゃ. This structure is frequently used, either with or without the added ならない.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事をしなければならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I must do my work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩が部屋に入って来たら立って挨拶をしなければならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If your senpai comes into the room, you must stand and greet them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日も帰りが遅くなったら妻に怒られるから、もうすぐ帰らなきゃ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My wife is going to scold me if I come home late today too, so I have to go home soon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は家事をやらなきゃならないから出かけられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have to do some chores today, so I can't go out.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生の話を聞かなければならないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You have to listen to the teacher (talk).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 髪の毛が長いから、切らなければならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My hair is long, so I have to cut it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 飛行機に乗りたいなら、空港に行かなければならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you want to ride an airplane, you have to go to the airport.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新しいノートを買わなければならないかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I might have to buy a new notebook.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語が上手になりたいから、勉強をしなければならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to become proficient in Japanese, so I have to study.

Name: 続(つづ)ける
Meaning: To continue
About: By attaching the verb 続(つづ)ける 'to continue' to the conjunctive form of another verb, we will be able to express that '(A) is continuing'. Let's have a look at a few examples of this structure.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サリーは暗くなるまで走り続ける。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sally will continue to run until it gets dark.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は漢字を覚えるまで、同じ漢字を書き続ける。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will continue to write the same kanji until I memorize it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語は難しいけど、勉強を頑張って続ける。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Japanese is difficult, but I will give it my best and continue with study. (Emphasis on the continuation of studying)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語は難しいけど、勉強を頑張り続ける。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Japanese is difficult, but I will continue giving it my best with study. (Emphasis on the continuation of giving it one's best)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テレビを見続けるつもりですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Do you plan to continue to watch TV?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まっすぐ見て、歩き続けなさい！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Look straight, and continue walking!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 文法の間違えを直し続けてみたらどうだ？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Why don't you try continuing to fix your grammar mistakes?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大きい魚を釣るまで釣り続けます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will continue to fish until I catch a big fish.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの警察官は一時間以上見回り続けた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That police officer continued to patrol around for over one hour.

Name: 様(よう)に言(い)う
Meaning: To tell, request, or order to do (in such a way)
About: ようにいう is an expression which combines the auxiliary verb ようだ, with the う-Verb 言(い)う. This indicates that something is being said in a way that instigates (A). As ようだ is being linked to the verb 言(い)う, it will take on its adverbial form, ように. As ようにいう means 'to be said in the way of (A) being done', it is regularly translated as 'to tell', 'to request', or 'to order'. In the case of requesting, 頼(たの)む may substitute for 言(い)う. For ordering, 命(めい)じる may substitute for it instead. 言(い)う itself is the most versatile of these three verbs, as it may imply 'to order', or 'to request'. This will depend on the tone of the speaker/overall context of the request/order.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供に水をこぼさないように言う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I tell my child not to spill his water. (To tell them in a way that 'not spilling the water' is the focus)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 弁護士が犯人に警察に話さないように言う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The lawyer told the criminal to not talk to the police. (To tell them in a way that 'not talking to the police' is the focus)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺の漫画を借りてもいいけど、破らないように頼むよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is okay for me to let you borrow my manga, but I request that you not rip it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 総理は国民に海外旅行に行かないように命じる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The prime minister will order citizens to not travel abroad.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムに手伝いをするように頼んだよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I requested (in such a way) that Tom help out.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供らが怖がらないように頼むよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I request that you not scare the kids. (in such a way)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 卵を買うように言ったはずだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I most definitely told you to pick up some eggs. (In such a way)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日試合があるので、今夜よく眠るように言った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since we have a game tomorrow, I told them to get a good night's sleep tonight. (In such a way)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 息子に本を月に1冊読むように言った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I told my son to read a book a month. (In such a way)

Name: 予定(よてい)だ
Meaning: Plan to, Intend to
About: 予定(よてい)だ is an expression that functions very similarly to つもりだ 'to intend to do'. The primary difference being that 予定(よてい) is a 'plan', rather than an 'intention'. Due to this,  予定(よてい) is used far more frequently for things that you have formal plans to do (like meeting a friend for lunch). To use 予定(よてい), just attach it to the non-past form of a verb, or to a noun (after inserting の).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今夜は先輩たちと飲みに行く予定だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I plan to go drink with my senpai tonight.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 休みは来週からの予定だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My break is planned to start from next week.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は友達とステーキを食べる予定だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have plans to eat a steak with a friend tomorrow. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は友達とステーキを食べる予定。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have an 'eating a steak with a friend' plan tomorrow. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会議は月曜日の予定です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The meeting is planned for Monday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 学校で研究をする予定です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I plan to do research at school.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 卒業してから、仕事を探す予定です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After graduating, I plan to look for a job.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電気代が高くなるけど、エアコンを点けておく予定だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The electric bill might be high, but I plan to leave the air conditioner on.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつ日本語を勉強し始める予定ですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When do you plan to start studying Japanese?

Name: 様(よう)に祈(いの)る
Meaning: Pray that/for, Hope that/for, Keep fingers crossed that
About: As we have seen several times now, the auxiliary verb ようだ is frequently used with verbs, to express that the 'completion' of an action is the specific goal/wish of the speaker. It does this implicitly through the meaning of the kanji 様(よう) 'manner of doing'. ようにいのる (or 祈(いの)る in its kanji form) is no different, and will imply that the speaker is praying for (A) to be done/completed. This comes from the meaning of the う-Verb 祈(いの)る itself, which can be translated as 'to pray', or 'to beg'. Despite being able to be used when actually praying, this grammar point is used most often to express a 'hope'. In a similar way to other ように structures, ないように may also be used with 祈(いの)る, to show that someone is praying for something 'not' to happen.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日雪が降って学校が休みになるように祈る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hope that it snows tomorrow and school gets canceled.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 世界が平和になるように祈る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hope that the world becomes a peaceful place.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 授業中に先生に呼ばれないように祈る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hope that the teacher doesn't call on me during class.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達の車に乗る前に死なないように祈る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Before I get in my friend's car, I pray that I don't die.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年は国に帰れますように。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I pray that you can go back to your country this year.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日のテストで合格できますように。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I pray that I can pass tomorrow's test.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 行きたい大学に行けるといいね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hope that you get into the college that you want to get into. (Hope for your sake)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来年は海外旅行に行けるといいな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hope I can travel abroad next year. (Hope for my own sake)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 生きてここを出られるように祈っているんだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am praying that I can leave this place alive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼が安全に帰れるように祈ろう！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's pray that he can come home safely.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うまく行くように祈って(ください)ね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please pray that it will go well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このノートパソコンに税金がかからないように祈っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am praying that this laptop is not subject to taxation!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うちの娘が事故に遭わないように祈っているわ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am praying that our daughter won't have an accident.

Name: ～たばかり
Meaning: Just did, Something just happened
About: As an adverbial particle, ばかり usually has one of three basic meanings. Degree: 程度(ていど) - Highlights the 'rough' amount/degree of something (similar to くらい). Limit: 限定(げんてい) - Highlights the 'limit' of something (similar to だけ). Completion: 完了(かんりょう) - Highlights the 'end', or 'completion' of something. In this lesson, we will focus primarily on the completion meaning. When connecting ばかり to the past form of a verb (using た), it will imply that a specific action has 'just finished', 'just stopped', or 'just been completed'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 駅に着いたばかりの時に友達から「やっぱり今日は遊べない」とメッセージが来た。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just as I got to the station, I got a message from my friend saying, 'Actually, I can't hang out today'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: スマホが壊れた。昨日買ったばかりなのに…。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My smartphone broke. Even though I just bought it yesterday...

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さっき食べたばかりだから、お腹はまだ空いていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I just ate earlier, so I am still not hungry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今、家を出た許りです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I just left home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電車に乗った許りの時に携帯を落とした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just when I got on the train, I dropped my phone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ユミに彼氏が出来たと聞いた許り。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I just heard that Yumi got a boyfriend.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その漢字を習った許りなのに、もう忘れた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though I just learned that kanji, I already forgot it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今の赤ちゃんは生まれた許りでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The baby we just saw was just born, right?

Name: 化(か)する
Meaning: -ification, -ization, To make something, To change, To become, Transform into
About: 化(か) by itself is a suffix in Japanese which means 'to change', or 'to transform'. When paired with する, it means 'to transform into (A)', where (A) is the noun that 化(か) is connected to. This structure is regularly translated as '~ification', or '~ization', and similar suffixes in English. When the する is connected to another noun, it may occasionally appear as した, or with の attached to the end of it. This will indicate that there is a relationship between (B) and (A). However, in formal/scientific writing, the する (and の) may sometimes be dropped.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あと数年で運転は自動化する。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In a few years driving will become automated.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は仕事で書類をデータ化する。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At work, I digitize documents.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 劣化した家を立て直す仕事をしたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want a job rebuilding deteriorated homes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本は紙社会なので仕事をオンライン化するのは厳しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since Japan is a paper society, digitalization of work is difficult.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本では高齢化が進んでいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In Japan, the population is aging progressively.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは単純化した英語のように見える。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
It appears to be simplified English.
(change/transform into)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ２０世紀には経済成長の原因の一つは自動化だと考えられている。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
It is considered that automation is one of the sources of economic growth in the 20th century.
(change/transform into)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お父さん、アプリはこうやって最小化するの。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Dad, you minimize apps like this.
(change/transform into)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その新たなタイプの電池が商品化する計画があると言われている。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
It is said that there are already plans to commercialize that new type of battery.
(change/transform into)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: プラスチックを液化する方法はエネルギ産業を一変させるかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
The plastic liquefaction method might revolutionize the energy industry.
(change/transform into)

Name: 命令形(めいれいけい)
Meaning: (Verb)!, Do (something)!
About: In Japanese, there are numerous ways to express an order, command, or instruction. The most direct, abrasive, and therefore least used method is called the imperative form, which happens to be one of the basic conjugations of verbs. Without particles following it, the imperative form is fairly uncommon in daily life, but will often be seen on traffic signs, posters, or banners. In addition, it can be also heard shouted at demonstrations, when cheering at sports events, or in urgent situations, such as an officer yelling at a suspect to stop. Verbs are conjugated into the imperative form in the following way. For う-Verbs, simply replace the last kana of any verb with the equivalent え sound kana from the same row. For る-Verbs, replace る with either ろ or よ. The imperative form may sometimes be softened with the particle よ. This is a pattern which is mostly used by men that are familiar with each other, in order to offer advice or encouragement. Women tend to use the more polite て-form of verbs instead. Any verb except for ある and いる may be conjugated to the imperative form, due to their meanings being based on existence and nothing more.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 道路標識：「止まれ！」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Road sign: 'Stop!'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 警察官：「手を上げろ。」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Policeman: Raise your hands!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 元気出せよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Cheer up!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 頑張れよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just give it your all!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: テスト：「１・２・３・４から一つ選びなさい。」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Test: 'Choose one answer out of 1, 2, 3, and 4.'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犬へ：「お座り。」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To a dog: 'Sit!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の携帯を返せ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Give back my cellphone!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もっと飲め！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Drink more!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ゴミはゴミ箱に捨てろ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Throw away your trash in the trash can!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 早く寝ろ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Sleep already!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生が「皆静かにしろ！」と言った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The teacher said, 'Everyone, be quiet!'

Name: 様(よう)に
Meaning: So that, In order to, In such a way that
About: When partnered with verbs in the potential form, or in the negative form, the auxiliary verb ようだ (in its adverbial form ように) implies that the speaker has a lack of direct control over an outcome, and therefore is 'trying to do (B) in the manner of (A)', but cannot guarantee the result. This grammar point is usually translated as 'to do (A) in such a way that will enable (B)', or 'in order to allow (B)'. To use ように in this way, simply add it to the non-past form of any verb in its negative, potential, or standard conjugation. As mentioned in our lesson about potential verbs, する does not actually have a potential form, and therefore できる will be used instead.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お母さんから離れないように手をつなぐ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hold my mothers hands so that I won't get separated from her.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 泥棒が入れないように家のカギを閉める。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I lock my house, so that burglars can't come in.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: マイケルジャクソンみたいに踊れるように毎日ダンスの練習をする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I practice dancing everyday, so that I can dance like Michael Jackson.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語をペラペラに話せるように毎日近所の人と日本語で話をしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I speak Japanese with my neighbor everyday, so that I can speak Japanese fluently.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勉強ができるように机の上を掃除した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I tidied up my desk so that I could study.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 平日にスキーが出来るように仕事を休んだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I took the day off of work, in order to be able to ski on a weekday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 例えば風邪を引かないように、暖かい服装をする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For example, I wear warm clothes so that I won't catch a cold.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼が理解出来るように説明しようと思っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I plan to explain it in such a way that he will be able to understand.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大事なことを忘れないようにいつもメモをしている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I always take notes so that I won't forget important things.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 間に合うように数分早く出るつもりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I plan to leave a few minutes earlier so that I will be on time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 太陽に目がくらまないように、スキーヤーはゴーグルをかけています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The skiiers wear goggles so that they won't be blinded (disoriented) by the sun.

Name: かしら
Meaning: I wonder
About: Originally, かしら was an abbreviation of か知(し)らぬ, or かしらん, which are both ways of expressing 'whether it's (A), I don't know'. These days, かしら is a standalone sentence ending particle that works in a similar way to かも, by expressing the speaker's uncertainty about the previous statement. かしら may be attached to the end of almost any phrase that the speaker wants to express doubt about.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あそこにいるのはタケル君かしら。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if that person over there is Takeru-kun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は晴れるかしら。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if it will clear up tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は雨が降るかしら。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder if it will rain today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: すぐ冷房をつけてくれないかしら。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder if they won't turn on the air conditioning for us soon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここで食べてもいいかしら。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder if it is ok to eat here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 納豆は変な匂いがするから、食べれるかしら。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since natto has a strange smell, I wonder if I will be able to eat it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あまり理解出来ていないみたい。行けるかしら。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It appears that they don't really understand. I wonder if it will go well.

Name: らしい ②
Meaning: typical of, -ish・like, appropriate for, becoming of, befitting
About: In our first らしい lesson, we discussed the auxiliary verb use of らしい. In this lesson we will focus on the 形容詞(けいようし)の一部(いちぶ) (auxiliary adjective) usage. An auxiliary adjective is a type of adjective that must be attached to another word for it to have any meaning. To use らしい in this way, it must be attached to the end of a noun, and will imply that something is 'typical of (A)', where (A) is the noun that comes before it. As this らしい behaves like an い-Adjective, it may also be conjugated to らしく, before a (B) phrase will explain more about 'what' is/was typical of (A). The primary use of this らしい is to express that (A) has some feature or trait that is expected of itself. It can be used for people, 'studying all night is so typical of Tanaka', or it can be used for things like seasons 'this heat is so typical of the Japanese Summer'. Other common translations are 'to be befitting of (A)', or 'to be appropriate for (A)'. However, it may also be used negatively, to show that something is (often surprisingly) 'uncharacteristic of (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムは本当に男らしいね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tom, you are really manly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タケル君はもうお兄ちゃんなので、お兄ちゃんらしくしなさい！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takeru, you are already an older brother, so you should act like an older brother!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やっと１０月らしい天気になったね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It has finally become October-like weather, don't you think?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムがこんなに勉強をしているのは見たことがない、トムらしくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I've never seen Tom study this much. It's very uncharacteristic of him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は８月らしくないです。涼しいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today is not typical of August. It's cool.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は女らしくない人だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She is an unladylike person.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年の８月は夏らしい夏だね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: August this year is the prime example of summer. (Literally, 'the most summery summer')

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「もっと大人らしくしなさいよ！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Behave more like an adult!' (befitting of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「やっと夏らしい日が来たよ！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'At last, a day befitting of summer has come!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「そんなことを言うのは、彼女らしい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Saying something like that, (it is) typical of her.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「カップルらしく映画を見に行こう！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Let's go to the movies like couples do!' (typical of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「あなたの笑顔の愛らしさに気づいたばかりだわ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I just noticed the loveliness of your smile.'

Name: にみえる
Meaning: To look, To seem, To appear
About: にみえる (primarily written only in hiragana) is a phrase that combines the case marking particleに, with the る-Verb見(み)える 'to appear', or 'to be visible'. This construction is regularly used with nouns, to show that something 'appears to be (A)', but it may also be partnered with the auxiliary verbs ようだ or そうだ (in their adverbial forms ように and そうに) to add a level of uncertainty. In these cases, it sounds closer to 'to seem to be (A)' in English. As with many other ようだ structures, みたい may be used instead. This creates the expression みたいにみえる. While this may appear confusing at first, it just means 'to look like something that could be (A)'. In this way it reinforces the 'guess' that the speaker is making.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの雲はアイスクリームにみえる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That cloud looks like ice cream.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サムの泳ぎ方は溺れているようにみえる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sam's way of swimming looks as if he is drowning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 寒そうにみえるけど、大丈夫？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You look like you are cold, are you okay?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの仕事は大変そうにみえる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That job looks like it is tough.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一人で暗い所にいるとなんでも顔のようにみえる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I am in a dark place alone, everything looks like a face.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このコートを着ると太ったみたいにみえるから嫌いだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems to look like I got fat when I wear this coat, so I don't like it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は忙しそうにみえる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He looks/appears busy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生は怒っているようにみえる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The teacher looks/appears angry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 水ぼうそうにみえるニキビ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Pimples that look like/have the appearance of chicken pox.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このスーツケースは軽くみえる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This suitcase looks light/appears light.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は幸せそうにみえる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She seems/appears happy.

Name: と見(み)える
Meaning: It seems that, It can be deduced, One can conclude that
About: とみえる (primarily written only in hiragana) is a phrase that combines the case marking particle と, with the る-Verb見(み)える 'to appear', or 'to be visible'. This use of the と particle in Japanese is called a result, and marks when (A) is something that has come to a conclusion, or can be concluded. In this way とみえる literally means 'from the way it appears, one can conclude that it's (A)'. However, this translates a bit more smoothly as 'it can be deduced that (A)', or 'it seems that (A)'. This expression is always used directly after the phrase that it is drawing as a conclusion. However, nouns and な-Adjectives will require だ before とみえる. While this phrase is conjecture (making a guess about something), it usually implies that the speaker has done some sort of research, or has some reason that led them to 'draw (A) as a conclusion'. Due to this, it appears reasonably confident.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家の窓が外から割られていた。泥棒に入られたとみえる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The windows of the house have been broken from the outside, so I can deduce that a burglar came in.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は上着を脱いだ。彼は暑いとみえる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He took off his jacket, so it seems that he is hot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はサンドイッチを残した。彼はサンドイッチが嫌いだとみえる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He left the sandwich, so I can conclude that he doesn't like sandwiches.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムは今日は会社に来なかった。トムは昨日風邪を引いたから今日は休みだとみえる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tom didn't come to work today. He caught a cold yesterday, so I can conclude that he is resting today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生が生徒に「廊下で走るな」と言った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The teacher said 'don't run in the hallway' to the students.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 母とレストランに行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I went to the restaurant with my mother.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昼寝をすると夜に寝れなくなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't fall asleep at night if I take a nap during the day.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの親は優しいとみえる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Those parents seem nice.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 家に行ったけど留守と見えた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I went to their house, but it seemed that they weren't home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はマラソンを走ったと見えてハアハア言っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It seems that he ran a marathon, he is breathing heavily.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テストに落ちたから、勉強してなかったと見える。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since he failed the test, one can conclude that he did not study.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 水と見えたが、ラムネでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It seemed that it was water, but it was lemon soda. (One can conclude that)

Name: 風(ふう)
Meaning: -style, Way, Fashion
About: 風(ふう) is a suffix that is used in Japanese to convey the meaning of 'in the style of (A)', or 'in the fashion of (A)'. Literally, this translates to 'in the wind of (A)', which is just the Japanese way of expressing the former statements. To use 風(ふう), attach it to the end of a noun that you want to label something as being in the 'style' of. の may also be attached to the end of 風(ふう), before connecting it to another noun. This will show that '(B) is in the style of (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ９０年代風ファッションがまた流行ってきています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: 90's style fashion is starting to gain popularity again.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アメリカ風料理が好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like American style food.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: メキシコ風の料理を食べたいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to eat Mexican food.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 広島風のお好み焼きが一番おいしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hiroshima-style okonomiyaki is the most delicious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お母さんはオランダ風のサラダが好きだよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My mother likes Dutch-style salad.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パブは韓国風のほうがいいと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When it comes to pubs, I think I prefer the Korean style.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 中国風のドレスがほしいよ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want the Chinese-style dress!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このイラストは漫画風だね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This illustration is in manga style, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それはアメリカ風の生活と言われている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is said that that is the American style of life.

Name: が見(み)られる
Meaning: Can see, Can be seen, Can observe, Can be observed, Be evident, Chance to see something
About: Unlike 見(み)える 'to be visible', which focuses on whether something can be seen or not, 見(み)られる (the potential form of 見(み)る) focuses on the viewer's physical ability to see something. Due to this が見(み)られる is used to highlight things that require some form of 'effort' to see, like 'changes', 'trends', etc. As a result of the 'effort' that is required, が見(み)られる is often translated as 'for (A) to be evident', 'it can be observed that (A)', 'it can be seen that (A)', and other similar structures. To use 見(み)られる, simply add it after the noun that you would like to show as being 'evident'. As られる is both the potential and passive form of 見(み)る, it may be interpreted either way. However, in the case of ラ抜(ぬ)き言葉(ことば) (ら removed verbs), only 可能(かのう) (possibility) may be expressed, not 受(う)け身(み) (passivity).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この部屋からは富士山が見られる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Mount Fuji can be seen from this room. (If you look closely, and it is a clear day)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 奈良に行くと、横断歩道を渡るシカが見られる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you go to Nara, you can observe deer crossing the crosswalk. (If you are lucky, and the timing is right)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近はタッチパネルが付いている冷蔵庫が見られる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, refrigerators with touch panels can be seen.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近はタッチパネルが付いている冷蔵庫が見れる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, you can see refrigerators with touch panels.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夏には、ここでクマが見られます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In summer, bears can be seen here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 最近ガラスでできているスマホが見られる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Recently, smartphones that are made of glass can be seen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつか姫路城が見られるといいな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I hope I can see Himeji Castle one day. (chance to be seen)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どこで紙芝居が見られますか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Where can the picture story show be seen?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: よく見てみると動物の足跡が見られる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you look closely, animal tracks can be observed.

Name: に気(き)が付(つ)く
Meaning: To notice (that), To realize (that)
About: に気(き)が付(つ)く is a common expression that highlights when someone 'notices that (A)', or 'realizes that (A)'. 付(つ)く 'to be attached' is the intransitive form of 付(つ)ける 'to attach', meaning that it is something that happens by itself. The case marking particle に marks the 'location' to where your 気(き) (sometimes interpreted as 'attention') becomes attached. This structure may be used after nouns, or verbs that have been nominalized with either の, or こと.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 待ち合わせ場所に着いてから、携帯を忘れたことに気が付いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I realized that I had forgotten my phone only after I arrived at the meeting place.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犬に餌をあげていないのに気が付いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I realized that I didn't feed my dog.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 猛スピードでこっちに来ている車に気が付いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I noticed that there was a car heading this direction at a crazy speed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何がないか気がついたのだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder if he has noticed what is missing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今、お金を忘れたことに気がついたばかりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I just now noticed that I forgot my money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自分のミスに気がつきましたか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Did you notice your mistake?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: わぁ！気がついたの？嬉しい！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Woah! You noticed? I'm so happy!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は母の誕生日だ！ 気がついていなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Today is Mom's birthday! I didn't notice.

Name: でも〜でも
Meaning: Whether ~ or, Neither ~ or
About: When the adverbial particle でも is used more than once in a sequence, it is an extension of one of its regular meanings, analogical reasoning. However, several 'analogies' are being presented. This use of でも is regularly translated as 'whether it is (A), or (B)', or 'neither (A) nor (B)', depending on whether the rest of the phrase is positive, or negative. Literally, the translation of 〜でも〜でも is closer to the following: Even if it's (A), even if it's (B), (C) is the result. (In a positive sentence) Even if it's (A), even if it's (B), (C) is not the result. (In a negative sentence)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サッカーでもバスケットボールでもいいからスポーツをやりたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether it is soccer or basketball, I want to play sports.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ケーキでもクッキーでも苺が入っていたらどちらも食べない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if it is a cake or a cookie, I will not eat it if it has strawberries in it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これでも、それでも、何でもいいです！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether this, or that, whatever (is fine)!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サッカーでも、卓球でも、彼ならスポーツは何でもできる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether it's soccer or table tennis, he can play any sport.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電車でも、バスでも行ける場所なので、便利です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You can get there whether by train or bus, so it's convenient.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼がＭａｃでもＷｉｎｄｏｗｓでも使えるって。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (He said) that whether it's Mac or Windows, he can use them.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: じゃんけんでも、サイコロでも何でもいいから、早く決めてよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether it is with rock, paper, scissors or with dice, or whatever, hurry up and decide.

Name: それに
Meaning: And, Besides, Moreover, In addition
About: The conjunction それに is regularly considered to be one word in Japanese, but is more correctly just a combination of the pronoun それ, and the case marking particle に. The thing that それ is 'substituting' for is the entire clause/sentence that came before it, while に highlights that extra information is about to be added. In this way, it translates to 'and to that', or 'and on that', where 'that' is the previous information. Often, it is translated simply as 'moreover', 'in addition', or 'and'. Because それに is 'adding' information with に, the (B) information itself must be something that would logically happen 'in addition to (A)', or 'as a result of (A)'. Therefore, それに will highlight something that has either all positive, or all negative connotations. Never both.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それに彼は家事もしないんでしょう？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In addition, he doesn't do house chores either, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: リサの会社には残業がない。それに給料もいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Lisa's company doesn't have overtime work. What's more, her salary is good too.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日、道で五千円を拾って、それに車が抽選で当たった！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Yesterday, I picked up 5 thousand yen on the street, and in addition to that I won a car in the lottery. (Natural Japanese, as both events are positive)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近は雨がいっぱい降るし、それに風も強いし、外に出れなくて寂しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, it has been raining a lot, and in addition to that the wind has been strong. I'm sad that I can't go outside. (Natural Japanese, as both events are negative)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今朝はマッサージに行って、それにスピード違反の切符も切られた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I went to get a massage this morning, and moreover I also got a speeding ticket. (Unnatural Japanese, as one event is positive, while the other is negative)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 運動は楽しいです。それに体にいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Exercise is fun. In addition, it's good for you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夜遅くまで働きます。それに朝も早いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I work late into the night. In addition, I am up early.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この旅館の料理が美味しい。それに周りの景色も美しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This Japanese-style hotel's food is delicious. Moreover, the surrounding scenery is beautiful.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本は住みやすい。それに病院代が安い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is easy to live in Japan. Moreover medical expenses are reasonable.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 山の上からの景色が綺麗。それに空気も綺麗。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The scenery from atop the mountain is beautiful. In addition the air is clear.

Name: それで
Meaning: Because of that, So?, And then?, Therefore, With that
About: Like それに, それで is another conjunction that is regularly considered to be one word in Japanese, but is more correctly just a combination of the pronoun それ, and the case marking particle で. The thing that それ is 'substituting' for is the entire clause/sentence that came before it, while で highlights that 'with that', or 'by means of that'. In this way, it translates to 'therefore', 'because of that', or 'with that' where 'that' is the previous information. それで is frequently used at the beginning of a second sentence, to highlight the information from the first.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は子供のころにお医者さんに命を救われた。それで医者になろうと思った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A doctor saved my life when I was a child. Due to that, I became determined to be a doctor.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は電車の中で痴漢をした。それで彼は警察に捕まった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He groped someone on the train. As a result of that, he got arrested by the cops.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サリーは世界中のほとんどの国に行ったことがある。それで旅行会社で働くことにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sally has been to most countries in the world. Because of that, she decided to work at a travel agency.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それでは、会議を始めます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well then, I will start the meeting.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それじゃミクは来ないの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In that case, Miku, are you not coming?

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「其れでプロジェクトどうなったのですか？」
「期限通りに終わりました。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'And then, what happened to the project?'
'We finished it on time.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ＪＬＰＴに合格したいです。其で毎日しっかり勉強しています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to pass the JLPT. Therefore, I study hard every day.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この辺りには多くの桜が植えられている。其で外国人が花見に来る人気の観光スポットになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In this area, numerous cherry trees are growing. Because of that, it has become a popular tourist attraction where many foreigners come to view cherry blossoms.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このヘビは有毒の一種です。其で非常に危険だと考えられています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This snake is one of (many) venomous species. Because of that, it is considered extremely dangerous.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いずくさんは子供の頃よくいじめられました。其で弱い者の味方になっています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Izuku-san was often bullied as a child. Therefore, he is now an ally of the weak.

Name: (Question-Phrase) + か
Meaning: Including questions within sentences
About: Often, the adverbial particle か is used in the middle of a sentence, in the same way that it is as a sentence ending particle. The main differences are as follows: Adverbial Particle: 副助詞(ふくじょし) - Highlights uncertain things '不確(ふたし)かであること'. This is the same か as in どこか 'somewhere'. Sentence Ending Particle: 終助詞(しゅうじょし) - Highlights doubts and questions '疑問(ぎもん)や質問(しつもん)'. This is a direct question.
