In the case of the adverbial particle か and 'uncertain things', this will almost always be followed by a word that is seeking information about the uncertain thing. As can be seen in these examples, sometimes the adverbial particle will appear by itself, and sometimes it will appear together with the sentence ending particle in the same sentence. However, due to the 'uncertainty' being displayed by the adverbial particle, the question marker at the end of the sentence is not required.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 忘年会に社長が来るか分かりますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you know if the CEO is coming to the end of year party? (Literally, 'If the CEO is coming, do you know?')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これで足りるか分かる？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you know if this is enough? (Literally, 'If this is enough, do you know?')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何でこのビルを壊すか知っていますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you know why they are destroying this building? (Literally, 'Why they are destroying it, do you know?')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お祭りは何時に終わるか知ってる？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you know what time the festival is going to end? (Literally, 'What time it will end, do you know?')

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕がどこにいるかわかる？
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Do you know where I am?
(question within a larger sentence)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつ美術館に行くか決めましたか？
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Have you decided when you are going to the art museum?
(question within a larger sentence)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の好みの味が何かわかる？
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Do you know what kind of flavor(s) he likes?
(question within a larger sentence)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼が誰のことを好きかわかりません。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
I do not know who he likes.
(question within a larger sentence)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何を消したか知っている？
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Do you know what was erased?
(question within a larger sentence)

Name: それでも
Meaning: But still, And yet, Even so, Nevertheless
About: それでも is a combination of the pronoun それ, and the adverbial particle でも. It is often translated simply as 'even so', or 'nevertheless'. Literally, it is a bit closer to 'even with that'. それでも is usually used between an (A) and a (B) phrase, to show that there is more information (usually surprising) to be considered. This grammar point primarily expresses that 'even with' what has been said previously, it is not all there is to think about.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は雨が降るよ、それでも釣りに行くの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's going to rain today, even with that, are you still going fishing?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は殴られたり、蹴られたりするのが嫌いです。それでも、空手が好きなので辞めれないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't like getting punched or kicked, even so, I like karate so it is hard to quit.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このコーヒーは甘いですが、それでも砂糖を加えます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This coffee is sweet but nevertheless, I will add sugar.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: タバコは体に悪いと言われている。それでも、止めにくい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is said that smoking is bad for you and yet it is tough to quit.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 高いのに、それでも買うつもりですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is expensive and yet you are still planning on buying it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そのカップルがずっと喧嘩している。それでも、よく旅行に行く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That couple is always fighting. Nevertheless they often go on trips together.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生がインフルエンザにかかった。それでも、学校を休んでいない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The teacher got the flu. Nevertheless he still came to school.

Name: たらどう
Meaning: Why don't you...?, What if you did...?
About: When the conjunction particle たら is used before the adverb どう, it primarily presents a situation, then asks a question about it potentially happening. This construction can be translated as 'why don't you (A)?', or 'what if you did (A)?'. Realistically, it just means 'when (A), how about that?'. It is often used for giving advice. To use this expression, convert the verb that you want to use into its たら form, and then add どう. Sometimes たら is used by itself, with a tone that implies that it is a question (or simply by adding a question mark in written language). This is an abbreviation of たらどう, and carries the same nuance. だ or か may be added to the end of たらどう, to emphasize the 'question' even further. However, they are not required.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 食べる量を減らしたらどう？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why don't you reduce the amount you eat?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: テレビがつかないの？叩いてみたらどう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Your TV doesn't turn on? Why don't you try hitting it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 暇なら外に行ったら？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are bored, why don't you go outside?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 警察に電話をしてみたらどうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why don't you try calling the police?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 苦いなら砂糖を入れたらどうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it is bitter, why don't you add some sugar?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たまには頭を使ったらどう？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why don't you use your head occasionally? (You should try thinking for once)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 公園に遊びに行ったらどうですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Why don't you go to play in the park?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あそこのゴミを拾ったらどうですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Why don't you go pick up that garbage over there?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ダイエットをしてみたらどう？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Why don't you try dieting?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんなに彼が好きだったら、付き合ったらどう？
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you like him that much, why don't you go out with him?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本に居て寂しいなら、アメリカに帰ったらどう？
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you feel lonely in Japan, why don't you go back to America?

Name: と考(かんが)えられている
Meaning: Is considered, Is thought of as
About: In its citation usage, the case marking particleと is often used with verbs in the passive form. Two of these regularly occurring verbs are 考(かんが)えられている 'to be considered', and 思(おも)われている 'to be thought'. This grammar point is used after a phrase, and translates as 'it is considered that (A)', or 'it is thought that (A)'. It is generally used to highlight a commonly held opinion that most people agree on (not your personal opinion). The primary reason that these constructions are used in their displacement (passive) form, is to show that the thought itself is not something that is related to the speaker's own opinions. However, people will often use this form as a way to strengthen their own opinions, in a similar way to how English speakers would say 'everyone knows that (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 「最初はグー」と最初に言ったのは、志村けんだと考えられている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Shimura Ken is considered to be the first person who said 'saisho wa gu'. (A phrase said before playing rock, paper, scissors, in Japan)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このトンネルは日本で一番呪われているトンネルだと思われている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This tunnel is thought to be one of the most cursed tunnels in Japan.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カバは世界で最も危ない動物だと考えられている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Everyone knows that hippos are the most dangerous animal in the world.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: イルカはとても賢いと考えられている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Dolphins are considered to be very intelligent.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この街に海賊が住んでいたと考えられている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is thought that pirates used to live in this town.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お金はどんな人にも悪い影響があると考えられている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Money is considered to have a bad influence on anyone and everyone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この建物は５００年頃建てられたと考えられている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This building is thought to have been built around the year 500.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一週間でひらがなを覚えることができると考えられている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is thought that you can memorize hiragana in one week.

Name: とされている
Meaning: To be considered, To be deemed, Be regarded as, Be accepted as, To be said, To be accredited with
About: とされている is an expression that is commonly translated as 'to be considered as (A)', or 'to be regarded as (A)'. Conceptually, it is similar to にする, which means 'to decide on (A)'. However, due to する being in the passive form in this construction, it is closer to 'to be decided on', and expresses the general opinions/thoughts of large groups of people. The と in this expression is a case marking particle, and expresses the result nuance of this particle.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今の時代にはインターネットが必要だとされている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In current times, the internet is widely considered to be necessary.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはニコラテスラが発明したものだとされている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is considered to be something invented by Nikola Tesla.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 水は氷となる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Water becomes ice. (As a result of transformation, water will be ice)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 温度が０度になると、水は氷となる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If the temperature is 0 degrees, it results in water becoming ice.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 論文：「ＷＰ４０は使用が多いとされている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Essay/article: 'WP 40 is (generally) considered to have many applications.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 論文：「ポーランド人には１３という数字は不吉な数字とされている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Essay/article: 'The number 13 is considered unlucky by the Polish.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 論説：「ジム・モリソンの正確な死因は不明とされているのである。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Dissertation: 'The exact cause of Jim Morrison's death is (widely) regarded to be unknown.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 論説：「歴史的に平仮名は元は『女のもの』だとされていた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Dissertation: 'Historically, hiragana was originally (widely) considered 'a woman's thing.''

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 論説：「過度のアルコール飲料の摂取は多数の病気の原因になるとされている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Dissertation: 'It is (generally) accepted that excessive consumption of alcohol causes numerous diseases.'

Name: と言(い)われている
Meaning: It is said that, Is known as
About: といわれている is often translated as 'to be said that (A)', or 'it is known that (A)'. Like とされている, it is another construction that links the case marking particleと, with the passive form of another verb, to mark a commonly held/public opinion. The verb in this case being 言(い)う. However, unlike とされている which expresses a 'result', といわれている expresses 引用(いんよう) a 'quotation'. To use といわれている, add it to the end of a phrase that you would like to express as being a common thing that is said. This particular grammar point is regularly seen both with, and without the kanji for 言(い)う, as the meaning will not change depending on its usage.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大阪のタコ焼きは日本一美味しいといわれている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is said that Osaka's takoyaki is the most delicious in Japan.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ティフアナは世界一危険な町といわれている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is said that Tijuana is the most dangerous city in the world.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 危ないと言われているので、しないほうがいいよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because it is said that it is dangerous, you shouldn't do it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ライオンがジャングルの王様だと言われている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is said that the lion is the king of the jungle.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: プロテインを食べると力がつくと言われている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is said that if you eat protein, you will gain power.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 見えないことは信じられないことだと言われている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is said that seeing is believing. (Things that cannot be seen are unbelievable)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ひどいことをしたから、犯人と言われている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is said that he is a criminal because he did terrible things.

Name: ば良(よ)かった
Meaning: Should have, I wish, It would have been better to
About: ばよかった is a common expression used when someone regrets that something has not been/was not done. It is a pairing of the conjunction particle ば, and the past form of the い-Adjective, 良(い)い (remembering that conjugations of いい use よ, and not い). This construction is often translated to 'I wish I did (A)', or 'I should have done (A)'. ばよかった is used after verbs, so requires the standard ば conjugation, before adding よかった. As ば highlights hypothetical situations, ばよかった literally means that 'it would have been good if (A)', where (A) is the thing that the speaker wishes had happened.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サービスエリアが一つもないじゃないか。高速に乗る前にトイレに行けばよかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There aren't any service stops, are there? I wish I had gone to the bathroom before we got on the highway.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日も残業？昨日は早く寝ればよかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have to work overtime again today? I should have gone to sleep early last night.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運転をしたくなかったら、電車で行けばいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you don't want to drive, it would be better if you went by train.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 次の電車を待てば良かったです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I should have waited for the next train.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ゲームより勉強をすれば良かったです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would have been better to study rather than play games.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 天気予報を見れば良かったです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I should have looked at the weather forecast.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スーパーに行った時、牛乳を買えば良かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I should have bought milk while I was at the store.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寝ないで、日本語を勉強すれば良かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would have been better to study Japanese rather than sleep.

Name: ばいい
Meaning: Can, Should, It'd be good if
About: In contrast to ばよかった, which is used for expressing regret about something that someone wishes had been done, ばいい highlights that the speaker is hoping for a particular result, in relation to something that has not happened yet. This translates as 'It'd be good if (A)'. To use ばいい, add the conjunction particle ば, to the end of the normal verb conjugation used for ば, and then attach the い-Adjective, いい. Although ばいい literally means 'if (A), it's good', it can also be used to give advice, and has a meaning that is similar to 'should (A)' in these situations. It is generally quite a soft way of giving advice.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どれを食べればいいか迷ってるところ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm a little lost as to which one would be good to eat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 行ければいいけど、行けるか分からない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would be good if I could go, but I don't know if I can.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: テストでいい点を取りたかったら、勉強すればいいんじゃない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you want a good grade on your test, shouldn't you just study?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなに疲れているなら、仕事を休めばいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are that tired, you should just take a day off.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 早く寝れればいいのに、全然寝れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would be good if I could fall asleep quickly, but I can't sleep at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 好きなら彼にそう言えばいいのに。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though you should just say it if you like him… (Why don't you)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 休めばいいのに、皆真面目だから休まない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They should take a break, but because they are all very diligent, they won't.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 運動をすればいいだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would probably be good if you exercised.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それいつまでにやればいい？
Questions.EnglishHTML: When would it be good to do it by?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 眠たいならちょっと仮眠をとればいいのに。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you are sleepy it would be good to take a short nap.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仕事に早くいけばいいと思いますよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think that it would be better to go to work early.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 道の案内を、誰にきけばいいのか分からない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't know who would be good to ask directions from.

Name: といい
Meaning: It would be nice if, It would be good if, Should, I hope
About: When any of the conjunction particles that carry the meaning of 'if' (たら, ば, or と) are paired with the い-Adjective, いい, they will express the desired result of the speaker. These all translate to 'it would be nice if (A)'. However, the speaker's level of certainty about the result being 'good' will change slightly, depending on the particle. ばいい - Hypothetically, (A) happening would be good. (Lowest strength/certainty) たらいい - When (A) happens, it will be good. (Medium strength/certainty) といい - The result of (A) is good. (Strongest/most certain) To use ば, たら, or と with いい, first add the conjunction particle to the end of any verb, and then attach the い-Adjective, いい.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日までに届けばいいんだけど、多分届かないと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would be good if it gets delivered by tomorrow, but I don't think it will.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私もあんなに早く走れたらいいな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would be nice if I could also run that fast.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来年は海外旅行に行けるといいね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would be nice if we could travel abroad next year, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 毎日、好きな番組が見れたらいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be nice if I could watch my favorite TV show everyday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自由にしたらいいでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be nice to just do whatever you want, wouldn't it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日と明後日も晴れるといいですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be nice if the weather was clear tomorrow and the day after, wouldn't it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 文句を言わないで！どうしたらいいのか教えてよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Stop complaining! Tell me what would be good to do!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕もイルカみたいに上手に泳げたらいいのに。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wish I could swim well like a dolphin. (it would be good if...)

Name: 中(ちゅう)
Meaning: During, While, Throughout, In the process of
About: As a suffix, 中(ちゅう) is frequently used to highlight a period of time (or space). By attaching the case marking particle に to 中, the sentence can be modified to show that (B) is happening/existing throughout the timeframe/space of (A). This is often translated as 'throughout (A), (B)', or 'during (A), (B)'. First, let's take a look at 中(ちゅう) being used to show events that are in process. Now, to show that a (B) event is happening within (A), simply add the case marking particle に to show a 'temporal location'. This will be done by attaching に to the end of any noun that you would like to indicate as the being the 'space' within which another thing exists/occurs. In these examples, we can see that 中(ちゅう)に is sometimes read/said as 中(じゅう)に. The basic rule for when to use ちゅう or when to use じゅう is as follows: 中(ちゅう)に - Expresses a very specific (usually small) amount of time/space, or something that is not always the same (an amount of time/space that can change, depending on the person/situation). This 'thing' that ちゅう highlights is usually a 'process', and therefore means that (A) is 'in the process' of happening. Examples - A meeting, class, visit to somewhere. 中(じゅう)に - Expresses a predetermined amount of time/space that will always remain the same, regardless of the person/situation. Therefore, じゅう does not highlight a 'process', but focuses on the 'length' or 'space' itself. This tends to mean 'all throughout', as it focuses on the full amount of time/space. Examples - A day, year, house, town or country.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今は仕事中なんだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am in the middle of working right now.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 締め切りは今月中なんです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The deadline is sometime (during) this month.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は休憩中に本を読む。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He reads books during his break. (At some point during the act of taking a break)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は勉強中に話されるのが嫌いだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't like being talked to while studying. (At some point during the act of study)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日中にレポートを提出してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please submit your papers by today. (Within today as the limit)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年中にイタリアに行きたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to go to Italy this year. (Within this year as the limit)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 食事中に電話がかかってくると、イラっとする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It ticks me off when I get a phone call while I'm eating.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ゴミが家中に広がっていて、歩くスペースがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is so much garbage throughout my house, that there is no room to walk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一日中、勉強をした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I studied (all) throughout the day.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 授業中に、トイレに行きたくなった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: During class, I had to go to the bathroom.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食事中にスマホをいじるのはやめなさい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Quit playing on your smartphone while you are eating!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まだ考え中だから、決めていないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am still in the process of thinking, so I haven't decided yet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テスト中に私の携帯が鳴ってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My phone accidentally rang during the test.

Name: の間(あいだ)に
Meaning: While, During, Between, Period
About: 間(あいだ)に is an expression that can be used with almost any type of word, to highlight that (A) is the period/space within which something else will or did happen/exist. It may also be a period/space 'until' something else will or did happen/exist. It is a combination of the noun 間(あいだ), and the case marking particle に. When used with verbs or い-Adjectives, 間(あいだ)に will simply follow the verb/adjective. However, の will be required after nouns, while な will be required after な-Adjectives. When 間(あいだ)に is being used to express the period/space 'until' something happens/exists, it will be paired with まで. With 間(あいだ)に, the (B) action/location is usually something that can or did happen/exist at a 'specific' point during (A), and does/did not take up the whole time-frame/space of (A). In this way, it can translate more literally as 'in the span of (A)'. This comes from the kanji 間(あいだ)'s common meaning as 'an interval'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あくびをしている間に笑わせないでって前も言ったじゃないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I told you before not to make me laugh while I'm yawning!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 若い間に色々な経験をした方がいいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would be better if you experience many different things while you are young.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 暇な間に、部屋の片付けをしておこう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While I'm free, I should clean my room. (Because I can't when I am busy)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫とシンクの間に箸を落としてしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I accidentally dropped a chopstick between the sink and the refrigerator.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １月から４月までの間に日本に行きたいと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think I want to go to Japan sometime between January and April.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １３時から１５時までの間に連絡をください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please give us a call from the period of between 1pm and 3 pm.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は冬休みの間に地元へ帰った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She went back to her home town during winter break.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コンタクトと目の間にゴミが入って、目がとても痛い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My eye is extremely sore because I got something between my contact and my eye.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつも眠っている間に歯軋りをしてしまう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I always grind my teeth while I'm asleep.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私が暇な間に、電話をかけてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please call me while I am free.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仕事に行くまでの間に掃除したかったけど無理だった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: During the time that I had before going to work I wanted to clean, but it was not possible.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私が家にいる間に、電話をかけてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please call me while I am at home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕が東京に行っていた５年の間に、彼は変わってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He had changed during the 5 years I was in Tokyo.

Name: 内(うち)に
Meaning: While, During
About: When うち, (sometimes seen using the kanji 内(うち), or 裡(うち)) is paired with the case marking particle に, it expresses a period/space 'within' which something else will/should happen/exist. It quite often (but not always) carries the nuance of (A) being the 'best', or the 'optimal' time/space within which (B) could occur/exist. In English, うちに can simply be translated as 'while', or 'during'. うちに may be paired with the dictionary or ている form of verbs, the plain form of い-Adjectives, nouns followed by の, or な-Adjectives that are followed by な. Unlike 間(あいだ)に, うちに expresses something that can happen/exist anywhere 'within' the span of (A), and is therefore non-specific as to where (B) is located.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼と毎日会ううちに、だんだんと彼の事が好きになってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As I meet with him every day, I have gradually come to like him. (As I spend more time with him every day, I have grown to like him)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 熱いうちに食べて！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Eat it while it's hot!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お爺ちゃんがまだ元気なうちに家族皆で旅行に行こう！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let's all go on a family trip while grandpa is still healthy!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今のうちに明日の準備をしておこう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let's get ready for tomorrow while we have time. (Before it is too late)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運転している間に眠くなったので、コンビニで休憩をした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I got sleepy while driving, so I took a break at a convenience store. (While in the process of driving)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運転しているうちに眠くなったので、コンビニで休憩をした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I got sleepy while driving, so I took a break at a convenience store. (At one point while driving)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 近い内に連絡します。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'll be in touch before long.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 鉄は熱い内に打て。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Strike while the iron is hot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 授業を受けている内に、宿題を完成させた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was able to finish my homework while taking a class.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 赤ちゃんは食べている内に寝てしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The baby fell asleep while eating.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本にいる内に東京に行ってみたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While I am in Japan, I want to see Tokyo.

Name: ない内(うち)に
Meaning: Before it becomes, Before ~ occurs, Without
About: In contrast to うちに, which is often used to express the 'optimal', or 'best' time within which something should occur, ないうちに expresses the time within which something 'does not' occur, and results in (or causes) something negative, or will cause something negative if not dealt with. This means that 'before (A) happens (B)', or 'without (A) happening, (B). うちに will be paired with verbs in their ない (negative) form, before the (B) phrase highlights something that 'is done to prevent (A) from happening', or 'happened unfortunately during (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こうき君、全然会わないうちに、凄く大きくなったね！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Kouki-kun, you have grown so much during the time we haven't met. (Since the last time I saw you)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: また電話をかけ忘れるところだった。忘れないうちに電話しておかなきゃ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was just about to forget to make a phone call again. I should call before I forget.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 出かける前にバイオリンの練習をしないといけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I need to practice playing my violin before I go out.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 知らないうちに家の前にあるラーメン屋が潰れていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Without realizing it, the ramen shop in front of my house went out of business.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暗くならない内に帰って来なさいよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Come back home before it gets dark.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私が知らない内に、友達が離婚していた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Before I knew it, my friend was divorced.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 冷めない内にお召し上がりください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please eat it before it gets cold.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 眠くならない内に宿題を終わらせよう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's finish the homework before I get sleepy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いくらも泳がない内に、向こう岸についてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Without swimming that much, I reached the other shore.

Name: べき
Meaning: Must, Should , Ought to
About: The auxiliary verb べき, being the attributive form of べし, is a structure in Japanese that is often paired with verbs to express that something 'ought to be done'. It implies some sort of moral obligation, or that (A) is the only reasonable course of action. This comes from the kanji 可(べ)き, which carries the meaning of being something 'permissible' (indicating that any other action would not be acceptable). べき will be paired with the plain (non-past) form of a verb, before being followed by either だ, or another noun. べき is also sometimes translated as 'must do (A)', or 'should do (A)' but it is important to remember that it will always have the nuance of being the only 'permissible' choice, and is therefore very strong.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そういう事は本人に言うべきだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You ought to say things like that to the person themselves.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客さんの意見はちゃんと聞くべきだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You ought to properly listen to customers' opinions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ハマサキさんは尊敬するべき人だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hamasaki-san is someone you ought to look up to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたに教えるべき事はこれで全部です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: With this, I have now taught you all of the things that I ought to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やばいやばい、車が止まりそう！高速に乗る前にガソリンを入れておくべきだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is not good… ahhh not good, the car is about to stop! I should have filled the car up with gasoline before I got on the highway.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大変申し訳ございません。こちらがもっと早く気づくべきでした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We are very sorry. We should have noticed this earlier.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 結婚する前に相手と将来の話しをするべきだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Before marrying, you should talk about the future with your partner.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家族は何があっても大切にすべきだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You should prioritize family no matter what happens.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 税金を払う可きです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You should pay taxes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 考える可きことが多すぎて、頭が痛い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are too many things I should think about, so my head hurts.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 言う可きことを言うのは親の義務だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Saying things that you should say is a duty of a parent.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰も見ていなくても、法律は守る可きだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even when no one is looking, you should obey the law.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日の会議は重大な話があるので、出席をする可きだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because we will talk about something important at tomorrow's meeting, everyone should attend.

Name: べきではない
Meaning: Should not, Must not , Ought not to
About: As an extension of the auxiliary verb べき, that is partnered with verbs to convey 'ought to do (A)', べきではない  (or べきじゃない) highlights the opposite, and means 'ought not to (A)', 'should not (A)', or 'must not (A)'. Just like べき, it is quite strong, and implies that doing (A) would be considered improper/incorrect. べきではない (or べきじゃない) will be paired with the plain (non-past) form of a verb.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 濡れている手でコンセントに触れるべきではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must not touch the outlet with wet hands.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんなにいう事を聞かなくても、子供に手をあげるべきじゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how much a child doesn't listen to what you say, you ought not to raise your hand at them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一人であの山に行くべきではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must not go to that mountain alone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 人を傷つけるような事を言うべきではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You ought not to say anything that could hurt a person's feelings.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: テストの前に徹夜をするべきではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You ought not to stay up all night before a test.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: くだらないことで警察に電話すべきではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must not call the cops for something trivial.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなた一人だけで決める可きではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You should not decide alone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 腐っている食べ物を食べる可きではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You shouldn't eat food that is rotten.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 禁煙場所では、タバコを吸う可きではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You should not smoke in places that are non-smoking.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大したことないよ。心配をする可きではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's not important. You shouldn't worry about it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人が嫌がることをする可きではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You should not do things people dislike.

Name: って
Meaning: As for, Speaking of, Casual は (Sentence topic marker)
About: Although って can be used as a casual quotation marker in Japanese (replacing と), it is also frequently used as a casual topic marker (replacing は). This is something that occurs primarily in spoken language, and will come directly after the sentence topic, in exactly the same way as the adverbial particle は usually would.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私って皆に嫌われている？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Am I disliked by everyone?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トマトって野菜なの？フルーツなの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are tomatoes vegetables? Are they fruits?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このパスタって美味しいよね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As for the pasta, it is delicious, don't you think?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人って誰？
Questions.EnglishHTML: As for that person, who is it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生って優しいね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As for the teacher, she is nice, don't you think?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ギターって弾けますか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: As for guitar, can you play it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 冬って寒いけど、雪は綺麗だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As for winter, it is cold, but snow is pretty.

Name: 中々(なかなか)
Meaning: Very, Quite, Considerably
About: なかなか (or 中々(なかなか) in kanji) is an adverb in Japanese that is frequently translated as 'very', or 'considerably'. It is regularly paired directly with other adjectives, or before nouns (with の coming between なかなか and the noun). なかなか can also sometimes have the nuance of being something that is 軽視(けいし)しがたい. This basically translates as 'difficult to dismiss', but is a bit closer to English expressions like 'nothing to scoff at', or 'not to be taken lightly'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここのラーメンは中々美味しいね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The ramen here is pretty tasty.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ミムラさんもなかなか可愛いよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Mimura-san is very cute.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのシェフが作るパスタはなかなかの物だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The pasta that the chef makes is very good.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 元カノはなかなかの美人でしたが、性格が悪かったので別れました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My ex-girlfriend was considerably beautiful, but her personality was bad, so I broke up with her.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なかなかの事をしてくれたな。こんな事をお客さんにどう説明したらいいんだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You have done something that is difficult to dismiss, haven't you? How am I supposed to explain this to our client? (What you did cannot be taken lightly. How am I supposed to explain what has happened to our client?)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先月始めたばかりなの？なかなか上手じゃないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You just started last month? You are quite a lot better than I expected!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このお菓子は中々おいしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This snack is quite good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここからの景色は中々いいですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The view from here is quite decent.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここの会員になるのは中々難しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Becoming a member here is considerably difficult.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 富士登山は中々大変です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Reaching the top of Mt. Fuji is quite grueling.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この子が描く絵は中々のものです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The paintings that this child paints are quite (extraordinary).

Name: 余(あま)り
Meaning: So much...that
About: As a noun, あまり means 'excess', and refers to an amount of something that is in surplus. This noun is quite often used after many different types of words, to indicate that something happened/exists to an excessive degree (which then resulted in something negative occurring). By itself, 余(あま)り is not negative. However, this grammar point can be thought of as a set phrase that is generally used in negative situations. To use あまり, you will need to attach it to the end of the following structures. A verb, an い-Adjective (that has been turned into a noun through the use of さ or み) followed by の, a な-Adjective followed by な, or a noun followed by の. Then, after あまり, a (B) phrase will highlight what the negative result was.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は仕事を終わらせることに集中するあまり、終電を逃しました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He was so concentrated on finishing his work that he missed the last train.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムは暑さのあまり、気を失った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It was so hot that Tom fainted.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は彼と別れて、悲しみのあまりボーっとしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She broke up with her boyfriend and is so sad that she is spacing out a lot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は音楽が好きなあまり、仕事を辞めてバンドを作った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He likes music so much that he quit his job and started a band.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ヤスエは初めてのライブで、緊張のあまり上手く歌えなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Yasue had her first concert, and she was so nervous that she couldn't sing well.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩は飲み会でお酒を沢山飲んだあまり、一人で帰ることができなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Senpai drank so much at the party that he couldn't get home by himself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近彼女と別れた友達を心配するあまり、友達の話しを聞きに行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was so worried about my friend, who has broken up with his girlfriend recently, that I went to his place to listen to him vent.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社長は社員全員に恐れられているあまり、誰も社長の提案を否定しない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The CEO of our company is so feared by all of the workers that no one will criticize his decisions.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムは驚きの余り、何も言えなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tom was so surprised that he was speechless.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 美味しさの余り、食べ飽きることはない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is so delicious that I can never get tired of eating it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 悲しさの余り、言葉を失った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was so distraught that I was at a loss for words.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 苦しさの余り、大きな声を出してしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The pain was so unbearable that I shouted out loud.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 喜びの余り、涙がとまらない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am so overjoyed that I cannot stop crying.

Name: 中々(なかなか)～ない
Meaning: Not really, Hardly, Not easily or readily, By no means, Far from
About: When used positively, なかなか means to be 'very', or 'considerably' something. However, when used in a sentence that has a verb in the ない (or ありません) form, it carries the meaning of 'not at all', 'hardly', or 'far from'. Quite often, this expression is used to highlight something that the speaker expects should happen, but for some reason does/is not. To use なかなか (or 中々(なかなか) in its kanji form), なかなか will be put at the beginning of a phrase (or directly before the negative verb), before further describing the situation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生、風邪がなかなか治らないんですけど、どうした方がいいですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Doctor, my cold is hardly getting any better, what should I do?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事が忙しくて中々休みが取れないんだよね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Work is getting so busy that I can hardly take a day off.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あいつなかなか来ないね。連絡もないし、俺たちだけで行こう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is not coming at all. Since he hasn't contacted us, let's just go without him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このシステムは中々改善されない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This system is far from being improved.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 調査が中々進まない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The survey hardly makes any forward progress.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 貯金が中々できない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can hardly save any money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 最近、あたしは中々やる気が出ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Recently I am not easily motivated. (hardly)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 痛みが中々良くならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The pain is not really getting better. (hardly)

Name: によると
Meaning: According to
About: によると, a combination of the case marking particle に, the う - Verb よる, and the conjunction particle と, is a phrase that is used to express that something is 'according to (A)', or 'going off (A)'. In these cases, (A) is considered to be the source of some form of information which will be conveyed in the (B) part of the sentence. This expression will be used after nouns, or with verbs that have been paired with ところ (to indicate the 'place' where the information came from). In newspapers and in articles, the more formal によりますと variant can also regularly be seen. However, this structure is not limited to using と, and the same meaning can be conveyed with によれば. This is just よる in its conjunctive form that pairs with the conjunction particle ば.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今朝の天気予報によると、今夜から雪が降るらしいですよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: According to the forecast, it is apparently going to start snowing from tonight.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生に聞いたところによると、来週からオンライン授業になるらしいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Going off of what I heard from the teacher, we are going to be taking online classes from next week.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 愛知県警によりますと、犯人は四十代の男性だと言う事です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: According to the Aichi Prefectural Police, the criminal is a 40 year old male.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今朝のニュースによれば、来月末から海外旅行が出来るようになる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: According to this morning's news, we are going to be able to travel abroad starting from the end of next month.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が聞くところによると、部長が転職するそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Going off of what I heard, the manager is going to be switching jobs.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 警視庁によると、イマダ容疑者は寝ている母親を包丁で刺していたという事です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: According to the Tokyo Metropolitan Police department, Imada, the suspect, stabbed his mother who was sleeping, with a knife.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 天気予報によると、明日は晴れです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: According to the weather forecast, tomorrow will be sunny.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 警察によると、犯人が逃げたそうです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: According to the police, the criminal escaped.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先輩の話によると、あの会社はブラック企業らしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: According to what my senior said, that company is one of those 'black companies'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 目撃者によれば、犯人は２０代男性だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: According to the witness, the criminal is a man in his 20s.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 聞くところによれば、彼はあの子が好きみたいだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: According to what I hear, it seems as though he likes that girl.

Name: による
Meaning: By means of, According to, Depending on, Because of, Due to
About: によって, による, and により are all different versions of the same expression, that can basically be translated as 'according to (A)', or 'depending on (A)'. This uses the same よる as seen in the grammar pattern によると. They will be used in the following way: によって - Generally used before a comma (although not always). Acts as the separation point between the (A) and (B) parts of a sentence. Made up of the case marking particle に, and the う - Verb よる in its て form. による - Generally used at the end of a sentence, to highlight that the previous statement depends on (A). により - Almost always used before a comma. Acts as the separation point between the (A) and (B) parts of a sentence. Made up of the case marking particle に, and the う - Verb よる in its conjunctive form. To use any of these constructions, attach them to the end of a noun that you want to express as being the 'dependent' thing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 地域によって、ゴミ出しルールが違う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Depending on the area, the rules for throwing out garbage are different.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 行けるか行けないかは休みが取れるか取れないかによる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether I can go or not depends on if I can take a day off.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ベンおじさんは強盗により、命を奪われた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Uncle Ben's life was taken by a robber.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このミスはヒューマンエラーによるものです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This mistake is caused by human error.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この地震による津波の心配はありません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no need to worry about a tsunami brought about from this earthquake.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その車の値段によって、決めます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will choose depending on the price of that car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 国によって、いろいろな伝統があります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are a variety of traditions depending on the country.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 調査によって新たな事実が明らかになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Through investigation, a new truth was discovered. (by means of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 納豆が好きかどうかは人による。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It depends on the person whether they like natto or not.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 話し合いによって決まったのだから、文句言わないで。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Our decision was made through discussion, so don't complain.

Name: 全(まった)く～ない
Meaning: Not~at all
About: 全く～ない is an expression that combines the adverb 全(まった)く, with a phrase that uses another word in its ない form. It is often translated as 'not at all (A)'. Literally, it is closer to 'completely not (A)', or 'entirely not (A)', coming from the kanji 全(ぜん)'s meaning of 'whole'. Like many other adverbs, まったく may be used at the beginning of a sentence, or directly before the word that it is describing as being 'not at all' (A). It is common to see this expression using both the kanji form, and plain hiragana form of 全(まった)く, so both should be learned early.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この子は全く吠えないですよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This dog does not bark at all. (子（こ） may sometimes be used about pets, if it is obvious what is being discussed)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんたに褒められても全く嬉しくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if I did get complimented by you, it wouldn't make me happy at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 店員さんが「この扇風機は静かですよ」って言ったから買ったのに、全く静かじゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The shopkeeper said 'This fan is very quiet', so I bought it. However, it was not quiet at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 全く筋肉がないので私だけでは持てません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't have any muscles at all, so I can't carry this by myself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 全く分からないので、手伝ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't understand at all, so please help me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 全然わからない。手伝って。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have no clue. Can you help me?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は全く勉強しない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He does not study at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 全く変化がない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no change at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 全く負けたことがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have never lost. Ever.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 全く学ぶつもりがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have no intention of learning at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 実は全く泳げないんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To be honest, I can't swim at all.

Name: 事(こと)だ
Meaning: Should, Ought
About: As a sentence ending particle, こと has two primary functions. These are as follows: 願望(がんぼう)や軽(かる)い命令(めいれい)を表(あらわ)す - Highlighting a desire or weak command. 感嘆(かんたん)や疑問(ぎもん)を表(あらわ)す - Highlighting astonishment or doubt. We will focus on the first meaning in this grammar point, as the 'astonishment' nuance is not as commonly used in modern Japanese, and is primarily used only by women. At the end of a sentence, こと will be paired with the dictionary (or ない) form of a verb, to highlight a particular action that either should, or should not occur. It is usually grouped with the auxiliary verb だ, although this is not always the case. This construction is most often translated as 'should/should not (A)', or 'ought to/not (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 面倒くさくても朝ご飯を食べることだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though it might be a pain, you should eat breakfast.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日の朝８時から試験が始まる。何があっても、時間通りに来ることだ。みんな、分かったか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The exams will begin tomorrow at 8 am. No matter what happens, you should come on time. Understood?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんなに疲れていても諦めないことだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You should not give up, no matter how tired you are.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 怪我をしたら、我慢をしないことだ。すぐ責任者に報告するように。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you get hurt, you shouldn't just suffer in silence. Immediately call your supervisor.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩、後輩はもっと大切にすることだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Senpai you should treat your kouhai with great care.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今回は、相手を信じてみる事だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think you ought to trust him/her this time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 生徒は、先生に従う事だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Students should obey their teachers.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大事なのは医者からもらった薬を飲む事だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: What is important, is that you should take the medicine the doctor gave you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まずはやってみる事だ。改善点が見えてくるから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You ought to try it first because you'll find out what needs to be improved.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 覚えたらすぐにしゃべってみる事だ。上達するから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As soon as you memorize something, you ought to say it out loud. If you do that, you will get better.

Name: そうだ
Meaning: I heard that, It is said that
About: The auxiliary verb そうだ has two primary functions in Japanese. It can convey one of the following things: Hearsay: 伝聞(でんぶん) - Highlighting things that have been heard from other people. Appearance: 様態(ようたい) - Highlighting the way that things 'appear', or 'seem'. The appearance nuance is covered in another lesson, so we will focus on hearsay in this grammar point. When used to repeat statements that have been heard from other people/sources, そうだ (or そうです) will be paired with the plain form of a verb or い-Adjective, or a noun/な-Adjective followed by だ. そうだ always implies that the speaker is not 100% certain about the validity of the information that they are conveying. Due to this, it does not sound as confident as other expressions, like ようだ.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この種類の鳥はよく鳴くそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that this bird chirps a lot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 次の患者さんは酷い事故にあったそうです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that the next patient was in a bad accident.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あそこから見る夕日は綺麗だそうです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that the sunset that you can see from there is beautiful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩は明日も仕事だそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that senpai will be working tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 美味しいそうだから、たくさん買った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard they taste good, so I bought a bunch.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムの彼女は女優だそうだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that Tom's girlfriend is an actress.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの方は親切だそうです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that that person is kind.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今晩雨が降るそうだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard it will rain tonight.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 来週から気温が下がるそうだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that from next week the temperature is going to drop.

Name: すると
Meaning: Having done..., If...is done..., (And/just) then, Thereupon, If so
About: すると, a combination of する and the conjunction particle と, is generally considered to be an abbreviation of そうすると, and means that 'once (A) is done, (B)', or 'upon (A), (B)'. すると is usually used at the beginning of a new sentence, to highlight something that occurred due to the circumstances mentioned in the previous sentence/statement. As a standalone statement, すると is classified as a conjunction.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 久しぶりに押入れの掃除をした。すると、無くしたと思っていた服が出てきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I cleaned my closet for the first time in a long time. Upon that, I found clothes that I thought I had lost.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お祖母ちゃんが川で洗濯をしていた。すると、川の向こうから桃が流れてきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: An old lady was washing her clothes in the river. Just then, a peach flowed down the river from a distance.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 猿にバナナをあげた。すると、猿がどんどん集まってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I gave a banana to a monkey. Having done that, more and more monkeys started to gather around me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １９歳なの？すると、大学１年生でしょう？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are 19? So you mean to say that you are a freshman, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 口笛を吹いた。すると、小鳥がやって来た。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I whistled. Having done that, a small bird came.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 目を閉じた。すると、一瞬で眠ってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I closed my eyes. And then I fell asleep immediately.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 川に魚を釣りに行った。すると、そこで旧友に会った。なんという偶然？
Questions.EnglishHTML: I went fishing on the river. And then I met an old friend there. What a coincidence!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 従兄弟が絵を描いていた。すると、弟も真似をして描き始めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My cousin was drawing a picture. And then my younger brother, imitating him, started to draw too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
A：「僕は◯◯年生まれです。」
B：「すると、車を運転できる歳ですね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'I was born in XX year.'
B: 'Then, you are old enough to drive, right?'

Name: そうすると
Meaning: Having done that..., If that is done..., (And/just) then, Thereupon, If so
About: そうすると, a combination of 然(そ)う (an adverb meaning 'like that', or 'as such') する and the conjunction particle と, expresses that 'once (A) was done, (B)', or 'upon (A), (B)'. そうすると is usually used at the beginning of a new sentence, to highlight something that occurred due to the circumstances mentioned in the previous sentence/statement. As a stand-alone statement, そうすると is classified as a conjunction.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もう少し遅く走ってみれば。そうすると、もっと長い距離走れるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Try to run a little slower. Once you do that, you will be able to run a longer distance.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 食べる前に軽く炙ってください。そうすると、もっと美味しく食べれます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please roast before eating. Having done that, it will taste even more delicious.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この餌を使ってみ。そうすると、もっと大きい魚が釣れるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Try using this bait. If you do so, you'll be able to catch a bigger fish. (Whether a fish bites or not cannot be controlled)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １９９３年生まれなんですか？そうすると、２９歳と言う事ですね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You were born in 1993? So that means that you are 29, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう少し音量を上げて。そうするとみんな聞こえるから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Raise the volume up just a little more. If that is done, then everyone can hear.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この道を右に曲がってください。そうすると案内板がありますから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please turn right at this street. Having done that, you will see a street map.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この時刻には家を出てください。そうすると間に合いますから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please leave the house at this time. If that is done you will be on time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ちょっと右に寄ってくれる？そうするとみんな見れるから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Could you move a little to the right? Having done that, everyone will be able to see.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新しい機械を導入するんですね。そうすると、僕の仕事はなくなるということですか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: The new machines are being introduced, huh? If that happens, does it mean that I will lose my job?

Name: のは～の方(ほう)だ
Meaning: It is...that..., It is...who..., ...is the one that..., ...is the one who...
About: のは～の方(ほう)だ is an expression used to show that (A) (usually despite expectations) is (B). It can be translated as 'the one that (A), is (B)'. This phrase is made up of the following parts: のは - Used for nominalization (creating a noun phrase). は highlights contrast between two (or more) elements. の方(ほう) - A combination of の, the case marking particle, and 方(ほう), a noun meaning 'side', or 'direction'. だ (or です) - The auxiliary verb used for 'determining' something. The literal meaning of this grammar point is something similar to 'that which is (A), is on the side of (B)'. By saying that something is on the 'side' of (B), it comes across more gently than expressly stating that it 'is (B)'. To use this construction, attach のは to the end of a phrase, and then follow it with a noun + の方(ほう)だ. Note that のは will become なのは if the final word before のは is a noun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 言い出したのは俺の方だから、俺がなんとかしておくよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am the one that said it, so I will do something about it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そのコップを壊したのはタケルの方だ！俺は関係ないよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The one that broke the cup is Takeru! I have nothing to do with it!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 謝らなければいけないのは私の方ですよ。あなたは何も悪くないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The one that needs to apologize is me. You are not in the wrong at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 危険なのはオレの方だよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am the one who is dangerous.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 主な賞を受賞するのはあちゃんの方だといいな。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
I hope that the one who will win the main prize will be A-chan.
(A-chan is the one who...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ドアを開けっぱなしにしたのはキちゃんの方だと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think that Ki-chan was the one who left the doors open (not me).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのときサカモトくんを誘いたかったのは、あたしの方だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am the one who wanted to invite Sakamoto-kun at that time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: わたしが怖いのは、犬ではなく飼い主の方だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The owner is the one who I am afraid of, not the dog.

Name: (Noun) + 型(がた)
Meaning: Model, Type, Pattern, Kind, Shape, Size(d)
About: 型(がた), or sometimes 形(がた), are two kanji that are often used as a suffix, to identify that something is 'shaped', or 'sized' according to (A). The primary reading of both of these kanji is かた, but becomes がた due to 連濁(れんだく) (sound changes due to conjugation). 型(がた) can be attached directly to the end of nouns, or to い-Adjectives. Occasionally, 型(かた) will be used after the case marking particle の. In these cases, because it is connected to の, and not directly to the noun, it will be read as かた, not がた. Although there are two different kanji that can be used in this expression, 型(がた) will be used far more frequently than 形(がた). This is primarily due to the base meanings that these kanji have. Those meanings are as follows: 型(がた) - Form (in regard to design, pattern, type, or model). 形(がた) - Shape (in regard to physical shapes only. Square, rectangle, triangle, etc). Due to this, 型(がた) is used when describing any form/pattern that is abstract, while 形(がた) is primarily only used for describing very basic (visible) shapes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この紙を星形に切ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please cut this paper into the shape of a star.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この型のスマホはよく壊れます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This type of smartphone breaks often.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 九十年代には犬型のロボットのおもちゃが人気だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: During the 90s, dog-type robots were popular.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しい型の自転車はいつ発売されますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When is the new model of this bike coming out?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 次はどんな髪型にしよう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What kind of hairstyle should I get next?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はハート形のアクセサリーが好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like heart-shaped accessories.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 文型は基本なのでしっかりと勉強しておきましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Grammar structures are the basics, so make sure to properly study them in advance.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 整数はデータ型の一つである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: An integer is one of the data types.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: きみの血液型は何？
Questions.EnglishHTML: What is your blood type?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「よう」という表現はさまざまな文型に使われている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The expression 'よう' is used in various sentence patterns.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君が言ったように、はるこは２０００年型のモペットを持っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is like you said, Haruko has a year 2000 model moped.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 母はハート型の枕を編み上げた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mom has finished knitting a heart-shaped pillow.

Name: てご覧(らん)
Meaning: (Please) try to, (Please) look
About: てご覧(らん) is an honorific language expression in Japanese that is used in a similar way to なさい. It is usually translated as 'please try to (A)', where (A) is the verb that ご覧(らん) is connected to, through the use of the conjunction particle て. However, despite being translated as 'please try to (A)', the literal meaning of 覧(らん) is 'to look', or 'to peruse' (to look at one's own leisure, without needing to rush). Due to this, てごらん can be thought of as being quite similar to てみる 'to try', but with the added emphasis of 'try as you like, when it suits you'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この本を読んでごらん。この本を読んだら日本について色々と学べるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Try reading this book. If you read it, you will learn various things about Japan.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 外を見てごらん。虹が出ているよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Look outside. There is a rainbow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これ食べてごらん。あなただったら絶対に好きだと思うよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Try eating this. If it's you, I think you'll definitely like it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 見てごらんなさい。こんな酷いことをネットにかかれたんだよ、酷くない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Look at this. Someone wrote something this cruel on the internet. Don't you think this is awful?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その景色を見てごらん。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Try to) take a look at that scenery.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ニュースを見てごらん。あなたが映っているよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Try to) take a look at the news. You are on TV.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの蝶々を捕まえてごらんなさい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Try to catch that butterfly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 手を貸してごらん。手袋をはめてあげるから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Try to) give me your hands. I will put your gloves on.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう一度やってごらん。きっとうまくできるよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Try it once more. I know you can do it.

Name: (Particle) + の
Meaning: Combined particles
About: In Japanese, many particles are often grouped together with the case marking particle の. The primary function of this is to form a link between noun (A), and noun (B). In each of these cases, noun (B) will be considered to have all of the qualities described by noun (A), and the first particle that follows it. The particle that comes before の will always be something that adds some form of immediate information about noun (A). The most common ones are as follows: Noun (A) と の Noun (B) - The (B) that is 'grouped with' (A). Noun (A) へ の Noun (B) - The (B) that is 'toward' (A). Noun (A) で の Noun (B) - The (B) that is 'done with' (A). Noun (A) まで の Noun (B) - The (B) that is 'until' (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはアメリカからのお土産です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is a souvenir from America.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 別れた後、彼との関係はどうなるんだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After breaking up with him, I wonder what our relationship would be like.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 海外への手紙はこちらのポストにお入れください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please put letters to be sent internationally into this mailbox.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 環境に悪いので車での通勤は控えてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because it is bad for the environment, please refrain from commuting by car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 出発までの時間、何をします？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What do you want to do until departure?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あちゃんとの握手会に行こう！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's go to the handshake event with A-chan!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これまでの話はなかなかおもしろい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The story so far is interesting.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は癌との戦いに勝ったそうだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that he won the battle with cancer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なぎさんは、はやてさんへの手紙をずっと書いている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Nagi constantly writes letters to Hayate.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サマーキャンプでの生活はとても楽しいですよ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Life at summer camp is very fun.

Name: である
Meaning: Formal or literary だ, Authoritative, Copula
About: である (or であります) is a construction in Japanese that is considered to be the formal equivalent of だ. This should not be confused with the polite speech word です, as である is simply a combination of the conjunctive form of だ, and the う - Verb, ある. である may be used in any place that だ would usually be used, but is most likely to be found at the end of sentences/statements.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本一デカイ博物館はこの博物館である。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The largest museum in Japan is this one.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここから悲しいことが起きるのである。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is where something sad starts to happen. (Here comes the sad bit)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私達が会えたのは運命であります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is destiny that we met.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大変であることを人にやらせるのは良くない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not good to make someone else do difficult things.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 重要である箇所をまとめた資料がこちらです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: These are the documents highlighting all the important sections.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 名前はタナカであります！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My name is Tanaka! (Responding to a person in a higher rank in a military)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最後のプリンを食べたのは私であります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am the one who ate the last pudding. (Jokingly polite)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はとてもハンサムである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is very handsome.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はパイロットであった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He was a pilot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: とても面白いドラマである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is a very interesting drama.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 題名：「吾輩は猫である。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Title: 'I am a cat.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夢は海外で成功することである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My dream is to be successful overseas.

Name: ところが
Meaning: Even so, However, Even though, But
About: ところが is a conjunction in Japanese that is a combination of the noun, ところ 'place', and the conjunction particle が. It is used to highlight that (A) was expected, but the unexpected result (B) occurred. It is usually translated as 'however', or 'despite that'. ところが is most often used at the beginning of a new sentence, before highlighting something that is contrary to what was described in the previous sentence. This use of が in Japanese is referred to as 確定(かくてい)の逆接(ぎゃくせつ), which basically means 'a contradictory conclusion'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は早く起きないといけなかったから９時に寝た。ところが、目覚ましがならなかったから寝坊した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I had to wake up early today so I went to sleep at 9pm. However, my alarm didn't go off, so I overslept.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しい洗濯機を買った。ところが、洗濯機が大きすぎて家に入らなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bought a new washing machine. However, it was so big that it didn't fit in my house.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達に勉強の手伝いを頼んだら嫌がると思っていた。ところが、喜んで手伝ってくれた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I thought my friend was not going to like it if I asked him to help me with studying, however, he did so without hesitation.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パンを買いに行きました。ところが、もう売り切れでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I went to buy bread. However, it was already sold out.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本のチームが勝つと思っていた。ところが負けてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I thought that the Japanese team would win. However, they lost.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人は非常に優しそうでした。ところが、裏がありました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person seemed extremely nice. However, they had ulterior motives.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達によると、テストは難しかったそうだ。ところが、彼は百点を取った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: According to my friend, the test was difficult. Even so, he got a perfect score.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テストに出そうなところを予想して勉強した。ところが、全然違う問題しか出なかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I studied what I thought would be on the test. However, the questions were totally different from what I had studied.

Name: ところで
Meaning: By the way, Incidentally
About: ところで is a conjunction particle that is made up of the noun, ところ 'place', and the case marking particle で. It is used in a similar way to 'by the way', or 'incidentally' in English, but will only be used for introducing new topics, not continuing within the same topic. ところで will primarily appear at the beginning of a sentence, before making a statement or asking a question about something unrelated. The literal translation of ところで is closer to 'and with that', and implies that something (within the previous topic) suddenly reminded the speaker of another thing (that happens to be a new topic).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ところで、昨日の話はどうなった？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: By the way, what happened to the plan you told me about yesterday?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ところで、お宅の旦那さんは元気にしていますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: By the way, is your husband doing well?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ところで、どこに行くつもりですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: By the way, where do you plan on going?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ところで、明日のパーティーに何を持って来ますか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: By the way, what are you going to bring to the party tomorrow?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ところで、パソコンの使い方をご存知ですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: By the way, do you know how to use a computer?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ところで内本さんはどこ出身？
Questions.EnglishHTML: By the way, where is Uchimoto-san from?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ところでもう雨はやみましたか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: By the way, has it stopped raining yet?

Name: 程(ほど)
Meaning: The more, About, To the extent that, So much… that
About: ほど, coming from the kanji 程(ほど) 'an extent', is used for describing rough estimates about the 'amount' of something. However, unlike expressions such as くらい (which focuses more on the speaker's uncertainty about the exact number), ほど puts emphasis on the upper (or lower) limit of something as having been 'reached'. Due to this, it is usually translated as 'so much that (A)', or 'to the extent that (A)'. ほど can be added on to the end of the attributive form of any word. The attributive form being the form that is able to be partnered directly with nouns.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 死ぬほど練習したけれど、試合に出られなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I practiced myself to death, but I was not able to participate in the match.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その気持ちは痛いほど分かるけど、だからってそういう事言ってもいいと言う訳では無いよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I understand how you feel to the point that it hurts, but that doesn't mean that you can say stuff like that.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは嫌なほど聞かされたから、分かってる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have been told that so much that I don't want to hear it anymore, I get it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あと１０分ほどで着きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will be there in about 10 minutes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日はもう二度と走りたくないと思うほど走った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today, I ran so much that I feel like I never want to run again.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遅れてごめんなさい。あと１０分程で着きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm sorry that I'm late. I will be there in about 10 minutes. (degree・bounds・limit)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ピンが落ちた音が聞こえる程、静かだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was quiet to the extent that you could hear a pin drop. (degree・bounds・limit)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう二度と食べたくないと思う程、ピザを食べた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I ate pizza to the extent that I don't think that I ever want to eat it again. (degree・bounds・limit)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 他の人がわがままだと言う程甘やかしている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am spoiling them to the extent that people would say they're selfish. (degree・bounds・limit)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今回は一週間程旅行するつもりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This time, I plan to go on a trip for about one week. (degree・bounds・limit)

Name: ば～程(ほど)
Meaning: The more…the more
About: ば～ほど is a combination of the conjunction particle ば, and the noun ほど. It is used in a similar way to 'the more ~ the more' in English. Literally, it just highlights that 'if it is (A), then the limit of (A) will be controlled only by its extent'. To use ば～ほど, ば will be paired with the hypothetical form of any verb/い-Adjective (or noun/な-Adjective with なら on the end), before the same word will be repeated in its attributive form. After this, a (B) part of the sentence will highlight what the expected result of (A) is. As である (the formal version of だ) may replace な with な-Adjectives (or なら with nouns), sometimes である will be used instead of な/なら, in regard to both nouns and な-Adjectives.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いい肉は噛めば噛むほど味が出る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The more you chew good meat, the more flavorful it gets.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 公園は広ければ広いほどいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The bigger the park is, the better it is.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ビルは丈夫ならば丈夫なほど安心できる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The stronger a building is, the safer you feel.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: プロならばプロほど速く泳げる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The more of a pro you are, the faster you can swim.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アプリが便利であれば便利であるほどユーザーが増える。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The more useful an app is, the more users will increase.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 職人であれば職人であるほど凄いものが作れる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The more of a craftsman a person is, the more likely that they will be able to make something amazing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 漢字の勉強をすればするほど色んな本が読めるようになる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The more you study kanji, the more you will be able to read various books.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 掃除をすればするほど、部屋が綺麗になっていく。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The more you clean, the cleaner your room will get.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 身体を鍛えるほど、身体が強くなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The more you workout, the stronger your body gets.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この豆を食べれば食べるほど痩せるらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I hear that the more of these beans you eat, the thinner you will become.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 早ければ早い程いい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The sooner the better.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 綺麗ならば綺麗なほど見続けたくなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The more beautiful it is, the more I want to continue looking at it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勝てば勝つほど、またやりたくなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The more you win, the more you want to play again.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強すればする程、日本語が上手くなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The more you study, the better you will be at Japanese.

Name: 程(ほど)～ない
Meaning: Is not as…as, Isn't... like..., Not to the extent of...
About: Another expression that uses the noun ほど 'an extent' in Japanese, is ほど～ない. In the (A) part of a sentence, an extent will be highlighted, before the (B) part of the sentence will use ない to negate that extent, saying that it has not been reached. This phrase can be translated as 'it isn't like (A)', 'it's not to the point of (A)'. Literally it means 'if (A) is the extent, then (B) is not true'. ほど will regularly be used after a verb or noun, while ない is more likely to be used after a verb, い-Adjective, or な-Adjective (as it is describing something about ほど). While this grammar point may be used for expressing that an extent has not been reached, it is also frequently used for making comparisons between two things. In these cases, it states that 'the example/limit of (A) is something that cannot be reached/repeated by (B)'. This is similar to '(B) is not as ~ as (A)' in English.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は思ったほど暑くなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today wasn't as hot as I expected.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 悩むほどの事じゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is nothing to worry about so much. (This is not as serious as you think it is)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自転車は車程速くないけど、健康にいいから自転車で会社に行っています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Bicycles aren't as fast as cars, but it is good for my health, so I ride my bike to work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この世にこのカレーほど辛い食べ物はない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no food as spicy as this curry in the world.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お母さんほどケーキ作りが上手な人はどこにもいない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no one in this world that is as good as my mom at baking cakes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君の母程優しい人はいない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There isn't anyone as nice as your mom.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 待って！あなたほど速く走れないんだ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Wait! I can't run as fast as you!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: タイタニック程感動する映画はないわ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no movie as touching as 'Titanic'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 思っていた程大変な仕事ではなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The job was not as rough as I thought it would be.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 宇宙では誰もがフリゾ程強くなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There was no-one as strong as Frizo in the universe.

Name: それでは
Meaning: If so, Well (then), In that case
About: では and じゃあ are both abbreviations of それでは, and used as conjunctions in Japanese. This structure may be considered as a combination of それ, the case marking particle で, and the binding (adverbial) particle は, but is commonly treated as a single word. それでは has two primary functions. It can be used to continue in the same topic, showing that '(B) is a result of (A)'. Or it may be used to change the conversation topic completely, showing that '(A) is at a good point to become (B)'. In each of these cases, it can be translated as 'and with that' in English. 'If so', 'well then', and 'in that case' are also common translations. The translation of 'in that case' is most commonly used when one person is making an assumption/drawing a conclusion about something that someone else has just said.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それでは、あなたは行きたくないという事ですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In that case, you mean that you don't want to go?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: では、こちらの商品はどうでしょう？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well then, how about this product over here?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 用意できた？じゃあ、５分で出よう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are you ready? In that case let's leave in 5 minutes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それでは、あなたがやったってことでいいですね？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In that case, would it be correct to say that you did it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: では、私はこれで失礼します。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well, this will be when I'm going to excuse myself.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: じゃあ、ここで失礼します。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Well then, I will take my leave.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: では、こうしたらどうでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Well, how about trying it this way?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: では、次の問題です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Well then, on to the next question!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: じゃあ…本を取ってくるから。ちょっと待ってて。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Well... I'll go grab my book. Hang on a sec.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: では、また来週の火曜日に会いましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Well, let's meet again next Tuesday.

Name: のに
Meaning: In order to
About: Regarded as a conjunction particle by itself, のに is simply a fusion of the case marking particles の and に. のに has two primary functions in Japanese. It can be used to show that something is the opposite of what is expected for (A) (translated as 'despite'), or it can be used to show that something is required for (A) to be realized (translated as 'in order to'). We will focus on the 'in order to' meaning in this lesson. To use のに, simply attach it to the base (non-past) form of a verb that you would like to express as being the 'goal', before following it with the conditions required to meet that goal.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トラックは車と違って、ブレーキをかけてから止まるのに時間がかかる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Unlike cars, trucks take longer to stop after stepping on the brakes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 風が強すぎて、ピクニックシートを広げるのに苦労した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The wind was so strong that I struggled to spread out the picnic blanket.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さっき食べたばかりなのに、またお腹が空いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I just ate earlier, but I am hungry again.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 食べるのに時間をかけすぎて寝る時間が遅くなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I took so long to eat, so I slept at a later time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 本を読むのに眼鏡を買った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I bought glasses in order to read books.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 背中をかくのに孫の手を使う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I use my backscratcher in order to scratch my back.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 宿題をするのに、３時間かかる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It takes 3 hours in order to do homework.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食べるのに時間がかかりすぎて、昼休みが終わってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It took too long in order for me to eat lunch, so my lunch break unfortunately came to an end.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お茶を飲むのに必要なコップがありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I do not have the necessary cup in order to drink tea.

Name: 為(ため)に
Meaning: For, For the sake of, In order to
About: ため (or 為(ため) in its kanji form) is a noun in Japanese that can be translated quite closely to 'sake' in English. However, it is classified as a non-independent word in Japanese, and must always be connected to another word which illustrates the 'sake' that ため is highlighting. The case marking particle に will often be added after ため, to show that (A) is a goal that something will be done to reach. Due to this, ために can be translated as 'for the sake of (A)', or 'in order to (A)'. To use ために, attach it to the end of verb in its non-past form, or a noun followed by の.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しい家を建てるために、土地を買った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In order to build a house, I bought land.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勉強をするために、親に机を買ってもらった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In order to study, I got my parents to buy me a desk.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私のためにやって。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please do this for me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 君のために買ってあげたのに、誰かにあげちゃったの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bought this for you, but you gave it to someone?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ２年前、車を買うために、親からお金を借りました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In order to buy a car two years ago, I borrowed money from my parents.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 骨折したため、明日からしばらく仕事を休みます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I broke a bone, I am going to take some time off of work starting tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 家を買う為にローンを組んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I took a loan in order to buy a house.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕はただいい点を取る為に勉強していません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am not studying just for the sake of getting a good score.
