Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何の為に生きているのか、それが知りたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to know what I am living for.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お金の為だけに仕事をするのは、つらいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's very hard to only work for money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 老後の為にちゃんと貯金しておかなければならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You have to save enough money for your retirement.

Name: 為(ため)に
Meaning: Due to, Because of, As a result of
About: ため (or 為(ため) in its kanji form) is a noun in Japanese that can be translated quite closely to 'sake' in English. However, it is classified as a non-independent word in Japanese, and must always be connected to another word which illustrates the 'sake' that ため is highlighting. The case marking particle に will often be added after ため, to show that (A) is a goal that something will be done to reach. However, when used with verbs in the past tense, ために more frequently highlights that something happened 'due to (A)', rather than 'for the sake of (A)'. Because of this, a more accurate description of ため in all situations is 'in light of (A)'. This expresses that (A) is the primary or major event/thing that resulted in (B). To use ために as 'in light of', 'as a result of', or 'because of', attach it to the end of verb in its past form, or a noun follow by の. It may also be used after い-Adjectives or な-Adjectives in their attributive form. This 'in light of (A)' nuance can be used in reference to things that have already happened (as above), or in reference to something that is considered as the purpose of an action (as in our other ために grammar point).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日の飲み会でお酒を沢山飲んだために、今日は二日酔いで身体がだるい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I drank a lot of alcohol at the party last night, I am tired today with a hangover.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 暑いために、職場で何人かが倒れた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to it being hot, a few people have passed out at work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このアプリは便利なために、ユーザーがどんどん増えてきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to this app being useful, the number of users are steadily growing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大雨のため、サッカーの試合を中止します。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to heavy rain, we will be canceling the soccer tournament.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 空手の試合で勝つために、毎日夜遅くまで練習しています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In order to win the karate tournament, I practice every day until late at night.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日は夜遅くまで練習していたため、今日は何もしたくないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to me practicing until late at night last night, I don't want to do anything today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夜更かしした為朝寝坊してしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I woke up late this morning, due to the fact that I stayed up late last night.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 台風の為、試合が中止になった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The game was canceled due to the typhoon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お金を使いすぎた為に、貯金がもうほとんどない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As a result of us having used too much money, we have almost no savings.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寒い為に、車が故障してしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My car broke down due to the cold.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寒さの為に、車が故障してしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The car broke down due to the cold.

Name: と言(い)う
Meaning: Called, Named, Known as, As much as
About: という is a combination of the case marking particle と, and the う - Verb 言(い)う. It is a set expression that primarily uses only hiragana. という connects two nouns, and means 'the (B) that is called (A)', or 'the (B) known as (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ローラというモデルさんを知っていますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you know the model called Rola?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 本山という駅で降りてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please get off at a station named Motoyama.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカタロウという少年を見つけたら、ここにお電話をください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you find a child named Tanaka Tarou, please call us.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここにボブという名前の男の人が来ませんでしたか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Did a man called Bob come here? (Natural)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここに小さいという男の人が来ませんでしたか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Did a man known as small come here? (Unnatural)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は強いというんだけど、ステロイドを使っているんじゃない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person is known as strong, but don't you think he uses steroids? (He looks strong, but isn't)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ポケモンと言うゲームを知っている？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Do you know the game called 'Pokemon?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今は梅雨と言う時期です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We are now in the time of year called 'Tsuyu' (rainy season).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スマホと言うものは便利なものだね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The things known as smartphones are very convenient.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 秋と言う季節が大好きだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I love the season (known as) 'Autumn.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 佐藤浩一と言う人を知っていますか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Do you know a man named 'Sato Koichi'?

Name: と言(い)う事(こと)だ
Meaning: I heard that, Rumor has it that, It is said that, It means that
About: Like ということ, an expression used for nominalizing a phrase in the fashion of 'the ~ that ~', ということだ makes use of the auxiliary verb だ (or です), and stresses that the nominalized phrase 'is' the case. This phrase is often translated as 'I heard that', or 'it is said that', but literally, it is closer to 'it is that it's ~'. The だ is what gives this expression a high degree of certainty, therefore implying that the speaker has heard the statement elsewhere, and is sure of its validity. ということだ can be added to the end of any phrase that the speaker wants to highlight as being something that is known. ということだ is regularly paired with other expressions that show the 'source' of information, such as によると, or によれば. When ということだ is being used to express hearsay (statements that cannot easily be proven), it can be rephrased as とのことだ. The literal difference between these two phrases is as follows: ということだ - It can be explained that (A) is ~ (more emphasis on the information). とのことだ - The statement of (A) has been applied to ~ (more emphasis on the source that 'applied' the information).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この井戸水は汚染されているということだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is said that this well water is contaminated.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この魚は全く臭くない。まだ新鮮と言う事だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This fish doesn't smell at all. It means that it's fresh.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生によると、この病気は薬では治せないということだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: According to the doctor, (it is said that) this sickness cannot be cured with medicine.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大阪府警によれば、犯人はまだ逃げているということだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is said that the criminal is still on the run, according to the Osaka prefectural police.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 地域によってルールが違うということだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It means that the rules differ depending on the area.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 地域によってルールが違うとのことだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is said that the rules differ depending on the area.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は家族に内緒で旅行に行ったそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that he went on a trip without telling his family.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は家族に内緒で旅行に行ったということだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is said that he went on a trip without telling his family.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人によって考え方が違うという事だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is said that different people have different ways of thinking.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: イルカは動物の中で頭が一番いいという事だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is said that dolphins are the smartest of all animals.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんと山田さんは、秘密で付き合っているという事だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is said that Tanaka-san and Yamada-san are dating in secret. (rumor has it)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それはただ文化が違うという事だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That means that their cultures are different. (it is said)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 忍耐先生によりますと、ガンの治療方法がとうとう見つかったという事です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: According to professor Nintai, (it is said that) the cure for cancer has been finally discovered.

Name: と言(い)うのは
Meaning: ~ Known as ~ is, ~ Called ~ is, ~ Means ~, Because
About: というのは is a phrase that combines the case marking particle と,  the う - Verb 言(い)う,  and the nominalizing particle combination のは. Together, they are usually translated as 'the ~ known as ~ is ~', or 'the ~ called ~ is ~'. Sometimes, it can even simply be '~ means ~'. In essence, というのは is just a way to turn an entire phrase into a noun, before explaining that noun further. This explanation of (A) will either be to give a definition of it, or to give a reason for it. To use というのは, attach it to the end of a phrase that you would like to indicate as being something that will be explained further '(A)', and then follow it with your definition/reason, '(B)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 筋肉と言うのは、鍛えないとすぐになくなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: (The thing known as) Muscles need to be trained, or you lose them quickly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 警察というのは市民を犯罪から守らなければいけません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: (Things known as) Police need to protect the citizens from crime.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今週末は遊べなくなっちゃった。というのも、義理の両親が来ることになったからだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It looks like I won’t be able to hangout this weekend. The reason for this is because it has been decided for my in-laws to come.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年も大会で優勝することができた。というのも、コーチが頑張ってくれたからだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We were able to win the competition again this year. The reason for this is because the coach worked so hard (for us).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 差別になることを言ってはいけません。というのは、私達はみんな同じ人間だからです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You shouldn't say anything that could be taken as discriminatory. What I mean to say is, we're all human.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたが言った事を否定するつもりで言っていません。というのは、私はそれが間違っていると思ったから言ったのです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't mean to disprove what you just said. What I mean is that, I said what I said because I personally thought that it was wrong.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: おかずとはなんですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What are side dishes?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人が７０歳とは信じられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't believe that person is 70. (70 years old, as I know it)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夢って簡単に諦められないよね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Dreams are so hard to give up. (Dreams as we know them)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 法律ってほんとうに必要なのか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are laws actually necessary? (Laws as we know them)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 雪というのは、自然現象です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (The thing called) Snow is a natural phenomenon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人生というのは儚いものだな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (The thing known as) Life is such a fleeting thing, isn't it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 働くというのは大変なことだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (The thing known as) work is a hard thing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供というのはかわいいものだな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (The thing known as) Children are cute.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 習慣というのは恐ろしいものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (The thing known as) Habit is such a scary thing.

Name: 的(てき)
Meaning: ~ly・~like・~al, Typical
About: 的(てき) is a 接語尾(せつごび) (suffix) in Japanese that has two primary uses. The first use is very similar to 'as' or 'for' in English, and means 'considering/within the category of (A), (B)'. The second use primarily relates to people, and will be covered later. As a single word, 的(てき) is often likened to adjective endings such as '~ly', '~like', and '~al'. To use 的(てき), attach it to the end of a noun that you want to express as being the focus point of either a verb or a noun that will come later in the sentence. When describing a noun, 的(てき) will be followed by な (meaning that it becomes a な-Adjective). When describing a verb, it will be followed by に (making it an adverb).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんな感情的にならなくてもいいのに。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You don't have to get that emotional. (Speaking in terms of emotions, there's no need to get like that)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: フィルターは定期的に掃除してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please clean the filter regularly. (Speaking in terms of regularity, please clean the filter as such)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは個人的な考えですよね？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is a personal way of thinking, isn't it? (Speaking in terms of individuality, it's that kind of thought, right?)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さっきなんかの宗教的な人たちが家に来た。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Earlier, some religious people came to the house. (Speaking in terms of religion, some people like that came earlier)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: リサ的にはどう思う？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In a Lisa-way, what do you think? (What is your opinion)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは本当にタナカ的な考え方だな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is such a Tanaka-way of thinking.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は英語圏の国に引っ越しました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He moved to an English speaking country. (A country within the English speaking world)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は国民的アイドルです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She is a national star. (Speaking in terms of the nation, she is a star)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 印象的な絵。
Questions.EnglishHTML: An impressive picture.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一般的な考え方。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A popular way of thinking.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一時的な大雨。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Temporary heavy rain.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 悪魔的な手口。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A devilish trick.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 時期的に雨が降りやすい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Typical of the season, it is more likely to rain.

Name: もの・もん
Meaning: Because, Cause
About: もの, an extremely common noun in Japanese that means 'thing', can also be used as a sentence ending particle. In these cases, it adds a small amount of emotion to a statement, and presents it as a reason. Due to this, もの is usually translated as 'because', or 'cause'. Literally, it just means 'it's an (A) thing!'. もの is quite casual, so should be avoided in formal situations. To use もの as 'because', attach it to the end of the plain form of any word. To emphasize もの even further, the explanatory んだ (after a verb or い-Adjective), or なんだ (after a な-Adjective or noun) will often be used.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたが言う事は何も信じられないわ。だって、あなたはいつも嘘をつくもの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't believe anything you say. Cause you always lie.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: だって、彼女が悪いんだもの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Cause she is the one in the wrong.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはあなたにあげられない。大切だもの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't give this to you, cause it is important.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: すぐ泣くに決まってるじゃん、まだこどもだもの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Of course he will cry, cause he is still a child.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: エアコンをつけて寝ているよ。だって、暑くて寝れないんだもの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I sleep with the A/C on. Cause it's so hot that I can't sleep, you see.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この子は失敗するに決まってるでしょう、まだ新人なんだもの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Of course this kid will make mistakes. Cause he's still new here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もうお腹いっぱいだもん。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Cause I'm already full.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いいよ、お前とはもう遊ばないもん！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's all good! (Because) I'm not going to play with you anymore! (Showing mild anger/jokingly)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんなものすぐに壊れるに決まっているじゃないですか、紙から出来てるんですもの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Of course something like this will break instantly. (Because) it is made of paper.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: しょうがないですよ、あの人は何も考えていないんですもの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We can't help it. (Because) that person doesn't think about anything.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まずいんだもん。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Because) it tastes bad!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は嘘をついているもの。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Because) she is lying.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 怒らないでね。子供なんだもん。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Don't be angry. (Because) he is just a kid.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寒いんだもん。風邪をひいてしまうよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Because) it's freezing. I'm gonna catch a cold, man!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「食べすぎ！」って言われても…、美味しいんだもん！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if someone says 'you are eating too much!'... (Because) it's delicious! (so I can't help it)

Name: ものだ
Meaning: Supposed to, Should, That's the way it is
About: もの (or 物(もの) in its kanji form) is classified as a 形式名詞(けいしきめいし) (dummy noun) in Japanese. This just means a noun that is used in a similar way to 'thing' in English. もの regularly refers to things that do not have their own name, or are difficult to name due to their complexity. When もの is combined with the auxiliary verb だ, it implies that the previously mentioned (A) is something that 'is what it is'. This is often used in relation to customs, conventions, common sense, or to highlight results that would naturally be expected in any given situation. To use ものだ, attach it to the end of the attributive form of any word/word that ends a phrase that you would like to highlight as being an obvious piece of information. ものだ as 'supposed to', or 'the way it is' can also be used to negate a phrase, and say that it is 'something that isn't expected', or 'shouldn't be the case'. To do this, だ will be replaced with ではない, or じゃない.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事は一生懸命するものだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Work is something you should put all your effort into.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ユウキが自分からプランを立てるのは珍しいものだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is rare for Yuki to plan something out on his own.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こどもは元気なものだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Kids should be energetic. (Man, kids are energetic)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 人生はそんなに簡単な物ではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Life is not something that is easy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家族は捨てるものじゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Family is not something you should throw away.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 東大に入れたのか？大したもんだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You were able to get into Tokyo University? That is impressive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ゴミを道に捨てるもんじゃない！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You should not throw garbage on the street!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ケーキは甘い物だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Cake is supposed to be sweet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 親は親切な物だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Parents are supposed to be kind.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食べ物はムダにする物じゃないよ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: You shouldn't waste food! (not supposed to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 悪いことは続く物だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Bad things usually continue. (That's just the way it is)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供は父母の言うことを聞く物だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Children are supposed to listen to their parents!

Name: 最中(さいちゅう)に
Meaning: In the middle of
About: While 中(ちゅう)に highlights that something is in the process of happening (when used in relation to events/actions), 最中(さいちゅう)に strengthens that meaning further, to show that something is 'right in the middle of happening'. As the kanji 最(さい) means 'utmost', we can see that the literal meaning is 'utmost middle'. This can be translated in a similar way to phrases like 'at the height of (A)', or 'in the midst of (A)', in English. When using 最中(さいちゅう)に, a (B) part of the sentence will usually highlight something else that happened during (A), somehow interrupting or disturbing it. To use 最中(さいちゅう)に, attach it to the end of the ている form of a verb, or a noun followed by の.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お祖母ちゃんの歯がお餅を食べている最中にポロっと取れた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Grandma's tooth fell out right in the middle of eating mochi.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事の最中に怪我をしたら、黙っていないですぐに責任者に電話をしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you get hurt in the middle of work, please don't keep it to yourself and notify your supervisor.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今、犯人を追いかけている最中だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Right now, I'm in the midst of chasing a criminal.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冗談でも悲しい最中に悪口を言われると、もっと悲しくなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if it is a joke, when someone says something mean when I am really sad, I get even more sad.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一生懸命な最中に話し掛けられると、一気に集中力がなくなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When someone talks to me when I am highly concentrated, I suddenly lose my concentration.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それについては考えている最中です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am in the middle of thinking about that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 朝の散歩の最中に、犬に噛まれた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was bitten by a dog while right in the middle of my morning walk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寝ている最中に声をかけるのはやめてほしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want you to stop trying to talk to me while I am sleeping.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テストの最中に眠ってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I fell asleep in the middle of taking the test.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 話している最中に邪魔をするのはやめてほしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want you to stop disturbing me while I am talking.

Name: 上(うえ)で
Meaning: After, Upon
About: 上(うえ)で is an expression in Japanese that is used after the past form of verbs, or nouns followed by の. It shows that something will happen 'after (A)', or 'upon (A)'. This grammar point is used in a similar way to its literal meaning, which is 'with the above/previous (A), (B)'. 上(うえ) as 'above', and で as 'with', in で's use as a case marking particle. 上(うえ)で is a structure that is primarily used in formal settings. Due to this, it will not be used in casual conversations very often. It also strongly hints at (A) being a requirement for (B), or (A) being something that would logically be expected before (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この企画は社長と相談した上で、キャンセルすることに決めました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Upon consulting the CEO of the company, we have decided to cancel this project.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 色んな車を運転した上で、どの車を買うか決めたいと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Upon driving various cars, I would like to choose which car to purchase.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 以下の内容を確認の上で、サインをしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Upon confirming the details below, please sign your name.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 以下のリンクからログインの上で、内容変更をしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Upon logging in from the link below, please change your information.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こちらの商品は医者に相談した上で、使用してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please use this product upon consulting with a doctor.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 医者に教えられた上で、使用してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please use this upon being told to be a doctor. (Unnatural)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 家の中を見た上で、買おうと思っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am thinking that I will buy the house after I have seen the inside. (upon)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 説明書を読んだ上で、ご使用ください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please use it after reading the instructions. (upon)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 変更した上で、間違いがあるかどうか確認するべきだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After making changes, you should check whether or not there are any mistakes. (upon)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 妻と相談した上で、手術を受けることを決めたいと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I would like to make the decision about undergoing surgery, after I discuss it with my wife. (upon)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 慎重な調査の上で、被告は有罪と決定しました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Upon careful investigation, the defendant has been found guilty. (after)

Name: お陰(かげ)で
Meaning: Thanks to, Because of
About: おかげで (or お陰(かげ)で in kanji) is an expression that is used to show thanks or appreciation in Japanese. It is usually translated simply as 'thanks to (A)', or 'because of (A)'. おかげで is a combination of the polite prefix お, the noun 陰(かげ) 'shade', and the case marking particle で. おかげで can be used after any word in its attributive form. Literally, お陰(かげ)で means 'in the shade of (A)'. This implies that (B) was only made possible due to (A) creating the ideal situation for it to occur.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タケルくんに手伝ってもらったお陰で仕事が早く終わったよ。今日は本当にありがとうね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We were able to finish work early, thanks to you helping us Takeru. Thank you so much for today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部屋が汚いお陰でどこに何があるか全く分からない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thanks to my room being so dirty, I don't know where anything is. (Sarcasm)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達が有名なお陰で、どんな高級レストランでも予約なしで入れる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thanks to my friend being famous, we can go to any fancy restaurant without a reservation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたのおかげで不自由のない生活ができている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thanks to you, we can live a life free of inconvenience.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前が変な事言ったおかげで、俺が言いたい事を忘れちゃったじゃん！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thanks to you saying something weird, I forgot what I wanted to say! (Sarcasm)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あいつのおかげでまた残業だよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We have to work overtime again thanks to him. (Sarcasm)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: おかげで、テストに合格することができました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thankfully, I was able to pass my test.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: おかげで、いい休暇を過ごせました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thanks to you, I was able to enjoy a nice holiday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 薬のお陰でだいぶよくなりました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Thanks to the medicine, I got much better.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 風が強いお陰で、ヨットのスピードが上がった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Thanks to the strong wind, the yacht gained speed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お陰で助かったよ。来てくれてありがとう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Thanks to you, I was saved. Thank you for coming.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スマホのお陰で、目的地にスムーズに着きました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Thanks to my smartphone, I had no trouble arriving at my destination.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君のお陰で取引は失敗だったよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Thanks to you the deal was a failure!

Name: に基(もと)づいて
Meaning: Based on, In accordance with
About: In order to say that one thing is 'based on' another in Japanese, the expression に基(もと)づいて will be used. This is a combination of the case marking particle に, the う - Verb, 基(もと)づく 'to originate from', and the conjunction particle て. This expression regularly highlights some kind of judgement/conclusion that the speaker has made, using (A) as their base. To use に基(もと)づいて, put the noun (or noun phrase) that you would like to identify as a 'basis' before に基(もと)づいて, and then express your judgment/conclusion in part (B) of the sentence. Alternatively, the past form of 基(もと)づく may be used when connected directly to a second noun. (A) に基(もと)づいた (B) directly expresses that (B) is based on (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: クライアントの指示に基づいて、編集をしておきました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have edited this based on the client's instructions. (Edited in advance, assuming that would be the client's wishes)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 以前成功した計画に基づいて、新しい計画を立てようと思っています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am thinking of making a new plan based on the previous successful plan.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は実話に基づいた映画が好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like movies based on true stories.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来週までに、アンケートに基づいたグラフを作成してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: By next week, please make a graph based on these surveys.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの国の法律は宗教に基づいて作られている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That country's law is founded on religion.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先月貰った資料に基づいて、このレポートを書きました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wrote this paper based on the documents you gave me last month.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この小説は歴史的実話に基づいて書かれている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This novel is written based on true historical events.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 信用に基づいて、お金を貸す。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I lend money based on trust.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 法律に基づいて、判断させていただきます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will make my judgment based on the law.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ちゃんと計画に基づいて、動いてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please proceed in accordance with the plan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたの意見に基づいて、変更を加えました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I implemented a modification based on your opinion.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 間違った前提に基づいているから、当然結果も間違っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The results are incorrect because (the experiment) is being based on incorrect assumptions.

Name: 点(てん)
Meaning: Aspect, Respect, Point, Way, In terms of, In that, From the point of view
About: 点(てん) is a kanji that is regularly used to express a specific 'point', 'spot', 'aspect', or something similar. When attached to the end of the attributive form of another word, it will highlight that word as a point of interest within the sentence. This is regularly translated as 'from the aspect of (A)', 'in respect to (A)', 'in terms of (A)', and other similar phrases that simply draw attention to something. To use 点(てん), attach it to the attributive form of another word, a noun followed by の, or a phrase followed by という. In many cases, 点(てん) will be followed by the case marking particle で, but other particles may be used depending whether 点(てん) is being conveyed as a subject, object, destination, or something being utilized. Sometimes, で (as 'with' or 'at') may be replaced with expressions such as について 'in relation to (A)', or からいうと 'speaking from (A)'. So long as the grammar structure that accompanies 点(てん) is also used to highlight something specific (and can be paired with a noun), it will sound natural.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 分からない点がありましたら、こちらまでお電話をください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please call here if there are any points that are hard to understand.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 漢字の一番難しい点は、読み方が沢山あることです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The most difficult aspect of kanji is that there are many ways to read them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アプリは使いやすさと便利さが一番重要な点で、見た目などはあまり綺麗じゃなくてもいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ease of use and convenience are the most important aspects of an app, so it is okay if it doesn't look too pretty.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: イギリスの食文化はいくつかの点でスペインの食文化と違う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Food culture of England and Spain is different in several aspects.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 十万人のユーザーが居るという点では凄いと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In terms of having 100,000 users, I think it is amazing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 分からない点について質問はありますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you have any questions in regards to something you don't understand?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 以上の点から言うと、来月までにオープンすることは不可能という事ですね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Based on the points mentioned above, this means that it is impossible to start business by next month, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語にひらがなとカタカナと漢字があるという点から考えると、中国語は大分違う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Japanese is very different from Chinese in that Japanese has hiragana, katakana, and kanji.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この点でそのスマホの方がいいですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In this respect, that smartphone is better.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 英語はあらゆる点で日本語と違っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: English differs from Japanese in all respects. (all points)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何らかのアクションが必要であるという点を総株主は認めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: All shareholders agreed on the point that some action is needed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いくつかの点で韓国語やトルコ語は日本語に似ている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In some respects, Korean and Turkish are similar to Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はちょっと忘れっぽいという点で彼の父と同じだね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In terms of being a bit forgetful he is just like his father, right?

Name: なぜなら + から
Meaning: Because, The reason is, That is because
About: When combined with the conjunction particle から, なぜなら (or なぜならば) forms a set pattern that can be translated as 'why (A), that is because (B)'. Essentially, it is a way to highlight that a 'because' is coming at the end of the sentence, drawing attention to it. なぜなら itself is a conjunction that is a combination of the adverb, なぜ 'why', and the hypothetical form of だ, なら. Literally, なぜなら～から is similar to 'why is (A) so, (B) is the cause'. This sounds quite dramatic in English, but is a perfectly natural way of emphasizing a statement/fact in Japanese. To use なぜなら～から, state that fact/important piece of information as (A). Then, at the beginning of a new sentence, なぜなら will be followed by the reason/cause, with から finishing the sentence. The primary function of なぜなら in Japanese (as opposed to simply using から or ので by itself) is to gain the attention of the listener, and inform them that important information is coming.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は仕事に来ません。なぜなら、明日は友達の結婚式に行くからです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will not come to work tomorrow. Why? That's because I will be going to my friends' wedding.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 卵を使わないで作ってください。なぜなら、私は卵アレルギーだからです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please make it without using eggs. Why? Because I'm allergic to them.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は泳ぎに行けなかった。なぜなら、寒かったから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He couldn't go swimming because it was cold.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: すみませんが、正直に言えないんです。なぜなら、秘密だから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm sorry but I can't tell you truthfully. The reason is that it is a secret.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼らは来るかどうかわからない。なぜなら、まだ連絡がきていないからです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't know if they are coming or not because they haven't contacted me yet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もうすぐ会えます。なぜなら、今度僕は日本に行くから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We can see each other soon. Why? Because I'll go to Japan next time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は仕事を休みました。なぜなら、インフルエンザにかかってしまったからです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I took the day off today. Why? Because I caught the flu.

Name: こそ
Meaning: For sure, For certain, Even more so, Underlined or bolded text
About: こそ is an adverbial particle in Japanese that primarily replaces either を or が. Its main role is to highlight the preceding noun (or noun phrase) as being the most important piece of information in relation to the rest of the sentence. In English, this is an effect that is primarily achieved through things like bold text, underlining, or emphasizing a particular word in speech. If we were to make a direct comparison to an English statement, then things like 'precisely because it's (A)', or 'rather it is due to (A)', are quite similar to こそ's function. こそ can be used directly after any noun that would usually take the を, or が particles, so long as that particular piece of information needs to be emphasized.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この曲こそ俺がずーっと探していた曲だ！やっと曲名が分かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This song is exactly the song I have been searching for! I finally figured out the title.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今度こそ勝つぞ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will win for sure next time!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いえいえ、私こそありがとうございます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No no no no, I am the one that should be thankful.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたこそリーダーにふさわしい！
Questions.EnglishHTML: You are fitting to be the leader!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今度こそ達成してみせる！
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will achieve (it) this time!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰かが「愛こそすべてだ」って言っていました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Someone once said that 'love is everything'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 困った時こその友達じゃないか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Without a doubt, friends help when you are in trouble, don't they?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんな時こそ僕の出番だ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: That is the time I will make my debut!

Name: からこそ
Meaning: Emphasized because, Precisely because
About: Traditionally, the adverbial particle こそ is used to emphasize whatever noun (or noun phrase) it is attached to. However, when combined with the conjunction particle から, it focuses on emphasizing the 'reason' for something. This structure is very similar to phrases like 'precisely because (A)' in English. からこそ is an expression that is primarily used after either verbs or nouns. In the case of nouns, the noun will need to be followed by the auxiliary verb だ, before からこそ is added. With からこそ, there may be several reasons for why something is the way it is, but こそ will show that there is a 'foremost' reason that should be considered before anything else.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺は努力したからこそ、試験に合格できたんだよ。頭がいいからだけじゃないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was able to pass the test, precisely because I gave it my all. It's not only because I am smart.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩に色々と教えて貰ったからこそ、私はここまでこれたのです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was able to get to where I am now because of all the things you, senpai, have taught me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 君だからこそできたんだよ。俺にはまだそんな凄い事は出来ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You were able to do it precisely because it was you. I can't do anything that amazing yet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここは綺麗な川だからこそ、こんな美味しい魚が釣れるんですよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You can catch great fish here precisely because the river is so clean.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカ君が休みなのに仕事に来てくれたからこそ、準備が早く終わったり、締め切りまでに仕事を終わらせることができたんです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We were able to finish with the prep work and finish work by the deadline, precisely because you, Tanaka-kun, came into work even though it was your day off.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたがいるからこそ、安心できるんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Precisely because you're here is why I can relax.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仲間がいるからこそ、頑張れる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can do my best precisely because I have friends.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 難しい状況だからこそ生まれるアイデアもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are also ideas that are born precisely because of difficult situations.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君が励ましてくれたからこそ、ここまでやってこれたんだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I could make it this far precisely because you have given me so much support.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 毎日努力をしたからこそ、一番になれた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Precisely because I worked hard every day, I was able to become number one.

Name: ばかり
Meaning: Just, Only, Nothing but
About: When used after verbs followed by the conjunction particle て, or nouns, the adverbial particle ばかり highlights that 'nothing but (A) is being done', or 'only (A) exists'. In relation to verbs, てばかり is often followed by いる, as a modified version of the standard ている. However, adding いる is not a requirement, and the same nuance may be conveyed without it. When a sentence consists of a part (A) and a part (B), ばかり will be followed by either で (with verbs or nouns), or いて (only with verbs). This is when ばかり appears directly before the sentence conjunction point, and other combinations are possible (such as ばかりだから). It should be noted that the で with ばかり here is not the particle で, but the conjunctive form of the auxiliary verb, だ.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生はいつも怒ってばかりいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Our teacher does nothing but get angry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近はお菓子ばかり食べているから、お腹がでてきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, I've been eating nothing but sweets, so my stomach is bulging out.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先月生まれた息子がずっと泣いてばかりいて、全然寝れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My son who was born last month does nothing but cry, so I can't sleep.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は毎日残業してばかりで、全然家の事を手伝ってくれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: All he does is work overtime everyday, and he won't help me with house chores.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は口を開けると文句ばかりで、一緒にいるだけで疲れる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When he opens his mouth, all he can do is complain, so just being with him is exhausting.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はいつも嘘ばかり言っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He does nothing but tell lies.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の弟はゲームをしてばかりですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My little brother does nothing but play video games.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 知らない顔ばかりだから緊張する。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because there are only/nothing but unfamiliar faces I feel nervous.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 甘い物を食べてばかりいると、虫歯が増える。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you only/do nothing but eat sweets, you will have more cavities.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつももらってばかりですみません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It seems that I do nothing but receive (gifts) from you. Sorry about that.

Name: ばかりだ
Meaning: (Only) continue to, Keep on -ing, More and more
About: Occasionally, the adverbial particle ばかり is combined with verbs in their attributive form, to show that (A) is the only thing that is occuring. It may also imply that (A) is happening 'more and more', or that 'it keeps on (A)'. This phrase utilizes ばかり's standard meaning of 'only', and combines it with the auxiliary verb だ (or です). As can be seen with these sentences, this use of ばかり is paired almost exclusively with verbs that describe some form of change (higher/lower, stronger/weaker, better/worse, faster/slower, etc). If the speaker would like to express further information in a (B) part of the sentence, だ will simply get changed to its conjunctive form で, before continuing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ガソリンの値段は上がっていくばかりだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The price of gas keeps rising.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近は全然体を鍛えていないから、筋肉がなくなっていくばかりだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently I haven't been working out, so I keep on losing muscle.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本の人口は減るばかりです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Japan's population continues to drop.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この辺は犯罪が多いので、治安が悪くなるばかりです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because there are so many crimes around here, the public safety of the area continues to get worse.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この町の治安が悪くなるばかりで、しばらく良くなりそうもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The public order of this town keeps on getting worse, and it doesn't look like it will get better anytime soon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 観光客が減るばかりで、周りの店が潰れていっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The amount of tourists keeps on dropping, and the stores around us are closing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日夜遅くまで働いているから、疲れがたまっていくばかりだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I work until late at night everyday, I keep getting more exhausted.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 病院を変えてから、体調が良くなっていくばかりだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ever since I changed hospitals, my health keeps on getting better.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は傲慢になるばかりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He continues to get more arrogant. (only)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: おじいさんの健康が衰えるばかりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The state of grandpa's health keeps on declining. (only)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 最近、ビットコインの価値が下がるばかりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Recently, the price of bitcoin keeps on dropping. (only)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 癌のため、体が弱っていくばかりです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because of the cancer, my body continues to get weaker. (only)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夏休みになってから、日本語を忘れていくばかりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have been continuously forgetting Japanese since summer vacation started. (only)

Name: ばかりに
Meaning: Simply because, Only because, Just because, Simply on account of
About: When paired with the case marking particle に, ばかり regularly conveys the meaning of 'simply because', or 'just because'. Literally, this expression means that 'even with just (A), (B) is/was able to occur'. This phrase is regularly paired with the past form of verbs, indicating that something that has already taken place, led to some other result. To use ばかりに, simply attach the expression to the end of any word in its attributive form. It should be noted that this particular grammar pattern has a strong tendency to be used with results that are negative. However, this is not a requirement. A high level of eagerness/enthusiasm can also be expressed when paired with grammar points like たい, or ほしい.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ボールをキャッチしたばかりに、肩が外れました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Simply because I caught a ball, I dislocated my shoulders.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 体が小さいばかりに、クラスメイトにいじめられた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Simply because I am small, my classmates bullied me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は練習が大変なばかりに、部活をやめることにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Simply because practice was difficult, he decided to quit.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新人であるばかりに、先輩たちがやりたくない仕事を押し付けられた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Simply because I am new, my senpai made me do all the work they didn't want to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 釣りに行きたいばかりに、仕事を休んで海に行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Simply because he wanted to go fish, he took a day off of work and went to the ocean.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しい車が欲しいばかりに、貯金を全部使った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because I wanted a new car, I used all my savings.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 貰った肉を食べたばかりに、お腹を壊してしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even just with eating the meat that was given to me, I got a stomach ache.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今回は許すけど、またやったら許さないからね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will forgive you this time, but I will not forgive you if you do it again.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 財布を忘れたばかりに、お弁当を買えなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Simply because I have forgotten my wallet, I couldn't buy a bento.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は驚かされたばかりに、気を失ってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He passed out simply because he got surprised.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 恋人に会いたいばかりに、インドネシアに旅行した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Simply because I wanted to see my significant other, I traveled all the way to Indonesia.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 良いリーダーがいなかったばかりに、チームは試合に負けた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just because they didn't have a good leader, the team lost the match.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 点検を怠っていたばかりに、タコマナローズ橋は崩壊した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just because of negligence in inspections, the Tacoma Narrows Bridge crumbled.

Name: 事(こと)がある
Meaning: Something is possible, Sometimes, Occasionally, There are times when
About: ことがある is an expression in Japanese that combines the noun こと with the case marking particle が, and the う - Verb, ある. It is often translated as 'to be possible', 'to occasionally occur', or 'to sometimes occur'. However, the more literal translation of ことがある is '(A) is a thing that exists'. ことがある may be paired with the attributive form of any other word. Occasionally, が may be replaced by も. In these situations, it implies that '(A) is also a thing that exists'. Basically this just highlights that (A) is something that needs to be considered (among other things).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この馬は人を蹴ることがあるので、馬の後ろに立たないで下さい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This horse kicks people sometimes, so please don't stand behind him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカ先生の授業はたまに楽しいことがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are times where Mr. Tanaka's classes are fun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事はだいたい大変だけれども、たまには楽なことがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Work is usually difficult, but there are times where it is easy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事は楽しいけど、大変なこともある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Work is fun, but there are times where it gets difficult.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生はいつも怒っているけど、優しいこともある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Our teacher is always angry, but there are times when he is nice.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 週に一回のペースでラーメンを食べることがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are times when I eat ramen once a week.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このラーメンは食べたことがあると思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think I have eaten this ramen before.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 頑張ってもうまくいかない事がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are times when no matter how hard you try, it doesn't go well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 学校に送ってもらう事がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I sometimes get a ride to school.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達は昼２時まで寝る事がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are times when my friend sleeps until two in the afternoon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの番組ならたまに見る事がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (There are times that ) I sometimes watch that TV program.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一日に二、三回ぐらい、ラーメンを食べる事がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are days where I eat ramen two or three times.

Name: 事(こと)にする
Meaning: To decide on, Have decided to
About: In a similar way to how にする means to 'decide on' something, ことにする means to decide on a situation, or course of action. This grammar point is a combination of 事(こと) 'thing' in its role as a nominalizer (a word that creates a noun-phrase), and にする 'to make it (A)'. Literally this grammar structure can be translated as 'to do (A)', or 'to make it (A)'. ことにする may be used with verb-phrases that are either in the affirmative, or negative (using ない) forms. As こと itself is a noun, the verb (or auxiliary verb) that comes before it will need to be in its attributive form. にする is a strong expression, which tends to make the speaker sound like they are fairly resolute in their decision.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日はワクチンを打ったから、明日は仕事を休むことにする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today I got vaccinated, so I will go with taking the day off tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タマキさんと箱根に行くことにする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have decided to go to Hakone with Tamaki-san.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は雨が降っているから、明日行くことにしない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is raining today, don't you want to make it that we go tomorrow?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勝手に僕が行くという事にしないでください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please don't decide that I will go without asking me. (Please don't assume that I want to go)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これからは肉を食べることにする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have decided to eat meat from now on.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これからは肉を食べることにしない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let's decide not to eat meat from now on.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これからは肉を食べないことにする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have decided to not eat meat from now on.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これからは肉を食べないことにしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have decided to not not eat meat from now on.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日はエイプリルフールだからウソしか言わない事にする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since today is April Fool's, I've decided to only tell lies.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの場所で、記念写真を撮る事にします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We've decided to take the commemorative photo at that place.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 九時に終わるか分からなかったが、早めに帰る事にしました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I didn't know if it would finish at nine but I decided to go home in advance.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これ以上言わない事にします。もし何か言ったら彼女を怒らせるでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have decided not to say anything else. If I say something, it would piss her off.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この商品、無料で配る事にします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have decided to hand out this product for free.

Name: 事(こと)なの
Meaning: (A) is (Description of A), (A) means that (Description of A)
About: When the noun こと (or 事(こと) in its kanji form) is combined with なの, it conveys an explanatory meaning that is similar to what can be seen in the んです・のです grammar pattern. As with んです, ことなの transforms 'it is (A)', into 'it is that it is (A)', simply emphasizing the point. ことなの may be seen in several different forms, and is quite often used in conjunction with というのは. In these types of sentences, というのは will present the topic, before ことなの will be used to show the conclusion that the speaker has drawn about that topic. This expression may be used with any word in its attributive form, nouns followed by の, or な-Adjectives followed by な. という may also be used directly before ことなの. However, this is not always the case, and is even more unlikely when it was already utilized in the first half of the sentence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 漫画家というのは漫画を描く人のことなのだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Manga artists are people that draw manga.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 付属品というのはメインの物に付属している物の事なんだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Accessories are things that come with the main product.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 雨が上がるというのは雨が止むことなのです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The thing which is 'for rain to rise' means 'to stop raining'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は超一流歌手ということなの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you mean that person is the most skilled singer?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 輸送とは荷物を送ることなの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: 'Freight' means to ship a package.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: つまりそこに一人で行くと危ないということなのか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You mean that it is dangerous to go there alone?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなに怒ることなのですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is this something you should get so worked up over?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ハダウェイ：「恋愛とはどういう事なのだろうか。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Haddaway: 'Love, what does it mean?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: つまり、その病気が感染症ではないという事なのである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In other words, it means that the disease is not infectious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: チーターのように走るとは足が速いという事なのだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Running like a cheetah' means to be fast.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「ザクシャ・イン・ラブ」とは「愛を永遠に」という事なのだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Zawsze in love' means 'forever in love'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 頭が切れるというのは頭がいい事なのだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'To be sharp' means ' to be smart'.

Name: 事(こと)になる
Meaning: It will end up being, It is the result of, It has been decided that
About: ことになる is an expression that combines the nominalizing use of こと (creating a noun-phrase), with the case marking particle に, and the う - Verb なる 'to become'. This expression can be translated as 'to become (A)', but has the nuance that someone/thing caused (A) to become that way. Due to this, it may also be translated as 'it has been decided that (A)', or 'it will end up being (A)'. ことになる is primarily used with verbs and い-Adjectives in their attributive form. It may also be used with な-Adjectives followed by な. The 'it has been decided that (A)' meaning only applies to verbs, as only verbs will be enacted by someone/thing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なんでも後回しにしているとあとから苦労することになる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you wait until it is too late, you are going to end up regretting it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなことをしたらとんでもないことになるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you do something like that, it is going to become a huge deal.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 出来るだけ早く治療をしないと、後から大変なことになる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you don't treat it soon, it is going to end up being a bigger issue.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうしてこんな事になったの？意味がわからないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Why did it end up like this? I don't get it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大変な事になったぞ。何か作戦を考えなければ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We ended up getting in trouble. We have to figure out a plan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私が会議に出る事になった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was decided that I will attend the meeting.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 連絡がなければ、僕が仕事に行く事になります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If we do not hear anything, I will end up going to work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 困った事になったな。もう電池が切れそうだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I ended up in a jam. It seems that my battery is about to die.

Name: は～で有名(ゆうめい)
Meaning: Is famous for
About: In order to describe what certain things/places are famous for, ～は～で有名(ゆうめい) is a common expression that will be used. This construction is made up of the adverbial particle は, the case marking particle で, and 有名(ゆうめい), a noun that may also be used as an な-Adjective. ～は～で有名 is usually translated as '(A) is famous for (B)', but literally means 'with (B), (A) is famous/renowned'. The structure may be broken down in the following way: (A) は - Presents (A) as the topic. (B) で - With (B), in で's use as 'with'. 有名(ゆうめい)だ - Is famous. As can be seen from these examples, こと (or の) may precede で有名(ゆうめい). This is quite common when an entire phrase is being described as the famous aspect of (A), rather than a single word.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ウサイン・ボルトは速く走れることで有名です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Usain Bolt is famous for being able to run fast.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この学校は野球が強いことで有名です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This school is famous for having a strong baseball team.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本は安全なことで有名です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Japan is famous for being safe.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 岡山は備前焼で有名です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Okayama is famous for Bizen-yaki.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: グランドキャニオンはアメリカで有名な観光地だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The Grand Canyon is a famous tourist site in America.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 出雲大社は島根県で有名な神社だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Izumo Taisha is a famous shrine in Shimane prefecture.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 札幌は雪まつりで有名です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Sapporo is famous for the snow festival.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大間はマグロで有名だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Ooma is famous for tuna.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの先生は授業がおもしろいことで有名です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That teacher is famous for his interesting classes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このうどんはコシが強いことで有名だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This udon is famous for its strong and chewy noodles.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この町は温泉で有名です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This town is famous for its hot springs.

Name: 事(こと)はない
Meaning: There is no need to, Never happens
About: ことはない is an expression that has two primary purposes in Japanese. To convey that there is 'no need for (A)', or that '(A) never happens'. In these cases, (A) is a verb that will appear directly before こと. ことはない is often used to reassure someone that something will not come to pass. In this expression, the adverbial particle は is working to present (A) as the extent (a regular role of adverbial particles), while the 形容詞(けいようし) ない negates that extent. This negation is up to interpretation, with the literal meaning simply being 'There is no (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなに慌てることはない。まだ時間がいっぱいあるからゆっくりやればいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no need to rush that much. We still have a lot of time, so it is okay if you pace yourself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １０年前に親と喧嘩をしてから、親と話すことはない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ever since I fought with my parents 10 years ago, I have not talked to them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなに心配した事が無い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There has never been a time where I worried that much.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなに心配することはないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no need to worry that much.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんな急ぐ事はない。ぼちぼちやればいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no need to hurry. You should take your time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もうあの家に帰る事はないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We will never return to that house, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう彼に教える事はありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no need to teach him anymore.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これ以上何も言う事はない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no need to say more.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この抽選で車が当たる事はないと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think that winning a car in this lottery never happens.

Name: と言(い)っても
Meaning: Although ~ might say that ~
About: As a construction that combines と言(い)う (presenting the previous statement as a quotation) and ても, meaning 'even if (A)', or 'even though (A)',  と言(い)っても will mean 'even if I say (A)', or 'although I say (A)'. This expression is used when the speaker wants to highlight (A), but draw the listener's attention to (B), in order to clarify something. This expression may be used after any word in almost any tense, due to the case marking particle と is being used in its quotation role. However, な-Adjectives and nouns will sometimes be followed by だ (although it is regularly omitted).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日走ると言っても、１５分しか走らないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although I say I run every day, I only run for 15 minutes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 辛いと言ってもピリ辛だから、あなたでも食べれると思うよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though I say it is spicy, it is only slightly spicy, so I think you should be able to eat it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この肉は新鮮だと言っても、３日前に買ったからそんなに新鮮ではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although I say this meat is fresh, I bought it 3 days ago, so it is not that fresh.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新幹線だと言ってもこだまに乗るから、そんなに早く着かないと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although I say I'm going by shinkansen, I will be riding the Kodama, so I don't think I will get there that fast.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 危険と言ってもおかしくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although some might say that it is dangerous, it's not that strange. (It is safe to say that it is dangerous)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 難しいと言っても、実際にやってみると意外と簡単です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though it is said that it is difficult, once you actually try it, it is quite easy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: プレゼントと言っても、たいしたものはない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although I say that it is a present, it is nothing special.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたは天才だと言っても過言ではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if someone says you are a genius, it is not an exaggeration.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生って言っても、いろんな人がいるよね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although you may say 'sensei,' there are different people (types of sensei).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 楽しいって言っても、サッカーの方が楽しいと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although you might say it is fun, soccer is more fun.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ほしいって言っても、高くて自分では買えません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although I might say I want it, it is expensive and I can't buy it for myself.

Name: といえば
Meaning: Speaking of, If it were the case that
About: と言(い)えば, と言(い)うと, and と言(い)ったら are all expressions that are translated quite closely to 'speaking of (A)', or 'if it were the case that (A)'. Each of these structures has a slightly different nuance, but are largely used in the same situations. と言(い)えば - More hypothetical, 'were it (A)'. と言(い)うと - More concrete, 'if it's (A)'. と言(い)ったら - More situational, 'when it's (A)'. These constructions are most commonly used after nouns, in response to something that has already been mentioned in the conversation (usually by someone else). The thing that has already been said is quite often the 'trigger' for someone remembering something, causing them to interject with と言(い)えば.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夏と言えばスイカバーでしょ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If we're talking (about) summer, it's gotta be a Suika-bar, don't you think? (Suika-bars are the best thing when it is summer, don't you think)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカさんというと、先月銀行強盗で捕まった人ですよね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Speaking of Tanaka-san, he is the person that got arrested for robbing a bank last month, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ラーメン？日本と言ったら寿司の方が人気でしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ramen? If it's Japan (we're talking about), sushi is more popular, isn't it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夏と言ったら祭りだから、明日の祭りに一緒に行かない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Speaking of summer, since it's a festival, do you want to go to the festival tomorrow?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: キクチ君といえば、幾つなんだろう？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Speaking of Kikuchi-kun, I wonder how old he is.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「夏休み、海に行きたいわ。」
Ｂ：「夏といえばかき氷だよね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'I want to go to the beach during summer vacation.'
B: 'Speaking of summer, shaved ice!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「コーヒーがほしい！」
Ｂ：「コーヒーといえば、新しい喫茶店が開店した。じゃあ、一緒に喫茶店に行こうか？」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'I want coffee.'
B: 'Speaking of coffee, a new coffee shop just opened. Wanna go?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「ビットコインの評価は最近下ったみたい...。」
Ｂ：「ビットコインといえば、今、売るべきなの？」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'It looks like the value of bitcoin has recently decreased...'
B: 'Speaking of bitcoin, should I sell now?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「最近、アニメは国際的に人気になっていくよ。」
Ｂ：「アニメといえばドラグーンボールの新しいシーズンが放送されているね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'Recently anime is getting popular internationally.'
B: 'Speaking of anime, a new season of 'Dragoon ball' has aired, right?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「カナダではオーロラや野生動物がよく見られるらしい。」
Ｂ：「オーロラの美しさといったら、言葉では表現できませんなあ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'I have heard that you can see auroras and wild animals in Canada.'
B: 'Speaking of the beauty of auroras, it cannot be described with words.' (if you were to speak of...)

Name: 合(あ)う
Meaning: To do for one another, Mutually, With
About: When following the conjunctive form of another verb, the う - Verb 合(あ)う means to do that action in concert with another person/group. This is often translated as 'to mutually do (A)', or 'to do (A) for one another'. Realistically, it just means 'to do (A) reciprocally', with involvement from both sides being required. In this usage, 合(あ)う is considered to be a suffix. This construction is often used with expressions like お互(たが)いに 'mutually', which simply emphasizes the point.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女と将来の事を話し合う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am going to talk with my girlfriend about our future.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供たちがおもちゃを取り合うのを見てお兄ちゃんの事を思い出した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The kids were fighting with each other over a toy, and that reminded me of my older brother.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達とポケモンカードを見せ合う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My friend and I show each other our Pokemon cards.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こういう時こそ、助け合うのが大切だよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At times like this, it is important to help each other out.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私達は夫婦なんだから、どんなことがあっても協力し合わないといけないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We are husband and wife, so no matter what happens, we need to cooperate.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 全チームが賞金をかけて競い合う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every team competed against each other with the prize money on the line.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 高校の頃、兄とドッキリをよく仕掛け合った...
Questions.EnglishHTML: During our high school days, my brother and I often pranked one another…

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 協力し合ったりしながら山をゆっくりと登った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We slowly climbed the mountain while aiding one another (among other things).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ＥＵで交流し合うことは重要だと考えられている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In the European Union, (to do) mutual cultural exchange is considered important.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「友達が苦しんでる時は、助け合うべきだね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Friends ought to help one another in times of trouble, right?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: かなださき：「私達、同時に告白し合ったんだよ！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Saki Kanada: 'We professed our love for one another at the same time!'

Name: に合(あ)わせて
Meaning: In accordance with, Matching, Fitting, Suitable for, Adjust or tune to
About: When the る - Verb 合(あ)わせる (sometimes 併(あ)せる) is seen in the form 合(あ)わせて, it conveys that something has been made to 'match (A)' or 'fit with (A)'. (A) being a noun that appears before に, followed by 合(あ)わせて. This structure can also have the nuance of 'in accordance with (A)', highlighting that (A) is the governing factor. It is also possible to see the う - Verb 合(あ)う used in its past tense form, linking an (A) noun to a (B) noun. This has a similar meaning, but is closer to '(B) that has met (A)'. In sentences that use either of these expressions, more information is usually given about why something is happening in accordance with (A), or what the purpose of (B) meeting (A) is/was.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 音楽に合わせてギターを弾く練習をしています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am practicing playing my guitar along with music.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 相手に合わせて話し方を変えるのは疲れる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is exhausting to change how you talk in accordance with who you are talking to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このソファーにあったテーブルを買おう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Lets buy a table that matches this couch.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 壁紙にあった家具が欲しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want furniture that matches the wallpaper.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: リズムに合わせて歌を歌う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I sing while matching the rhythm. (I sing to the rhythm)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 合図に合わせてスタートする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To start in accordance with the signal.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 合図に合わせて、スタートしてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In accordance with the signal, please begin.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 服装は季節に合わせて、変えるものだよ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: You are supposed to change your clothes to match the season.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 状況に合わせて、やり方を変えてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Change your approach in accordance with the situation.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私に合った服を選んで。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please choose some clothes that suit me. (match)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの音楽に合わせて、踊ろうよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's dance (in accordance) with that music.

Name: について
Meaning: Concerning, About, Regarding
About: について is a combination of the case marking particle に, the verb う - Verb 就(つ)く 'to assume a position', and the conjunction particle て. It is most often translated as 'about (A)', or 'concerning (A)', with the literal translation being closer to 'taking the position of (A)', or 'assuming the topic of (A)'. について may be used after nouns, or noun-phrases (phrases that use こと, の, etc). について may also appear before の + noun. In this use, it means '(A) that is about (B)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女と別れたことについて話したいんだけど時間ある？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to talk to you about breaking up with my girlfriend, but do you have time?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 契約のことについて、何か質問はありますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you have any questions regarding the contract?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 行きたい国について、作文を書いてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please write an essay about the country you want to visit.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 契約についてのパンフレットは明日届くので、しっかりとお読みになってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The brochure regarding the contract will be delivered tomorrow, so please make sure to read it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は和製英語についてのレッスンをしたいと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today, I am thinking of giving you a lesson about Wasei Eigo.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この問題について、誰かに話しましたか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Have you talked to anyone about this problem? (concerning)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 火災について、訓練をするべきです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There should be training regarding fires. (about)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 震災についての情報を教えてもらった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was taught information regarding earthquake disasters. (concerning)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 原因についてはまだ調査中です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regarding the cause, we are still investigating. (concerning・about)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日の持ち物についてお伝えします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You will be informed about what to bring tomorrow. (regarding)

Name: の姿(すがた)
Meaning: Figure, Shape, Appearance, Looks, Wearing, Dressed in, Presence
About: When the noun 姿(すがた) 'figure' is used as a suffix, it describes the outward appearance of someone. This may be in relation to what the person is wearing, their overall shape, body type, or style. 姿(すがた) is often translated as '(A) looking', 'wearing (A)', 'clad in (A)', or 'performing (A)'. 姿(すがた) may be used after verbs in their attributive form, or after nouns followed by the case marking particle の. 姿(すがた) is a word that focuses primarily on the way that someone appears to observer. Therefore, it is also often used to describe the observer's impression of who they are looking at, in regard to their presence, or lack thereof.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日初めてお父さんが働いている姿を見た。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Yesterday was the first time I saw my father (his figure) working.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子が悲しんでいる姿を見ると、私まで悲しくなってくる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I see my son in a sad state, it makes even me sad.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さっき男の人の姿が見えたけど、気のせいかな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Earlier, I saw a man (his figure), but maybe I was seeing things.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: デパートで息子の姿が見えなくなって、少しパニックになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I lost sight of my son's presence at the department store, and it made me panic a little.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 娘の歩く姿が夫に似ている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The way my daughter walks looks just like my husband.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犬の寝ている姿はとてもかわいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The way my dog looks when he is sleeping is so cute.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やっとお前の花嫁姿が見れて嬉しいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am so happy that I can finally see you as a bride.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: シンデレラは１２時になった瞬間に元姿に戻った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As soon as it reached 12 oclock, Cinderella turned back into her original appearance.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この地域には人の姿が見えない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no human presence in this area. (figure)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたの動く姿が好きです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like the way you look when you move. (moving figure)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達との話：「あの人は顔も綺麗だし、立ち姿も美しい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between friends: 'That person has a pretty face, and also the way they stand is attractive.' (standing figure)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 衣料品店、クライアント：「自分の姿を鏡で見てみるよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Clothing store, client: 'I will look at my appearance in the mirror!' (figure)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ２０１２年に最後に会ってから、あの男の姿を見ていない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I haven't seen him (his presence) since the last time I met him in 2012. (figure・appearance)

Name: と言(い)える
Meaning: Would or could say that..., Can probably say that..., Fair to say that...
About: と言(い)える is a common expression that utilizes the potential form of the verb 言(い)う 'to say', to highlight that it is possible for something to be said. This phrase is often used to express a general idea about something that the speaker believes to be correct. と言(い)える translates as 'it is fair to say (A)', or 'one could say (A)'. As the case marking particle と is being used in its 引用(いんよう) (citation) use, と言(い)える may follow any direct phrase/statement. と言(い)える is regularly seen paired with grammar patterns like だろう, or でしょう. This makes the overall statement more friendly, by considering the listener's thoughts about the issue being presented. と言(い)えるだろう can simply be translated as 'can we not say (A)?', or '(A) can be said, right?'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この儀式は日本の文化の一つと言える。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is fair to say that this ceremony is part of Japan's culture.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのビルは日本一高いビルだと言える。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: One could say that the building over there is the tallest building in Japan.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このプランは成功したと言えるだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We could say that this plan was a success, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカ選手は国民的アスリートだと言えるでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Can it not be said that Tanaka is an athlete loved by everyone in the country?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 人が話しているときに、携帯を見るのは失礼だといえよう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let it be said that looking at your phone while someone is talking to you is rude. (Anyone would say this, so don't make me say it to you)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼らは同時にゴールインしたと言えるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: One could say that they got to the finish line at the same time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 船は飛行機ほど速くないが、それでも船旅を好む人は多いと言えるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Boats are not as fast as planes are, but it is still fair to say that a lot of people enjoy trips by boat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 発明家は、「変人」という評価を一般の人から下されてきたと言えるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You can probably say that the inventors were labeled as 'eccentrics' by the common folk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ２０世紀にはコンピュータによって生活しやすくなってきたと言えるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is fair to say that life is getting easier due to (the advent of) computers in the 20th century.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このマニフェストは自然環境の現在の状態についてのひとつの意見だと言えるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: One could say that this manifesto is one of the opinions about the current state of the natural environment.

Name: ちゃんと
Meaning: Properly, Neatly, Orderly, Sufficiently, Decently
About: In Japanese, two 副詞(ふくし) (adverbs) that are used to express very similar ideas are ちゃんと, and きちんと. These words may be used either at the beginning of a sentence (to modify the meaning of the whole sentence), or before verbs. ちゃんと and きちんと both translate quite closely to 'properly', or 'neatly'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ちゃんと宿題した？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Did you properly do your homework?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ちゃんと野菜も食べなさい！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Properly eat your vegetables too!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今度からはもっとちゃんとした車を買おう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From now on, I should buy a proper car. (From now on, I'm not going to cheap out on a car)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 結婚式にはきちんとした服装で来てください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please come to the wedding dressed properly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社長が来たぞ。ちゃんと立て。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The CEO is here. Stand up, quick! (Stand up now, quickly, don't slouch)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遊びに行く前にきちんと部屋の掃除をしなさい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You have to clean your room properly before you go out and play.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
妻：「ガスをちゃんと閉めたか、わからない。」
夫：「心配しないで、僕がちゃんと閉めたよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Wife: 'I don't know if I have properly turned the gas off (or not).'
Husband: 'Don't worry, I have properly turned it off.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
優しい次長：「昼休みなんだからちゃんと休んでね。」
部下：「はい! わかりました、次長！」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Gentle vice-director: 'It's lunch, so take a proper break.'
Subordinate: 'Yes! Understood, vice-director!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達との話：「悪いことをしたならちゃんと謝るものだ！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between friends: 'If you have done something wrong, you are supposed to apologize properly!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 母親は子供に言う：「お祖母さんが来る前に部屋をきちんと片付けしなさい！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mother speaking to her child: 'Clean your room properly before grandma comes!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大人との話、子供を褒める：「あの子は、ちゃんとしてるわね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between adults, praising a child: 'This child behaves properly, don't they.' (has good manners)

Name: その為(ため)に
Meaning: For that reason, Because of that, To that end
About: そのために is a frequently used conjunction in Japanese that utilizes その, the noun ため 'reason' (occasionally seen as 為(ため)), and the case marking particle に. そのために is most commonly translated as 'for that reason', or 'to that end'. そのために will be used at the beginning of a new sentence, to highlight something that will be done/occur due to the circumstances/goal of something in the first sentence. に is often omitted.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ハマダさんはとても釣りが好きです。そのため毎朝仕事に行く前に、釣りに行っています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hamada-san loves fishing. For that reason, he does it every morning before he goes to work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本では高齢化が進んでいる。そのため、子供が生まれたら政府からお金がもらえる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Japan's population continues to age. To that end, when a child is born, you receive money from the government.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供達にはなんの不自由もない生活をしてほしい。そのために毎日夜遅くまで仕事をしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want my kids to have a life without any struggles. For the sake of that, I work until late at night everyday.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しい車が欲しいけど今は住宅ローンで精一杯。そのために車を買うのを我慢している。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want a new car, but I am struggling to pay my mortgage. For that reason, I am holding off on doing it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ５人の家族を養う。その為に僕は働く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I support a family of 5. For that reason I work. (for the sake of that)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夜遅くまで仕事をした。その為寝坊してしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I worked until late. Because of that I overslept. (for the sake of that)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会社が倒産した。その為に失業した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The company went bankrupt. Because of that I lost my job. (for the sake of that)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は鉄道オタクです。いろんな電車の写真を撮るのですが、その為に徹夜することもあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am a railway 'enthusiast'. I take pictures of a variety of trains, because of that I sometimes pull all-nighters. (for the sake of that)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女の夢を実現させたい。その為にできるだけのことはしたいと思っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will make her dream a reality. For that reason I want to do all I can (to help). (for the sake of that)

Name: その結果(けっか)
Meaning: As a result
About: その結果(けっか) is a conjunction in Japanese that is used to highlight the result of something that has been previously said. The noun 結果(けっか) itself means 'result'. This expression translates as 'as a result of (A)', or 'resulting from (A)'. その結果(けっか) will be used at the beginning of a new sentence, before a (B) phrase will highlight the result of (A). その結果(けっか) may be used to highlight either positive, or negative results interchangeably. However, the (B) part of the sentence almost always focuses on a new 'situation' or 'condition' that has been created due to (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 学校を３ヶ月休んだ。その結果、皆と卒業することができなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I took three months off from school. As a result, I was not able to graduate with everyone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日焼け止めを塗らずにビーチで一日過ごした。その結果凄く日焼けをして、しばらくシャワーに入るのが辛かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I spent the whole day at the beach without sunscreen. As a result, I got a bad sunburn and it was painful to take a shower for a while.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日朝早くから夜遅くまで練習した。その結果、試合で優勝することができた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We practiced every day from early in the morning to late at night. As a result, we were able to win the tournament.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカ君は一年間運動をしないでゲームばっかりしていた。その結果２０キロも太った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-kun only played video games without exercising for a year. As a result, he gained 20 kilograms.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夜更かしをした。その結果、遅刻した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I stayed up till late. As a result, I was late.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 無理をして走った。その結果足がつった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I overdid it running. As a result, I got a leg cramp.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 値上げをした。その結果、売り上げが下がってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The price increased. As a result, sales decreased.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の分も買ってきてあげた。その結果褒められた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I got one for him too. As a result, I was praised.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 運動をやめてしまった。その結果、五キロも太った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I gave up on exercising. As a result, I gained 5 kilos.

Name: に比(くら)べて
Meaning: Compared to, When compared to
About: に比(くら)べて is a set expression in Japanese, used when comparing one thing to another.
