It is often simply translated as '(A) compared to (B)', or 'when comparing (A) to (B)'. 比(くら)べる is a る - Verb that means 'to compare', or 'to contrast'. に比(くら)べて will be attached directly after a noun, before the (B) part of the sentence will explain the comparison that is being made. Occasionally, the case marking particle と will be used instead of に. に and と are largely interchangeable in this expression, with に focusing slightly more on the changes/differences between similar features of (A) and (B). Alternatively と often mutually contrasts (A) and (B), discussing their individual/unique characteristics.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 東京の冬は北海道の冬に比べて全然寒くない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tokyo's winter is not cold at all compared to Hokkaido.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 去年に比べて今年の冬は暖かい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Compared to last year, this year's winter is warm.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大阪の人口は東京の人口に比べて小さい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Osaka's population is smaller compared to Tokyo.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼も真面目だけど、君は彼に比べるともっと真面目だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is serious too, but you are more serious compared to him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 君は彼と比べて真面目だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Compared to him, you are serious. (You are serious, while he has other qualities)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本はアメリカと比べて小さい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Compared to America, Japan is small. (Japan is small, compared to America, which is big, among other things)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 他の地域に比べたら、この地域は住みやすい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Compared to other areas, this area is very easy to live in.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 去年に比べれば今年は寒いけど、昨日に比べたら今日は暖かい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If compared to last year, it is colder this year. However if we compare it to yesterday, it is warm today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新型のパソコンに比べるとこのパソコンは遅く感じるけど、そんなに遅くない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If we compare this computer to a new model, it feels slow, but it's not that slow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 野球に比べたら、サッカーの方が好きだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When compared with baseball, I like soccer more.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一学期に比べて成績がよくなった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My grades have improved compared to first semester.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昨日に比べたら今日は暖かい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Compared to yesterday, today is warmer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 去年に比べて今年は雪が多い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is more snow this year compared to last year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昔に比べると、今の人は長生きだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: People live longer nowadays compared to those in the past.

Name: どんなに～ても
Meaning: No matter how
About: As explained in the そんな grammar point, the こそあど言葉(ことば) may occasionally be seen in the forms こんな, そんな, あんな, or どんな. どんな itself is an abbreviation of どのような, meaning 'in what way', or 'what kind of'. When partnered with に (creating an adverb), and ても, どんなに～ても is used to express the extent of something that is insufficient. It can be translated as 'no matter how (A), (B)'. どんなに may be attached to any type of word, so long as that word is then followed by でも (in the case of nouns or な-Adjectives) or ても (in the case of い-Adjectives or verbs). どんなに～ても can literally be translated as 'even if (A) is in however/whatever (way), (B)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今はお金が無いからどんなに伊豆に行きたくても行けないんだよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Right now I have no money, so no matter how much I want to go to Izu, I can't.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩の話しがどんなにつまらなくてもあくびをしてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how boring your senpai's stories are, you should not yawn.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自分の運転がどんなに上手でもシートベルトはしなくてはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how good you are at driving, you must wear a seatbelt.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんなにお金持ちでも、働かないとお金が無くなっていく。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how rich you are, if you don't work, money will just continue to disappear.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんなに頑張っても無理だと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think that it is impossible no matter how hard I try.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんなに笑われても、前に進もう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter how much they laugh at us, let's keep pushing forward.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんなに勉強しても、合格できないと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter how much I study, I don't think that I can pass.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんなに暇でも、掃除するつもりはない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter how bored I am, I won't even think about cleaning.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんなに苦しくても、僕はぜったいにあきらめない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will never give up no matter how hard it is.

Name: いくら～でも
Meaning: No matter how (much)
About: In a similar way to どんなに～ても, いくら～でも is regularly translated to 'no matter how (A), (B)'. However, unlike どんな (which is an abbreviation of どのような), いくら is a noun that comes from the kanji 幾(いく)ら, meaning 'how much'. When partnered with ても (with verbs and い-Adjectives), or でも (with nouns and な-Adjectives), the literal meaning means 'however much (A), (B)'. With いくら～でも, the (B) part of the phrase will usually highlight something that is being negated, giving the phrase it's 'no matter how much' nuance. Despite this trend of being used in sentences that contain ない or ありません, いくら～でも may also be seen in positive sentences. In these cases, despite not being negative, the (B) phrase will still be something that is surprising/unexpected in some way (due to its extent or amount).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人にいくら言っても、何も変わらないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how much you tell him, he won't change.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いくら新しくても落としたら壊れるに決まってるじゃん。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how new it is, of course it is going to break if you drop it!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人のことがいくら嫌いでも、そんな事言ったら可哀そうだよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how much you dislike them, that is a hurtful thing to say.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いくら俺でもそんな重いものは持てないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter if it is me, I can't lift something that heavy. (Even if it is me, who is strong, I cant lift something that heavy)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 相談ならいくらでも聞いてあげるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'll listen to you vent however much you need.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お菓子ならいくらでもあるから、好きなだけ持っていきな！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As for snacks, I have plenty, so take all you want!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お金はいくら払ってもいいのでその靴を私に下さい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will pay however much for those shoes, so please let me have them! (Amount only)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お金はどんなに払ってもいいのでその靴を私に下さい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will pay whatever sort of money for those shoes, so please let me have them! (Possible amount or type. Dollar, yen, euro, etc)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いくら急いでも土曜日までには終わらない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter how quickly I do it, I won't finish before Saturday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いくら泣いても、泣き止まない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter how much they cry, they won't cry themselves out.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いくらお金があっても、愛は買えない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter how much money you have, you can't buy love.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いくら頑張っても、彼にはかなわない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter how hard I try, I can't compete with him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いくら稼いでも、妻がすぐに使ってしまうから困っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am having trouble because no matter how much I earn, my wife spends it all.

Name: かは〜によって違(ちが)う
Meaning: Depends on, Changes depending on, Differ depending on
About: ～かは～によって違(ちが)う is an expression in Japanese that appears quite complex at first, but is actually quite simple when broken down into its parts. かは is a combination of the case marking particle か in its role as a quotation, paired with the adverbial particle は, highlighting the topic of the sentence. Together these can be translated as 'whether (A)'. によって違(ちが)う is made up of the case marking particle に (highlighting a location), the て form of よる (a う - Verb), followed by 違(ちが)う 'to differ', (another う - Verb). All together, this can be translated as '(A) depends on (B)'. More accurately though, the meaning is 'whether (A) will differ depending on (B)'. かは is regularly used after an entire phrase, followed by a noun and then によって違(ちが)う. Alternatively, かどうか may be used instead of かは. This changes the nuance from 'whether (A)', to 'whether or not (A)'. When translated directly, かどうか is quite similar to 'whether (A) or however'. Finally, this expression may also be seen without 違(ちが)う. In a sentence like this, 'differs' is simply removed, becoming 'whether (A) will depend on (B)'. As conjugation between the verbs is no longer required, によって will become による.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本が好きか嫌いかは人によって違う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether they like Japan or not depends on the person.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お酒を飲んで肌が赤くなるかならないかは体質によって違う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether someone's skin will turn red or not after drinking depends on the person.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 川の流れが早いか遅いかは場所によって違う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether the river flows fast or slow depends on the location.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 銃を簡単に買えるかどうかは国によって違う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether you can easily buy a gun or not depends on the country.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この技が凄いかどうかは見る人によって違う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether this trick is amazing or not depends on who judges.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日、早く帰れるか帰れないかは仕事の進み具合による。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether I can go home early or not today will depend on how work goes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 納豆を食べられるか食べられないかは人の好みによる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether or not a person can eat natto will depend on what they like.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 音楽が好きか嫌いかは人それぞれによって違う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It depends on the person, whether they like music or not.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 果物が高いかどうかは季節によって違う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether fruit is expensive or not changes depending on the season.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何が良いかは各人の主観によって違う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether something is good or not depends on each person's personal opinion.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 海が深いかどうかは場所によって違うでしょうね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether the sea is deep or not differs depending on location, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何歳で退職できるかは国によって違う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The age at which one can retire differs depending on the country.

Name: かなり
Meaning: Quite, Considerably, Pretty, Fairly
About: かなり is an adverb that is used to convey a 'considerable' amount of something. It is often translated as 'quite', 'fairly', 'considerably', or 'pretty'. かなり will almost always appear directly before a phrase, or directly before a noun (in which case の will come between the noun and かなり).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今月もかなりお金を使ったね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This month we used a considerable amount of money again, didn't we?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は一日中仕事をしていたからかなり疲れた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I was working all day today, I am pretty tired.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: メキシコまではかなりの距離があるから、船で行くより飛行機で行った方が早くつく。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since there is a considerable distance to Mexico, you will get there quicker if you go by airplane, rather than by boat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日の事故でかなりの人が怪我をした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Quite a lot of people got hurt in the accident yesterday.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 初めて作ったの？かなり美味しいよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You made it for the first time? It's pretty good!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: かなり痛いです。骨が折れていると思いますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's quite painful. Do you think a bone is broken?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達との話、地図を見て：「ここはかなり遠くの方だね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between friends, after looking at the map: 'This place is quite far away, isn't it?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
会社の社長：「新しいシステムを導入しよう。」
社員：「わかりました。でも、かなり費用がかかりそうですよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Company president: 'Let's adopt the new system.'
Company employee: 'Understood. However, it seems to be quite expensive.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
配送会社、労働者１：「じゃあ、はやくこれ、(トラックに）積んでしまおう。」
労働者２：「でもこれ、かなり重いんだけど。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Transport company, worker 1: 'Well then, let's quickly load it on the truck.'
Worker 2: 'But it is quite heavy…'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 文法ちゃん：「ユーザーさんの日本語は、かなり上級レベルだと思う。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Bunpou-chan: 'I think that User-san's Japanese is of quite a high level.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 従業員の噂話：「次長は、家ではお孫さんに優しいおじいちゃんらしいよ。そんな風に見えないけどね。会社ではかなり厳しい人だから。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Employees gossiping: 'I heard that the vice-director is a gentle grandpa who is sweet to his grandchild at home. He doesn't look like that though, right? Because he is fairly strict at the company.'

Name: 余(あま)りに
Meaning: So much...that, (Way) too...
About: Being the adverbial form of 余(あま)る 'excess', あまりに is a grammar structure that is used to convey an 'excessive' amount of something that caused a certain result. あまりに will almost always be used in sentences expressing some sort of surprise/shock about the degree of (A). Often, あまりに is translated simply as 'so much (A) that (B)', or 'way too much (A)'. In the last example, we can see that あまり will be followed by の when linked to a noun. Occasionally, にも will be used instead of に. This just emphasizes the 'excess' of (A) further. As the literal meaning of あまりに is quite close to 'excessively', it may be easier to remember this translation, rather than 'so much (A) that (B)'. Usually, 'it is excessively (A), so (B)' will cover most possible nuances.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日の仕事はあまりに楽過ぎて仕事をした感じがしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Work today was so easy that I don't feel like I worked at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今朝は会社にあまりに遅く着いたため、先輩に怒られた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This morning, I got to the company so late that I was yelled at by my senpai.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はあまりの恐怖に、声をあげて叫んだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She was so scared that she screamed out loud.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達の話しがあまりにもつまらなくて途中からほとんど聞いてなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My friend's story was so boring that I stopped paying attention halfway.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トマトはあんまり好きじゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't like tomatoes too much.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この映画はあんまりおもしろくなかったね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This movie wasn't excessively interesting.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 余りに早く着いてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I unfortunately arrived too early.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そのケーキは余りに大きすぎて、食べられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That cake is too big to eat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 余りに寒すぎて、帰ってきてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was too cold, so I turned back.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その計画は余りに非現実的だよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That plan is too unrealistic!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 余りに仕事が多すぎて、手に負えない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have too much work to deal with.

Name: 訳(わけ)だ
Meaning: For that reason, No wonder, As you'd expect, Naturally, Thus, This is why
About: One of the most misunderstood words in Japanese is 訳(わけ). Of the many ways it can be translated, the most common are 'reason', 'cause', 'meaning', or 'conclusion'. Despite this, it may be beneficial to consider it almost identical to an equally versatile English word 'so'. In all of its uses, わけ simply highlights the plain existence/determination of something in the same way that 'so' does in English. This can be seen in its most basic form in わけだ. A combination of わけ and the auxiliary verb だ. わけだ will be used at the end of sentences, and is sometimes preceded by という. This use is often translated as 'for the reason of (A)', 'no wonder its (A)', or 'its (A), as you'd expect'. Realistically though, it just means 'it is so that it's (A)', or 'so it's (A)'. Due to わけ being a noun, it will need to follow the attributive form of whatever word comes before it. As we can see 'so' and わけ have an extremely close pattern of nuances, ranging from 'because', all the way through to simple emphasis (like with 'naturally', and 'as you'd expect'). わけ may also be used in questions, implying that the speaker is trying to determine something that they have heard. わけだね 'so its (A) right?', and わけですか 'so is it that (A)?' are good examples of this.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 事故で電車が遅れたの？だから珍しく遅れて来たというわけだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The train was late due to an accident? So that's why you came in unusually late.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 指の骨が折れていたのですね。だから指を動かしたら痛かったという訳ですね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are saying that my finger was broken? So that's why my finger hurt when I moved it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やっぱり全然練習してないでしょ？どうりで一年たっても下手なわけだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As I expected, you didn't practice at all, did you? No wonder you haven't improved even after a year.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は休日か。だから定休日のわけだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today is a holiday, isn't it? So that's why they are closed today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺と一緒にいたくないわけだね？分かったよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: So you are saying that you don't want to be with me, right? I understand.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩たちは後から来るというわけですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Senpai, so will you be coming later?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 雪が降っていた。寒い訳だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It snowed, so as you'd expect, it's cold.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: また忘れたの？それで先生に叱られた訳だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You forgot again? No wonder you were scolded by the teacher.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夜更かししてばかりいるの？それじゃあ遅刻する訳だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Why do you keep staying up late? No wonder you are always late.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お金を無駄に使っている。貯金がない訳です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You waste your money. No wonder you have no savings.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は医者になりたいから、医学の勉強をする訳だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Since she wants to be a doctor, this is why she is studying in the medical field.
(as you'd expect)

Name: 訳(わけ)ではない
Meaning: It doesn't mean that, It is not the case, It's not like
About: As mentioned in the 訳(わけ)だ grammar point, わけ is a noun that is used for strong determination/conclusion in Japanese, in the same way that 'so' is in English. Naturally, this determination may sometimes be negative, as is the case with わけではない. ではない being the conjugated form of the auxiliary verb だ, the adverbial particle は, and the い-Adjective ない. わけではない may be translated as 'it doesn't mean that (A)', or 'it's not the case that (A)'. Although, 'it is not necessarily so that it's (A)', or 'so it's not (A)' are closer to the actual nuance of わけ. わけではない can be used at the end of any sentence, so long as the word before わけ is in attributive form. As always, では may be replaced by じゃ.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本に住んでいるから日本語を話せるわけではないです。私は日本に来る前に日本語の勉強をしていました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not the case that I am able to speak Japanese because I live in Japan. I studied Japanese before I came.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の家は広いわけではないけど、小さくもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not necessarily that my house is big, but it is not small either.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事が大変なわけではない。忙しいだけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that my job is difficult, it's just busy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 熱のわけではないけど、体がだるい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not necessarily that I have a fever, but my body feels heavy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの監督は有名だけど、映画を監督して有名になったわけじゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That director is famous, but he did not become popular because he directed a movie.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたが悪かったって言っているわけじゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that I am saying that you were in the wrong. (I am not strictly saying that you were in the wrong)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたの事が嫌いというわけではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not necessarily so that I dislike you. (But I sure don't love you)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたの事が嫌いというわけがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I so don't dislike you. (I don't dislike you at all)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「北海道といえば、Ｃさんによれば一年中寒いらしい。」
Ｂ：「夏でも寒いわけではない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'Speaking of Hokkaido, according to C it is cold there all year long.'
B: 'It doesn't mean it is cold even in summer.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「天気予報によると明日は晴れるだろう。」
Ｂ：「雨が降らないわけではない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'The weather forecast calls for clear skies tomorrow.'
B: 'It doesn't mean it won't rain.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「また試合に負けたよ。もう我慢できない！泣いちゃいたい！」
Ｂ：「いつもうまくいくわけではない。失敗はつきものだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'I lost a match again! I can't stand it anymore! I want to cry!'
B: 'It is not the case that things will always turn out well. Failures are an unavoidable part of life.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「あなたはデートを忘れていたわ！私は腹が立っているから話しかけないで！」
Ｂ：「遅くなってしまいましたが、忘れていたわけではありませんよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'You forgot about our date! I am angry, so don't speak to me!'
B: 'I may have been late, but that doesn't mean that I forgot.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「Ｂさんは、来年結婚するつもりということだね。」
Ｂ：「まだ決まったわけではないから、内密にお願いします。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'B, I heard you are going to get married next year.'
B: 'It is not the case that it is set in stone, so please keep it a secret.'

Name: と同時(どうじ)に
Meaning: At the same time as, The instant, The moment, As well as
About: To convey that things are happening at the same time in Japanese, と同時(どうじ)に will often be used. This is a combination of the case marking particle と in its listing particle use, 同時(どうじ), a noun meaning 'the same time', and に, the case marking particle marking a location. と同時(どうじ)に translates as 'at the same time as (A)', 'the instant that (A)', or 'as well as (A)'. In sentences that use this grammar structure, (A) is considered to be the primary event, but any (B) or (C) events are not considered any less important. In the case of nouns and な-Adjectives, である is often omitted. While the literal meaning of と同時(どうじ)に is 'at the same time', this expression is also regularly used when listing multiple roles or functions that someone/thing has. This comes across as 'as well as', but still carries the 'at the same time nuance'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サイレンが鳴ったと同時に、犯人は逃げた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As the siren went off, the criminal ran away.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この機械は便利であると同時に危険である為、気をつけて使用してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This machine is useful, but at the same time, it is very dangerous, so please use it with caution.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その人は博士であると同時に宇宙飛行士でもある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person is a scientist and also an astronaut.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の家は自宅と同時にオフィスでもある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My place is a house, and at the same time it is also my office.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 野菜と同時に肉を鍋に入れてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please throw the vegetables and meat into the pot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カギと同時に携帯をどこかに忘れてきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I lost my keys as well as my phone somewhere.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 財布と同時に免許証もなくしてしまいました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I lost my wallet and my driver's license at the same time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 毎朝日の出と同時に起きる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wake up with the sunrise every day. (at the same time as)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 目覚めると同時に着替えて出かけた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The moment I woke up, I got dressed and went out. (at the same time as)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 録画すると同時にナレーションも入れてほしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want you to record the video and, at the same time, narrate.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 決断力と同時に慎重さも必要だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Decisiveness as well as caution is necessary.

Name: ところだった ①
Meaning: Almost, Nearly, About to, On the verge of
About: As explained in the ところ grammar point, ところ is a noun that is often used to highlight the situation within which a verb is 'about to' happen (when that verb appears in its non-past form). However when followed by だった, it emphasizes that the thing that was 'about to' happen never actually eventuated (or that another more important event happened at that moment). This can be translated as 'to almost (A)', or 'to be on the verge of (A)'. The verb that ところ is paired with may also be seen grouped with the auxiliary verb ない. In this case, it implies that something was 'about not' to happen (but then did).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やばい、大事な書類を捨てるところだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Oh shoot, I was just about to throw away an important document.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毒キノコを食べるところだったが、キノコに詳しい友達が止めてくれた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was about to eat a poisonous mushroom, but a friend that is very knowledgeable about mushrooms stopped me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この電車に間に合ってよかった。もう少しで待ち合わせ時間に間に合わないところだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am so glad that we made this train. I was about to be late for the meet up.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 現金が足りなくて家賃が払えないところだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was about to not be able to pay my rent because I didn't have cash.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう少しで船からおちるところだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I nearly fell off the ship (had I been a little closer to the edge).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ちょうど電車が発車するところだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was right when the train was about to depart.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 危うく遅刻するところだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was on the verge of being late.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう少しで事故が起こるところだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I nearly had an accident.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 好きな声優に会えないところだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I almost didn't meet my favorite voice actress.

Name: だって
Meaning: I heard/was said, Because, But, Even or also, Even if or even though
About: だって is a colloquial combination of the auxiliary verb だ, and the adverbial particle とて in Japanese (a combination of the particles と, and て). It has a wide range of uses, but primarily exclaims that something is the 'premise' for whatever has been said, or will be said next. This 'exclamation' is usually translated as 'I heard', 'cause', 'but', or 'even if'. The meaning that will be conveyed is determined primarily by where だって appears in a sentence. When placed at the beginning of a sentence, だって highlights the speaker's (usually) displeasure about something that has just been said, before following it with an explanation or counterpoint. This だって is quite similar to でも. At the end of a sentence, だって is used to express hearsay, in a similar way to 'I heard that', or 'it was said that', in English. In these cases it will be preceded by なん. なんだって always appears after a noun, or a phrase that has been nominalized (with の or こと).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: え〜 行きたくないよ。だって、俺の元カノも誘ったんでしょう？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Awwww maaaan I don't want to go. It's because you also invited my ex-girlfriend, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: だって、サメとか怖いもん。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's because I'm afraid of things like sharks.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: レムの実家は農家なんだって。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that Rem's family owns a farm.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: キリコは明日から一週間休みなんだって。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hear that Kiriko will be on break for a week starting tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺だって行きたくないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even I don't want to go.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなこと言ったら、誰だって傷つくよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you say something like that, anyone would get hurt.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 全員合格だってよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is said that everyone had passed the exam.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: だって、全然知らないんだもん。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because, I have no idea.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼だって落ち込むこともあるよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even he gets depressed from time to time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「たけしさん、海外旅行だって？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Is it true (what I have heard) that Takeshi is on vacation abroad?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 月にだって行けるかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You can probably even go to the moon.

Name: んだって
Meaning: I heard that, He or She said that
About: When used at the end of sentences, だって often expresses something that has been heard by the speaker. This particular use of だって will always be paired with ん or なん. As だって is a grouping of the auxiliary verb だ, and the adverbial particle って, なんだって primarily expresses the following: なん - Presents an explanation. だ - Determines something to be true. って - An abbreviation of と言(い)って 'is said' or と思(おも)って 'is thought'. In this way, it translates quite similarly to 'it is that (A) was said/thought'. Realistically though, it is used in the same way as 'I heard that (A)', or 'it's thought that (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サクラちゃん来年結婚するんだって。うらやましいね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that Sakura-chan is going to get married next year. I am jealous, aren't you?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タケル君が新しいおもちゃが欲しいんだって。どうしよう？買ってあげる？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that Takeru-kun is wanting a new toy. What should we do? Should we buy it for him?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの博士は凄い事言っているように聞こえるけど、実は言っていること全部適当なんだって。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It sounds like that scientist is saying some amazing stuff, but I heard that everything he says is hot air.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タクミさんはレスラーみたいな体しているけど、好きなスポーツはフィギュアスケートなんだって。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takumi-san has a body like a wrestler, but I heard that his favorite sport is figure skating.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムは、また元カノと付き合っているんだって。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Someone) said that Tom is back with his ex-girlfriend.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は真面目なんだって。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Someone) said that he is pretty serious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: やっと旅行に行けるんだって。お金が貯まったから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (They) said that (they) can finally travel. Because (they) saved up money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まだできていないんだって。あんなに時間があったのに…
Questions.EnglishHTML: (He) said that it is not ready. Even though (he) had all that time to get it done.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 本当は嫌なんだって。口では言えないけど。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Someone) said that (he) doesn't actually like it. Although (he) can't tell you to your face.

Name: 関係(かんけい)がある
Meaning: (Not) involved with, (Not) concerned with, (No) connection with, (No) relationship with, (Not) related to
About: When the noun 関係(かんけい) 'a relation' is paired with がある 'to have', it will be received in a similar way to phrases like 'involved with (A)', 'concerning (A)', or 'in relation to (A)'. 関係(かんけい)がある will often be preceded by the case marking particle に, expressing the location 'where' the connection exists. に itself will always be preceded by a noun or noun-phrase. Alternatively, に can be replaced by other case marking particles such as と or の. Each has a slightly different nuance, but are used quite interchangeably. に関係(かんけい)がある - Relating to (A). と関係(かんけい)がある - Related with (A). の関係(かんけい)がある - Having a relation with (A). Naturally, ある may be replaced by ない, to express that there is 'no relation' between (A) and (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さっき森の方に逃げた人は事件に関係があると思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think the person that ran into the forest earlier is involved in the crime.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この仕事に関係がある資料を全て提出してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please submit all documents concerning this work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの工場は川の汚染と関係があるそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that that factory has something to do with the pollution of the river.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この事件と関係がある人を全員ここに連れてきてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please bring everyone related to this case over here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それとこれはなんの関係があるのだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder what relationship this and that have.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この被害者との関係がある人を集めてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please gather all people that are connected to this victim.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは私に関係がないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That, I have no connection to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 授業に関係がない本はしまってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please put away books that aren't related to class.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この事件に関係がない人は帰ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: People that have no connection to this crime, please go home.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の話と関係がないことを言わないで。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please don't say anything that isn't related to my story.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その問題は私には関係はないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That problem has nothing to do with me. (Has no relation to me)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これと事故の間になんらかの関係があるはずだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There has to be some kind of relation between the accident and this. (has a relationship)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼らはそれぞれあいざわさんと不透明な関係があるように見える。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It seems that they each have some unclear relationship with Mr. Aizawa.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 容疑者と直に関係がある人物が全員呼び出された。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Each person directly related to the suspect was summoned. (has a relationship)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本食に関係がある単語で空欄を埋めてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Fill in the blanks with words that are related to Japanese food. (has a relationship)

Name: に関(かん)して
Meaning: Related to, About, Regarding
About: に関(かん)する and に関(かん)して are two grammar patterns in Japanese that are regularly used to show when (B) is 'about' or 'related to' (A). 関(かん)する itself is a verb meaning 'to relate'. に関(かん)する will be followed directly by a second noun, while に関(かん)して creates a pause in the sentence, before (B) will be explained in the second half of that sentence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は今地盤汚染に関する研究をしています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He does research related to pollution in the Earth's crust.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このアプリの使い方に関する質問はありますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you have any questions concerning how to use this app?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この農薬に関して、知っておくべきことはありますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is there anything I should know relating to this pesticide?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 幼稚園に関しては、全然詳しくないので僕に聞かれても困ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am not knowledgeable in regards to kindergartens, so even if you ask me I won't know.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼が電車の事について話し出すと、永遠に話し続ける。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Once on the topic of trains, he will talk forever. (Casual)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼が電車の事に関して話し出すと、永遠に話し続ける。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Once the topic is related to trains, he will talk forever. (More formal)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ダンスに関する本が机の上にあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are books related to dance on the desk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 過去に関しては、悲しまなくてもいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You don't need to be sad about the past. (related to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 環境に関して、質問はありますか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Do you have any questions related to the environment?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その件に関しては改めてご説明いたします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will provide more details related to that issue at another time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 経済に関しては全然詳しくありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am not very knowledgeable in anything related to economics.

Name: に対(たい)して
Meaning: In contrast to, While, In regard to, Whereas
About: に対(たい)する and に対(たい)して are two grammar patterns in Japanese that are regularly used to show when (B) is 'opposed to' or 'in contrast with' (A). 対(たい)する itself is a verb meaning 'to oppose'. Although this feeling of 'opposition' may be negative, in most circumstances, it just means 'toward' in the sense of targeting something. に対(たい)する will be followed directly by a second noun, while に対(たい)して creates a pause in the sentence, before (B) will be explained in the second half of that sentence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 君に対する気持ちは一生変わらない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My feelings toward you will never change.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は店員に対する態度が悪い人が苦手です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't like people who have a bad attitude towards store employees. (People who target their bad attitude at store employees)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ああいう風に、先輩に対してタメ口を使うのは良くないと思うよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't think it is best to talk to a senpai using casual speech in that manner. (Talking casually toward a senior)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何でいつも私に対してそういう酷いことを言うの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why do you always say mean things like that to me? (With me as the target)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このプロジェクトに関して質問がある方は私に直接電話をしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you have any questions concerning this project, please give me a call directly. (Questions in relation to this project)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はサッカーが好きなのに対して、彼はバドミントンが好き。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In contrast to me liking soccer, he likes badminton. (Opposed to me who likes soccer)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: マサミは難しい本を読んだのに対して、カスミは簡単な本を読んだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Masami read a difficult book, whereas Kasumi read an easy book.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の仕事は楽なのに対して、僕の仕事はものすごく大変。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: His job is carefree, whereas my job is very difficult.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はみんなに対して優しい人なんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is kind towards everyone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本の教育制度に対してどう思う？
Questions.EnglishHTML: What are your thoughts in regards to the Japanese school system?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰に対しても親切な人になりたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to be nice towards anyone and everyone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 父が厳しすぎるのに対して、母は優しすぎる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My father is too strict, in contrast, my mother is too nice.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: はぐらかさないで質問に対して答えてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regarding the question, please answer it, without dodging.

Name: くらい ②
Meaning: To the extent that, So…that, About the only thing that...
About: Often, the noun くらい is used as an adverbial particle. This use of くらい (or ぐらい) expresses the limit of something, in a similar way to ほど. This means that it can be translated as 'about (A)', 'so (A) that (B)', or '(A) to the extent of (B)'. Let's take a look at a few examples. Despite translating in the above ways, we can see that this use of くらい is similar to the standard kanji use 位(くらい), which literally means a 'rank', or 'grade' of something. What this means is that (A) will usually be considered to be at the 'grade' of something that was required in order to cause/allow (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日はもう一生走りたくないくらい走った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today, I ran so much that I don't want to run again in my whole life.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: わたしも叫びたいくらい、怖かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was so scared that I wanted to scream too.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ５連休が必要なぐらい疲れています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am tired to the extent that it is necessary for me to have 5 days off.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺もキヨミさんくらいピアノが弾けるようになりたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to be able to play the piano to about the level of Kiyomi-san.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寝ることしか出来ないくらい、疲れている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am so tired that I can't do anything but sleep.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの仕事は、泣きたいくらいつらかったよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That job was rough to the extent that I wanted to cry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: プロ選手ぐらい上手になりたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to be skilled to the extent that pro athletes are.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 残っているのはやきとりくらいですが。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Yakitori is just about the only thing left...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: みんなを泣かすくらいスパイシーなチリのサラダを作った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I made a chili salad so spicy that it made everyone cry.

Name: は～くらいです
Meaning: About the only, To the extent that
About: は～くらいです is an expression in Japanese used to convey that '(B) is all that exists within (A)'. As with other grammar points that use くらい, this nuance will be shown in the form of an 'extent'. In は～くらいです, both は and くらい are being used as adverbial particles. This structure is often translated as '(B) is about the extent of (A)'. To use this grammar pattern, (A) will come before は, highlighting the situation, place, thing, or person within which a limit exists. The (B) part of the sentence will then describe what that limit is, followed by くらいです (or だ). In order to add extra emphasis, のもの or なもの may follow くらい.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 休日の日に家を出るのは、買い物に行くときくらいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Going out to go shopping is about the only thing I do when I have a day off.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事で忙しいのは、月曜日ぐらいだけです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Monday is about the only time I am busy at work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は基本的になんでも食べられますよ。食べ物で嫌いなのは茹で玉子ぐらいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In general, I can eat anything. Boiled eggs are about the only thing I dislike in regards of food.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の夢は家族を作ることぐらいかな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Starting a family is about the extent of my dreams.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 距離は５キロくらいのものです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The distance is only about 5km.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電車は仕事に行くときに使っているくらいなものです。プライベートでは車しか使いません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Commuting to work is about the only time I use the train. In my personal time, I only use my car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私が得意なのは料理くらいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Cooking is about the only thing I'm any good at. (extent)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の仲間は、犬と猿と雉くらいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A dog, a monkey and a pheasant are about the only friends I have. (extent)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私が苦手なのは、ネギくらいのものです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Green onion is about the only thing that I do not particularly care for. (extent)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の友人は、君と愛犬くらいだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As far as my friends go, it’s basically just you and my pet dog. (extent)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の友人は、君と愛犬ぐらいだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As far as my friends go, it's basically just you and my pet dog. (extent)

Name: さ (Interjection)
Meaning: All right, There we go, Now, You see, Well (I don't know, let me see)
About: さ is a 感動詞(かんどうし) (interjection) in Japanese that has three primary uses. These are as follows: 誘(さそ)い、促(うなが)し - To invite, incite, or draw attention to something. 驚(おどろ)き、当惑(とうわく)し - To express surprise, confusion, or bewilderment. 話(はなし)の流(なが)れを抑(おさ)える - To control or keep in check the flow of a conversation. In this lesson, we will be focusing on the first meaning (to invite or draw attention). In English, this is usually translated as 'there we go', 'ok then', or 'well you see'. さ (or sometimes さあ) will come at the beginning of a sentence, before the point that the speaker would like to highlight is explained.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さーさー、遠慮をせずにどんどん食べてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There we go! Please eat a lot without holding back.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さあ、そろそろ行きますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Okay then, should we go soon?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのさ、昨日は暑さに負けて倒れちゃった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well, you see… I lost to the heat yesterday and passed out. (Yesterday, I passed out due to the heat)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さあ、それはどうでしょう？私に聞いてもわからないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well let me see… I don't know about that. Even if you ask me I wouldn't have a clue.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「さあ、仕事を始めよう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Alright, let's start working!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「さあ、行きましょう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Alright, let's go!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「あの人、誰？」
「さあ…」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Who is that person?'
'Well… '

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「足は（どう）？」
「大丈夫よ。さあ早く…」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'(How is) your leg?'
'It is ok. Now, quickly (keep moving)…'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「さ、早く乗ってください。」
「うん。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Alright, now quickly get on.'
'Yeah.'

Name: さ (Filler)
Meaning: Like, You know, You see, Listen, Uhh
About: さ is a 感動詞(かんどうし) (interjection) in Japanese that has three primary uses. These are as follows: 誘(さそ)い、促(うなが)し - To invite, incite, or draw attention to something. 驚(おどろ)き、当惑(とうわく)し - The express surprise, confusion, or bewilderment. 話(はなし)の流(なが)れを抑(おさ)える - To control or keep in check the flow of a conversation. In this lesson, we will be focusing on the second meaning (to express surprise, confusion, or bewilderment). In English, this is used in a very similar way to 'like', 'you know', 'uhh', and other short phrases that are employed when a speaker is searching for the right thing to say, and is filling the silence. This さ may be used in any position within a sentence, simply to create thinking time. The 'confusion' that this さ expresses is not necessarily a bad thing, and is used by many people to simply express that they have not finished talking yet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのさ、私さあ、この前さあ、お金貸したじゃん？あれさあ、返してくれない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hey, um… I, uhh, lent you, like, money before, right? You know… can you give that back to me?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ね～聞いてよ。彼女がさ、急に別れたいっていって来たんだけどどうすればいいの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Heyyy, listen to this. You know my girlfriend? She suddenly came to me saying that she wants to break up with me, what should I do.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来週箱根に行くんだけどさ…どこか美味しいところ知らない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am going to Hakone next week, soooo… Do you know any good restaurants?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夜中に急に娘から電話が来てさあ...本当にビックリしたよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You know, my daughter suddenly called me in the middle of the night, and… I was really worried.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「今朝さあ、母さんに怒られたよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I got scolded by mom in the morning, you know.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達との会話：「あのさ、俺、彼女ができたんだ！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between friends: 'Listen, I got myself a girlfriend!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「あのさぁ、好きな人とかいるの？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Listen, do you have someone you like?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「内緒だけどさ、彼宝くじに当たったんだよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Between us, you see, he won the lottery.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「私さぁ、明日から５連休なんだ！」
Ｂ：「いいなぁー」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'I have, you see, a 5 day weekend starting from tomorrow.'
B: 'Lucky!'

Name: さ (Casual よ)
Meaning: Casual よ
About: さ is a 感動詞(かんどうし) (interjection) in Japanese that has three primary uses. These are as follows: 誘(さそ)い、促(うなが)し - To invite, incite, or draw attention to something. 驚(おどろ)き、当惑(とうわく)し - To express surprise, confusion, or bewilderment. 話(はなし)の流(なが)れを抑(おさ)える - To control or keep in check the flow of a conversation. In this lesson, we will be focusing on a specific feature of the first meaning (to draw attention). Unlike other types of drawing attention that さ is able to be used for (see this grammar point), this さ will only appear at the end of sentences. Here, さ is almost identical in meaning to that of よ, with a slight added nuance of high confidence in what one is saying.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼氏がもう私のことを信用できないってさ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My boyfriend told me that he can't trust me anymore. (Added confidence gives the nuance of 'can you believe it!')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: インスタで見たんだけど、キヨミの赤ちゃんが明日生まれるんだってさ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I saw it on instagram, but I heard that Kiyomi is going to give birth tomorrow!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなこと心配ないさ!俺に任せとけ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Such a thing is not necessary! Leave it to me! (Trust it to me in advance, so that it is not a problem later)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前さ...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You… (Are you freaking serious)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たかし君も行きたいってさ。どうしよう？彼も招待する？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takashi-kun said he wants to go too. What should we do? Should we invite him too?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなの俺にだってできるさ。分からないけど。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although I am not certain, even I would be able to do something like that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「僕はＮＢＡでやるつもりさ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I intend to play in the NBA.' (emphasis; softer than よ）

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「彼が約束を破ったってさ。」
Ｂ：「そんな人じゃないさ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'I heard that he broke his word.'
B: 'He is not that type of person!' (emphasis; softer than よ）

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「まぁ、なんとかなるさ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Well, somehow I'll get by.' (emphasis; softer than よ）

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「寒い。寒すぎるよ。」
Ｂ：「どうってことないさ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'It's cold. Soo cold.'
B: 'This is nothing.' (emphasis; softer than よ）

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「テレビで台風がやってくるってさ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'They say on tv that a typhoon is coming.' (emphasis; softer than よ）

Name: それぞれ
Meaning: Each, Respectively
About: それぞれ is a noun in Japanese that is used similarly to 'each' in English. Like other nouns that can be used adverbially (ほとんど, 沢山(たくさん), and かなり for example), それぞれ regularly comes before a whole sentence, or before a specific noun preceded by の.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 皆それぞれ食べたいものを頼んでね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Everyone, please (each) order something you want to eat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それぞれ別の行動をした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We each did our own separate things.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 人それぞれの考え方があるから、しょうがないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Each person has different ways of thinking, so there is nothing we can do.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それぞれのチームに分かれてから開始してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please start once you have divided yourselves into each separate team.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それぞれ行きたいところに行きましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's go to each of the places we want to go (respectively).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 生き物はそれぞれ食べるものが違う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Living things each eat different things respectively.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それぞれ好きな運動をした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We each (respectively) did exercises that we like.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これからはそれぞれの道を行くことに決めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We decided that we will each (respectively) go our separate ways from now on.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人それぞれ癖というものがあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Each (respective) person has a habit.

Name: ままに (As Is)
Meaning: As is, While remaining, Left in a state
About: まま, coming from the kanji 儘(まま), which means 'as it is', is a noun in Japanese that is used for describing the 'unchanged state' of something. This expression may be translated as 'while remaining (A)', 'as (A) is', or 'left in the state of (A)'. It can be used after any word in its attributive form. However, when used with verbs, it has a tendency to be used with the た (past) form most frequently. まま often expresses that something should be left alone, or undisturbed. This is generally seen with verbs in the ない form.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: うぁ〜、マジかよ。電気とガスを点けたままだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whaaat. Are you serious? I left my gas and electricity on.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部屋を汚いままにしていたらゴキブリが沢山出てきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: So many cockroaches appeared because I left my room dirty.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いつまでも元気なままでいてね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please always stay healthy, okay?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今のままだと、一生結婚できないと思うよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are the way you are now, I don't think you'll ever be able to marry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 許可を取らないまま駅で撮影をしていたら、警察が来た。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While I was filming at the station without getting a permit, the police were called.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夕食を食べないまま寝たら、お腹が空いて３時ぐらいに起きてしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I slept without eating dinner, I woke up around 3 am from hunger.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: エンジンを点けたままにしておいてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please keep your engine on.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 扇風機を点けたままにして家を出る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I leave my house with my fan turned on. (Often)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これどこに片付ければいいかわからないからこのまんまでいい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don’t know where to put this so is it okay if I just leave it here?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コートを着たままだと少し暑いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I feel a little hot keeping this jacket on.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昨日は窓を開けたまま寝た。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Last night I slept with the windows left open.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 生徒は答えられなくて、黙ったままでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The student couldn't answer and stayed quiet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このまま行くと図書館が見えます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you stay on this course, you will be able to see the library.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ありのままの君が好きだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like you, just as you are.

Name: そこで
Meaning: Accordingly, Now, Therefore, To that end
About: そこで (very rarely seen as 其処(そこ)で) is a combination of そこ 'there', and the case marking particle で. It is often translated as 'to that end', or 'accordingly'. Literally, it just means 'at that place', with で's use as 'with' or 'by' highlighting that something will be done there ('there' often being a situation). This phrase behaves very similarly to 'as such' in English. Usually, a first sentence will highlight what the 'situation' is, before そこで goes on to explain how that situation was or will be resolved. As で implies the 'use' of something, this expression should only highlight actions that are controllable.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は雨の中、傘なしで立っている。そこで、私は車から出て彼に私の傘をあげた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is standing in the rain without an umbrella. As such, I got out of the car and gave him mine.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女と結婚をすることにした。そこで、彼女の親の実家に行って挨拶をすることに決めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have decided to marry my girlfriend. To that end, I have decided to go to her parents' place to talk to them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: うちには泥棒が３回も入っている。そこで、防犯ガラスを買うことにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Our house has been burgled 3 times already. As such, I have decided to buy an anti-theft window.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 信号が赤になったのでブレーキをかけた。そこで、後ろの車に私の車をぶつけられた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because the traffic light turned red, I stepped on the brakes. As such, the car behind me crashed into me. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供が泣き始めた。そこで、子供に飴をあげて落ち着かせた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My kid started to cry. As such, I gave them some candy to calm them down.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は彼女を愛している。そこで、結婚を申し込むことに決めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I love her. Accordingly, I decided to ask her to marry me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この方法ではもう限界だと分かった。そこで、新たな方法を試してみることに決めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I found out there was a limit to this method. Accordingly, we decided to try another one.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は暗記が苦手だ。そこで、暗記のコツを教えてあげることに決めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She is not good at memorizing things. Accordingly, I decided to teach her a trick to memorize things effectively.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この荷物は重い。そこで、仲間を呼んで手伝ってもらうことに決めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This luggage is heavy. Therefore, I decided to get my friends to help.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うちには工具箱がありません。そこでお願いなのですが、ドライバーを貸してもらえませんか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: We don't have a toolbox. Therefore, I have a favor to ask you, could you please lend me your screwdrivers?

Name: しかない
Meaning: Have no choice but, Only, Just
About: しかない is a commonly used expression in Japanese that is partnered with verbs. It is a combination of しか, the adverbial particle, and the い-Adjective ない. This structure may be translated as 'to have no choice but (A)', or 'there is only (A)'. しかない regularly emphasizes the point that nothing apart from (A) is possible. To use しかない, simply attach it directly to the non-past form of whichever verb you would like to highlight as being the 'only' possible action. Unlike だけ, which implies that one particular option was chosen (out of several), しか always insinuates that (A) is the only option, and therefore will sound much stronger than だけ. Also, as only one option exists, it will often be assumed by the listener that some particular circumstances resulted in (A) being all that can be done.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こうなったら警察を呼ぶしかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it's come to this, there is no choice but to call the police.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もう電車が来ないから、車で行くしかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since trains won't be coming anymore, there is no choice but to go by car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この時間帯はピザハット以外どこも開いていないね。こうなったらピザを頼むしかないね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At this hour, nowhere is open other than Pizza Hut. Now that it's come to it, there is no choice but to order some pizza, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今月は休めないから、コンサートに行くのを我慢するしかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't take a day off this month, so I have no choice but to resist going to the concert.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この技で倒れないのなら、必殺技を使うっきゃないな！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I can't defeat them using this move, there is no other choice but to use my special move, is there?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これほど完璧なチャンスは二度とないから、今やるっきゃないでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: An opportunity this perfect will not come around a second time, so I have no other choice but to do it now.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人が多いから、並ぶしかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because there are a lot of people, we have no choice but to line up.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 時が来るのを待つしかないですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You have no choice but to wait for the time to come.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんなにうまくいかないかなあ… もう笑うしかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To think that it would go this poorly... I have no choice but to laugh!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 素直に謝るしかないです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have no choice but to sincerely apologize.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この部屋はゴミだらけなので掃除するしかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This room is full of trash. I have no choice but to clean it.

Name: ～ても構(かま)わない
Meaning: It doesn't matter if, I don't mind
About: ても構(かま)わない is often used to express that something 'doesn't matter', or that the speaker 'doesn't mind'. This structure is a combination of ても (with verbs and い-Adjectives), or でも (with nouns and な-Adjectives) grouped with the negative conjugation of the う - Verb 構(かま)う, which means 'to brace'. Literally, this expression can be thought of as being similar to 'to not be uptight'. However, it is almost always simply used to convey that there is no issue with something. ても構(かま)わない may be used with any type of word that appears in its ても or でも conjugation form.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 君がお金を出すなら、ピザでも寿司でも何を頼んでも構わないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are going to pay, I don't mind whether you order pizza, sushi, or anything else.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運転手さん、遅くても構いませんので、安全運転でお願いします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Chauffeur, I don't care if it's slower, please drive safely.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事はどんなに大変でも構いません、仕事が出来ればうれしいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't care how busy work is, I am happy so long as I can do my job.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アルバイト募集中。未経験者でも構いません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hiring part time workers. It doesn't matter if you are not experienced.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 無視されても構わない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It doesn't matter (even) if I am ignored.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その写真なら、見ても構いません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it is that picture, I don't mind if you look at it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 欲しい人がいればあげても構わない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If someone wants it, I don't mind (even if) giving it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 答えたくなければ、答えなくても構いません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you don't want to answer, it doesn't matter (even) if you don't answer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暇な時はゲームをやっても構わない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It doesn't matter (even) if you play games when you have free time.

Name: ～ても～なくても
Meaning: Whether ~ or not
About: Like かどうか, another way that Japanese conveys 'whether or not' is through the use of ～ても～なくても. This grammar structure literally means 'even if (A), even if not (A)', to show that whatever the result is will not change, regardless of (A). ～ても～なくても is used primarily with verbs, and will always have the same verb appearing both before ても and なくても.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人がいてもいなくても、仕事の量は変わらないから、首にしてもいいと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether or not he is here doesn't change the workload, so I think it would be good if we fired him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は運動しても運動しなくても痩せられないから、もう運動はしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether or not I exercise, I can't lose weight, so I will not exercise anymore.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここの居酒屋ではビールを頼んでも頼まなくても、ビールを持ってくる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether you order beer or not, they will bring you one at this izakaya.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 釣れても釣れなくても、釣りは楽しいらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard fishing is fun whether you are able to catch any fish or not.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 言っても言わなくても、彼はちゃんと仕事ができるよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether you tell him or not, he will get the job done.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お金を持っていても持っていなくても、幸せになることは可能です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You can be happy whether you have money or not.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会えても会えなくても、１８時には解散して帰りましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's finish up and go home by 6pm, whether we can meet (them) or not.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 助手がいてもいなくても、やることはたいして変わらない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether I have an assistant or not, there won't be much difference in what I do.

Name: んじゃない
Meaning: Don't, Mustn't, Shouldn't have
About: んじゃない is a slightly slang grammar pattern used with verbs to prohibit or request that something not be done. It will usually just be translated as 'don't do (A)', or 'you mustn't (A)'. んじゃない is almost always used from a higher position toward someone of a lower status. It may be used when the speaker is angry, but not always. んじゃない is a combination of the case-marking particle の, and the abbreviated form of ではない, じゃない. It will connect to the dictionary form of verbs. Despite being slang, the slightly more formal version んじゃありません can also be seen occasionally. This variation is common when the speaker wants to forbid something, but not sound angry, such as when an adult is talking to a child. The more literal translation of Verb + んじゃない is just 'it's not (verb)'. This sounds a bit strange in English, but might be similar to something like 'you're not (verb)', where a person is directly telling another what they shouldn't do. It is also common to see the abbreviated ている form, てん, before じゃない.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 親に向かってそんなこと言うんじゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't say something like that directed at your parents!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこら辺のキノコを食べるんじゃない！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't eat the mushrooms from around there!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は混んでるからパパから離れるんじゃないぞ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's crowded today, so don't get separated from your dad!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勝手にお友達のものを取るんじゃありません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You shouldn't just freely take your friend's things.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 乳児にハチミツをあげるんじゃありません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't give honey to infants.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いつまでもケラケラしながら話してんじゃない！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't keep laughing while you're talking!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一日中ダラダラしてんじゃない！いい加減、仕事でも探してこい！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't laze around all day! Get your act together and find a job!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな安い車を買うんじゃなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I shouldn't have bought a cheap car like this.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんな怪しい話に乗るんじゃなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I shouldn't have gotten swept up in such a suspicious story.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 本当は彼も来たかったんじゃない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Really though, didn't he want to come too?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕をバカにするんじゃない！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Don't make a fool of me!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生：「カンニングをするんじゃない！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Teacher: 'Don't cheat!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嘘をつくんじゃない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You shouldn't lie.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなた、仕事をサボるんじゃありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Hey, don't skip work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まだ子供ですよ。門限を破るんじゃありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You're still a kid. Don't break curfew!

Name: 訳(わけ)がない
Meaning: There is no way, There is no reason, It is impossible, Cannot be
About: One of the strongest ways to use the noun わけ in Japanese, is in the expression わけがない. This is regularly translated as 'there is no way that (A)', or 'it is impossible that (A)'. However, as mentioned in other わけ lessons, わけ is used very similarly to 'so' in English, so may also be thought of as 'it is SO not (A)', with 'so' being used for emphasis. In this structure, わけ is combined with the case marking particle が, and the い-Adjective ない. わけがない may be used with verbs, or adjectives in their attributive form.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このステーキ２キロもあるの？！こんなの一人で食べれるわけがない！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This steak weighs 2kg?! I SO can't eat something like this alone!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: キムラシェフが作ったパスタだよ、不味い訳がないじゃん！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This pasta is made by Chef Kimura, there is no way this would taste bad!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このアパートは線路の隣にあるから静かなわけがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This apartment is next to the train track, so there is no way it is quiet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はいつも遊んでいるが、暇なわけではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is always going out, but it is not necessarily so that he has a lot of free time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はいつも仕事をしているから、暇なわけがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since he is always working, he SO does not have any free time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼が嘘をつくわけがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no way he would lie.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あんな大ニュース、知らないわけがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no way not to know this. It is such big news!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本人ならそんなことを言うわけがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no way that a Japanese person would say that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あれだけ着込んだら寒いわけがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no reason why you would feel cold, wearing all those extra clothes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんなやり方でうまくいくわけがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: With the way you're doing it, it is impossible for it to go well.

Name: とすると
Meaning: If it were the case that, Assuming that...
About: When partnered with several of the assumption based expressions that are used in Japanese, the case marking particle と may be used to show a hypothesis about a certain result. This is one of the result highlighting uses of と. Structures that may be seen are as follows: (A) としたら (B) - When (A) is the result, (B). (A) とすれば (B) - If the result is (A), (B). (A) とすると (B) - A result of (A) will be (B). Although these nuances are slightly different, realistically they are used in almost exactly the same way, to express a possible (undetermined) result. This can be translated to 'assuming that (A)', or 'if it were the case that (A)'. To use these expressions, simply attach と and your chosen variation of したら to the end of any verb/い-Adjective, or noun/な-Adjective followed by だ.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来週出かけるとしたらどこに行きたい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If we were to go out next week, where would you want to go?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 歯が痛いとすれば、虫歯かもしれません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If your tooth hurts, you might have a cavity.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この壁が真っ直ぐだとすると、こっちの壁は斜めっていうこと？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Assuming that this wall here is straight, does that mean that this one here is slanted?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 通勤手段が車だとしたら、交通費は出ません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Assuming that your mode of transportation is your car, transportation will not be compensated.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 付き合うとしたら、田中さんと山田さんどっちがいい？
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you were to date Tanaka or Yamada, who would you choose?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 無料だとすれば、人が大勢来る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If we suppose it was free, lots of people would come.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 留学に行くとすると、論文が必要。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Assuming that you study abroad, an essay is necessary.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 買い物に行かないとしたら、晩御飯はどうする？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Assuming that I don't go shopping, what will be done about dinner?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もし会えるとしたら、明日か明後日だね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Assuming that we can meet, it will be either tomorrow or the day after.

Name: として
Meaning: As (i.e. in the role of), For
About: When the case marking particle と is used to highlight a result, it regularly translates to 'as' in English. This nuance of 'as' simply assumes that (A) is a plain or unchanging fact from which something (usually an opinion or evaluation) is based. Combining this nuance of と with して (the conjugation form of する), として will present (A) as the base point from which (B) can be determined. Despite being a combination of several individual parts, として is often considered to be a 副助詞(ふくじょし) (adverbial particle) by itself, meaning that it will most often be seen connected directly to nouns. As として works in the same way as a 副助詞(ふくじょし), it may be connected directly to a second noun to express that (B) is something functioning as (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ミキは友達としては最高だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a friend, Miki is awesome.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このゲーム機はＤＶＤプレイヤーとしても使えます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You can use this game console as a DVD player.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 動物を傷つける奴は人間として失格だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: People who hurt animals are a failure as humans.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは会社としての目標です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is the goal as a company.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカさんは友達としてはいい人なんだけど、先輩としてはよくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san is a nice person as a friend, but not as a senpai.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私たちは先生としての彼を尊敬します。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We look up to him as our teacher.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 妻としての役割をよく果たしてくれている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She does well as a wife.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 挨拶は礼儀として必要です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As a courtesy, greetings are important.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ジョチはチンギス・カンの長男として生まれた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Jochi has been born as the first son of Genghis Khan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の嫁さんは母として、そして妻として、本当にいい人だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As both a mother and as a wife, my wife is really a great person.

Name: にしては
Meaning: (Even) considering, (Even) for
About: Like として, にして highlights an aspect of something from which another thing happens. The primary difference being that と implies that (B) results from (A), while に implies that (B) happens/exists at the same time as (A). This reflects the case marking particle に's use as a location. The adverbial particle は presents the entire (A) phrase as something that will be compared. にしては is regularly translated as 'considering (A), (B)', or 'even for (A), (B)', and may be used with both verbs and nouns. Like として, にして is often considered as a stand-alone adverbial particle, despite stemming from several parts. Despite the 'considering (A), (B)' translation, にしては is closer in meaning to 'while (A), (B)'. This expresses that (A) and (B) share a simultaneous relation, but also that (B) is not necessarily a result of (A) at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は毎日漢字の勉強をしているにしては全然漢字を読めない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For someone that studies kanji every day, he can't read it at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 始めたばかりにしては結構じょうずだね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Considering you have just started, you are considerably good.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田舎にしてはコンビニがいっぱいあるね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Considering that this is the countryside, there are many convenience stores.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は俳優にしてはあまりイケメンじゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Considering he is an actor, he is not very attractive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 中卒にしては頭がいいけど、大卒の同級生と比べるとそうでもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Considering that he is a middle school graduate, he is smart, but compared to a college graduate of the same age he is not that smart.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新人にしてはよく働くけど、他と比べるとあまり働いていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For a new worker he works a lot, but compared to others, he doesn't work that much.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供にしては静かな方だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Considering (she) is a child, (she) is a quiet one.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 力士にしては結構細いですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Considering he is a sumo wrestler, he is quite thin.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 猫にしては大きすぎませんか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Even) for a cat, isn't it too big?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うどんにしては随分細い麺だな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Considering it's udon, these noodles are quite thin.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昔話にしては、随分現実的な話ですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Even) considering it is an old folk tale, it is quite a realistic story.

Name: にしても
Meaning: Even though, Even if, Even when, Also
About: In the same way that にしては highlights a point to be considered about (A), or simply 'while (A)', the replacement of は with the adverbial particle も will put further emphasis on (B) being a surprising or unexpected thing that accompanies (A). This continues to reflect the case marking particle に's use as a location. にしても may be translated as 'even considering (A), (B)', or 'even while (A), (B)', and may be used with any word in its plain form. にして by itself is often considered as a stand-alone adverbial particle, despite stemming from several parts. にしても is very regularly used with Japanese's equivalent of WH-words, like どこ, どの, だれ, なに, etc. In these cases, it highlights that 'even considering (A) is undetermined (in location, number, amount, etc), (B)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パーティーに行くにしても、私はシャイだから一人で飲むことになる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if I did go to a party, I am shy so I'd just end up drinking alone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冗談にしても、言っていいことと言ってはいけないことがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if it's a joke, there are things that are fine to say and things that you can't say.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事で忙しいにしても、連絡はしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if you are busy with work, please at least contact me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今は怠惰な私にしても、元々こうだったわけではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though I'm being lazy now, this isn't what I was like originally.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ハイキングをするときは、どこに行くにしてもベルを持って行った方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter where you go hiking, you should take a bell with you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もし近所のルールを守っていない人を見つけたら、誰に注意するにしても注意をしなければいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In the case that you see someone not following the rules of the neighborhood, even if you're warning someone you don't know, you need to warn them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このプロジェクトが難しいとしても、クライアントのためにやらないといけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if this project is hard, we have to do it for the client. (Even though it is hard, we must do it for the client)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このプロジェクトが難しいにしても、締め切りまでには終わらせないといけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if this project is hard, we must finish it by the deadline. (Even if we go off that fact that it is hard, it must be finished by the deadline)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テスラモデルＳにしても、この値段は高すぎる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if it is a Tesla Model S, this price is too expensive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ジュースがいっぱいの樽を頼むにしても、まだ足りないと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if we order a barrel full of juice, I still think it won't be enough.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 風邪にしても、楽しい英語の勉強はできるはずだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if I were to have a cold, I would surely be able to study English, which is fun.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 言うにしても言い方というものがあるでしょ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if you (decide to) say something, there is still something called manner of speech.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 分からないにしても、少しくらいは調べてくれてもいいじゃないか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if you don't know, you can do a bit of research, right?

Name: と言(い)うのは事実(じじつ)だ
Meaning: It is a fact that ~, There is no doubt that
About: ～というのは事実(じじつ)だ is a phrase used to strongly express that (A) is something that is 'true', 'a fact', or has 'no doubt'. というのは may be used after almost any phrase, before the noun 事実(じじつ) 'truth', paired with the auxiliary verb だ (or です) will determine that phrase to be a fact. The literal translation というのは事実(じじつ)だ is 'that which is (A) is true', as (A) is just a nominalized phrase. It is also quite common to see this expression with という omitted, the only difference being that it sounds slightly weaker.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この人が私の母親を殺したというのは事実だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is a fact that this person killed my mother.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女が弁護士だというのは事実だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is a fact that she is a lawyer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 赤信号を無視したのは事実だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is true that I ignored the red light.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女と仲直りしたのは事実だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is a fact that I worked it out with my girlfriend.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼が俳優だというのは事実だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is a fact that he is an actor.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女が二十歳だというのは事実だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is a fact that she is 20 years old.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 地球が丸いというのは事実だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is a fact that the earth is round.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼に前科があるというのは事実だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is a fact that he has a criminal history.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 父が病気だというのは事実です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is a fact that my dad is ill.

Name: から言(い)うと
Meaning: Speaking in terms of, From the point of view of
About: からいうと (appearing with or without kanji) is a phrase in Japanese that is used to express a particular viewpoint or standpoint from which some type of evaluation, conclusion, or opinion can be drawn. The と that appears here is one of the assumption uses of this particle, meaning that から言(い)えば may also be used. からいうと will always follow a noun (or noun phrase), before the (B) part of that same sentence will describe some kind of evaluation/opinion/etc. This structure closely reflects phrases like 'speaking in terms of (A), (B)', or 'what can be drawn from (A) is that (B)'. Occasonally, the use of particles such as と or ば may be skipped entirely, with から言(い)って being used instead.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の経験から言うと、このやり方が一番効率がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Speaking from my experience, this way of doing it is the most efficient.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の立場から言えば、彼は絶対いつか成功する。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Speaking from my position, he will make it big one day.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この結果から言って、この計画はあまりよくありませんでした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Speaking from these results, this plan was not that great.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タクミから言うと、後輩のタケシ君は次の試合で勝てそうなの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Speaking as Takumi, do you think your kouhai, Takeshi-kun can win in the next competition? (Unnatural)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タクミの立場からいうと後輩のタケシ君は次の試合で勝てそうなの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takumi, speaking from your position, do you think your kouhai, Takeshi-kun is going to win at the next competition? (Natural)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サトミの視点からいうと、あの人たちは採用しない方がいいという事ですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Satomi, from your point of view, are you saying that we should not recruit those people? (Natural)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家のレイアウトから言うと、この家は３０年前に建てられた家だと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Speaking from the layout of this house, I think it was built 30 years ago. (Not incorrect, but a little unnatural)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 法律から言うと、それは違反です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Speaking in terms of the law, that is a crime.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 結論から言うと、失敗です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Speaking in terms of results, it is a failure.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 値段から言うと、このコーヒーは高すぎるよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Speaking in terms of price, this coffee is too expensive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 物価から言うと、この地域は住みやすいですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Speaking in terms of prices in general, this region is easy to live in.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 景色から言うと、あの山は最高だよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Speaking in terms of scenery, that mountain is the best.

Name: にとって
Meaning: To, For, Concerning
About: にとって (or に取(と)って when appearing as kanji) is a structure in Japanese that is used to convey opinions, or just generally to discuss something from a particular perspective. This expression regularly appears after names/pronouns, but may also be used with regular nouns. にとって is often translated as 'to (A)', 'for (A)', or 'concerning (A)'. However, it is used in almost exactly the same way as から見(み)て 'from the perspective of (A)'. To use にとって, simply attach it to the end of a noun (or noun phrase) that you would like to express a certain viewpoint, judgment, or opinion from.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タケミにとって一番大切な人は誰ですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takemi, who is the most important person to you?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は私にとって親みたいな存在です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is like a parent to me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この石はタケル君にとって、宝物です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To Takeru, this rock is a treasure.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私にとって一番大事な友達はあなたです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are the most important friend to me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私にとってあの会社は人を働かせすぎだと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To me, I think that company makes people work too much.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは会社に取ってもいいアイデアですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That is also a great idea for the company.
