Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君に取って友達を作ることは簡単だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is easy for you to make friends.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰に取っても親は大切です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Parents are important for everyone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君に取っては簡単でも、僕には難しいよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It might be easy for you but it's difficult for me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お父さんに取って、仕事は大切だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Your father's job is important to him.

Name: 事(こと)から
Meaning: From the fact that
About: In order to come to a logical conclusion about something in Japanese, sometimes strong expressions like ことから will be used. This is a combination of the noun こと, and the case marking particle から. ことから literally means 'from that which is (A), (B)', but is generally simply translated as 'from the fact that (A), (B)'. ことから may be connected to the end of any phrase, so long as the word before it is in its attributive form.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな早い時間に妻が寝ていることから、今日は色々と大変だったと気づいた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the fact that my wife is sleeping at such an early time, I noticed that she was busy with many things today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家の家具が全部新しいことから、彼はここに引っ越してきたばかりだと分かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the fact that all his furniture is new, I realized that he has just moved here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供が静かなことから、何か悪いことをしていると分かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the fact that my kids were quiet, I knew that they were doing something bad.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これらのことからイベントを中止することに決めました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From these facts, we have decided to cancel the event.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コーヒーが冷たいことから、コーヒーが淹れられたのは結構前だと分かる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the fact that the coffee is cold, you can tell that it was poured quite a while ago.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コーヒーが冷たいことだから、コーヒーが淹れられたのは結構前だと分かる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since coffee is a cold thing, you can tell that it was poured quite a while ago. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 以上の事から、この結論に至りました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From (the facts) above, we arrived at this conclusion.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「お父さん」と呼ばれている事から、子供がいるのだと分かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the fact that he is being called 'dad', I discerned that he has children.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 指輪をしている事から、既婚者だと分かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I realized that he is married from the fact that he is wearing a ring.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 野球がとても上手な事から、将来は有名になりそうだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the fact that he is really good at baseball, it seems like he will be famous one day.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田代島は猫が多い事から、猫の島と呼ばれるようになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the fact that there are many cats in Tashirojima, it came to be called 'Cat Island'.

Name: と言(い)うより
Meaning: ...is more of a... than a..., Rather than saying that...
About: When combining the quotation use of the case marking particle と with the う - Verb 言(い)う 'to say', and the case marking particle より 'comparing', というより presents a phrase that is being compared through further evaluation/reconsideration. This may be thought of as similar to 'rather than saying (A), (B)' in English.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は仕事をしているというより、仕事をさせられている感じがする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Rather than saying that he is working, it seems like he is being made to work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本の天井が低いというより、あなたの身長が高いだけだと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Rather than Japanese ceilings being low, I think you are just tall.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 僕は暇だというより、なにをすればいいか分からないだけだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Rather than having nothing to do, I just don't know what I should be doing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここは公園というより、小さい広場みたいな物だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Rather than calling this a park, it is something more like a small field. (だ used at the end rather than following 'park', as 'field' is the actual state that the speaker considers true)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: マサミさんは綺麗というより、かわいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Masami is more cute than beautiful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その話がつまらないというより、興味がないだけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that the story is boring, it's just more that I have no interest in it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は暖かいと言うより暑い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is hot rather than warm today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人はかわいいと言うより綺麗。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person is beautiful rather than cute.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は聡明と言うよりずる賢い人です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Rather than saying that he is wise, he is cunning.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は技術者と言うより芸術家だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is more of an artist than an engineer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは悲しさと言うより後悔に近い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Rather than saying that this is sorrow, it is closer to regret.

Name: はもちろん
Meaning: Not only but also, Let alone, Not to mention, Of course
About: はもちろん, or occasionally は勿論(もちろん), is a phrase in Japanese that presents (A) as being something obvious, while (B) should still be considered/mentioned. In this expression, the adverbial particle は presents (A) as being a stand-alone topic, before the adverb もちろん 'naturally' emphasizes that (A) is what it is. After this, the (B) part of the sentence will describe some other factor that is worth mentioning. はもちろん will be used directly after noun (A), before the sentence will go on to discuss noun (B). This construction can be translated as 'not only (A), but (B)', 'not to mention (A), (B)', and other similar English expressions. In many cases, despite (A) being the obvious factor, (B) is being highlighted as sharing similar qualities to (A). This means that in はもちろん sentences, も will almost always be seen after (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パソコンのことはもちろん、電化製品の事ならなんでも聞いてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please ask me anything, not only about computers but also other electronics.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 数学はもちろん、学校の科目を全て一人で教えることができる人を探している。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We are looking for someone not only who can teach math, but every subject in this school by themselves.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は日本語はもちろん、韓国語も話すことができます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not only can she speak Japanese, but she can also speak Korean.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この作家の本はもちろん、歌もうまいから人気がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This author is popular, not only because of his book, but also because he is a good singer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 平日はもちろん、土日も働いている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I work not only on weekdays, but also weekends.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここのそば屋はそばはもちろん、カレーも美味しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This soba restaurant not only has delicious soba, but also delicious curry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は、英語はもちろん、日本語も話せる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is not only able to speak in English, but also in Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 父は、スマホはもちろん、ガラケーも持っていません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not only a smartphone, dad doesn't even have a flip-phone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強はもちろん、運動もできるのだからすごい人だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is an amazing person because he is not only good in academics, but also in sports.

Name: を始(はじ)め
Meaning: Not only...but also..., Starting with
About: When presenting a topic in Japanese as a 'starting point', を始(はじ)め will often be used to show any logic (or planned) progressions from that point. This is often translated as 'not only (A), but (B)', or 'starting with (A), (B)'. To use を始(はじ)め, one noun will be highlighted as the starting point, before another (or several others) will appear in part (B) of the sentence. Due to sentences featuring をはじめ placing emphasis on (A) as a starting point, additional expressions such as として (or とする) will sometimes be paired with it. These structures function to further emphasize (A), and are similar to 'with (A) as the starting point, (B)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この会社は車を始め、ロケットなども作っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not only does this company make cars, but it also makes rockets.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の近所には、公園をはじめ、博物館など、プラネタリウムがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not only is there a park in my neighborhood, but also a museum, and a planetarium.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ストリートファッションはアメリカを始めとして、世界中に進出していく。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: With America as the starting point, street fashion spread all over the world.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この商品には卵をはじめとする多くのアレルゲンが含まれている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Starting with eggs, there are many allergens in this product. (Eggs being the primary allergen)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スーツを始め、シャツや靴も新しくした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Starting with a suit, I also upgraded my shirts and shoes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説を始め、本なら何でも読みます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Starting with short novels, I read all kinds of books.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 犬を始め、様々な動物を飼うようになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Starting with dogs, I have come to raise various animals.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 東京を始め、国内観光ツアーに行きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am going on a countrywide tour starting in Tokyo.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ヨーロッパを始め、世界中を旅行してみたいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Starting in Europe, I want to travel the world.

Name: ～て初(はじ)めて
Meaning: For the first time, Not until, Only after, Only when, Only because
About: て初(はじ)めて is an expression in Japanese that highlights one verb as being the catalyst for some particular result/state. Verb て初(はじ)めて literally means 'with (A) done, for the first time (B)'. Often, this translates similarly to 'only after I (A) did I (B)', or 'not until (A) did I (B)'. In this structure, it should be noted that the (A) verb is not necessarily being done for the first time ever, just that this time resulted in the speaker's first experience of (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生になって初めて、先生の大変さが分かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It was only upon becoming a teacher, that I understood how hard it is to be one.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 好きなバンドのコンサートに行って初めて、歌手の人が男の人だと気づいた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It wasn't until I went to a concert of my favorite band that I realized the singer was a man.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 駅にある時刻表を見て初めて、土日には電車が来ないことを知った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I didn't know that trains don't come during the weekends, until I saw the train schedule.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カレンダーを見て始めて今日は休日だってことを知った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Commencing with checking the calendar, I noticed that today is a holiday.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カレンダーを見て初めて今日が休日だってことを知った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Only after checking the calendar did I notice that it is a holiday today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 失って初めて、その価値が分かりました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only after I lost it, did I understand its value.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: やってみて初めて、難しさを痛感しました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only after I tried it, did I fully realize the degree of difficulty.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 話を聞いてみて初めて、君の苦労を知った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only after I heard your story, did I understand what you had been through.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テレビを見て初めて、地震があったことを知った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It wasn't until I saw what was on TV, that I became aware of the fact that an earthquake had occured.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 指摘されて初めて、寝癖がついていることに気づいた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only after it was pointed out, did I notice that I had bed hair.

Name: さえ
Meaning: Even
About: さえ is an adverbial particle in Japanese that is used to place emphasis on something existing in certain state. It is often translated as 'even'. さえ has three primary meanings, which are as follows: Analogical Reasoning: 類推(るいすい) - Analogy, (A) is an outstanding example of something. Limit: 限定(げんてい) - Limit, (A) is all that is needed for something. Addition: 添加(てんか) - (A) compounds something that is pre-existing. さえ is regularly paired with other particles and is often followed by verbs in negative form, with the overall meaning usually being determined by what part (B) of the sentence is conveying. Let's look at a few examples. In each of these cases, we can see how さえ is showing that (A) is an extreme example of something.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 上級者の彼でさえ出来ないのに、あなたが出来るわけがないでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even someone in the advanced class level can't do it, there is no way you can do it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は親にさえ知らせずに彼氏と結婚をした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She got married to her boyfriend, without even telling her parents.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はストレスのせいで、晩飯を食べることさえ出来なくなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to him being stressed, he couldn't even eat dinner.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカ君は酷くない？彼女を傷つけたのに、謝りさえしなかったらしいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't you think Tanaka-kun is a jerk? He hurt his girlfriend, but I heard he didn't even apologize.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなの放っておいてさえいたら、すぐ直るよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if you leave it as it is, it will get well quickly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このレベルはプロでさえ難しいというのに、よくできたね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am impressed you were able to do this, let alone that it is difficult even for professionals.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムがこんなに漢字を知っているのは凄いと思うよ。日本人でさえ漢字は難しいのに。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tom, I think it is impressive that you know this many kanji. Not to mention that it is difficult even for Japanese people.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 富士山の頂上は夏でさえ寒い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is cold on the summit of Mt. Fuji even in summer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんな初歩的なことは、子供でさえ知っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even children know things that basic.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小さい戦いさえ、私はしたことがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I've never even been in a small fight.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのことについてさえ知っているんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I even know about that thing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 家族さえも応援してくれないんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even my family doesn't support me.

Name: さえ～ば
Meaning: If only…then, As long as..., Provided..., Only thing ... needs for ... is ...
About: As a set expression, さえ～ば is a combination of the adverbial particle さえ, and the conjunction particle ば. It is used to highlight assumption, and presents (A) as a extreme limitation that is required to achieve (B), hypothetically. This structure may be translated as 'if only (A), then (B)', 'the only thing needed for (B) is (A)', or 'as long as (A), (B)'. さえ may be grouped with any word, but will require the conjunctive form, or て form before it when grouped with verbs. It also regularly appears after other particles, forming a dual-particle meaning. This use of さえ is an example of limit, with (A) being a hypothetical limit presented by the ば particle. It is also possible to see さえ with other hypothetical indicators (such as たら), but is quite rare in modern Japanese, as さえ～ば is considered a set pattern. This limitation is also sometimes referred to as a 'stipulation', or 'condition'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この薬を毎日飲みさえすれば、すぐに治りますよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As long as you drink this medicine every day, it will heal quickly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もっと若い頃からお金を貯めてさえいれば、今頃デカい家を買えてたかも。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If only I had saved up money since I was young, by now, I would have been able to buy a big house.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの背が高い人さえ横にずれてくれれば、ちゃんと見えるのにな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If only that tall person moved to the side, (then) I would be able to see.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカさんは若くさえあれば、あんな人でも雇う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san will hire anyone, so long as they are young.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家の前の道さえ広ければＳＵＶが買えたのに。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I would have been able to buy an SUV, if only the street in front of my house was bigger.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 僕は静かでさえあればどこでも寝れます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As long as it is quiet, I can sleep anywhere.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: バンドメンバー募集中。ギターさえ弾けたら誰でもオッケーです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Looking for a new band member. Anyone is okay, so long as you can play the guitar.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本で英語さえ話せたら、どこでも働けます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As long as you can speak English in Japan, you can work anywhere.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 妹は暇さえあれば、運動する。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As long as my little sister has free time, she will exercise.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は自分さえ良ければ、いいと思っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He thinks that as long as it is good for him, it is good (for everyone). (only if)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 天気さえ良ければテニスできるのに…
Questions.EnglishHTML: If only the weather was good, then I would be able to play tennis, but...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 機会さえあれば、会えるのに…
Questions.EnglishHTML: If only there was a chance, then I would meet him...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君さえいれば、他には何もいらない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't need anything else, as long as I have you. (if only you exist)

Name: ～たものだ
Meaning: Used to
About: As mentioned the ものだ lesson, the combination of the noun 物(もの) 'thing', with the auxiliary verb だ forms a strong determination about whatever comes before it as being 'the way it is'. As an extension of this nuance, ものだ can be paired with verbs in the past tense, creating a phrase similar to 'I used to (A) in the past'. However, the literal meaning is closer to '(A) was the way it used to be'. Due to ものだ being a strong determination of something's existence/truth, this expression quite often carries the nuance that the speaker is nostalgic about (A), reminiscing about (A), or being introspective about (A). This means that it will not sound natural when describing things that are seemingly inconsequential, or have no meaningful significance. When highlighting things in the past that are not particularly important, たことがある will be used instead.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供の頃はよく先生に怒られたものだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I used to get yelled at by the teacher often when I was still a kid.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昔はよく親父と釣りに行ったものだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I often used to go fishing with my father in the past.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 若い頃は色々と苦労したものだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I was young, I used to suffer a lot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 小学生の頃は毎日学校に行ったものだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I used to go to school everyday when I was an elementary student. (Unnatural, as this is a normal event)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昔は毎日のように親父とけんかをしたものだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In the past I fought with my father everyday. (Natural, as this is a meaningful event)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 多分子供の頃に食べたことがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I may have eaten this when I was a kid. (Unimportant)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供の頃はよく、神社で遊んだ事がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I was a kid, I played at the shrine a lot. (Potentially important, but not in this speaker's opinion)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 若い頃は、いろんな苦労をしたものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I used to have lots of hardships when I was young.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供の頃はよく海に泳ぎに行ったものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I used to go swimming in the ocean a lot when I was a child.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昔はよく、車を運転して遠くに出かけたものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A long time ago, I often used to go out and take long drives.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供の頃は授業中、よく居眠りをしたものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When I was a child, I used to nod off a lot in the middle of class.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私が子どもの頃、よく父に映画を見に連れていってもらったものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Dad used to take me to the movies when I was a child.

Name: さて
Meaning: Well, Well then
About: Acting as a conjunction, さて is a word used when one wants to change the topic of conversation, or is ready to move on to a new point. Usually it is translated as 'well', or 'well then'. さて will appear at the beginning of a sentence, before the speaker highlights what the new topic is.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さて、そろそろ出ますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well then, let's head off soon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さて、とりあえず乾杯しましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well, first things first, let's have a toast.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 扨、この問題の答えが分かる人はいますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Now, is there anyone here that knows the answer to this question.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 偖、その荷物をこの箱の上においてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Now, please place that luggage on top of this box.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: さて、順番に並べましたか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Well then, have you lined up in order?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: さて、出発してもいいでしょうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Well then, may I take off?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: さて、行きましょうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Well then, shall we go?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: さて、準備はできましたか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Well then, are you ready?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: さて、次のテーマは何にしますか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Well then, what would you like for the next theme?

Name: むしろ
Meaning: Rather, Instead, Over
About: When a speaker is making a determination about something in Japanese, the adverb むしろ is often used to express a more accurate depiction of what has already been said. This is regularly translated as 'rather', or 'instead'. むしろ will mostly appear at the beginning of new sentences, or the beginning of a second clause within a sentence, before information about (A) will be clarified. As むしろ seeks to give a more accurate description about something, it will often be paired with grammar patterns such as より, to show where the comparison is being made.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何でそっちが怒ってるの？むしろこっちが怒りたいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why are you mad? I want to be the one that is mad instead. (It would be preferable if I was mad, because you're the one that is wrong)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: むしろ、安い方を買った方がいいとおもう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Buying a cheaper one would be better instead.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車をリースするより、むしろ中古の車を買った方が安く済む。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Instead of leasing a car, it would be cheaper if you bought a used one.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺はＭＭＯよりむしろシングルプレイヤーのゲームの方が好きだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Rather than MMOs, I like single player games more.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: むしろ、そっちに謝ってほしいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Preferably, I want you to apologize. (Rather than me, it would be better if you apologized)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: むしろ、先生に聞いてみた方がいいんじゃない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Preferably, wouldn't it be better to ask the teacher? (The teacher will give a much more preferable answer than me)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼よりも寧ろあなたに来てほしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'd rather you come than him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕はコーヒーより寧ろ紅茶が飲みたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to drink tea rather than the coffee.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日より寧ろ今日行きたいんですが、駄目ですか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to go today rather than tomorrow. Is that OK?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 韓国に行くより寧ろ日本に行きたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Rather than going to Korea, I'd go to Japan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 事態は寧ろ好転してきたように思える。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Rather, I think that the situation is changing for the better.

Name: つまり
Meaning: In short, To sum up, In other words
About: つまり (or 詰(つ)まり) is a word in Japanese that is often used as an adverb. It takes a previous statement (said either by the speaker or by someone else) and summarizes it. This translates as 'in short', 'in other words', and similar expressions in English.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ハマサキさんはまた何も言わずに休んだのですか？つまり、また無断欠勤という事ですね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hamasaki-san didn't come to work without saying anything again? In other words, he ditched work again, didn't he?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼氏と本当に別れたの？つまり、もうあんな奴と関わらなくていいということ？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Did you really break up with your boyfriend? In other words, that means we don't have to deal with him anymore?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: また誰か辞めたんですか？つまり、今すぐ新しい人を見付けないといけないという事ですね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Someone quit again ? In other words, we need to find a new person as soon as possible, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたは昨日一日中家でゲームをして、家の事は何もしなかったってことですね。つまり一日中ダラダラしていたという事ですね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are saying that you were at home playing video games without doing any chores yesterday. Condensed, you were being lazy. (In short)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日何時でも良いんだって。詰まり、夜遅くなっても良いらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They said anytime tomorrow is good. To sum up, it seems that even late at night is ok.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はいつも約束を破る。詰まり、私のこと好きじゃないよね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He's always breaking his promises to me. In other words it seems that he isn't fond of me, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この車は電気自動車です。詰まり、ガソリンが要らないです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is an electric car. In other words it doesn't need gasoline.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 詰まりそれはどういうことですか？もっと簡単に説明してください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To sum up, what do you mean? Please explain it in a more simple manner.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今は失業しています。詰まり、あまりお金がないということです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is unemployed now. In other words he doesn't have very much money.

Name: 即(すなわ)ち
Meaning: In other words, That is, Namely
About: In a similar way to つまり, 即(すなわ)ち is another grammar pattern in Japanese that is often translated as 'in other words'. It may also be translated as 'namely', or 'that is to say'. While 即(すなわ)ち is an adverb, it is often used as a conjunction, linking two sentences via some sort of reasoning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この人は私の妻のお母さんです。すなわち、義理の母です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This person is my wife's mother. In other words, my mother in law.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はゲームしてお金を稼いでいます。すなわち、プロゲーマーです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I get paid for playing video games. In other words, I am a professional gamer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この車はもう動かないです。すなわち廃車です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This car does not run anymore. In other words, it is a decommissioned car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は僕の父の弟です。つまり叔父です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is my father's brother. In other words, he is my uncle.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕は肉を食べない。即ち菜食主義者だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't eat meat. In other words, I am a vegetarian.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 和食、即ち焼き魚やお味噌汁のようなものが食べられるお店に行きたいんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to go to a restaurant where I can eat Japanese food, namely grilled fish, miso soup and the like.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は学校の先生、即ち教育者だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is a school teacher, that is, an educator.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は私の母の弟の息子、即ち従兄弟です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is my mother's brother's son. In other words, he is my cousin.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ５割引きの商品とは、即ち元の値段の半額ということだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A product that is 50% off is, in other words, half off.

Name: 却(かえ)って
Meaning: All the more, On the contrary, Conversely
About: In order to revoke, or take a step back from a statement that has already been made, 却(かえ)って will often be used. 却(かえ)って can translate as 'rather', or 'all the more'. If a sentence consists of '(A) 却(かえ)って, (B)', what it means is 'putting aside (A), (B)'. 却(かえ)って is an adverb. 却(かえ)って itself translates most closely to 'instead'. However, this is not the 'instead' used for phrases like '(B) was chosen over (A)', but the 'instead' used for phrases like '(A) couldn't be achieved, so (B)'. This shows that (A) is usually the intention or aim of the speaker, but (B) was the result instead.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 手伝ってくれてるのはありがたいけど、却って邪魔になってるからあっちに行ってくれる？ごめんね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am grateful that you are helping me, but putting that aside, since you are in the way, can you go over there please? I'm sorry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お母さんを元気にするつもりだったけど、却って怒らせてしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was supposed to make my mom happy, but rather than that I actually made her angry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 「宿題やれ！」って言われると、却ってやりたくなくなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When someone tells me to do my homework, taking a step back from that, it makes me not want to do it even more.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遅く走った方が安全だと思うかもしれないけど却って危ないから、高速道路ではスピードを落とさないで。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You might think that it is safer to drive slower on a highway, but taking a step back from that, it is actually dangerous. So, please don't slow down on the highway.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 欲張ると却って損をしますよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you are greedy, you'll lose all the more.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「やれ」と言われると、却ってやる気がなくなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If someone says 'do it', on the contrary, I'll lose motivation.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 情けが却って仇となることもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: On the contrary, there are times when pity can backfire.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕がいると却って邪魔になると思うんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: On the contrary, if I stick around I think that I'll just get in the way.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お手伝いのつもりでしょうが、却って迷惑です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I realize that you are trying to help, on the contrary you are getting in the way.

Name: まるで～様(よう)だ
Meaning: It is entirely as if, It is just as though
About: まるで～ようだ is an expression in Japanese that combines the adverb まるで (sometimes written as 丸(まる)で), and combines it with a description of (A) followed by the auxiliary verb よう (with or without either だ or です after it). 丸(まる)で can be translated as 'entirely', or 'completely', while the whole expression may be understood as 'it seems entirely as though (A)'. まるで will be used at the beginning of a sentence, before the description of what (A) seems to be like. Instead of ようだ, other expressions of conjecture may also be used, such as みたい.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このゲームはものすごくリアルだ。まるで映画を見ているようだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This game is very realistic. It is as if I am watching a movie.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は私の母親と同じ年だけど運動神経がいい。まるで２０代のようだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person is the same age as my mother, but is very athletic. It is as though she's in her twenties.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人の仕事の仕方はまるで楽みたいだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: How that person works looks as if it is super easy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は弟にそっくりだ。まるで兄弟みたいだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He looks very similar to my younger brother. It is as if they are siblings.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客さんと話すときにはちゃんと目を見て話せ！目を見ていないとまるでお客さんの話を聞いていないみたいじゃないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Look at the customers eyes when you talk to them! If you don't make eye contact, it is as though you are not listening to what they are saying.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なんだそのフォームは？まるでなってないぞ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What is that form? That is completely unacceptable. (Natural, but different meaning)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたの顔はまるで幽霊を見たようだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Your face totally looks as though you saw a ghost.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 全部の家事をしてくれたの？まるで天使のようだ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: You did all the housework? You are just like an angel.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの二人は仲がいい。まるで兄弟のようだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Those two really get along well. It is just as though they are siblings. (entirely)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は、まるで山のように積まれた本を見て驚いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He was surprised to see books stacked just as if they were a mountain. (entirely)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんな日がくるなんて、まるで夢のようだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To think such a day would come, It is just as though I am in a dream. (entirely)

Name: 様(よう)な気(き)がする
Meaning: Have a feeling that
About: ような気(き)がする is a phrase that takes the base meaning of 気(き)がする 'to have a feeling that (A)', or 'to give off a vibe that (A)', and adds an extra layer of uncertainty through use of the auxiliary verb よう. This can be understood as meaning 'to have a funny feeling that (A)', or 'to kinda have a feeling that (A)'. As always, よう must be attached to the attributive form of any word that comes before it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの技はなんか簡単そう。俺でも出来るような気がする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That technique looks easy. I feel like I would be able to do it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこへ一人で行くのは危ないような気がする。ガイドと一緒に行った方がいいと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have a feeling that it would be dangerous to go there alone. I think it would be better to go with a guide.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あいつと話した感じでは元気なような気がするけど…
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Based on talking to him, he seemed like he was doing well, but…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 前にいる人は警察のような気がする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have a funny feeling that the person in front of us is a cop.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 分かるような気がする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have a feeling that I understand.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人に騙されたような気がする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have a feeling that I was deceived by that person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今回は合格するような気がしています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have a feeling that I will pass this time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 道を間違えたような気がします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have a feeling that I went the wrong way.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この問題、分かったような気がするぞ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have a feeling that I know the answer of this question.

Name: とても～ない
Meaning: Not ~ at all, Cannot ~ at all
About: When seen in sentences containing verbs negated with the auxiliary verb ない, とても carries the nuance of 'not (A) at all', or 'cannot (A) at all'. とても is supposed to only be used when expressing 'impossibility', 不可能(ふかのう). Due to this, it will primarily appear alongside the potential form of verbs.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その考え方はとても理解できない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I cannot understand that way of thinking at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はいつも嘘ばかり言うから、彼の言う事はとても信じられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He always just lies, so I cannot trust what he says at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼に子供ができたの！？彼が親になることを想像するのはとても無理だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He has a baby coming? I cannot imagine him becoming a parent at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どこの航空会社も今はチケットを売っていないから、旅行をするのがとても無理だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No airline company is selling airline tickets, so it is not possible to travel at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: とても考えられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot think of it at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: とても観光できない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot do any sight-seeing at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: とても観察できない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot do any observations at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: とても完成させられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot complete it at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: とても記憶できない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't memorize anything at all.

Name: 別(べつ)に～ない
Meaning: Not really, Not particularly, It's not like...
About: When paired with ない (either the い-Adjective or the auxiliary verb), the adverb 別(べつ)に 'separately' changes slightly in definition to that of 特(とく)に 'especially'. Let's have a look at a few examples. This 'especially' nuance of 別(べつ)に comes from 'separately' being negated. The literal meaning of 別(べつ)に～ない is something like '(A) cannot be separated/differentiated'. This comes across as 'maybe it is a little (A), maybe a lot (A), but in any case, it cannot be said that it IS (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は別に構わないけど、お父さんはそういうの気にするから、お父さんの前ではそういう事言わないでね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I actually don't mind, but my dad cares a lot about things like that, so please don't say such things in front of him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 別に痛くないよ。少しチクってするだけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not really painful. It just stings a little.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたの事は別に嫌いではないよ。ただあなたと何について話せばいいか分からないだけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that I don't like you at all. It's just that I don't know what to talk about with you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パーティーってみんな言っているけど、別にそんなに大したものではないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Everyone is calling it a party, but it is actually not that big of a deal.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 別にケーキが嫌いというわけではない。今は食べたくないだけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not that I dislike cakes. I just don't want one right now.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 別にケーキが嫌いというわけがない。今は食べたくないだけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not that I SO don't not like cakes. I just don't want any right now. (Grammatically correct, but very confusing for the listener)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムが悪いとは別にいっていないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm not really saying that Tom is bad. (not particularly)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは別に悪いことではないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That's not particularly a bad thing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 別に夢がないわけではないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not that I don't really have a dream.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私はそんなに音楽がうるさくても、別に気にしない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if the music is that loud, I don't particularly care.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 別に楽しくないわけではない。少し疲れているだけだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not like I am not particularly having fun. I am just a bit tired.

Name: ばかりでなく
Meaning: Not only…but also, As well as
About: ばかりでなく is a combination of the adverbial particle ばかり, with the conjugated (and negated) form of the auxiliary verb だ. It can be translated as 'not only (A), (B)', or 'not limited to (A), (B). As ばかり is an adverbial particle, it may be paired with the attributive form of other words. Like all other grammar points that negate だ, several forms may be seen. でなく, でなくて, ではなく, ではなくて, じゃなく, じゃなくて. However, it is important to remember that the addition of the は particle will place further emphasis on ない.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は仕事ばかりではなく、家事もちゃんとやっています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not only does he work, but he also takes care of the housework properly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 都内にある安いアパートは古いばかりではなく、だいたい小さくて汚い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Cheap apartments in metropolitan areas aren't only old, but they are usually small and dirty.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この池は綺麗なばかりではなく、ワニが沢山いるので危ないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This lake is more than just beautiful, there are a lot of alligators, so it is dangerous too.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は宝くじに当たって、車ばかりではなく、ボートとバイクも買った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He won the lottery, and not only did he buy a car, but he also bought a bike and a boat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は友達だけでなく、家族にも内緒で海外へ引っ越した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not only did he not tell his friends, but he didn't even tell his family about moving abroad.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はバスケだけでなく、水泳もするそうです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not only can she play basketball, but I heard that she can swim too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんはサッカーばかりでなく水泳も上手です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tanaka is good at soccer as well as swimming.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語は漢字ばかりでなく、ひらがなとカタカナもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Japanese not only has Kanji, but also has Hiragana and Katakana too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 悪いことばかりではなく、楽しいことを考えてみよう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Try not to think only of bad things, but fun things as well!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自分ばかりでなく、家族にも迷惑をかけてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have inconvenienced not only myself, but also my family.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強ばかりでなく、運動もした方がいいと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think you should not only study, but also exercise.

Name: ではなくて
Meaning: Not A but B, Conjunctive
About: When the auxiliary verb だ is seen in its negative conjugated form, it states that (A) is not correct, but (B) is. This form is ではなく, and may appear either with or without the conjunction particle て attached to the end. ではなくて is commonly seen grouped with nouns, or other words that have been nominalized through the use of の or こと. In ではなくて, the adverbial particle は is not strictly required. However, as this expression is comparing what (A) is 'not' to what (B) 'is', the contrast that は provides means that the phrase will sound far more natural with its inclusion.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 事故を起こしたら逃げるのではなくて、警察に電話をしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When you get into an accident, don't run, but call the police please.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 赤いのではなくて、青いのをください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please give me the blue one, not the red one.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は暇ではなくて忙しいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that I am bored today, but busy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: メールではなくて、ファックスで送ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please send it via fax, and not email.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その建物は刑務所ではなくて、学校です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That building is not a prison, but a school.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は正社員でなくて、アルバイトです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is not a full time worker, but a part time worker.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このラーメンは不味いのではなく、味が薄いだけです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not﻿﻿ that this ramen tastes bad, but it is bland.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は高いのではなく安いのを買った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bought the cheap one, not the expensive one.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は兄弟ではなくて従兄弟です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is not my sibling, but my cousin.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 魚じゃなくて肉が食べたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to eat meat, not fish.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 科学ではなくて化学です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not science, but chemistry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 火曜日ではなくて水曜日です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's not Tuesday, but Wednesday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの選手は天才ではなくて、努力家だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That player is not a genius, but a hard worker.

Name: だけでなくて～も
Meaning: Not only ~ but ~ also, Not just ~ but ~ also
About: As an extension of the standard だけでなく, meaning 'not only, but also', adding the adverbial particle も to the (B) part of a sentence will place extra emphasis on the thing that is being included in the same category as (A). だけ itself is an adverbial particle, so will primarily follow nouns. After this, the negative conjunctive form of the auxiliary verb だ (でなく) will create the 'not only' meaning. て is not strictly required as part of this structure, but will help to create a far more natural 'separation' between (A) and (B) when it is used. Either じゃなく or じゃなくて may also be used, as is the case with all でなく and ではなく based grammar structures.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アメリカだけではなく、韓国とチリにも行った事があります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not only the US, I have also been to Korea and Chile.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本は地震だけでなく、台風も多いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not only are there earthquakes in Japan, there are also many typhoons.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 漫画は子供だけではなくて、大人にも人気があります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not only is manga popular amongst children, it is popular among adults too.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お年玉は子供だけじゃなく、大人ももらえたらいいのにね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't you think it would be nice if adults also got money during new years and not just kids?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遊園地だけじゃなくて動物園にも連れて行ってほしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not only the amusement park, I also want you to take me to the zoo.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アイスクリームだけじゃなくて、プリンも買いました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I didn't just buy ice cream, I also bought pudding.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 机だけじゃなくて、椅子もほしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't just want a desk, I want a chair too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 市場だけでなく、スーパーにもいきませんか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Won't you not only go to the market, but the store too?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君だけじゃなく、僕も悪かったと思っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's not only you, I think that I am also to blame.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 体だけじゃなく、心も疲れてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am tired not only physically but mentally as well.

Name: だけしか～ない
Meaning: To emphasize '~only', Nothing but
About: だけしか is a combination of two adverbial particles, だけ 'only', and しか 'nothing but'. This structure primarily follows nouns, before part (B) of the sentence will have a corresponding ない based word. Despite all of these possibilities, it should be noted that だけしか～ない is an expression that appears with negative verbs, far more than any of the other combinations.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は野菜だけしか食べられません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He can only eat vegetables.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 土曜日だけしか空いてる日がないから、出来たら土曜日がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have no days except for Saturdays that are free, so if possible, it would be better if it was a Saturday.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この中ではタケシだけしか下手じゃない。他はみんな結構うまい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In this group, Takeshi is the only one that isn't good. Everyone else is considerably skilled.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何でこのコップだけしか５００円ではないの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why is this cup the only one that is 500yen?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は日本語だけしか話せないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can only speak Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日曜日しかだけ休みが取れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can take only breaks on Sunday. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日曜日だけしか休みが取れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can only take breaks on Sunday. (Natural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この時間、医師は一人だけしかいません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At this time of day, there is only one doctor present.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 椅子はここにあるものだけしかありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chairs are the only things here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私には従兄弟が一人だけしかいません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I only have one cousin.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕は日本語だけしかできません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can only speak Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 現金は今１０００円だけしかありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I only have 1000 yen in cash.

Name: は言(い)うまでもない ①
Meaning: It goes without saying (that), (It is) needless to say, I don't need to remind you
About: は言(い)うまでもない is a structure that combines the adverbial particle は, the う - Verb 言(い)う, two (2) additional adverbial particles まで and も, and the い-Adjective ない. This is regularly translated as 'it goes without saying that (A)', or 'it is needless to say (A)', where (A) is whatever comes before は. This expression may be preceded by almost any phrase, but is often emphasized even further by the inclusion of こと (or の), or ということ (or の). Literally, this expression is a combination of the meanings of its individual parts. は - Presents the topic. 言(い)う - Presents that topic as something that can be said. まで - Presents 'being said' as an extent. も - Emphasizes the extent set by まで. ない - Expresses that extent as not existing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の成績がクラスで一番なのは言うまでもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying that his grades are the best in the whole class.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ガソリンの値段が上がれば、電気自動車の数が増えることは言うまでもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If the gas prices go up, it goes without saying that the amount of electric cars will increase.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 師匠の戦い方が凄いということは言うまでもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying how amazing the master's fighting style is.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は歌うのが上手い。ピアノも言うまでもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She is very good at singing. Needless to say, the piano too.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の日本語がうまいのは言うまでもないが、日本語が上手いのは日本に３０年住んでいるからである。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying that his Japanese is very good, but he is good at Japanese because he has been living in Japan for 30 years.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一人で山を登るのが危ないというのは言うまでもないが、気をつけて行けばそれほど危なくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying that it is dangerous to climb a mountain on your own, but if you go cautiously, it is not that dangerous.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 困っている人を助けるべきと言うのは言うまでもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying that one should help people in need.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: エネルギーの無駄使いをやめれば、電気代が下がることは言うまでもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying that if you stop wasting electricity, the electricity bill will go down.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ともちゃんの大阪での知名度が高いことは言うまでもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying that Tomo-chan's popularity in Osaka is high.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「にせあい」がこの世代の最良の漫画の一つであることは言うまでもないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying that 'False love' is one of the best manga of this generation.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 生きるのに酸素が必要なことは言うまでもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying that oxygen is essential to live.

Name: 決(けっ)して〜ない
Meaning: Never, By no means
About: 決(けっ)して by itself is the て form of the verb 決(けっ)する 'to determine'. However 決(けっ)して is special in that it is considered to be a stand-alone adverb. As an adverb, it carries the meaning of 'decidedly', or 'assuredly', and is used in sentences that contain ない, in order to convey 'never (A)', 'under no circumstances (A)' or 'by no means (A)'. Like many other adverbs in Japanese, 決(けっ)して can appear at the beginning of a sentence, or directly before the word it is modifying (which will be in its ない form). While the translation is 'never', the literal meaning of 決(けっ)して is 'decidedly not (A)', or 'assuredly not (A)', simply emphasizing the negative point within a sentence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この道はものすごく危ないので、決してグループから離れないで下さい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This road is very dangerous, so please under no circumstances leave the group.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 決して痛くないとは言えないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: By no means, can I say that it does not hurt.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この乗り物は決して危険ではないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This ride is by no means dangerous.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この子は決して悪い人ではないけど、時々失礼なときがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: By no means do I think that this person is bad, but they are rude at times.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この宝石を決して渡すものか！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no way I will hand over this treasure!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前に決してお金を貸すものか！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no way I will lend you money!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嘘をついたら決してゆるさない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will never forgive you if you lie to me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何があっても、決して諦めない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will never give up, no matter what happens.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は決して妥協しない人だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is a person that never compromises.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人は決して嘘をつかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person never tells lies.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたのことは決して忘れません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will never forget you.

Name: 訳(わけ)には行(い)かない
Meaning: Cannot afford to, No way, Impossible to do
About: わけにはいかない is a statement that combines わけ 'to be so', 'reason', or 'cause', with the case marking particle に, the adverbial particle は, and the 'cannot go' meaning of 行(い)かない. It can be translated as 'cannot afford to (A)', or 'impossible to (A)'. However, the literal meaning is much closer to 'it cannot be so that (A)'. This structure will be used directly after the non-past form of verbs, in order to highlight them as being either highly undesirable, or highly unattainable. Although わけにはいかない primarily highlights things that are undesirable, it may also highlight something that is desirable, but impossible for some reason. This will depend largely on the speaker's tone of voice, and context of the conversation. In these types of sentences, the expression is quite similar to the 'I guess it's just not meant to be so' nuance that can be conveyed in English, highlighting regret.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この料理は妻が頑張って作ってくれたやつだから、不味くても残すわけにはいかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This food is something that my wife tried her best to make for me, so even if it tastes bad, there's no way that I can leave it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は人手が足りないから、休むわけにはいかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since we are short-handed tomorrow, I cannot afford to take a day off.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このジャケットが欲しいけど、今月はお金を使い過ぎたから買うわけにはいかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want this Jacket, but because I spent too much money this month, it cannot be so that I buy it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩に誘われたから、断るわけにはいかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was invited by my senpai, so there is no way that I can decline the offer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕はその問題を黙って見過ごす訳には行かない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot afford to silently overlook that problem.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まだやるべきことがあるから、死ぬ訳には行かないんだ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't afford to die, because there are still some things I have to do!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大統領に頼まれたので断る訳には行かない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since I was asked by the president I can't afford to say no.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは捨てる訳には行きません。大切な人からもらったんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't afford to throw it away. I got it from my special someone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まだ許す訳には行きません。ちゃんと反省してないでしょ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't afford to forgive you yet. You haven't taken the time to properly reflect on what you have done.

Name: う・よう + としない
Meaning: Not willing to, Not make an effort to, To not attempt or try to, Volitional + としない
About: Like ～ようと思う 'I think that I shall do (A)', ～ようとしない is a combination of a verb that has been grouped with the auxiliary verb う (or よう), followed by the case marking particle と, and then another verb. In this case, する. ～ようとしない is often translated as 'shall not (A)', but with emphasis on a lack of effort, or willingness.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は怒っているから、誰の話も聞こうとしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since he is angry, he is not willing to listen to what anyone has to say.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家になかなか帰ろうとしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He isn't quite trying to go home. (It doesn't seem like he is going to leave anytime soon)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自分から買って食べようと思わないけど、誰かに貰ったら食べるかも。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't think I would eat it if I had to buy it myself, but I might if someone gave it to me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は性格を変えようと思わない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think I shan't change my personality.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は好きな男を諦めようとしない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She is not willing to give up on the man she likes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 皆に嫌われているのに、性格を変えようとしないの？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though you're disliked by everyone you won't try to change your personality?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんなに天気がいいのに、うちの息子は外に出ようとしない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although it's nice outside, my son is not willing to go outside.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これだけ説明しても信じようとしないならもういいよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you are not willing to believe me, even after I took the time to explain things to you, then so be it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は現実を見ようとしない。逃げてばかりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is not willing to face (see) reality. He is just running from it.

Name: もしかしたら
Meaning: Perhaps, Maybe, Possibly
About: もしかしたら and its alternatives are usually treated as stand alone 副詞(ふくし) (adverbs) in Japanese that are used to present hypothetical situations, and what could happen within those situations. These expressions are a combination of the adverb 若(も)し, the case marking particle か, and one of several combinations of する (したら, して, or すると). It is often translated as 'perhaps', 'maybe', or 'possibly'. As with many other Japanese adverbs, it will often appear at the beginning of sentences. Due to もしかしたら presenting hypothetical situations, かもしれない will regularly appear in the same sentence (although it is not required). As もしかしたら is a combination of もし 'if', か (presents a question), and したら 'so happens that', the literal translation is close to 'does it so happen that', or 'should it so happen that', with past or present tense being controlled more so by the following statement.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もしかしたら、行けるかもしれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Maybe, I will be able to go.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もしかして仕事があるかもしれないから、今ははっきりしたことが言えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I may have to work, so I can't say anything for certain.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もしかすると、アンちゃんも来るかもしれないけど皆は大丈夫？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Maybe Ann-chan might come, but are you all okay with that?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もしかしたら明日も休むかもしれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Perhaps I will take a day off tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もしかしたら昨日だったかもしれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Perhaps it could have been yesterday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もしかしたら…病気かもしれないんだ…
Questions.EnglishHTML: I might be ill...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もしかしたら採用されるかもしれません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I might be hired.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もしかしたら今晩雪になるかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Perhaps it will snow tonight.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もしかしたら気が変わって、来てくれるかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He/she might change his/her mind and come.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「もしかしたら嫌われてるのかな？」なんて思ってしまうことがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I sometimes think 'maybe I am disliked?'

Name: たとえ〜ても
Meaning: Even if…is the case, Supposing that
About: たとえ, coming from 仮令(たとえ), an adverb meaning 'supposing that', is a word in Japanese that is often used with ても (or でも), in order to present possible circumstances, and their contradictory and/or (usually) undesirable outcomes. たとえ is primarily seen at the beginning of a sentence, before some kind of possibility, comparison, or supposition will be stated. たとえ tends to be used to present situations where 'even if (A) were true, (B) still may/may not happen'. This is called a 'contrastive' example. もし on the other hand tends to be used for examples in which (A) will directly result in (B). This is called a 'resultative' example.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 空手ではたとえ試合で勝っても、ガッツポーズをしてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if you win in a karate competition, you should not celebrate visibly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たとえ暑くても、虫が入ってくるのでこの窓は開けないで下さい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if it is hot, bugs will come in, so please do not open this window.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たとえ好きでも、そんなことをされたら、嫌いになる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if I like them, if someone does such a thing, I will start to dislike them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たとえ電車でも３０分はかかる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even by train, it will take at least 30 minutes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たとえ来年までに完成したとしても、中に入る店が決まっていないから来年中にはオープンされないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if it is completed by next year, the shops that it is going in have not been decided, so it is unlikely that they will open next year.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もし今年中にモールの工事が終わったら、来年の頭にはオープンするはず。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If the construction for the mall finishes within this year, it should open at the beginning of next year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仮令雪が降らなくても、スノーボードをしに行く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if it doesn't snow, I'm going snowboarding.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仮令笑われても、正しいことをしたいんだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to do the right thing, even if they laugh at me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仮令叱られても、譲れないことがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if (I am) reprimanded, there are things that are non-negotiable.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仮令あなたが行かなくても、僕は行きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if you don't go, I will.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仮令嬉しくても、笑ってはいけない時もある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are times when you cannot laugh, even if you are happy.

Name: ことに
Meaning: Extremely, Especially, To my ...
About: When 事(こと) 'thing' is combined with the case-marking particle に following a statement, it highlights that something is of a 'great extent'. Common translations include 'particularly', 'especially', or 'to my (A)'. This grammar pattern almost always describes some kind of feeling or emotion. ことに is regularly seen after verbs, い or な-Adjectives. In most situations, '(A) ことに (B)' can be translated quite literally as 'to a particularly (A) extent, (B)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ビックリしたことに、久しぶりに小学生時代の友達から電話がかかってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am especially surprised that I got a phone call from a friend from elementary school after such a long time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 珍しいことに、彼がいいレストランに連れていってくれた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is particularly rare to be taken to a nice restaurant by him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 残念なことに、その商品はもう販売中止になりました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Unfortunately, that product is no longer being sold.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 幸いなことに、近所の人が私の猫を見つけて家まで届けてくれた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Fortunately, my neighbor found our cat for us, and brought her home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 幸せな事に、来年結婚します。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am extremely happy about getting married next year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 不思議な事に、最近物事がすべてうまくいく。
Questions.EnglishHTML: By some extreme oddity, lately everything seems to be going well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嬉しい事に、みんなが協力してくれるようになりました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am extremely happy that everyone started to cooperate with me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嬉しい事に日本語能力試験に合格しました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am especially happy about passing the JLPT.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 驚いた事に、六ヶ月で赤ちゃんが初めて歩いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To our extreme surprise, the six month old baby took its first steps.

Name: 事(こと)か
Meaning: How…, What..., God knows...
About: ことか is a combination of こと 'thing', and the case marking particle か, used to present a question. In sentences with ことか, words that highlight some particular number or extent are often used, before ことか comes at the end of the statement, expressing that 'extent' as being particularly unusual, or even unbelievable (thanks to the addition of か). This is often translated simply as 'how (A)', 'what (A)', or even 'god knows (A)'. Let's look at a few examples. Literally, ことか can be translated as 'to what particular (A) is (B)!?', as the enquiry is often not directed at anyone specifically, but instead presents itself as a question simply to emphasize its magnitude.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人のコンサートには何回いったことか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: God knows how many times I have gone to that person's concert.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: うちの犬はどんなに可愛いことか。こんなに可愛いワンチャンは他にはいないはず。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: How can I explain how cute my dog is? There is no other dog as cute as her.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なんて暇なことか。こんなに暇なのは久しぶりだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: God knows how bored I am. It's been a long time since I've been this bored.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子を一人で電車に乗せるのがどれだけ心配であることか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: God knows how worried I am to let my kid on the train by himself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どれだけお前の事を愛していたことか！それでも俺はお前に裏切られた！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: God knows how much I loved you! Still, you betrayed me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 知らない人にありがとうと言われるのがどれだけ嬉しいことか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: God knows how nice it feels to have a stranger thank you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これをどれだけ待っていた事か。
Questions.EnglishHTML: God knows how long I have waited for this!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 文プロがあってどんなに便利な事か！
Questions.EnglishHTML: How convenient it is to have Bunpro!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君に会えてどんなに嬉しかった事か。
Questions.EnglishHTML: How happy I was after meeting you!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君に会える日を、どんなに夢見た事か。
Questions.EnglishHTML: How much I have dreamed of the day I could finally meet you!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このプロテインのなんと美味しい事か！すごく飲みやすい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: How delicious this protein is! It goes down like nothing.

Name: かと言(い)うと ①
Meaning: Why? Well..., Why? Because..., If you ask me why..., The reason why is..., It is because...
About: ～かというと is a phrase that has two primary functions. The first is used in conjunction with 'why' and 'how' words, like どうして or なぜ, while the other is used with 'who', 'when', 'where', and 'what'. We will focus on the former in this lesson. かというと is a combination of the case marking particle か in its use as a question marker, the case marking particleと in its citation use, the う - Verb 言(い)う 'to say', and the case marking particle と in its result use. This is quite a few particles combined together, but the literal meaning is more simply 'if (A) were to be asked', before the speaker will go on to highlight their reasoning in (B). As ～かというと will come before some sort of explanation, から will also regularly be used at the end of the sentence as 'because', emphasizing the speaker's reasoning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうして明日のパーティーに行きたくないかというと、元カレが来ると聞いたからです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The reason why I don't want to go to tomorrow's party is because I heard that my ex-boyfriend is coming.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なぜこの計画で進めようと思ったかというと、以前この計画に似たプランが成功したからです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The reason why we have decided to continue with this plan is because a similar plan succeeded last time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうして冬でも冷房をかけているかと言えば、お客さんに汗をかかずに買い物をさせる為です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you ask me why we keep the air conditioning on even in the winter, it is because we want the customers to shop without sweating.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なぜ安い方を選んだかといったら、安いやつも、高いやつもついている機能が同じだからです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you ask me why I picked the cheaper one, it is because both the cheaper one and the expensive one have the same functionality.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なぜ彼はそれをしたのかというといまだに私自身もわからない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you ask me why he did that, well, even now I don't know.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうしてそのブランドのスマホは買いたくないかっていうと、前に一回買ったけど二週間で壊れたんだよね.
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you ask me why I don't want to buy that brand of smartphone, it is because I bought one before and it broke in (just) two weeks.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: キリンには長い首がある。なぜかというと、その長い首を使って高い木の上にある葉を食べるためだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Giraffes have long necks. The reason why is because by using their long necks they can eat leaves on the top of trees.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうしてバスを使うよりは自転車を使うようにしているかというと、自転車はより安いばかりではなくて交通渋滞の中でもより速いからです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you ask me why I do my best to bike (to work) rather than take a bus, it is because bicycles are not only cheaper but also faster in traffic.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 法律によって犬や猫にチップをつけることが要求されています。なぜかというとペットが捨てられた場合にすぐにオーナーがわかるようにするためです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The law requires that dogs and cats be microchipped. Why? Because in the event that the pet is abandoned, the microchip will allow the owner to be quickly identified.

Name: かと言(い)うと ②
Meaning: If you ask me..., If I had to say, If I were to say, If I were to choose one, I'd rather
About: ～かというと is a phrase that has two primary functions. The first is used in conjunction with 'why' and 'how' words, while the other is used with 'who', 'when', 'where', 'which' or 'what'. We will focus on the latter in this lesson. かというと is a combination of the case marking particle か in its use as a question marker, the case marking particle と in its citation use, the う - Verb 言(い)う 'to say', and the case marking particle と in its result use. This is quite a few particles combined together, but the literal meaning is more simply 'if (A) were to be asked', before the speaker will go on to highlight their reasoning in (B). 何(なん)で, 何(なに), どちら, 誰(だれ), どの, and similar words often appear as the 'who', 'where', or 'which' words in these sentences. As ～かというと will come before some sort of explanation, から will also regularly be used at the end of the sentence as 'because', emphasizing the speaker's reasoning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何で日本に引っ越して来たかというと 、私の家族が日本に住んでいるからです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I were to say why I moved to Japan, it is because my family lives here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰と旅行に行きたいかというと 、大親友と行きたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I were to say who I wanted to travel with, it would be my best friend.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どの街に住みたいかというと 、両親が住んでいる街に住みたいと思っています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I were to say which city I wanted to live in, I think it would be the city that my parents do.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何でこんな事になったかといえば、私がきちんと確認をしなかったからです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I were to say why something like this happened, well, it is because I did not check properly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰が一番上手かといったらＢ組のタカハシさんです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I were to say who was the best, it would be Takahashi-san from class B.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一方、自分にとってどちらかというと丈夫な車のほうが優れていると思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: On the other hand, if you ask me, I think that sturdy cars are superior.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
イオさん：「どっちのほうがいいの？」
ツミキさん：「どどどっちかっていうと、こっちのほう...」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Io: 'Which do you like more?'
Tsumiki: 'If, if, if I were to say, I like this more...'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
イチカさん：「ミクちゃんは好きな人がいるみたいに見えるよ。」
イツキさん：「誰が好きかっていうときっとフウタロウくんでしょう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Ichika: 'It looks like Miku has a crush on someone.'
Itsuki: 'If I were to say on who, then it would be Futaro.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
ヨツバさん：「その犬はどのくらい大きいの？」
フウカさん：「どのくらい大きいかというと....えーと....こんなに大きいくらいでしょう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Yotsuba: 'How big was that dog?'
Fuuka: 'If you ask me how big, hmmm, I think about this big?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何でこんなことになったかというと、すべてが始まったのは一週間ほど前に学校から帰っていた時...
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I were to say why it turned out like this, well, it all started around 1 week ago when I was coming back from school...

Name: で言(い)うと
Meaning: In, Of, According to
About: でいうと is an expression in Japanese that is commonly used to ask questions, or to give information about how one thing corresponds with another. It is a combination of the case marking particle で meaning 'with', and 言(い)うと meaning 'if said', or 'if we say'. This structure will be seen after nouns, and can be translated as 'if said with (A), (B)'. でいうと will often be seen in sentences with に当(あ)たる 'to be equivalent to', another common grammar structure used for drawing connections between things.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このバイクは、車で言うとランボルギーニみたいなものだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If we say it's a car, this bike is something like a Lamborghini.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本で言うとパンみたいなもの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If we say Japan, is it something like bread? (Would this be considered bread in Japan)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一言で言うと彼は本当に凄い人だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If said in a word, he is an amazing person.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 「What's up」は日本語でいうと、「元気」に当たる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If said with Japanese, 'what's up' is equivalent to 'Genki'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コンピューターでいうとＲＡＭに当たる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If speaking about computers, it is equivalent to RAM.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一言で言うと彼とはもう会わないことにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To sum it up, I have decided to never see him again.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 統計で言うと、客の７０％が観光客だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: According to statistics, 70% of customers are tourists. (speaking of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この年をとっていそうな猫は人間の年齢で言うと８４歳ぐらいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This old-looking cat is about 84 years old in human years. (in terms of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: つまり、「hmmm」は日本語で言うと「うーん」に当たります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To sum up, 'Hmm' corresponds to 'うーん' in Japanese. (in terms of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: わかりやすい言葉で言うと俺は上司だが、君は部下だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To put it in simple words, I am the superior and you are the subordinate. (in terms of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「I am batman」って日本語で言うとどうなる？
Questions.EnglishHTML: What is 'I am batman' in Japanese? (in terms of)

Name: ずつ
Meaning: One at a time, Per, Each, Gradually
About: ずつ, or 宛(ずつ) in its kanji form, is a suffix in Japanese that is used to highlight things that occur/exist in specific amounts. It is often translated simply as 'each', 'per', or 'at a time'. Depending on the source, ずつ may also be considered to be an adverbial particle. However, this will not change the way that it is utilized. ずつ is used directly after the number/amount of something that it is highlighting as being the 'at a time' grouping.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: メニューに載ってるもの一つずつちょうだい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Give me one of each thing on the menu!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一人ずつゆっくりとお入りください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please enter slowly, one person at a time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このお酒は強いので少しずつ飲んでください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This alcohol is strong, so please drink a little at a time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎月いくらかずつお金を貯めて旅行に行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every month, I want to save up some money, and go on a trip.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一グループずつ前に出て来てください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please come to the front one group at a time. (Group = allotment)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パーティーに来る人は一人一つずつ食べ物を持って来てください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whoever is coming to the party, please bring your own portion of food. (Portion = allotment)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それぞれのテストを２回宛チェックした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have checked each test two times each.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 静かにして下さい！一人宛お願いします！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please be quiet! One person at a time, please!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １０宛に分けて数えてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please divide (it) into 10's and count. (10 at a time)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一人宛入場できる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: One person can enter at a time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 生徒は１０人宛のグループに分かれてバスに乗った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The students were broken up into groups of 10 each and got on the buses. (10 at a time)

Name: ずっと ②
Meaning: By far, Way, Far...er, Far...more
About: In addition to the ずっと used to mean 'always', or 'non-stop', this adverb may also convey that one thing is 'by far (A)', or 'much more (A)' than something else. In these phrases, ずっと usually comes at the beginning of the sentence, before some form of comparison will be made between (A) and (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さっき見た鳥よりずっと大きかったよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It was much bigger than the bird we saw earlier.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それよりずっと昔だよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It was way more before that. (That happened way before that)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ずっと運動していなかったから体が全然動かない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I haven't exercised for an extremely long interval, so my body does not move at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんな変な奴よりこっちの方がずっとすごいよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This one is so much better by a lot, compared to that weird thing!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この車は私のよりずっとよく見える。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This car looks way better than mine.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「でも勇者さまはずっと強いし...」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'But our hero is far stronger and...'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕よりもずっと年上だということ、信じられないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't believe that he is far older than (even) me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 太陽のほうが地球よりずっと大きいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The sun is far larger than Earth.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コンピュータは以前に比べてずっと使いやすくなった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Computers have become much easier to use than before.

Name: だらけ
Meaning: Completely covered in, Full of
About: だらけ is a suffix that is used in Japanese to express when one thing is 'covered in', or 'filled with' another thing. だらけ will be attached to the end of nouns, before (sometimes) being followed by the case marking particle の and a second noun. The second noun is frequently omitted if the place or thing that is 'covered in' something is obvious.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パンケーキの裏側が穴だらけで気持ち悪い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The underside of this pancake is covered in holes so it is gross.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この公園はゴミだらけだからこどもを連れて来たくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This park is covered in garbage, so I don't want to bring my kids here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 傷だらけの車に乗っているのを見られたくないからいつも妻の車に乗ってる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't want someone to see me drive a car covered in scratches, so I always drive my wife's car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 泥だらけの服を洗濯機にいれないで！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't put mud-covered shirts in the washing machine!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 壁をしろだらけに塗ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please cover my wall with white paint. (Unnatural, unless the speaker specifically wanted paint speckled, rather than covering the wall)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 血だらけのシャツをクリーニングに出した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I took my blood-covered shirt to the dry cleaner. (Natural, as blood drops may be scattered)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 床が泥だらけになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The floor became covered in dirt.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 汗だらけでもかまわない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't mind being covered in sweat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの壁はいつも落書きだらけだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That wall is always covered with graffiti.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 欠点だらけの人はいない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No one is completely full of faults.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人の話は矛盾だらけだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person's stories are full of contradictions.

Name: 尤(もっと)も
Meaning: Although, But, However, For all that, Provided that
About: もっとも, sometimes also seen as 尤(もっと)も, is a conjunction that is used to clarify when (A) is not the only important thing to be considered. This expression is usually translated as 'although'. However, 'for all that', or 'with that said' are also accurate translations, depending on the context. Let's look at a few examples. Due to もっとも offering clarification about something, the (B) phrase will often end with が, けど, けれども, and other similar expressions. When もっとも is used, the speaker is agreeing that (A) is true, but not the whole picture. As a noun itself, 尤(もっと)も can be described as 道理に適(かな)う, which means 'to stand to reason'. This nuance is kept, and may also be used as an accurate translation for もっとも as a conjunction.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の妹はピアノを弾くのがじょうずだ。もっとも、弾けるのは一曲だけだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My sister is good at playing the piano. Although, she can only play one song.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺はすき焼きが大好きだ。もっとも、毎日食べれる訳では無い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I love sukiyaki. Although, it does not mean that I can eat it everyday.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は韓国についてものすごく詳しいです。もっとも、韓国には行った事が無いけど。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am very knowledgeable about Korea, although I have never been there.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は会社に自分のパソコンを持ってきた。もっとも、自分のパソコンはいらないが。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I brought my own computer to work today, although I don't need to.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語を話せます。尤も、少しだけですが。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can speak Japanese. But only a bit.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: みんなラーメンが好きだ。尤も、例外もありますよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Most people like ramen. But, there are exceptions.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それはいい質問です。尤も、十分に説明できませんが。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a great question. However, I am not able to fully explain it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君は正しい。オレの一番好きなものは、ラーメンだ。尤もいつも食べられるわけではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You are right! My favorite one is ramen. But it doesn't mean I can always eat it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: とうとう仕事を見つけた。尤も今では自分の時間がなくなったけど。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Finally, I have found a job. But now I don't have time for myself.

Name: 再(ふたた)び
Meaning: Again, Once more, A second time
About: 再(ふたた)び is an adverb that means 'to repeat'. It is regularly translated as 'again', 'once more', or 'a second time'. Usually, 再(ふたた)び will appear at the beginning of a sentence, before some sort of request or statement will be made about what needs to be repeated. Despite meaning 'to repeat', 再(ふたた)び specifically has the nuance of repeating something 'for the second time'. Because of this, it will not be used to highlight things that need to be repeated over and over again.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は刑務所から出て、再び犯罪を犯した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After he left prison, he committed a crime once more.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 再びふるさとに戻りたいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to go back to my home town again.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: また来週会いましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let's meet again next week. (Natural)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 再び来週会いましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let's meet once more next week. (Unnatural)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は再び紙飛行機を飛ばした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He threw a paper airplane a second time. (once more)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 免許をなくして、再び発行してもらった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I lost my driver's license and had it issued again. (a second time)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 来年も再びここに来たいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to come here again next year. (a second time)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は再び夜空を眺めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She looked at the night sky once more. (a second time)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今家に帰ったばかりなのに、再び呼び出された。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I just got home, but I was called in again. (a second time)

Name: 味(み)
Meaning: ~ness, Used to indicate conditions or nature
About: み is a common suffix in Japanese that has the role of transforming adjectives into nouns. This is often translated as '(A)ness' in English, but has a few small differences. To use み, attach it to the stem form of either い-Adjectives or な-Adjectives. The 語幹(ごかん) (stem form) being the form with い removed (for い-Adjectives), or な removed (for な-Adjectives).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 温かみのある家に住みたいな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to live in a house with warmth.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大人になってから将棋の楽しみが分かってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since becoming an adult, I understand shogi's fun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この色からこのフルーツの新鮮みがかんじられる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the color of this fruit, you can see its freshness.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達の大切みがわかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Now, I understand the importance of friends.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どれぐらいの辛みの物が食べられる？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What's the hotness of something that you can eat? (Unnatural, as どれぐらい implies an amount, rather than a quality)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このケーキの甘みがちょうどいい。
