AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The sweetness of this cake is perfect. (Natural, as this just means the 'type' of sweetness, rather than the 'level')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昆布の旨味がちゃんと出てる！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The flavor of the kelp is really coming out! (The savory quality, rather than the intensity of savory flavor)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 髪を染めてから、赤みがなくなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After dying my hair, the redness has gone away. (The red quality, rather than the intensity of redness)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このスープは魚のうま味が感じられるね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can taste the deliciousness of the fish in this soup, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人の痛味がわかる人間になろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's become people who can understand the pain of others. (~ness)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 弱味を人に見せたくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't want to show others my weakness.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この文章は全然面白味がないな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This sentence is not interesting at all. (~ness)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 渋味がある食べ物は苦手だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't really like foods that have a bitter taste. (bitterness)

Name: と同(おな)じくらい
Meaning: About the same as, About as, No less
About: As a combination of the case marking particle と, the noun 同(おな)じ 'the same', and the adverbial particle くらい. と同(おな)じくらい is an expression used to highlight that something is 'about the same as (A)'. To use と同(おな)じくらい, attach it to the end of a noun that you want to highlight as being the prime example, with whatever is comparable to it coming later in the sentence, or directly attached through the case marking particle の. If you want to express that an action is being performed in 'almost the same way' as (A), に may replace の, after くらい.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼のパソコンはプリンターと同じぐらい大きい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: His computer is about as big as his printer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生、昨日と同じぐらい痛いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Doctor, it hurts about the same as yesterday.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は車と同じぐらいのスピードで走れる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He can run at about the same speed as a car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今飼っている犬と同じぐらいのサイズのワンチャンが欲しいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want a puppy that is about the same size as the one I have now.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 値段が同じぐらいになるのなら、もっといいのを買います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If the price is going to be about the same, I will buy the better one.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの女の人はお母さんと同じぐらいに見えたけど、年齢を聞いたらお祖母ちゃんと同い年だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That lady looked about the same age as my mother, but when I asked her, she was the same age as my grandma.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うちのぽちはこの箱と同じくらいの大きさだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Our Pochi is about the same size as this box.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつか、トモキと同じくらいの身長になりたいな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: One day, I want to be about the same height as Tomoki.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うちの娘はきみの息子と同じくらいの年齢だね？
Questions.EnglishHTML: My daughter is about the same age as your son, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ぼくにとってきみは金と同じくらい貴重だよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For me, you are about as precious as gold. (about the same as)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このトランペットはピラミッドと同じくらい古いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This trumpet is about as old as the pyramids. (about the same as)

Name: とおなじで・とちがって
Meaning: Like, Similar to, Unlike, Dissimilar to
About: Two regular expressions that are used in Japanese for conveying similarity, and dissimilarity are と同(おな)じで 'the same as (A)', and と違(ちが)って 'different to (A)'. While both of these structures use the case marking particle と to mark (A), 同(おな)じ is a noun, while 違(ちが)って is the て form of the う - Verb, 違(ちが)う. Due to this, the auxiliary verb だ is required after 同(おな)じ, in order to link (A) and (B). だ will appear in its conjunctive form. Both と同(おな)じで and と違(ちが)って will be preceded by a noun or noun phrase, before the (B) part of the sentence will describe the similarity/dissimilarity. In this structure, as the conjunction particle て, has a similar role to the conjunctive form of だ (で), both expressions are simply stating that (B) is existing in a state of 'having sameness', or 'having difference' with (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は僕と同じで、猫アレルギーです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just like me, he is allergic to cats.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 母も私と同じで、アウトドアが好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just like me, my mother likes the outdoors.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は弟と違って、本を読むのが大好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Unlike my brother, I love to read books.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は私と違って、遊園地が苦手です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Unlike me, she does not like amusement parks very much.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君と同じでその意見に賛成だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Like you, I agree with that opinion.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: フィンランドと違って、ハワイは一年中暖かい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Unlike Finland, Hawaii is warm year round.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 天気予報と違って今日はとても暖かい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Unlike what the forecast said, today is very warm.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大統領と違って、副大統領は優しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Unlike the president, the vice president is kind.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生と同じで、僕も日本語が大好きです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Like my teacher, I love Japanese.

Name: と並(なら)んで
Meaning: In line with, Comparable with, Along with, Just like, As … as
About: Often, when the case marking particle と is used alongside the conjunction particle て containing form of the う - Verb 並(なら)ぶ 'to line up', the meaning of 'to be comparable with (A)', or 'to be in line with (A)' will be conveyed. と並(なら)んで will be preceded by nouns, or noun phrases. Occasionally, the plain form of 並(なら)ぶ can be seen alongside ほど, to show that (B) is 'at the extent of being in line with (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このアニメはサザエさんと並んで、日本中で愛されている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This anime is as loved as Sazae-san in Japan. (In line with the same level of love)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここではきしめんも手羽先と並んで人気です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Here, kishimen is comparable in popularity to chicken wings.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日産はトヨタと並ぶほど車を出しています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Nissan produces about in line with the same number of cars as Toyota.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この映画はあの映画と並ぶほどいいが、ほとんどの人はこの映画を選ぶ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This movie is almost comparable to that movie in how good it is, but most people would choose this one.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ラーメンもまた、寿司と並んで人気の日本食だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In line with sushi, ramen is also a popular Japanese food.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この芸術作品はモナ・リザと並んで高く評価されている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This piece of art is valued as highly as Mona Lisa. (comparable・along with)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 喫煙は揚げ物と並んで癌を引き起こす確率が高い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Smoking has as high a probability of causing cancer as deep-fried foods do. (comparable・along with)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 東京大学は慶應義塾大学や早稲田大学と並んで日本屈指の大学として考えられている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The University of Tokyo, along with Keio University and Waseda University, are considered to be Japan's best universities. (comparable with)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 宮崎駿は小津安二郎や黒澤明と並んで日本三大監督の一人と言われている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Hayao Miyazaki is said to be one of the three great Japanese directors, along with Akira Kurosawa and Yasujiro Ozu. (comparable)

Name: に違(ちが)いない
Meaning: There is no doubt that, I'm sure
About: When the case marking particle に is combined with the noun 違(ちが)い 'difference', and the い-Adjective ない, an expression similar to 'there is no doubt that (A)', or 'I'm sure that (A)' is created. に違(ちが)いない may be used with any verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives or nouns in their plain form.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼らは、先生がいなくなったらふざけるに違いない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no doubt that they will muck around once the teacher has gone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたが美味しいというなら、美味しいに違いない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you say that it is good, I have no doubt that it is.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカ君は全然料理を食べてない。この料理が嫌いに違いない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takana-kun is not eating his food at all. There is no doubt that he does not like it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今のピンポンは近所の子供のいたずらに違いない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There's no doubt that the doorbell I just heard must have been a prank by the neighbor's kid.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人はカメラマンに囲まれている、有名人に違いない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person is surrounded by cameramen. There is no discrepancy in that person being famous. (No reason to disbelieve)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの顔は日本人に違いない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That face... there is no doubt that that person is Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は病気に違いない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no doubt that she is sick.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんなに遅いなんて…、何かあったに違いない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Being so late... there is no doubt that something happened.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの言い方だと、何か隠しているに違いない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the way he speaks, there is no doubt that he is hiding something.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大雪が降って大変だったに違いない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am sure that it was tough after that heavy snowfall.

Name: 当(あ)たり
Meaning: Per~, A~, Apiece, Each
About: When attached to the end of numbers or counters, the noun 当(あ)たり 'to hit' will be used as a suffix. In these cases, the meaning is usually translated as 'per (A)', or 'each (A)'. Let's take a look at some examples.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一個当たり五円で作ることができます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We are able to make this for 5 yen each.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一食当たりのカロリーは５００ｋＣａｌです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It has 500 calories per serving.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この車は１台当たり１トンあります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This car equates to 1 ton per vehicle.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一人当たり５０００円で入場できます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The price for entry per person equates to 5000 yen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは１個当たり５０キロカロリーあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: These have 50 kilocalories apiece.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このコーヒーは一缶当たり￥１３０（税込）。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This coffee is 130￥per can (tax included).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一個当たりの代金は千円です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The price is 1000 yen per item.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一人当たり三個ずつパンを配ります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will hand out three pastries per person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １日当たり１０００円の手当てが出ます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: 1000 yen will be provided per day.

Name: に当(あ)たる
Meaning: Correspond to, Amounts to, Equals to, Is appropriate
About: As mentioned in our 当(あ)たり lesson, 当(あ)たる often has a meaning that is similar to に対(たい)して 'to be in regard to'. Due to this, when combined with the case marking particle に, に当(あ)たる will be translated as 'to correspond to', 'to amount to', 'to be appropriate for', or 'to be in regard to'. These may seem quite different, but we will examine the similarities shortly. To use に当(あ)たる, attach it to the end of an (A) noun that you would like to mark as being the 'point of reference'. (B) may come directly after に当(あ)たる, or earlier in the sentence, so long as it is clearly separated from (A). As for the link between に対(たい)して and に当(あ)たる, it is as follows. In に対(たい)して, (A) and (B) exist simultaneously, but (B) opposes something about (A). In に当(あ)たる, (A) and (B) exist simultaneously, but (B) matches something about (A). Due to this, unless the speaker is specifically trying to highlight something that is 'opposing', or 'matching', the base meaning of '(A) and (B) existing simultaneously' may be the standard translation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 英語の「what's up」は日本語の「元気」に当たる表現だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: 'What's up' in English corresponds to the expression 'genki' in Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その人は私の親戚に当たる人です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person is my relative.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生はタナカ君のいとこに当たる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The teacher is Tanaka-kun's cousin.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年は仕事を始めてから５年目に当たる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This year amounts to the 5th year since I've started working. (It's been 5 years since I've started this job)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ハクは納豆を食べるのが好きなのに対して、チヒロは納豆があまり好きじゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As opposed to Haku who likes eating natto, Chihiro does not like eating it as much.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 「Hello」は日本で「こんにちは」に当たる言葉です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: 'Hello' corresponds to the Japanese word 'konnichiwa'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: おじと呼んでいるけど、実はいとこに当たるんだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I call him 'uncle,' but in reality, he is my cousin.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 江戸という都市は現在の東京に当たる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The city called 'Edo' corresponds to present-day Tokyo.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女の長男のリンゴパンはパムの父に当たる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Her eldest son, Ringopan, also corresponds to the father of Pamu.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「地下鉄」に当たる言葉は、イギリスでは「underground」で、アメリカでは「subway」です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The word corresponding to 'chikatetsu' is 'underground' in the United Kingdom, and 'subway' in the United States.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ドイツでは日本の首相に当たる役職を「Bundeskanzler 」と呼んでいる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In Germany, the position corresponding to the Japanese prime minister is called 'Bundeskanzler'.

Name: に限(かぎ)る
Meaning: Nothing better than, There's nothing like, Limited to
About: に限(かぎ)る is a combination of the case marking particle に (marking a location), and the う - Verb 限(かぎ)る 'to limit'. This expression can be translated as 'there's nothing better than (A)', or 'there's nothing like (A)'. に限(かぎ)る may be paired with verbs in their base form, or with nouns. に限(かぎ)る may also appear with verbs that have been negated with the auxiliary verb ない. Care will need to be taken with translating these sentences, as they will express that 'there is nothing better than -not- doing (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 暑い日は冷たいシャワーを浴びるに限る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is nothing better than taking a cold shower on a hot day.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 回転寿司はくら寿司に限る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is nothing better than Kurazushi when it comes to kaiten-sushi.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 寒い日には温かい部屋を出ないに限る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is nothing better to do than not leaving your warm room on a cold day.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 休みの日には仕事をしないに限る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is nothing better than doing no work on a day off.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 暑い日にはアイスクリームを食べるに限る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am bound to eat ice cream on a hot day.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この施設を利用できるのはこのアパートの住民に限る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Using this facility is limited to those who live in this apartment complex.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 疲れた時は寝るに限る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is nothing better than sleep when you are tired.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寒い夜は鍋に限る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is nothing better than nabe on a cold night.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: やっぱり秋刀魚は目黒に限る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is nothing like Samma (fish) from Meguro.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仕事の後はジュースに限る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is nothing better than a juice after work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 登山をするなら、富士山に限る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you are going climbing, there is nothing like Mt. Fuji.

Name: とは限(かぎ)らない
Meaning: Not necessarily so, Is not always true, There is no guarantee that
About: とは限(かぎ)らない is regularly used to convey the meaning of '(A) is not necessarily so', or 'there is no guarantee that (A)'. This expression utilizes the case marking particle と in its use for highlighting results, the adverbial particle は, and the negated form of the う - Verb 限(かぎ)る 'to limit'. This structure may be used with verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives, or nouns. However, だ will be required after な-Adjectives and nouns. 限(かぎ)らない literally means 'to not be bound', or 'to not be limited'. Therefore, despite と highlighting a result, that result is then being clarified as 'not the only possibility'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本に２年間住んでいるからといって、日本語を話せるとは限らない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because someone lives in Japan for two years does not necessarily mean that they can speak Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日が出てても暖かいとは限らない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because the sun is out, doesn't necessarily mean that it is warm.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田舎でも静かだとは限らない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A place being rural doesn't necessarily mean that it is quiet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社長だからといって乗っている車が高級車だとは限らない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not limited to him driving a luxury car, just because he is the CEO.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: にわとりは鳥ですが、飛べるとは限りません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A chicken is a bird, but it does not necessarily mean it can fly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰もがお寿司が好きだとは限らない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not everyone necessarily likes sushi.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たとえどんなに緻密な計画を立てても、うまくいくとは限らない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter how detailed your plan, it is not guaranteed to go well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君の言うことがいつも正しいとは限らないでしょ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The things you say are not necessarily always right.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強ができても、頭がいいとは限らない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just because one is good at studying, doesn't necessarily mean that he (she) is smart.

Name: 滅多(めった)に〜ない
Meaning: Hardly, Rarely, Seldom
About: めったに～ない is an expression that may be translated as 'hardly', 'seldom', or 'rarely'. Originally, 滅多(めった) is a な-Adjective that means 'thoughtless', or 'reckless'. Due to this, as an adverb, 滅多(めった)に literally means 'thoughtlessly' or 'recklessly'. めったに～ない will usually be paired with a verb in the negative form, or following a noun, and the adverbial particle は.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大人になってから駄菓子屋にはめったに行かない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ever since I became an adult. I hardly go to candy stores.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 親とは正月以外にはめったに会わない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Other than New Years, I hardly see my parents.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんなチャンスはめったにないぞ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A chance like this is very rare.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パーティーに行くことはめったにない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I rarely go to parties.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は何か大事が起きない限り、電話はめったに掛けない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Unless something big happens, I don't mindlessly make phone calls.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家の誰かがテレビを見ていない限り、自分からはテレビをめったに見ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Unless someone in my house is watching TV, I don't aimlessly watch TV on my own.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 父は滅多にテレビを見ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My father rarely watches TV.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんなにいい話しは滅多にない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Such a nice story is rarely (heard).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 滅多に泣かない彼が泣いていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He, who hardly cries, was crying. (seldom・rarely)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕のおじいちゃんは滅多に笑わない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My grandpa seldom smiles.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は滅多に忘れないのに、今日はどうしたんだろう？
Questions.EnglishHTML: He rarely forgets, I wonder what happened today?

Name: 割(わり)に
Meaning: Although, Despite, Rather...for, Unexpectedly, Comparatively, Considering
About: As an adverb, 割(わり)に is usually used in a similar way to 'although', 'despite', or 'comparatively' in English. 割(わり)に may be used at the beginning of a sentence, or after any word/phrase that it is highlighting as being 'comparative'. When following な-Adjectives or nouns, な or の will be required. 割(わり) itself is a noun meaning 'proportionate', and is primarily used as a suffix. 割(わり)に may be thought of as a direct extension of this use, as 'proportionately' is its closest literal meaning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この肉、高い割には味がないね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although this meat is expensive, it is not flavorful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 太っている割には運動神経がいいんだね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although you are fat, you are very athletic, aren't you?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この機械のパワーは強い割にめちゃくちゃ遅いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although this machine is very powerful, it is very slow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この部屋は綺麗な割には臭いね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although this room is clean, it smells bad.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ラッシュアワーの割には空いていますね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although it is during rush hour, the road is very clear.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これ割と美味しいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is unexpectedly tasty.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日買った包丁は割といい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The knife I bought yesterday is quite good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は冬の割に暖かい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Today is rather warm for winter.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 高い食べ物の割に、美味しくなさそう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The expensive food looks unexpectedly unappetizing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私はたくさん勉強した割に、テストの点数が悪かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although I studied a lot, I got a bad score on the test.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人は頭が良い割に、コミュニケーションが苦手です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although that person is smart, he is bad at communication.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 疲れている割には、かなり動けた方だと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think he is quite active for how tired he is.

Name: う・よう + とする
Meaning: Try to, Attempt to, To be about to
About: When combined with the auxiliary verb う (or よう), とする carries the meaning of 'to try to do (A)', or 'to be about to do (A)'. The case marking particle と in this expression highlights a 'result'. To use おうとする, modify the (A) verb into its う or よう receiving form, and then add とする. As う and よう mark volition (the express intent to do something), とする adds the nuance that the express intent has been decided, and all that remains is to 'do' the action. This translates quite closely to 'to endeavor to do' in English, where the past form 'endeavored to do' will suggest that the attempt was unsuccessful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この子はなんでも食べようとするから、お菓子は隠してね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This one will try to eat anything, so please hide any snacks.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生が話している間に帰ろうとすると、先生に怒られる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you try to go home while the teacher is talking, he will yell at you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年は毎日日本語の勉強をしようとしたが、時間がなくて出来なかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I tried to study Japanese everyday this year, but I couldn't because I didn't have time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: クラスメイトのスズキさんに話し掛けようとしたけど、緊張し過ぎて話せなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I tried to talk to my classmate, Suzuki-san, but I got so nervous that I couldn't.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家を出ようとしたら、急に雨が降り始めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It suddenly started to rain when I was about to leave the house.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部屋が暗かったから電気を点けようとしたら、妻に電気を点けるなと言われた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As I tried to turn on the lights in my room because it was dark, my wife told me not to.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一度に二つのことをしようとするな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Don't try to do two things at once.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ひよこは親のように飛ぼうとしても、できなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though the chick attempted to fly like its parents, it couldn't.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 答えようとしたのに、隣の人に遮られた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I tried to answer but the person next to me cut me off.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 見ようとしたわけではないのに、見えてしまいました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though I tried not to look, I inevitably saw it. (It's not like I tried to look)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は止めようとしたのに、言うことを聞いてくれないんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I attempted to stop them, but they won't listen to what I say.

Name: う・よう + としたが
Meaning: Tried to ~ but ~, Was about to ~ but ~, Was going to ~ but ~
About: As mentioned in our ようとする lesson, when combined with the auxiliary verb う (or よう), とする carries the meaning of 'to try to do (A)', or 'to be about to do (A)'. The case marking particle と in this expression highlights a 'result'. However, the addition of structures like the conjunction particles が, or たら, to the past tense of する will indicate that something interrupted (A), and therefore it was unable to be completed. In these cases, the translation becomes 'to have tried to do (A), but (B)', 'was about to (A), but (B), or 'was on the verge of (A), but (B)'. う and よう mark volition (the express intent to do something), while とする adds the nuance that the express intent has been decided, and all that remains is to 'do' the action. Due to this, when something interrupts a ようとする verb, it strongly suggests that (B) is/was highly unanticipated.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: クライアントに電話を掛けようとしたが、夜遅かったので朝まで待つことにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I tried to make a phone call to our client, but it was late at night so I decided to wait until morning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 池で泳ごうとしたら、警察に止められた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was stopped by the police when I was about to swim in the lake.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 逃げようとしたけど、捕まったら大変なことになるから逃げなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was about to run away, but if I got caught, it would have become a bigger deal, so I didn't.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 兎の世話をしようとしたが逃げられた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was going to take care of the rabbit but it ran away.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は徹夜しようとしたけれど寝てしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He tried to pull an all-nighter, but fell asleep.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 説得しようとしたが、失敗した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I tried to persuade him, but I failed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お弁当を食べようとしたが、箸が入っていなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was about to eat my bento, but there were no chopsticks inside.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は彼女の手伝いをしようとしたが、断られた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I tried to help her, but was rejected.

Name: 言(い)うまでもない ②
Meaning: It goes without saying, It is needless to say, Of course, Obviously
About: Unlike は言(い)うまでもない, which usually comes after other phrases, 言(い)うまでもない tends to come at the beginning. It is a structure that combines the う - Verb 言(い)う, two (2) adverbial particles まで and も, and the い-Adjective ない. This is regularly translated as 'it goes without saying that (A)', or 'it is needless to say (A)', where (A) is whatever comes later in the sentence. 言(い)うまでもない is often followed directly by ことだが, が, けど, and similar expressions, to add the nuance of 'but'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 言うまでもないことだが、毎日漢字の勉強をすれば、どんどん漢字を覚えることができる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying that if you practice kanji everyday, you will steadily memorize them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電化製品を使っている間、言うまでもないが、濡れた手や水の周りで使うのは危険だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While you are using electronics, it is needless to say that it is dangerous to use them with wet hands or around water.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 言うまでもないけど、君に会えて良かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying, but I am glad that I met you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 言うまでもないことだが、お酒を飲んで運転をしてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Obviously, you should not drink and drive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 言うまでもないけど、それが恋だった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying, but that was love.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 言うまでもなくもうこんなこと知ってるよね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying that you already know this, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: しかし、言うまでもなく、私たちはいつものように負けた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: However, it goes without saying, we lost just as always.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 言うまでもないことだが、文章を読みやすくするために、括弧は使われている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying that brackets are used to make reading easier.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: さだおさんの妻のえみさんは英語は言うまでもなく、韓国語も話せます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Sadao-san's wife, Emi-san can speak Korean, not to mention English.

Name: そうもない
Meaning: Very unlikely to, Does not seem that, Does not appear that
About: そうもない is an expression used with verbs in Japanese, to indicate that some particular action is very unlikely. It is a combination of the auxiliary verb そう, the adverbial particle も, and the い-Adjective ない. To recap, one of the primary uses of そう is to highlight appearance. Therefore, そうもない literally means 'to not even appear like (A)'. This structure will be used after verbs in their conjunctive form.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 腕がまだ治っていないから、あと一週間ぐらい運動が出来そうもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My arm hasn't healed yet, so it is very unlikely that I will exercise for another week.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は雷が酷いから、釣りに行けそうもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since the thunder is very bad today, it does not even appear like I can go fishing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな量、食べられそうもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This amount, it doesn't even seem like I can eat it! (There is way too much to even seem possible to eat)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は１１時まで帰って来ないかもしれないから、いつも見ているテレビ番組が見られそうもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today, I might not be coming home until 11, so I might not be able to watch the show I always watch.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今回のテストは受かりそうもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is very unlikely I will pass the test this time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このテーブルは重たいから、一人で運べそうもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since this table is so heavy, it's very unlikely that I'll be able to carry it by myself.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人、僕の意見を聞いてくれそうもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is very unlikely that that person will listen to my opinion.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんなすごい技、僕にはできそうもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's very unlikely that I will be able to perform such a cool trick.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 予報は雨だけど、全然降りそうもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The forecast predicted rain, but it doesn't appear that it will rain at all.

Name: ない事(こと)はない
Meaning: Is not impossible, It doesn't mean that it isn't
About: ないことはない is an expression that utilizes either the auxiliary verb ない, or the い-Adjective ない, depending on what type of word it is used with. This structure may literally be translated as something similar to 'not (A) is not all there is'. However, the common translations are '(A) is not impossible', or 'it doesn't mean that it isn't (A)'. This expression may be used with the ない form of any verb, い-Adjective, or な-Adjective. Let's have a look at a few examples before exploring the meaning further. By itself, ことはない highlights something that is unneeded, or never happens. This is partly due to the adverbial particle は expressing something as being 'complete'. In this way, 'there is no situation in which (A)', is quite an accurate translation of ことはない. By adding ない to the (A) verb, all ないことはない is doing is simply changing this nuance to 'there is -not- no situation in which (A)', a double negative expressing that (A) is actually possible.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 映画は見ないことはないが、詳しくもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that I don't watch movies, but I am just not knowledgeable about them at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここは危なくないことはないから、気をつけた方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that this place isn't dangerous, so you should be careful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 元気ではないことはないけど、すごく元気なわけでもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It doesn't mean that I am not healthy, but it is not the case that I am very fit.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 納豆は食べられないことはないけど、自分から買って食べようとは思わない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that I don't like natto, it's just that I don't think I will buy it myself to eat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 歩いていけないことはないけど、歩いたら６時間ぐらいかかるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that you can't walk there, but if you did, it would take about six hours.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「浅いからここで泳ごう！」
Ｂ：「浅いけど、危なくない事はない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'It's shallow so let's swim here!'
B: 'It is shallow, but that doesn't mean that it isn't dangerous.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
清水：「昨年買ったドレスを着たら、どう？」
木村：「着れない事はないが、少しサイズが小さいな。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Shimizu: 'What about wearing the dress you bought last year?'
Kimura: 'It's not that I can't wear it, but it's a bit too small…'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
林：「怪我はないか？歩ける？」
森：「歩いて行けない事はないんですが、かなりゆっくりですね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Hayashi: 'Are you hurt? Can you walk?'
Mori: 'It's not that I can't walk, but I'll be quite slow…'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
小川：「ビットコインのことを何か知ってるの？」
村上：「何も知らない事はないが、詳しくもない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Ogawa: 'Do you know anything about bitcoin?'
Murakami: 'It's not that I don't know anything, but I am not familiar either.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「お金がないから君と一緒に旅行にいけないんだ。」
Ｂ：「お金がなくても旅行に行けない事はないよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'I don't have money so I can't go on a trip with you.'
B: 'It is not impossible to take a trip without any money.'

Name: なんて
Meaning: Such as, Things like, Emphasis
About: なんか is an expression in Japanese that is frequently associated with the adverbial particle など. They are thought to have overlapping meanings in many circumstances, and なんか itself may be considered an adverbial particle. なんて is an extension of this, and may be considered an abbreviation of などという 'to say something like'. Both なんか and なんて are used in the same way as など, having translations like 'such as', and 'things like' in English. The primary difference between なんか and なんて is that なんて is far more common after 用言(ようげん) (conjugatable words). This includes verbs, い-Adjectives, and な-Adjectives. On the other hand, なんか is almost exclusively used after 体言(たいげん) (unconjugatable words). In other words, nouns. Despite the 体言(たいげん) and 用言(ようげん) tendency, most native speakers will not consider it incorrect to use either なんか or なんて with any type of word.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな嵐の中走るなんて、頭おかしいんじゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are going to do something like run in the storm? You must be crazy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 北海道がこんなに寒いなんておもわなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I didn't think Hokkaido would be this cold or anything.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 心配なんてしている場合じゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is no time for things such as worrying.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: テレビなんか叩けばだいたい直るだろ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Things like TV's will be fixed most of the time if you hit them, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私なんか５年間スペイン語の勉強をしているのにまだ全然会話ができないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have studied Spanish for 5 years, but I can't speak it at all yet. (Humility)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前なんてどうせ、家でゴロゴロしているだけだろ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Someone like you probably just loafs around the house, don't you? (Insult)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 酷いことを言ったのは分かるんだけど、なんか、情熱的になって言っちゃった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am aware that I said something mean, but, you know, I said it because I got emotional.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人生なんてそんなもんさ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Such is life.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お世辞なんて大嫌いだ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: I hate things like flattery!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嘘なんかつかないよ。信じてよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I would never do something like lie to you. Trust me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私が太っているなんて言わないで。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Don't say things like I am fat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕には道案内なんてできませんよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am unable to do things like give directions.

Name: 又(また)〜も
Meaning: Moreover, Additionally, And also, In addition, Furthermore, Or
About: 又(また)～も is a combination of the adverb 又(また), a noun, and the adverbial particle も. It can be translated as 'moreover', 'additionally', or 'furthermore'. As も is being used, whatever is being said in (B) will usually be new information. To use 又(また)～も, an (A) phrase will be stated, before 又(また) will open the (B) phrase, and then be followed by a noun + も. Instead of も, でも or ても may be used for extra emphasis.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このキーボードはピアノの音が出せる。また、ギターの音も出せる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This keyboard can make piano sounds. Additionally, it can produce guitar sounds.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この電子レンジはオーブンとして使えて、またトースターとしても使える。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This microwave can be used as an oven, additionally, it can be used as a toaster.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ササキ先生は理科の先生です。また、地理の先生でもある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sasaki-sensei is a science teacher. She is also a geography teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私達は何でも買います。また、古くても買い取ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We will buy anything. Moreover, we will buy it even if it's old.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 犬はイヌ科である。又、狐もイヌ科である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Dogs are canidae. Additionally, foxes are also canidae.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その詩は悲しく、又、感動させる文学でもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That poem is sad, additionally, it is also a touching piece of literature.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このアプリはＪＰＧファイルを読み、又、ＰＮＧファイルも読む。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This application reads JPG files, in addition, it also reads PNG files.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 燕尾服を着てもよいです。又、スーツを着てもよいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You can wear a tailcoat. Additionally, you can also wear a suit.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は有名な歌手であり、又、腕のいい外科医でもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is a famous singer, additionally, he is also a skilled surgeon.

Name: 序(つい)でに
Meaning: While you are at it, On the occasion
About: 序(つい)でに is an adverb in Japanese that is used in a similar way to 'while you're at it', or 'on the occasion of (A)' in English. 序(つい)で itself is a noun that means 'precedence' (in terms of being the first thing to happen). Due to this, the literal meaning of 序(つい)でに may be thought of as 'with (A) as the precedence, (B)'. 序(つい)でに is commonly used with verbs, or nouns. In the case of nouns, it will need to be preceded by the case marking particle の.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 買い物に行くついでに、郵便局に行ってこの荷物を出しておいてくれる？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Can you bring these packages to the post office while you go shopping?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 散歩のついでに寄って行ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please go and visit while you are on a walk.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お母さんの所にテレビを返しに行くのでしょう？序でにこの、私が作った梅酒を持って行って。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are going to go to your mothers place to give back the TV you borrowed, right? While you're at it, can you take the Umeshu I made?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達を家に送ったついでに、床屋に行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the way back from driving my friend home, I went to the barber. (One-off occurrence)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 旦那はいつも、私が寝てる間に帰ってくる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My husband always comes back while I am sleeping. (Regular occurrence)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は晴れているときに出かける。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go out when it is sunny. (Regular occurrence)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 序でに君の分も払ってあげるよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While I am at it, I will pay for your share too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 序でに君の車も洗ってあげようか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: While I am at it, do you want me to wash your car too?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここまで来たなら序でにうちにも寄ってよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: On the occasion of coming this far, why don't you drop by my house?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 話の序でに言っておきたいことがあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While I am on the subject, I want to tell you something.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 給油の序でに車を点検してもらいました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While I was refueling, I also had my car checked.

Name: と共(とも)に
Meaning: Together with, At the same time,  As well as
About: 共(とも) is a noun in Japanese that is frequently used as a either a prefix, or a suffix. In the case of と共(とも)に, it is used in conjunction with the case marking particle と as an adverb. と共(とも)に expresses that (A) will happen 'together with (B)', or 'at the same time as (B)'. と共(とも)に may be used after verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives or nouns. With な-Adjectives, it will sometimes be preceded by である.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 風が強くなると共に雨が降ってきます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As the wind gets strong, it will start to rain.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの先生は厳しいが、厳しいと共に優しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That teacher is strict, but as strict as he is, he is also very kind.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 僕が住んでいる場所は静かであると共に、空気が綺麗だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The place I live is very quiet, together with the air being clean.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私と共に人生を歩んでくれませんか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Would you please walk together with me forever. (歩（あゆ）む is a poetic way of saying 'to walk' that often means 'to travel a passage')

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 年を取ると共に、身体がどんどん硬くなってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As I get older, I am starting to get less flexible.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この池は綺麗であると共に、危険である。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This lake is beautiful and dangerous at the same time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 風と共に去りぬ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Gone with the Wind.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 心身と共に健康だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am healthy physically, as well as mentally.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夜明けと共に旅立った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (I) departed with the break of dawn. (together with)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 驚きと共に喜びが溢れ出してきた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am becoming overwhelmed with surprise coupled with delight.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は今でも父と共に仕事をしています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I still work together with my father.

Name: に連(つ)れて
Meaning: As…then, In proportion to, (Along) with
About: につれて, or に連(つ)れて when using kanji, is an expression that may be translated as 'as (A), then (B)', or 'in proportion to (A), (B)'. It is formed through the use of the case marking particle に, the る - Verb 連(つ)れる 'to take along', and the conjunction particle て. Literally, the translation is similar to 'being taken along with (A), (B)', or 'in tow with (A), (B)'. につれて will be used after the plain, non-past form of verbs, or nouns. As 連(つ)れる is a transitive verb, (A) につれて (B) implies that (A) is causing (B) to happen simultaneously. This does not have to be something that (A) is purposely doing (although it may be), just a 'domino' type effect, where (A) is considered the instigator.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日運転をするにつれて、どんどん運転が嫌いになってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Along with driving everyday, I am starting to dislike it more and more.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夏になるにつれて、日が昇るのが早くなってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Along with it becoming summer, the time the sun comes up is getting earlier.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犬の成長につれて、食欲が変わる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As the dog grows, how much he eats changes (in proportion).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 時代の変化につれて、食文化も変わる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As the times change, food culture also changes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冬になるにつれて、太陽が沈む時間が早くなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Along with it becoming winter, the time the sun sets gets earlier. (Natural, as winter directly affects the time the sun sets)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冬になるにつれて、犬が成長していく。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In tow with it becoming winter, the dog grows more. (Unnatural, as there is no relationship)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日がたつに連れて、怪我が悪化してきた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As the days go by, my injury gets worse and worse.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こちらの木が大きくなるに連れて、影が広がります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As these trees grow tall, their shade spreads.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供は、成長するに連れて、性格が変わる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Along with their growth, the personality of children changes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 進むに連れて道がどんどん狭くなるから心配になってきた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As I continued on, the road grew increasingly more narrow, so I started to feel anxious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 経済の発展に連れて一般市民の日常生活は良くなっていく。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As the economy develops, the daily life of citizens improves.

Name: 直(ただ)ちに
Meaning: At once, Immediately, As soon as
About: The adverb  直(ただ)ちに is commonly used in Japanese to convey that something is happening 'immediately', or 'at once'. Like many adverbs, it will regularly appear at the beginning of a sentence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 直ちに避難所へ向かってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please head to the evacuation point immediately.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この山から、 直ちに出て行ってください。ここは私有地です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please leave this mountain at once. This is private property.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 地震が起きたら直ちに家を出てください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If an earthquake occurs, please leave the house immediately.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 計画が変わったら、直ちに報告してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If the plan changes, please notify me immediately. (Intentional)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このファッションは忽ち世界で広まった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This fashion spread around the world immediately. (Unintentional)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 効果は直ちに現れるわけではありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The effect will not become immediately apparent.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 直ちに安定した仕事を見つけなければ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I must find a stable job at once.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この案件は直ちに対応する必要がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is necessary to deal with this problem immediately.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 結果が出たら直ちにお伝えします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will tell you as soon as the results are available.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 急ごう。直ちに出発した方がいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's hurry. We'd better leave at once.

Name: た途端(とたん)に
Meaning: The instant or moment, As soon as, Just as
About: たとたんに, frequently seen using its kanji form た途端(とたん)に is a structure used to convey that something happens 'the instant', or 'the moment' that something else occurs. It is a combination of the auxiliary verb た (indicating the completion of a verb), and the noun 途端(とたん) 'on the tip of' used adverbially (with に). (A) た途端(とたん)に (B) is used to express (B) things that are beyond the control of the speaker, and may be considered strange, or unexpected. As 途端(とたん) literally means 'on the tip of', any (B) action is considered to happen either directly upon (A), or even simultaneously with (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高速に乗った途端に、タイヤがパンクした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The moment I got on the highway, my tire got punctured.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 布団に入った途端に先輩から電話がかかってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The moment I got into my futon, I received a call from my senpai.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 出た途端に、雨が降り始めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The instant I went outside, it began to rain.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 帰ろうとした途端、仕事を頼まれた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just as I was about to leave, I was given more work to do.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 青になった途端に飛び出すのは危ないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's dangerous to speed off the instant (a traffic light) turns (became) green.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 家に入った途端呼び鈴が鳴った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just as I got into the house, the doorbell rang.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女を見た途端に恋をしてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I fell in love the instant I saw her.

Name: 置(お)きに
Meaning: Repeated at intervals, Every other, Every, At intervals of
About: 置(お)きに  is  a combination of 置(お)き, a suffix meaning 'opening' or 'interval', and the case marking particle に. Primarily written without kanji, it is an expression used to show that something happens 'every (A)', or 'at intervals of (A)'. The difference between something being interpreted as 'every', or 'at intervals of' can be tricky though, so we'll look at both. Due to おきに being a suffix, it will be attached to the end of numbers, counters, or any 'space' that it is highlighting as being an 'opening' or 'interval'. Looking at these sentences, we can see that the 'interval' is a bit difficult to understand even in English. However, the easier way to think of おきに in this sense is 'leaving a space of (A), (B)'. So if we say 'leaving a space of two days, (B)', it becomes a bit clearer that something is happening during the third day.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この薬は一日おきに飲んでください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please drink this medicine at intervals of one day. (Every second day)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一ヶ月おきに病院に来るように先生に言われました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was told by the doctor to come to the hospital at intervals of one month. (Every second month)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 二日おきに部屋の掃除をしないと気が落ち着かない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't relax if I don't clean my room at intervals of two days. (Every three days)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一日ごとに目薬を差す。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I use my eye drops every day. (It doesn't matter what part of the day, but it does happen every day)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一日おきに目薬を差す。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I use my eye drops every second day. (It makes sense to wonder when it may occur during the second day, but we know it doesn't happen for at least an interval of one whole day)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日２時間ごとに体を動かしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I move my body every two hours, every day. (At some point during every group of 2 hours)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日２時間おきに体を動かしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I move my body every two hours, every day. (After every interval of two hours. Nobody cares about 'when during the third hour', so we just understand it as 'every two hours')

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ３０分置きに休憩しよう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's take a break in intervals of 30 minutes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 約３分置きに電車が来ます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Trains come about every 3 minutes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １時間置きに温度を測ってください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please check the temperature every other hour.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ５０メートル置きに自動販売機がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are vending machines every 50 meters.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 階段を一段置きに飛ばして上がる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He goes up the stairs skipping every second step.

Name: 度(たび)に
Meaning: Each time, Every time, Whenever
About: 度(たび)に is the adverbial form of the noun 度(たび), meaning 'time' (as in 'at the time of'). たびに is frequently paired with either verbs, or nouns, in order to show that something happens 'whenever (A)', or 'each time (A)'. After nouns, the case marking particle の will be required before たびに.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカ君と飲みに行くたびに、二日酔いになる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every time I go out to drink with Tanaka-kun, I get a hangover.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 牛乳を飲むたびにお腹が痛くなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every time I drink milk, I get a stomach ache.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は休みのたびにハワイへ行きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whenever I have a holiday, I go to Hawaii.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は洗い物のたびに指を切る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every time he does the dishes, he cuts his finger.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事を休むたびに、雨が降って予定が台無しになる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every time I take a day off, it rains and messes up my plans. (Natural Japanese, as たびに follows an action)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ２週間たびに、実家に帰る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every two weeks, I go to my parents house. (Unnatural Japanese, as たびに does not follow an action. ２（に）週間（しゅうかん）経（た）つたびに would work here)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君は会う度に大人になってゆく。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Every time I see you, I see how much you have matured.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この映画を見る度に、泣いてしまう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Every time I watch this movie, I cry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 旅行の度に、いい思い出を作ろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's make good memories each time we take a trip.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 冬の間は、休みの度にスキーに行っています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I go skiing every holiday in winter.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 買い物へ行く度に、いらないものを買っちゃう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whenever I go shopping I buy things I don't need.

Name: 或(あ)るいは
Meaning: Or, Possibly, Maybe, Perhaps, Or possibly
About: あるいは is a construction in Japanese that is used as a 接続語(せつぞくご) (conjunction). It usually appears after statements that have been marked with the adverbial particle か. あるいは may be loosely translated as 'possibly', 'maybe', or 'or'. Although usually being treated as a single word, あるいは is actually a combination of the attributive form of 或(あ)る, a verb meaning 'a certain', the suffix character い (used for making い-Adjectives), and the adverbial particle は. Due to this, the literal meaning of あるいは is just 'another possibility', as it highlights a certain something existing within the same area/category as (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運動をさせるかあるいは餌を減らしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please make them exercise or possibly lessen the amount of food.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パソコンの動作が遅いかあるいは電源が点かなくなった場合は、私達が直します。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In the event that the computer gets slow or doesn't turn on, we will fix it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 有名かあるいは綺麗であれば誰でも入れるらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that if you are famous or maybe beautiful, anyone can get in.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 土曜日かあるいは日曜日までには終わらせておきます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will try to have it finished by either Saturday or possibly Sunday.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 牛乳あるいはチーズが使われている料理は食べられません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't eat anything that uses milk, or another possibility is cheese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 月曜日あるいは火曜日に新しい生徒が来ます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A new student will come on either Monday, or another possibility is Tuesday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 鍋或いは深めのフライパンを使いましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's use a pot or a deep frying pan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 動画或いは写真でもいいので送ってください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please send me video or pictures, anything is ok.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 月曜日或いは火曜日であれば、参加できます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it is Monday or Tuesday, I can attend.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 植物或いは昆虫を観察しましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's observe some plants or bugs.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 晴れ或いは曇りであれば、お祭りに行きましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether it is sunny or cloudy, let's go to the festival.

Name: ながらも
Meaning: But, Even while, Even though, Despite, Although
About: ながらも is a combination of the conjunction particle ながら, and the adverbial particle も. Coming from the kanji 乍(なが)ら, with the meaning of 'while', ながら almost always keeps this nuance. Because of this, ながらも can be translated as 'even while (A), (B)', or 'although (A), also (B)'. ながらも usually expresses surprise at the coexistence of (A) and (B), and may be used after い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives, nouns, or the conjunctive form of verbs. ながらも is used to highlight a thing that comes after the existing state of (A) 'そのままで後(あと)に続(つづ)く事(こと)'. Due to this, ながらも may only be used with verbs that highlight states of existence (like feelings), rather than ongoing actions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 才能を持ちながらも、彼は色々と苦労した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although he is talented, he struggled with various things.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は悲しみを感じながらも、笑顔で友達に話しました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even while she was sad, she talked with her friends with a smile on her face.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は料理が苦手ながらも、一生懸命作りました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although he is not good at cooking, he gave it his all and cooked.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私達は貧乏ながらも、定期的にコンサートへ行っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although we are poor, we go to concerts every now and then.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 「こんなことしちゃだめだ」と思いながらもやってしまった。 (Action)
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even while I thought to myself, 'I shouldn't do something like this,' I did it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 緊張しながらも、初めての舞台でのびのびと歌うことが出来た。 (Feeling)
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although I was nervous, I was able to sing comfortably at my first concert.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: すこし狭い乍らも楽しい我が家。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although it is a bit small, it is a happy home. (even while)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「やらなきゃいけない」と思い乍らもダラダラしてしまう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite thinking 'I have to do it', I just end up idling around. (even while)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 不本意乍らも、従うしかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although I am unwilling, I have no other choice but to obey. (even while)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 足を引きずり乍らも、マラソンを完走しました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite my legs turning to jelly, I finished the marathon. (even while)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 良くないと知ってい乍らも、注意することができませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite knowing that it was not right, I just couldn't warn them. (even while)

Name: に於(お)いて
Meaning: In, On, At, Regarding, In terms of
About: において is a combination of the case marking particle に in, and the 接続語(せつぞくご) (conjunction) おいて. Either 於(お)いて, or 於(お)ける may be used, with no difference in meaning. において itself is usually translated as 'at', 'in', 'on', or 'regarding'. において (or における) will be used after nouns, or when connecting one noun to another. In the case of connecting one noun to another, における, or においての will be required. においての (and における) are primarily used in formal language, and will not commonly be used in daily speech.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 現代において、インターネットなしの生活は考えられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In this day and age, it is impossible to think of a life without the internet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自分の住んでいる地域における、井戸水の汚染について研究をしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am doing research regarding pollution in wells in the area that I am living in.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはこの工事においての難しい作業になります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is the most difficult work in terms of this construction.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田舎における高齢化の問題は深刻です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The aging population in the countryside is very serious.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本においての、電車やバスなしの生活は考えられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Within the scope of Japan, it is impossible to think of a life without buses or trains.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 会社においての、パワハラについてのミーティングが行われた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A meeting was held regarding power harassment within the scope of our company.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 数に於いては劣っているが、力に於いては負けていない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although we are fewer in numbers, we aren't losing in strength.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大都市に於ける渋滞の問題は深刻だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The problem of traffic jams in big cities is serious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この文脈に於いての「空」は、「そら」ではなく「から」だと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think this kanji is read 'kara' rather than 'sora' in this context.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 現代に於いて、電気のない生活は考えられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In this day and age, it is impossible to think of life without electricity.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 東京に於ける環境についての会議を行います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A meeting concerning the environment will take place in Tokyo.

Name: 第一(だいいち)
Meaning: Start, First (point), Foremost, To begin with
About: 第一(だいいち) is an expression in Japanese which may be used either as an adverb, or as a noun. As a noun, it will carry the meaning of 'foremost', or 'most important'. As an adverb, it can mean 'first', or 'above anything'. To use 第一(だいいち) adverbially, pair it with に. As a noun, it will usually be followed by の (when connecting nouns), or by the auxiliary verb だ, when at the end of a sentence. に will often be omitted when there is no need to put specific emphasis on a time. Occasionally, まず 'first of all' will be paired with 第一(だいいち). This may seem redundant, but is like saying 'the very first' in English.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 第一彼は何であんな時間にここにいたんだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: First of all, why was he here at that time?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはここの第一のルールだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is the number one rule here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お金よりも健康でいることが第一だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: More than money, being healthy is the most important thing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まず第一にこの計画を担当する人を決めましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Firstly, let's pick the person that will be in charge of this plan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 安全は第一だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Safety first.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 第一節第一款検察官の義務等。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Section 1, Subsection 1, Duties of public prosecutor, etc. (one・first)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ハグ・クラブルールの第一、ハグ・クラブのことを明かすな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The first rule of Hug Club is: you do not talk about Hug Club.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: オリンピック選手になるには、優れた身体能力が第一条件だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The first condition to become an Olympic athlete is outstanding physical ability.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 第一章：「自動販売機として生まれ変わった日。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chapter 1: 'The day I got reincarnated as a vending machine.'

Name: 益々(ますます)
Meaning: Increasingly, More and more, Decreasingly, Less and less, Keep -ing
About: When using the adverb ますます, it will have the meaning of 'increasingly', 'more and more', or even 'to keep (A)ing'. It is used to emphasize continuous trends, and will regularly be seen at the beginning of a sentence. Occasionally, the kanji form 益々(ますます) will be used. This will not change the nuance at all. The kanji 益(えき) simply means 'gain'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 良いにおいだね。この匂いを嗅いでるとますますお腹が空いてくる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That smells good, doesn't it? I am going to get more and more hungry if I keep smelling it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は成長するにつれて、ますます美しくなっています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She is getting more and more beautiful as she develops.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 年を取るにつれて、益々目が悪くなっていくよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As I get older, my eyes are getting worse (and worse).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日日本語の勉強をしているので、ますます日本語が話せるようになってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I am studying Japanese everyday, I am able to speak more and more.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冬になってから、ますます涼しくなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since becoming winter, it has become more and more brisk.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事が忙しくて、ますます子供と過ごす時間が減っていく。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because work is so busy, I have less and less time to spend with my children.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コロナのせいで観光客がますます減って行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because of Covid, the number of tourists becoming less and less.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 益々寒さが厳しくなってまいりました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's growing increasingly colder.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 景気は益々悪くなるばかりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The economy is getting worse and worse.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 商売は益々繁盛している。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My business is more and more prosperous.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 益々責任が重くなってきた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My responsibilities are getting more and more difficult to bear.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 水不足が益々深刻になってきている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The water shortage is growing more and more severe.

Name: 一方(いっぽう)だ
Meaning: More and more, Continue to, Keep on, -er and -er
About: 一方(いっぽう) is a noun that is often seen after verbs, in order to convey the meaning of 'more and more (A)', 'continuing to (A)', or 'getting (A)er and (A)er'. 一方(いっぽう) will be paired with the auxiliary verb だ (at the end of sentences), or で, だ's conjunctive form when it will be followed by some sort of explanation. As the literal meaning of 一方(いっぽう) is 'single direction', it may be used with things that are increasing, decreasing, intensifying, or weakening, so long as the shift is all in a single direction.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アメリカとロシアの関係は悪化する一方だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The relationship between the US and Russia keeps on getting worse.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事の量が増える一方で、休みが取れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because the amount of work keeps on increasing, I can't take a day off.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高齢化が進んで、人口が減る一方だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because of the aging society, the population continues to decline. (Natural)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供が怪我をして泣く一方だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The child cries in one direction because he got injured. (Unnatural)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 災害は増える一方です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: More and more disasters happen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会社の財政は厳しくなる一方だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The financial situation of the company continues to get more and more strict.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うちの町の人口は減る一方だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The population of my town keeps on decreasing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このままだと借金が増える一方だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I keep going on like this, my debts will continue to increase.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 残念ながらこんな事件が増える一方だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Unfortunately, there are more and more cases like these.

Name: 一方(いっぽう)で
Meaning: On the other hand, At the same time, While
About: 一方(いっぽう)で is a combination of the noun 一方(いっぽう) 'one direction', and the case marking particle で, in its nuance as 'at'. Together, they are used in a similar way to a conjunction particle, carrying the meaning of 'on the other hand', 'at the same time', or 'while'. 一方(いっぽう)で may be used after the attributive form of other words, or at the beginning of new phrases. As 一方(いっぽう)で has a literal meaning similar to 'at the (A) side', or 'in the (A) direction', it is expressing that another direction also exists, which may then be compared or contrasted with (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は関西は晴れる一方で、関東では雨が降るそうです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While today will be sunny in Kansai, I hear that it will rain in Kanto.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 甘えるのが好きな猫がいる一方で、人間を警戒する猫も多くいます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are cats that like being affectionate, but on the other hand, there are also lots of cats that are wary of people.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田舎は、日中は静かな一方で、夜になると虫やカエルの鳴き声でうるさいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The countryside is very quiet during the daytime, but on the other hand, the calls of insects and frogs are annoying once it's night.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は歌手である一方で、政治家でもある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is a singer, while at the same time, a politician.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一方で、長野県では夏祭りが開催される。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the other hand, the summer festival will be held in Nagano Prefecture. (The previous sentence would have had some contradictory information)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私のお金は貯まっていく一方で、彼のお金は減っていくばかりです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My savings is increasing, but on the other hand, his savings continue to decline.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎月お金が減っていく一方で、全然貯まりそうもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every month I keep losing money, and it doesn't even seem like it will increase.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この靴は、温かい一方で、重いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: These shoes are warm but on the other hand they are heavy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの食べ物は体に良い一方で、食べ過ぎたら、体に悪い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: On the one hand, that food is good for your body. On the other hand, if you eat too much, it is bad for you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の会社が儲かる一方で、うちの会社は経営状態が悪化している。
Questions.EnglishHTML: His company seems to be profitable, but, on the other hand, the condition of our administration is growing worse.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友人たちがスキーを楽しむ一方で、私は働かなくてはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My friends are having a fun time skiing, but I, on the other hand, have to work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会社ではいい上司だが、その一方で、家では酒乱だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is a good boss at the company, but, at the same time, he is a violent drunk at home.

Name: 遂(つい)に
Meaning: Finally, At last
About: Like とうとう, 遂(つい)に is an adverb that is frequently used to mean 'finally', or 'at last'. It will usually come at the beginning of a sentence. 遂(つい)に may be seen equally as often with or without kanji. When compared to 到頭(とうとう), ついに is slightly more formal.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遂に日本上陸！！！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Finally it has arrived in Japan!!!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遂にドラゴンズが勝った！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The Dragons have finally won!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遂に最後の日ですね、今まで色々とありがとうございました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Finally it is your last day. Thank you for everything up until now.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: とうとう今日で最後だね。今まで色々とありがとう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's finally your last day. Thank you for everything up until now.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遂に結婚したのか！おめでとう！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You finally married!? Congrats! (Natural)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日貰った袋を遂に捨てた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I finally threw away the bag I bought yesterday. (Unnatural)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遂に論文を書き上げた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I finally finished writing my thesis.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遂に犯人を捕まえることができた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was finally able to catch the criminal.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遂に借金を払い終えた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was finally able to pay off my debt.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遂に孫に身長で負けてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My grandchild outgrew me at last.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女にプロポーズをする日が遂に来た。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The day I propose to her has finally come.

Name: 既(すで)に
Meaning: Already, Too late
About: As a formal alternative to もう, the adverb 既(すで)に is used in Japanese as 'already'. Usually, 既(すで)に will come at the beginning of a phrase that it is clarifying as being 'already (A)'. すでに has several nuances in Japanese beyond just 'already', let's take a look at a few of these possibilities: のこらず - Nothing remaining. あまねく - All around. ことごとく - Altogether. もはや - Already. まぎれもなく - Beyond doubt. These may all seem quite different, but together they show the full meaning of 既(すで)に very clearly. That meaning is 'to be completely unchanging'. Let's take a look at how すでに can be used with each of these nuances.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お湯はすでにわいている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The hot water is already boiled.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: すでにお支払い済みです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It has already been paid for.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もうすでにチケットは売り切れです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The tickets are already sold out. (Nothing remains)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はすでに国民から名前を忘れられている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: His name has already been forgotten by the citizens. (Universal opinion)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はすでにみんなと仲良くなっていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He was already becoming friends with absolutely everyone. (Altogether)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さっき食べたばかりなのに、もうすでにお腹が空いてきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I just ate earlier, but I am already starting to get hungry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはすでに決まった事なので、もう私達じゃ何もできません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is beyond doubt that this has been decided, so we can't do anything about it. (Beyond doubt)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電車はすでに出発しました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The train has left already. (And there is nothing we can do about it)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 時既に遅し。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You are already too late.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電話料金は既に払い終えました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have already paid the telephone bill.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたの席は既にここと決まっています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It has already been decided that your seat will be here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕が来た時には、電気は既につけてあった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The light was already on when I arrived.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 旅行に行くための休みは既に取りました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I had already taken a day off for a trip.

Name: ずに
Meaning: Without doing
About: Although it is not considered to be one of the primary 18 auxiliary verbs that are used in modern Japanese, ず is a classical auxiliary verb that has the same role as ぬ, and ない. This role is negating the verb that it is attached to. ずに is simply the addition of the case marking particle に to ず. Together, they mean 'without doing', in a similar way to ないで. To use ずに, attach it to the indeterminate form of the verb that you wish to express as 'without doing (A)'. This is the same form used with ない. ずに is quite a bit more formal than ないで, but still frequently used in modern Japanese. Especially as part of set phrases, like ずにすむ (which we will learn about in another lesson).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 朝ご飯を食べずに仕事に行ったから、仕事中に倒れた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I went to work without eating breakfast, I fainted in the middle of my job.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 水を飲まずに運動をしていたから、頭が痛い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I exercised without drinking water, I have a headache.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勉強せずにテストを受けたから、テストの点数が低かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I took the test without studying, I got a low score.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんまり無理をせずに頑張ってくださいね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please do your best without trying too hard.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 忘れずに届けてくれてありがとうございます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Thank you for notifying me (without forgetting).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何も知らずにあんなこと言ってごめんなさい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Sorry for saying those things without knowing the full story.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 悩まずに生きるなんて不可能なのかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It might not be possible to live without worrying.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 値段を見ずに買ったら大変なことになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I bought it without checking the price and now I am in a bind.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は朝ごはんを食べずに仕事に行きました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He left for work without eating breakfast.

Name: ずには居(い)られない
Meaning: Cannot help doing something, Cannot resist doing something
About: As mentioned in our ずに lesson, ず is an auxiliary verb that is not commonly used in modern Japanese, except for in set expressions. It has the equivalent role of ない, in expressing that something 'has not', or 'will not' happen. The case marking particle に is then combined with the adverbial particle は, and the negative-potential form of いる, いられない. ずにはいられない may be translated as 'cannot help doing (A)', or 'cannot resist doing (A)'. ずにはいられない will be attached to the indeterminate form of verbs. This is the same stem form as ない uses. Although ずにはいられない is often translated as 'cannot resist (A)', the literal meaning is simply 'cannot be without (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 美味しそうなステーキが目の前にあったら、食べずにはいられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If there is a delicious looking steak in front of me, there is no way I can resist eating it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この映画を見ると誰でも泣かずにはいられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter who you are, if you watch this movie, there is no way you can not cry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この１０年間色々とお世話になったから、先輩には感謝をせずにはいられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This past 10 years, I have been helped a lot by my senpai, so there is no way I can go on without showing them some appreciation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は猫アレルギーなのでくしゃみをせずにはいられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am allergic to cats so I can't not sneeze.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供が生まれて泣かずには居られない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You can't help but cry when your child is born.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はよく嘘をつくから、疑わずには居られない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't help but be suspicious because he always tells lies.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 事故を目撃したら、助けずには居られない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When you witness an accident, you can't help but help out.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それを思い出すたびに恥ずかしくならずには居られない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Everytime I recall that I can't help but get embarrassed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の変顔は面白すぎて、笑わずには居られません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: His strange faces are just too funny, I can't help but laugh.

Name: 無(な)し
Meaning: Without, No
About: Although it is used almost exclusively as a suffix, なし is actually a noun that means ないこと 'thing without'. なし, or 無(な)し when using kanji, will be used after nouns that it is indicating as 'not having (A)'. Depending on what the speaker wants to convey, なし is often partnered with the auxiliary verb だ, or its conjunctive form で. なしで will mean '(A) that is without (B)'. When connected directly to another noun, の will be required after なし. Again, this will mean '(A) that is without (B)'. なし does not always need to be connected directly to another noun. Often, it can be used in reference to an event or thing that someone wants to skip, or avoid. In cases like this, it may be paired with the case marking particle に, to show determination to avoid something.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その考えは間違いなしだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That way of thinking is without error. (That way of thinking is flawless)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 許可なしで公園に店を出さないで下さい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please don't put up a store in the park without permission.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 肉なしの人気料理はなんですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What is a popular dish without meat?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日は沢山食べたから、今日は昼飯なしにする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I ate a lot yesterday, I am going to skip eating lunch today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩が来ると盛り下がるから、先輩なしにしよう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let's avoid inviting our senpai because he kills the mood.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: わさび抜きでお願いします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Remove the wasabi please.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 唐辛子無しでお願いします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Without the red peppers please.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ことわざ：「死人に口無しだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Proverb: 'Dead men tell no tales.' (Literally - Without a mouth)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 告白：「あなた無しで生きていけない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Confession of love: 'I cannot live without you.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 商品ラベル：「砂糖無しのダイエットドリンク」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Product label: 'Diet drink without sugar'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: エッセイ：「今では現生人類はスマホ無しでは生活できないだろう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Essay: 'Nowadays, modern humans probably cannot live without smartphones.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テスト飛行は文句無しの成功でした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The test flight was an undisputed success. (without)

Name: あり
Meaning: Possibility, To have, With
About: あり itself is the literary form of the う-Verb 有(あ)る 'to be', and is used in a similar way to なし. However, rather than meaning that something is 'without (A)', it shows that something is 'with (A), amongst other things'. This 'amongst other things' is important, as あり will primarily be used when something is being presented as a single possibility among many possibilities. あり can be and often is used simply as a reply to a statement to indicate agreement, or that the listener thinks that what the speaker is saying is possible.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ラーメンもありじゃない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ramen is possible, isn't it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 駐車場ありのホテルを取っておいてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please book a hotel with a parking lot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 字幕有りで見たいから字幕つけてもらえない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to watch it with subtitles, so could you please turn it on?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML:
鈴木先輩：「来週ＢＢＱも有りじゃない？」
浜崎くん：「めっちゃありです。」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML:
Suzuki senpai: 'Don't you think a BBQ would be a good option next week?'
Hamazaki-kun: 'That is totally possible.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遊びに行くなら、遊園地もありだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If we're going to hang out, a theme park is also a possibility.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何か動物を飼いたい。ネコもありだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wanna have some kind of animal. Even a cat is a possibility.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日のデート、水族館もありじゃない？
Questions.EnglishHTML: The aquarium is also a possibility for tomorrow's date, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: キッズメニューありのレストランに行こう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's go to a restaurant with a kids menu.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この香りもありだけど、あの香りの方が好き！
Questions.EnglishHTML: This scent is also an option, but I like that scent better!

Name: 考(かんが)えられない
Meaning: Unthinkable, Inconceivable, Unimaginable, Cannot think
About: 考(かんが)えられない is the negative potential form of the る - Verb 考(かんが)える 'to consider'. It will regularly be used after the adverbial particle など (なんか, or なんて), or any expression that nominalizes a phrase, like ということは. 考(かんが)えられない is regularly translated as '(A) is unimaginable', or '(A) is unthinkable', which is quite close to the literal meaning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ２０年前は、携帯で映画を見たりゲームをしたりすることは考えられなかったでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It was probably unthinkable 20 years ago that you could do things like watch movies and play video games on your phone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 人に手を出すなんて私には考えられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is unimaginable that I would raise my hand at a person.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんなに小さな人が相撲をやろうと思ったとは考えられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is unthinkable that a person that small decided they wanted to do sumo.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 人違いだったことは考えられないか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is it unthinkable that you misremembered the person?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 死んだ後のことなどほとんど考えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't think about what happens after dying.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 結婚した後の事など考えていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm not thinking about stuff like what happens after getting married.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 妻と離婚することなど考えられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is unimaginable that I would get a divorce with my wife.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「ほかの方法は考えられない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I cannot think of another way.' (unthinkable)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 論文：「チタンは考えられないほど硬いので、飛行機によく使用される。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article/essay: 'Since titanium is unthinkably strong, it is often used in airplanes.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ブログの投稿：「君の事以外は何も考えられない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Blog post: 'I cannot think about anything but you.' (unthinkable)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達との話：「子供がそんな難しい数学の問題を解くということは考えられない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between friends: 'It is unthinkable for a child to solve such a difficult mathematical problem.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ブログの投稿：「電気なしの生活は私には考えられない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Blog post: 'Life without electricity is unimaginable for me.' (unthinkable)

Name: 必(かなら)ずしも
Meaning: Not always, Not entirely, Not necessarily
About: Although it is often considered a stand-alone adverb, 必(かなら)ずしも is a combination of the adverb 必(かなら)ず 'invariably', or 'certainly', and the adverbial particles し and も. し and も are often combined in order to strengthen the meaning of the word before it.
