Due to this, 必(かならず)ずしも may be translated as something similar to 'absolutely certainly'. However, 必(かならず)ずしも is an expression that is only used in negative sentences, so is commonly translated as 'not always (A)', 'not entirely (A)', or 'not necessarily (A)'. Despite this, the literal meaning is close to 'not absolutely certainly (A)'. 必(かならず)ずしも is often used at the beginning of a phrase, before expressing something that is not 100% certain.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 男の人は必ずしも強いわけではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Men are not necessarily always strong.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 刑務所にいる人たちは必ずしも犯罪を犯したとは限らない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: People in prison are not always in there because they have committed a crime.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 女の人は必ずしも買い物が好きだとは言えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Women do not necessarily love shopping.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 失敗は必ずしも悪いわけではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Failure is not necessarily bad.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 必ずしも上達するわけではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You will not necessarily become more proficient.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 思い出が必ずしも美しいとは限らない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Memories are not always beautiful.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 天気予報は必ずしも当たるわけではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Forecasts are not always right.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 必ずしもこの情報が正しいとは限らない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This information is not necessarily correct.

Name: 連用形(れんようけい)
Meaning: Formal Conjunctive
About: In Japanese, the conjunctive form is often called 'the ます form', or 'the conjunctive form'. 'The conjunctive form' is much more accurate, as it is used with more than just verbs. Basically, the conjunctive form is the form of any word that will be used in standard conjugation with other structures. For い-Adjectives, this is the form that uses く, for verbs, the ます stem. The reason that conjunctive form is sometimes referred to as 'the formal conjunctive' is due to its use before a comma. Usually, the conjunction particle て would be used to separate clauses in sentences, however, the formal conjunctive allows this to be done without て. Let's look at some examples. As we can see, although て is not required, a 読点(とうてん) (Japanese comma) will be required to prevent the sentence from becoming confusing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 飛行機のエンジンが爆発をし、海に墜落した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The engine of the airplane exploded, (and) it crashed into the ocean.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 朝食を食べ、出かける準備をしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Eat your breakfast, (and) please get ready to go out.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 北海道は寒く、景色が綺麗。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hokkaido is cold, (and) the scenery is pretty.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 学校は楽しく、色々学べるので学校が好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: School is fun, (and) I can learn various things so I like it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 風が吹き、悪魔が現れた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The wind blew, a demon appeared.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 空は青く、海より広い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The sky is blue, (and) bigger than the sea.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スピードを出しすぎ、警察に捕まった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was going too fast, (and) a cop pulled me over.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 公園に行き、子供と遊んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I went to the park, (and) played with kids.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夢は大きく、志は高く！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Have big dreams, (and) be ambitious!

Name: 向(む)き
Meaning: Suitable for, Facing
About: 向(む)き is another noun in Japanese that is frequently used as a suffix. 向(む)き comes from the intransitive verb 向(む)く, meaning 'to face'. This word is often attached to the end of other nouns, in order to show that something is 'facing (A)', or 'suitable for (A)'. Due to 向(む)き being intransitive, it usually implies that something is facing toward (A) naturally, or through chance. Because of this, it may convey that something is 'suitable for (A)', but not necessarily designed specifically for it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたは本当に前向きな人なのですね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You really are a forward facing person! (You really are a positive thinker)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この部屋のベランダは南向きですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is this room's veranda south facing?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この本は初心者向きですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is this book suitable for beginners?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は子供向けの本を書いています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I write books for children. (Intended for children)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供向きの本を探しているのですが、お勧めはありますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am looking for books suitable for children, but do you have any recommendations? (Not necessarily intended for children, but still suitable)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この部屋は南向きですか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Does this room face south?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それだと向きが逆ですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If that's the case, the way it's facing is back to front.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 経済は上向きのようですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The economy seems to be looking up. (facing)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたはいつも前向きな人だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You are always positive. (Facing forward)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは若い者向きの本だな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This book is suitable for young people. (facing)

Name: 向(む)け
Meaning: Intended for, Aimed at
About: 向(む)け is a shortened form of the transitive verb 向(む)ける 'to aim at', and is considered to be a 造語(ぞうご) (neologism). This means a word that was created for a specific purpose, and may not necessarily be used for anything outside of that purpose. The purpose of 向(む)け is to attach to other nouns, in order to express that something is 'intended for (A)', 'aimed at (A)', or 'oriented toward (A)'. 向(む)け may be seen followed by the case marking particle に (when followed by a phrase), or the case marking particle の, when linked with another noun. In terms of products and similar items, although 向(む)け highlights that something has been intended for (A), it doesn't necessarily mean that it is limited to (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この教科書は上級者向けに書いてある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This textbook is written oriented toward advanced people.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供向けに書かれた本を読んで日本語を勉強したら？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why don't you study Japanese by reading books written for children?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: オフィス向けのパソコンを１０台買うとしたらいくらになりますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I were to buy 10 computers intended for office use, how much would that cost?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは大人向けの映画だから、お前には見せれないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This movie is intended for adults so I can't show it to you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が住んでいる所は一人暮らし向けのアパートだけれども、３人家族でもなんの不便無く住める。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The place I am living is intended for one person, but even as a three person family, we can live there with no inconveniences.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そのおもちゃは猫向けに作られている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That toy is made for cats.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 上級者向きの本は難しいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Books suitable for advanced learners are hard.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この番組は大人向けだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This TV program is aimed at adults.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは女性向けの服だから、僕には着れない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: These clothes are intended for women so I can't wear them.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: Ｘというライトノベルは子供向けに書かれたんだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The light novel called X was written for children.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このアプリは学生向けだが、誰でも使用できる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This app is intended for students, but anyone can use it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは海外向けの番組だから、何を言っているのか全然分からない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a TV program aimed at foreigners, so I have no idea what is being said.

Name: 上(あ)がる
Meaning: Something is finished, To finish something, Something has come to an end, To do something completely, To do something through
About: When used after the conjunctive form of a verb, either of the verbs 上(あ)げる 'to raise', or 上(あ)がる 'to rise' may be used. They will convey that something has been done 'to the limit'. 上(あ)がる will be used for actions that take place by themselves (intransitive), while 上(あ)げる will be used for actions that have an instigator (transitive). Although 上(あ)げる and 上(あ)がる show that something has been done 'to the limit', the nuance is usually 'to do (A) to the point of completion', or 'to do (A) through to the end'. Therefore, the 'limit' that is being highlighted is usually a natural ending, and not due to running out of some kind of resource. Let's have a look at some examples. 上(あ)げる and 上(あ)がる are most commonly used when some kind of effect or product is produced as a result of the (A) action. In these cases, the literal meaning of 'to (A) up' is very similar to 'to finish up (A)' in English.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: レポートは書き上げた？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Did you finish writing the paper?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この炊飯器を使えば２０分でご飯が炊きあがるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you use this rice cooker, your rice will finish cooking in 20 minutes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日の朝までに書き上げるのは無理かな？頑張らなきゃ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is it impossible to finish up writing this paper by tomorrow? I should give it my all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は砂を使って小さな街を作り上げた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He used sand to build up a small city.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の作品は５分で書きあがる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: His pieces are drawn up in 5 minutes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 古いコンピューターは立ち上がるのに１０分かかる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It takes an old computer 10 minutes to finish up booting.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ラッピングが仕上がったら番号でお呼びします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We will call you by your number once we finish wrapping it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あれはどんな風に仕上がるかな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder how that will be completed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ところで、やっと絵が描き上がったよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: By the way, the picture has finally been completely painted.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 作品がし上がる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The piece will be finished.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なんとかドレスを縫い上げました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have somehow managed to finish sewing the dress.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ご飯が炊きあがる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The rice will finish up cooking.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 空は雨の後で晴れ上がった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The weather cleared completely after the rain.

Name: 切(き)る
Meaning: To do something completely to the end, Utterly, Resolutely
About: Another verb that is often seen used after the conjunctive form of other verbs is the う - Verb 切(き)る 'to cut'. 切(き)る will give the (A) verb the nuance of being done 'to completion'. However, the 'completion' that is being conveyed with 切(き)る is usually caused by the running out of some kind of resource, like energy. Due to this, 切(き)る is often translated as 'to do (A) to the point of being unable to continue' (or not needing to continue), or 'to totally and utterly do (A)'. Occasionally, 切(き)る may also be used to show that (A) is being done at 'full pelt', 'full steam', or 'full capacity'. In these cases, it is similar to 'to resolutely do (A)', and just means that 100% effort is being put into the action.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自分は全部使い切るまで、新しいのを買わない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Personally, I don't buy new ones until I use everything up.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日はライトノベルを２冊も読み切った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I finished reading 2 light novels today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 水筒の水を飲み切ったがまだのどが渇いている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I finished drinking the water in my bottle, but am still thirsty.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このカーブではスピードを落とさずに走り切るのが重要だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At this curve, it is important to drive at full pelt without slowing down.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今回の大会で全力を出し切ることができて良かったです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am happy that I was able to do the best that I can do at this tournament. (Full capacity of power)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 使い切ってから次のジャムを買ってよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Buy another jar of jam after you use one up completely.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日の寒さで冷え切ってしまいました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because of the cold today, I am completely frozen. (utterly)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 給料をもらった日に使い切ってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I completely used up my entire paycheck the day I got it. (utterly)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たとえどんなことがあっても勇者さまを信じ切ります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter what will happen, I trust the hero completely.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先週末、三冊のマンガを読み切った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I completely finished reading three manga last weekend.

Name: 切(き)れない
Meaning: Being unable to finish or complete
About: In the negative-potential form, 切(き)れない will attach to the conjunctive form of other verbs, to express that a particular action is 'unable to be completed'. Let's look at some examples. Unlike 切(き)る, which usually attaches to verbs to show that something was done to the point of running out, 切(き)れない often implies the exact opposite. This means that the (A) verb cannot be completed specifically because there is too much/many of something in order to finish it. 切(き)れない may also imply that something cannot be done 'to the point of satisfaction'. In this case, the feeling of dissatisfaction is what the speaker considers too much to overcome.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大盛頼むの？いくらあなたでもここの大盛は食べきれないと思うよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are you going to order the large one? I don't think you can possibly finish the portion they serve here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの山は一日では登り切れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You can't possibly finish climbing this mountain in one day.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 宇宙には数え切れないほどの星がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are too many stars in space to count. (Can't finish counting)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この肉は厚すぎて歯では噛み切れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This meat is so thick that it is not possible to chew with your teeth.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私のこの気持ちは言葉では表しきれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I cannot possibly explain this feeling of mine with words. (Cannot explain satisfactorily)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 楽しみ過ぎて待ちきれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am so excited that I can't wait. (Cannot wait satisfactorily)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 空の星の数が数え切れない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You can't completely count the number of stars in the sky.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お皿が多すぎて、洗い切れない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are too many dishes. I will be unable to finish washing them.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新曲の発売日が待ち切れない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I absolutely cannot wait for the release of their new song.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 辛かったから、食べ切れなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because it was spicy, I was unable to finish eating the food.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この溢れる思いを抑え切れない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am unable to completely control my emotions from overflowing.

Name: きり
Meaning: Only, Just, Since
About: As an adverbial particle, きり may convey that 'upon (A)', where (A) is usually a verb, that action was the 'first and last time'. This is frequently translated as 'only', 'just', or 'since'. きり comes from the う - Verb 切(き)る 'to cut'. きり is often used after the plain past form of verbs, with nouns, or with counters. Let's look at verbs first. With verbs, きり is primarily used to show that (A) occurring was all that was required for (B). Usually, this results in some permanent consequence, or permanent change of opinion. In almost every situation, (A) is something that has only happened once, and きり can be interpreted as 'ever since'. When it comes to the use of きり with nouns or counters, it will express that something is happening with (A) as the limit 'nothing more, nothing less'. In other words, (A) is all that will be included in some particular situation/action.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日、晩ご飯食べたきり何も食べてないから、めちゃお腹が空いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I haven't eaten anything since last night, so I am extremely hungry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お祖母ちゃんは去年病気で倒れて、寝たきりになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Grandma got sick last year, and has become bedridden. (Can only sleep)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一人きりになれる時間が欲しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want some time where I can be alone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼とは一度きりしか会えていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was only able to meet him once.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 二人っきりの時間はいいね！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A time just for the two of us is nice, isn't it!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: やっと二人っきりになれたね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is finally just the two of us.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寂しい時、一人っきりで泣く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When I am sad, I cry alone. (just/only myself)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 父がついに寝たきりになってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My dad has become completely bedridden (only/just sleeps).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女とは喧嘩したっきり会っていません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I haven't seen my girlfriend since we had a fight.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: チャンスは一度きりしかないから緊張する。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am nervous because I have only one chance.

Name: 掛(か)け
Meaning: Half-, Not yet finished, About to, Begin to
About: Being an unofficial helper verb, かけ is what is known as a 造語(ぞうご) (neologism), and carries one specific meaning when used in conjunction with other words. This is  similar to 向(む)け. かけ comes from the verb 掛(か)ける 'to suspend', and may be attached to the conjunctive form of other verbs, in order to convey that they are 'unfinished'. Usually this translates as 'half (A)', 'about to (A)', or 'not yet finished (A)'. かけ behaves like a noun, so may be followed by the case marking particle の when attached directly to another noun, or by だ when at the end of a sentence. Occasionally, the verb 掛(か)ける itself may be used instead of the noun form, かけ.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺の食べかけだけど大丈夫？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is half-eaten by me, is that okay?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは私の飲みかけだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is my half-drunk one.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は死にかけの子犬を救った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He saved a puppy that was about to die. (Half dead)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は壊れかけのパソコンを買って直すのが趣味だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Her hobby is to buy half-broken computers and fix them. (Computers on the verge of breaking)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やばい、死にかけるところだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Wow, I was about to die right there. (Almost on the verge of dying)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 飲みかけた水を捨てる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will throw away my half drunk water.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先週の事故で死にかけそうになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was on the verge of dying in an accident last week.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 壊れかけていた椅子に座ったら、椅子が壊れた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I sat on a chair that was on the verge of breaking, it broke.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 終わりかけだからちょっと待って。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm in the process of finishing, so can you wait a little.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食べ掛けのケーキでも良ければありますよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have some half-eaten cake, if you would like.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 描き掛けの絵を早く完成させたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to finish this half-drawn picture quickly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この時計壊れ掛けだけど、ないよりはいいか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This watch is half-broken, but is still better than nothing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 忘れ掛けていた思い出が急に蘇った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The half-forgotten memory suddenly came back.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 交通事故で危うく死に掛けた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I nearly died in the car accident. (half-dead)

Name: に掛(か)けて
Meaning: Over (a period), From ~ until, Through
About: Coming from the る - Verb 掛(か)ける 'to suspend', にかけて conveys that something is happening 'over a period of time', 'from (A) until (B)', or 'all through (A)'. This grammar structure is a combination of the case marking particle に, and 掛(か)ける combined with the conjunction particle て. Literally, the meaning can be thought of as follows: に - Marks (A) as the location/state. 掛(か)けて - States that something is 'suspended' (in an ongoing process) in that location/state. The 'something' that is an ongoing process will usually be indicated by a (B) part of the sentence. This expression will primarily be used with nouns. にかけて is primarily used in written language, although it appears quite often in the news as well, indicating that some weather pattern is expected to continue for a set period of time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今夜から朝にかけて大雨が降るでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It looks like it will rain from tonight through til the morning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎年、三月末から五月の頭にかけて多くの人が引っ越しをします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every year, a lot of people move from the end of March through the beginning of May.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今は雨が降っているが、朝にかけては晴れるでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is raining right now, but it seems like it will clear up during the morning. (Limited to the extent of tomorrow morning)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今月から来月にかけては忙しい時期になるので、無理せずに頑張ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Limited from this month through until next month, it is going to be a busy season, so please do your best without overworking yourself.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今週末に掛けて、雨が降るでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It looks like it is going to rain over the weekend. (through)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この一年に掛けて、いろいろなことを経験したい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to experience a variety of things over this next year. (through)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先週に掛けて降った大雪が、まだ全然溶けない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It kept snowing all through last week, and it hasn't melted yet. (over)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 来年に掛けての目標を立ててください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please establish your goals over the next year. (from ~ until)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 関東から東北に掛けて雨が降り続いている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It has been raining from the Kanto area to the Tohoku area. (throughout)

Name: 立(た)て
Meaning: Freshly ~ed, Just ~ed
About: たて, coming from the verb 立(た)てる 'to stand' is a suffix in Japanese that is often used after the conjunctive form of verbs. たて conveys that something has 'just been finished', or is 'freshly finished'. As a suffix, たて transforms verbs into nouns. This means that they may be followed by a (B) phrase, or followed directly by the case marking particle の and a noun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここにあるのは全部揚げたてですよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Everything here is freshly fried.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 釣りたてだから新鮮だよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is just fished up, so it is fresh!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は出来立てのパンを食べるのが大好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like to eat freshly baked bread.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 生まれたての赤ちゃんっておさるさんみたいじゃない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't newborn babies look like monkeys?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 取り立ての野菜で作るサラダは美味しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Making salad with freshly picked vegetables is delicious.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この靴は濡れたてだから、乾かすのに少し時間がかかると思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: These shoes got freshly wet, so it will take some time to dry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 釣り立ての魚を食べるのは最高！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Eating freshly caught fish is the best!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この魚は焼き立てです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This fish has been freshly cooked.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 出来立てのお菓子を食べたのは初めてだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's my first time eating freshly made sweets.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このお店ではとり立ての野菜が買えます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You can buy freshly picked vegetables at this shop.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 淹れ立てのコーヒーの香りが好きだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I like the smell of freshly made coffee.

Name: 込(こ)む ①
Meaning: To go into, To put into
About: In Japanese, the う - Verb 込(こ)む 'to jam into' is frequently used as a suffix to convey several different meanings. The primary meanings are as follows: (A) 込(こ)む - To enter completely into doing (A), or the state of being in (A). (A) 込(こ)む - To enter a state of doing (A) that will not be considered complete until 'success'. (A) 込(こ)む - To enter a state of doing (A) that cannot be escaped from. In this lesson, we will exclusively focus on the first meaning, which is usually translated as 'to put into (A)', or 'to go into (A)'. This form will be attached to the conjunctive form of other verbs. Despite the multiple meanings, 込(こ)む can almost always be thought of as 'jamming (B) into (A)'. This means that whatever the (A) action is, will be something that is not easily entered, but also not easily escaped from.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ピンを壁に押し込む。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To push a pin into a wall.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 薬を飲み込むのが苦手です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am not the best at drinking down medicine. (I am not the best at swallowing medicine)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電車のドアが閉まる前に、電車に走り込んだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Before the train door closed, I ran in.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サウナから出て、水風呂に飛び込むように入った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I came out of the sauna and went into the water bath as if I was leaping into it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 教師：「教科書に答えを書き込んでください。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Teacher: 'Please fill in your textbooks with answers.' (put into)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムはジェロニモと叫びながら、プールに飛び込んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tom jumped into the pool while screaming 'Geronimo!' (put into)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「どうして窓が閉めてあるの？」
Ｂ：「冷たい風が入りこまないように。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'Why is the window closed?'
B: 'So that cold air won't get in.' (put into)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: バッキンガム宮殿の警護官について：「笑いを飲み込みながら、移動せずに立ったままだった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: About a Buckingham Palace guard: 'He kept standing, unmoving, while holding in a smile.' (swallowing・put into)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達との話：「彼女は泥棒の顎に見事に拳を打ち込んだそうだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between friends: 'I heard that she fantastically drove her fist into the thief's face.' (put into)

Name: 込(こ)む ②
Meaning: Remain, To do thoroughly, Deeply, Intensely
About: In Japanese, the う - Verb 込(こ)む 'to jam into' is frequently used as a suffix to convey several different meanings. The primary meanings are as follows: (A) 込(こ)む - To enter completely into doing (A), or the state of being in (A). (A) 込(こ)む - To enter a state of doing (A) that will not be considered complete until 'success'. (A) 込(こ)む - To enter a state of doing (A) that cannot be escaped from. In this lesson, we will exclusively focus on the second and third meanings, which are usually translated as 'to remain in (A)', 'to thoroughly do (A)', 'to do (A) deeply', or 'to do (A) intensely'. This form will be attached to the conjunctive form of other verbs. Despite the multiple meanings, 込(こ)む can almost always be thought of as 'jamming (B) into (A)'. This means that whatever the (A) action is, will be something that is not easily entered, but also not easily escaped from.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 警察が道の真ん中で座り込んでいる人に話しかけた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The police went to talk to the person that remained seated in the middle of the road.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もうこんな時間か、話し込んじゃったな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's already this time, we got lost in talking, didn't we?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなに考え込まなくてもいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You don't have to think so deeply about this.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今は取り込み中なので手が空いたらかけなおします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am held up working right now, so I will call you back once my hands are free.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: みんないっせいに黙り込んでいた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At once, everyone sunk into an intense silence and remained silent.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ノベル：「れつこは気分が悪くなり、座り込んだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'Retsuko felt weak and sat down.' (deeply・thoroughly)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 疲れていたので、シャワーを浴びずに眠り込んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was tired, so I fell deeply asleep without taking a shower. (intensely・thoroughly)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達との話：「何を長々話し込んでたの？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between friends: 'What were you so intently talking about for so long?' (deeply・thoroughly)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: エッセイ：「熱心にひとつの事に打ち込むことが必要だと思っている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Essay: 'I think that devoting oneself deeply to one thing is important.'

Name: 振(ふ)りをする
Meaning: To pretend, To act as if
About: ふりをする is an expression in Japanese that is used to show that someone is 'pretending to be (A)', 'putting on airs of (A)', or 'acting as if (A)'. This construction comes from a combination of the noun 振(ふ)り 'a shake', the adverbial particle を, and する. It can be thought of as meaning 'to give off the impression of (A)', or 'to shake off the impression of (A)'. As ふり itself is a noun, this expression may be used with the attributive form of any other word.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この蛇は人等の大きな動物が近づくと死んだ振りをするらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that this snake pretends to be dead when humans and other similar big animals approach it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 僕は子供の頃、よく寝ている振りをした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I was a child, I would often pretend to sleep.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 欲しいのはこれではなかったけど、せっかく買ってくれたから嬉しい振りをする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is not what I wanted, but since they went out of their way and bought it for me, I will pretend that I am happy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺の前ではそんな、元気な振りをしなくていいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You don't have to pretend that you are happy in front of me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カケル君はカエルが好きだからいつもカエルの振りをして遊んでいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because Kakeru-kun likes frogs, he always pretends to be a frog when he plays.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 泣いた振りをしたって無駄ですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When you pretended to cry, it was useless.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の犬は寝た振りをすることがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are times when my dog pretends to sleep.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供は、注意された時に、聞こえない振りをした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The child pretended not to hear while she was being scolded.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 病気の振りをして会社を休んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Pretending to be sick, I took the day off work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 見て見ない振りをするのは良くない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's not good to turn a blind eye to something. (pretend not to see)

Name: できれば
Meaning: If possible
About: Remembering that する has no potential form, the replacement る - Verb できる 'to amount to' will often be used in conjunction with particles, to indicate whether the possibility of amounting to something exists. The conjunction particles ば or たら will most frequently be used. できれば and できたら are usually translated simply as 'if possible'. Both できれば and できたら will come at the start of a sentence, before the following statement will express some (desired) outcome.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 出来れば車で行きたいけど、電車で行った方が早いかもしれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If possible, I would love to go by car, but it might be faster by train.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 出来たら薬局に行って頭痛薬を買って来てくれる？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If possible, can you go to the chemist and buy me some headache medication?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: できたら運転して欲しいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If possible, I want you to drive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: できればお弁当を作って欲しいな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If possible, I would like you to make me a bento.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: できれば本人と会って話がしたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If possible, I would like to talk with him directly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それができたら嬉しいんですけど。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it's possible for you to do that, I would appreciate it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: できればあの会社で働きたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If possible, I want to work at that company.

Name: で良(よ)ければ
Meaning: If it is alright, If you don't mind, If you would like, If possible
About: でよければ is an expression that is constructed with the case marking particle で, and the potential form of the い-Adjective いい, よければ. The literal meaning of 'if with (A) is good/fine', or 'if by (A) is good/fine' is quite similar to the standard translation, which is 'if (A) is ok'. でよければ will always follow nouns or noun-phrases. でよければ is a phrase that is often used in relation to oneself, in order to politely offer some sort of help, advice, or service. As で is being used in its standard meaning of 'with' or 'by', でよければ implies that the speaker is enquiring whether the quality/ability of (A) is good enough to achieve some specific result.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 焼き肉でよければ、うちの近くに美味しいところがあるから、そこに行かない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If yakiniku is fine, there is a good yakiniku place near my house, so do you want to go there?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 中古で良ければいいのが沢山ありますよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If used ones are fine, we have many good options.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私でよければ手伝うよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you don't mind, I can help you. (If I am a suitable option, I can help you)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生でよければ、先生が写真を撮ってあげるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you don't mind me, the teacher, then I can take a picture for you!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この籠で良ければ作れますよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If this is the basket that you would like, I can make it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この傘で良ければお貸しできます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Sir, I can lend you this umbrella if you'd like.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日中で良ければ空いてます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If daytime works for you, I am free then.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この値段で良ければ売ります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If this price works for you, then I will sell.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これくらいの出来で良ければ、すぐに作れます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you don't mind this quality, I can make it for you in no time.

Name: 次第(しだい)
Meaning: As soon as
About: 次第(しだい) is a noun that is often translated in different ways, depending on what type of word it follows. In this lesson, we will look at the meaning associated with the conjunctive form of standard verbs, and the stem of する verbs. Although it is a noun, 次第(しだい) may also be classified simply as a suffix in many cases.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 用意が出来次第、僕に声をかけてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As soon as you get ready, please let me know.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ミュージカルが終わり次第、連絡をください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please call me as soon as the musical ends.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 待ち合わせ場所に到着し次第、私に連絡してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please give me a call as soon as you arrive at the meet up spot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 計画が決まり次第、あなたに報告します。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will notify you as soon as we decide on the plan.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 行くか行かないかは君次第だよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether you go or not will depend on you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ６人も乗れるかは車のサイズ次第だね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether or not 6 people can fit will depend on the size of the car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 準備が出来次第出発しますよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We will depart as soon as you are ready.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼が来次第、知らせてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please notify me as soon as he comes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: プロジェクトが済み次第、ご連絡ください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please contact me as soon as the project is finished.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お金を受け取り次第、郵送します。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will send it as soon as I receive the money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 学校を卒業し次第、仕事を探すつもりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As soon as I graduate, I plan to look for a job.

Name: 通(とお)り
Meaning: In that way, Exactly, Precisely, Just as
About: Often, the noun とおり carries the meaning of 'in that way', or 'just like that'. In its kanji form, とおり will be written as 通(とお)り, and literally means 'street', or 'way'. However, it is regularly used to indicate the level of 'sameness' one thing has with another. This 'sameness' meaning appears when とおり is used as a suffix. とおり (or どおり) may be used with verbs or nouns. In the case of verbs, it is common to see it being used after both the plain form, and the simple-past form. Both どおり and のとおり may be used directly after nouns. However, とおり will only be used when the case marking particle の comes between the noun and とおり. While both of these structures may be used interchangeably, どおり is more common, especially in speech.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客様のおっしゃる通りです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Honored guest, the thing you say is precisely correct. (That's exactly right)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は僕の思った通りの時間に帰ってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just as I expected, he came back when I thought he would come back.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 計画どおりに進めて行きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We will continue as the plan suggests.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ご覧の通り、私の手には何もありません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As you can see, I have nothing in my hands.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: リカの言った通りだった！あそこのパン屋さんはすごくおいしかった！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It was exactly as you said, Rika! The bakery over there was very delicious!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 本当にその通りです！何でいつも私たちがやらないといけないんですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That's honestly exactly it! Why do we have to do it all the time?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 思った通りでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was just as I thought.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたのおっしゃる通りです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It will be precisely/just as you say.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 合格者は次の通りです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Those who passed are as follows... (Precisely)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お察しの通り、彼は病気です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Exactly/Just as you may guess, he is quite ill.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 物事はいつも計画通りにはいかないものだなぁ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Things will not always go precisely/exactly as planned.

Name: でもある
Meaning: Be also, It also is
About: As an extension of the formal version of the auxiliary verb だ, である, でもある simply conveys that something 'is also (B)'. However, as も often shows something that is surprising or unexpected, でもある will primarily be used to describe additional facts about (A) that may be unexpected. Due to this, でもある usually fills the (B) role in sentences like 'while (A), it is also (B)', or 'in spite of (A), it is also (B)'. でもある may be used after nouns, or な-Adjectives.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカさんは英語の先生だし、休みの日は船の船長でもあるから休む時間がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While Tanaka-san is an English teacher, he is also the captain of a ship on his days off, so he doesn't have any time to rest.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは洗濯機でもあるけど、同時に乾燥機でもある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In spite of this being a washing machine, it is also a dryer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: バンジージャンプは楽しいけれども、同時に危険でもある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In spite of bungee jumping being fun, it is also dangerous at the same time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この機械は重くて邪魔だけど、同時に便利でもある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While this machine is heavy and a nuisance, it is also useful.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この車は少し狭いけれども、快適でもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This car is a bit small, but it is also comfortable. (it also is)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: オーストラリアは国であり、大陸でもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Australia is a country. It is also a continent. (it also is)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は優れたプログラマーだ。そして多言語話者でもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is an excellent programmer. He is also a polyglot. (he also is)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は良い社長であったし、良い父親でもあった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He was a good company president and also a good father. (he also was)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ひとみさんは中学生であるとともに社長でもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Hitomi is a middle school student, she is also a company president. (she also is)

Name: どうしても
Meaning: Regardless of, No matter what
About: どうしても is a construction in Japanese that is often considered to be a stand-alone adverb meaning 'no matter how', or 'regardless of anything'. Originally, it is a combination of the adverb どう 'how', and the ても form of する, しても 'even doing'. どうしても will regularly be used at the beginning of sentences before conveying something that is considered by the speaker to be 'absolutely true'. Alternatively, どうしても may be used after verbs, following the case marking particle と. This will express that 'if (A) happens, (B) is unavoidable'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうしても欲しいのなら、自分で買いなさい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you want it no matter what, buy it yourself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうしても我慢ができなくて買っちゃった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I accidentally bought it because I couldn't resist no matter what.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 牛乳飲むとどうしてもお腹が痛くなるんです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of anything, If I drink milk, I get a stomach ache.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 寝る前にお腹いっぱいに食べるとどうしても寝れなくなっちゃうんだよね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I eat till I'm full, before I sleep, I am unable to sleep no matter what.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうしてもヘリコプターには乗りたくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In any case, I don't want to ride a helicopter.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうしてもお土産を買いたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to buy a souvenir no matter what.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食べるとどうしても眠たくなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I eat, I get sleepy no matter what.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうしてもアイスクリームが食べたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to eat ice cream no matter what.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君にどうしても伝えたいことがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is something I want to tell you, no matter what.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この癖はどうしても治らない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter what I do, this habit won't go away.

Name: もしも～なら
Meaning: If, Supposing
About: もしも is an adverb in Japanese that strengthens the base meaning of もし 'a bit'. Therefore, the literal meaning of もしも is 'even a bit'. Despite this, as もし and もしも are almost exclusively paired with sentences that use some sort of assumption, or 'hypothesis' based expression, もしも will often be translated as 'supposing that'. もしも will be used at the beginning of sentences that include almost any form of hypothesis expression. For example, ば, と, なら, or ても. Although もしも is considered a stand-alone adverb, it is just a combination of もし, and the adverbial particle も.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もしも、今年中に引っ越すのならば、僕が手伝ってやるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Supposing that you move within this year, I will help you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もしも仕事で怪我をすると、現場が止まるので気をつけてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Supposing that you get hurt at work, the site will be shut down, so please be careful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もしも明日休みなら、一緒に博物館へいかない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Assuming you have a day off tomorrow, do you want to go to the museum with me?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もしも彼がいたとしても、今日中には終わらなかっただろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Supposing he were even here, don't you think we would not have been able to complete it by today?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もし、また宿題を忘れたら親に電話をします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Assuming you forget your homework again, I will call your parents. (Calling their parents will be the result of forgetting their homework)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たとえ、テストが難しくても最後まで諦めないで頑張ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If, for example, the test is hard, don't give up, and do your best until the very end. (If the test is difficult, doing your best is not a result, just one of many choices that could be made)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もしもドラえもんがいたなら、助けてもらえるのに。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If Doraemon were here, he would help us.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もしも僕がドラえもんでも助けられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if I were Doraemon I would be unable to help.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もしも戦うなら囲碁がいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If we are going to battle, I say we settle it with a game of Go.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もしも可能なら、僕も仲間に入りたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If possible, I want to join you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もしもこれが現実でも、受け入れられると思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if this is a hard fact, I think that I can accept it.

Name: 同士(どうし)
Meaning: Fellow, With each other, Mutually, Between, Among, Together, With
About: 同士(どうし) 'fellow' is a noun that may be used in the same way as a suffix. When used this way, it conveys things that are 'mutually (A)', 'fellow (A)', or '(A) together'. To use 同士(どうし), attach it directly to the end of another noun, before expressing further information about that 'mutual' relationship. Alternatively, (noun + 同士(どうし) + の + noun) is also common, and expresses that noun (B) is a grouped form of noun (A). 同士(どうし) is used most often to express two different types of 'mutuality'. These are as follows: 種類(しゅるい) - Type. (A) is the same type as (B). 関係(かんけい) - Relationship. (A) shares the same relationship as (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは弁護士同士の話しなので勝手に入って来ないで下さい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is a conversation between lawyers, so please don't barge in.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家族同士で会話をするときはほとんど日本語です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When we talk between family members, we mostly use Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は友達同士の約束を破った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He broke a promise that was made between friends.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お互い大人同士なんだから、落ち着いて話し合おうよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We are fellow adults, so let's calm down and talk about this.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたたちは本当に似たもの同士ね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You guys are really similar (in personality).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは兄弟同士の問題でしょ？私を巻き込まないで。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is an issue between siblings, isn't it? Don't pull me into it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この糊は紙同士だとよくくっつきますがプラスチック同士だとあまりくっつかないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This glue sticks really well between paper, but between plastic, it does not stick well. (Natural, but not very common)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: プロの格闘家同士の戦いは見ていて楽しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Watching a fight between two professional martial artists is fun. (Natural)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このように紐でページ同士を結びつけることができます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You can connect pages together with a string like this.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 負けた者同士で飲みに行こうよ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Those among us who have lost, let's go drinking!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 中学生同士は結婚するには若すぎる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Middle schoolers are too young to marry (each other).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 同級生同士だから、助け合わなきゃね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We are fellow classmates, so we have to help one another, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達同士の約束だったのに彼は破った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though it was a promise among friends, he broke it.

Name: がたい
Meaning: Hard to, Difficult to
About: Coming from the same kanji as 難(むずか)しい 'difficult', 難(がた)い is a suffix that also means 'difficult'. However, in the case of がたい, it will be attached to the conjunctive form of verbs, and conveys that '(A) is difficult to do'. がたい is almost always written without kanji in this meaning. Compared to にくい, which can simply imply that something is 'uncomfortable' to do, がたい refers almost exclusively to 困難(こんなん)であること 'things that involve a high degree of difficulty, distress, or infeasibility'. Due to this, がたい will come across as far stronger than にくい, and may imply that a certain task is almost impossible. Summed up, these nuances basically translate as the following: にくい - Something is difficult based on someone's opinion, experience, or general feeling. がたい - Something is difficult based on the task itself having a high level of difficulty.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あいつが言う事は信じがたいが、今は信じるしかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is hard to believe what he says, but we have no choice but to trust him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 言いがたかったから言わなかったけど、シャツ反対だよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I didn't say this because it's hard to say, but your shirt is inside out.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の声は聞こえにくい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: His voice is a bit tricky to hear. (It is kind of hard to hear his voice, based on my ability/feeling)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この話が信じがたいのは分かるが、信じてくれ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I understand that this story is impossible to believe, but please believe me! (Believing something like this is not easy)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの罪は許しがたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That crime is unforgivable. (Nearly impossible to forgive)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう一つのアイデアも捨てがたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The other idea is also hard to give up.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人の言っていることは信じがたいですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's hard to believe what that person is saying.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 忘れがたい出来事に遭遇した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I encountered an event that is nearly impossible to forget.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 皆から近寄りがたいってよく言われます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am often told that I am hard to approach.

Name: まさか
Meaning: I never dreamed, Never, No way, Don't tell me, You don't say
About: Almost always written purely in hiragana, まさか is a combination of まさ, a noun meaning 'precise', or 'exact', and the adverbial particle か. In modern Japanese, まさか is thought of as a single adverb meaning 'it can't be true', 'no way', or 'don't tell me'. As it is treated primarily as an adverb, まさか will most often appear at the beginning of a sentence, before some statement about what the speaker is shocked/surprised about.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まさかタナカ君もこのジムに通っているとは思っていなかったよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I never would have believed that you also came to this gym.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まさか彼がキャプテンなんて。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't tell me that he is the captain!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 全然待っていないですよ。僕も今まさに着いたところです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I didn't wait at all. I actually just arrived now.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まさかリアがフランスに帰るって本当なの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is it actually true that Lia is going back to France?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まさかこんなところで君に出会えるなんて⁉︎
Questions.EnglishHTML: I never dreamed I would meet you in a place like this!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まさかこんな大雪が降るなんて思わなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I never dreamed it would snow this much.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まさか…あのこと本当に彼に話したの？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Don't tell me... Did you really tell him about that?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まさか…また財布忘れたわけじゃないよね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Don't tell me... There's no way you forgot your wallet again... right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まさか彼が犯人だなんて… ショックだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I never dreamed that he would be the criminal… I'm in shock.

Name: 前者(ぜんしゃ)は～後者(こうしゃ)は
Meaning: The former ~ the latter, The first ~ the second
About: Used in almost exactly the same way as 'the former' and 'the latter' in English, 前者(ぜんしゃ) and 後者(こうしゃ) are two nouns that appear frequently in Japanese. The adverbial particle は will appear after these words, to express contrast between the two. 前者(ぜんしゃ) will be used for 'the former', while 後者(こうしゃ) will represent 'the latter'. Both 前者(ぜんしゃ) and 後者(こうしゃ) appear at the beginning of their own statements, with a specific comment about each being made after は.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どの大学に行くか迷っています。前者は家に近いが学費が高い、後者は家から遠いが学費が半分ぐらい安い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am undecided on which college to go to. The former is close to my house, but the tuition is expensive. The latter is far from my house but the tuition is almost half the price.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 地下鉄と新幹線、前者は地下をゆっくりとはしり、後者は速いスピードで地上を走る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Subways and bullet trains. The former runs slowly underground, and the latter runs above ground at a high speed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こっちの車とこっちの車どっちを買おう。前者は安くて古くて、後者は高くて新しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This car and this car, which should I buy? The former is cheap and old, and the latter is expensive and new. (Natural)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日動物園に行くか今夜本を読むかで、迷っています。前者は動物がいて空いている、後者は寝る前にゆっくりできる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am undecided on whether to go to the zoo tomorrow, or to read a book tonight. The former has animals and isn't crowded, but the latter is relaxing before bed. (Unnatural)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
ダンゴムシとワラジムシ、前者は触ると丸まり、
後者は触っても丸まらないという違いがあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
If you want to know the difference between pillbugs and sowbugs,
the former rolls into a ball if touched and the latter doesn't.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そうめんと冷麦、前者は細く、後者は少し太い。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
The difference between soumen and hiyamugi noodles is that
the former is thin and the latter is thick.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
宿泊場所の候補が二つあります。
前者は温泉があり、後者はご飯がおいしいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
There are two choices for places to stay.
The first has hot springs, the second has delicious food.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 交通の札には切符と整理券の二つがあります。前者は電車に乗るために必要なもので、後者はバスに乗るときに取るものです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are two types of transportation tickets: 'kippu' and 'seiriken'. The former is a thing needed for getting on a train, and the latter is taken when boarding on a bus.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どちらのパソコンがいいですか？前者は安いが性能は一般向け、後者は高いが高性能。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Which laptop is better? The former is cheap, but the specifications are average.
The latter is expensive, but has better performance.

Name: つい
Meaning: Accidentally, Unconsciously, Against one's better judgement
About: Appearing most frequently at the beginning of sentences, つい is an adverb that may be translated as 'accidentally', 'unconsciously', 'absentmindedly', or 'against one's better judgment'. つい will often be paired with statements that use てしまう, to emphasize that something was unintentional.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ごめんタケシ君のクッキーが目の前にあったからつい食べてしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sorry Takeshi-kun, your cookie was right in front of me, so I absentmindedly ate it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生に怒られると、つい笑っちゃうんだよね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I am being scolded by the teacher, I unconsciously laugh.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運転中に携帯を使ったらだめなのは分かっているんだけど、メールが来るとつい携帯を見ちゃう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I know that I shouldn't use my phone while driving, but when I get a text I unconsciously look at my phone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 早く起きて準備をしても、つい遅れてしまう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if I wake up early to get ready, I'll be late due to a lapse of time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電車が遅れると、ついイライラしてしまう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When the train is late, I'll get angry due to a lapse in judgment.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お腹が空いていなくても、目の前に食べ物があるとつい食べてしまう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if I am not hungry, if there is food in front of me, I will eat it due to a lapse of forethought.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: つい楽な方に流されてしまう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I always end up unconsciously taking the easy route.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 運転中、ついよそ見をしてしまう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While driving, I become unconsciously inattentive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 運動を始めると、ついやり過ぎてしまう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When I start doing exercises, I always end up accidentally overdoing it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 笑ってはいけないのに、つい笑ってしまう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since I am not supposed to laugh, it feels like I might accidentally laugh.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「つい食べ過ぎてしまう」なんて言い訳だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Saying things like: 'I unconsciously eat too much' is just an excuse.

Name: せいで
Meaning: Because of, Due to, Blame
About: Although written almost exclusively in hiragana, せい is a noun that may be better understood from its kanji, 所為(せい), meaning 'doings'. せい is used to convey negative results that occurred due to the behavior or actions of another person/thing. Because of this, common translations of せい are 'fault', 'due to', or 'because of'. As せい is a noun, it may be used after the attributive form of any other word. The case marking particle で will also regularly be seen after せい, especially when conveying the (B) result that occurred 'with' or 'by means of' those 'doings'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日夜遅くまで起きていたせいで寝坊した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I stayed up late last night, I overslept today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 外が寒いせいで風邪を引いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because it is chilly outside, I caught a cold.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犬の手術の事が心配なせいで今日は寝れなさそう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to me being worried about my dog's surgery, it doesn't seem like I am going to be able to sleep.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大雪のせいで道が渋滞してる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because of the heavy snow, the road is congested.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遅刻したのは渋滞のせいだ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Me being late is the traffic's doing!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 台風のせいでまた予定が変わったよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to the typhoon's doings, my plans have changed again.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムは暑さのせいで気を失った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tom passed out because of the heat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰のせいでもないと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't think it's because of anyone. (no one to blame)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 湿気のせいでカビがひどい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The mold is out of control because of the humidity.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ストレスのせいで病気になってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I became ill due to stress.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 物忘れがひどいのは、たぶん年のせいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You are quite forgetful probably because of your age.

Name: 癖(くせ)に
Meaning: Even though, And yet, Despite
About: 癖(くせ) is a noun that means 'habit' or 'tendency'. However, as it usually refers to a negative thing, 'vice' is another accurate translation. くせに (usually appearing without kanji) is the combination of くせ, and the case marking particle に. This structure is often used to criticize the actions of others, and is used in a similar way to 'despite', 'even though', or 'and yet' in English. As くせ is a noun, くせに may be used after the attributive form of any other word.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さっき寝るって言ってたくせにまだ起きてるの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though you said that you are going to sleep earlier, are you still up?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 若いくせに何ダラダラしているんだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why are you working so sluggishly even though you are young?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自分だって下手なくせに何偉そうに言ってるんだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Despite you also being no pro, why are you talking so high and mighty.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この子は犬のくせにニャーと鳴く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though he is a dog, he meows.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食べきれない癖にたくさん注文するのはやめてほしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though you cannot eat it all, you order a lot. I want you to stop (doing that). (despite)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昨日休んだ癖に、なんで知ったかぶりするの？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Why do you pretend to know (what we are talking about) despite having the day off yesterday?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人は先輩の癖に、いつも僕におごらせようとする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite being my senior, he/she always tries to make me pay.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寒い癖に「寒くない」とやせ我慢するのはやめてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please stop pretending like you're not cold even though you are. (despite)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 給料を沢山もらっている癖に、貯金がないらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite getting paid a lot, I have heard that he has no savings.

Name: がち
Meaning: Apt to do, Tend to do, Prone to do
About: がち is a suffix in Japanese that will be used after nouns, or the conjunctive form of verbs. It conveys that someone is 'apt to (A)', 'tends to (A)', or 'is prone to (A)'. Although not always negative, がち is most frequently used to express negative tendencies.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここに来るといつもパフェを頼みがちだけど、今日はパンケーキを頼む。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I come here I always tend to order parfait, but today I am getting a pancake.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: うちの子は病気がちなので、週に二、三日ぐらいは学校を休みます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My child is prone to getting sick, so they usually miss two or three days of school each week.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: サボりがちな人はだいたい成績が悪い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: People who tend to skip school usually have bad grades.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 暇なときはテレビを見がちだけど、忙しい時には全然見ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Watching TV wins out when I am bored, but when I am busy I don't watch it at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺が回すと当たりがちだから、俺にやらせてみろ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hitting the jackpot wins out when I spin it, so why don't you let me do it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 釣れないことはありがちだから、落ち込まなくてもいいよ。そういう日もあるさ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Times that you cannot catch anything often win out, so don't be so upset. It happens.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは初心者にありがちのミスですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That is a mistake beginners tend to make.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はいつも遠慮がちだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He always tends to hold back.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の息子は病気がちだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My boy is apt to get sick.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人はすぐ、痩せることを諦めがちだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person is prone to quickly give up on losing weight.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は昔から遅刻しがちだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have always been prone to being late.

Name: 気味(ぎみ)
Meaning: Looking, Feeling a little, Touch of, Tending to, Slightly
About: Coming from the noun 気味(きみ) meaning 'sensation', ぎみ is a suffix that is used to convey weak signs of (A). ぎみ may be used with nouns, or the conjunctive form of verbs. Often, ぎみ is translated as 'looking (A)', 'a touch of (A)', 'feeling a little (A)', or 'slightly (A)'. ぎみ refers to the senses of the person who is experiencing them, and therefore may be used to refer to feelings about other people/things, or feelings about oneself. As ぎみ expresses 'weak signs of (A)', it is often used to soften a statement, so that the speaker does not appear overconfident.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近太り気味だから、ダイエットしなきゃ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I feel slightly fat, so I should go on a diet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今週は色々と忙しかったから疲れ気味だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I have been busy this week with various things, I am feeling a little tired.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今朝は風邪気味だったので、学校を休んだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I felt a little sick this morning, I took a day off of school.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 現場の人がほとんどバテ気味だったので、作業を中断した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Most of the people on the site seemed a little worn out, so we stopped work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電車が遅れ気味だから、待ち合わせ時間まで間に合わないかも。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because the train seems a bit late, I might not be able to make it by our agreed time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 風邪気味なのかな？身体がだるい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I feel like I have a cold, my body feels heavy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タカシ君疲れ気味じゃない？ちゃんと休憩取った？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takashi-kun, you look a bit tired, did you take a proper break?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は風邪気味だと言った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She said she was feeling a little sick.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 最近、彼女は太り気味らしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that lately, she is a bit plump.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 貧血気味なので、採血はやめておきましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since you are looking somewhat anemic, let's not draw any blood.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暗いニュースばかりで食傷気味だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I feel sick listening to nothing but negative news.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 台風のせいで天気が荒れ気味だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The weather is a bit stormy due to the typhoon.

Name: っぽい
Meaning: -ish, -like, Characteristic of, Typical of, Tendency to
About: っぽい (occasionally also seen as ぽい) is a suffix that may be attached to many different types of words, in order to create new い-Adjectives. In all cases, っぽい indicates something that is 'exhibiting characteristics of (A)'. This is most often in reference to the way (A) is acting, or the way (A) looks. In English, っぽい may be translated as '(A)ish', '(A)like', or 'tendency to (A)'. っぽい quite often carries a negative connotation. As っぽい creates い-Adjectives from other words, it may be used with the conjunctive form of verbs, or the 語幹(ごかん) (stem form) of any other word.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は飽きっぽいから、何も続かない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I have a tendency to get sick of things, I can't continue with anything.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 白っぽいやつをください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please give me the whiteish one.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカ君はファッション業界では有名っぽいよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Apparently Tanaka-kun is popular in the fashion industry!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今の話は嘘っぽいけど本当の話なの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The story I just told you sounds like a lie, but it is actually true.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昔は紫っぽかったのに今はなぜか赤っぽい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Back in the day, it was purpleish, but now for some reason it is reddish.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この靴なんか安っぽくない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't these shoes look cheapish?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寅さんは惚れっぽく、飽きっぽい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tora-san has the tendency to fall in love, and also has the tendency to lose interest. (~ish)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なんかこの牛乳は水っぽいな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This milk is somewhat watery… (~ish)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 怒りっぽい人はあまり好かれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: People that have a tendency to get angry are not liked much. (~ish)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トムは記憶力がいいどころか、忘れっぽいよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Far from having a good memory, Tom is actually pretty forgetful. (~ish)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こういう時は黒っぽいスーツを着るべきか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Should I wear a blackish suit for this occasion?

Name: っぱなし
Meaning: Leaving something in a certain state, Left as is, Keep on -ing
About: っぱなし is a suffix that originally comes from the う - Verb 放(はな)す 'to let loose'. When attached to the conjunctive form of verbs, it is used to indicate that something has been 'left' in a certain state. っぱなし is almost exclusively used negatively.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: また電気点けっぱなしじゃん！何回言えば消してくれるの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You left the light on again! How many times do I have to tell you to turn it off?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫を開けっ放しにしないで下さい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please don't leave the refrigerator open.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 歯を磨いている間、水を出しっぱなしにしていたら、お母さんに怒られた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I left the water on while I was brushing my teeth, my mother scolded me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勝ちっぱなしだとつまらないね、たまには負けを味わいたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't you think it is boring to keep winning? I want to taste defeat sometimes. (I want to lose sometimes)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 秋の間は窓を開けっぱなしにして寝ています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: During autumn, I sleep with the windows left open.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰かがそのドアを開けっ放しにした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Someone left the door open.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ライトをつけっ放しにしないで。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Don't leave the light on.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電話が鳴りっ放しだけど…大丈夫？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Your phone keeps ringing... Is that not a problem?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつも開けっ放しで、ちゃんと閉めてよね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You always leave it open, make sure you close it ok?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 水を出しっ放しにするのはやめてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please stop leaving the water on.

Name: わざわざ
Meaning: Expressly, Especially, Go out of one's way, Take the trouble to
About: わざわざ is an adverb that is used to express when someone has gone out of their way to achieve a certain result. It may be translated as 'expressly', 'especially', or 'to go out of one's way to (A)'. わざわざ will usually be used at the beginning of sentences, before some statement will be made about an activity that was intentionally done. わざわざ has a tendency to be used positively, although it may be used with negative connotations as well.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: わざわざ私が好きな饅頭を買いに行ってくれたの？ありがとう！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You went out of your way to buy me my favorite manju? Thank you!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: わざわざ会社に行って仕事しなきゃいけない理由がわからない、別に家でも出来るのに。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't understand the reason to go out of my way to go into an office to work, I can work from home.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: わざわざここまで来てくれてありがとうございます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thank you very much for going out of your way to come here. (Positive)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何でわざわざそういうひどいこと言うの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why do you go out of your way to say something so mean? (Negative)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: わざと押したでしょ？あんた最低。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You pushed me on purpose, didn't you? You are the worst.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何でわざわざ邪魔しに来るの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why do you come here especially to bother me?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: わざわざここまで働きに来ているんですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I see you came here expressly to work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: わざわざ批判しなくてもいいのに。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You didn't have to go out of your way to criticize.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: わざわざ独りで行くんですか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: You will go out of your way just to go by yourself?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: わざわざ傘を返しに来てくれたの？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Did you come all the way here expressly to return the umbrella?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: わざわざ自慢しなくてもいいじゃないか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You don't have to go out of your way to boast about it, do you?

Name: 一体(いったい)
Meaning: (What) the heck?, (Who) in the world?, (Where) on earth?, (How many) f*ing...
About: In order to convey the feeling of 'what the heck', with any 'how', 'what', 'where' or 'why' type question, the adverb 一体(いったい) will be used in Japanese. いったい appears frequently both with, and without kanji. いったい will usually be seen at the beginning of sentences, before some statement about what the speaker finds unbelievable. The literal meaning of いったい is 'one body', or 'one form'. In this way, when paired with questions, いったい can be thought of meaning 'in a way that can be understood, what is (A)', or 'in a way that makes sense, what is (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一体ここで何が起きたんだ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What the heck happened here?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは一体どういうことだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What is the meaning of this?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一体なんでこんな事になったの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Explain to me in a way that makes sense, why something like this happened?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一体なんであんな奴と付き合おうと思ったの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In a way that I can understand, why did you think of dating someone like him?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アメリカ人は一体に親切です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Americans are generally polite.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人は一体誰なのだろう…
Questions.EnglishHTML: Who the heck is that person?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一体いつ、掃除をする暇があるというんだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When the heck do I have time to clean?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は一体どういうつもりなんだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: What on earth does he intend to do?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人は一体何歳なんだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: How freaking old is that person?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕たちの未来は一体どうなるんだろう…
Questions.EnglishHTML: What on earth will become of us in the future?

Name: 折角(せっかく)
Meaning: With trouble, At great pains, Take the trouble, Might as well..., Rare/long-awaited occasion
About: 折角（せっかく) is an idiomatic adverb that is often used to express doing something 'with trouble', 'at great pains', or 'to be a rare/long-awaited occasion'. Being an adverb that often modifies the meaning of a whole sentence, it will commonly appear at the beginning of a statement. When 折角(せっかく) is nominating an event as being long awaited, it will appear directly before the event, separated only by the case marking particle の.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: せっかく君が欲しかった靴を買ってあげたのに友達にあげたの？最悪。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I took great trouble to get you the shoes that you wanted, but you gave them to your friend? How inconsiderate.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: せっかく休みを取ったのに雨が降ったから予定が台無しだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I went through the trouble to get a day off, but it rained, so my plans were ruined.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: せっかくの誕生日会を台無しにしてごめんなさい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sorry for ruining your long awaited birthday party.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 台風のせいで、せっかくの休暇が中止になった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to the typhoon, my long awaited vacation has been canceled.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 折角この旅行の準備してきたのに....
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite going through all the trouble to finish preparations for the trip...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 折角の友達との遠足だから、たくさん遊びたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since this trip with friends is a rare occasion, I want to have a lot of fun.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 折角のデートが風邪でつぶれた。ちょっと残念だよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A long-awaited date was spoiled because I caught a cold. It is a little disappointing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 折角大学を卒業したんだから、いい会社で働くつもりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I graduated university at great pains, I plan to make use of it by finding a good job.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 折角高性能のコンピューターを買ったんだから、新しいゲームをしようと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since I went through great pains to purchase a high-end computer, I am going to make use of it by playing new games.

Name: っけ
Meaning: What is…again?, Was it... that... ?, Did you say...?
About: け is a sentence ending particle in Japanese that is used to convey when the speaker is trying to either remember, or confirm information that they have forgotten. In this way, it is very similar to the 'again' in 'what is (A) again?' け may only be used after the past form of the auxiliary verbs だ or た. This means that け (should) only be seen as だっけ or たっけ. It is also common to see のだ and んだ utilized to make verb tenses a possibility.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日の朝は朝ご飯を食べたっけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Did I eat breakfast this morning?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あれ、テイラーの車って青かったっけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Um, Taylor, was your car blue, again?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 土曜日って暇だっけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Was I free on Saturday, again?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人誰だっけ。やばい、思い出せない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Who was that again? Shoot, I can't remember.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: クミコって納豆食べれるんだっけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Kumiko, were you able to eat natto again?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: レポートの修正は君がやってるんだっけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are the one editing the paper, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムって日本語話せるっけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tom, were you able to speak Japanese again?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この道って通れるっけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Were we able to take this road again?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あれ、カギ掛けたっけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Umm, did I lock the door? (Asking oneself)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あそこのレストランって犬を連れていけるっけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you remember if we could take our dogs to that restaurant over there? (Asking another)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんなもの家にあったっけ？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Was it that you had something like that at home?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日って晴れるんだっけ？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Was it that it will be sunny tomorrow?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もうすぐ梅雨も終わりだっけ？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Was it that the rainy season will be over soon?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この資料渡したっけ？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Did I pass you this document? (was it that...?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一昨日もラーメン食べたっけ？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Did we have ramen the day before yesterday too? (was it that...?)

Name: 代(か)わりに
Meaning: Instead of,  In place of, In exchange for
About: 代(か)わり 'a substitute' is a noun that is used to convey when (B) is acting as a replacement or substitute for (A). The case marking particle に will come after 代(か)わり, before a (B) statement will highlight who the replacement is, and possibly what they are doing. As 代(か)わり is a noun, it may be used after the attributive form of any word. Occasionally, 替(か)わり 'to exchange' may be used instead of 代(か)わり 'to substitute'. However, within the context of this particular grammar structure, there is little to no change in nuance.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺が社長に電話する代わりに、お前はお客さんに電話をしておいて。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In exchange for me calling the boss, can you call the client in advance?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのプールは古い代わりに安い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That pool is cheap, to substitute for it being old.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事は大変な代わりに楽しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Work is fun, in exchange for it being difficult.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の代わりにやってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Can you do it in my place?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 代わりに行ってくれない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a replacement, can you go for me?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 代わりにこれを持って行って。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Instead of that, can you go take this?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: バターの代わりにマーガリンを使っています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am using margarine instead of butter.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コーヒーの代わりに紅茶では駄目ですか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is tea in place of coffee not good enough?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 玉ねぎの代わりに長ねぎを使おう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's use green onions in place of ordinary onions.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電話の代わりに、メールを送った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Instead of calling, I sent him an email.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の代わりにこの問題を解いてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please solve this question instead of me.

Name: に代(か)わって
Meaning: In place of, On behalf of, To succeed
About: に代(か)わって is an expression that will only appear with nouns, conveying that (B) is doing something 'in place of (A)', or 'on behalf of (A)'. This is a combination of the case marking particle に, the う - Verb 代(か)わる 'to substitute', and the conjunction particle て. に代わり may also be used, as this is the formal conjunctive. Also known as the conjunctive form.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 妹に代わって、私が買い物に行くことに決まった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It has been decided that I am going to go shopping in place of my sister.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が彼女に代わって会議に出ます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will be attending the meeting in place of her.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タナカさんに代わり、今日は私があなたたちの担当をします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In place of Tanaka-san, today, I am going to be in charge of you guys.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 世界中ではファックスに代わりメールが主流になったが、日本ではまだファックスしか使わないところが多い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: All around the world, fax has been replaced by email as the main form of communication, but there still are places in Japan that only use fax.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は社長に代わって、私が会議を進めます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today, I will take charge of the meeting in place of the CEO.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 父に代わって、皆に挨拶をした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In place of my father, I greeted everyone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 月に代わってお仕置きよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: On behalf of the moon, I will punish you!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私に代わって説明をしてくれてありがとう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Thank you for explaining it on my behalf.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私に代わって、あなたが発表をすることになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It has been decided that you will do the presentation instead of me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 機長に代わって副操縦士が操縦した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The co-pilot flew on behalf of the captain (of the aircraft).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 社長に代わって、山田さんが乾杯の挨拶をします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: On behalf of the CEO, Mr. Yamada will do the toast.

Name: どころか
Meaning: Far from, Anything but
About: どころか is a combination of the noun ところ 'place', and the sentence ending particle か. The change from ところ to どころ is a consistent sound change that is seen regularly in sentences that use 所(ところ) negatively. どころか may be translated as 'far from', 'let alone' or 'anything but'. It strongly negates any statement before it, while also emphasizing what comes after it. どころか may be paired with the attributive form of any other word. However, this is not a strict rule, as it can also be seen with the 語幹(ごかん) stem form of な-Adjectives, and directly attached to nouns. Sentences that use どころか must always have a part (B) that emphasizes some type of far more important information (in the speaker's opinion).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このカレーは甘いどころか、辛かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Far from being sweet, this curry was spicy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 北海道は寒いどころか、暑かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Far from being cold, Hokkaido was hot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日の仕事は楽などころか、めちゃくちゃ大変だったよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Far from being easy, work yesterday was hectic.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は酎ハイどころかビールも飲まない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let alone Chuhai, she doesn't even drink beer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなにゆっくりしているどころか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is not the time to be even remotely that relaxed!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺がやるどころか？そんなことをやるのは弟しかいないだろ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you honestly think I would do such a thing? My brother is the only person who would do that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そのケーキは甘いどころか、酸っぱかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Far from being sweet, that cake was sour.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 吹雪はやむどころか、かえってひどくなっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Far from stopping, the storm instead got stronger.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 謙虚になるどころかかえって傲慢になっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Far from being humble, he is arrogant.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は休むどころか、全力を出し切った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Far from taking a break, he gave everything he had.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 親切にしようとしたけど、感謝されるどころか、叱られた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though I tried to be nice to her/him, far from being thanked, I was scolded.

Name: と言(い)う理由(りゆう)で
Meaning: For (that) reason; on the grounds of (that), With the reasoning, Under the pretext of, Due to
About: という理由(りゆう)で is a phrase that is used when giving reasons for (A). (A) may be a range of different things, from what happened, to what one's opinion is.
