Due to という quoting the previous statement as being the 'reason', という理由(りゆう)で puts quite a bit of emphasis on the reason itself. Because of this, the expression is quite similar to 'being that' in English. The case marking particle で will be used after 理由(りゆう) to show that 'with' or 'by means of' that reason, (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コストコは安く沢山買い物が出来るという理由で人気がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At Costco, you can shop for many things at a cheap price. For that reason it is popular.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大変だという理由で彼は仕事を辞めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Being that his job was a hassle, he resigned.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 安くて美味しいという理由で、この店の前にはいつも行列ができています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Being that this place is cheap and delicious, they always have a long line in front of the store.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一人で行きたくないという訳では無いです。一人で行くのは危ないと言いたいのです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not so that I don't want to go alone. I am saying that it is dangerous to go alone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: という理由で、この企画はキャンセルすることにします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For that reason, we are going to cancel this plan. (Unnatural)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: というわけで、この企画はキャンセルすることにします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well with that, we will decide on canceling this plan. (Natural)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ストアのルールを破ったという理由で五つのアプリが削除されました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: 5 apps were removed on the grounds of breaking the store rules.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仕事がとても大変だった。そういう理由で、今日はゆっくりしたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Work was really rough. For that reason, I want to take it easy today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ゴルゴさんはプロフェッショナルです。そういう理由で彼を雇う予定です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Golgo-san is a professional. For that reason, I plan to hire him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「高すぎるなぁ」という理由で課長は提案に反対した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: With the reasoning: 'it is too expensive,' the section manager opposed the proposition.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: やまださんは年寄りだという理由で、詐欺師によってターゲットによくされている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mr. Yamada is often targeted by con-artists on the grounds that he is elderly.

Name: は～となっている
Meaning: It is (has been), Have/has become, Happen to be, Has been established
About: (A) は (B) となっている is a common expression used to show that '(A) is becoming (B)', or (more commonly) '(A) has become (B)'. This expression will only appear with nouns, or な-Adjectives in their 語幹(ごかん) (stem form). (A) は (B) となっている is often translated as '(A) happens to be (B)', '(A) has been established as (B)', or 'it has been decided that (A) is (B)'. Let's have a look at some examples, and then how this structure is formed. Despite the different translations, (A) は (B) となっている always has the same meaning, which can be understood as follows: (A) は - (A) is a constant unchanging thing. (B) と - (B) is a result. (coming from the case marking particle と's role in highlighting results.) なっている - (A) is existing in the state 'having arrived at the result of (B)'. Due to this, the literal translation may be thought of as 'it is now that (A) is (B)' in almost all situations.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 鬼滅の刃は非常に人気となっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It happens to be that Demon Slayer is very popular.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本ではドラッグは法律上、違法となっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In Japan, it has been established that drugs are illegal, by law.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このプールでは、飛び込みが禁止となっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At this pool, it happens to be that jumping in is not allowed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今の時代にはインターネットは必要となっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is now that the internet is necessary in the present age.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この高校ではアルバイトが禁止となっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is now that working part-time at this school is prohibited.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今の時代にはインターネットは必要になっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is now that the internet is becoming necessary in the present age.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このイベントは来月５日からとなっており、明日から前売り券を買うことができる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is now that next month's event from the 5th has pre-order tickets that are purchasable from tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 納期限は４月３０日までとなっています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The due date of the tax payment has been established as April 30th.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アメリカをはじめとして、電気は主要な光源となっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Starting with the USA, electricity has become the main source of light.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 中国では男性の女性に対する割合は１１８対１００となっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The proportion of men to women in China happens to be 118 to 100.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: フランツ・フェルディナント大公の暗殺が開戦の原因の一つとなっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand has been established as one of the causes of war.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それが標準となっていて他の方法はほとんど使用されない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That has become a standard, and other methods are hardly used.

Name: 左右(さゆう)する
Meaning: Influence, Impact, Control
About: 左右(さゆう) is a noun that may literally be translated as 'left and right'. This particular noun is quite often used as a する verb, in order to convey the level of control someone has over a specific situation. This control may be translated as 'influence', 'impact', 'dictate' or simply 'control'. 左右(さゆう)する may be used by itself, when describing a whole clause, or it may be followed directly by another noun, to show exactly what is being controlled/influenced. 左右(さゆう)する is frequently seen in the passive form 左右(さゆう)される. This is used most often when the noun following される is the thing that is being controlled itself, rather than こと or もの referring back to an earlier statement.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しくできる法律が、国民の自由を大きく左右するかもしれません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The new law that is being made may largely influence the freedom of citizens.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 砂糖を入れるか入れないかで、味を大きく左右することが出来ます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Depending on whether you put sugar in or not, you can greatly influence the taste.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 商品の値段はお客さんが商品を買うか買わないかを左右することがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are times when the price of a product dictates whether the customer will buy it or not.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 肉を焼いてからタレをいれることは、味を大きく左右する原因の一つだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Cooking the meat before you add the sauce is a factor that will greatly impact the flavor.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この人は話す人に意見を左右されることが多いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This person's opinions are easily influenced by those they talk to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 農業は天気に大きく左右される仕事です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Farming is a job that is largely controlled by the weather.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 流行についてのサイト、記事のタイトル：「靴磨きが靴の寿命と美しさを左右する」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Website about fashion, title of an article: 'Polishing shoes influences the shoe's lifespan and beauty.' (impacts・affects)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 歴史書：「古代ギリシャ人は自分たちの生活が神々に左右されると信じていた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: History book: 'Ancient Greeks believed that their lives were influenced by gods.' (impacted・controlled)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ビジネス記事：「新しい法律が電気自動車の需要を左右するかもしれない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Business article: 'The new law may influence the demand for electric cars.' (impact・control)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 教科書：「裁判官は賄賂などによって左右されないよう良い給与が保証されている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Textbook: 'Judges are guaranteed a decent salary so that they won't be swayed (influenced) by bribes and the like. ' (impacted・controlled)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「平均余命を大きく左右するのは食生活や睡眠時間だと考えられている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'One's eating habits and the amount of sleep one gets are thought to have a huge influence on life expectancy.' (impact・control)

Name: 得(え)る
Meaning: Is able to, Can, Possible
About: 得(え)る is a る-Verb that has the meaning of 'to gain', or 'to acquire'. When attached to the conjunctive form of verbs, it takes on the nuance of 'for (A) to be possible', or 'to be able to (A)'. Compared to できる, which means that the potential to do something exists, 得(え)る means something closer to 'there is a possibility that (A) can be done', or 'the possibility to do (A) has been gained'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 順調にいけば、二年後に会社を立ち上げることもあり得る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's possible that I'll set up my own company if everything goes well after two years.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いくら気をつけていても、交通事故は起こり得るものだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how careful you are, it's possible for a car accident to occur.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そういう事はセクハラにもなりえるので、そういう事はやらない方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Things like that can be considered as sexual harassment, so you shouldn't do that.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 考えうる事は、すべてこの企画書に書いておきました！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wrote everything I can think of on this proposal!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: うん、それもあり得るね...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Yeah, that is also a possibility...

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電気代がまた値上がりするみたいだよ。マジあり得ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It looks like the electricity bill is going to go up again. There's no way.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それはあり得る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That can be possible!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その対策は考え得る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is possible to consider that countermeasure.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 災害はいつだって起こり得る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Disaster can occur at anytime. (there is a possibility that it can occur)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 対応次第でストライキは回避し得る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A strike can be avoided depending on how it is dealt with.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 耕し得る土地を持っている方は田植えができます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: People who own arable land can plant rice. (can be farmed)

Name: 得(え)ない
Meaning: Unable to, Cannot
About: 得(え)る is a る-Verb that has the meaning of 'to gain' or 'to acquire'. When attached to the conjunctive form of verbs, it takes on the nuance of 'for (A) to be possible', or 'able to (A)'. In addition to this, when 得(え)る is combined with ない, that nuance switches to 'unable to (A)', or 'cannot (A)'. Compared to できない, meaning that the potential to do something does not exist, 得(え)ない means something closer to 'there is no possibility that (A) can be done', or 'the possibility to do (A) has not been gained'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この個人情報は、本人以外は知り得ない情報だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This personal information is something that nobody apart from the person in question can know.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １０年後の自分なんて、想像し得ません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Something like me 10 years in the future, I cannot imagine it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんな大きな災害は起こりえないと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think that it's impossible for a disaster that big to happen. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんな大きな災害は起こりうないと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think that it's impossible for a disaster that big to happen. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まあ、それもあり得るかもしれないけど...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well, that is possible, but…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんはすごく頭がいいから、不合格になるなんて絶対あり得ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san is very smart, so it is absolutely impossible for him to fail.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そこまで大きな地震は起こり得ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: An earthquake of that magnitude cannot occur.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 本来、水と油は混ざり得ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Naturally, you cannot mix water and oil.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんなことはほとんど起こり得ないと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think that there is a good chance that such a thing cannot happen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私がその夢を叶えることはあり得ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not possible for me to achieve that dream.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君の話術を持ってしても、説得し得ないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if I had your skill in conversation, I probably couldn't persuade them.

Name: ざるを得(え)ない
Meaning: Can't help doing, Have no choice but
About: ざる is the 連体形(れんたいけい) (attributive form) of the old-fashioned auxiliary verb ざり. ざり carries the same meaning as the modern ない, in negating what comes before it. When joined with a combination of the る-Verb 得(え)る 'to gain', or 'to acquire', and the auxiliary verb ない, it becomes a double-negative structure meaning that one 'cannot help doing (A)', or 'there is no choice but to (A)'. More literally, it means that one 'can't not (A)'. For the most part, this structure will conjugate with other verbs in exactly the same way as ない.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 山の頂上まで登りたかったが、天候が悪くなって来たから諦めざるを得ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wanted to hike to the peak of the mountain, but the weather was getting worse so we had no choice but to give up.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩に指示されたので従わざるを得ません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because my senpai told me to do it, I had no choice but to obey.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: フランスの大学へ行くため、フランス語を勉強しざるを得ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In order to go to a college in France, I have no choice but to study French. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: フランスの大学へ行くため、フランス語を勉強せざるを得ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In order to go to a college in France, I have no choice but to study French. (Natural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サプライズのプレゼントに、驚かざるを得なかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I couldn't help but be surprised at the surprise present.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 思い掛けない出会いに、感動せざるを得なかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I couldn't help but be moved at the chance meeting.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんはとても忙しかったのでゴルフの誘いを断らざるを得なかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mr. Tanaka was so busy he had no choice but to turn down an invitation to play golf.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 古い家屋は倒壊する恐れがあるから、壊さざるを得ません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The old building is at risk of collapsing, so I have no choice but to tear it down.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今まで使った顕微鏡が壊れたから、新しいのを買わざるを得ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The microscope I have been using until now broke, so I have no choice but to buy a new one.

Name: ～ざる
Meaning: To not ~, Un~
About: ざる is the attributive form of the classical auxiliary verb ず. It keeps the same negation 'not' meaning as ず, and will conjugate with verbs in the same way as ない. ざる will also often be translated as 'un~', like in 'unstoppable'. In most cases, ざる will be seen attached to verbs that are describing a noun that comes directly after them. Although ざる may be used in place of ない, in modern Japanese it is primarily only seen as part of common expressions or sayings, such as the ざるを得(え)ない 'have no choice but to (A)' grammar structure.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はどんな辛い時でも弱音を言わざる人だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is a person that will not complain, no matter how hard it gets.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 記事のタイトル：「演歌歌手鈴木太朗の知られざる過去。」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Title of an article: 'The unknown past of the enka singer Suzuki Taro.'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 病気や事故などの理由で、宿泊をキャンセルせざるをえない場合はキャンセル料は発生致しません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No cancellation fee will be charged if you need to cancel your stay due to illness or accident.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たゆまざる努力のおかげで成功者になった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Thanks to my unrelenting efforts, I became a successful person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たゆまざる努力をすることが、成功への鍵だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Putting in unrelenting effort is the key to success.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの作家の知られざる名画を僕は知っています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I know that artist's unknown masterpiece.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 消えざる傷を負ってしまい、落ち込んでいる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I suffered a wound that will not disappear, so I am depressed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嘘をつかざる人しか信頼することができない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You cannot trust anyone apart from a person who does not lie.

Name: つもりで
Meaning: With the intention of doing, Instead of..., Act as if or pretend, Believing that..., Thinking that...
About: つもりで, being a combination of the noun つもり 'intention', and the case marking particleで 'with', this structure is used in several different ways, depending on what comes before it. When combined with verbs, な-Adjectives or nouns in their plain forms, it implies that (B) is being done with the intention of (A). As つもり is a noun, の will be required before it when grouped with other nouns, while な will be required when linked to な-Adjectives. However, when paired with verbs in the past form, つもりで implies that the speaker is 'acting as though (A)', 'pretending that (A)', or 'is convinced that (A)'. This meaning simply comes from the intention of something being contrary to what is actually true.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何も買わないつもりで新しく出来たショッピングモールへ行ったが、色々買ってしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I went to the newly built shopping mall without any intention of buying anything, but I ended up purchasing various things.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新鮮な魚を選んだつもりで買ったのに、パックから出したらものすごいにおいがした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I chose this believing that it would be fresh fish, but when I took it out of the package, it smelled incredibly bad.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冗談のつもりで言っただけなのに、相手を傷付けてしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Despite saying it with the intention of making a joke, I ended up hurting their feelings.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今度は、主人公になったつもりで読んでみてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Next, try reading it as if you were the main character.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パーティーでダンサーになったつもりで、みんなの前で踊った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At a party, I danced in front of everybody, as if I was a dancer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ご馳走するつもりで行ったのに、おごってもらうことになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite going with the intention of treating everyone, they treated me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 本にするつもりで執筆していたが、これはボツだな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wrote with the intention of publishing a book, but this will surely be rejected.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お土産のつもりで買ったが、食べてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I bought it with the intention of giving it as a gift, but I ended up eating it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 車掌になったつもりで、毎日電車に乗っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I ride the train every day acting like/pretending I have become a conductor.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本に行ったつもりで、日本語を勉強しています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am studying Japanese as if I went to Japan.

Name: どうせ
Meaning: Anyhow, At any rate, In any case, I have no doubt that, Probably
About: どうせ is an adverb used in Japanese to express that some particular state or condition of (A) will result in (B). Usually, there is no way to stop (B) from happening, and it is considered a natural consequence of (A). In English, this translates closely with phrases like 'at any rate', or 'in any case'. Being an adverb, どうせ most often appears at the beginning of sentences, before going on to describe the inevitable situation. どうせ often carries the nuance of frustration or resignation that (A) cannot be changed. In these cases, it is often paired with other grammar structures such as なら or だから. This shows that if (A) cannot be changed, then (B) is a good idea. This usage translates similarly to 'if (A), you might as well (B)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうせまたパチンコに行くんでしょ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In any case, you are going to the pachinko parlor again, aren't you?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうせ私のことなんて好きじゃないんでしょ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In any case, you probably don't even like me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうせ新しいスマホを買うならもうちょっといい奴買いなよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you're going to buy a new smartphone, you might as well buy something a little better.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうせまた負けるんだから頑張っても時間と体力の無駄だよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We're going to lose again anyway, so trying our best would be a waste of time and energy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうせダイアモンドなんて買ってもらえない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have no doubt I won't be able to get them to buy me diamonds.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうせ「ウドの大木だ」と悪口を言われるのがオチだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have no doubt that it will just end with me being called 'big and useless'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうせ通訳はつけてもらえない。自力で頑張るしかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In any case, I can't have it interpreted. I have no choice but to try my best.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私がどう謝っても、どうせ彼は許すつもりはないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter how much I apologize, I have no doubt that he won't forgive me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうせご飯を炊かないといけないのだから、あなたの分も炊きますよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In any case, since I have to cook rice, I will cook your share too.

Name: せめて
Meaning: At least
About: Coming from the verb 責(せ)める, meaning to have the 'onus to do (A)', せめて is an adverb that indicates that doing (A) is the minimum expected in order to achieve some desired outcome. It is often translated simply as 'at least' in English. せめて usually alters the meaning of an entire phrase, and will appear at the beginning of sentences. Stemming from 責(せ)める, this structure usually implies that there is some sort of onus or responsibility to do (A), rather than (A) simply being a minimum amount. Due to this, it is often used with grammar points that express desire or opinions such as たい, ほしい, てほしい, べき, and others.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ご飯は残しても良いから、せめて刺身だけは全部たべて。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You can leave the rice, but at least finish the sashimi please.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: せめて国語の宿題はやっておきなさい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At least finish your Japanese homework in advance.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: せめてこの曲だけでも弾けるようになりたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to be able to play this song, at least.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: えっ... たったの５千円だけ？せめて１万は欲しいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What…only five-thousand yen? I want at least ten-thousand yen.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 別に毎日洗濯をしろっては言わないけど、せめて晩御飯だけは毎日作ってほしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm not telling you to do laundry everyday, but I want you to at least make dinner every night.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １日にせめて１リットルの水を飲むべきだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You should drink at least 1 liter of water a day.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: せめてドアくらい閉めて欲しかった...。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I would have liked them to at least close the door...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 親：「せめておかずだけでも食べて。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mother: 'At least eat your sides or something.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: せめて着替えさせてもらえませんか？びしょ濡れなんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Would you at least let me change? I am soaked.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いい案ではなくてもいいので、せめてアイデアだけでも出してください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since it is okay even if it isn't a good idea, please at least submit an idea.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 楽器を寄贈させてください。せめてもの恩返しです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please let me give you an instrument. It is at least a repayment of the favor.

Name: どうやら
Meaning: Apparently, Looks Like, Seems like
About: どうやら can be translated as 'apparently', or 'it seems like', and is often grouped together with other phrases of speculation such as ようだ, そうだ, and らしい. Due to this, どうやら simply strengthens the uncertainty of things that the speaker is already unsure about. This is in a similar fashion to phrases like 'in some way it seems like (A)'. Like many adverbs that express amount or speculation, どうやら will appear at the beginning of sentences and modify the meaning of the entire phrase.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 鈴木くんはいるか？居ないのかな？どうやら今日も休んでいるみたいだね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is Suzuki-kun present? Maybe he's not here? It seems like he's taking today off as well.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうやら私は彼女には必要がないようだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems like I am not needed by her.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうやら彼は結婚しているらしいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that he is apparently married.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お隣の鈴木さんがどうやら来月からイギリスに行くらしいですよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Our neighbor, Suzuki-san, is apparently going to England next month, or something.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの二人、どうやら結婚してる感じだよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It seems like those two are married.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの動画、どうやら削除されたみたいだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It looks like that video was deleted.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうやら今年の紅葉は遅れているらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It looks like fall colors are late this year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうやら「心当たりがない」というのは本当らしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Apparently it is true that he 'has no clue.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はどうやらお小遣いをもらったことがないようです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It seems like he has never received an allowance.

Name: なにやら
Meaning: Something (or other), Some kind of
About: 何(なに)やら is an adverb which expresses uncertainty about what exactly something is or why something is happening. Similar to どうやら, although it is often treated as a single word, 何(なに)やら is composed of the question word 何(なに) and the particle やら which denotes uncertainty and self-questioning. 何(なに)やら is often translated as 'something or other', 'some kind of', or 'for some reason' depending on the context. Although 何(なに)か and 何(なに)やら can both be translated as 'something', they are not interchangeable. 何か can be used for general statements, but 何(なに)やら is only used when the speaker is unsure of what the thing in question is.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人に何やら言われても何にも感じない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't feel anything when that person says something to me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やっと子供が落ち着いたと思ったら、何やら歌い出した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I thought my kid finally settled down, he started to sing some kind of song.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家に帰ってカバンを開けたら何やら見覚えのないレシートが入ってた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I opened my bag when I got home, there was a receipt in there that I have no recollection of for some reason.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 洗濯やら何やらをしない奴は文句言うな！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a person who doesn't do things such as cleaning and other things, don’t complain! (As someone who doesn't do chores, you have no right to complain)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの二人の間で何やらあったらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Apparently something happened between those two. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お茶か何やら飲みますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you want tea or something? (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何やらお隣の家が空き巣にあったみたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that our next door neighbour got burglarized or something.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうやら昨日この付近で事故があったようだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that there was an accident around here or something.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人はどこやら怪しいんだよな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Something about him is suspicious.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼が帰ってくるのはいつやら…
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder when he will come home…

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何やらいいにおいがします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I smell something or other nice.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人、何やら困っているようです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person seems to be bothered by something or other.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女のまなざしには、何やら言葉にならない想いが隠されていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In her gaze, some kind of ineffable sentiment had been concealed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何やら母は、宝くじの一等を当てたことを、家族全員に黙っていたらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For some reason, it seems my mother kept quiet to the entire family that she’d won the first prize in the lottery.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何やら社長に隠し子がいたらしく、その噂がオフィスの他社にも広まっているよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For some reason, it seems the boss had a secret child, and the rumor is even spreading to other companies.

Name: より他(ほか)ない
Meaning: To have no choice but, No other way than, Have to
About: Used in a similar way to しかない, より他(ほか)ない is a structure that emphasizes that only (A) is possible, when attached to the end of verbs. This grammar pattern is a combination of the case marking particleより 'than', or 'from', the noun 他(ほか) 'other', and the い-Adjective, ない. From this it can be translated directly as 'there is nothing other than (A)'. However, the emphasis is usually on the impossibility of doing anything other than (A), rather than the existence of nothing else. Common interpretations include 'to have no choice but to (A)', 'there is no other way than (A)', or simply 'have to (A)'. Occasionally,  the particles に, は, or a combination of both as には may come between 他(ほか) and ない. While this does not change the meaning, it does further emphasize the point that there is no choice but (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 人身事故のせいで電車が止まったので、会社までタクシーで行くよりほかはなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because the train stopped due to an accident, I had no choice but to take a taxi to work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 靴に穴が空いたので、新しいのを買うよりほかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have no choice but to buy a new pair of shoes because there's a hole in mine.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 被害者が無事であることを祈るよりほかにない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is nothing we can do other than pray that the victims are safe.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰もお婆さんを助けようとしなかったので、私が助けるよりほかはなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No one was trying to help the old lady, so I had no choice but to help her.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事をクビになったので新しい仕事を探すよりほかにはない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I got fired from my job, so I have no choice but to look for a new one.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このコースレイアウトだと、刻むよりほかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it is this course layout, there is no choice but to lay up the ball.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 給与が悪すぎる。仕事を代えるよりほかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The salary is too poor. I have no choice but to change jobs.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 教養がなさすぎる。勉強するよりほかありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They lack education. There is no choice but to study.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 車を出せなかったので、自転車で行くよりほかはなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I couldn't get my car out, I had no choice but to ride my bike.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 材料が入手できない。休業するよりほかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't obtain the material. There is no choice but to suspend business.

Name: 確(たし)かに
Meaning: Surely, Certainly
About: 確(たし)かに is the adverbial use of the な-Adjective 確(たし)か, meaning 'to be certain', or 'to be assured'. It may be used in the same way as 'certainly' or 'surely' in English, especially when the speaker wants to highlight (A) is definitely the case.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 確かに彼はイケメンですが、マナーが悪いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is certainly handsome, but he has bad manners.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 確かにさっきのは言い過ぎだった。ごめん。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What I said earlier was certainly out of line. I'm sorry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 確かに結構難しいね。ちょっと甘く見てたわ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is certainly difficult. I underestimated it. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 確かに！宿題が終わってるならゲームをしてもいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Certainly! You may play video games if you finish your homework. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は確かたくやくんのおじさんだったような気がする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I recall correctly, I feel like that person was Takuya-kun's uncle.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そう言えば、前いくら借りたっけ？確か３千円だったよね？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: By the way, how much money did I borrow the other day? If I remember correctly, it was three-thousand yen, correct?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 確かに彼は信頼できます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He certainly is reliable.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 確かにその服はあなたに似合う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Those clothes certainly look good on you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: みんな焦っているようだ。確かに期限が迫っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It appears that everyone is in a hurry. The deadline is certainly approaching.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 学校の規則上、確かに生徒は先生に従うべきだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the standpoint of the school's rules, students should certainly obey their teacher.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼のうちは音楽一家らしいが、確かに楽器がうまい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard he is from a musical household, but he is certainly skilled with an instrument.

Name: 一応(いちおう) ①
Meaning: Just in case, Just to be sure
About: When used as an adverb, 一応(いちおう) can often carry the nuance of (A) not being perfect, but the minimum required in order to prevent (B). This particular nuance of  一応(いちおう) may be interpreted as 'just in case, (A)', or 'just to be sure (A)'. When  一応(いちおう) is used this way, it frequently highlights that (B) happening is unlikely, but the precautionary measure of (A) might be a good idea to avoid it. This is in contrast to another common use of  一応(いちおう) which can be translated as 'more or less', or 'for the time being'. However, in both of its uses, it simply indicates the minimum amount of (A) which is fulfilling some requirement.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日はずっと晴れって天気予報で言ってたけど曇ってきたから 一応傘を持って行ったほうがいいかも。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They said it was going to be sunny all day today on the forecast, but it's starting to get cloudy so it might be better to bring an umbrella just in case.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これで大丈夫だと思うけど、 一応チェックしておいてくれない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think this is fine, but just to be sure, can you please double check it for me?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中：「仕事慣れてきた？」鈴木：「はい、 一応...」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tanaka: 'Have you gotten used to work?' Suzuki: 'Yes, more or less…'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一応はよくなってるみたいですけど、また来週病院まで来てください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For the time being, it seems like you're getting better, but please come to the hospital again next week.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「一応夜道だから、気をつけてね。それじゃまた明日。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Just in case, be careful since you are walking at night. Alright, I'll see you tomorrow.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ルームメイトの間での話：「Ｆａｃｅｂｏｏｋアカウントは一応持ってるけど、あまり使ってない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between roommates: 'I have a facebook account just in case, but I don't use it much.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 教師が生徒に：「ハサミが必要になるかは分かりませんが、一応持ってきてください。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Teacher to students: 'I do not know if scissors will be necessary, but just in case, please bring some.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達は助言する：「引越ししたら、一応、隣近所に挨拶しないとね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A friend is giving advice: 'If you move, just in case, greet the neighbors.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達の間での話：「このスマホは充電してあるけど、一応モバイルバッテリーも持ってきた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between friends: 'This phone is already charged, but just in case, I also brought a power bank.'

Name: 一応(いちおう) ②
Meaning: more or less, for the time being, tentatively, roughly
About: When used as an adverb, 一応(いちおう) can often carry the nuance of (A) not being perfect or ideal, but the minimum required in order to satisfy some requirement. This 'requirement' is frequently related to the time or amount of something. When used this way, 一応(いちおう) may be interpreted as 'more or less, (A)', 'for the time being, (A)', or 'tentatively (A)'. This use of 一応(いちおう) is in contrast to the other common use of 一応(いちおう), which can be translated as 'just in case', or 'just to be sure'. In these cases, the speaker is usually indicating that (A) is being done in order to avoid or prevent (B). However, in both of its uses, it simply indicates that (A) is the minimum amount which is fulfilling some requirement.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一応私が店長ですが、どうかなさいましたか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm more or less the manager. Did something happen?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は一応ここまでにしておきましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For the time being, let's call it a day for today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 周りの人たちが立ち始めたので、僕も一応立った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: People around me started to stand up, so tentatively, I also stood up.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今夜は寒くなるかも知れないから、一応ジャケットかなんか持ってきな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why don't you take a jacket or something, just in case, since it might get cold tonight.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一応言っておくけど私は踊るのが下手だからね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just to be sure, I want to let you know that I am not a good dancer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「もうコンピュータを直したの？」
「一応ね。時間がかかったけど。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Have you repaired the computer?'
'More or less. It took a while though.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 医者、患者について：「ふう…一応、容態は安定化できました。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Doctor, about a patient: '*sighing* We were able to stabilize her condition, for the time being.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 若く見えるメリオダズさん：「これでも一応、僕は大人なんです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Young looking Melodiaz: 'Despite this (the way I look), I am more or less an adult.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 部長：「残念ながらもう時間がありませんので、これで一応会議は終わりです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Head of the department: 'Unfortunately, we have run out of time, so with that, the meeting is finished for the time being.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
転んだ友達１に話しかける友達２：「大丈夫？」
友達１：「一応。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Friend2 talks to Friend1 who has fallen: 'Are you ok?'
Friend1: 'More or less.'

Name: に相違(そうい)ない
Meaning: Without a doubt, Certainly, Surely, Not mistaken
About: In a similar fashion to に違(ちが)いない, に相違(そうい)ない is a structure that firmly states that something is 'without a doubt (A)', or that there is 'no mistaking (A)'. It may be used to strengthen one's own opinions, or to strongly agree with the opinion of another. Although 相違(そうい) may be used by itself meaning 'to differ', or 'to have a discrepancy', 相違(そうい)ない is considered as a set い-Adjective. When combined with ない, the literal meaning is just 'there is no discrepancy in (A)'. に相違(そうい)ない may be used with verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives and nouns. に相違ない will often follow から, highlighting that there is no mistaking the 'cause' of (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は小学生の頃から一生懸命勉強をし続けたので、いい大学に行けるに相違ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since he's been studying hard since he was in elementary school, there's no doubt that he can go to a good university.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このコースはあの世界的に有名なシェフによって作られたものなので美味しいに相違ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This course has been prepared by a world famous chef, so there is no doubt that it will be delicious.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この街には電車が３分に１本来るので便利に相違ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In this city, a train comes every 3 minutes, so there is no doubt that it is convenient.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの事件の犯人はあの人に相違ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no doubt that that person is the culprit.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼がキョロキョロしているのは、嘘をついているからに相違ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no doubt that he's being restless because he's lying.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この技が全国の大会で禁止されているのは危ないからに相違ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There's no doubt that the reason why this move is forbidden in all competitions across the nation is because it's dangerous.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この下駄は彼の物に相違ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no doubt that these geta are his.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは県庁からの指示ということに相違ないか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no doubt that these are instructions from the prefectural office?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは我が社の公式の見解ということに相違ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no doubt that this is our company's official view.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: わたしの意見は妻の意見ということに相違ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no doubt that my opinion is my wife's opinion.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これはゴッホの絵のコレクションに相違ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is without a doubt Gogh's collection of paintings.

Name: 万(まん)が一(いち)
Meaning: Just in case, In the worst-case scenario, In the unlikely event, By any chance
About: 万(まん)が一(いち), or sometimes simply 万一(まんいち) is a grammar pattern that literally means '1 in 10000'. It is used in a similar way to phrases such as 'in the unlikely event of (A)', or 'just in case (A)' in English, and will usually highlight some measure against (A), or what will happen as a result of (A) in the latter half of the sentence. 万(まん)が一(いち) is primarily used adverbially, so will often come at the beginning of sentences.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 万が一の時のために防災セットを買っておきましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let's buy a disaster kit (in advance) just in case.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 万が一来れなくなった場合は、連絡をください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In the unlikely event that you are unable to come, please contact us.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 万が一の時のためにメールアドレスも教えていただいてもよろしいでしょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Can I possibly have your email address too just in case.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 万一分からないことがあれば、何でも私に聞いてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If by chance, there is something you don't understand, you can ask me anything.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 万が一のために、消火器を買うことにした。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
I decided to buy a fire extinguisher, just in case.
(in the unlikely event...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 万が一思いついたら、アイデアを教えてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Just in case you think of something, please tell me your idea.
(in the unlikely event...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 万が一嫌がられても、次の手は打ってある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even in the worst case scenario that they hate it, I will take alternative measures.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 万が一裁判で争うことになっても、受けて立ちますよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even in the unlikely event that we dispute it in court, I will accept that challenge.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 万が一入れ物がないと困るから、袋を持って行こう。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Since we will run into trouble not having a bag, let's take a bag along just in case.
(in the unlikely event...)

Name: 様(よう)がない
Meaning: There's no way to, It's impossible to
About: 様(よう)がない or 様(よう)もない is an expression used to highlight that there is no 'method' or 'manner' in which to do (A). It can be interpreted as 'there is no way to (A)', or 'it's impossible to (A)'. This phrase will appear attached to the conjunctive form of verbs. 様(よう)がない often focuses on that the action of (A) is not possible, despite that the speaker may actually want to do it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車も自転車も壊れているので買い物に行きようがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because my car and bicycle are broken, there is no way for me to go shopping.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パソコンが車にひかれて粉々になったため直しようがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's impossible to fix my computer because it was run over by a car and smashed to pieces.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電話番号もメールアドレスも分からないので、連絡のしようがありません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have no way to contact them because I don't know their phone number nor their email address.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何とも言いようがない味だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no way to put this taste/flavor into words.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 弁解のしようがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is impossible to explain.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これはどうにもしようがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no way to do this.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は速すぎて追い越しようがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is too fast, there is no way to overtake him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんなバレバレのサプライズ、驚きようがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is impossible to be surprised with such a ruined surprise.

Name: に他(ほか)ならない
Meaning: Nothing but, None other than, Simply
About: に他(ほか)ならない is a grammar pattern used with nouns to indicate that something is 'definitely (A)', or 'nothing but (A)'. Other common translations are 'none other than (A)', or 'simply (A)'. This expression is often used to emphasize statements, reasons, or causes. Being a combination of the noun 他(ほか) 'other' and the negated form of the う-Verb なる 'to become'. This phrase literally just states that (A) will not become anything other than what it is, as the given definition is already the most accurate.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: かすみさんがみんなに好かれるのはお人よしだからに他ならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The reason why Kasumi-san is liked by everyone is simply because she is a good person.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな夜遅くに訪問してくるなんて迷惑に他ならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Visiting me at such a late time is nothing but a nuisance.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: Ａチームがこの大会で優勝できたのは岡村コーチのおかげにほかならぬ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The reason why team A was able to win this tournament is simply because of coach Okamura.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 我が社の商品が人気なのは広告が印象的だからにほかならぬ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The reason our company's products are popular is simply because our advertisements leave a lasting impression.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 第一にすべきは人命にほかなりません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: First and foremost is nothing but living your life.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 三位という結果は彼の実力にほかならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Getting (the result of) 3rd was simply due to his skill.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 結局「笑い」というのは好き嫌いにほかならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In the end, 'laughing' is simply up to your likes and dislikes. （好き嫌い = noun)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼があの番組に出たのは、宣伝にほかならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Him going on that show was simply for publicity.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 通常の事故の原因はスピード違反にほかならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The common cause of the accidents is simply people going too fast.

Name: っこない
Meaning: There is no chance of, There is no way of, Impossible
About: っこない is a combination of the suffix っこ, and the い-Adjective ない. When attached to the conjunctive form of verbs, it creates new い-Adjectives that express the impossibility of (A). (A) being whichever verb is used. Common translations of っこない include 'there is no chance of (A)', or 'doing (A) is impossible'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年中に３０万円貯めたいの？お前の給料じゃできっこないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You want to save up three hundred thousand yen this year? There's no chance you can with your salary.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんなに鍛えてもあの人だけには勝てっこないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how much I train, there's no chance that I can beat him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんなデカい家、どんなに貯金しても買えっこないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will not be able to buy a house that big, no matter how much I save.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日までに５ページのレポートとか、絶対書けっ子ないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no way that I can write a 5 page essay by tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな漢字だらけの新聞なんて読めっ子ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no way I can read this newspaper that is filled with kanji.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「今持っているスキルでリングは何も滅ぼせっこありません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: With the skills we possess right now, we can’t destroy anything with this ring.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 練習をたくさんしなくては、楽器の演奏なんかできっこない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you do not practice a lot, there is no way you will be able to do a musical performance.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語で書く練習をしないと、日本語で書けるようにはなりっこない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you do not practice writing in Japanese, there is no way you will become able to write it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 怒ったお母さん：「ひきこもりのように、一日中家でゲームしてばかりでは、何も成し遂げっこない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Angry mother: 'There is no way you are going to accomplish anything if you are just sitting at home, playing games like a hikikomori.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんなに勉強したって「は」と「が」の違いなんて分かりっこない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter how much I study, there is no way for me to understand the difference between 'は' and 'が'.

Name: それなら
Meaning: Then, If that's the case
About: Acting as a conjunction, それなら is a structure used for highlighting that if the previous statement is the case, then (B) will probably also be true, or will need to be considered. それなら may be interpreted as 'if that's the case, then (B)'. それなら is most often used when replying to some statement that the speaker has just heard from another person. In these cases, it will come before some sort of guess, suggestion, or consideration about what the speaker has just heard. だったら and それだったら may also be seen, and carry the same meaning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 駅の近くにあるスーパーに行くの？それならついでに私を駅まで送ってくれない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You're going to the supermarket near the station? If that's the case, can you drop me off at the station?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カメラの画質がいいスマホをお探しなんですか？それならこのスマホをお勧めします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are looking for a smartphone with a good camera? If that's the case, I recommend this one.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それなら彼でもできるようだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If that's the case, it seems like even he will be able to do it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それなら早く警察に電話したほうがいいよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If that's the case, you should call the cops as soon as possible.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それなら先生に聞いたほうがいいと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If that's the case, you should ask the teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一人で食べに行くの？だったら僕も一緒に行ってもいい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You're going to go eat alone? If that's the case, can I come with you?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中君もコストコに行くの？それだったら一緒に行こうよ。そのほうがガソリン代も節約できるし。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-kun, are you also going to Costco? If that's the case, let's go together. That way, we can save money on gas.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
遠藤さん：「アプリをもっと使いやすくしました。」
土井さん：「それなら普及すると思います。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Endo-san: 'They made the application easier to use.'
Doi-san: 'If that is the case, I think it will spread.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
岩村さん：「もう誰も食べないんだね。」
山崎さん：「それなら蓋をした方がいい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Iwamura-san: 'No one else is going to eat anymore.'
Yamasaki-san: 'If that is the case, it would be good to put the lid on.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
藤本さん：「この戸は鍵が壊れてかからない。」
横山さん：「それならあまりにも物騒だ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Fujimoto-san: 'The lock on this door is broken and won't lock.'
Yokoyama-san: 'If that is the case, it is exceedingly dangerous.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
松本さん：「あそこは開かずの踏切だ。」
山端さん：「それなら陸橋を渡った方がいい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Matsumoto-san: 'That is a railway crossing that never opens.'
Yamahata-san: 'If that is the case, it would be better to go over the overpass.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
森口さん：「今鍋が使えない。」
上田さん：「それなら代わりにフライパンを使えばいい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Moriguchi-san: 'Right now we can't use the pot.'
Ueda-san: 'If that is the case, it would be good if we used a frying pan as a substitute.'

Name: ものなら ①
Meaning: If, If one could, If something would be possible
About: Often seen after the potential form of verbs is the conjunction particle ものなら. This grammar pattern expresses that while (A) is not thought to be possible, if it were possible, (B). Common translations include 'if (A), (B)', if one could (A), (B)', and 'if (A) were possible, (B)'. As ものなら is just a combination of もの and the hypothetical form of だ (なら), ものなら simply states that if (A) were a 'thing', then (B). Due to ものなら regularly expressing a desired outcome in the (B) part of sentences, this grammar structure will usually be accompanied by てみる or てみたい. Additionally, もし may also appear at the beginning of the sentence to further increase the nuance of 'if'. てみる is often used for criticism, suggesting that if someone thinks that (A) were possible, then perhaps they should try it. てみたい on the other hand is more commonly seen when (A) is wished for, and the speaker would like to do it if possible. While not a strict rule, the verb in both the (A) and (B) parts of ものなら sentences is frequently the same. Especially when expressing a desire to do (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺のことを捕まえることができると思うものなら、捕まえてみろ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you think that you can catch me, try and catch me!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: すぐに直せるものなら直したいけど、今はちょっとお金がないから厳しいかな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it can be fixed soon, I'd like to fix it, but it might be tough right now because I don't have money.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もしあなたが私より上手に書けるものなら自分で書いてみたらどうですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you can write it better than I can, why don't you write it yourself?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もし行けるものならケニヤに行ってみたいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it's possible, I would like to go to Kenya.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私よりもっと上手くやれるものならやってみろ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you can do this better than me, I'd like to see you try.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もしできるものなら、二年前にビットコインを買ったんだが。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I could, I would have bought bitcoins two years ago.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 行けるものなら僕だって大学院に行きたいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I could go, even I want to go to graduate school.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なれるものなら体操選手になりたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I could become one, I want to become a gymnast.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 直せるものなら短所を直したいが、簡単ではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I could, I would like to fix my shortcomings, but it is not easy.

Name: に任(まか)せる
Meaning: Leave 〜 up to, Entrust 〜 to
About: (A) を (B) に任(まか)せる is a structure used to highlight that something is being 'entrusted' or 'left up to (B). This can be thought of as a standard function of the る-Verb 任(まか)せる 'to entrust'. In (A) を (B) に任(まか)せる sentences, (A) を will identify the task, while (B) に will identify the person or thing that (A) is being left up to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は忙しいから、あなたにペットの世話を任せてもいい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is it alright if I trust you to take care of my pet since I'm busy?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先月入社して来たばかりの新人くんにあの重要なプレゼンを任せたの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You entrusted that important presentation to a newcomer who just joined the company last month?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女と付き合えるかどうかを神様に任せる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm going to leave it to God to decide if I can go out with her or not.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの会社に入れるかどうかは運に任せる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'll leave it to luck if I can join that company or not.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アンテナの修理を息子に任せた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I entrusted repairing the antenna to my son.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 研修生に掃除を任せます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will leave the cleaning up to the trainee.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 奇跡が起こるかどうかを神様に任せる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether or not a miracle happens I will leave up to the gods.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 育児を親に任せっきりというのはよくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Completely leaving child rearing to parents is not good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 井戸の調査を専門家に任せよう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's leave the well inspection to a professional.

Name: 活(い)かす
Meaning: To make use of (something), To take full advantage of, To capitalize on, To leverage (skills), Bring out (the quality of)
About: When を活(い)かす is partnered with a noun, it shows that (A) is something that is being made good use of, or leveraged. This can be in relation to skills, experiences, attributes, and many other things. This grammar point may appear either in the form of the う-Verb 活(い)かす 'to enliven' or 生(い)かす 'to keep alive', with very little change in nuance. However, 活(い)かす tends to appear far more frequently, as the focus of this kanji is less in relation to the preservation of life, and more on just 'making good use' of something. When linked to a (B) noun, in order to show that something 'has' been made good use of, 活(い)かす will appear in the past tense.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このパソコンの機能を十分に活かすのにはたくさんの知識が必要だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You need to be very knowledgeable in order to make use of all the features of this computer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この失敗を次に活かしてみてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please try to make use of this failure next time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私のくせ毛を活かした髪型にカットしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please give me a haircut that makes good use of my curly hair.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この料理は鯖の旨味を活かした料理なので調味料はあまり使っていません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This dish makes the most of the flavor of mackerel, so not much seasoning is used.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は仕事で日本語を十分に活かせるかが心配です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am concerned about my ability to fully make use of my Japanese at work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勉強が出来る時間は限られている為、時間を有効に活かせるようにプランを立ててから勉強をするようにしています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The time that I can study is limited, so in order to make good use of my time, I make sure to make a plan before I start studying.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達との話：「ぼくはこのチャンスを活かしたい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between friends: 'I want to take full advantage of this chance.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新聞記事：「ルイスさんは技師としての経験を活かして修理業を始めました。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Newspaper article: 'Louis made good use of his experience as a technician and started a repair business.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ノートパソコンの生産者のサイト：「アルミニウムの美しさを最大限に活かしたノートパソコン」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Laptop producer's website: 'A laptop that takes full advantage of the beauty of aluminum'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 教師、生徒に：「マックス、すばらしい写真をとる才能があるのだから、それを最大限に活かすべきだよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Teacher to pupil: 'Max, you are talented at taking excellent photos, so you have to take full advantage of it!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ジョブ広告：「資格を活かした仕事です。一緒に頑張ってくれる仲間を募集中。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Job advertisement: 'This is a job that takes full advantage of your qualifications. Recruiting colleagues who will work hard with us.'

Name: おおよそ
Meaning: Approximately, Roughly, About, Outline, Gist
About: およそ or おおよそ, alternatively written as either 凡(およ)そ or 大凡(おおよそ) is an adverb that commonly translates as 'approximately' or 'roughly' in English. It is primarily used in slightly more formal contexts, and can frequently be heard over announcements. As おおよそ is an adverb that is used in relation to time or distance more than anything else, it will usually be positioned at the beginning of sentences.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この物件から最寄りの駅までは徒歩でおよそ１０分かかります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It takes approximately 10 minutes to walk to the nearest train station from this property.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はおおよそ理解したけど、周りの子達はポカーンとした表情で先生を見ていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I understood most of it, but the people around me were looking at the teacher with a blank stare.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 美術館では、凡そ高価な作品を展示している。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a rule, museums display expensive pieces.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まずは計画のおおよそを説明しよう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To start with, let's roughly explain the plan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 地震による犠牲者はおおよそ１２０人です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are approximately 120 victims as a result of the earthquake.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の家から実家までおよそ１０キロ離れている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My house is separated from my family home by approximately 10 kilometers.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: およその見積もりを立ててから詳細をつめる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's hammer out the details after setting up a rough approximation.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パーティーにくるおおよその人数を把握する。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To figure out roughly how many people will come to the party.

Name: まい
Meaning: Won't, Intend not to, Probably not
About: The auxiliary verb まい is used in Japanese to express negative volition. This means that in many ways, it is the opposite of う and よう, which are the auxiliary verbs that express positive volition. まい connects to the base form of verbs, and is considered slightly formal. まい may be translated as 'won't (A)', 'to intend not to (A)', or 'probably not (A)'. It can be considered as a condensed way of expressing ～ないだろう.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんな接客が雑なレストランにはもう行くまい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I probably won't go back to that restaurant with such poor customer service.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのアパートの家賃は高いので、あそこには住むまい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The rent for that apartment is expensive, so I probably won't live there.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中くんはとてもいい人なので、そんなひどい事はしまい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since Tanaka-kun is a nice person, he probably wouldn't do such a terrible thing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 台風の警報が出ているので、今日中に届くはずだった荷物はこまい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since there was a warning announced for the typhoon, I probably won't get the package that I was expecting today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの店は行列がすごすぎる。もう行くまい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The line at that shop is too crazy. I probably won't go again.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 税金が高いから、この町には住むまい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't intend to live in this town because the taxes are high.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私のせいでものすごい苦情だ。もう失敗するまい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I caused the terrible grievances. I intend not to fail again.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人の話は下品だ。二度と聞くまい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person's stories are vulgar. I probably won't listen to them a second time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昨日飲みすぎてしまったので、二度と酒は飲むまい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I drank too much last night, I don't intend to drink ever again.

Name: 上(じょう)
Meaning: From the standpoint of
About: Attaching to nouns, 上(じょう) is a suffix that highlights when something is being presented 'from the standpoint of (A)'. The 'standpoint' that 上(じょう) will indicate is usually a specific field or area of concern. The (B) part of the sentence will then go on to describe what exactly is being considered from that standpoint. 上(じょう) is fairly formal, and can be interpreted similarly to に関(かん)して 'in connection to', in that it is just expressing that (B) is being discussed in relation to (A). As 上(じょう) will be used with matters of concern, it is very frequently seen with words that express broad fields, such as work '仕事(しごと)', 'education' 教育(きょういく), 'history' 歴史(れきし), 'health' 健康(けんこう), 'experience' 経験(けいけん), 'the law' 法律(ほうりつ), and other similar things.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 法律上、伊勢海老を許可なく釣り上げて持って帰ることが禁止されている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From a legal standpoint, it is prohibited to fish for lobsters and bring them home without a permit.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 規則上、生徒は髪を染めてはいけないのに、髪を染めている生徒が複数います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the standpoint of the rules, it is prohibited for the students to dye their hair, but there are a few students that have dyed hair.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 鈴木上、会社Ａが会社Ｂに買収される事はいい事だと思っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the standpoint of Suzuki, he thinks that company A being bought by company B is a good thing. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 予算上、その依頼は断るしかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From a budget standpoint, I have no choice but to deny that request.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのビルは構造上地震に弱い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That building, from a construction standpoint, is weak to earthquakes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 規則上、このアパートでペットを飼うのは禁止です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the standpoint of the rules, this apartment prohibits pets.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは飽くまで計算上の話で、実際にはそう簡単にはいきません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That is a discussion that will only ever be viewed from the standpoint of forecasting. In practice, it wouldn't go that easily.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 立場上ああいう発言をしたが、個人的には争う気持ちは全くない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From that (situation's) standpoint, I made that sort of remark, but personally I'm not in the mood to quarrel at all.

Name: 上(うえ)に
Meaning: As well, Besides, In addition to
About: 上(うえ)に is a grammar pattern that functions as a slightly formal way of saying 'and' in Japanese. It shows that something is 'in addition to (A)', 'as well as (A)', or 'besides (A)'. Literally, it simply shows that 'on top of (A), (B)'. 上(うえ)に may be used after that standard form of verbs and い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives followed by な上(うえ)に, and nouns followed by の上(うえ)に. Occasionally, the に may be dropped from this structure, without changing the meaning at all. When it comes to な-Adjectives and nouns, it is also common to see である上(うえ)に used as a conjugation pattern.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の犬は子供を見ると吠える上に噛みつこうとするので子供には近づけさせないようにしています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In addition to barking, my dog tries to bite children when he sees them, so I try not to let him get close to them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家の近所にあるレストランはまずい上に、高いからいつも空いている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The restaurant near my house is always empty because in addition to having bad food, they are expensive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高橋くんは無礼な上に清潔感がないため、周りの人たちには避けられている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takahashi-kun is rude as well as unhygienic, so he is avoided by the people around him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は調理師免許の上に健康食アドバイザーの資格も持っているので、彼女が作る料理は健康的で美味しいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In addition to having a chef's license, she also has qualification as a nutrition advisor, so the food she makes is healthy and delicious.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あそこの駅は不便である上に利用者が減っている為、来月の中旬に取り壊されるそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that the station over there is going to get torn down in the middle of next month because in addition to being inconvenient, it is losing users.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ケントさんは新聞記者である上にスーパーヒーローでもあった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Kent-san was a newspaper reporter as well as a superhero.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの建築会社が建てる家は丈夫な上にお洒落なので、すごく人気があるらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Apparently that building company is very popular right now because the houses they build are durable as well as stylish. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はハンサムな上に失礼だから、あまりモテない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is not very popular because in addition to being handsome, he is rude. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そのジムは安い上に、私の家から近い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As well as being cheap, that gym is close to my house. (on top of that)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの店はリフォームした上に、メニューも変わったらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that restaurant changed its menu, in addition to being remodeled. (on top of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はお洒落な上にイケメンだから、モテモテだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because he is stylish as well as good-looking, he is well-liked. (on top of that)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日の宿題は簡単な上に、少ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In addition to being easy, today's homework load was light. (on top of that)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人の説明は、曖昧な上に不正確だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person's explanation was vague, as well as inaccurate. (on top of that)

Name: 以上(いじょう) ②
Meaning: Since, Now that, As long as, If
About: When combined with the adverbial particle は, 以上(いじょう) is frequently translated as 'since (A), (B)', 'now that (A), (B)', or 'as long as (A), (B)'. This is a formal structure that is rarely found in daily speech. This construction may be used with verbs and い-Adjectives in their standard forms, and な-Adjectives or nouns followed by である以上(いじょう)は. As with many other grammar points, the particle is often dropped, leaving 以上(いじょう) by itself. Due to である以上(いじょう)は often presenting something which is being acted upon, the (B) part of sentences that include this grammar structure will frequently include the resolutions or intentions of the speaker, and can be thought of as either obvious or necessary once considering (A). This usually appears in the form of べきだ, つもりだ, はずだ, たい, ほうがいい, and similar patterns.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 猫を飼うと決めた以上は、最後まで責任を持って育てないといけないと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Now that I have decided to keep a cat, I think that I have the responsibility to raise it until the end.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 体調が悪い以上は、会社に来ないでください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As long as you are sick, please don't come into work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 有名である以上は、テレビではもちろん、ＳＮＳでも発言に気をつけなければいけません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As long as you are famous, you will have to watch what you say, not only on television, but also on social networks.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この地域の住民である以上は、この地域のルールをしっかりと守ってもらわないと困ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As long as you are a resident of this community, we need you to properly follow the rules of this community.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: キャプテンに選ばれた以上、結果を残すために精一杯頑張ります！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Now that I have been chosen as captain, I will do my best to achieve results!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんなに気を付けていても、人間である以上、ミスは防げないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how careful you are, as long as you're human, you can't avoid making mistakes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 試験を受ける以上、休むことはできない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As long as I am taking the exam, I can't rest.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 親である以上は子育てを頑張るべきだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since you are a parent, you should do your best to raise your child.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本に来た以上、真剣に日本語の勉強をしたいと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Now that I have come to Japan, I think I want to study Japanese seriously.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 都心に住んでいる以上、渋滞は避けられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Now that I am living in the city center, I can't avoid the traffic.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この条件で引き受けた以上、文句は言えない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Now that I have agreed to these terms, I can't complain.

Name: 以上(いじょう)に
Meaning: More than, No less than, Even more
About: Like other structures that include 以上(いじょう) 'beyond', 以上(いじょう)に highlights that (A) is beyond some specific extent. In this grammar pattern, the case marking particleに will indicate the word that 以上(いじょう)に is attached to as an amount. With (A) being considered as 'beyond' something, 以上(いじょう)に can be translated as 'more than (A)', or 'even more than (A)'.以上(いじょう)に may be used after verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives, or nouns in their standard forms. Occasionally, に may be replaced by の when a specific amount or quantity is being indicated with a second noun. The noun attached to の may not always obviously be an 'amount', but it is something that the speaker is 'measuring' in regard to (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しく発売した商品の評判が思っていた以上に良かったのでびっくりした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was surprised to find that the newly launched product was more well-received than I had expected.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日の風は冷たい以上に痛い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: More than it is cold, today's wind is painful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今節約中だから必要以上にお金を使わないようにしてる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I am saving money right now, I am trying not to use more money than necessary.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はスキー以上にスノーボードが好きだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like snowboarding more than skiing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 僕の最初のライブに想像していた以上の人が集まったので、すごく嬉しかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was very happy that more people than I expected showed up to my first concert.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の先輩は思った以上の人生を送っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My senpai is living a better life than I thought.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 天気は予想以上に悪かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The weather was worse than I thought.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼には思った以上の人生がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He has more of a life than I thought.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は、競馬以上に競輪が好き。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She likes bicycle racing more than horse racing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お父さんのギャグは、僕のギャグ以上にくだらない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My father's jokes are more stupid than mine.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は、カーブ以上にシュートをよく投げる投手です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is a pitcher who throws screwballs more than curve balls.

Name: 途中(とちゅう)に
Meaning: On the way, Partway, In the middle of
About: With 途中(とちゅう) meaning 'on the way', the addition of either the case marking particleに or で will indicate that something is either being done 'on the way to (A)', 'partway through (A)' or 'in the middle of (A)'. 途中(とちゅう) may be seen after verbs in their standard form, or nouns followed by の. As always, に will put more emphasis on the time or duration of (A), while で will put further emphasis on the process of (A) being the cause of (B), or being used as an opportunity to do (B). Let's take a look at both. The meanings of で and に in regard to this particular grammar point can overlap quite often, so it may be necessary to see many examples before the slight difference in nuance becomes apparent.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 待ち合わせ場所に向かっている途中に、「ごめん、やっぱり今日行けないかも」と友達からメールが来た。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the way to the meeting place, I received a text from a friend saying, 'Sorry, I might not be able to make it today after all'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 授業の途中に校長先生から呼び出された時はビクッとした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was a bit startled when the principal called me out in the middle of class.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 会社から帰る途中で変なおじさんに話しかけられた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On my way home from work, a strange man tried to talk to me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ミーティングの途中で社長が倒れて、会社中がパニックになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The president collapsed in the middle of a meeting and everyone in the whole company panicked.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: シャッターが途中で閉まらなくなってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The shutter unfortunately stopped closing in the middle.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 集金の途中でお釣りがなくなってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I lost the change partway through collecting money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 面接の途中でリクルーターはいきなり笑い始めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In the middle of an interview, the recruiter suddenly started laughing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 朝ご飯を作っている途中で電話が鳴った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In the middle of making breakfast, the telephone rang.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: シーズンの途中で引退会見をするのは微妙だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Holding a retirement press conference in the middle of the season is questionable.

Name: 中(なか)を
Meaning: In, On, Into, Inside of
About: Coming from the base meaning of the noun 中(なか) meaning 'inside', the addition of the case marking particleを in its role of identifying the place where an action is taking place creates a grammar structure that can be translated as 'doing (B) in (A)', 'doing (B) on (A)', or 'doing (B) inside of (A)'. With this grammar point, (B) will be the action, while (A) will be a noun indicating the location.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家に帰ってきたら、まずは弁当箱の中を空にしてっていつも言ってるじゃん！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I always tell you to empty out the inside of the lunch box first thing when you come home, don't I?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: スーパーの中を何も買わずにウロウロしていたら、警備員のおじさんに怪しまれて声をかけられた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I was wandering around (inside) the supermarket without buying anything, the security guard thought I was suspicious so he came to talk to me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供が妙に静かだな〜と思い、子供部屋の中を覗いてみたらただ寝ていただけだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I thought, 'My kid is suspiciously quiet', so I peeked into their room, but they were just sleeping.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トンネルの中を覗く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will peer into a tunnel.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 鍋の中を洗う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will wash the inside of a pot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 家の中を猫が駆け回っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The cat is running around the inside of the house.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ペットボトルの中をちゃんと洗ってください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please wash the inside of the plastic bottle.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人混みの中を歩くのは大変です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is hard to walk within a crowd of people.

Name: を中心(ちゅうしん)に
Meaning: Focused on, Centered on or around, Mainly, Most notably
About: When combined with nouns, the expression を中心(ちゅうしん)に indicates that something is being 'focused on' or 'centered around'. Occasionally, it may also be translated simply as 'mainly (A)', or 'most notably (A)'. 中心(ちゅうしん) itself is a noun that expresses the 'pivot', or 'central focus point' from which something else is occurring. The case marking particleに just marks '(A) を中心(ちゅうしん)に' as the target that is being focused on. Due to 中心(ちゅうしん) itself marking a 'central point', it may also be used just to express the middle of something, rather than something that is being concentrated or focused on. By adding する in either its dictionary or past forms, を中心(ちゅうしん)にする or を中心(ちゅうしん)にした may appear before another noun. This will highlight the noun that comes after as being the overall thing through which the 'focus on (A)' is taking place. Additionally, the case-marking particle と may sometimes replace に. This change will put more nuance on the focus point being conclusive, rather than progressive or decisive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのアイドルは若者を中心に人気を集めている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That idol is gaining popularity, mainly among young people.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は今日本語の文法を中心に勉強をしています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Currently, I am focusing my studies on Japanese grammar.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日からは札幌を中心に大雪が降るところがあるでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There will be heavy snow in some areas, mainly in Sapporo, starting tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この業界ではお客様を中心にすることが一番重要なことだと言われている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is said that the most important thing in this industry is to focus on the customers.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これからはクライアントの提案を中心にした話を進めたいと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From now on, I would like to proceed with a focus on the client's proposal.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここはスケートボードを中心にしたポップアップストアです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is a pop-up store focusing on skateboards.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 健康診断に行ったら先生に揚げ物を中心とする食生活はやめるようにと言われた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I went to my physical check-up, my doctor told me to stop centering my diet around fried food.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: てるはしさんを中心に世界が回っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The world revolves mainly around Teruhashi-san.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: マコさんはコンピューターを中心として生活をしている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mako leads a life centered around computers.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 妻は働き、私は育児を中心に生活しています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My wife works and I place my focus on raising the children. That is our livelihood.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのアンテナを中心に家を何軒か建てましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's build some houses centered around that antenna.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 息子はあいかわらずお金を中心に物を考えているようだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As always, my son always thinks in terms that are focused on money.

Name: その上(うえ)
Meaning: Besides, In addition, Furthermore
About: その上(うえ) is a formal expression used in Japanese to indicate that something is 'besides', 'in addition to', or 'furthermore' in relation to the previous statement. It primarily comes at the beginning of sentences before reflecting back on and adding new information in regard to what has already been said. The literal meaning can be thought of as 'on top of that (B)', where 'that' is the information that has already been mentioned. Despite often being used in formal settings, it is not uncommon to hear this phrase used in daily speech, due to its simplicity in highlighting something being 'in addition'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高橋さんはとても頭がいい。その上、人柄もいいので会社での評判がいいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takahashi-san is very smart. Furthermore, he has a very good personality so he has a very good reputation in the company.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今住んでいる家はものすごく小さい。その上隣に住んでいる住人が一日中うるさいので、来月引っ越そうと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The house I live in now is extremely small. In addition, the people who live next door are noisy all day long, so I'm thinking of moving out next month.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は学校で先生に怒られた。その上家に帰ったら親に怒られたのであまりいい一日ではなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was scolded by my teacher at school today. In addition, I was scolded by my parents when I came home, so it was not a very good day today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は勇ましい。その上優しいのだから、言うことない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is brave. In addition, he is kind, so there isn't anything to say.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の家は薄暗い。その上寒いから、冬場は悲惨だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: His house is gloomy. Furthermore, it is cold, so winter time is terrible.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 顔が青白い。その上、唇は紫だ。大丈夫だろうか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: His face is pale. Furthermore, his lips are purple. Is he okay, I wonder?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は思い込みが激しい。その上頑固だから、手に負えない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: His prejudices are intense. In addition, he is stubborn , so I can't manage him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は植木職人だ。その上パソコンのプログラムもできるなんて、すごい人だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is a gardener. In addition, he is an impressive person who can do things like computer programming.

Name: 上(うえ)は
Meaning: Once, Since, Now that, As long as
About: A fairly old-fashioned phrase, 上(うえ)は highlights that something is being done or considered as a result of (A). It may be interpreted as 'once (A), (B)', 'since (A), (B)', 'now that (A), (B)', or 'as long as (A), (B)'. In these meanings, (B) will always be something that is deemed as either obvious or necessary. 上(うえ) in this phrase is a noun, and will be attached to the adverbial particle は. This creates a literal meaning that is similar to 'over and above (A), (B)'. This 'over and above' has a similar nuance to 'with that said', or 'all things considered' in English, and just presents (A) as something that is finalized. This structure follows verbs in the standard form. Due to 上(うえ)は being quite old-fashioned, expressions like からには or 以上(いじょう)は will be heard more frequently in modern-day Japanese, and will carry a similar meaning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一人暮らしを始めた上は、家事など料理は自分で全部やらなくてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Now that I have started living alone, I must do all the housework and cooking on my own.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アイルランドに住むと決めた上は、アイルランドの文化などを勉強しなければならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Now that I have decided to live in Ireland, I must study things such as Irish culture.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この会社の従業員として働く上はきちんと我が社のルールを守ってもらわないと困ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As long as you are working as an employee of this company, we need you to follow our rules.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ワンちゃんを保護すると決めたからには、最後まで責任をもって育てなくてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Now that you have decided to adopt a puppy, you must take responsibility and raise it until the end.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 十分な証拠がない以上は、彼を逮捕することができません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since we don't have sufficient evidence, we can't arrest him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: かくなる上はきさまを殺すしかない。今すぐ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since it has come to this, I have no choice but to kill you. Immediately.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何かをし始める上は正しくやらなければならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once you start doing something, you have to do it properly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本に来た上は勉強するつもりです。
