Questions.EnglishHTML: Now that I have come to Japan, I intend to study.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 卒業した上はより大人らしくなるべきだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Now that I have graduated, I should act more like an adult.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 市長になった上は住民のために何かをしてあげたいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Now that I am mayor, I want to do something for the citizens.

Name: の下(もと)で
Meaning: Under, Under the supervision of, On the basis of
About: When the noun 下(もと) 'underneath' is combined with either of the case marking particles で or に, it will indicate that something is happening either under the influence, guidance, or basis of (A). (A) will be a noun that is connected to 下(もと)で or に through the case-marking particle の. In this grammar structure, (A) may mark either a specific person or some situation equally as naturally. Occasionally, に or で will be able to be omitted in preference of a comma directly after 下(もと). This expression is considered quite formal, and the omission of the particle in favor of a comma will make it sound even more formal.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな厳しい環境の下で試料を採取できたのは皆様のおかげです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thanks to all of you, we were able to gather samples under such harsh conditions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩の下で働けて光栄です！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is my pleasure that I can work under you!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その行為はこの法律の下で禁止されています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That action is prohibited on the basis of this law.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 皆さんの協力の下、このプロジェクトを無事に終えることができました。皆さんありがとうございました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Under everyone's hard work, we were able to successfully complete this project. Thank you all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 佐々木先輩のご指導の下、企画書を作成しています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am creating a proposal, on the basis of Sasaki-senpai's guidance.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 沖縄は１９４５年から１９７２年までアメリカの統治下であった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Okinawa was under the reign of America from 1945 to 1972.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その国は現在敵国の支配下にある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Currently, that country is under the control of our enemy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ベジカと戦うためにそんゴツウはカエ王様の下で修行した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In order to battle with Vegika, Songotsu trained under King Kae.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 叔父さんの下で働いた３年間は、僕にとって宝物です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The three years that I worked under my uncle were special to me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 盤石な地盤の下での選挙だが、余裕というわけではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is an election on the basis of solid foundations, but that does not mean that it will be a walk in the park. (under)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 優秀な講師の下で実験をしていたから、いろいろなスキルが身につきました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The experiments I performed under an excellent lecturer allowed me to master a number of skills.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 高い基準の下で訓練を受けたから、その後の仕事が楽にこなせる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because you trained under (while being held to) high standards, the rest of the work you do will be a breeze.

Name: 後(あと)の + (Noun)
Meaning: …left, Rest, Remaining, In, …to, …else
About: One of the common uses for the noun 後(あと) 'behind' is to express a remainder, or everything after a certain point. This can be translated as 'what's left of (A)', 'the rest of (A)', 'what's remaining of (A)', or even 'other than (A)'. Let's have a look at a few examples. 後(あと) will be grouped with the case marking particle の before nouns, come directly before numbers, or be used at the beginning of whole phrases. Despite having many different translations, the base meaning of 後(あと) will always just be to identify a sequence of things, and what comes 'after' or 'behind' a specific point in that sequence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今あなたが持っている段ボール箱はキッチンまで運んでおいてください。後の段ボール箱は全部寝室までお願いします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please bring the cardboard box you are carrying into the kitchen. Please take all the rest to the master bedroom.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 後ちょっとで着くからもうちょっと我慢して。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We will arrive in a little bit, so please be patient for a little longer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 映画公開まで後三日！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Three days left until the movie gets released!

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「次の電車はいつくるの？」
「後八分で来るよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'When is the next train coming?'
'It will be coming in eight minutes.' (after)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
いすずちゃん：「この問題は私がやるわ。」
かにえくん：「じゃあ、後はこっちに任せてくれ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Isuzu: 'I will deal with this problem.'
Kanie: 'If so, then leave the rest to me.' (remaining)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
チトゲさん：「ラクさんが来るまで、後何分？」
オノデラさん：「まだ後五分！」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Chitoge: 'How many minutes left until Raku comes?'
Onodera: 'Still 5 minutes left!' (remaining)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
彼女：「たまごと牛乳はあるの。」
彼氏：「後は何が必要なの？」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Girlfriend: 'We have eggs and milk.'
Boyfriend: 'Do we need anything else?' (remaining)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
ヨツバちゃん：「ミクとイツキは先に行ったわ。」
フウタロウくん：「後の連中は？」
ヨツバちゃん：「全然わからないわ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Yotsuba: 'Miku and Itsuki went ahead.'
Fuutarou: 'And the rest of the group?'
Yotsuba: 'I have no idea.' (remaining)

Name: 手前(てまえ)
Meaning: Before, In front of, From one's standpoint or side
About: The noun 手前(てまえ) 'in front of' has several different meanings in Japanese depending on whether it is being used with a verb in its standard form, or with a noun. Regarding verbs, it expresses 'going forward from (A), (B)'. This is usually in relation to something that has happened either accidentally or completely, and may represent what will be done as a result of being in that situation. This can also be interpreted as 'now that (A), (B)', and simply highlights that nothing can be done except to move on or 'forward' given the current circumstances. When 手前(てまえ) appears with nouns followed by the case marking particle  の, it often expresses that what is 'in front' of (A) is the reason for (B), or simply is 'in front of (A)'. Despite the many translations, 手前(てまえ) always shows something that is 'facing' the noun or verb that appears with it. Due to this, thinking of this structure as similar to 'faced with (A), (B)' may be helpful, as English also expresses lack of option and finality in this way.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 崖から落ちる手前で父親に腕を引っ張られた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My father pulled me by my arm before I fell off the cliff.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勢いで手を上げてしまった手前、答えずに手を下げるわけにはいかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the standpoint of me raising my hand in the heat of the moment, there is no way of me backing out without answering the question.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩にはいつもお世話になっている手前、彼女の頼みを断るわけにはいかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since my senpai always takes good care of me, there is no way that I can turn down her request.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 娘の手前、運動音痴な姿を見せるわけにはいかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't show my unathletic self in front of my daughter.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女の両親の手前、発言には気を付けなければいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have to be careful of what I say when I am in front of my girlfriend's parents.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたの手前にあるものを見てください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please look at the thing that is in front of you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: オルガンをもっと手前に配置してください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please position the organ even more in front.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 死んでしまう一歩手前で助かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was helped just before I would have died. (on the brink)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の手前の人が、私の友達です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The person in front of me is my friend.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 火山の被害がうちの手前まで及んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The damage from the volcano extended to right in front of my house.

Name: を巡(めぐ)って
Meaning: Concerning, In regard to, About, (Split) over
About: One of the more indirect ways that 'to be concerning (A)' is conveyed in Japanese is through the pairing of a noun with the case marking particle を and the う-Verb 巡(めぐ)る 'to go around' in either its て-form, or standard form when paired with a second noun. This grammar point can be translated as 'concerning (A)', 'in regard to (A)', or 'about (A)'. However, following the most natural translation, we can see that 'to go around the topic of (A)', or 'encompassing (A)' are also acceptable.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 隣人と土地の境界線を巡ってトラブルが起きた時は誰に連絡するべきですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Who should I contact if I have a problem with my neighbor concerning my property line?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この島を巡る争いは私が生まれる前から続いています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The conflict concerning this island has been going on since before I was born.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ゴミ出しルールを巡ってのトラブルはどの地域でも珍しいことではありません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter the community, conflicts concerning garbage disposal rules are not uncommon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 数が限られている限定商品を巡ってお客様同士が言い合いになってしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Customers argued with each other over a limited number of limited edition products.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 税金の使い方を巡る議論から、内戦が始まってしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A debate over the use of taxes has led to a civil war.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本には金魚を巡る戦いがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is conflict in Japan over goldfish.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの組合せを巡っては、やらせの疑いがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is suspicion of a prearranged performance concerning that match (in a contest).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ファイルの形式を巡る話し合いが今も続いています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The discussion over the file format is still going on, even now.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 伝説の釜を巡って、専門家たちが言い合いをしています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The specialists are quarreling over the legendary iron pot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 塩分の過剰摂取を巡って、意見が分かれている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Opinions are divided over the excessive consumption of salt.

Name: に渡(わた)って
Meaning: Across, Throughout, Extends, Over (a period of time or range)
About: Partnered with the case marking particle に, the う-Verb 渡(わた)る 'to cross' in its て-form highlights a span of something in regard to breadth, size, or time. This structure is often translated as either 'across (A)', 'throughout (A)', 'extending through (A)', or 'over the period of (A)'. Like other verb structures that pair with nouns, the standard form may also be used when paired with a second noun, in order to modify that noun. Coming from the meaning of 渡(わた)る 'to cross', this grammar pattern always expresses that something is either happening or exists 'all across (A)', or 'from the start to the finish'. Additionally, に渡(わた)って is considered quite formal, so will often be seen in articles or on the news.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は脱獄後長年に渡って警察から身を隠し続けた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He continued to hide from the police for many years after his escape.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １５年に渡る戦争は、ついにその幕を閉じた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A war that has been taking place for over fifteen years has finally come to its end.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今朝に渡って行われた会議がようやく終わった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The meeting that has been going on throughout the whole morning has finally ended.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今晩に渡って落ち続けていたＡ社の株がやっと上がった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The stock of Company A has finally risen after going down throughout tonight.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この車の細部に渡るこだわりはさすがですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The obsession over this car's details is impressive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 三日に渡って降り続いた雨がようやくやんだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The rain that continuously fell over three days has finally stopped.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ４０分に渡る校長先生の話が退屈だった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The principal's speech that took place over 40 minutes was boring.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 長期に渡って利用してきたサービスが終了してしまう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Unfortunately the service we have come to use over a long period of time will end.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日から７回に渡って、このテーマで授業を進めていきます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From today, I am going to make progress on the class theme that will take place over seven classes.

Name: に沿(そ)って
Meaning: Along, In accordance with, In line with
About: When used with the case marking particle に, the う-Verb 沿(そ)う 'to run alongside' in its て-form expresses that something is going 'along with (A)', 'in accordance with (A)', or 'in line with (A)'. This is primarily in relation to laws, conventions, traditions, needs, and other things which are not usually deviated away from. The nuance with this particular grammar structure is that (A) is the controlling factor, and (B) is being done with that in consideration. に沿(そ)って may also appear with the verb in its standard form when paired with a second noun, in order to modify that noun. As the base meaning of 沿(そ)う is 'to follow along', it will also regularly be seen in relation to going along some specific path or street. While this grammar structure is relatively formal, when literally meaning 'alongside', it will be used fairly frequently.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 会社のルールに沿って、残業をする方は必ずタイムカードを押してからにしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In accordance with company rules, please make sure to clock-in before you begin overtime.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: クライアント様の希望に沿う方向で進めたいと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We would like to proceed in accordance with the client's wishes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ご予算内でお客様のご希望に沿ったお家を建てれるよう全力を尽くします！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We will do our best to build you a home in accordance with your needs and within your budget!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この点線に沿って切ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please cut along this dotted line.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スケジュールに沿って作業を進めていきます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will continue operations in line with the schedule.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この台本に沿って司会してください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please lead the meeting in accordance with the script.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: じゅうたんに沿ってしるしを付けるのはやめてほしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want you to stop making marks along the carpet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 提示した資料に沿ってチェックを進めてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please continue the check in accordance with the presented materials.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「道に沿っていったら、そのうちスーパーが見えてきますよ」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'If you go along the street, the supermarket will eventually come into view'.

Name: ～た末(すえ)
Meaning: After, As a conclusion of
About: Appearing with verbs in their past form, or grouped with nouns after の is 末(すえ), a word meaning 'end tip'. に will follow 末(すえ) , marking the 'tip' as the point from which something will result. While this grammar pattern is usually translated as 'after (A), (B)', or 'as a result of (A), (B)', the nuance is on various things having happened along the way, and then finally reaching the 'point' or 'conclusion' of (A). 末(すえ)に may highlight either positive or negative results, but will suggest that some long-lasting effort or struggle eventually resulted in (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 色々と考えた末に、お父さんの会社を継ぐことに決めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After much thought, I decided to take over my father's company.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 迷いに迷った末に、彼女と別れることにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After much hesitation, I decided to break up with her.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ５年間にわたる争いの末、アメリカ軍が撤退を開始した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After five years of conflict, the U.S. military began to withdraw.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社長と長い議論の末に、人事の伊藤さんをクビにすることに決めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After a long discussion with the president, we decided to fire Ito-san from human resources.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 温泉をほりあてた末に、旅館を建てることにした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After (much) digging to reveal the onsen, I decided to build a ryokan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは、蚊にさされた末の感染症です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is an infectious disease that arises after being bitten by a mosquito.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いろいろ面接した末に、大企業に雇われたんだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After (doing) many interviews, I was hired by a big company.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人は、散々おそわった末に仕事をやめてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person, after being thoroughly taught (continuously), unfortunately quit.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 無理をして試合にでた末に、大怪我をしてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After going (all out) into the match without listening to my body, I ended up getting severely injured.

Name: に従(したが)って
Meaning: As, Following, As then, According to, In accordance with
About: By grouping the う-Verb 従(したが)う 'to comply' with に, a common pattern meaning 'to comply with (A)', 'in accordance with (A)', or 'following (A)' will be created. This is a fairly strong and formal structure, indicating that (B) is being controlled or heavily influenced by (A). (B) will often express some kind of ongoing or sudden change caused by (A). に従(したが)って may appear after either verbs or nouns in their dictionary forms. As this expression is quite formal, it is common to see it used in relation to matters that are usually discussed in formal or official situations, such as laws, standards, conventions, or traditions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 年を取るに従って、目がどんどん悪くなっていってる気がする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I feel like my eyes are getting worse and worse as I get older.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: テレワークの普及が進むに従って、通勤するサラリーマンが減っていっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As teleworking becomes more widespread, the number of office workers commuting to work is decreasing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 僕はただ上司の指示に従って仕事を進めていただけです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was just following my boss' instructions to get the job done.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この説明書に従って、パソコンの初期設定を行ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please follow these instructions to perform the initial setup of your computer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この原稿に従ってインタビューに答えてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please answer the interview in accordance with this manuscript.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 憲法に従って、新たな法律が成立する。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In accordance with the constitution, the new law will be established.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: クラスメイトの言うことに従って意地悪をしてはいけません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You must not act unkindly in accordance with what your classmates say.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この足跡に従って進めば、きっとみんなに会えるはずです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you progress in accordance with these tracks, you will surely be able to see everyone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会社の指示に従ってオートメーション化を進めています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The change to automation is progressing according to the company's specifications.

Name: に伴(ともな)って
Meaning: As, Due,  Along with, Hand-in-hand with, Resulted in, Be consequent upon
About: When the う-Verb 伴(ともな)う 'to accompany' in its て-form is used with に and attached to the end of nouns or verbs in their dictionary forms, it is regularly translated as 'due to (A), (B)', 'hand in hand with (A), (B)', or 'along with (A), (B)'. In all of these meanings, the base interpretation of 'to accompany' is being highlighted. As 'accompanying' does not specifically indicate that (A) is controlling (B), this grammar structure may be used simply to indicate things that happen at the same time, rather than when something is being directly caused by the first. However, (A) having a strong influence on the change of (B) is usually implied. に伴(ともな)う may also appear directly before another noun when it is being modified by the verb. に伴(ともな)って is used both for events that are progressively changing at the same time, and momentary events that cause a sudden change.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この町の人口が減少するに伴って空き家が増加して来ました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As the population of this town has declined, the number of vacant houses has increased.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パソコンの初期化をするのに伴う手順は取扱説明書の５１ページに記載されています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The procedure associated with formatting the computer is described on page 51 of the instruction manual.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: インターネットの普及に伴って、オンラインで買い物を済ませる人が増えた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: With the spread of the Internet, more and more people are completing their purchases online.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高速道路の情報サイト：リフレッシュ工事に伴う車線規制のお知らせ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Highway information website: Notice of lane restriction due to road reconstruction.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 津波は地震に伴い発生することが多いが、火山現象に伴い津波が発生することも有るそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Oftentimes, tsunami occur due to earthquakes, but apparently they can also occur due to volcanic phenomenon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 歳を取るに伴って物忘れが酷くなってきてる感じがする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I feel like I'm getting more forgetful as I get older.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 春が始まるに伴って、植生は復活する。
Questions.EnglishHTML: With the beginning of spring, the vegetation returns. (along with・consequent upon)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 医学の進歩に伴って平均寿命が伸びています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Along with the advancement of medical sciences, the average life expectancy is increasing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 円高に伴い輸出の量は減る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As the value of the yen rises, the volume of export decreases. (along with・consequent upon)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 火傷に伴う痛みは神経への刺激が原因だとされている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Pain associated with burns is considered to be caused by nerve stimulation.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 城の改修中、床の修理に伴って、壁も塗りなおされた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: During the castle renovation, along with the floor repairs, the walls were also repainted.

Name: に就(つ)き
Meaning: Due to, On account of, Each or every
About: Although rarely seen in its kanji form, につき is a grammar pattern that comes from a combination of に and the conjunctive form of the う- Verb 就(つ)く 'to take up (A)', or 'to assume (A)'. This meaning is usually in regard to assuming a new position, such as a new job. However, the particular meaning conveyed here will be closer to 'due to (A), (B)', 'on account of (A), (B)', or 'for each (A), (B)'. につき will follow nouns directly, before the (B) part of the sentence describes what is happening 'due to' or 'on account of (A)'. This grammar point is quite formal, so it is often seen in formal documents, announcements, and notifications. Regardless of the several common English translations, the base meaning of 'to affix to (A)' is kept in all of the uses of につき, as it simply implies that (B) is in answer to, exists in a way that is directly linked to, suitable for, or caused by (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 閉店につき、特別セール開催中！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to our store closing, there is a special sale going on!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 工事中につき、この先立ち入り禁止。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to construction, entry beyond this point is prohibited.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この商品は大人気のため、一人につき二つまでとさせていただいております。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since this product is very popular, we are limiting it to two per person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 工事中に就き、迂回してください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Due to construction, please take a detour.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 開店に就き、事務員を募集する。
Questions.EnglishHTML: On account of opening a new shop, we are hiring clerks.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今なら１００円に就き５ポイントもらえる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Right now, you get five points for each 100 yen you spend.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日は祭日に就き、会社は休みです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: On account of tomorrow's festival, the company will be closed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここは私有地に就き、通り抜け禁止です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Due to this being private land, it is prohibited to cut through here.

Name: に付(つ)け
Meaning: Whenever, Every time something happens
About: In a similar way to につき, につけ implies that there is a something that is 'affixed' to the event or occasion of (A). However, unlike に就(つ)き this structure is a combination of に and the conjunctive form of the る-Verb 付(つ)ける 'to affix', or 'to adhere'. When using につけ, the most common translation will be that something is happening 'every (A)', or 'whenever (A)'. In the (B) part of the sentence, the thoughts or feelings of the speaker will often be expressed in relation to (A). Additionally, (B) will always be something that is thought to happen naturally due to (A). This structure may appear with either verbs or nouns in their dictionary forms. It is also possible to see につけて, but the abbreviated form is far more common.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 元カノが写っている写真を見るにつけ、胸が痛くなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every time I see a picture with my ex-girlfriend, my heart aches.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この防波堤で釣りをするにつけ、父親のことを思い出す。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every time I fish on this breakwater, it reminds me of my father.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は何かにつけ文句を言うので、一緒にいるだけで疲れる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since he complains whenever anything happens, it's exhausting being around him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 妻は妊娠中なので悲しい思いをしたり嬉しい思いをしたりするにつけ、すぐに泣き出します。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since my wife is pregnant, she immediately bursts out crying whenever she has sad or happy experiences.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの時先輩に言われた事を思い出すにつけて、怒りが込み上がってきます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every time I remember what my senpai said to me, I get filled with anger.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼と一緒に時間を過ごすにつけて、なんでこんな人と付き合っているんだろうと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every time I spend time with him, I think to myself, 'why am I still dating such a person'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 話し合いをするに付け、喧嘩ばかりしてしまう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whenever we have a discussion, unfortunately we end up only fighting.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この絵を見るに付け、子供の頃のことを思い出す。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Every time I see this picture, I recall my childhood.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 悪い噂を聞くに付けて、だんだん不安になってきた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Every time I hear a bad rumor, I gradually become anxious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 雨に付け雪に付け、どうせ仕事には行かなければならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whenever it rains, whenever it snows, I somehow have to go to work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 隣の叔父さんは何かに付けて文句を言う人だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The old man next door is a person who complains whenever something (anything) happens.

Name: に関(かか)わる
Meaning: To relate to, To have to do with, Concerning, Depends on
About: When grouped with に, the う-Verb 関(かか)わる 'to be concerned with' is frequently used to show a relation between (A) and (B). This grammar pattern may be translated as 'relating to (A), (B)', 'concerning (A), (B)', or '(B) that has to do with (A)'. This structure appears after nouns, and is occasionally followed directly to a second noun in order to modify its meaning. Also, it is most common to see this pattern in its non-kanji form. This grammar pattern may also highlight that (A) is something that the speaker should be cautious about, due to a potential negative outcome.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの試験は私の人生にかかわるので、一生懸命勉強しなくてはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: ​​I have to study hard for that exam because my life depends on it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 別に命にかかわる病気では無いので、すぐに治療する必要はないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is not a disease that will affect your life, so there's no need to treat it immediately.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この面接は私の人生にかかわるので、頑張らなければいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This interview concerns my life, so I must do my best.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そのファイルにはお客様にかかわる大切な情報が記載されているので何があっても絶対無くさないようにしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That file contains important information concerning our customers, so please do not lose it at all costs.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このツールの使い方にかかわる質問はありますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you have any questions that have to do with how to use this tool? (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このツールの使い方に関する質問はありますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you have any questions concerning how to use this tool? (Natural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 医師は命に関わる仕事です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A doctor's job has to do with life.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 判事の行動は司法の信用に関わる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The actions of judges are connected to trust in the legal system.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会社の存亡に関わる危機に直面している。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We are confronting crises that have to do with the life and death of the company.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: わたしの将来に関わる面接だから、重要なんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since this is an interview that has to do with my future, it is important.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人間関係に関わる問題はなかなか難しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Problems concerning human relations are rather difficult.

Name: に向(む)かって
Meaning: Towards, To face, To head to
About: Coming from a link between に and the う-Verb 向(む)かう 'to face', or 'to go towards' in its て-form, に向(む)かって indicates that some specific action is being done 'towards (A)' or 'facing (A)'. (A) usually marks a stationary object or destination in the form of a noun. However, it can also mark less obvious destinations, such as the future '未来(みらい)'. Additionally, when 向(む)ける (the transitive form of the verb) is used, it will imply that the speaker is intentionally 'aiming' or 'facing' something towards (A). This is especially true when the objective of the speaker is to make something 'suitable' for (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: マイクに向かって何か一言お願いします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please face the mic and say something.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 空に向かって大声を出した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I shouted loudly towards the sky.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明るい未来に向かって一緒に人生を歩もうじゃ無いか！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why don't we walk toward a bright future together!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新入社員に向けて何かアドバイスを一言お願いします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please share a few words of advice suitable for the new employees.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼らは全国大会に向けて毎日朝から夜までトレーニングをしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They are training towards the national championship from morning to night everyday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: カメラに向かって、笑顔をお願いします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please face the camera and smile.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 受験生に向けてアドバイスをお願いします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please give some advice aimed at a student preparing for exams.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本をはじめ、外国に向けてブランドを広げたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Starting with Japan, I want to expand my brand towards foreign countries.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 通貨統一に向けての動きが加速している。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The movement toward the unification of currency is accelerating.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 深夜のアルバイトに向けて昼寝をしておこう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Aiming toward my late night part time job, I am going to take a nap in advance.

Name: が気(き)になる
Meaning: To be interested in, To be concerned about
About: One of the many collocations in Japanese based on 気(き) 'attention', or 'focus', is 気(き)になる. This is just a combination of the noun 気(き), に, and the う-Verb なる 'to become'. Also, 気になる will come after (A) が, where (A) marks the thing that is drawing the 'attention' or 'focus' of the speaker. The most common translations for this structure are 'to be interested in (A)', or 'to be concerned about (A)'. This grammar pattern will appear before nouns, and noun-like phrases.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家自体は良いと思うんですけど、やっぱり値段が気になります。なんでこんなに安いんですか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think the house itself is nice, however I am concerned about the price. Why is it so cheap?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は高橋さんが気になる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am interested in Takahashi-san.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やっぱりお前がさっき言ったことが気になる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am still concerned about what you said earlier.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は好きな人の考えていることが気になる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am interested in what the person I like is thinking about.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が気にすることは彼が良い人かどうかだけです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: All I care about is whether he is a good person or not.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が気になることは彼が良い人かどうかだけです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The only thing that I am concerned about is whether he is a good person or not.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの工場見学が気になる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am interested in taking a tour of that factory.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 最近、芸能界が気になる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Recently, I have become interested in the entertainment world.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの映画が気になっている。あらすじだけは知っているけど。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am interested in that movie. I only know the summary of it though.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この香水を付けている人が気になる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am interested in people who wear this perfume. (concerned with)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: クッキーよりもその入れ物が気になっている。すごくかわいいから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am even more interested in the box than the cookies. It is so cute!

Name: に気(き)を付(つ)ける
Meaning: Take care, Be careful, Pay attention, Make sure, Watch out
About: Another of the large number of collocations in Japanese based on 気(き) 'attention', or 'focus', is 気(き)を付(つ)ける. This is just a combination of the noun 気(き), を, and the る-Verb 付(つ)ける 'to adhere', or 'to attach'. 気(き)を付(つ)ける primarily follows (A) に. This marks (A) as something that the speaker is 'adhering' their attention to, and translates as 'to pay attention to (A)', 'to be careful of (A)', or 'to watch out for (A)'. This grammar pattern is used after nouns or noun-like phrases, indicating the thing that is being warned about, or that the speaker themselves is being cautious of. Most often, 気(き)を付(つ)ける will be used to warn about possible errors that could be made, mistakes, or simply the loss of focus. Due to this, it frequently follows negative verbs as ないよう, highlighting that something should be done in a 'manner' that doesn't result in (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近、電車に痴漢が沢山いるらしいから怪しい人に気をつけて帰ってくるんだよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hear there are a lot of perverts on the trains these days, so watch out for suspicious people on your way back home.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車で歩道を横切る時には歩行者に気を付けましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Be careful of pedestrians when you drive through a sidewalk.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このギターは俺の姉ちゃんのやつだから壊さないように気を付けてね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This guitar belongs to my sister, so please be careful not to break it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今月はお金を無駄遣いしないように気を付けよう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This month, I will be careful not to waste money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 頭をぶつけないようにシャッターに気をつけよう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's be careful not to bump our head on the shutter.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電柱に気をつけて車庫入れをしてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please watch out for the telephone poles when parking.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 氷は滑りやすいから、足もとに気をつけて。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The ice is slippery, so please watch your step.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 妊娠中の女性は、健康に気をつけるべきだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Pregnant women should be careful of their health.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 階段は急だから、落ちないように気をつけなさい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since the stairs are steep, take care not to fall.

Name: も構(かま)わず
Meaning: Without worrying about
About: も構(かま)わず is an expression that combines も, the う-Verb 構(かま)う 'to mind', or 'to care', and the literary auxiliary verb ず, which connects to verbs in the same way, and has the same meaning as ない. Common translations for this pattern include 'without worrying about (A), (B)', and 'without minding (A), (B)'. This structure is seen with verbs, い-Adjectives, and な-Adjectives followed by の, but may also follow nouns without the addition of の. Occasionally, にも may be used instead of も for further emphasis. も構(かま)わず is used most frequently to express that (A) is something that is either being ignored or that the speaker is not worried about. The (B) part of the statement will regularly highlight something that is being without any consideration for (A). This comes from the standard 'to brace', or 'to give pause' meaning of 構(かま)う.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 娘はレポートの提出日が迫っているのも構わず、友達と遊んでばかりいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Without worrying about the due date of her paper, all she is doing is hanging out with friends.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は遠いにも構わず、広島まで休憩なしで運転し続けた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Without worrying about the long distance, he kept driving to Hiroshima without taking a break.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は危険なのも構わず、池で溺れていた猫を救出した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Without worrying about the danger, she rescued a cat that was drowning in the lake.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 鈴木先輩は時間も構わず、電話を掛けてくるから困っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am annoyed because Suzuki-senpai calls me without worrying about the time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 医者にストップをかけられていたにも構わず試合に出て、大怪我をしてしまいました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I participated in the tournament without caring about the doctor's order to stop, and got seriously injured.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 御馳走もかまわず、仕事に没頭している。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Without worrying about food, they immerse themselves in their work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: さんざん失敗したにも構わず、まだ研究に打ち込んでいる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Without worrying about all of the stuff ups, I am still diving into my research.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サイレンにもかまわず、避難しようとしない人もいる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Without worrying about the siren, there are people who are not willing to evacuate.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 錆もかまわず放置していたせいで、使えなくなってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I left it without worrying about the rust, so I ended up not being able to use it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 塩辛いと感じていたにもかまわず食べ続けて、病気になってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I continued eating without worrying about sensing a salty taste and ended up getting sick.

Name: 兼(か)ねる
Meaning: Cannot, Be unable to, Hard to, Hesitant to
About: 兼(か)ねる, a る-Verb meaning 'to spread across' (usually 2 different activities or thought processes), often follows the ます-stem of other verbs in order to highlight that '(A) is not possible'. However, 兼(か)ねる often indicates that the speaker would actually like to do (A), but cannot due to some external circumstances such as difficulty, already being busy, being hesitant, etc. This particular grammar pattern will most frequently be seen in its non-kanji form, although both are possible. 兼(か)ねる is somewhat formal, and may be used in cases where a phrase like できない would be considered too strong, so the speaker wants to lightly imply that (A) cannot be done.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こう言う場合でも返金はできかねます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even in situations like this we can't give you a refund.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それはお客様のプライバシーに関わる情報なのでお答えしかねます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is information regarding our client's privacy so we cannot answer that.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お電話での予約受付は受けかねます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We cannot accept reservations by phone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 弊社は内装専門なので外装に関わるお仕事はお引き受けしかねます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would be a bit of a stretch for us to accept exterior work, as we specialize in interiors.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「役者になりたい」だなんて、賛成しかねる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot agree to (someone who says) 'I want to be an actor'. (hesitant)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 専門的なプログラムには対応し兼ねる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot deal with a technical program. (hesitant)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんな乱暴なやり方は承服し兼ねる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot consent to such reckless behavior. (hesitant)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんな無茶な要望はお引受けし兼ねます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot accept such an absurd demand. (hesitant)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そういう方針ということでしたら、応援し兼ねます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it is that kind of policy, I cannot support it. (hesitant)

Name: 兼(か)ねない
Meaning: Might, Could be, Capable of, Possible
About: The negative form of the る-Verb 兼(か)ねる 'to spread across' (usually 2 different activities or thought processes) is a grammar pattern that indicates a possibility of (A) happening, especially when it is something that the speaker themselves cannot control. 兼(か)ねない is often translated as 'might (A)', 'capable of (A)', or '(A) is a possibility'. This structure will be seen connected to the ます-stem of verbs, or after nouns followed by に. Both the kanji and non-kanji forms may be used. It is quite common to see 兼(か)ねない come after conditional phrases that include と, ば, たら, でも, and similar structures. This indicates that 'if (A) were to happen, (B) may also occur'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは命を落としかねない感染症らしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Apparently that is an infectious disease that could lead to death.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 地震の後には津波が起こりかねないので、出来るだけ早く避難しましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A tsunami might follow an earthquake so try to evacuate as soon as possible.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ベッドでの喫煙は火災になりかねないのでご遠慮ください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please refrain from smoking on the bed as it might cause a fire.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事のやりすぎは、鬱の原因になりかねない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Working too much could be a cause of depression.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 操作を間違えれば怪我人が出かねない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you operate it wrong, it could cause injuries.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんなに注意をしていても、事故は起こりかねない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how careful you are, accidents might happen.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ちゃんと毎日勉強すれば、来週のテストは合格できかねない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I study everyday, I might do well on the test next week.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はどんな病気でも治しかねない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It wouldn't be a stretch to say that she can cure any disease.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この事をそのままにしていたら、摩擦をうみ兼ねない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you leave it at that, it might cause conflict.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 危険な運転をすれば、事故が起こり兼ねない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you drive dangerously, an accident might occur.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この犬に噛まれたら、大怪我をしかねない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If this dog bites you, it is capable of causing serious injury.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この程度の怪我でも、ウイルスに感染し兼ねない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even with this degree of injury, you might get a virus infection.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 灯油の保管をちゃんとしないと、火事になり兼ねない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you don't properly store kerosene, a fire is possible.

Name: を除(のぞ)いて
Meaning: Except, With the exception of, Unless
About: を除(のぞ)いて is a formal grammar structure that combines を and the て-form of the う-Verb 除(のぞ)く 'to exclude'. This pattern will be seen following nouns in their dictionary form, and carries the meaning of 'except for (A), (B)', 'with the exception of (A), (B)', 'unless (A), (B)', or 'excluding (A), (B)'. As with many verb-based expressions, the standard form may also be used when directly modifying a second noun. を除(のぞ)いて is more formal than 以外(いがい) 'except for', and is frequently found in formal writing, on street signs, and other similar places.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高橋さんと浜崎さんを除いて、他のみんなは残業をしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Everyone, with the exception of Takahashi-san and Hamasaki-san, please work overtime.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は第２土曜日を除いて、毎日働いています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: With the exception of the second Saturday of the month, I work every day.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこの壁にかけてあるギターを除く全てのギターは母親のものです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: With the exception of that guitar hanging on the wall, all of it is my mother's.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 中田先生を除く全ての先生は同じ大学を卒業したらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Apparently, all of the teachers, except Mr. Nakata, graduated from the same college.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 病院スタッフを除いて、入ってはならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: With the exception of hospital staff, do not enter.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: エウロパを除いて、これらすべての世界が人間に属しています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: All these worlds belong to humans, except Europa.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一部の作業を除いて、ほとんどがオートメーション化されている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: With the exception of one part of the work, it was mostly converted to automation.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたを除いて、他の社員は皆お帰りください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Would all staff please go home, except you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの楽器を除くすべての楽器はわたしの私物です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Excluding that instrument over there, all of the instruments are mine.

Name: に関(かか)わらず
Meaning: Regardless of, Whether or, No matter, With or without
About: In order to convey 'regardless of (A)', 'no matter if (A)', or 'with or without (A)', the expression に関(かか)わらず will often be used. This is a combination of に, the う-Verb 関(かか)わる 'to be affected', 'to be influenced', and the literary auxiliary verb ず, which connects with verbs in the same way, and carries the same meaning as ない. This structure may be seen with verbs or adjectives in either their dictionary or negative forms, or with nouns. Frequently the same word is repeated in both the positive and the negative, or grouped with かどうか in order to strengthen the 'whether (A) or not (A)' nuance. As the literal meaning of this structure is 'without being influenced by (A), (B)', or 'without being affected by (A), (B)', the primary nuance is on the fact that (B) is something that exists or will happen without consideration for (A). Due to this, に関(かか)わらず may also be used to show that 'any type of (A) will result in the same (B)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 雨が降るか降らないかに関わらず、運動会は開催されます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The sports day will be held, regardless of whether it rains or not.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このビーチは天気がいいかどうかに関わらず、毎日サーファーたちで賑わっています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This beach is crowded with surfers regardless of the weather.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 上手い下手に関わらず、何事も一生懸命やるのが大切だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of if you are good or bad, it is important to do your best at everything you do.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は性別や国籍に関わらず、誰とでも友達になれる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of gender or nationality, he is able to become friends with anyone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このゲームは年齢に関わらず、誰でも楽しめます！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of age, anyone can enjoy this game!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 点数に関わらず、参加しただけで合格できる試験もある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are tests that you can pass just by attending, regardless of your score.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 好き嫌いに関わらず、この課題はやってもらわないと困ります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether you like it or not, if I do not have you perform this task, I won't be too happy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 流行に関わらず、彼は昔からああいう格好をしています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter if it is in vogue or not, he has been wearing that kind of clothing for a long time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 実力に関わらず仕事を与えるから、かなり効率が悪い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They are given a job regardless of their ability, so performance is quite bad.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この棚の商品に限り、大きい小さいに関わらず、全品100円。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Limited to only this shelf: regardless of whether it is big or small, all products are 100 yen.

Name: にも拘(かか)わらず
Meaning: Despite, In spite of, Regardless, Nevertheless
About: にもかかわらず is a formal grammar structure in Japanese used to convey that something is 'in spite of (A)', or 'despite (A)'. This pattern is a combination of に, も, the う-Verb 拘(かか)わる 'to fixate on', or 'to stick to', and the literary auxiliary verb ず, which connects with verbs in the same way, and carries the same meaning as ない. This structure is most frequently seen connected to verbs, い-Adjectives and nouns in their standard forms. In most cases, this pattern will appear without kanji. Literally, this phrase can be thought of as expressing 'without being affected by (A), (B)', or 'without fixating on (A), (B)'. However, it is almost always used in exactly the same way as のに 'despite'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 浜崎さんは毎日一生懸命働いていたのにもかかわらず、会社をクビになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Despite working hard every day, Hamasaki-san was fired by the company.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼が悪いのにもかかわらず、私に謝らせようとしてきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Despite him being in the wrong, he tried to make me apologize.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんは優しくて親切であるにもかかわらず、見た目が怖いから田中さんのことをよく知らない人からは怖がられて避けられている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Despite Tanaka-san being kind and helpful, he's feared and avoided by those who don't know him well because of his scary appearance.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 深夜にもかかわらず上司が鬼電をしてきたので、労基に報告しようと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Despite being late at night, my boss blew up my phone, so I'm thinking of reporting it to the labor standards inspection office.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客さんが来ることを知っていたにもかかわらず、部屋の掃除をしていなかったので息子を叱った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Despite knowing that we were going to have guests over, my son did not clean his room so I scolded him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客さんが来るかどうかに関わらず、部屋は綺麗にしておいてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please keep your room clean no matter if guests are coming or not.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勘違いしたにもかかわらず、彼は一切謝らない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though he made a mistake, he will never apologize.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あんなにかわいがったにもかかわらず、裏切られるなんて…
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite showing them that much adoration, (who would have thought) that they would betray us...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 間隔があいたにもかかわらず、相変わらずいいプレーをしますね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though a space opened, they made a nice play, like usual.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 乾燥しているにもかかわらず加湿しないから、喉をやられた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since I didn't run the humidifier regardless of it being dry, my voice got hoarse.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 喉が渇いているにもかかわらず、飲み物を与えないのは虐待だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite me being thirsty, not giving me anything to drink is cruel.

Name: に限(かぎ)って
Meaning: Particularly when, Those who, Only when
About: The expression に限(かぎ)って in Japanese is a phrase that has three primary uses, the first is to show that (B) is an unbelievable thing about (A), the second is to express that something is limited to (A), and the third highlights that in most cases for (A), (B). Depending on the particular nuance that is being used, common translations include 'particularly when (A), (B)', 'those who (A), (B)', and 'only when (A), (B)'. This structure is comprised of に, and the て-form of the う-Verb 限(かぎ)る 'to limit'. Let's look at a few examples of each potential meaning. First, when something about (A) is unbelievable due to what is either expected or previously known. Second, when something is limited to (A). Third, when (B) is true in most cases concerning (A). While each of these uses can roughly be translated as 'only when', it will be important to keep all three meanings in mind when interpreting sentences that use に限(かぎ)って.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: うちの子に限って、他の子に手を出すなんて考えられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't imagine that my child, in particular, would hit another kid.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼に限って、こんな簡単なことでミスをする訳が無い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no way that he, in particular, would make a mistake on something this simple.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 武くんと釣りに行く日に限って、いつも雨が降るんだよな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Only on days when I go fishing with Takeshi-kun does it always rain.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩は忙しい日に限って、飲みに誘ってくる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My senpai invites me to go drinking with him only on days that I am busy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 「クレームを入れるぞ」って言う人に限ってクレームを入れないからあまり気にしていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm not too worried because particularly those who say, 'I'm going to file a claim', never do (file a claim).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 「絶対後でやる」って言う人に限って、いつまでもやらない人が多い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Many of those who say, 'I'll definitely do it later', never do.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昼寝をしている時に限って電話が鳴る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Particularly when I am napping does the phone ring.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕がカメラを忘れた日に限って虹が出る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only on days when I forget my camera, do rainbows appear.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新曲発売日に限って大雨だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only on days when a new song is released is it pouring rain.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 早口の人に限ってたくさんしゃべるから、聞き取れない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only those who talk fast have a lot to say, so I can't catch it all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 外に調査へ出かける時に限って、雨が降る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is only when I go out to investigate that it rains.

Name: に限(かぎ)らず
Meaning: Not just, Not only… but also
About: に限(かぎ)らず is a sentence pattern in Japanese used that highlights when something is 'not just (A), but (B) too', or 'not only (A), but also (B)'. It is a combination of に, the う-Verb 限(かぎ)る 'to limit', and the literary auxiliary verb ず, which connects with verbs in the same way, and carries the same meaning as ない. This structure will appear after nouns, before the (B) part of the sentence will go on to explain things that can be included in the same scope or category as (A). Occasionally, も may be added for extra emphasis in the (B) part of に限らず sentences. This is especially true when several extra things are being indicated, not just (B). For example, '(B) も (C) も'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ＵＳＪは週末に限らず、平日でも多くの人で賑わっています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: USJ is crowded not only on weekends, but also on weekdays.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この遊園地は子供に限らず、大人でも楽しめます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This amusement park is enjoyable not only for children, but also for adults.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このカフェは女性に限らず、男性の方にも人気があります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This café is popular not only with women, but also with men.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このブランドは日本だけに限らず、韓国でも中国でも愛されています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This brand is loved not only in Japan, but also in Korea and China.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しい言語を習う場合、文法に限らず、その国の文化もニュアンスも同じぐらい勉強したほうがいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When learning a new language, you should study not only the grammar, but also the culture and nuances of the country, if possible.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ラッシュアワーに限らず、電車にはあまり乗りたくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not only during rush hour, but I don't really want to ride the train.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: マンションに限らず、綺麗な部屋なら住んでみたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not just apartments, but if there are beautiful rooms I want to try living there.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: オルガンに限らず、鍵盤楽器はだいたい弾けます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not just the organ, but I can somewhat play any instrument with a keyboard.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 生け花に限らず、正座をするのが苦手です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not just in ikebana, but I don't like (sitting in) seiza (in general).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 英文に限らず、アルファベットを使った文章が好きです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not only English sentences, but I like sentences that use the alphabet.

Name: 尚(なお) ①
Meaning: Still, Even, Yet
About: When used at the beginning of a statement, the adverb 尚(なお) 'furthermore' will often carry the meaning of 'still', 'even', or 'yet'. This use is regularly seen after the previous statement ends in も, and will emphasize that 'even after (A)', or 'even though (A) is a fact, (B) is still true'. Especially when the information expressed in the (B) part of the sentence is surprising or shocking in some way. This structure will almost always appear without the kanji being used. Additionally, the (B) part of statements that include 尚(なお) will also frequently include も, in order to specify that the new information is 'in addition to (A)'. 今(いま)もなお has come to be used as a set phase, and may be heard in may different situations. Despite this, 尚(なお) itself is quite a formal grammar structure.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 上司のパワハラを人事に報告してもなお、上司のパワハラが続いている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even after reporting my boss to human resources for power harassment, his harassment is still continuing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は先生に注意されてもなお、指摘された事を直そうとしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He still refuses to fix what was pointed out to him, even after being warned by his teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 豊橋市では今もなおチンチン電車が走っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Trams are still running in Toyohashi-city.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 浜崎先生は卒業後もなお、私たちの事をしっかりと覚えている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Mr. Hamasaki still remembers us even after graduation.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アメリア・イアハートの消失は今も尚謎である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The disappearance of Amelia Earhart is still a mystery.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大学院生になっても尚、夜遊びをやめない人もいる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are people who become graduate school students, but still don't quit their nightlife.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大工になっても尚、高いところが苦手な人もいるらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Apparently there are people who become carpenters but are still scared of heights.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 短所に気づいても尚認めようとしない人に未来はありませんよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: People who notice their shortcomings and still don't acknowledge them, have no future.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 蒸気機関車は今も尚、電気がない地域において使用されている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Steam locomotives are still used in areas where there is no electricity.

Name: 尚(なお) ②
Meaning: In addition, Incidentally, Furthermore, Moreover
About: When used at the beginning of a sentence, 尚(なお) 'furthermore' takes on the role of a conjunction, and will often carry the meaning of 'in addition', 'furthermore', 'even more', or 'moreover'. This use is regularly seen after the previous sentence or clause has expressed some base fact or situation that the second sentence will then add to. Especially when the information expressed in the (B) part of the sentence is surprising or shocking in some way. This structure will almost always appear without the kanji being used. As 尚(なお) is a formal grammar structure, it will most frequently appear in letters, posters, commercials and other similar material.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それでは只今から説明会を開始したいと思います。なお、ご不明な点がある場合はお気軽にお申し付けください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well then, I'd like to begin the information session. In addition, if you have any questions, please feel free to ask.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ５日の土曜日には１１時までに待ち合わせ場所に集合してください。なお、遅れる場合は私のＬＩＮＥまで連絡をください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please be at the meeting place by 11:00 am on Saturday the 5th. Moreover, if you are going to be late, please message me on LINE.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 内容の確認が出来ましたら、「次へ」をクリックしてください。なお、「次へ」をクリックした後には内容の変更ができないのでご注意ください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After confirming the details, please click 'Next'. Furthermore please note that you cannot make changes after clicking 'Next'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日は臨時休業です。尚、定休日は水曜日です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tomorrow is a temporary holiday. In addition, Wednesday is our set store holiday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 作品の提出は今月いっぱいまで。尚、テーマは各自で考えること。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The window for turning in your work is through the end of the month. In addition, you should think about your theme individually.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 只今パンを焼いております。尚、出来上がりは１１時を予定しております。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Bread is currently being baked. In addition, it is scheduled to be ready at 11.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 説明は以上です。尚、手続きは明後日までにお願いします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This concludes the explanation. In addition, please do the formalities by the day after tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: では、これで試験を終わります。尚、点数は追って発表いたします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Well, this concludes the test. In addition, I will announce the score afterwards.

Name: 限(かぎ)り
Meaning: As long as, While… is the case, Limited to
About: Although several grammar patterns make use of the う-Verb 限(かぎ)る 'to limit', 限(かぎ)り may be the most versatile. This is partly because it does not include に like other 限(かぎ)る based structures, and therefore will have its meaning modified by the word that comes directly before it. 限(かぎ)り will follow verbs in their standard forms, and nouns linked to である. Let's take a look at a few of the standard meanings and translations. The first meaning indicates that (B) is something that is limited to being within the scope of (A). This is the most standard meaning and can be translated as 'limited to (A), (B)'. The second meaning highlights that within the limit or scope of some particular source of information, (B) is true. This scope usually relates to the senses (like vision), or to knowledge. This may be interpreted as 'as far as (A), (B)', 'as long as (A), (B)'. The third and final meaning of 限(かぎ)り will imply that 'limited to (A) being the case, (B) will occur'. In this nuance, 限(かぎ)り simply implies that assuming that (A) is true, (B) is something that will need to be taken into account as well. This will be interpreted as 'while (A) is the case, (B)', or 'assuming (A), (B)'. Despite these various meanings, 限(かぎ)る will always highlight (A) as the limit or constraint within which the logic of (B) exists.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼が真剣に芸人になりたいと言っている限り、彼の夢は叶うだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As long as he keeps saying he seriously wants to become a comedian, his dream will probably come true.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この商品の販売は今週限りとさせていただきます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sales of this item will be limited to this week.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼から聞いた限り、田中君は退学になるらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As far as I heard from him, apparently, Tanaka-kun is getting expelled.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このアパートの住人である限りは、アパートのルールを守っていただかないと困ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As long as you are a resident of this apartment, we need you to follow the apartment rules.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本に住む限り、日本の法律を守らなければいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Assuming that you live in Japan, you need to obey Japanese law.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家族の大黒柱である限り、家族を支えなければならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I am the pillar of the family, I must support my family.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 行列に並ばない限り、あのパンは買えない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As long as you do not get in the large line, you cannot buy that bread.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 意識して気を付けない限り、あの癖は直らない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As long as you are not mindful, you will not break that habit.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 離島に漂流者：「見る限り、水しかない...」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Castaway on an isolated Island: 'As far as I can see, there's nothing but water...'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 休息をとらない限り、体調は回復しませんよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You will not regain your strength, as long as you do not rest.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの教えを心に刻んでいる限り、人の道を踏み外したりはしないはずだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As long as those teachings are etched in their mind, they should not lose their way.

Name: 次第(しだい)だ
Meaning: Depending on, So
About: Coming after another noun, 次第(しだい) 'directly following' is a noun that will often be used in a similar way to a suffix. In these cases, it will be followed by だ, or で and a part (B) statement. In this use, 次第(しだい) will be translated as 'depending on (A), (B)', or '(B) depends on (A)'. (A) will most frequently highlight a person or some specific situation that is considered to be in control of what happens next.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夢をかなえられるかどうかは君の努力次第だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Being able to make your dream come true or not depends on you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 第一希望の大学へ入れるかは、試験の結果次第だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether I can go to the college of my first choice or not, depends on my test results.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 内装工事の完成日次第で、鍵の引き渡し日が変わる可能性があります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Depending on the completion date of the interior construction, the date for handing over the key may change.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 値段次第で、ナビを付けるか付けないかを決めます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Depending on the price, I will decide on whether I want to install a navigation system or not.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ワインの渋味は濃度次第だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Wine's astringency depends on its concentration.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 成功は大抵努力次第だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Success depends mostly on effort.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 天気次第で、日帰りか一泊二日かを決めます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Depending on the weather, we will decide on a daytrip or staying overnight.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アイデア次第で、売上にかなりの違いが出てきます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Depending on the idea, a considerable difference in sales will show up.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 応援次第で、試合の結果が変わることもあり得ます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Depending on the support, it is likely that the result of the match could change.

Name: 次第(しだい)に
Meaning: Gradually
About: 次第(しだい)に is an adverb that expresses that something is happening 'gradually' or 'bit by bit' over time. This phrase is made up of the noun 次第(しだい), 'course of events' or 'circumstances', and the particle に, which turns it into an adverbial phrase. While the noun 次第(しだい) implies a sequence or order, when used as the adverb 次第(しだい)に, the main focus shifts to how something progressively and gradually changes over time. 次第(しだい)に can be used for both positive and negative changes. だんだん and 次第(しだい)に both mean the same thing however 次第(しだい)に sounds slightly more formal and is more likely to be seen in formal written language than だんだん.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: わずか数ヶ月のうちに二人は次第に疎遠になった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Within a few months, the two gradually drifted apart.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ガソリンの価格は次第に安くなると予測されている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Gasoline prices are expected to gradually become cheaper.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友人の祖父の健康状態が次第に悪化していることも知らずに、変なことを聞いてしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I asked him such insensitive questions, unaware that his grandfather’s health was gradually deteriorating.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この対策により、次第に経済が回復すると予想されています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This measure is expected to gradually restore the economy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なんか最近物価がだんだん上がってきたね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't you think prices of things have been gradually going up?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 時が経つにつれ、次第に彼への愛情は無くなっていった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: With the passing of time, I gradually lost my love for him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 膝の痛みは次第に和らいでいった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My knee pain has gradually eased up.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 朝晩の冷え込みが次第に激しくなり、冬の訪れを感じた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As the morning and evening cold has gradually become harsher, I felt winter’s arrival.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 薬を飲んだら、次第に痛みが引いてきたよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once I took some medicine, the pain gradually receded.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 次第に雲行きが怪しくなり、イベントの中止をせざるを得なくなった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As the outlook gradually turned ominous, we had no choice but to cancel the event.

Name: ～てこそ
Meaning: Only if, Because, By, Unless, Until
About: In a similar way to how the particle こそ highlights a particular word as being the 'precise' or 'exact' reason for something, its combination with the て-form of a verb will indicate that (B) is absolutely reliant on (A). This reliance can be translated in several different ways, and will usually become clear in the (B) part of sentences. Standard interpretations include 'only if (A), (B)', 'unless (A), (B)', or 'until (A), (B)'. The reliance that (B) has on (A) can be translated in several different ways, but the most common interpretations are that (A) will determine either the outcome, assessment, or evaluation of (B), based on the speaker's opinion, values, or understanding of the situation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 海外に留学してこそ、日本食の美味しさが分かる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Only by studying abroad can one appreciate the deliciousness of Japanese food.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 親になってこそ、子育ての大変さがわかる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's only when you become a parent that you understand how hard it is to raise a child.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: チーム全員の責任を背負ってこそ、キャプテンになれる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You become a captain only if you take on the responsibility of the whole team.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 他のチームに勝ってこそ、世界一になれる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Only by beating other teams can we become the best in the world.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 助け合ってこその親友じゃないか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: One is being a friend only by helping one another, isn't that right? (only because)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 全部揃えてこそのコレクションだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A collection is a collection only when everything is complete. (because・until/unless)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 優勝してこそ、自信に繋がる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is only by winning that one becomes confident. (unless/until)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: くだらないプライドを捨ててこそ、男らしくなれる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only if you throw aside your worthless pride will you be able to become more manly. (until/unless)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 全員参加してこその遠足だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is only because everyone is participating that it is an outing. (until/unless)

Name: を問(と)わず
Meaning: Regardless of, Whether or not, No matter, With or without
About: を問(と)わず is a pattern which makes use of the special-class う-Verb 問(と)う 'to inquire' and the literary auxiliary verb ず, which connects with verbs in the same way, and carries the same meaning as ない. While the literal meaning of this grammar structure is 'without questioning (A), (B)', it is used more as a formal way to express 'regardless of (A), (B)', 'whether (A) or not, (B)', or 'with or without (A)', (B)'. This structure is seen almost exclusively after nouns, but can also follow structures like か, or かどうか that are modifying adjectives. を will mark the 'question' which is 'not being asked'. Occasionally, は will replace を at the beginning of 問わず. This puts further emphasis on contrast, and slightly strengthens the phrase overall.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 宗教や国籍を問わず、このイベントには誰でも参加できます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Everyone is welcome to attend this event, regardless of religion or nationality.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パソコンの上級者か初心者かを問わず、初めてこのサービスをお使いになられる方には初心者コースから始めてもらいます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether you are an advanced computer user or a beginner, we ask first-time users of this service to start with the beginner course.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このマンションを買うかどうかを問わず、この物件を押さえたい場合は手付金を払ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you want to hold on to this property, whether you buy this apartment or not, you must pay a deposit.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どのブランドかは問わず、とにかく新しい靴が欲しいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I just want a new pair of shoes, regardless of which brand.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は昼夜を問わず、ずっと働いている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether it is day or night, he is always working.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は昼夜に関わらず、ずっと働いている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of day or night, he is always working.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんな役かは問わず、主役であればね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of the role, if it is a leading role (it doesn't matter). (no matter)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は彼女と結婚したい。手段を問わない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to marry her! No matter what. (regardless・whether or not)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 買う買わないを問わず、商品を試しに来てください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Regardless of) whether you will buy it or not, please come and try the product.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 好き嫌いを問わず探せば、仕事は見つかります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of your likes and dislikes, if you look, you will find a job.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 上手い下手を問わず、習字の練習は続けてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether you are good at it or bad at it, please continue to practice your penmanship (calligraphy). (regardless of)

Name: より仕方(しかた)がない
Meaning: There is no choice but, Can't be helped, Inevitable
About: Often seen as a set phrase, よりしかたがない consists of より, the noun 仕方(しかた) 'way' or 'method', が and ない. When preceded by a verb in its dictionary form, it just conveys that 'there is no choice but (A)', or that '(A) cannot be helped'. Occasionally the が will be dropped, between 仕方(しかた) and ない. Keeping almost exactly the same style of translation is a similar pattern, より他(ほか)にない. The only actual difference is that this structure expresses that there is no 'other' alternative, rather than being no 'method'. The noun 他(ほか) 'other' and に will simply replace 仕方(しかた) 'method' and が. As with 仕方(しかた)が, the に will often be dropped in 他(ほか)に. Both よりしかたがない and よりほかにない have a tendency to express some particular evaluation of (A) that cannot be helped or denied, or simply that 'given the situation, (A) cannot be avoided'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この建物はボロボロでいつ倒れてもおかしくないから、倉庫として使いたいなら立て直すより仕方がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This building is in bad condition and could fall down at any time, so if I want to use it as a warehouse, I have no choice but to rebuild it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高速道路が通行止めになっている為、下道を使うより仕方がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since the expressway is closed, there is no choice but to take the normal road.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 生活をするにはお金が必要だから働くより仕方ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I need money in order to live, so there is no choice but to work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自転車のチェーンとブレーキがぶっ壊れたから、捨てるより他にない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My bicycle chain and brakes are busted, so I have no choice but to throw them away.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 上司のパワハラのせいで病んできたので、精神科に行くより他にない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My mental health is not doing well because of my boss' power harassment, so I have no choice but to go to a therapist.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんなひどい事を言ってしまったので、謝るより他ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I said such a terrible thing, I have no choice but to apologize.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 税金は、高くとも納めるより仕方がない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We have no choice but to pay taxes, even if they are high.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 税金は、納めるより仕方のないものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is a fact that there is no choice but to pay taxes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ミシンが故障しているから、手で縫うより仕方がない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since the sewing machine is broken, there is no choice but to sew (it) by hand.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 見本がないから、頭の中でイメージして作るより仕方がない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since there is no example, there is no choice but to make an image in my head.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: マラソン大会に出たいなら、地道にトレーニングを積むより仕方がない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you want to enter a marathon, there is no choice but to steadily pile on the training.

Name: に越(こ)したことはない
Meaning: There is nothing better than, It is the best, Would be the best
About: Used to convey the meanings of 'there is nothing better than (A)', or '(A) would be the best', に越(こ)したことはない is a phrase that combines に, the past-tense form of 越(こ)す, an う-Verb meaning 'to cross over', or 'to surpass', こと, は, and ない. Literally, it means 'there is nothing beyond (A)', or 'nothing surpasses (A)'. This structure will be seen with verbs, adjectives, and nouns in their standard forms. に越(こ)したことはない sentences generally present something positive, or some ideal outcome that is wished for.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩と待ち合わせているなら、待ち合わせ時間の１０分前に着くに越したことはない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are meeting a senpai, it is best to arrive 10 minutes before the meeting time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家は広いに越した事はないが、値段と場所も大切だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There's nothing better than a spacious house, but the price and location are also important.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部屋は綺麗であるに越した事はないので、毎日掃除をしています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I clean my room every day because there's nothing better than a clean room.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 億万長者であるに越した事はない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is nothing better than being a billionaire.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 災害は起きないに越したことはない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is nothing better than a disaster not happening.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 映画はつまらなくないに越したことはない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is nothing better than a movie not being boring.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: テストは複雑ではないに越した事はない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is nothing better than a test that is not complicated.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こう言う時には一人っ子ではないに越した事はない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At times like this, there is nothing better than not being an only child.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 休息できるに越したことはないが、あまりにもひまだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Being able to take a break is the best, but I'm too bored.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 応援してもらうことに越したことはないが、ちょっとやり過ぎです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is nothing better than having someone cheer for you, but I think they are overdoing it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 受験は受かる確率が高いに越したことはない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There would be nothing better than if my chances of passing the exam are high.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: オーケストラの楽器は多いに越したことはないが、限度がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is nothing better than having many instruments in an orchestra, but there are limits.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 基礎がしっかりしているに越したことはないが、基礎にばかり時間をかけられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is nothing better than having a strong foundation, but you can't spend all of your time on foundation alone.

Name: 要(よう)するに
Meaning: To sum up, In summary, In short
About: 要(よう)するに is an expression in Japanese used to highlight important information in a similar way to 'to sum up', 'in summary', or 'in short' in English. It is a combination of the する-Verb 要(よう) 'to need', or 'to require', and に. Literally it means something similar to 'as for what's necessary (A)'. This is a phrase that will only ever take the initial position in a sentence, before expressing a condensed version of what has previously been said.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 要するに、あなたは履歴書に嘘を書いたと言う事ですね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In short, this means that you lied on your resume, doesn't it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 要するに、小麦が入っている食べ物は食べれないと言う事ですね？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: So, in summary, I can't eat any food that has wheat in it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 要するに、俺はあいつに使われていたと言うことだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In short, I was being used by him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 要するに何でもいいよね？
Questions.EnglishHTML: In short, it is all the same to you?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 要するに、あなたは反省していないということですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In summary, you aren't contemplating your actions.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 要するに、発想が貧弱だということでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In summary, this way of thinking is insubstantial, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 要するに、期限を延ばすことは許されないということです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In summary, you will not let me extend the deadline.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 要するに、乗換を間違えて遅刻したということですね？
Questions.EnglishHTML: In summary, you made a mistake on your train transfer and are late, right?

Name: てからでないと
Meaning: (Not) unless ~ cannot, (Not) until ~ cannot
About: Constructed from the て-form of verbs, から 'from', で, ない, and と, てからでないと is a grammar pattern that expresses that 'unless (A), (B) will not happen', or 'until (A), you cannot (B)'. Due to this, the (B) part of sentences that use this grammar pattern will always be negative. This structure simply indicates that (B) must come after (A). This could be in relation either to (A) and (B) being finished, or simply to (B) becoming possible after (A). Alternatively, the hypothetical ば form may be used instead of と. This will appear as てからでなければ. てからでないと can be thought of as an extension of the base てから grammar pattern that expresses that (B) only happens after (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 全ての書類が揃ってからでないと、本申し込みができません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You can't submit the actual application unless you have all the documents.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このアプリをインストールしてからでないと、携帯に入れた音楽は聴けません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You cannot listen to the music you put in your phone until you install this app.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 資格をとってからでなければ、面接が受けられません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Unless you get the qualification, you cannot be interviewed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その件については上司と相談してからでなければ、ご回答できません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will not be able to respond to you until I have discussed this matter with my supervisor.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サンプルを見てからでないと、買うかどうかは決められません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Until I see the sample, I cannot decide whether to buy it or not.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 猫舌なので、冷めてからでないと飲めない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since I am sensitive to hot things, until it cools, I cannot drink it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電源を切ってからでないと、コンセントを抜いてはいけません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Unless you turn off the power, you cannot unplug it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サークルに入ってからでないと、活動に参加できない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Unless you join (enter) the club, you cannot participate in the activities.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 撮影してからでないと、ギャラは入りません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Until you (take) some photographs, you will not be paid.

Name: なくはない
Meaning: It's not that…, Kind of, might, Slightly, Somewhat, In some respects
About: Used to express that something is 'slightly (A)', 'somewhat (A)', or 'in some respects (A)' in Japanese is the phrase なくはない. This is comprised of ない in its なく (conjunctive) form connected to either verbs or nouns, は, and ない. The literal meaning of this structure is close to 'it's not that it isn't (A)', and is a type of double negative. Although preceded mostly by verbs, this structure sometimes appears following nouns. When that is the case, が, は, or sometimes even に may be between なくはない and the noun. Additionally, the は in なくはない is interchangeable with も, with only a slight strengthening of the nuance when も is used. This structure often appears with the potential form of verbs, in order to show that something is not impossible, despite appearances or what one may think.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 別に出来なくはないけど、めんどくさいから業者に頼むわ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that I can't do it, but since it is too much of a hassle, I'm going to hire someone to do it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それを買うお金がなくはないが、そんなくだらないことにお金を使いたくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that I don't have money to buy that, but that I don't want to spend my money on something so stupid.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 時間はなくはないんですが、もっと時間を有効に使いたいだけです。
