AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that I don't have time, but that I just want to make better use of my time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家にテレビがなくはないけど、アンテナがつながっていないからモニターとして使ってる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that I don't have a TV at home, but since the antenna is not connected, I am using it as a monitor.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 納豆は食べれなくはないけど、どうせ食べるならもっと美味しいものを食べたいかな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that I don't like natto, it's just that if I am going to eat something, I want to eat something more delicious.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その距離だったら、頑張れば走れなくはない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it was that distance, it would be hard work, but I may be able to run that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 貯金すれば買えなくはない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I save, I may be able to buy it. (Literally - I won't not be able to buy it)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: かなり固い木だが、このカンナで削れなくはない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The tree is quite hard, but it's not that it can't be planed with this wood planer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 難しそうだが、自分で組み立てられなくはない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It looks difficult, but it's not that you can't put it together yourself.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その意見を考えた上で、賛成できなくはない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After considering that opinion, I can somewhat agree. (Literally - I can't not agree)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 原理は分からなくはないが、すべてを理解するのは難しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's not that I don't understand the principle, but comprehending it entirely is difficult.

Name: ない事(こと)には～ない
Meaning: Unless you do something
About: ないことには～ない is a 2-part structure in Japanese that is used to express that 'unless you do (A), (B) will not happen or exist'. This is a combination of ない, こと, に, は, and then something followed by ない in the (B) part of the sentence. Literally, it just means 'within the situation of (A) not being a thing, neither will (B)'. This structure may appear with verbs and い-Adjectives in their ない forms, or nouns followed by でない. In sentences that use ないことには～ない, (A) can be considered the condition for (B) being able to occur or proceed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ヘルメットを被らないことには、この工事現場には入れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You cannot enter this construction site unless you wear a safety helmet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ジェットコースターは、スリルがないことには楽しくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Roller coasters are no fun, unless they are thrilling.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何事も一生懸命でないことには、何も上手くなれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You won't get good at anything, unless you try your best in everything you do.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 許可書がないことには、ここへは入れません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Unless you have a permit, you cannot enter beyond this point.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 漢字がかけないことには、このテストは難しすぎるかもしれません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Unfortunately, this test may be too hard if you are unable to write kanji.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高速を使わないことには、待ち合わせ時間に遅れてしまう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Without using the highway, I am going to be late.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: やってみないことには、出来るかどうか分からない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You won't know if you can do it or not unless you try.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 髭を剃らないことには、仕事に行けない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Unless you shave your facial hair, you cannot go to work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夫婦では仲良くしないことには、うまくいかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Unless married couples get along, things won't go well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田植えをしないことには、米を収穫できません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Unless you plant it, you cannot harvest rice.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 退院しないことには、仕事復帰できない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Unless you are released from the hospital, you cannot return to work.

Name: ないではいられない
Meaning: Cannot help doing something, Cannot resist doing something
About: In order to express that something cannot be helped or cannot be resisted in Japanese, the phrase ないではいられない will be used. This is a structure that is comprised of verbs in the negative form connected to で, は, and the negative-potential form of the る-Verb 居(い)る 'to be'. In this way it just means 'to be unable to be without (A)'. ないではいられない primarily expresses the inability of the speaker to tolerate (A) not happening, due to wanting to do it. It may also indicate that they will unfortunately do it despite knowing that they shouldn't. ないではいられない may also be used to highlight that in the situation of (A), some particular emotion, feeling, or reaction cannot be repressed. (B) is something that happens naturally as a consequence of (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: セール品を見ると、買わないではいられなくなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I see something on sale, I can't help but buy it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は辛い物を食べると、牛乳を飲まないではいられないの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I eat something spicy, I can't help but drink milk.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ペットのワンちゃんが自分の尻尾を追いかけているのを見るとおかしくて、笑わないではいられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I see my pet dog chasing his tail around, it's so funny that I can't help but laugh.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大親友が事故でなくなったときは、泣かないではいられなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When my best friend died, I couldn't help but cry. (Emotion)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: おばあさんが困っているのを見ると助けないではいられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I see an old lady in need, I can't resist helping them. (Feeling)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 上司に理不尽に怒られた時には、キレないではいられなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When my boss yelled at me unreasonably, I couldn't help but lose my temper. (Reaction)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 悔しすぎて、飲まないではいられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am so frustrated, I can't help but drink.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いい金魚を見つけてしまった。買わないではいられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I found a good goldfish. I can't help but buy it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 架空請求され、怒らないではいられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was charged with a fictitious claim. I can't help but feel angry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 困ったことがあって、神様に頼らないではいられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I got into some trouble and I can't help but rely on the gods.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 引退試合に負けて、泣かないではいられません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Having lost his last game before retirement, he can't help but cry.

Name: ねばなら + ぬ
Meaning: Must, Have to, Should
About: Unlike the standard ば form of hypothetical phrases, ねば makes use of the classical auxiliary verb ず in its ね form. However, the meaning is the same as the modern なければ  'if not (A)'. ねば connects to verbs in the same way as ない, and will then be followed by the negative form of なる 'to become', ならない. Like なければならない, ねばならない will translate to 'must do (A)', or 'have to do (A)', and is simply a double negative that literally means 'if not (A), it won't be (B)'. This is a formal structure, and will mostly be found in literature. As ね is a form of the literary auxiliary verb ず, the base of する will change to せねば, in the same way it changes to せず in other grammar patterns.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今月の１３日までに電気代を払わねばならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have to pay the electric bill by the 13th of this month.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は一応私の先輩なので何を言われても、従わねばならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person is my senpai, more or less, so no matter what he says, I must obey him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客さんが来る前に掃除をせねばならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I must clean before the guests arrive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語を今より話せる様になりたいのならば、もっと努力をせねばならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you want to be able to speak Japanese better than you do now, you have to work harder.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社長には僕に任せてくださいと言ったので、何があっても成功せねばならぬ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I told my boss to leave it to me, so no matter what happens, I must succeed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もうこんな時間ですか、そろそろ帰らねば。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's already so late! I must go home soon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたたちは兄弟でしょう？もっと仲良くせねば。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You guys are siblings, aren't you? You guys have to be nice to each other.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 家賃を月末までに払わねばならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have to pay rent by the end of the month.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 後輩の意見もちゃんと聞かねばならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You must also listen to your kouhai's opinion.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 根本的な構造から見直さねばならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We must review the fundamental structure.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 見学した感想を書いて提出せねばならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I must write and submit my impressions on the field trip.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 公衆の面前ではちゃんと秩序を保たねばならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I must maintain order in the presence of the general public.

Name: 給(たま)え
Meaning: (Please) do!, Ask to, Beg to, (Order somebody to do something)
About: Originally coming from the う-Verb 給(たま)う 'to give', or 'to bestow', the imperative form たまえ may be seen attached to the ます-stem of verbs, in order to create a light order. It is often translated simply as 'please do (A)'. Despite this, たまえ is a structure that is only used to someone of lower status than the speaker, and primarily only by men. This 'lower status relationship' is usually one that is obvious between both the speaker and the listener, such as a boss and subordinate.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まあまあ、とりあえず座りたまえ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well, please, take a seat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何か言いたそうな顔をしている君！考えてる事を言いたまえ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You look like you want to say something! Please say what you are thinking!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遠慮せずどんどん食べたまえ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please eat as much as you want without holding back.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 我らに罪を犯す者を、我らが許すごとく、我らの罪をも許したまえ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Forgive us our trespasses as we forgive those who trespass against us.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強をやりたまえ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Study! (bossy command)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 上司：「これを、明日までに終えたまえ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Boss: 'Finish this by tomorrow.' (bossy command)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「神様、豊穣の願いをかなえたまえ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'God, please grant us an abundant harvest!'
(outdated way of asking a favor/praying・can also be a command)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: オフィスの中で：「次の人、入りたまえ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: In the office: 'Next person, come in.' (bossy command)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: Ａ：「何て、言ったの。」Ｂ：「お前にうんざりだ！うちの会社をとっとと辞めたまえ！って言ったんだよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A: 'What did he say?' B: 'He said: 'I am fed up with you. Leave my company at once!'' (bossy command)

Name: の内(うち)で
Meaning: Of the, Among(st)
About: Coming from the noun 内(うち) 'within', のうち is a grammar pattern that appears after nouns or numbers, in order to signify 'amongst (A)' in the same way as の中(なか). Like の中(なか), のうち is often followed by で. However, it can also be followed by の when attached directly to another number. The noun specified by の内(うち) may represent a range or a limit, and is not limited to appearing with numbers. Like の中(なか), it may also appear followed by から in place of で. のうち is far less common than のなか when specifying 'amongst', due to this, のなか will be the preferred (more natural) option in speech. Additionally, although coming from 内(うち), the kanji form is far less common than plain hiragana.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この会社のうちでもっとも偉い人は田中さんです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Among everyone in this company, Tanaka-san is the most important.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここにいる５人のうちで一番給料が高いのは鈴木さんです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Among the 5 people that are present here, Suzuki-san has the highest salary.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 村上監督が監督した映画のうちで、一番好きな映画はどれですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Among the movies that Murakami has directed, which is your favorite movie?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここにある釣竿、１０本のうちの４本は海釣り用だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: 4 of the 10 fishing rods that are here are for saltwater fishing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 学校の科目全てのうちから、一番好きな科目を教えてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Out of all of the school subjects, what is your favorite subject?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここにある１００枚のうちから１枚引いてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please draw one of the 100 cards here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ひなさん：「すべての食べ物のうちでイクラが一番好きです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Hina: 'I like the salmon roe the most of all foods.' (of the・among)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「１９５国のうちで一番狭いのはバチカンだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'Of the 195 countries, Vatican City is the smallest.' (among)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「一万人のうち一人ぐらいが成功できるそうだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'It is said that about one in ten thousand people are able to achieve success.' (of the・among)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「金属のうちで最も一般的なものはアルミニウムだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'Aluminum is the most common among metals.' (of the)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「山のように積み重ねたＣＤのうち１枚ぐらいは聞く価値があるかもしれない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Among the mountain of CDs, maybe (only) about one is worth listening to.' (of the)

Name: つつ
Meaning: While, And
About: つつ is a particle in Japanese that appears after the ます-stem form of verbs. When used, it indicates that (B) is an action that is happening at the same time as (A). This usually translates simply as 'while (A), (B)'. つつ is a formal grammar structure and will appear in writing more than in speech.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 環境に悪いと知りつつ、レジ袋を使い続けている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While I know that it is bad for the environment, I continue to use plastic bags.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: インターネットでレシピを見つつ、料理をしたので今日の晩御飯は美味しいはずです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Dinner tonight should be delicious since I cooked while looking at a recipe on the internet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 走りながら携帯でゲームをしていたら、電柱にぶつかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bumped into a telephone pole because I was gaming on my phone while I was walking. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 走りつつ携帯でゲームをしていたら、電柱にぶつかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bumped into a telephone pole because I was gaming on my phone while I was walking. (Physical action, unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事に関係ないことを考えながら仕事をしていたら、大きなミスをしてしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I made a big mistake at work because I was working while thinking about something unrelated to work. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事に関係ないことを考えつつ仕事をしていたら、大きなミスをしてしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I made a big mistake at work because I was working while thinking about something unrelated to work. (Non-physical, natural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ツバメは飛行しつつ、寝ることができる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The swallow can sleep while flying.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 布団をしきつつテレビに見入ってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While laying out my futon, I got transfixed by the TV.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 集金しつつ、空き家の調査もしています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While working as a bill collector, I am also surveying empty houses.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 育児をしつつ、フルタイムで働くのは大変なことです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Working full time while raising children is really hard.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 父の足跡をたどりつつ、自分の生き方を探している。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While following in my father's footsteps, I am searching for how to live my own life.

Name: つつも
Meaning: Even while ~ing, Even though ~ing, Despite ~ing, Although ~ing
About: In addition to the base meaning of つつ 'while doing (A)' when used by itself, the addition of も simply adds the nuance of 'even'. This is often translated as 'even while doing (A), (B)', or 'although doing (A), (B)'. (B) will almost always be something that is somehow contradictory to (A). Like つつ, つつも will appear after the ます-stem of a verb that is the original ongoing action.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一人で洞窟に入るのは危ないと知りつつも、入ってしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Despite knowing that going in a cave alone is dangerous, I went in.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 初めてのライブで緊張しつつもものすごく楽しめました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Despite being very nervous at my first concert, I was able to enjoy it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は足を骨折していながらも、大会に出場しようとしたところ、監督に止められた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Despite having a broken leg, he tried to enter the tournament, but was stopped by the coach. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は足を骨折していつつも、大会に出場しようとしたところ、監督に止められた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even while having a broken leg, he tried to enter the tournament, but was stopped by the coach. (Physical action, unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なんかこの話は怪しいなと思いながらも、彼のことを信じてみた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Despite thinking, 'this sounds fishy,' I believed him. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なんかこの話は怪しいなと思いつつも、彼のことを信じてみた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though I thought that the story was fishy, I believed him. (Non-physical, natural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 斜めになりつつもなんとか持ちこたえたジェンガ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite becoming slanted, the Jenga tower somehow held out.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 上を狙いつつも、まるで狙っていないかのような素振りをしています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite aiming up, he is swinging like he isn't even aiming.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 南極点遠征はよく備えつつも、失敗した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite (everyone) preparing well, the south pole expedition failed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 車庫のシャッターを開けつつも、まだ行こうか行くまいか迷っていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite opening the garage door, I was still debating whether or not to go.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 船は、沈みそうになりつつも、なんとか港まで帰って来た。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though the ship was on the verge of sinking, it somehow made it to the harbor.

Name: に際(さい)して
Meaning: On the occasion of, At the time of
About: Like 際(さい)に 'on the occasion of (A)', に際(さい)して will be used to show some particular occasion, and is used most frequently in regard to one-off events, or chance occurrences. However, unlike 際(さい)に, に際(さい)して is a combination of に, and the て-form of 際(さい)する, which is a verb that usually has the meaning of 'to come to pass'. Despite the more literal translation of 'when (A) comes to pass', に際(さい)して will often just be interpreted as 'on the occasion of (A)', or 'at the time of (A)'. This is a formal grammar pattern that is seen connected either to nouns, or verbs in their dictionary form.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しいプロジェクトを始めるに際して、新しいグループリーダーを決めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the occasion of starting a new project, we chose a new leader.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: クレジットカードを申し込むに際して、運転免許証が必要です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the occasion of signing up for a credit card, you will need your driver's license.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 引越しに際して、いらなくなった家具を全部捨てた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At the time of my move, I threw out all the furniture I don't use anymore.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 面接でくるに際して印鑑と運転免許証をお持ちください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please bring your stamp and driver's license at the time of your interview.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 面接でくる際には印鑑と運転免許証をお持ちください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When you come to your interview, please bring your stamp and driver's license.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ホームページから登録されたに際して、確認のためこちらからメールを送信することがあります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the occasion where you have registered using our website, we may send you an email for confirmation. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ホームページから登録された際には、確認のためこちらからメールを送信することがあります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the occasion where you have registered using our website, we may send you an email for confirmation. (Natural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 応援に際して守ってほしいルールがあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: On the occasion of supporting (someone), there are some rules that I would like you to follow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 移転に際して必要なものがあれば言ってね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: On the occasion of being transferred, let me know if there is anything that (you) need.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「受験に際しての注意事項」をよくお読みください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please, read the 'points to keep in mind at the time of the exam' carefully.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 車を追い越すに際して気をつけるべきことがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At the time of passing another vehicle, you should take necessary precautions.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 独立するに際して、先輩のご意見をいただけませんか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: May I get your (senpai's) opinion at the time of becoming independent?

Name: 際(さい)に
Meaning: When, At the time of, In case of, On the occasion of
About: 際(さい) is a noun in Japanese that means 'verge'. This is as in 'to be on the verge', and translates mostly as 'on the occasion of (A)', 'at the time of (A)', 'in case of (A)', or 'when (A)'. In the same way as 'verge' in English, it implies a fairly big or somehow important event, and will not be used with standard occurrences. 際(さい)に will appear after verbs in either their dictionary or past-tense forms, and after nouns. In the case of nouns, it will be preceded by の. While (A) is likely to be a temporary or one-off event, 際(さい)に is not limited to one-off situations. It may also appear with regularly occurring events, but the way of reacting to that event may change depending on some one-off circumstances.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この建物に入る際には、必ずヘルメットを被ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When entering this building, please wear a helmet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この薬品が誤って肌に飛び散った際には、直ぐにかかりつけの医者に相談してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If this chemical accidentally splashes onto your skin, consult your physician immediately.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日の面接の際には、印鑑を持ってきてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please bring your stamp when you come to the interview tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 商品を並べる際に、注意しないといけない事はなんですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is there anything I should be careful about when arranging the products?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車を動かす際には、周りに子供がいないか確認してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When moving your car, please make sure there aren't any kids around.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本では家を出る時に行ってきますと言う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In Japan we say, 'I'm leaving,' when we leave the house. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本では家を出る際に行ってきますと言う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In Japan we say, 'I'm leaving,' when we leave the house. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 炎天下で働く際には帽子などを持ってきてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When working under the scorching sun, remember to bring things like a hat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 休講の際には連絡しますから、ちゃんと授業に出てください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We’ll notify you in the event of a class cancellation, so please attend class properly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 稽古の際に教わったことを本番でどこまで発揮できるかが問題だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The issue is to what extent you can demonstrate what you were taught when training at an actual performance.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 警備の際に注意してほしいことを書き出しておきましたので、確認してください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since I wrote out the things I want you to be careful of when on guard, please verify it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 血圧を測る際には、できるだけ平常心でいたほうがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be best to have as much presence of mind as possible on the occasion of having your blood pressure measured.

Name: に当(あ)たって
Meaning: When, When doing something, On the occasion, At the time
About: に当(あ)たり or に当(あ)たって is a formal grammar pattern in Japanese used to convey the meaning of 'at the time of (A)', 'when doing (A)', or 'on the occasion of (A)'. Like に際(さい)して 'on the occasion of (A)', it will often be used in regard to preparation for future events. This structure is a combination of に, and the う-Verb 当(あ)たる 'to hit', or 'to come into contact' in either its formal-conjunctive form or て-form. に当(あ)たり will appear following verbs in their dictionary form, or nouns. There are two primary nuances that this structure will be used for, so let's look at a few examples of each. The first is when (A) is some sort of special occasion or condition from which (B) will be done. The second is when (A) is some sort of goal or target for which (B) will be the means or measures in response to that goal.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 就活を始めるに当たり、新しいスーツを買った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the occasion of starting my job search, I bought a new suit.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 卒業にあたって、みんなで卒業旅行として韓国に行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the occasion of my graduation, we all went to Korea as a graduation trip.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 転職をするに当たり、インターネットで自分に合った会社を探すことにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At the time of changing jobs, I looked for a company that would suit me well on the internet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しいお店の開店にあたって、オープニングスタッフを募集しました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We recruited opening staff at the time of opening a new restaurant.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 母の葬式に際して必要な書類を準備した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I gathered all the necessary documents at the time of my mother's funeral. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 母の葬式に当たって必要な書類を準備した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I gathered all the necessary documents at the time of my mother's funeral. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: レーザーの試験に当たり、必ず保護メガネを着用してください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Be sure to wear safety glasses when testing the laser. (on the occasion of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 綱渡りをするに当たり、命綱をつけてもらった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When I did a tightrope walk, I had a safety wire connected. (at the time of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彫刻を彫るに当たり、彫刻刀を買い換えた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: On the occasion of carving a sculpture, I bought a new chisel.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 課長の退職に当たって、お別れの一言を述べさせていただきます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let me say a few words of farewell on the occasion of the section manager's retirement.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パスポートの申請に当たり、顔写真を必ず持ってきてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Be sure to bring headshots at the time of passport application.

Name: を契機(けいき)に
Meaning: Lead to, As a good opportunity to, As a result of, As a trigger
About: を契機(けいき)に is a grammar construction made up of を, the noun 契機(けいき) 'chance' or 'trigger' and に. It is a formal pattern that is used to indicate some sort of trigger and may be translated '(A) led to (B)', 'as an opportunity to (A), (B)', or 'as a result of (A), (B)'. (A) may either be a positive or negative event, but will usually be something extremely big in terms of life, or current/historical events in the world. を契機(けいき)に will be seen after nouns, or verbs that have been nominalized with either の or こと. Alternatively, にして or として may replace に without any change in the overall meaning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供が生まれたのを契機に、パチンコをやめることに決めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I decided to quit pachinko as a result of my child being born.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 移動制限が緩和されたことを契機に、観光客の数が増えた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The travel restriction being eased led to an increase of tourists.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は出産を契機に、会社を辞めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She quit her job as a result of giving birth.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんは入院を契機にして、タバコを止めました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san being hospitalized led him to quit smoking.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大統領の暗殺を契機として、戦争が始まった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The assassination of the president led to a war.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩が楽しそうに料理をしている姿を見たのをきっかけに、私も料理を始めることにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Seeing my senpai enjoy cooking led me to start cooking too. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩が楽しそうに料理をしている姿を見たのを契機に、私も料理を始めることにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Seeing my senpai enjoy cooking led me to start cooking too. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供の独立を契機に家を改造することにした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As a result of my children becoming independent, I decided to remodel the house.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テレビ取材を契機に、（レストランの）人気が加速していった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The television coverage triggered the acceleration of popularity (for the restaurant).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 転職を契機に落ち着きを取り戻した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As a result of my change in occupation, I was able to regain my composure.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あんなに大人しかった彼が、引越しを契機によく話すようになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He, who was so quiet, has, as a result of moving, become quite talkative.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 温泉を掘り当てたことを契機に大金持ちになりました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Digging up the hot spring led to me becoming very rich.

Name: つつある
Meaning: -ing, Be -ing
About: When the particle つつ 'while doing' is combined with ある 'to be', it indicates that someone or something is in the ongoing process of (A). (A) will be a verb in its ます-stem form. This formal grammar structure primarily highlights that (A) is slowly but surely continuing or changing. This 'change' is often in regard to an increase, decrease, expansion, contraction, or something similar. This pattern can be translated simply as 'to be (A)ing'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎年、年金の受給額が減りつつあるので、生活に困っている高齢者が増えてきている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every year, more and more elderly people are having trouble making ends meet because their pension benefits are decreasing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本では物価が上がりつつある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Prices in general are rising in Japan.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近はインターネットを使って買い物ができるので、わざわざお店に行って買い物をする人が減りつつある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: These days, people can shop using the Internet, so fewer people are going out of their way to go to stores to shop.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はりんごを食べている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is eating an apple. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はりんごを食べつつある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is eating an apple. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: おかげさまで、病気は治りつつあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Fortunately, my disease is healing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 契約しつつあったのに決裂した。惜しいことをした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite being in the process of signing a contract, the discussions broke down. I did something regrettable.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大流行したインフルエンザの猛威も、今は落ち着きつつある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The fury of the widespread influenza is now calming down.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アフリカの野生動物の数が減りつつあるのは残念だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is a pity that the number of wild animals in Africa is decreasing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 在庫過剰になりつつあるから、値下げしてでも売ってください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since inventory continues to overflow, please sell them even if you have to lower the price.

Name: ～所(ところ)に
Meaning: At the time, When, While, Timing
About: ところに will be used to highlight the time of (A), and can be interpreted as 'at the time of (A)', 'while (A)', or 'with the timing of (A)'. As it is a structure that makes use of the noun ところ 'place' or 'spot', it puts more emphasis on the scene or situation, rather than the action itself. This pattern follows verbs in their ている or ていた forms. Also, rather than appearing with に, へ is sometimes used instead. Depending on the form of the verb, ところに may indicate being 'on the verge of (A)', 'partway through (A)', or having 'just finished (A)'. Compared to other ところ based structures, the addition of に or へ will often precede a (B) statement indicating that 'at the precise moment of (A), (B) happened'. This may either be positive or negative.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車で左折しているところに、急に自転車が飛び出してきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was making a left turn in my car when a bicycle suddenly came out of nowhere.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 休憩室で踊っていたところに後輩たちが休憩室に入ってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was dancing in the break room when my juniors came in.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 倉庫を取り壊しているところへ近所の人が来て手伝ってくれた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My neighbor came to help me when I was tearing down the shed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 上司に怒られて落ち込んでいたところへ、先輩がきて慰めてくれた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My senpai came to comfort me when I was feeling down because I was yelled at by my boss.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お見苦しいところをお見せして申し訳ございません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am terribly sorry that you had to see such a thing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 正直なところ、彼の言うことはあまり信じない方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To be honest, you shouldn't trust what he says.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩、お休みのところすみません。今お時間大丈夫でしょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Senpai, I'm sorry to bother you on your break. Do you have some time right now?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 犬を散歩させているところにTさんに出くわした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When I was walking the dog, I came across T-san.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ちょうどジャガイモの皮をむこうとしているところに電話が鳴った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The telephone rang while I was trying to peel the potatoes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: セメントを入れているところへ猫がやって来て足跡を付けた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A cat came by and left prints when the cement was being poured.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 店を閉めているところへお客さんが来ちゃった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A customer came right when I was closing up the shop.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 車を洗っていたところにウチの犬がやってきて、車にオシッコをした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While I was washing the car, my dog came over and peed on it.

Name: か〜ないかの内(うち)に
Meaning: Right after, As soon as, Just when, Barely
About: か～ないかのうちに is a slightly formal grammar structure used in Japanese to indicate a precise point in time where the action of (A) can not be determined as either being started, or finished. Usually, it highlights the exact moment either before or after (A) commences. This grammar structure is comprised of か, ない, か, の, the noun 内(うち) 'within', and に. Literally, it just means 'while not knowing whether (A) or not (A), (B)'. The verb that appears before か and ないか must be repeated in this grammar pattern, and may be used in its dictionary form. Standard translations include 'right after (A)', 'as soon as (A)', and 'barely when (A)'. Additionally, か～ないかのうちに may be used to highlight relatively short periods of time within which something happens. This is usually in regard to some sort of positive or negative occurrence that would not usually be expected to be able to happen so quickly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 父はビールを飲み終わるか飲み終わらないかのうちに、新しい缶を開けた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My father opened a new can of beer as soon as he finished his beer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は椅子に座るか座らないかのうちに、テレビをつけた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He turned his TV on just as he sat down.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は車が止まるか止まらないかのうちに、ドアを開けて駅へと走っていった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just as the car stopped, she opened the door and ran to the station.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 就活を初めて一週間経つか経たないかのうちに、仕事が見つかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In just a week of looking for a new job, I found a job.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 戦争が終わるか終わらないかのうちに、原爆が落とされた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: An atomic bomb was dropped, just when the war was about to end.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 焦がすか焦がさないかの内に、肉を取るのが僕の流儀。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My style is to take off the meat just when it starts to burn.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 御馳走をいただくかいただかないかの内に、帰る時間になってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just as I was about to eat, it was time to go home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 削除されるかされないかの内に、自ら手を引いた方がいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just when you are about to be eliminated, it is better to withdraw oneself.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 清書するかしないかの内に、下書きを紛失してしまいました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just as I was about to write a clean copy, I lost my rough draft.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 言葉が終わるか終わらないかの内に、彼女は意識を失った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As soon as she finished her remark, she had lost consciousness.

Name: 掛(が)けに
Meaning: On the way to, As you go
About: Although not used much in modern Japanese, the suffix 掛(が)け 'support', or 'hanger' followed by に may occasionally appear after the ます-stem of verbs. When seen used this way, 掛(が)けに simply means 'on the way', 'as you go', or 'while doing (A)'. (B) may just be considered as something done while doing (A), or as being done specifically because (A) is a good opportunity to do it. This structure may be used either with or without kanji, so it will be important to remember both.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 帰りがけに駅前のたこ焼き屋でたこ焼きを買った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On my way home, I bought some takoyaki from the takoyaki store in front of the station.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は学校への行きがけにコンビニで弁当を買う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today, on my way to school, I will buy lunch at the convenience store.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お父さん、通りがけにサービスエリアにでも寄って行こ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Dad, let's stop by the service area on the way!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 女の子の噂話：「さっきあいつ、来掛けに妙なことを言ってたね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Girls gossiping: 'Just now, on the way here, that dude was saying weird things.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達との話：「帰り掛けにタイコさんを誘って一緒に戻ろうか。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between friends: 'Do you want to invite Taiko on the way home, and go back together?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生は生徒と話している：「タカスさん、このプリントを帰り掛けにアイサカさんに持って行ってください。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A teacher is talking with a student: 'Takasu, please bring this handout to Aisaka on the way home.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ライトノベル：「彼はスーパーへの行き掛けに何かを思い出したように突然止まり速く家に帰った。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Light novel: 'He suddenly stopped as if he remembered something on his way to the supermarket and quickly returned home.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 病気の友達の見舞いに行く時、友達との話：「病院への行き掛けに花屋に寄って花束を買おう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Visiting a sick friend, chat between friends: 'Let's drop by the florist on the way to the hospital, and buy a bouquet.'

Name: ていては
Meaning: If one keeps doing something, When, If something is...
About: ていては is a structure often seen with verbs that will express that 'if one continues with (A), (B)'. In most cases, this will indicate a negative outcome. ていては is a combination of the て-form of a verb, 居(い)る 'to be' in its て-form, and は. The final ては is often considered its own conjunctive structure that may either exhibit hypothetical situations, or repetitive actions. In this case, it's a bit of a mix of both, depending on the verb it is attached to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日お菓子ばかりを食べていては、いつまで経っても痩せませんよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you keep only eating snacks, you'll never lose any weight.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎晩遊んでいてはお金はたまりませんよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you keep going out every night, you won't save up money.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事の事ばかりを気にしていては、旅行は楽しめませんよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you keep worrying about work, you won't be able to enjoy your trip.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 黙っていては、相手に気持ちが伝わらないんじゃない？
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you stay silent, how will the other person know how you feel?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 来るのが遅すぎます。先に始めていてはいけませんか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will be very late. Would you mind if you start without me?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 力を抜いていては持てない。もっと力を入れて！
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you keep relaxing, you won't be able to hold it. Put more effort into it!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暖房をつけていては暑すぎる。もう春なんだから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you keep turning on the heat, it is too hot. It's already spring, you know.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんな歩き方をしていては、ペンギンかと思われますよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you keep walking like that, people will think that you are a penguin.

Name: ところだった ②
Meaning: Was just about to do something, Was in the middle of...
About: When combined with the dictionary form of verbs, ところだった will indicate that something was about to happen, and will regularly be translated as 'was just about to do (A)', or 'was in the middle of (A)'. In many cases, ところだった will indicate either a positive or negative result that came about from 'not doing (A)'. As this grammar pattern is a combination of ところ 'place', and the past tense of だ, だった; it will put emphasis of 'having been in the place or situation of (A)', before something happened that caused the expected result to change. In cases where a positive result was narrowly missed out on, のに will often appear directly after ところだった. This can be interpreted as 'despite almost doing (A), (B)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 危なかった。危うくあの人をひくところだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That was close. I was about to run over that person.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 起きるのが３分遅かったら、遅刻するところだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was about to be late if I had woken up three minutes later.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今から家を出るところだったのに、いきなり雨が降ってきたから雨が止むまで待つ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was just about to leave the house, but it suddenly started raining, so I'm going to wait until the rain stops.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もうすぐ犯人が自白するところだったのに、お前が余計なことを言うから...。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The killer was just about to confess, but you went off on a tangent...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 絵の具をつけてしまうところだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was just about to apply the paint.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 危うく期限が切れてしまうところだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was just about to narrowly miss the deadline.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今から関西弁を教わるところだったのに。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was just about to be taught the Kansai dialect.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 出掛けるところだったが、雨が降ってきたのでやめました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was just about to go out, but because it started raining, I stopped.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 捕まえた犯人を危うく逃すところだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The captured criminal was just about to barely escape.

Name: どころではない
Meaning: This is not the time for…, Far from, Out of the question
About: When the voiced form of ところ 'place', どころ appears in Japanese, it will very often be part of a set phrase expressing some kind of negative situation or evaluation. どころではない is no different, and highlights that it is 'far from (A)', or that '(A) is out of the question'. These translations appear when the actual situation is considered to be even more remarkable than the phrase that どころではない is attached to. This grammar pattern will be seen at the end of phrases indicating some situation which is not ideal. Additionally, ではない may be replaced with じゃない in more casual settings. どころではない may also sometimes be translated as 'it is not the time for (A)'. In sentences that use this interpretation, (A) is considered to be something that there is no allowance for due to there being far more important matters. This use will reflect the personal opinion of the speaker.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 出産は痛いどころではないらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They say childbirth is far from painful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 締め切りが迫って来てるから、休憩を取るどころじゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The deadline is approaching, so taking a break is out of the question.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お母さんからお父さんが倒れたと連絡があったので、仕事どころではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not the time for working, since I got a message from my mother telling me that my father collapsed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今は仕事が忙しいし、お金も全然ないから、結婚どころじゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I am busy with work and have no money, it is not the time to get married.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 休みの日はたくさん寝たい。レジャーどころではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: On my day off, I want to sleep a lot. Leisure activities are out of the question.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 腰を痛めてしまったから、マラソンどころではありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I unfortunately injured my lower back, a marathon is out of the question.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 熱があるというのに、遊園地どころではないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When you have a fever, it is not the time to go to an amusement park.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なんとか通じればいい。アクセントどころではありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be good if you could somehow communicate. This is not the time to worry about accent.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 急用が入ったので、お出掛けどころではなくなった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Urgent business came in, so going out became out of the question.

Name: 振(ぶ)りに
Meaning: For the first time in, Haven't done for some time
About: When used as a suffix, the voiced form of 振(ふ)り 'style', 振(ぶ)り will be used to indicate either the way something appears, or some specific lapse of time since the last time something happened. In this lesson, we will focus on the 'lapse of time' meaning. This can be translated as 'for the first time in (A)', or 'haven't done (B) for (A) time'. As ぶり (appearing most often in hiragana) is a suffix, it will be used after nouns. When followed by に, the part (B) portion of the sentence will give more information about what wasn't done for the period of (A). Additionally, ぶり may be followed by の when attached directly to a second noun that is being modified by ぶり.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一年ぶりに五キロも走ったから明日は絶対に筋肉痛だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am definitely going to be sore tomorrow because I ran a 5K for the first time in a year.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ３年ぶりに風呂に入る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bathed for the first time in 3 years.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ４年ぶりの寿司だ！やっぱり日本の寿司はうまいな！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is my first time having sushi in 4 years! Man, Japanese sushi is the best!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高橋選手が１０年ぶりの優勝！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takahashi won for the first time in 10 years!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ５１分ぶりに家に帰る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will go home for the first time in 51 minutes. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 歯医者に行くのは二年振りだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Going to the dentist is something I haven't done in 2 years.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 十年振りに、高校の友達に会った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I met a high school friend who I hadn't seen for 10 years.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ２週間振りの寿司を食べた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I ate sushi for the first time in two weeks.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 三年振りに日本食を味わえて幸せです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For the first time in three years, I am happy that I could taste Japanese food.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 十日振りの快晴で、とてもさわやかだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For the first time in 10 days, the weather is nice and it is very refreshing.

Name: ～ては
Meaning: If, With, Since, Because
About: When the particles て and は are combined, they form a regular composite structure that is used primarily to highlight repeating actions, or to make assessments or judgments about potential situations. In this grammar structure, we will be looking at the nuance that is used with potential situations. This may be interpreted simply as 'if (A), (B)', 'when (A), (B)', or 'because of (A), (B)'. At times when used as 'if', ては will generally express some sort of negative expectation or comment. Depending on what ては appears after, では may be used instead. This is the case when following nouns, な-Adjectives, or verbs that require で to be used instead of て when conjugating. As with many other structures that use ては or では, it will often be shortened to じゃ or ちゃ.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そのように力を入れて回してはネジがだめになってしまいますよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you turn it with such force, you're going to ruin the screw.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなに長くては鞄に入らないので、半分に折ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It won't fit in my bag if it's that long, so please fold it in half.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は掃除が苦手なので、そんな几帳面では私と住むことはできないでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't like cleaning, so if you are that well-organized, you probably won't be able to live with me. (You probably won't enjoy living with me)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんな貧乏くさい格好ではあのレストランには入れないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you have such a poor-looking outfit, they won't let you into that restaurant.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: リーダーがあの人じゃ嫌です。どうしてもあの人じゃないといけないなら私を別のチームに入れてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If that person is the leader, screw that. If there is really no other way than making that person the leader, then please put me on a different team.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ご飯を全部食べなくちゃ大きくなれないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you don't eat all your food, you won't grow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 無理に引っぱっては壊れてしまいますよ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you pull it forcibly, it will break!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寝る前にそんなコーヒーを飲んでは寝られない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you drink coffee before going to bed, you won't be able to sleep a wink.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんなに塩辛くては売り物にならないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it is this salty, it will not sell.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんな服装ではあの店には入れてもらえないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: With those clothes, you won't be able to enter that shop.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そのような給与では、あの工場で働くには無理がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not worth working in that factory if that is what you will be paid.

Name: ～ては〜ては
Meaning: Repeating action, If, Since
About: Another structure making use of the combined て and は particles is ては～ては. This grammar pattern highlights that the actions of (A) and (B) are continuously being repeated and can be interpreted as 'doing (A) and (B) repeatedly'. The (A) and (B) actions will often be things that contrast each other in some respect, such as starting and stopping, walking and running, going forwards and then backwards, etc. ては～ては will be used with verbs in the て-form, so will occasionally appear as では. The abbreviated versions of ちゃ and じゃ may also be seen with the grammar point, but it may be considered unnatural if the same abbreviation is not used both times. This is mainly due to the level of formality being required to stay the same within sentences.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここ最近は食べては寝て、食べては寝ての繰り返しだから太ってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently I've been eating and sleeping, eating and sleeping, so I've gained some weight.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事ではミスしては怒られ、怒られてはミスをする。毎日この繰り返しだから仕事を辞めようと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At work, I make a mistake and get yelled at, get yelled at and make a mistake. This repeats every day so I'm thinking of quitting my job.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運動しないで食っちゃ寝食っちゃ寝ばかりしていると牛になるよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you eat and sleep, eat and sleep without exercising, you are going to turn into a cow!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 薬を飲んじゃ吐いて、飲んじゃ吐いてを何回も繰り返したから喉が痛い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My throat hurts because I've taken medicine and thrown up, then taken it and thrown up over and over.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ５キロを休憩なしで走れるようになるには、疲れるまで１キロ走っては休憩しての繰り返しを１ヶ月間毎日続けることが必要です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To be able to run 5 kilometers without taking a break, you need to run for a kilometer, then take a break, and repeat that process everyday for a month.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田舎者：「働いては寝て、働いては寝てばかりだ。このような人生はダメだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Countryman: 'I only work and sleep, work and sleep (repeatedly)… This is not the good life.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あくびをしてはフリスクを食べ、あくびをしてはフリスクを食べ、何とか起きていられた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: By yawning and eating a mint, yawning and eating a mint, I was somehow able to wake up.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 曖昧なことを言ってははぐらかし、嘘をついては逃げようとし、あの人はどうしようもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person is a lost cause, saying ambiguous things and lying and trying to run.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 酒を飲んでは暴れ、暴れては物を壊す。彼は酒癖が悪い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Drinking alcohol and acting violently, raging and breaking things. He is a bad drunk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 受け取っては誰かに渡し、渡されては受け取るというだけの仕事です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The job is just taking stuff and handing it off to others, taking and handing off.

Name: も又(また)
Meaning: Too, Also (with more emphasis than も alone), Again
About: When used adverbially, the grouping of も and 又(また) 'once again', or 'also' will indicate that 'in addition to (A), (B)', or 'also with (A), (B)'. This structure appears after nouns, or noun-like phrases and simply emphasizes that something important needs to be considered about (A). The noun or noun-phrase that もまた is connected to will be interpreted to be the primary point of a statement, regardless of any contrasting opinion that is given within a sentence. Additionally, もまた will primarily appear in hiragana, and may be thought of simply as a stronger version of も.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高橋さんが提案したアイディアはいいのですが田中さんが提案したことを実行するのも又、いい考えだと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The idea suggested by Takahashi-san is good, but I also think it's a good idea to implement what Tanaka-san suggested.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カレーは甘くても美味しいけど、辛いのもまた美味しいんだよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Curry is good even if it's sweet, but spicy curry is also good.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生になるには知識がたくさん必要です。ですが、経験が必要なのも又確かだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Being a teacher requires a lot of knowledge. However, experience is also necessary.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日もまた同じ時間にここにきてね！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please come here again at the same time tomorrow!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: チームのキャプテン：「今日も又頑張ろう！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Team captain: 'Let's do our best today again!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 社長：「今年も又利益増大に取り組みます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Company president: 'This year, again, we will work on increasing profit.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 論文：「盆栽をいじるという趣味も又中国がルーツである。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'The hobby of manipulating bonsais also has its roots in China.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 論文：「お金は、使うことだけでなく稼ぐことも又楽しいです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Essay/article: 'Not only spending, but also earning money is fun.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子育てについての論文：「可愛い子に旅をさせてみること、それも又大切なことです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Essay/article about parenting: 'Sending your beloved children out into the world, that is also important.'

Name: 結果(けっか)
Meaning: As a result of
About: 結果(けっか) 'result' is a noun in Japanese that is often seen paired with the past form of verbs, or with nouns followed by の. This grammar structure can be translated as 'as a result of (A), (B)', and simply indicates (A) as being the cause for how something ended up.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お酒を飲んで運転した結果、電柱にぶつかって免許を取り消された。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a result of drinking and driving, I drove into a telephone pole and my license was revoked.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: みんなが努力した結果、大会で優勝することができた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a result of everyone doing their best, we were able to win the competition.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 話し合いの結果、親が学費を払ってくれることになりました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a result of the discussion, it has been decided that my parents are going to pay my tuition.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 調査の結果、この土地の土は汚染されていることが確認できました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a result of the examination, we were able to confirm that the soil on this property is contaminated.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事で頑張った結果、昇進する事が決まった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a result of my hard work, I'm getting promoted.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パートナーと話し合いをした挙句、離婚することになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After having a discussion with my partner, we have decided to get divorced.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 叫んで暴れた結果、逮捕された。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As a result of shouting and acting violently, I got arrested.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 占いの結果など信じたりはしない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't believe in such things as the results of fortunetelling.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 運動を怠った結果、太ってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As a result of neglecting exercise, I got fat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 研究の結果、新しい粒子が見つかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As a result of research, new particles were discovered.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 裁判で争った結果負けてしまうなんて…
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot believe that the result of the court battle will end up in me losing...

Name: 以来(いらい)
Meaning: Since, Henceforth
About: When the noun, 以来(いらい) 'ever since' is paired with the て-form of verbs, or with nouns, it indicates that (B) is something that has continued non-stop since (A), or will continue non-stop from (A). This may be interpreted as 'since (A)', 'henceforth', or 'ever since (A)'. The key point of 以来(いらい) is that it indicates an ongoing state. Due to this, it focuses on (B) being something that will continue non-stop until a change is caused externally.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 二年前にタバコをやめて以来、一本も吸ってない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I haven't smoked a single cigarette ever since I quit 2 years ago.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本に来て以来、全然母国の友達と連絡をとっていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I haven't kept in touch with my friends back home ever since I moved to Japan.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 久しぶり！卒業以来じゃない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Long time no see! (We haven't met) since graduation, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 入社以来、あの先輩には色々とお世話になっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That senpai has helped me in many ways since I've joined the company.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 海外転職して以来、５年も日本に帰っていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have not been back to Japan for five years since I changed jobs overseas.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 去年この大学に入学して以来、１回しか実家に帰っていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have only been back to my parents' house once since I entered university last year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの原稿を読んで以来、すっかり彼のファンになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since reading that manuscript, I have become a total fan of his.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 紅葉が始まって以来、店は超満員だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since fall colors started, it has been teeming with people at the restaurant.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 卒業して以来だな。この校舎を見に来たのは。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I haven't come to see this school building since graduation.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: シフトを交替して以来、彼とは全然会わなくなった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since changing shifts, I haven't seen him at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 休業して以来、再開の目処が立っていない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since closing my business, the prospect of reopening hasn't come up.

Name: に先立(さきだ)ち
Meaning: Before, Prior to, In preference over
About: Being a combination of に and the う-Verb 先立(さきだ)つ 'to take the lead', or 'to precede', this structure connects to both nouns and verbs in their dictionary forms, to indicate that (B) is a preliminary step required for (A). It may be interpreted as 'before (A), (B)', 'prior to (A), (B)', or 'in preference over (A), (B)'. Despite these several interpretations, the literal meaning of 'standing before (A), (B)' can be useful to remember, as it highlights the importance of (B) as a first step. As 先立(さきだ)つ is a verb, it may be seen in its dictionary form when followed directly by another noun, or in its て-form when indicating the whole (B) phrase as preceding (A). Additionally, the formal-conjunctive form, 先立(さきだ)ち will often be used in preference of the て-form, as に先立(さきだ)つ is a formal grammar structure.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しい機械を導入するに先立って、色々な会社のサイトを見てスペックを比較します。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Prior to installing a new machine, I will visit websites of various companies to compare the specs.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 映画の公開に先立ち、予告編が公開された。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Prior to the release of the movie, the trailer was released.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 引越しに先立つ１日前に洗濯機や冷蔵庫の水抜きをしておかなければならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Washing machines and refrigerators must be drained one day prior to moving.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 海外へ移住したいけど、先立つものがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to move abroad, but I don't have the means to do it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しい車を買いたいけど先立つものがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want a new car, but I don't have the means to buy one.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このアプリの使用に先立ち、ライセンス契約を読んでおいてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please read the license agreement prior to running this application.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: クリストファー・コロンブスに先立ってヴァイキングはアメリカを発見したと考えられている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The vikings are considered to have discovered America before Christopher Columbus.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: レーザーの電源を入れるに先立って、保護メガネをかけておいてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Prior to turning on the laser, please put on safety glasses in advance.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あるゲームの通知：「冒険に挑むに先立って仲間を集めよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Certain game: 'You must gather your party before venturing forth.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ＰＣケースを開けるに先立ち、万が一のためにまず電源を切っておかなければならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Before opening the computer case, as an extra precaution, you have to turn off the power.

Name: 果(は)たして
Meaning: Wonder if ~ (really)?, Wonder how ~ (actually)?, Sure enough, As expected
About: 果(は)たして, being the て-form of the う-Verb 果(は)たす 'to fulfill', or 'to come to fruition', is an expression that is used adverbially to strengthen phrases of speculation. It may be translated as 'I wonder if (A)', 'how actually (A)', or 'how really (A)'. 果(は)たして will often be seen paired with other structures that indicate speculation, such as だろうか, でしょうか, かな, or かしら; and can be thought of as just emphasizing them further. As this grammar point will be used adverbially, it will primarily appear at the beginning of sentences. In sentences that do not include other speculative grammar patterns such as だろうか, 果(は)たして will regularly be translated as 'sure enough', or 'as expected'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 果たして彼が言っていることは本当なのだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if what he is saying is the truth.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 果たして、あのやり方で本当に成功するのでしょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if that approach will really work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は取引先の信頼を失う事をしてしまった。果たして、彼はクビになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He did something to lose the trust of his clients. As expected he was fired.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は自分の意見を彼に押し付けようとしたが、果たして彼は自分の意見を変えなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She tried to push her opinions onto him, but as expected he did not change his.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大学院に進学するのは果たして私にメリットがあるのでしょうか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if going on to graduate school will actually benefit me in the end.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼以外誰も仕事に来なかったため、果たして彼が全員の仕事をすることになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since no one came to work except him, he ended up having to do everyone's job in the end as expected.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 迷子：「果たしてどうやって帰るの？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Lost child: 'I wonder how will I actually get back home?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「バンジージャンプしてみたいなぁ〜。」
Ｂ：「果たしてできるかしら？」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'I want to try bungee jumping.'
B: 'I wonder if you can actually do it?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あんな厚かましいお願いをして、果たしてうまくいくのだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder, with such an impudent request, if it will actually turn out well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大学を中退するのは果たして賢明な行動でしょうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder if dropping out of university is really a wise thing to do?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 首相は減税を約束した。果たして首相は公約を守らなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The prime minister promised to cut taxes. Sure enough, he broke his promise.

Name: 甲斐(かい)がある
Meaning: To be (not) worth, To (not) pay off
About: 甲斐(かい), a noun meaning 'worth' or 'effect', will often be used following verbs or nouns, in order to show that (A) was or will be worth doing. In many cases, this grammar point will be seen in hiragana, and will appear as either かい or がい, depending on how it is conjugating with the previous word. Possible translations include things like 'it is worth doing (A)', or '(A) will pay off'. が and the う-Verb ある 'to be' will follow かい. This states that the 'worth of (A) exists'. Occasionally, the が will be omitted. When following verbs, がい will be used after the ます-stem, or かい may be used after any standard form. The primary difference between these conjugation patterns is that there is more focus on the tense of the verb with かい, whereas がい will frequently have the nuance of it 'always being worth (A)'. When pairing with nouns, の will be required before かいがある. Alternatively, かいがない may be used in order to indicate that it is 'not' worth doing something. かいがある is primarily used when the speaker wants to convey that a positive result will come from something that is either difficult or unpleasant.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この食パンを買えて、朝の４時から並んだ甲斐があった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It was worth standing in line since 4 a.m. as I was able to buy this bread.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こういう景色を見ると生きている甲斐があると思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This kind of scenery makes me feel that life is worth living.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は何回注意しても上達しないから教えがいがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She is not worth teaching because she does not improve no matter how many times I give her advice.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: みんなの努力の甲斐があり、この大会で優勝する事ができました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Everyone's hard work paid off, and we were able to win the tournament.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 看病の甲斐があり、父がどんどんと元気になってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Nursing my father paid off and he is rapidly getting better and better.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: しょっぼ、なにこれ。こんなもんのために東京からきた甲斐がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What the heck is this, this is it? It was not worth coming all the way from Tokyo for something like this.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「彼は勉強しないので教え甲斐がない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'It is not worth to teach him, because he is not studying.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 移転した甲斐があり、今やうちは人気店だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Now my shop is popular. Moving was worth it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの選手の本音を聞けて、インタビューした甲斐がありました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The interview was worth it as I was able to hear what that athlete truly thinks.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あんだけ喜んでもらえれば、頑張って手で編んだ甲斐がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If they are going to be that happy about it, it is worth it to knit it by hand.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: やっぱり、消火器を取り付けておいた甲斐があって、今回役に立った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As expected, it paid off to install a fire extinguisher, which proved to come in handy this time.

Name: やがて
Meaning: Before long, All too soon, In the end, Eventually
About: 軈(やが)て, meaning 'all too soon' is an adverb that appears at the beginning of sentences in order to indicate that some particular state that does not currently exist, will end up happening within an unspecified (usually short) amount of time. This can be translated as 'before long (A)', 'in the end (A)', or 'eventually (A)'. In the vast majority of cases, やがて will appear in hiragana.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そのアニメもあのアニメのようにやがて人気がなくなるでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That anime will probably lose popularity like that anime eventually.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日漢字を読む練習をしていれば、やがて小説を読めるようになるだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you practice reading kanji every day, eventually, you will be able to read a novel.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もう５時なので、やがて日が沈み始めるだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is already 5 p.m. so the sun will probably set soon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やがて６０歳になるけど、経済的に余裕がないので死ぬまで働き続けざるを得ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am nearly 60 years old, however, I have no choice but to keep working till I die because I have no excess money.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語を勉強し始めてから、やがて２年が経つ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It has been nearly 2 years since I have started studying Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 軈てきみは失恋したことも忘れるかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Perhaps, eventually you will forget you were once heartbroken.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 軈て３０歳になるけど、お金も名声も持ってない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although I will be 30 all too soon, I have neither money nor fame.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それがきっかけで、軈て新たな戦争が起こる可能性がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As a result of that, a new war might break out soon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: オデュッセウス：「時間と手間をかけても、軈て家に帰れる！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Odysseus: 'Even if it takes time and effort, I will eventually return home!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんな本も軈て読み終わります。けれど、果たしてそれは本当でしょうか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter the book, it will come to an end before long. However, I wonder is that really true?

Name: 従(したが)って
Meaning: Therefore, Thus, As a result
About: When used as a conjunction, the う-Verb 従(したが)う 'to comply' in its て-form will indicate that something is 'following on from (A), (B)', or 'as a result of (A), (B)'. As 従(したが)う highlights something that 'obeys with (A)', this construction will only be used to show a logical conclusion that is caused by (A). A typical pattern where 従(したが)って will be seen, is two sentences in which the first expresses a cause, and the second begins with 従(したが)って and then lists the logical result. This is a fairly formal grammar pattern, so is more likely to be encountered in more formal speech or writing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 現在東名高速の名古屋インターと岡崎インターの間でリニューアル工事が行われている。従って、その区間は現在通行止めとなっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Renewal work is currently underway on the Tomei Expressway between the Nagoya Interchange and the Okazaki Interchange. Therefore, that section is currently closed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年は去年より台風が多かったです。従って、今年の米の値段は去年より高くなるでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There were more typhoons this year than last year. Therefore, the price of rice this year will be higher than last year.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 会社ではインフルエンザが流行っている。従って、会議は全てオンラインで行われることになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The flu is going around in my company. Therefore, it has been decided that all meetings are going to take place online.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの会社は業界大手だ。従って、強気に出てくるはずです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That company is a major enterprise. Therefore, they should show strength.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 値下げしないよう連絡がありました。従って、定価で売るしかありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I received a message not to cut prices. Therefore I have no choice but to sell them at the fixed price.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 意見の相違がありすぎる。従って、契約は破棄させていただきます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is too much difference in our opinions. Therefore, let's break the agreement.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 公害が増大している。従って、工場は閉鎖する方向になります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Pollution is increasing. Therefore, it has been decided that we will close the factory.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電車が脱線してしまった。従って、今日中の到着は無理だと思われます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The train derailed. Therefore, I think it is impossible for me to arrive before the day is over.

Name: 挙句(あげく)
Meaning: After, In the end, After all, Eventually
About: 挙句(あげく) 'in the end', is a noun used in Japanese to express a negative result that occurs, despite a considerable amount of time, effort, or resources that was put into (A). あげく will often be used in situations where the escalating situation of (A) somehow caused or prompted the negative result of (B). あげく will appear after the past-tense form of verbs, or after nouns followed by の. Alternatively, あげく may be used to express some sort of troublesome or negative process that led to the conclusion of (B). In these cases, the outcome itself may not be undesirable, but arriving at that result of (B) somehow was.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は夫と話し合いをしたあげく、離婚することに決めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After having a discussion with my husband, we have decided that we are getting a divorce.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日落とした財布を長い時間探したあげく、見つける事ができなかったので交番に行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After looking for my wallet that I dropped yesterday, I couldn't find it, so I went to the police station.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんと中田さんは口論のあげく、喧嘩になってしまい、警察のお世話になった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After an argument, Mr. Tanaka and Ms. Nakata got into a fight and were taken care of by the police.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生と色々と相談したあげく、レポートを書き直すことにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After much discussion with the teacher, I decided to rewrite the report.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 父親との議論のあげく、俺は大学を中退して会社を継ぐことになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After some discussion with my father, I decided to drop out of college and take over his company.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 走って転んだ挙げ句に、壁に衝突した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After running and falling, I crashed into a wall.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: さんざん泣いた挙げ句、彼女は眠ってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After crying a lot she fell asleep.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 数回追い越した挙げ句に、ドライバーはガードレールにぶつかってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After overtaking a few times, the driver hit the guardrail.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お酒を飲んで泥酔した挙げ句に、財布を盗られた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After drinking alcohol and getting drunk, I had my wallet stolen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: さんざん考えた挙げ句に親の意に反して大学を辞めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After considering it thoughtfully I have quit university against wishes of my parents.

Name: 切(き)っ掛(か)け
Meaning: Lead to, Because of, As a start or trigger of, An opportunity
About: きっかけ 'chance', or 切(き)っ掛(か)け in its kanji form is a noun in Japanese that expresses when the trigger of (A) led to (B). It is often translated simply as 'because of (A), (B)', 'with (A) as a trigger, (B)', or 'with the opportunity of (A), (B)'. きっかけ primarily appears in two different forms. (A) をきっかけに (B), or (A) がきっかけで (B). This grammar pattern may be seen either with verbs in their past-tense form or nouns. However, in the case of appearing after verbs, it will often be preceded by の or some other nominalizing structure like こと. In many cases, the trigger of (A) will have the effect of instigating a rather large change or new beginning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女とは、パーティーで会ったのをきっかけに付き合い始めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Meeting her at the party led us to start dating.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は入院をきっかけにタバコを止めることにしました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Getting hospitalized led me to stop smoking.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この音楽は有名な歌手がカバーしたのがきっかけで再び有名になった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This song became famous again because that famous singer made a cover of it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このゲームがきっかけで、プログラマーになる事ができた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This game led me to become a programmer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 木から落ちたのをきっかけに、両腕を骨折した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a result of falling from a tree, I broke both of my arms. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 相手チームのエラーを切っ掛けに、逆転して勝った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The opposing team's mistake triggered the turnaround and we won.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: クモに刺されたのを切っ掛けとして、彼はスーパーヒーローになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Being bitten by a spider has led him to become a superhero.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: オランダで自転車が普及するようになったのは、オイルショックが切っ掛けである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The popularization of bicycles in the Netherlands was triggered by the oil crisis.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の母はスモーカーだったけど、電子たばこを贈ってあげたのを切っ掛けに、止めてくれた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My mother used to be a smoker, but gifting her an e-cigarette led to her stopping.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サラエボ事件を切っ掛けにして、１９１４年から１９１８年にかけて、後に世界大戦と呼ばれるようになった戦争が起きた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: With the incident in Sarajevo as a trigger, a war that lasted from 1914 to 1918 broke out and was later called a world war.

Name: にかけては
Meaning: When it comes to, Regarding, Concerning
About: When に is combined with the て-form of the る-Verb 掛(か)ける 'to hang' or 'to suspend' and は, a common phrase meaning 'when it comes to (A), (B)', or 'regarding (A), (B)' is created. (A) にかけては (B) is used to express that within a certain field or domain, (B) is the best, or has a distinct advantage. This expression will be seen following a noun expressing the 'field' that is being discussed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大工の技術にかけては彼が一番だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When it comes to carpentry skills, he is the best.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はゲームは下手だけど、スポーツにかけては誰にも負けない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am bad at video games, but when it comes to sports, I won't lose to anyone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのスマホは機能にかけては、他のスマホとは比べ物にはならないほどいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are no other smartphones that can compare to this one when it comes to features.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩の歌唱力にかけては、社内で一番下手だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My senpai is the worst in the company when it comes to singing. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 朝から夕方にかけて肉をゆっくりと煮込んだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I slow-cooked the meat from morning to night.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ＲＰＧゲームをすることにかけては誰にも負けない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When it comes to playing RPG games, I won't lose to anyone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 格闘にかけてはリュ◯の右に出る者はいない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When it comes to hand to hand fighting, there is no one superior to Ry*.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 算数にかけてはあの子がうちのクラスでトップだと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When it comes to math, I think that child is the top in my class.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 香水にかけては彼女が一番詳しいと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When it comes to perfume, I think she is the most well versed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: クーラーの掃除にかけてはあの会社が一番だと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When it comes to cleaning air conditioners, that company is number one, I think.

Name: 疾(と)っくに
Meaning: Already, A long time ago, Long ago
About: 疾(と)っくに, seen primarily as とっくに, is an adverb that can be translated roughly as 'long ago'. This word is an emphasized version of 疾(と)うに, a literary form which is not used much in modern Japanese. とっくに is a sentence altering adverb, so will appear most often at the beginning of sentences, or before the verb it is describing as having happened a long time ago. When compared with structures like すでに and もう, とっくに will either indicate something that has happened much further in the past, or may be used simply for exaggeration.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: とっくに食べちゃったよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I already ate.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もうとっくに寝る時間じゃん、まだ宿題も始めてないのに...どうしよう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is already time to sleep. I haven't even started my homework… What should I do?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 提出期限はとっくに過ぎているのでやってもやらなくても関係がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The due date has long since passed, so it won't matter if I do it or not.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遅いぞ！みんなはもうとっくに帰ってるぞ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are late! Everyone has already gone home ages ago!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんな事は言われなくてもとっくに知ってるよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was aware of this well in the past, so no need to tell me!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「バス？疾っくに行っちゃったよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'The bus? It has already left.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「お前は疾っくに死んでいる。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'You are already long dead.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「うちの子は疾っくに歩けるようになった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Our child has already developed the ability to walk!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「魔王と勇者の栄光時代は疾っくに過ぎた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'The golden era of heroes and demon kings has already passed.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「よく寝るために、暗号通貨から疾っくに撤退した。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'In order to sleep well, I have already pulled out of cryptocurrency.'

Name: 未(いま)だに
Meaning: Still, Not yet, Even now
About: Although stemming from the same kanji, まだ 'still' will almost always be read as 未(いま)だ 'still' when appearing in its kanji form. When combined with に, like まだ, 未(いま)だ will indicate that something is 'still (A)', or 'not yet (A)', depending on whether the verb it is paired with is negated or not. As 未(いま)だに will be used adverbially, it will mostly appear at the beginning of sentences. Compared to まだ, 未(いま)だに is more formal, and will often imply that something has been continuing for a much longer period of time. This is similar to adding the word ずっと to a standard sentence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: スマホが普及している中、未だにガラケーを使っている人がいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While smartphones are becoming more and more popular, there are people who still use flip phones.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が子供の頃に巻き込まれた事故のことは未だに覚えている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I still remember the accident that I was involved in when I was a child.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部長は人事に注意されて２ヶ月も経つのに、彼の態度は未だに変わらない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's been two months since the director was warned by HR and his attitude still hasn't changed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 去年行方不明になった少女は未だに発見されていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The girl who went missing last year has still not been found.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 小学生の頃、高橋くんにいじめられたことをまだ根に持っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am still holding a grudge over the fact that I was bullied by Takahashi-kun when I was in elementary school.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 小学生の頃、高橋くんにいじめられたことを未だに根に持っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am still holding a grudge over the fact that I was bullied by Takahashi-kun when I was in elementary school.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説、語り手：「そのようなことが起こったとは、未だに信じられない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Narrator: 'I still cannot believe that such a thing happened.' (not yet・even now)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 歴史書：「未だにクロサキマサキ氏の死に関して不明な点が多い。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: History book: 'There are still many unknowns concerning the death of Masaki Kurosaki.' (not yet・even now)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説、語り手：「未だに俺は、なぜ彼女があんなにも怒っていたのか、よくわからない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A novel, the narrator: 'I still don't really know why she got so mad.' (not yet・even now)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 苦情の内容：「購入してから三週間経ったものの未だに商品が届いていません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Letter of complaint: 'Even though it has been three weeks since I made my purchase, the goods haven't arrived yet.' (not yet・even now・still)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「専門家は未だに伝説上の街の位置を巡り論争している。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'Even now experts dispute the location of the legendary city.' (not yet・still)

Name: を元(もと)に
Meaning: Based on, From, According to
About: When linked to a noun, を元(もと)に is an expression that indicates that something is 'based on (A)', 'from (A)', or 'according to (A)'. This is a combination of を, the noun 元(もと) 'origin', and に. The literal meaning is similar to 'with (A) as the origin, (B)', and is used primarily to reference a source from which something is created or started. Most of the time, をもとに will be written without kanji, but it is also possible to see it as を元(もと)に. As this grammar pattern is mainly used to highlight an origin of creation, it will often be seen in sentences that use verbs like 書(か)く 'to write', できる 'to be able', and 作(つく)る 'to make'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このドラマは実際に起こったことをもとに作られたそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Apparently, this TV show was created based on actual events.
