AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 研究の結果をもとにレポートを書いてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please write a report based on the results of the research.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はこのデータをもとにこのグラフを作成しました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I created this graph based on this data.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は法律に基づいて処分されるだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He will be receiving punishment according to the law.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は法律をもとに処分されるだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He will be punished based on the law.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これはクックパッドを元に作ったうどんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is udon made according to Cookpad.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このインタビューを元に記事を書いてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please write an article based on this interview.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 息子の足跡を元に後を追った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I pursued my son based on his footprints.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電話帳を元に宛名を書いてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please write the name and address according to the telephone book.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんな主観を元に恨まれても困るよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you feel bitter about it based on that personal opinion, I will not be thrilled.

Name: からには
Meaning: As long as, Since, Given
About: からには is an expression in Japanese that is used to indicate when something is either obvious or determined upon based on the previous information. This may translate as 'as long as (A), (B)', 'since (A), (B)', or 'given that (A), (B)'. It is a combination of から, に, and は, and literally means something like 'from within (A), (B)'. からには may follow any word in their standard forms, but occasionally also follows nouns or な-Adjectives that end with である. からには focuses mainly on the determination of the speaker that (A) is something that is the 'base' state (emphasized with には), so going from that point (emphasized with から) is either unavoidable, or the most logical. The second part of the sentence will then make some statement about that determination. This may either be a personal opinion about the situation, or what the speaker intends to do about it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 沖縄に来たからには、一番綺麗なビーチへ行きたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I am in Okinawa, I want to go to the prettiest beach.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高いスマホを買ったからには、様々な機能を使いこなさなければならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Given that I bought an expensive smartphone, I need to make the most of its various features.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 有名になったからには、その影響力を良い方向に使いたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Given that I have become famous, I want to use that influence in a positive course.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 兄弟として生まれたからには、お互いに助け合うつもりだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since we were born as siblings, we intend to help each other out.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 教師であるからは、生徒の手本となるべし。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As long as you are a teacher, you must be an example to your students.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本に住むからは、日本語を勉強するべきだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As long as I am living in Japan, I must study Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 二十歳になるからには、ドライブしに行こう！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since I will be turning 20, let's go for a drive!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: インタビューをするからには、本音を聞き出したい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since we are doing an interview, I want to get their true opinion.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 休業するからには、事前の説明をきちんとしてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As long as you are going to shutdown your business, please give a precise explanation in advance.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 行事を任されたからには、絶対に成功させます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since I was entrusted with the event, I will definitely make it a success.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 演劇をやるからには、まずは発声練習が大切です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since you will be performing, to start, speaking practice is important.

Name: いつの間(ま)にか
Meaning: Suddenly, Unnoticed, Without noticing, Too soon
About: Although a combination of いつ 'when', の, 間(ま) 'interval', に, and か; いつの間(ま)にか is a set expression that is used as a stand-alone adverb to mean 'suddenly', or 'without noticing'. Literally, it just highlights an unknown interval within which something occurred, as seen by the question marking particle, か.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ３年間日本人の友達と毎日日本語で話していたら、いつの間にか日本語が上手になっていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After three years of speaking Japanese every day with my Japanese friend, I became fluent in Japanese without noticing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 久しぶりにクレジットカードの明細を確認してみたら、いつの間にか自動車保険の値段が上がっていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I checked my credit card statement for the first time in a while and found that the price of my car insurance had suddenly gone up.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 気づいたら、いつの間にか冬になっていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Before I knew it, it was winter.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 楽しいことをしているとあっという間に時間が過ぎるよね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Time flies when you're having fun, doesn't it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: オレはみんなからいつの間にかポチと呼ばれるようになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Without noticing they have come to call me 'Pochi.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつの間にかもう１年が経ってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Without me realizing it, another year has passed (all too soon).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「いつの間にか彼女はネイティブみたいに話せるようになった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Without me realizing, her speaking has grown to that of a native.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 帽子を被ってないといつの間にか風邪を引く。だからきちんと帽子を被って。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you do not wear a hat, you will catch a cold before you know it. That's why you should put on a hat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたの子供から目を離せばいつの間にか迷子になるかもしれない。ご注意ください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you take your eyes off of your child, they might get lost without you even noticing. Please be careful.

Name: 一旦(いったん)
Meaning: Once …, If … for a short time, Temporarily (stop), For now or the time being
About: 一旦(いったん), an adverb meaning 'for a short time', or 'briefly', is a structure that is used in Japanese to indicate that 'once (A), (B)'. This particular meaning comes from the inclusion of hypothetical structures such as ば, と, or たら, and will usually appear with a negated verb in the (B) part of a sentence. 一旦(いったん) based sentences will indicate that returning to the previous state will be difficult, at least for a short time. Other common translations include 'for the time being', and 'for now'. 一旦(いったん) will primarily appear at the beginning of sentences, or directly before a ば, と, or たら modified verb.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一旦再起動をすれば、もとに戻るはずです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Once the system is rebooted, it should return to normal.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 娘は一旦泣き出したら、しばらく泣き止まないので大変です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Once my daughter starts crying, she wont stop for a while, so it can get hard.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一旦集中力が切れてしまうと、再び集中するのに時間がかかる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Once I lose focus, it takes me a while to regain my focus.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一旦これをしたら残りをＡさんに任せてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once you do this, please leave the rest to A-san.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一旦勉強し始めたら、すべて知りたいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once I start learning, I want to know everything (about what I am learning).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一旦機械の電源がはいるとなかなかとまらない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once this machine is turned on, it won't be easily stopped.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一旦一戸建てに住めばアパートに戻れない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once you live in a stand-alone house, you won't be able to go back to an apartment.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一旦何かを学ぶのを止めると再開しにくくなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once you stop learning something, starting again becomes hard.

Name: は元(もと)より
Meaning: Not only... but also, Let alone, Of course,
About: は元(もと)より, commonly seen purely in hiragana, is a grammar pattern that indicates 'not only (A), but also (B) ', or 'let alone (A), (B)'. This construction is just a combination of は, the noun 元(もと) 'origin', and より. In this way, it is just highlighting that 'even compared to the original fact of (A), (B)'. Often, (A) will be something that is considered obvious, or the most well known information in regard to the topic. はもとより may appear after nouns, or verb phrases that have been nominalized with の or こと. Alternatively, はもとより may be used in structures where it is simply showing that (A) is the base from which (B) is also a fact. Although this may sound similar to the previous meaning, it translates closer to 'from the start, (A) is (B)', or 'by nature, (A) is (B)'. Which meaning is being used will usually be clear in the context of the overall sentence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この商店街は地元の人はもとより、全国からの観光客で賑わっています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This shopping street is crowded with not only locals, but also tourists from all over the country.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近の車は自動運転はもとより、自動駐車もできるそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They say that modern cars can not only drive automatically, but also park automatically.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この学校では日本語が上手になることはもとより、日本でのマナーや文化を理解できる授業が行われています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The school offers classes that not only help students become proficient in Japanese, but also give them an understanding of Japanese manners and culture.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このテストはもとより、合格できるとは思っていなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I did not think that I could pass this test from the start.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 親は自分の子供を守るのはもとより、何不自由ない生活をしてほしいと思っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Parents want not only to protect their children, but also want them to live a comfortable life.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 失敗はもとより、もっと酷くなることを覚悟していたから、そんなに悔しくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let alone failure, because I was prepared for it to get even worse, I'm not that disappointed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 速く走るのは元より経済的でもある車を買いたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not only a fast one, but I want to buy a car that's also economical.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 最近ではコンピューターやスマホは元より、歯ブラシさえＷＩＦＩを備えている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Recently, not only computers and smartphones, but even toothbrushes are equipped with wifi.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 英語はイギリスやアメリカの母国語としては元より台湾でも使われている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: English is not only the native language of England and the US, but it is even used in Taiwan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 我が社が製造する棒茶は日本全国は元より、海外でもよく売られている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The twig tea manufactured in our company is not only sold all over Japan, but also abroad.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アニメや漫画は子供は元より大人や老人の関心も集める。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Anime and manga attract not only children, but also adults and the elderly.

Name: そうにない
Meaning: Unlikely to, Showing no signs of
About: Compared to そうもない 'very unlikely to (A)', そうにない is a grammar structure that has a very similar meaning, but is not quite as emphasized. In this expression, も will be replaced with に. Also, apart from indicating that something is very unlikely, it may also indicate that something is showing 'no signs of (A)'.  Occasionally, そうにもない may also appear, and has the strongest nuance of being unlikely to happen amongst そうにない, そうもない, and そうにもない. Note that the only difference between these three structures is the addition, subtraction, or combination of the に and も particles. As this structure is just an extension of the use of the auxiliary verb そう (used primarily for speculation, or hearsay), it is simply indicating that (A) does not have any appearance of occuring.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ごめん、定時で上がれそうにないから先に食べてて。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sorry, it seems unlikely that I can leave work on time, so go ahead and eat without me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は行けそうにないのでキャンセルでお願いします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is unlikely that I am going to be able to make it today, so please cancel my appointment.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は雨が降りそうにもないから釣りに行こう！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is unlikely that it will rain today, so let's go fishing!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 列が進みそうにもないのでまた今度来ましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The queue is showing no signs of moving so let's come back another time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日雪は降りそうにない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is unlikely that it will snow tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このストーブでは、いつまでたっても暖まりそうにない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This stove is showing no signs of warming up, no matter how much time is allotted.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は荷物を受け取れそうにない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is unlikely that I will be able to get my luggage today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ２回連続で宝くじには当たりそうにない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is unlikely you will win the lottery two times in a row.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 偉大すぎて、父を追い越せそうにない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Being so great, it is unlikely that I will be able to surpass my father.

Name: に反(はん)して
Meaning: Go against, Contrary to
About: に反(はん)して, a combination of に and the て-form of 反(はん)する 'to oppose', or 'to go against', is a construction in Japanese that is used to present counter opinions or arguments in relation to the previous statement. Common translations include 'contrary to (A), (B)', and 'going against (A), (B)'. に反(はん)して will appear after nouns, before expressing some opposing or contrasting point. Alternatively, に反(はん)する may be used when directly modifying the following noun. Unlike に対(たい)して, に反(はん)して will often be used when a prediction does not match the actual reality of a situation. に反(はん)して is a fairly formal grammar pattern, so will be found mostly in literature, official documents, or speeches.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼らは会社のルールに反して交際をしているらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that they are dating, which goes against the company rules.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 予想に反してクライアントの反応がいまいちだったので、最初からやり直さなきゃいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Contrary to our expectations, the client's response was not good, so we had to start over from the beginning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は上司の指示に反することはできません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I cannot do anything that goes against my supervisor's instructions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 予想に反して早く終える事ができた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Contrary to our expectations, we were able to finish early. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 予想に対して早く終える事ができた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Contrary to our expectations, we were able to finish early. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 神様の教えに反するようなことをしてはいけません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot do things that go against God's doctrine.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は法律に反して、大学に裏口入学した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Going against the law, he bought his way into university.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うちのチームは予想に反して、 昨年優勝したチームに勝ったよ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Contrary to expectations, our team beat the team that won the race last year!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: モラルに反してまで成り上がった彼を、羨ましいとは思いません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am not envious of he, who even went against morality to move up in the world.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 予想に反してものすごい売行きで、社員一同驚いている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Contrary to expectations there was a huge (sales) demand, surprising all of the staff.

Name: 逆(ぎゃく)に
Meaning: On the contrary
About: 逆(ぎゃく)に is a grammar pattern that indicates that something is 'contrary' to what has previously been said. This is a structure made up of the noun 逆(ぎゃく) 'reverse', 'opposite', or 'converse', and に. Due to the inclusion of に, this phrase behaves adverbially, and will usually appear between two phrases, to indicate that 'on the contrary to (A), (B)', or 'conversely to (A), (B)'. In modern Japanese, 逆(ぎゃく)に is also frequently used at the beginning of a sentence, simply to indicate a rebuttal toward something that someone has just said, or as a slang version of 別(べつ)に when asked questions about preferences, or similar things.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 手袋をはめた方が安全だと思うかもしれませんが、手袋が回転部に巻き込まれると逆に危険なので、手袋を外してから作業をしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You may think it is safer to wear gloves, but on the contrary, it is dangerous because they could get caught in the rotating parts. So, please remove your gloves before working.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 近道だと思っていたのに、地図アプリで調べてみたら逆に回り道だった事がわかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I thought that it was a shortcut, but on the contrary, I found out that it was actually a detour when I checked on a map app.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 食べやすいようにスパゲティを半分にして茹でたけど、逆に食べにくくなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I broke the spaghetti in half to make it easier to eat, but on the contrary, it made it harder to eat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 逆に、何歳に見えますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the contrary, how old do I look?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 逆に、ラーメンは？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't care too much what we eat, how about ramen?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの話は事実らしいが、逆に信じにくい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that that story is true but on the contrary, it is hard to believe.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 親切で声をかけたのに、逆に苦情を言われた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though I called out to him in a gentle voice, on the contrary he complained.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遅刻になると思って、急いだが逆に余裕でした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I thought that I would be late and hurried, but on the contrary, I made it with plenty of time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: クレーム対応をしっかりしたら、逆に売上げが伸びました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I dealt with the complaint firmly (assuming there would be a negative impact), on the contrary my sales increased.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寒いと思って厚着をして行ったら、逆に暑かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I thought it was cold and went wearing thick clothing. On the contrary, it was hot.

Name: 反面(はんめん)
Meaning: While, On the other hand, Although, However, On the flip side
About: 反面(はんめん), a noun meaning 'the opposing side', is a construction in Japanese that appears between two phrases, to show two contrasting or opposite features of a single person or thing. This usually translates as 'while (A), (B)', 'although (A), also (B)', 'on the other hand to (A), (B)'. Being a noun, 反面(はんめん), can be used after any word that could create a modified noun, such as verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives, or even other nouns followed by である.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 都内に引っ越して色々と便利になった反面、家賃が前住んでいた所の倍になった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While moving to Tokyo has made many things more convenient, the rent has doubled from where I used to live.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カリフォルニアの夏は日本より暑い反面、湿度が低いので過ごしやすいそうです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although summer in California is hotter than Japan, I heard that it is more comfortable because of the low humidity.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの日本語教室の先生達は日本語を教えるのがとても上手な反面、生徒達にはとても厳しいそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although the teachers at that Japanese language school are very good at teaching Japanese, they are very strict with their students.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中くんはとても頭のいい子である反面、怠け者なのでいつも先生に怒られています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although Tanaka-kun is very smart, he is always getting scolded by the teacher because he is lazy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのパティシエが作るお菓子はとても美味しそうに見える反面、食べてみると味はいまいちだそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While the pastries made by that pastry chef look very tasty, the taste is not so good when you try them. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのパティシエが作るお菓子はとても美味しそうに見える反面、とても美味しいそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While the pastries made by that pastry chef look very tasty, apparently, they taste very good. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 商品が豪華である反面、参加費が高額だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While the products may be luxurious, the participation fee is high.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は慎重な反面、消極的なところがあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is cautious, but on the other hand, he also has a passive side.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一人暮らしは楽しい反面、自分で料理したり掃除したりする必要もある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While living alone is fun, it is also necessary for you to do all the cooking, cleaning, and the like.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 厳しいトレーニングを積むと筋力はつく反面、風邪をひきやすくなるらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Relentlessly training builds physical strength, on the other hand, I seem to become more susceptible to catching a cold.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 消防署が近くにあると安心できる反面、夜中にサイレンがなるから大変だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Being close to the fire station gives a sense of safety, on the other hand, since sirens go off in the middle of the night, it can be troublesome.

Name: 抜(ぬ)く
Meaning: All~, Completely, See through, Overcome, To the bitter end
About: When connected to the ます-stem of another verb, the う-Verb 抜(ぬ)く 'to extract' is often used to indicate that (A) has happened 'completely'. This 'extract' nuance frequently indicates that beyond completion, (A) has been 'overcome', or 'seen through to the bitter end'. The literal meaning of 抜(ぬ)く can be thought of as being quite close to the English expression 'to pull through', for example, 'despite difficulties, I pulled through in the end'. Let's look at a few examples of where 抜(ぬ)く will be used. Alternatively, 抜(ぬ)く may be used in situations where (A) is something that is done to a very deep or substantial degree. This nuance is less like 'to pull through', and closer to 'thoroughly', or simply 'deeply'. This meaning tends to appear with verbs that don't have an obvious end, like 知(し)る 'to know'. Despite this nuance seeming different, the verb with 抜(ぬ)く attached to it in these types of sentences is usually considered to have already been done to a 'finished' degree, where there is nothing left beyond that point. With the example of 'to know', it would mean 'to know every single little detail'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の計画は彼に見抜かれていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He saw through my plans.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自分の子供達を守り抜くためならなんでもできる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I could do anything to protect my kids till the end.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は何があっても最後までやり抜かないと気が済まないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't have peace of mind until I finish something completely, no matter what happens.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 考え抜いた結果、俺は大学を中退して親父の会社を継ぐことにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After thoroughly thinking about it, I decided to drop out of college and take over my father's company.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中師匠は俳句の事なら知り抜いている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Master Tanaka is all-knowing when it comes to haiku.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この洗濯機ではこの量の洗濯物は洗いぬけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This washing machine cannot completely wash this amount of laundry. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この洗濯機ではこの量の洗濯物は洗い切れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This washing machine cannot completely wash this amount of laundry. (Natural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ウォルターさんは化学のことなら知り抜いている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Walter-san is all-knowing when it comes to chemistry. (completely)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 木材に刺さった釘を引き抜く。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To completely pull out the nails in the lumber.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 徹夜してでも、このプロジェクトをやり抜きたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if I have to sit up all night, I want to complete this project.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は漁師として人生を生き抜いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He lived life completely as a fisherman.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 真の友というのなら、信じ抜く心が必要だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If they are a true friend, they need to have a heart that you can completely believe in.

Name: 抜(ぬ)きで
Meaning: Without, Unless
About: 抜(ぬ)きで, a combination of the noun form of the う-Verb 抜(ぬ)く 'to extract', and the particle で, is a construction that usually indicates something being done 'without (A)', or 'with the removal of (A)'. As ぬき indicates the extraction of something, this grammar pattern is primarily used to indicate 'leaving out', or 'setting aside' something that is regularly included. 抜(ぬ)きで acts as a suffix, so will be utilized after nouns, to indicate the thing that is being left out. Both the plain hiragana and kanji forms are fairly common. Additionally, の will replace で when ぬき is followed directly by another noun. Occasionally, にして may also replace で, but this is structure is more common when the part (B) section of the sentence includes a ない or できない based statement. These expressions indicate that something 'will not happen without (A)', or 'is not possible without (A)'. However; this is not always the case, as ぬきで or ぬきでは may also appear in negative sentences, with the same meaning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は冗談抜きで怖いから怒らせない方がいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That guy is scary, no joke, so you shouldn't upset him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あいつら全然来ないな、あいつら抜きで始めちゃおうぜ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They aren't coming at all (it doesn't seem like they are coming anytime soon). Let's start without them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ワサビ抜きの寿司なんて寿司じゃないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sushi without wasabi is not sushi.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 若い労働者抜きにしては、日本の建築業は成り立たない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Without young workers, Japan's construction industry would not exist.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 公共交通機関抜きにしては便利な生活ができない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Without public transportation, you cannot live a convenient life.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: リスク抜きには決してフグを食べられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You can never eat fugu without risk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「クソ、渋滞だ。あいつら、パーティーをオレ抜きで始めそうだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Damn, a traffic jam. It seems that they will start the party without me.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「食べれる」のような「ら」抜きの言葉は人気になっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Words without 'ら', like '食べれる' are getting more popular.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: Ｃ：「ＡとＢは付き合ってんのよ」Ｄ：「マジ！？冗談抜きで？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: C: 'A and B are dating!' D: 'Whaa? No kidding? (without joking)'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夫婦の会話：「子供抜きでどこか面白いところに行こう！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A conversation between a married couple: 'Let's go somewhere fun, without the children!'

Name: 愈々(いよいよ)
Meaning: At last, Finally, More and more
About: 愈々(いよいよ), seen primarily in hiragana, is an adverb that indicates that (A) has or will 'finally happen'. In many cases this is after some state that has been continuing for a long time, or has been compounding further and further until (A). Like many other sentence altering adverbs, いよいよ will appear at the beginning of a phrase. It is also considered quite casual when compared to other grammar points like ついに. As いよいよ highlights something that is compounding, it can also frequently be translated as 'more and more'. The difference between the nuance of いよいよ being 'finally' or 'more and more' will usually be clear due to the statement following it being either conclusive (finally), or inconclusive (more and more).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いよいよ明日で卒業か...。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tomorrow is finally our graduation, isn't it…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いよいよ俺の番だ。緊張するけど頑張らなくちゃ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is finally my turn. I am nervous, but I must do my best!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 台風が接近するにつれて、いよいよ風が強くなってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As the typhoon approached, the wind started to blow more and more.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の話を聞いていると彼がいよいよ怪しくなってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Listening to his story makes him more and more suspicious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 愈々春がやって来た。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Spring has finally arrived.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: じゃ、愈々俺の番だ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Finally, it's my turn.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 愈々夏休みが始まった！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Summer vacation has finally begun!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 愈々大学を卒業する！
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have finally graduated college!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 愈々ステージが始まる。わくわくしてきた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The performance will finally start. I am getting excited.

Name: ずに済(す)む
Meaning: Get by without doing something, To get away with
About: ずに済(す)む is a grammar construction used in Japanese to indicate that one can 'get away without doing (A)', or 'it's no problem without (A)'. This structure is just a mix of ず, a literary auxiliary verb that attaches to verbs in the same way as ない (and has the same meaning), に, and 済(す)む, a う-Verb meaning 'to come to pass', or 'to end up'. Literally, it can be thought of as meaning 'it will work out without (A)'. As mentioned, ず connects to verbs in the same way as ない, so this structure will be seen after the verbs that they are negating. As the primary element in this grammar point that controls the meaning is 済(す)む, other negations such as ないですむ, or なしですむ may also be seen. 無(な)しで functions as a suffix, so may be used directly after nouns, unlike ないで and ずに. In most cases, (A) will be something that is thought of as unpleasant or bothersome, therefore highlighting the speaker's relief that it can be avoided.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今宿題をやっておけば後でやらずに済むから、今のうちにやっておこう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I do my homework now, I can get by without doing it later, so I shall do it right now.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このＶＩＰパスを使えば待たずに済みます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you have this VIP pass, you can get by without waiting.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今月契約すると初期費用を支払わないで済むので、今月中に契約することをお勧めします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We recommend that you sign the contract within this month so that you can get by without paying the initial cost.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年の冬は去年より暖かかったので、ヒーターなしで済みました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since winter this year was warmer than last year, I got by without using the heater.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 洗い物をせずに済む。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To get away with not doing the dishes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 事故が起こったけど、怪我をせずに済んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: An accident occurred, but I got away without getting injured.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 犯人は警察から、捕まらずに済んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The criminal got away without being arrested by the police.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 基礎からトレーニングを積んでいたから、潰れずに済んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I built my training up from the foundation, I got by without being crushed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ちゃんとペース配分したから、体力を消耗せずに済んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I properly paced myself, I got by without exhausting my physical strength.

Name: に応(おう)じて
Meaning: Depending or based on, According to, In response to, Suitable for or to
About: に応(おう)じて is a combination of に, and the て-form of the る-Verb 応(おう)じる 'to apply to'. This grammar structure is often translated as 'depending on (A), (B)', or 'in response to (A), (B)'. However; in almost all cases, it is just indicating that (B) is something that is done in a way that is 'applicable' to what is necessary of (A). に応(おう)じて will appear after nouns, or as に応(おう)じた when directly modifying a second noun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語を教える際には、生徒達のレベルに応じてクラスを分ける必要があります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When teaching Japanese, it is necessary to divide classes according to the level of the students.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この地域の土地は、面積に応じて値段が高くなります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Land in this area is priced according to its surface area.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私たちはクライアントの要望に応じたデザインを提供しています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We provide designs that meet our clients' requests.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ジムでは実力に応じて、練習を選べるべきだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At the gym, you should choose exercises suitable to your ability. (in response to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 赤ん坊のために年齢に応じたダイエットが必要です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For a toddler, it is necessary to have a diet that is suitable for their age.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私共のホテルではＶＩＰレベルのニーズに応じたサービスをご提供いたします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In our hotel, we offer services suitable for VIP needs. (in response to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本人は相手への尊敬度に応じて、お辞儀の角度を変える。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The Japanese change the angle of their bow, depending on the degree of respect for the other party. (in response to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 警察官は状態や必要に応じて暴力を行使できる場合もあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In some cases, policemen can use force depending on circumstances or necessity. (in response to)

Name: を通(つう)じて
Meaning: Through, Via, Throughout
About: を通(つう)じて and を通(とお)して are two grammar patterns in Japanese that have very similar meanings to each other, and are used in many overlapping situations. Primarily, they can be thought of as meaning 'through (A), (B)', or 'via (A), (B)'. This 'through' may either indicate a method, or a location. 通(つう)じる 'to flow', or 'to go through' and 通(とお)す 'to make a path', only differ in that the former is intransitive, while the latter is transitive. Because of this, 通(つう)じる will be seen more often in regard to information or communication where (A) is the connection through which (B) occurs. 通(とお)す on the other hand more often refers to direct locations through which something is transferred or relocated. As this expression begins with を, it will appear after nouns, before expressing in the (B) part of the sentence exactly what was done 'through' (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その事件はネットニュースを通じて知りました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I learned about that incident through online news.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はアニメを通じて日本語を学んだそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that he learned Japanese through anime.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 語学留学を通して日本の文化などを学びました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I learned about Japanese culture and other aspects of Japan through language study.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事を通して今の妻と出会いました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I met my current wife through work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ロシアには年間を通じて寒い村があるらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that there is a town in Russia that is cold throughout the year. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 事故にあった際には弁護士を通じて相手に連絡をするようにしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are involved in an accident, you should contact the other party through your attorney. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 事故にあった際には弁護士を通して相手に連絡をするようにしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are involved in an accident, you should contact the other party through your attorney. (Natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ロシアには年間を通して寒い村があるらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that there is a town in Russia that is cold throughout the year. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このプロジェクトを通じて多くのことを学んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have learned a lot through participating in this project.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 看病を通して人の愛を知りました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Through nursing a patient, I came to know human affection.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 叔父さんを通して仕事の依頼がきた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Through my uncle, I got a job commision.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 打合せを通して新たな発見をすることもよくある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are many new discoveries made through business meetings.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 植木を通して自然の尊さを学びました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I learned the nobility of nature through planting.

Name: に応(こた)えて
Meaning: In response to, Meet
About: にこたえて is a construction formed from に, and the て-form of the る-Verb 応(こた)える. It is often translated as 'to meet (A)', or 'in response to (A)'. Like に応(おう)じて 'to apply to', にこたえて indicates that (B) is something that will change based on what is considered necessary, suitable, or appropriate on a case-by-case basis when it comes to (A). にこたえて often appears in hiragana alone, and will attach to the end of nouns that it is marking as the (A) that something being done in response to. Alternatively, にこたえる will be used when connected directly to a second noun. In many cases, (A) will indicate a request, wish, or expectation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 生徒達の要望に応えて、レッスン料金を１０００円安くした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In response to our students' request, we have reduced the lesson fee by 1,000 yen.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: クライアントのリクエストに応えて、デザインを少しだけ変えました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We changed the design slightly in response to the client's request.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 弊社ではお客様のニーズに応えるサービスを提供するよう、日々努力しています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We are committed to providing services that meet the needs of our clients.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたの要望に応える自信はありますが、このデザインを完成させるには時間がかかると思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We are confident we can meet your request, but it will take time to complete this design.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 応援の声に応えて、勝利したチームが礼をした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In response to the cheering, the victorious team bowed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 選手の活躍に応えて、トレー二ングルームを新しくした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In response to the athletes' great efforts, we remodeled the training room.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アイドル歌手の喝采に応えた笑顔が素晴らしかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The idol singer's smile in response to the applause was wonderful.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 我が社はクライアントのニーズに応えた商品を開発するべきだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Our company should develop products that respond to our clients' needs.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 演劇人気に応えて建てた劇場の維持費が大変だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The maintenance cost for the theater built in response to the popularity of plays is enormous.

Name: それとも
Meaning: Or, Or else, Rather
About: それとも is a conjunction in Japanese that may be translated as 'or', or 'otherwise'. It is used to highlight alternative options or choices between (A) and (B). それとも is a combination of それ, and the particles と, and も. This grammar structure will only be used when the options are limited to either (A), or (B). それとも will appear either after a comma, or at the beginning of new sentences. In many cases, (A) and (B) will be opposites of each other. However, this is not a requirement for using それとも.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は文法の勉強をしますか。それとも漢字の勉強をしますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you want to study grammar today? Or rather, do you want to study Kanji?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来週はどこに行きたい？動物園に行く？それとも家でゆっくりする？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Where do you want to go next week? Do you want to go to the zoo? Or rather do you want to relax at home?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は海に行こうか、それとも川に行こうか、迷うな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't know whether to go to the ocean or the river today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: クレジットカードで払う？それとも現金で？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Are you paying with a credit card? Or rather, in cash?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 苦情を言うべきか、それとも我慢すべきか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Should we complain? Or rather, should we persevere?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今夜はカラオケに行く？それとも映画館？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Are you going to karaoke tonight? Or rather, to the cinema?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたの大学は国立？それとも私立？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is your university a national one, or rather a private one?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 生きるべきか、それとも死ぬべきか。それが問題だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To live, or to die. That is the question.

Name: にしたら
Meaning: From the point of view of
About: When に is combined with the hypothetical forms of する (すれば, or したら), it forms a structure used in Japanese for conveying that the speaker is making an opinion about (A), from its point of view. This is frequently translated as 'from the point of view of (A)', or 'from the standpoint of (A)'. Literally, it means something close to 'if we go off (A)', and just highlights that the speaker is choosing a particular aspect of (A) to discuss as a possibility. In many cases, the (B) part of にしたら or にすれば expressions will be an opinion about what the speaker expects to be true for (A). にしたら and にすれば are structures that will be used after nouns that identify people or organizations, from which the speaker will then make an assumption about them/it. Although almost identical in meaning, にすれば will be the preferred choice in formal sentences.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客様にしたら、値段が安い方がいいだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the point of view of the customer, a lower price is probably better.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 納豆が嫌いな人にしたら、納豆はただ臭いだけに違いない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the point of view of a person that does not like natto, natto must just stink (natto is something that stinks and nothing more).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供が何歳になろうとも、親にすればいつまでも子供に見える。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the parent's point of view, their children look like kids no matter how old they are.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本人にすれば普通なことでも、海外の方が見たら驚く事がたくさんあるらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems that there are many things that are ordinary from the point of view of Japanese people that are surprising to people from other countries.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私にしたら、それは高すぎます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Going off of me, that is too expensive. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼にしたら、それは高すぎるそうです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Going off of him, apparently that is too expensive. (Natural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 妻にしたら、私はもっと家事をしなくてはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the perspective of my wife, I have to help more with the house work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 赤ちゃんは可愛いが、親にしたら苦労もあるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Babies are cute, but from a parent's point of view there are hardships as well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大人にしたら、童話は少し物足りない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the point of view of an adult, fairy-tales are somewhat unsatisfactory.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 床屋さんにしたら、散髪はアートのようなものなのかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the perspective of a barber, cutting hair is probably something like art.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人にしたら、僕の成功が憎らしくてたまらないのだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the point of view of that person, I imagine that he hates my success...

Name: にしても～にしても
Meaning: Regardless of whether
About: にしても, a grammar point consisting of に, the て-form of する, and も, is used to convey that 'regardless of (A) or (B), the result will still be (C)', or '(C) is true, regardless of either (A) or (B)'. While it is common for this grammar pattern to appear with the positive and negated versions of a verb in (A) and (B), it may actually be used with any verbs, nouns, or adjectives that are contrasting in some way. In many cases, ～にしても, ～にしろ, and ～にせよ will be completely interchangable. However, the latter ～にしろ and にせよ are more direct, so will be seen less in formal situations.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 忘年会に出席するにしても、しないにしても、参加費を払わないといけないのはおかしいと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think it is unfair that we need to pay the attendance fee for the year-end party regardless of whether we attend or not.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家を立て直すにしても、リフォームするにしても、費用は同じぐらいになりそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether the house is rebuilt or remodeled, the cost is likely to be about the same.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 水深が深いにしても、浅いにしても、ライフジャケットは着ておいた方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether the water is deep or shallow, you should wear a life jacket.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語が上手にしても、下手にしても、勉強は毎日しておいた方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether you are good or bad at Japanese, you should study every day.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 平日にしても祝日にしても、ディズニーランドは多くの人で賑わっています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Disneyland is crowded with people, regardless of whether it is a weekday or a holiday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 貸すにしても売るにしても、とにかく元を取れればそれでいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether you rent it out, or sell it, it is fine as long as I break even somehow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食べるにしても、食べないにしても、料理代を払わないといけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether you eat or not, you still have to pay for the food.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 貸家にしても、自宅にしても、家族がいるだけで十分。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether you own a house or rent one, as long as you have family, that is enough.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 簡単にしても、難しいにしても、宿題を終わらせるべきだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether the homework is easy or hard, you must finish it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 煮るにしても焼くにしても、素材の良さを活かした料理にしてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether you boil it or fry it, please make use of the quality of the raw materials.

Name: としては
Meaning: As a, For a, As for
About: Like として, a grammar point meaning 'as', としては functions as an extension of this, with the は particle merely emphasizing the (A) subject as a stand-alone entity that is about to be compared with something, or that the speaker is assuming the result of (B), from the standpoint of (A). としては may be translated as 'as (A)', or 'for an (A)'. (A) will frequently highlight a person or organization in cases where the speaker is making an assumption from that standpoint. This structure will be used after nouns, and is a combination of と, the て-form of する, and は. The literal translation is something similar to 'going off that (A) is (A), (B)'. In cases where the noun connected to としては is not a person or organization, the translation will often simply be 'as for'. In these sentences, としては is merely highlighting the broad topic of (A), before the speaker offers their thoughts about what applies to that topic. In contrast to にしては, としては is more frequently used to make broad judgements taking into consideration all aspects of (A), and what would usually be expected of (A), rather than for giving personal opinions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は先輩としてはいいけど、友達になろうとは思えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a senpai, he is a good person, but I don't think I would want to be friends with him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの会社は建築会社としてはホワイトな方だと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think that company is white as far as construction companies go.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アイデアとしてはいいんですが、実際にやるとなるとものすごい費用がかかると思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is good as an idea, but I think it would cost a tremendous amount of money to actually do it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ピアノは趣味としては好きだけど、ピアノで食べていこうとは思わない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like playing the piano as a hobby, but I don't want to make a living out of it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 概論としては、まだ不十分です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For an outline, it still needs work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 晴れ着としては、ぼろすぎないか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: For your Sunday best (clothes), aren't they a little raggedy?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アイデアとしてはいいが、実現するのは難しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As an idea, that is good. However, it will be difficult in practice.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: イメージとしては分かりますが、説明が曖昧すぎます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As a mental image I understand, but the explanation is too vague.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 趣味としてはいいが、編物だけで食べていくのは難しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As a hobby it is fine, but it is difficult to make a living off of just knitting.

Name: としても
Meaning: Even if (we assume), Assuming,  Also as
About: としても is a structure used in Japanese for expressing thoughts about (A), assuming that it were what is being described. This may be translated as 'even if we assume that it's (A)', or 'assuming that (A)'. However, the literal translation is quite close to 'even going off that it were (A), (B)', as としても simply expresses that despite (A) not being true, the speaker is willing to say that it is for arguments sake, before giving their thoughts about that hypothetical situation. としても will be seen following verbs and い-Adjectives, or nouns and な-Adjectives that are followed by だ. In some cases, としても just functions as an extension of として 'as', and can be interpreted as 'even as (A)'. This nuance primarily highlights people or organizations in the position of (A), and states that 'even for (A), it will still be (B)'. Unlike the previous nuance, this としても will only be used with nouns.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たとえ早くついたとしても、一番乗りになることはないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if we get there early, that probably doesn't mean that we will be the first to get on.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたが言っている事が正しいとしても、私は賛成できません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if we assume that what you are saying is correct, I do not agree with it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たとえ仕事が簡単だとしても、仕事は丁寧にやるべきだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if work is easy, work should be done with care.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冗談だとしても、そういうことは言わない方がいいと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if that was a joke, I don't think that you should say something like that.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな急に内容を変えられたら、私としても困ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It will even inconvenience me if you change the details so suddenly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 環境問題に取り組んでいる会社としてもこういうことをしたくないのですが、仕方がないんです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a company that works on environmental issues, we don't want to do this, but we really don't have a choice.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たとえできるとしても、やらないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wouldn't do it even if I could.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 例え話だとしても許されない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if it is a parable, I can't permit it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大人向きの本だとしても売れます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You can also sell it as a book for adults.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はピアノ奏者だが、オルガン奏者としても有名です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is a pianist, but he is also famous as an organ player.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それが正式な回答だとしても、僕はまだ諦めきれません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if we assume that is the correct answer, I still cannot accept it.

Name: それにしても
Meaning: Nevertheless, Even so
About: それにしても is an expression used in Japanese as an extension of にしても 'even though', or 'even if'. This grammar pattern may be translated as 'nevertheless', or 'even so', and merely points out that despite what was said previously, the speaker's primary opinion is the following statement. In most cases, それにしても simply highlights that while the speaker accepts or acknowledges the previous statement as true, that is not all there is to be considered. それにしても will primarily appear at the beginning of sentences, or directly after a comma. Due to それにしても being used when the speaker is already aware of or accepts the situation of (A), (B) will frequently highlight something that is above or beyond that expectation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は新人だから仕方がないが、それにしても仕事ができなさすぎる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She's new so we can't blame her, but even so, she is not good at her job at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中くんは遅れてくると言っていたが、それにしてもくるのが遅すぎる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-kun said he will be late, but even so, it's taking him too long to come.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 漢字を勉強し始めてから１年になる。それにしても、まだ全然漢字が読めない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It has been a year since I started studying kanji. Nevertheless, I still can't read kanji at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家に来たばかりのときなんかお手もできなかったのにね。それにしても、大きくなったね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When he first came to our house, he couldn't even give me his paw. Nevertheless, he got so big, don't you think?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩、昨日はご馳走様でした！それにしても、あそこの料理は最高でしたね！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Senpai, thank you for treating me yesterday! Nevertheless, that restaurant was awesome, wasn't it?!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ラッピングをお願いしたが、それにしても、かなりの過剰包装だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I asked for wrapping, but even so, the wrapping was excessive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼らが問題の解決に手を貸していますが、それにしてもそれは難問です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They are lending a hand to solve that problem. Even so, that is a tough one.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 古い車だから仕方がないが、それにしても加速が悪すぎる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is an old car so it can't be helped, but nevertheless, the acceleration is terrible.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 上司から許可を得ました。それにしても、本部に連絡しないといけません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We received permission from the boss. Even so, we have to contact the headquarters.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 災害を防止するには、避難訓練が必要だ。それにしても、完全な予防は無理だろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In order to prevent disasters, disaster drills are necessary. Nevertheless, complete prevention is probably impossible.

Name: ぬ
Meaning: Classical negative, Classical verb [ない]
About: ぬ is the attributive form of ず, a classical auxiliary verb that is used for negation like ない, and connects to verbs in the same way. As ぬ is the attributive form of ず, it may be seen modifying nouns that directly follow it. However, this use is not common in modern times, and in many cases it will be used as part of set expressions that have not changed in the time since ない became the far more widely used structure for negation. Alternatively, it may just be used for artistic expression, or to make a character seem 'classical'. In the case that the verb being negated is いる, the old fashion おる will be modified to おらぬ instead. Alternatively, する will be negated as せぬ, and くる will be negated as こぬ. This is consistent with the standard conjugation patterns seen with the use of ず.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんなに狭い道は通れぬ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I cannot pass a road this narrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なんだこの飯は！こんなまずそうなものは口に入れぬ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What is this food? I will not put this disgusting thing in my mouth!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 貴様みたいなものには、わしなど殺せぬ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I cannot be killed by someone like you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 鈴木殿はここにはおらぬ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Suzuki-dono is not here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの方は人を傷つけるようなことはせぬ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person would never do anything to hurt anyone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 婆さんが川から帰ってこぬ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My wife won't come back from the river.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「愚か者、男には殺せぬのだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Fool, no man can kill me.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こちらでは性による差別は許可されておらぬ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Sex discrimination is not permitted here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ペーネロペー：「オデュッセウスはまだ戻ってこぬのか？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Penelope: 'Odysseus has not returned yet?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「隅に置けぬ人」というのは「侮れない人」ということなのだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'A person who (can't be placed) in a corner' means 'a person who cannot be taken lightly'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 上司は部下が向上できるように、至らぬ点を教えてあげるべきだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A superior should tell his/her subordinates where they fall short so that they can improve.

Name: 事無(ことな)く
Meaning: Without ~ing
About: Like ないで 'without', ことなく is an expression used in Japanese following verbs that expresses (B) being done 'without (A)'. However; ことなく is used in more formal situations, and when there is some contrast between (A) and (B). This may appear in one of two ways, which we will discuss in a moment. ことなく is a mix of こと, and なく, the adverbial form of ない. It will follow the dictionary form of verbs. The first contrastive use of ことなく illustrates that (A) is something negative, to which (B) should be done as a preventative measure, or was able to be done while avoiding (A). The second use of ことなく highlights when (A) is something that was or would be wished for, but unfortunately (B) happened without it being realized. In this way, (A) is frequently some kind of unmet desire.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 怪我人を出すことなく、人質を全員救出する事ができたそうです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They were able to rescue all the hostages without injuring anyone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遅刻することなく、職場に着いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was able to arrive at work without being late.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犯人が捕まることなく１０年が経つ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ten years pass without the culprit being caught.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は社長に何も言うことなく会社を辞めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He quit his job without telling the boss.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何ごとも理解されることなく終わる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It will end without me understanding anything.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 真実を知ることなく終わる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It will end without me knowing the truth.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遅れることなく到着した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To arrive without being late.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 耕すことなく種を植えても、うまくいくはずがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Without tilling, even if you plant seeds, there is no way it will turn out well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うちの子には、散らかすことなく遊ぶという特技があります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Our child has a special skill where they can play without leaving things untidy.

Name: にて
Meaning: In, At, With, Using, By
About: にて is often considered as its own stand-alone particle, despite originally being a mix of に, and the conjunction particle, て. When combined, にて becomes a formal case-marking particle that is used in the same way as で. This means that it can convey the meaning of 'with (A)', 'by (A)', 'at (A)', or 'using (A)'. にて will primarily appear following nouns that illustrate a means, method, time, location, reason, or origin that the speaker wants to highlight. As this grammar structure is formal, it will primarily be seen in writing, or heard in announcements. で will be the far more natural choice in casual conversation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は金時計にて集合しましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let's meet tomorrow at the Golden Clock.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 当店は午前９時にて開店いたします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This store will open at 9:00 a.m.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 予約をされる場合は電話にてご連絡ください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you want to make a reservation, please make one by phone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これにて一件落着。
Questions.EnglishHTML: With this, the case is closed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 応接室にてお待ちしております。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am waiting in the waiting room.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 面接は本社にて行います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The interview will take place at the company headquarters.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: メールにてご連絡いただけると助かります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It would be helpful if you could contact me using email.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 午後五時にて閉店いたします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We will close (the shop) at five in the afternoon.

Name: には
Meaning: In order to, In regard to, For
About: には is a common particle combination in Japanese that is used to express contrast in regard to the topic. As a function of the particles that combine to make には, に highlights that something is 'for (A)', while は emphasizes that a generalization or contrast is being made about (A). Common translations for には include 'in order to', 'in regard to', or 'for'. This structure will appear following either verbs in their dictionary form, or nouns.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このホームセンターは会員制なので、買い物をするには会員登録が必要です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since this home improvement store is only open to members, you will need to sign up in order to shop here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 海外に行くにはパスポートが必要です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You need a passport in order to travel abroad.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この本は子供には難しすぎるだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This book is probably too difficult for children.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 通勤には車を使わないでください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please do not use your car for commuting.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「移動にはスクーターを使ったらどう？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'What about using a scooter for transportation?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夢を実現するには時間がかかる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It takes time in order to make one's dream happen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 出産には、我慢強さが必要です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In order to give birth, endurance is necessary.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一戸建てを買うには多くの金がかかる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It costs a lot of money to buy a detached house.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 間違いを認めてやり直すには勇気が要ります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: One needs courage in order to admit a mistake and start over.

Name: 思(おも)う様(よう)に
Meaning: As one hopes, As desired, As one thought
About: 思(おも)うように is a common sentence pattern in Japanese that is used for illustrating when something either does or does not happen in the way that one had thought. This phrase may be interpreted as 'as one hopes', 'as desired', or 'as one thought'. 思(おも)うように is simply a combination of the う-Verb 思(おも)う and the conjunctive form of the auxiliary verb ようだ, ように. Typical sentence structures that use this pattern will start with an (A) phrase highlighting the 'expectation', be followed by 思(おも)うように, then finished with a (B) phrase indicating the outcome. When (B) is a simple noun, 様(よう)な will be used instead. As the (B) part of 思(おも)うように sentences will contain the information about whether the 'expectation' of (A) either was or was not met, this phrase may be used either positively or negatively to show that something did not meet, met, or even exceeded that expectation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近仕事が思うように行かなくてストレスが溜まってきてるんだよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, work has not been going as well as I hoped, so I am starting to get stressed out.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日漢字を練習しているが思うように上達しない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am practicing kanji every day, but I am not making as much progress as I thought.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 事故に遭ってから指が思うように動かなくなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since the accident, my fingers have become unable to move as I had thought.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この車は思うように加速しないからイライラする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is irritating that this car doesn't accelerate like I hoped it would.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: オーケストラのメンバー集めが思うようにいきません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Assembling orchestra members is not going as I had hoped it would.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: プリンを作ったら、思うように固まらなくて困った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When I made pudding, I had trouble getting it to firm up like I hoped it would.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ケーキ屋みたいなお菓子が思うように作れなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Making sweets like they do at the pastry shop didn't go as I had hoped it would.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 育児というのは、親の思うようにはいかないものです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Childcare is known as something that is expected to not go how the parents hope it will.

Name: かと思(おも)うと
Meaning: Then again, Just when I thought, No sooner than
About: When the adverbial particle か is combined with と, the う-Verb 思(おも)う, and either of the hypothetical markers たら or と, it forms a compound that is used to illustrate uncertainty about whether (A) has been finalized or not. In most cases, this translates as '(A), then again (B)', 'just when I thought (A), (B)', or 'no sooner than (A), (B)'. Literally, the meaning is close to 'before (A) could even be confirmed as having happened, (B)'. かと思(おも)うと and かと思(おも)ったら will regularly appear after verbs in either their dictionary or past-tense forms. Alternatively, this structure may also be seen following nouns, especially when the meaning is focused on the speaker's feelings about (A). Either なの (or の when used with verbs) may appear between the target phrase and かと思(おも)ったら when the (B) phrase includes the speaker's feelings.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何を言い出すかと思ったら、みんなの前で俺の悪口を言い出した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just when I thought of something to say, he started bad-mouthing me in front of everyone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 赤ちゃんが泣き止んだかと思ったら、また大声で泣き始めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just when I thought the baby had stopped crying, he started to cry loudly again.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 娘が宿題を始めるのかと思うと、パソコンを開いてユーチューブを見始めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just when I thought my daughter was going to start doing her homework, she opened the computer and started watching YouTube.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供が転んだかと思うと、立ち上がって走り出した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just when I thought my kid fell down, she got up and started running.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんは冷たい人かと思ったら、ただ人見知りなだけだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No sooner than thinking that Tanaka-san is a cold person, I found out that he was just shy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日の試合が最後かと思うと、悲しくなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just when I remembered that today's game is the last one, I got sad.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新人社員が入ってきたと思ったら、次の日には仕事を辞めていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just when I thought a new employee had joined us, he had quit by the next day.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子と息子の友達が喧嘩をしていると思うと、友達とゲラゲラ笑いながらゲームをしていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just when I thought that my son and his friend were fighting, I heard him giggling while playing video games with his friend.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ミスが続いたのであきれられたかと思ったら、そうでもなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just when I thought they would grow disgusted of their continued mistakes, they didn't.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嫌がられるかと思ったら、あっさりＯＫしてくれた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just when I thought they would hate it, they easily gave me the okay.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暴れていたかと思ったら、やけに大人しくなることもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just when I thought that they were throwing a tantrum, they become extremely docile.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はあれだけ怒られて悲しんでいるかと思ったら、すぐに笑いだした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just when I thought that he was sad because he got scolded, he started laughing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何を言い出すかと思ったら、コンビ解散の話だった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just when I thought of something to say they were already talking about dissolving the duo.

Name: と言(い)うものでもない
Meaning: There is no guarantee that…, Not necessarily
About: というものではない is an expression in Japanese that indicates that 'there is no guarantee that (A)', or that it is 'not necessarily (A)'. As this structure is just a combination of と, the う-Verb 言(い)う 'to say', もの 'thing', and ではない 'isn't', the literal meaning can be thought of as being similar to 'it's not a thing that one can say is (A)'. は may be replaced with も, with only a slight change in nuance. As with many grammar patterns, the version with も will be considered a bit more emphasized. というものではない may follow any word in its standard form, but may occasionally be preceded by だ when used with nouns or な-Adjectives (despite not being required). In most cases, this grammar pattern will indicate that while most of the time (A) might be something that is expected to be true, there are exceptions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いい大学を出たからと言って、いい会社に入社できると言うものではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no guarantee that you will get into a good company just because you graduated from a good university.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 洋服は高ければいいと言うものでもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not necessarily true that clothes are better if they are expensive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アプリの機能は多ければ多いほど便利だと言うものでもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The more features the better is not necessarily true when it comes to apps.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのブランドが人気だからと言って、あのブランドの商品がいいものだと言うものでもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no guarantee that that brand's products are good just because they are popular.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語が上手であれば日本語の勉強をし続けなくてもいいと言うものではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not necessarily true that you should stop studying Japanese, just because you are good at it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: プレゼントは高額であればいいと言うものではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not necessarily true that a gift is better the more expensive they are.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 愛があれば結婚できるというものでもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not necessarily true that you are able to get married if you love each other.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スマートに見える人が皆痩せているというものでもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no guarantee that everyone who looks slim is actually thin.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 車は高ければ高いほどいいというものでもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The more expensive the better is not necessarily true when it comes to cars.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 漫才は、素人だからといってできないというものでもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just because you're a novice, it's not necessarily true that you can't do comic dialogue.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 図鑑にはすべての生き物が載っているというものでもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no guarantee that all living animals are listed in the field guide.

Name: と考(かんが)えられる
Meaning: Can be considered as, Is thought to be, One can think that, It is conceivable that
About: In order to express an objective opinion in Japanese, the expression と考(かんが)えられる will often be used. This is a combination of と, and the passive-indicating auxiliary verb られる. Common translations for this structure include 'can be considered as (A)', 'is thought to be (A)', or 'it is conceivable that (A)'. As と考(かんが)えられる begins with と, this structure will frequently appear at the end of entire phrases, converting them into a quote. When wanting to express a subjective opinion, と思(おも)われる will be used instead.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの事故は煽り運転のせいだと考えられる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tailgating is thought to be the cause of this accident.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語は文字種が多いことから、第二言語として習うのが難しいと考えられる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is thought that Japanese is difficult to learn as a second language due to having several different character types.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私には彼がこの事件の犯人だと思われる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems to me that he is the one responsible for this incident.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私にはあなたが悪いと思われる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems to me that you are in the wrong.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 衆議院、いよいよ解散すると考えられる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is thought that the lower house of representatives will finally dissolve.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの子の親は育児放棄していると考えられる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is thought that that child's parents are neglecting the child.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの政策なら、一定の支持が得られると考えられる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it is that policy, it is conceivable that we would receive standardized support.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 安易に決定したと考えられるが、もしかしたら作戦かもしれません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is thought that the decision made was to be easy-going, but it might just be a tactic.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そのプロジェクト、一旦白紙に戻すということも考えられませんか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is it conceivable that you would think of wiping the slate clean on that project? (won't you?)

Name: と言(い)う点(てん)から考(かんが)えると
Meaning: From the standpoint of, From the perspective of, From the viewpoint of, Think in terms of, Viewed from the angle of
About: と言(い)う点(てん)から考(かんが)えると is a set phrase which indicates that something is being discussed from the 'point of view of (A)'. This may be translated as 'from the viewpoint of (A)', 'speaking in terms of (A)', or 'when viewed from the angle of (A)'. The noun 点(てん) 'point' can be thought of as directly indicating the aspect of (A) that is being focused on. Literally, the meaning is 'if considered from the aspect of (A), (B)'. This expression often follows either verbs or nouns, However, when following nouns, の may occasionally replace という, especially in cases where it is a simple noun, rather than an entire quotation that just happens to finish with a noun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本のデジタル化が遅れているという点から考えると、デジタル人材の育成やデジタルインフラの整備に力を入れなければ日本のデジタル化はどんどん遅れていくだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If we think in terms of Japan's digitalization lagging behind, if Japan doesn't focus on improving their digital workforce and infrastructure, it's digitalization will fall further and further behind.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供の教育という点から考えると、楽しく勉強をさせる事が重要です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the standpoint of educating children, it is important to make learning fun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 健康の点から考えると休む時はちゃんと休まなければ身体を壊す可能性が高まります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the standpoint of health, if you don't rest when you need to rest, the possibility of physical damage increases.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もし、うまくいくとしても製造のコストの点から考えるとまだ非効率である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if we assume it will work, if one thinks in terms of production costs it is still inefficient.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: エンドユーザーの便利さという点から考えるとそれはむしろ不便である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If we think in terms of end user convenience, that might actually be inconvenient.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仕事の効率の点から考えると１時間に５分の休憩を取る方がいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If we think in terms of work efficiency, it is better to take a 5 minute break every hour.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ビジネスという点から考えると需要が高いということは高い利益の可能性があるということだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If we think in terms of business, high demand means a high probability of profit.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 健康の点から考えると砂糖の多い食べ物を食すればするほど肥満の可能性が高くなる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If we think in terms of health, the more sugary food you consume, the higher the chance of obesity.

Name: と言(い)う事(こと)は
Meaning: That means, That is to say
About: ということは is a phrase in Japanese that often appears in the middle of sentences, expressing that the previous statement is something that is about to be clarified. This can be translated as 'that means', or 'that is to say'. ということは based sentences will often finish with ということだ, although it is not limited to appearing this way. The more literal translation is something similar 'that which is said to be (A), (B)'. In this way, it simply presents (A) as a thing that requires further explaining. Additionally, ということは will appear at the beginning of sentences, when the speaker is confirming their understanding about something that has just been said. Often in the form of a question. In these cases, the translation is similar 'so you mean to say that (A)?'. As can be seen from the breakdown of という, こと, and は, this statement just expresses that the 'thing' which is 'classified as' (A) is 'in general' understood to be (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの有名なＩＴ企業で働いているということは、結構いい大学を出たってこと？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You work at a very famous IT company. That means that you graduated from a pretty good university, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女から返事が来ないということは、今は忙しいということだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The fact that she hasn't responded to me means that she is probably busy at the moment.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語を上手に話せるということは、日本に長い間住んでいたということですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You can speak Japanese well. Does that mean that you have lived in Japan for a long time?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もう仕事終わったの？ということは、今日こそは一緒に晩御飯が食べれるということだね！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are already done with work!? That means that we can finally eat dinner together today!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 妊娠したの！？ということは、私はおばあちゃんになるってこと？！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are pregnant!? Does that mean that I am going to be a grandma?!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 末っ子ということは、本当は甘えん坊なんじゃない？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is it not to say that the youngest child is really spoiled?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ステージに立つということは、誰にでもできることではないと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I do not think that standing on a stage means that anybody can do it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 素直であるということは、君の表情からも分かります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You are docile. That is to say, I know this just from your facial expressions.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここに隙間があるということは、欠陥住宅の疑いがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is a crack here, that is to say I am suspicious of this residence being defective.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼が一人で旅に行くということは、大人になったということだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is going on a trip by himself. That is to say, he has become an adult.

Name: 風(ふう)に
Meaning: ~ way, In a way that suggests, Like ~
About: 風(ふう) 'wind', 'air', commonly appearing as kana, is a suffix in Japanese used to indicate that something is in the style, manner, or method of what comes before it. This use of ふう appears following verbs, and works in the same way as a な-Adjective. This means that it will be followed by に when being used adverbially to further describe something that is being done 'in the way of (A)'. Also, it is common for ふうに to be used after pre-noun adjectival words such as こんな, そんな, and あんな. This just highlights that something is being done 'like this', 'like that', etc.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は仕事をやっているふうに見えるけど、ただそう見えるだけで、何もしていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He looks like he is doing his job, but it just looks like it and he isn't actually doing anything.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩には頑張っているふうには見えないかもしれないけど、これでもめちゃくちゃ頑張っているんです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Senpai, it may not look like I'm working hard, but this is me trying my hardest.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんなふうに結んだらすぐ解けちゃうよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you tie a knot like this, it will get undone easily.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなふうに私をみないでよ。私は本当に何もやってないから！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't look at me like that. I really didn't do anything!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんなふうには絶対なりたくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I never want to be like that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつか自分もこんなふうになりたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At some point, I too want to become like this (way).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんなふうにやればいいのか分からない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't know in what way doing it would be good. (I don't know how to do it)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうすればあんなふうになれるのだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder what it would take to (what if done would) be able to become that way.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 兄はすぐに嘘をつく。僕はそんなふうにはなりたくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My older brother will instantly lie. I don't want to become like that (way).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 聞いていないふうに振舞っているが、本当は聞いている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He acts in a way that suggests he isn't listening, but he really is listening.

Name: と言(い)う風(ふう)に
Meaning: As if to say, As if to suggest that, In such a way that, Things like
About: Like ふうに, the grammar point indicating that something is being done 'in the way of (A)', というふうに uses the same suffix of 風(ふう) 'wind', 'air', to express that something is being done 'as if to say (A)', 'as if to suggest (A)', or 'in such a way that (A)'. As this construction is just a combination of という 'to say', and ふうに 'in a manner', the literal meaning of this expression is similar to 'in a way that would say that (A)'. This simply highlights the speaker's uncertainty about what the actual situation is, and that they are only commenting on appearances. というふうに may be seen directly after verbs, or after nouns expressing the way in which something is being done. The (B) portion of these phrases will then indicate exactly what is being done 'in a way as if to say (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は昼休憩に帰るというふうに聞いています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard something as if to suggest that she is going to go home during lunch break.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 鈴木さんはこの試験に命がかかっているというふうに勉強をした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Suzuki-san studied as if to suggest that his life depended on this exam.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は今まで自分が一番仕事ができる人だというふうに思っていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Until recently, I always thought in such a way as to suggest that I was the most capable person when it comes to work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はデザイン、僕はプログラミング、というふうに役割を分けてアプリを開発することにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We decided to develop the application by dividing the roles in the following way: he would do the design and I would do the programming.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 父：「母に、遅れるだろうという風に言って。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Father: 'Tell mom in such a way as to suggest that I will be late.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 秘書が仕事を辞めるという風に聞いていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard something as if to suggest that the secretary decided to quit.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は命がかかってるという風に走っていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She was running in a way that suggested her life depended on it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 入団してすぐに活躍という風になかなかいかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is quite difficult to do things like activities immediately after enrolling.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 合格は堅いという風に言われても、やっぱり不安です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if I am told in such a way that suggests that passing is a given, I am still uneasy.

Name: ものの
Meaning: Although, But, Even Though
About: ものの is a formal conjunction-particle used to illustrate that while (A) is a fact, the result or condition of (B) cannot be attributed to (A), could not be predicted through (A), or is in direct contrast to (A). ものの may appear directly after verb, い-Adjectives, nouns followed by である, or な-Adjectives followed by な.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: マッチングアプリで出会った人とデートに行ったものの、共通点が何もなかったのでまた会うことはないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although I went on a date with someone I met on a matching app, we had nothing in common, so I doubt we will meet again.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今の仕事の給料は高いものの、家族と過ごせる時間が少ないから転職を考えている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although my current job pays well, I am considering changing jobs because I don't have much time to spend with my family.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのお店が出す商品はユニークではあるものの、高すぎるので手が出せない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although the products offered by that store are unique, they are too expensive for me to afford.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 伊藤先生は英語の先生ではあるものの、日常的な英語は話せないそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though Ms. Ito is an English teacher, I have heard that she doesn't speak everyday English.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はいろんな楽器を演奏できるものの、楽譜は読めないらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although she can play a lot of instruments, I heard that she can't read music.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は日本語を勉強しているものの、韓国語も勉強している。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although he is studying Japanese, he is also studying Korean.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ＡとＢを組み合わせてみたものの、ほとんど味が変わらないな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although I tried combining A and B, it tastes almost the same.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 工夫してみたものの、結果は大して変わらない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though I tried solving (the problem), there won't be any significant change.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自分で組み立ててみたものの、見栄えが悪すぎる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though I built it myself, it has absolutely no charm.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: クーラーを最大にしてみたものの、全然涼しくならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though I got the largest air conditioner, (the room) doesn't get cool at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 口紅をつけてみたものの、全然女性らしく見えないのはなぜ？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although I put on lipstick, I don't look ladylike at all. Why!?

Name: と言(い)うものだ
Meaning: Speaker's impression, Criticism or conclusion
