About: というものだ is a fairly strong expression in Japanese that indicates that the speaker has the impression that (A) is the way it is, based on their objective judgment. This is usually translated as 'my impression of (A) is that'. However, the more literal translation is closer to '(A) is just a thing that'. This emphasizes that the speaker has high certainty that what they are saying (based on their experience) is the true nature of (A) in most cases. というものだ is constructed of という, the noun 物(もの) 'thing', and だ. It will be seen at the end of phrases that the speaker or writer is making a judgment about. As this grammar pattern is quite direct, it is often used when criticizing something. However, this is not always the case, so will need to be judged based on context.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何があってもお互い助け合うのが友達というものだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Helping each other no matter what is just what friends do.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩が着く１０分前に着く。それがマナーというものだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Arriving 10 minutes before your senpai arrives. That is just manners.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんなに疲れていても諦めない。それがアスリートというものだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not giving up no matter how tired you are. That is my impression of an athlete.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何があっても泣かない。それが男ってものだ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not crying no matter what. That is my impression of a man!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その言い分はわがままというものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My impression is that your complaint is selfish.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたの好き嫌いは食わず嫌いというものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My impression is that your likes and dislikes are prejudiced (dislike without trying).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嘘はつかない。それがジャーナリストというものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not telling lies. That is my impression of what a journalist is.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 楽しくないと意味がない。それがサークルというものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it isn't fun, it is pointless. That is my impression of club sports.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はいつも結果を出す。あれが実力というものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He always gets results. That is my impression of competency.

Name: から見(み)ると
Meaning: From the point of view of, By the look of
About: から見(み)ると is a common sentence pattern seen when something is being viewed either from the perspective of (A), or a judgment is being made based on looking at the situation of (A) objectively. This may be translated either as 'from the point of view of (A), (B)', or 'from looking at (A), one could say (B)'. This grammar construction is comprised of the conjunction particle から 'from', the る-Verb 見(み)る 'to look', and any of the usual hypothetical statement markers such as と, たら, ば, or even the て-form. It will appear following nouns.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アニメに興味がない人から見ると、どのアニメも同じに見える。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the point of view of someone who is not interested in anime, all anime looks the same.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 外からみたら、私のコレクションはゴミに見えるでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From an outside point of view, my collection probably just looks like garbage.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私から見れば、彼女はあまり美人じゃない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From my point of view, she is not that much of a stunner.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このタイヤ跡の大きさから見て、犯人はトラックを使ったに違いない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: By the looks of the size of these tire tracks, the perpetrator must have used a truck.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人の喋り方から見ると、あの人は日本人ではないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the point of view of how they speak, that person probably isn't Japanese. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 外から見ると、やりやすそうです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From an outside point of view it looks easy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 老人夫婦から見ると、若者の恋愛は懐かしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the point of view of elderly couples, young love is nostalgic.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 普段から見て、今年は稀な気象が多かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the view point of what is normal, there were a lot of rare weather phenomena this year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 脇役から見ると主役は羨ましいが、主役は主役で大変らしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the point of view of a supporting role, the lead part is enviable, however the lead role looks very tough.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小学生から見ると中高生は大人に見えるが、実際はそうでもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the point of view of an elementary schooler, junior and senior high schoolers look like adults, but that is not really the case.

Name: ところを見(み)ると
Meaning: Judging from, Seeing that
About: ところを見(み)ると is a set phrase in Japanese that highlights the situation or place of (A), before examining it subjectively. This often comes across simply as 'judging from (A)', or 'seeing that (A)'. Literally, it can be thought of as 'if looking at the aspect of (A)', before the speaker will then go on to state what their judgment is. This grammar pattern will appear directly following verbs in any of their standard forms. Due to ところを見(み)ると expressing primarily subjective opinions based on single observable actions, the (B) part of sentences including this structure will often include things like だろう, かも, でしょう, ね, etc, in order to show that the speaker is not actually claiming anything factually.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼がニコニコしているところを見ると、テストに合格したに違いない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Seeing that he is smiling, I have no doubt that he passed the test.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 漢字を綺麗に書けるところを見ると、彼は長い間漢字を勉強しているのかもしれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Judging from the fact that he can write kanji very nicely, he probably has been studying kanji for a long time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 怒られていてもずっと携帯を見ているところを見ると、彼は全然反省していないんだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Seeing that he is looking at his phone despite being scolded, he probably doesn't feel any remorse.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 香水をつけているところを見ると、お出掛けですね？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Seeing that you are wearing perfume, are you going out?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 心当たりがないところを見ると、誤解かもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Seeing that you have no clue, it is probably a misunderstanding.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このタイミングで交替したところを見ると、あのピッチャーは怪我をしたのかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Judging from the timing of the change, that pitcher was probably injured.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼が落ち込んでいるところを見ると、恋人に振られたのかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Judging from the fact that he is sullen, he was probably dumped by his lover.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 焦がしたところを見ると、彼女は料理が苦手なのでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Seeing that she burned it, she is not that great at cooking, is she?

Name: からすると
Meaning: Judging from, Considering
About: からすると is an expression combining the conjunction particle から 'from', する 'to do', and either of the hypothetical markers と or ば. It may be translated as 'judging from (A), (B)', or 'considering (A), (B)'. However, the way that する behaves in these types of sentences is quite comparable to expressions like 'going off' in English, in that it just indicates that (A) is the basis from which the speaker is about to make their judgment. からすると or からすれば will be seen following nouns, before the (B) part of the sentence will highlight the speaker's assessment of (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この成績からすると、あなたは全然勉強をしていないでしょう？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Judging from these grades, you didn't study at all, did you?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この甘さからすると、塩と間違えて砂糖を入れてしまったに違いない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Judging from how sweet this is, they must've mistakenly added sugar instead of salt.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本育ちの私からすれば、これは寿司ではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Going off being a person raised in Japan, this is not sushi.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女の反応からすると、本当に驚いているようだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Going off her reaction, it seems like she is genuinely surprised.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの煙突からすると、たぶん薪ストーブですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Judging from that chimney, maybe it is a wood stove.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 歴史からすると、京都はかつて首都でした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Judging from history, Kyoto was once the capital.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたが言っていることからすると、彼はそこにいなかったようですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Judging from what you are saying, it seems that he wasn't there right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 足の速さからすると、彼はプロの選手になれるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Considering how fast he is, he can probably become a professional athlete.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのアクセントからすると彼は日本人ではないようです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Judging from his accent, it appears that he is not Japanese.

Name: からして
Meaning: Even..., Judging from, Based on
About: からして is a combination of the conjunction particle から 'from', and the て-form of する. It is used to express when the speaker is making a partially objective opinion about (A). This frequently comes across as 'judging from (A)', or 'based on (A)'. The literal meaning is 'going from (A), (B)'. This simply highlights that (A) is the only information or method available from which an assessment can be made, so 'going from that information, (B) can be said', or 'going with that method, (B) can be said'. からして will appear directly after the noun which indicates either the method or information from which a judgment will then be made. As からして is partially objective, this just means that the speaker does not have the full information available to say anything with certainty, and is therefore making a guess about (A) based purely on what appears to be true. Due to this, からして sentences often have the nuance of 'from the available piece of information about (A), (B) is likely the whole picture'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の性格からして、彼と一緒に住むことは無理だろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Based on his personality, it is probably impossible for me to live with him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 値段からして、このお店は新鮮な食材を使っているに違いない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Based on the price, this restaurant must be using fresh ingredients.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このゲームは名前からしてつまらなそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Judging from the name, this game seems boring.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このスープは匂いからして美味しそうだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Judging from this soup's smell, it seems delicious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの演奏からして、彼は楽器のプロだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Judging from that performance, he is a professional with that instrument.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の感覚からして、このスイカは甘いと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Judging from my intuition, I think this watermelon is sweet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの看板からして、店の中もきっとオシャレなのだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Judging from that signboard, surely the inside of that store is also fashionable.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 稽古の内容からして、あの先生は厳しそうだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Judging from the contents of their training, that teacher seems strict.

Name: からといって
Meaning: Just because
About: からといって is a grammar pattern in Japanese comprised of the conjunction particle から 'from', と, and the て-form of the う-Verb 言(い)う 'to say'. It is usually translated to 'just because (A)', and will indicate that the underlying reason of (A) does not necessarily mean that (B) is also true, or that (B) is not good. As this grammar structure often includes a negative statement in the (B) part of the sentence, the more literal translation is closer to 'from saying that (A), doesn't mean (B)'. This simply focuses the nuance on that (A) does not equal (B), despite what one may think. からといって may appear after verbs and い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives and nouns that are followed by だ. In most cases, からといって will be used for giving strong opinions, or for criticism of someone's actions or behavior.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たくさん勉強をしたからといって、テストに合格するとは限らない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because you studied a lot doesn't mean that you will pass the test.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 公園が広いからと言って、犬の放し飼いをしてもいいと言うわけではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because the park is spacious doesn't mean that dogs are allowed off leash.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 丈夫だからといって、雑に扱えば必ず壊れます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because it is sturdy, it will definitely break if you handle it roughly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本人だからといって、漢字を書けるとは限らない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because someone is Japanese doesn't mean that they can write kanji.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本に２年間住んでいたからとて、日本語が話せるとは限らない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because someone has lived in Japan for 2 years doesn't mean that they can speak Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 暑いからって、そんなに休憩ばかりしていたら仕事が進まないだろ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you keep taking so many breaks just because it's hot, you will never get your job done.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ご機嫌斜めだからといって、八つ当たりしないで。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please don't burst out in anger, just because you are in a bad mood.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 丼物だからといって、安いとは限りません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just because it is 'donburi', doesn't confine it to being cheap.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 慰められたからといって、すぐに気持ちは晴れない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just because I was comforted, doesn't mean that my mood will immediately improve.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 懐かしいからといって、なんでもすぐに買うのはやめてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please, stop buying stuff on a whim just because you find it nostalgic.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 憎いからといって、人を殺していいわけないでしょ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just because you hate the person, that isn't a reason for it to be okay to kill them.

Name: そういえば
Meaning: Speaking of which, By the way, Come to think of it
About: そういえば is a hypothetical structure in Japanese consisting of the adverb そう 'like that', and the ば conjunctive form of the う-Verb 言(い)う 'to say'. Common translations include 'speaking of which', 'by the way', and 'come to think of it'. These translations are actually very close to the literal translation of 'if saying that' in that they all refer back to the previous statement as being a trigger for bringing up a topic that the speaker wants to discuss. そういえば will primarily appear at the beginning of sentences, before the speaker will then bring up the topic that they were reminded of.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そういえば、この前借りた本読み終わったよ！めちゃくちゃ面白かった！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: By the way, I finished reading the book I borrowed from you the other day! It was super interesting!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そういえば、大家さんに家賃振り込んでくれた？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Speaking of which, did you transfer the rent to the landlord for me?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そういえば、さっき駅でお母さんの友達に会ったよ。よろしくだって。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Speaking of which, I met your friend at the station. She told me to tell you she said hi.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML:
中田さん： 今度バッティングセンターに行こ！
高橋さん：そういえば、藤田さんと伊藤くんが付き合い始めたって聞いた？

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そういえば、今日は母の日だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Come to think of it, it is Mother's Day today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そういえば、昨夜は何時に家に帰ったの？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Speaking of which, what time did you get home last night?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そういえば、着替え持ってきてくれた？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Speaking of which, did you bring the change of clothes for me?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そういえば、昨日の卒業式はどうだった？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Speaking of which, how was the graduation ceremony yesterday?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そういえば、客席に君のお父さんとお母さんがいたよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Speaking of which, your father and mother were in the guest seating!

Name: お～願(ねが)う
Meaning: Please, Could you please
About: お～願(ねが)う is a humble speech expression in Japanese used for making requests in the same way as お～ください 'please do (A)'. As with many other polite structures, the use of お will primarily appear with words of Japanese origin, while ご will be used for the majority Chinese-origin kanji compounds. 願(ねが)う itself is a う-Verb meaning 'to petition', and the literal translation is something like 'I petition that you do (A) for me', which sounds incredibly stiff in English, but gets the point across that someone is doing a favor for you. Naturally, due to being a polite sentence pattern, お～願(ねが)う will almost always appear in it's ます-form, お～願(ねが)います. Interestingly, words of western origin, such as katakana loanwords, will often omit both お and ご, appearing simply with 願(ねが)う attached to the end. Additionally, お～願(ねが)う can be used in the question form, お～願(ねが)えますか to convey a polite request. This comes across as 'may I ask you to (A)', or 'could I get you to (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こちらからのメールが届いているか、お確かめ願います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Could you please make sure that you have received our email.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 鈴木社長はもうすぐ到着するので、もう少々お待ち願います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: President Suzuki will be arriving shortly, so please wait a moment.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この契約書にご記入された情報に間違いがないか、ご確認願います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please make sure that the information you have entered in this contract is correct.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 歩道での禁煙にご協力願います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We kindly ask for your cooperation in not smoking on the sidewalks.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この契約書の下の方と、この書類の下の方にサイン願います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please sign at the bottom of this contract and at the bottom of this document.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 書類のこの下にサイン願います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please sign at the bottom of the document.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 問題が起こった場合はご連絡願います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you have any problems, please feel free to contact us.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここは図書館です。お静かに願います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a library. Please be quiet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一週間以内にお返事願います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please reply within one week's time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この文章で間違いないか、ご確認願います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please check if there are any mistakes in this sentence.

Name: ～て頂戴(ちょうだい)
Meaning: Please do
About: て頂戴(ちょうだい) is a phrase that is used to make a request of someone, normally someone who has a very close relationship with the speaker or someone who is in a social position below the speaker. It is formed by taking the て form of a verb and then attaching 頂戴(ちょうだい), originally a humble word that can be used to mean 'receiving', 'eating' or 'drinking'. Although 頂戴(ちょうだい) can be used as a humble word in other contexts, when attached to the て form of a verb, this phrase is most often used informally, such as among family members. It is sometimes considered a more feminine version of てください.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お兄ちゃん、ちょっとこれ開けてちょうだい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hey big brother, can you please open this?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お父さん、コンビニ行くなら砂糖買ってきてちょうだい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Husband, if you are going to the convenience store, can you get sugar?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これお姉ちゃんに渡してきてちょうだい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Go hand this to your big sister.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: グミちょうだい！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Gimme gummies!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 少しお時間を頂戴しますが、よろしいでしょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We would need to take a moment of your time, but would that be okay?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こちらのお土産はありがたく頂戴いたします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will receive this souvenir with great thanks.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お母さん、そこのリモコンを、取ってちょうだい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mom, please pass the remote.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今忙しいんだから、私に構わないでちょうだい！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since I’m busy right now, would you please stop bothering me!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会議室の予約をしてちょうだい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please book the meeting room.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「私のために…世界を救ってちょうだい♡」と姫が仰せです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: ‘Please save the world…for my sake ♡’, orders the princess.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: おばあちゃんに、白菜を届けに行って来てちょうだい！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please go and deliver the cabbage to Grandma!

Name: とか
Meaning: I heard that… something like, They said ... or something
About: Being a combination of the particles と and か, とか 'quotes' the previous statement as being something that has been heard, but is unconfirmed or uncertain. In English, this translates as 'I heard something like (A)', or '(A) or something was said'. とか may appear after verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives, or nouns. This meaning of 'or something' when using とか is fairly casual and will often be heard in everyday conversation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遠藤さんと近藤さんが結婚するとか。意外じゃない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that Endo-san and Kondo-san are getting married or something. Isn't that surprising?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの大手家電メーカーが開発した最新のスマホはたくさんのブロートウェアがインストールされているせいで動作がものすごく重いとか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that the latest smartphone developed by that major appliance manufacturer performs extremely slow because of all the bloatware that comes installed, or something like that.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高橋くんの彼女が美人だとか。あんなやつに美人な彼女ができたとは信じられないけどな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that Takahashi's girlfriend is beautiful or something. I can't believe that a guy like that could have a beautiful girlfriend, though.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は実はお金持ちだとか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that person is actually rich or something.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 納豆は体にいいんだとか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that Natto is good for your body or something like that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このワンピースは体型をカバーするとか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that this dress conceals your physique or something like that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ＡＫＢ４８という音楽グループは解散するとか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that the music group called AKB48 is going to break up or something like that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 最近はカラーサングラスが流行っているとか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that color sunglasses are popular recently or something like that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お母さんが朝ごはんを食べるのは大事だとか言っていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mom was saying that eating breakfast is important or something like that.

Name: う・よう + ではないか
Meaning: Let's do something, Why don't we
About: ようではないか is a construction that will primarily be used for making suggestions for mutual activities. This is a combination of either of the auxiliary verbs う or よう, ではない, and the sentence-ending particle, か. う and よう primarily express will or intent like 'shall' in English. Due to the negation following them, the literal translation will be similar to 'shall we not do (A)?'. For ease of translation, this structure can be remembered as simply 'let's do (A)', or 'why don't we do (A)'. As with all structures that use う or よう, ようではないか will be attached to the end of a verb indicating the action which is being suggested. Alternatively, the abbreviated form of じゃない may be used in place of ではない. Despite this, ようではないか is primarily a formal grammar structure, so will most often use the unabbreviated version, or even more polite ようではありませんか construction.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 正々堂々と戦おうではないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why don't we fight fair and square?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この問題をどう解決するかみんなで考えようではないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why don't we all think about how we can solve this problem?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こういう時こそお互い助け合おうじゃないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why don't we help each other, especially in times like this.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: せっかく日本に来たのだから、食べれるだけの日本食を食べようじゃないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since we have come all the way to Japan, why don't we eat as much Japanese food as we can.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もっと綺麗に壁紙の張り替えができるのなら、張り替えてもらおうではないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you think that you're able to reapply the wallpaper better, then why don't I just get you to do it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 乗せていってくれるって言っているんだから乗せて行ってもらおうではないか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They said that they will give us a ride, so why don't we have them give us a ride.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の成功を信じようではないか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Why don't we trust that he will be successful?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 共に素晴らしい世界を創っていこうではないか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Why don't we (go and) build a wonderful world together.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語を身につけるために頑張ろうではないか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Why don't we try our best in order to learn Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この瀬戸物をちゃんと鑑定してもらおうではないか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Why don't we get this porcelain appraised?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 意見の相違があっても、話し合おうではないか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if our opinions differ, why don't we discuss it?

Name: かの様(よう)だ
Meaning: As if, Just like
About: かのようだ is a set phrase in Japanese indicating that something 'appears to be (A)', but the speaker is not certain. It will be translated as 'as if (A)', or 'just like (A)'. This is a combination of the adverbial particle か, の and the auxiliary verb 様(よう)だ 'appearing to be'. The more literal meaning can be thought of as 'is it not like (A)?', due to the uncertainty expressed by か. かのようだ may follow verbs and い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives and nouns followed by である. When ようだ is altering the meaning of a verb or a noun later in the sentence, ように or ような may also be used. This grammar construction will often be seen with expressions that emphasize the speaker's assumption about (A), such as まるで. If compared to English, this merely strengthens the sentence in a similar way to the difference between 'it's as if (A)', and 'it's just as if (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このＶＲフライトゲームはものすごくリアルだ。まるで本物の飛行機を操縦しているかのようだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This VR flight game is so realistic. It is just as if I am flying an actual airplane.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なんだこの静けさは。この町には誰もいないかのようだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What is this quietness? It is as if there is no one in this town.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はまるで私と話すのが面倒であるかのようだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He talks to me as if it was a chore.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼と僕は兄弟であるかのようだが、実は彼は僕のパートナーです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is as if he and I are brothers, but actually he is my partner.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 長谷川くんのお母さんは私を自分の子供であるかのように小さい頃から可愛がってくれていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hasegawa-kun's mother has taken care of me just as if I was her own child.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このスーパーに入ると、まるで母国に帰ってきたかのような感じがする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I enter this supermarket, I feel as if I am back in my home country.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その作品は、あの有名な作品を真似たかのようですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That item looks as if it is imitating that other famous item.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はまるでお腹に風船を入れているかのようだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is just as if he has a balloon in his belly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの会社は営業中も休業しているかのようだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That company looks as if they are closed even during operation hours.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は相当目がいい。望遠鏡を使っているかのようだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He has extremely good eyesight. It is as if he is using a telescope.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのシャツの色と柄じゃあ、包帯をしているかのようですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That shirt's color and patterns makes it look as if you are wearing a bandage.

Name: のではないでしょうか
Meaning: I think ... isn't it?, It might be that..., Don't you agree?
About: のではないだろうか is a fairly long grammar pattern in Japanese that is used when one wants to express their opinion indirectly, in the form of a rhetorical question. Common translations include 'I think it's (A), isn't it?', and 'it might be that (A)'. However, being that this is just a combination of の, ではない 'isn't', だろう 'probably', and か, the literal meaning is simply 'is it probably not that it's (A)'. Just like in English, the elongation of the phrase and not saying anything with certainty makes it sound more modest. のではないだろうか may be seen following verbs and い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives and nouns when preceded with な. Additionally, でしょう may replace だろう. This phrase can also be used when seeking agreement from the listener, or when mildly trying to persuade them that your way of thinking may be correct.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩は疲れているのじゃないだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think that our senpai is tired, don't you think?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子がおもちゃをじーっとみている。あのおもちゃが欲しいのじゃないだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Our son is staring at a toy. I think he wants that toy, don't you agree?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 長谷川さんは田中さんのことが好きなのではないでしょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think that Hasegawa-san likes Tanaka-san, don't you agree?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人の右腕に入ってるタトゥー、防犯カメラに映っていたのと全く同じです。あの人は犯人なのではないでしょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The tattoo on that person's right arm is exactly the same as the one seen on the security camera. I think that he is the perpetrator, don't you agree?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はもしかして、あきれているのではないだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think that he is probably amazed, isn't he? (don't you agree?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あそこに見えるのは、虹ではないだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think the thing you can see over there is a rainbow, isn't it? (don't you agree?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この症状、伝染病ではないだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: With these symptoms, I think it's a contagious disease, isn't it? (don't you agree?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この調子だと、停電が長引くのではないだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At this rate, I think the blackout will drag on, won't it? (don't you agree?)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんなお願いをしてしまって、厚かましかったのではないだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think it was pretty bold/shameless to make a request like this, don't you agree? (isn't it?)

Name: ～て当然(とうぜん)だ
Meaning: Natural, As a matter of course
About: て当然(とうぜん)だ is a commonly used expression which indicates that '(A) is natural', or '(A) is a matter of course'. This is a combination of the て-form of either verbs of い-Adjectives (or で when used with nouns), the noun 当然(とうぜん) 'naturally', and だ. て当然(とうぜん)だ is a fairly strong phrase, and will often be used when pointing out things that the speaker considers to be obvious facts.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんな生意気なやつは嫌われて当然だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is only natural that a cocky person like that is hated.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このスープは俺が作ったものだから、美味しくて当然だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am the one that made this soup so, of course it is delicious.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このビルは先月建てられたばかりだから、綺麗で当然だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This building was only built last month, so of course it is beautiful.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんなに食べたら、太って当然だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you eat like that, of course you will get fat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は厚かましいから、避けられて当然だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because he is impudent, it is natural that you would avoid him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は優しいから、好かれて当然だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because she is nice, of course she is liked.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アイデアがいいから、人気があって当然だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because the idea is good, it is natural that it would be popular.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 脂を取り過ぎたら、気持ち悪くなって当然だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you consume too much fat, it is natural that you would come to feel bad.

Name: のも当然(とうぜん)だ
Meaning: It is only natural that, It is no wonder
About: Like て当然(とうぜん)だ, the grammar point indicating that (A) is 'natural' or 'obvious', のは当然(とうぜん)だ works in a similar way, and highlights that it is 'no wonder that (A)', or 'it is only natural that (A)'. This construction will be seen following verbs and い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives and nouns that are followed by な. As can be seen in several of the above examples, も may replace は, with only a slight change in nuance (も will place extra emphasis on the obviousness of the remark, according to the speaker). Compared to て当然(とうぜん)だ, のは当然(とうぜん)だ is slightly stronger, and separates the previous statement from what the speaker considers 'natural'. This is equivalent to the difference between 'being happy is natural' (slightly weaker), and 'it's natural that one would be happy' (slightly stronger) in English.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 会社のお金を勝手に使ったなら、クビになるのは当然だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you did use company money without permission, it's only natural that you get fired.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このタワーマンションは六本木にあるので、家賃が高いのは当然です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This high-rise condo is located in Roppongi, it is only natural that the rent is expensive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: おばあちゃんは毎朝１０キロも散歩しているから元気なのも当然だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My grandma walks 10 kilometers every morning, so it is no wonder she is so healthy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この１年間全然勉強をしてこなかったから落第も当然だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have not studied at all for the past year, so it's no wonder I flunked out.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 税金を納めていないんだから、逮捕されるのも当然です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since (he) didn't pay (his) taxes, it is only natural that (he) would be arrested.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 練習を怠ったんだから、ああいう結果になるのも当然だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since you neglected practice, it is only natural that you would see those kinds of results.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんなマッチョな体型では、エプロンが似合わないのも当然だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is only natural that an apron would not look good on such a muscular body.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼があんな風に振舞っていたなら、ほかの人からの受けが悪いのも当然だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If he was behaving in that way, it is only natural that he is poorly received by other people now.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 久しぶりに彼に会ったのだから、彼女が嬉しそうなのは当然だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since she got to see him after being apart for a while, it is only natural that she seems happy.

Name: たったの
Meaning: Only, Just, No more than
About: たった is a common adverb in Japanese that originates from an emphasized alteration of 唯(ただ) 'only', 'merely'. たった keeps the same meaning of ただ in that it just expresses that something is 'only (A)', 'just (A)', or 'no more than (A)'. This nuance is usually used when the actual number of (A) is exceptionally low compared to the speaker's expectation of anticipation. たった will often appear at the beginning of sentences, and will either modify the whole sentence, or a specific number when followed by の and then that number. As たった is an adverb that is usually used for emphasis, it often accompanies other similar grammar patterns like だけ, しか, etc.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カップ麺はたった３分で出来上がる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Cup noodles can be prepared in just 3 minutes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 僕、たった一人でここまで歩いてきたのかい？偉いね！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Kid, you walked here all alone? I'm proud of you!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: クラスメイト全員を招待したのに、たったの３人しか僕の誕生日パーティーにこなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I invited everyone in my class, but only 3 people showed up to my birthday party.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このホテルからビーチまでの距離はたったの１０メートルです！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's merely 10 meters in distance from this hotel to the beach!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その電車はたった今出発したので次の電車が来るまで少々お待ちください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That train has just departed, so please wait until the next train arrives.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「彼はたった一人の兄弟です。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'He is my only sibling.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
友達１：「１０００円貸してくれる？」
友達２：「たった５００円しかないよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Friend 1: 'Can you lend me 1000 yen?'
Friend 2: 'I only have 500 on me.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
そうまさん：「ケーキ、出来ました。」
えりなさん：「え、たった５分で出来たの？！」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Souma: 'The cake is done.'
Erina: 'Wha?! You finished it just in 5 minutes?!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自分の子供について、母親：「ケビンはずっと、たったひとりで家にいた！！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mother, about her son: 'Kevin was at home all alone the whole time!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 市場の商人：「安いよ、安いよ、りっぱな高級時計がたった千円。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Merchant on the market: 'Cheap! Cheap! Amazing, high-quality watches only 1000 yen.'

Name: 恐(おそ)れがある
Meaning: There is a risk or fear that, Be in danger of, Possibility of
About: 恐(おそ)れがある is a set phrase in Japanese that is used in a fairly literal sense to convey that 'there is a chance of (A)', or 'there is a fear of (A)'. This is a combination of the noun, 恐(おそ)れ 'fear', が, and the う-Verb ある 'to be'. 恐(おそ)れがある will be used when (A) is a negative outcome that may potentially occur in some particular situation, and is usually used to warn about being careful of something. 恐(おそ)れ is primarily used directly after verbs, or nouns followed by の. In most cases, 恐(おそ)れ carries the meaning of something that innately carries some kind of concern in relation to it, so depending on the context, alternative suitable translations could be 'concern', 'anxiety', 'worry', etc.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高温にすると爆発する恐れがあるので、直射日光が当たるところに置かないでください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since there is a possibility of explosion when this reaches high temperatures, please don't place this in direct sunlight.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 津波の恐れがある場合には、速やかに避難所まで避難してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When there is a risk of a tsunami, please rapidly evacuate to the evacuation area.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 若者が将来について恐れを抱くことは普通のことです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is normal for young people to have fears about the future.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夏場の現場では熱中症の恐れが強まるので、作業員の方はこまめに水分補給と休憩を取るようにしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Workers are encouraged to hydrate and take frequent breaks, as the risk of heat stroke increases at construction sites during summer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お辞儀をしすぎると腰を痛める恐れがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you bow too much, there is a risk of hurting your back.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 教わっても忘れる恐れがあるから、メモしておこう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if I am taught (it), there is a risk of forgetting (it), so I will take notes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このオイルだとエンジンに負担をかける恐れがあるからやめたほうがいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since there is fear that this oil may be taxing on the engine, it would be better to not use it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの勢いでお代わりされると、ご飯が足りなくなる恐れがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I am asked that way for seconds, there is a risk that there won't be enough food.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この絵の具は中身が漏れる恐れがあるから袋に入れてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is a risk that the contents of these paints will leak, so please place them in a bag.

Name: 恐(おそ)らく
Meaning: Probably, Perhaps, (Most) likely, (I) fear that
About: 恐(おそ)らく is an adverb which originally stems from the conjugation of the yodan verb, 恐(おそ)る 'to fear'. In most cases, 恐(おそ)らく is simply used as a formal way to say 'probably', or 'perhaps', and is usually partnered with other structures of conjecture such as だろう, かもしれない, etc. As 恐(おそ)らく behaves adverbially, it will most often appear at the beginning of sentences before a statement of conjecture is made. Although 恐(おそ)らく can, and often does, carry the meaning of 'I fear that (A)', it isn't necessarily always used in relation to negative things. In the case of this particular grammar pattern, the main nuance that 'I fear that (A)' conveys is modesty on behalf of the speaker in that they fear their assumption may be right, given the available information.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 妻は今夜会社の人たちと飲み会に行くと言っていたので、おそらく１１時ごろぐらいまでは帰ってこないと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My wife said she was going to a drinking party tonight with some people from work, so she probably won't be home until around 11:00 or so.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あいつの不自然な行動からして、おそらくあいつが犯人だろう！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Judging by that guy's unnatural behavior, he's probably the culprit!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: おそらく明日は雨なので、明日予定していたピクニックは中止しましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Perhaps it may rain tomorrow, so let's cancel the picnic we had planned for tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 恐らく彼はここにいないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He most likely isn't here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 恐らく明日雨が降る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Perhaps it will rain tomorrow. (I fear that...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼だったら、恐らくこんなことできっこないでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it's him, he most likely won't be able to do it. (I fear that...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「くそ、恐らくあなたの結婚式には行けないじゃないか。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Dang it, I think I probably won't be able to go to your wedding.' (I fear that...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 道路に沿って行けば恐らくガソリンスタンドが見つかるでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you go along the road, you will most likely see the gas station.

Name: ものか
Meaning: Definitely not, Absolutely not, Impossible, Do you really think~?
About: ものか is a set expression in Japanese that is used to strongly suggest that the previous statement absolutely will not happen, or is definitely not true. It is a combination of the noun もの 'thing', and the adverbial particle use of か for conveying 'doubt' or 'uncertainty'. Common translations include 'definitely not (A)', 'absolutely not (A)', and 'do you really think that (A)'. Literally, the meaning is quite close to 'as if' in English, as ものか just poses a strong question to which the speaker already completely disagrees with. ものか may appear after any word that could attach to もの, such as a verbs and い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives and nouns followed by な. Other forms which may be seen are もんか, もんですか, and ものですか, with women being more traditionally likely to use the もんですか and ものですか variants. Additionally, when following the た form of verbs, ものか will imply that the speaker cannot bear for (A) to eventuate, due to evaluating it as something highly negative.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: バカ言うな。俺がそんな派手な服を着るものか！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don't be stupid! Do you really think that I would wear something so flashy?!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事？毎日怒られてばかりだから楽しいもんか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Work? I get yelled at everyday, so I am definitely not having a good time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は毎日残業しているし、家に帰ったら家事を全部やっている。元気なものか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I work overtime every day and when I get home I do all the chores. Do you really think I have any energy left?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前みたいな奴は友達なものか！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A person like you is absolutely not my friend!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一人でこの量の仕事を明日までにできたもんか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As if it's possible to do this amount of work by tomorrow myself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんなまずい飯、食べられたもんか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As if I could have eaten something so awful.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あんなひどいこと言われたんだ。平気なものか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Such a terrible thing was said. It is impossible to be calm.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼が皮肉なんて言うものか。そういう奴じゃない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He absolutely will not use sarcasm. He is not that kind of a person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんな安っぽい言葉が心に響くものか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Such insignificant wording absolutely will not make an impression.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それくらいの研究で理解など深まるものか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Research to that degree absolutely will not deepen understanding.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの山が噴火するものか。あれは火山じゃない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That mountain absolutely will not erupt. It is not a volcano.

Name: お負(ま)けに
Meaning: In addition, On top of that, What is more, To make matters worse
About: お負(ま)けに is a phrase which often functions as a conjunction between the (A) and (B) parts of a sentence in order to show that (B) is 'in addition to (A)'. This structure stems from the common use of the noun お負(ま)け which indicates a 'discount' or 'freebie' that is added in addition to the base of (A). Despite お負(ま)け itself primarily being used for positive things お負(ま)けに may convey 'in addition', 'on top of that', or 'what's more' regardless of whether the original topic is a good thing or not. However, (A) and (B) will always either be both good things, or both bad things, never a mixture of both. Being a combination of お負(ま)け and に, this phrase will appear either at the beginning of a new sentence, or at the beginning of a second clause of a 2-part sentence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は仕事に遅刻して部長に怒られたし、おまけに取引先の人も怒らせちゃったから、今日は最悪の日だったよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today was one of the worst days because I got yelled at by my boss for being late to work, and to make it worse, I upset one of our clients.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日は彼氏に美味しいご飯をご馳走してもらって、おまけにプレゼントまでもらった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Yesterday, my boyfriend treated me to a delicious dinner and on top of that he even gave me a gift.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パソコンが全然立ち上がらない。おまけにスマホの充電がないから仕事が全然できない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My computer won't turn on. To make matters worse, my smartphone is out of battery, so I can't work at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 家を掃除した。御負けにランチを作っといた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cleaned the house. On top of that, I also made lunch in advance. (what is more)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 宝石を買ったら、御負けに香水をサービスしてくれた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They included perfume in addition to the jewel I bought. (on top of that)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自転車が盗まれただけではなく、御負けに雨が降りそうだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not only has my bike been stolen, but to make matters worse, it looks like it is going to rain. (what is more)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 競馬で負け、御負けに帰りに財布を落とし、最悪だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I lost at the horse races and, to make matters worse, I lost my wallet on the way home. Worst day ever.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 体重が激増し、御負けに髪まで薄くなった。ストレスですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: On top of my hair thinning, my weight suddenly increased. This is definitely stress. (what is more)

Name: に決(き)まっている
Meaning: Surely, Bound to, Certainly, Be decided
About: に決(き)まっている is a strong expression which indicates that (A) is something that the speaker either strongly believes to be true (but cannot confirm), or that they believe that (A) is only natural. These meanings primarily end up being translated as 'surely (A)', 'bound to be (A)', or 'certainly (A)'. As this structure is a combination of に and the ている-form of the う-Verb 決(き)まる 'to be decided', the closest literal translation is 'for (A) to be decisively the case'. に決(き)まっている may appear directly following verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives or nouns. に決(き)まっている primarily focuses on the speaker's subjective opinion about (A). This means that it takes into consideration their own preformed opinions or thoughts about (A), regardless of what the actual facts may be.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの選手は足が速いから勝つに決まっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That athlete is fast at running, so they are bound to win.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いくらクリフダイビングのプロでも、あの高さからダイブするのは怖いに決まってる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Diving off a cliff that high is surely scary, even for a professional cliff diver.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この家はあの有名な建設会社が建てた家だから、丈夫に決まってる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This house was built by that famous construction company, so it is bound to be sturdy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人はみんなに好かれているからいい人に決まっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person is liked by everyone, so he is bound to be a good person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの店のトロはどれも脂がのっているに決まっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That shop's tuna is bound to be rich in fat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このセーター、ウール１００％でしょ？高いに決まっています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That sweater is 100% wool, right? That is bound to be expensive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 毎日お菓子を食べることはダメに決まっている！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Eating sweets every day is certainly no good!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼のことだから、あいかわらずいい人に決まっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since it is him, he is bound to be a good person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: かなりひどいことを言ってしまったから、恨んでいるに決まっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since I said a very terrible thing, (they) decidedly feel bitter towards me.

Name: 事(こと)になっている
Meaning: To be expected to, To be scheduled to
About: ことになっている is an alternation of ことになる, a grammar point showing that something has been decided by someone other than the speaker. It is a combination of the nominalizing use of こと (for creating noun-phrases), and the ている-form of the う-Verb なる 'to become'. The primary difference between ことになる and ことになっている is that the latter focuses more on that something is 'expected to (A)', or 'scheduled to (A)'. In other words, it is 'becoming that (A)', but has not actually happened yet. This structure is often used after either the る or ない versions of verbs, in order to highlight an action which is either 'not expected/scheduled' to occur, or 'expected/scheduled' to occur. Let's take a look at the 'scheduled to' meaning first. When indicating that something is 'expected to (A)', this is an example of ている's use for expressing habitual or ongoing actions/states that reoccur under some specific set conditions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 授業は１２時から始まることになっています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The class is scheduled to start at 12.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社長は来週の飲み会に参加しないことになっています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The president is scheduled to not come to the party next week.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タクシーは左から乗ることになっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is expected for customers to get into the cab from the left side.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 生徒たちは授業中に教室を出れないことになっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Students are expected to not leave the classroom during class.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この寮では、起床時間は６時ということになっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In this dorm, it is expected that you are up by six o'clock.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 来年も契約を更新することになっています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is expected that the contract will be renewed next year as well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 来週あの工場を見学することになっています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We are expected to have a field trip at that factory next week.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 原稿は、郵送ではなく、メールで送ることになっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The manuscript is expected to be sent by email, not by post.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会議は東京にある官庁で行うことになっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The meeting is scheduled to take place in a government office in Tokyo.

Name: 気(き)
Meaning: Feel like ~, Spirit
About: When used after verbs, 気(き) often indicates either the will or desire to do that particular action. This use of 気(き) is often interpreted as 'to feel like doing (A)' in English. More literally, 気(き) may be translated as 'mind', as is similar to the way phrases like 'to have half a mind to (A)' in English, indicating that something is either positively or negatively drawing the speaker's attention toward doing (or avoiding) the action of (A). As 気(き) itself is a noun expressing the 'mind' or 'intention' to do (A), it may be followed by a variety of different verbs indicating an array of slightly unique nuances. Common patterns are 気(き)がある 'to have the feeling of (A)', 気(き)がない 'to not have the feeling of (A)', 気(き)がする 'to feel like (A)', 気(き)がしない 'to not feel like (A)', 気(き)が出(で)る 'for the feeling of (A) to come about', and 気(き)が出(で)ない 'for the feeling of (A) to not come about'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お風呂でゆっくりしていたら、勉強をする気がなくなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I lost my motivation (spirit) to study, when I was relaxing in the bath.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: よーし、やる気が出てきたぞ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Alright! I am starting to get motivated!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やばい、明日までに終わる気がしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Shoot, I don't feel like I can finish this by tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰かに見られている気がする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I feel like I am being watched by someone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何もやる気が起きない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't muster any motivation (spirit). (Feel like doing)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 応援されて、やる気が出た。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was cheered on and found motivation (spirit). (Feel like doing)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 娘は好き嫌いが多すぎる気がする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I feel like my daughter is too picky.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の送別会には行く気がしない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't feel like going to his farewell party.

Name: 気(げ)
Meaning: Seemingly, Giving appearance of, [Expresses emotions or feelings]
About: げ, sometimes seen in the kanji form 気(げ) is a suffix in Japanese that expresses that something is 'giving off the feeling of (A)', or 'seems like (A)'. げ is frequently used in relation to emotions, feelings, and things that the speaker generally can't be 100% sure of due to them not being directly visible. げ is primarily seen used after the stem form of い-Adjectives, but may also appear following the stem forms of nouns of な-Adjectives. In all of these cases, the addition of げ creates a new な-Adjective meaning '(A) seeming'. Due to this, げ may then be followed by either な or に, depending on whether it is altering a verb or a noun later in the sentence. げ is more subjective (based on the speaker's opinion) than そう, and is considered to be very low confidence. This may be considered a byproduct of the original 気(き), meaning of 'attention', referring to the way that the speaker 'senses (A)', regardless of what is actually true for (A) on the inside.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自信ありげに見えたかもしれないけど、実はめちゃくちゃ緊張してて吐きそうだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I may have given off the appearance of being confident, but actually, I was super nervous and felt like I was going to throw up.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高校生たちがファストフード店で楽しげに話しているのを見て、自分が高校生の頃を思い出した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I saw highschool students seemingly having a good time talking to each other at a fast food restaurant, it reminded me of the time when I was a highschooler.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高橋くんは不安げに手を上げました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Seemingly nervous, Takahashi-kun raised his hand.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 教養がありすぎて可愛気がないのもどうかと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder about things that are too refined and therefore don't give off the appearance of being cute.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼が恥ずかし気に自分の弱点を教えてくれた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Seemingly embarrassed, he told us about his weak points.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 涼し気な顔でマラソンを走りきるんだから大したもんだよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was considerable that he finished running the marathon while seemingly undeterred.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はとても素直だが、どことなく儚気なのが気になります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She is very honest, but I am concerned by her somehow fickle appearance.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供たちが羨まし気に見ているから、お菓子を分けてあげた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Looking at the children they were giving the appearance of being envious, so I divided up the candy and gave it to them.

Name: 事(こと)だから
Meaning: It is exactly because
About: ことだから is a set expression used for indicating that the speaker is fairly certain about (B), based specifically on their experience with (A). This is often translated as 'it is exactly because (A) that (B)', or 'precisely because it is (A), (B)'. ことだから is a combination of the noun こと 'thing', だ, and から. The literal meaning can be interpreted as 'from that it's (A), also (B)'. This just implies that due to (A) being a predetermined fact, (B) too can be assumed to be true. When making assumptions, ことだから will often be seen following verbs in their dictionary forms, or nouns followed by の. In the case of nouns, it will usually be the name of someone that the speaker knows well. Alternatively, ことだから may appear following verbs in any of their standard forms when the situation of (A) is considered as a good opportunity to also do (B), according to the speaker. Lastly, ことだから may simply imply (strongly) that (A) is the reason for (B). In these cases, either verbs in their standard forms, nouns followed by の, or な-Adjectives followed by な may precede ことだから. Despite having these three slightly different nuances, the speaker's intended meaning will usually be clear in the (B) part of the sentence. Due to this, ことだから may always be thought to simply mean that 'by the logic of (A), definitely (B)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人がすることだから、どうせ人を騙して儲けているに違いない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Precisely because it is something that person does, there is no doubt that he is making money scamming people.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いつも遅れてくる田中くんのことだから、今日も遅れてくるだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is exactly because Tanaka-kun always arrives late, that he will probably arrive late today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お父さんとお母さんが珍しくうちに来ていることだから、久しぶりにみんなで映画でも見よう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Dad, mom, considering that you guys are here, which is a rare occasion, why don't we watch a movie together for the first time in a while.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 撮影が無事終わったことだから、打ち上げでもしましょう！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Considering that we have finished filming, it is a good opportunity for us to have a party!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客様のプライバシーに関わることなので、これ以上詳しいことは言えません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because this is something that has to do with the privacy of our customer, we can't give you further details.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部長のことだから、またミスをしたらクビにさせられると思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is exactly because it is my boss, he will probably fire me if I mess up again.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 神様のことだから、必ず助けてくれます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is exactly because it is God, that He will surely help me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたのことだから間違いなくうまくいくと思うよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is exactly because it's you that I definitely think it will go well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あれは基礎問題ということだから、簡単だったでしょ？
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is exactly because that is a basic problem that it was easy, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の勘違いということだから、許してやってほしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is exactly because he misunderstood that I want you to let it slide.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつもウソをついている彼のことだから、今回も信じがたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is exactly because he is always lying that it is hard to believe him this time too.

Name: ものだから
Meaning: Because, The reason is
About: ものだから is a strong phrase that is used when explaining something or giving an excuse for one's reasoning. This grammar structure can simply be thought of as an extension of から 'because', with the noun もの 'thing' having its usual role of emphasizing what is said before it. Common translations include 'because (A)', and 'the reason is (A)'. ものだから may appear directly after verbs and い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives and nouns that are followed with な. Occasionally, ものだから will be abbreviated to もので, or もんで, without any change in the overall meaning. The change of だ to its conjunctive form で indicates that there is something coming after, despite the fact that what comes after may sometimes be omitted if it is obvious.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: すみません、今仕事をしているものだから、また後でかけ直します。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sorry, because I am working right now, I will call you back later.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 週末は人が多いものだから、週末に行くのはあまりお勧めしません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I would not recommend going on the weekends, because it is usually crowded on weekends.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 生の魚は苦手なものだから、寿司は食べられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't eat sushi because I don't like raw fish.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は新人なものだから、まだこの会社のルールをよくわかっていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because he is new, he doesn't really understand the rules of this company.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は夕方から娘の発表会があるもので、私はそろそろ帰りますね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because my daughter has a recital this evening, I am going to go home soon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近は日本語を話す機会が減ってきているもんで、日本語を忘れてきた感じがする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I feel as if I have forgotten some Japanese, because I have fewer opportunities to speak Japanese these days.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まあ、安いもんで...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well, because it's cheap…

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 郊外に家を買ったものだから、通勤に２時間もかかる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I bought a house in the suburbs, the commute to work takes two hours.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 税関に引っかかったものだから、遅くなってしまいました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I was stopped by the customs officer, I ended up being late.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 素人が制作したものだから、やっぱりすぐに壊れてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because it is something created by a novice, as expected, it broke right away.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 英語が苦手なものだから、海外旅行に行くのは楽しくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I am bad at English, taking trips abroad isn't fun.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 墨で黒く塗ってしまったものだから、何て書いてあったか分からない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because it is painted black with ink, I don't know what was written.

Name: ものですから
Meaning: Because, My excuse is, My explanation is
About: ものですから is a strong, slightly emphasized version of ものだから, a phrase that is used when explaining something or giving an excuse for one's reasoning. This grammar structure can simply be thought of as an extension of から 'because', with the noun もの 'thing' having its usual role of emphasizing what is said before it. Common translations include 'because (A)', and 'the reason is (A)'. ものですから may appear directly after verbs and い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives and nouns that are followed with な. Occasionally, ものですから will be abbreviated to もので, or もんで, without any change in the overall meaning. The change of だ to its conjunctive form で indicates that there is something coming after, despite the fact that what comes after may sometimes be omitted if it is obvious. Despite the slight difference in emphasis, ものだから and ものですから can be thought of as a single interchangable grammar structure in most situations.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昔大工として働いていたものですから、リフォームなら私に任せてください！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I used to work as a carpenter, if you are renovating, leave it to me!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この道路は狭いものですから、スピードを落として運転をしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because this road is narrow, please drive slowly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 苦いものが苦手なものですから、コーヒーやお茶は飲めません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I don't like bitter things, I can't drink things such as coffee and tea.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この車は中古なものですから、不具合だらけです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because this car is second hand, it is full of defects.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は日本に住んでいたもので、日本語はまあまあ話せます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because he lived in Japan, he speaks Japanese fairly well.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は運転をするのが嫌いなもんで、出かけるときにはいつもタクシーと電車を使っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I don't like driving, I always use taxis and trains when I go out.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いや、危なかったもんで...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well, because it was dangerous…

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 売上が良かったものですから、発注しすぎてしまいました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because sales were good, I accidentally over-ordered.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 育児は初めてなものですから、いろいろと教えてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because it is my first time raising a child, please teach me various things.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 熊の足跡があったものですから、山に入るのはやめました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because there were bear tracks, I gave up on going into the mountains.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アクセントが違ったものですから、地元の方ではないのかと思いました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because his accent was different, I thought, he isn't from my hometown.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明け方まで仕事をしていたものですから、もう眠いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because I was doing work until dawn, I am already sleepy.

Name: ものがある
Meaning: Strong judgement, There is something, Feel strongly that
About: ものがある is an interesting grammar structure in Japanese that is used to declare that something has a particular trait of (A), according to the speaker's subjective opinion. Often, ものがある is translated as 'I feel strongly that (A)', or 'there is something (A) about (B)'. The latter meaning is very close to the literal translation here, as もの 'thing', がある 'there is' implies that the speaker strongly senses the presence of (A) within (B), even if they themselves cannot figure out why they feel that way. ものがある is primarily seen following verbs in either their dictionary or negated forms, い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives followed by な. As ものがある emphasizes the existence of (A) within (B), it is very common for the emphasized には to also be used in place of に when highlighting the topic.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この映画は人の心を動かすものがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This film has something that moves people's hearts.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の話には納得いかないものがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is something about his story that I don't agree with.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自分が好きなことを仕事にできるのは、嬉しいものがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is something delightful about being able to do what you love for a living.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供だけで川で遊ばせるのは、危険なものがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is something dangerous about letting children play in the river alone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の運動神経の良さは目を見張るものがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: His athleticism is remarkable.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: モナリザには、神秘的なものがあるよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I feel strongly that that (the) Mona Lisa is mysterious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 文房具には魅力的なものがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I feel strongly that stationery is fascinating.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この絵って、うまく説明できないけどすばらしいものがあるよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't explain well, but this painting gives me a strong feeling of amazement.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の遺した言葉には考えさせられるものがあった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I felt strongly that his last words were inspiring.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 売店には全然売れないものがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For a shop, I feel strongly that it doesn't sell well at all.

Name: 傾向(けいこう)がある
Meaning: Tendency, Trend, Inclination
About: 傾向(けいこう)がある is a slightly formal grammar pattern used when indicating that there is some sort of 'trend' or 'tendency' existing within (A). Being a combination of the noun 傾向(けいこう) 'inclination', and がある 'to have', the literal meaning is almost identical to the standard English interpretation. As 傾向(けいこう) itself is a noun, this structure may appear after verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives followed by な, and nouns followed by の. Although がある is the most frequent structure seen with 傾向(けいこう), alternatives such as が見(み)られる 'the trend of (A) can be observed' are also widely used. It should also be noted that 傾向(けいこう)がある may be used both in instances where the trend is either positive or negative.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この国では首都に近づけば近づくほど物価が上がっていく傾向がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In this country, there is a tendency of prices rising as you get closer to the capital.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 鬱で悩まされている人は気分の浮き沈みが激しい傾向がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: People suffering from depression are inclined to have severe mood swings.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの会社が発売する教科書は使いやすくてユニークな傾向があると言われている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is said that textbooks released by that company have a tendency to be user-friendly and unique.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近は世界中で小家族化の傾向がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, there has been a trend toward smaller families around the world.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近ではコンピューターやスマホが文字を自動変換してくれるので、漢字の書き方を忘れてしまう傾向が見られる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, computers and smartphones automatically convert characters, so people tend to forget how to write kanji characters.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本は少子化の傾向にある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Japan is experiencing a declining birthrate. (Ongoing trend)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この研究によると、勤務時間が短いほうが仕事の効率がよくなる傾向にあるようだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: According to this study, shorter work hours tend to improve work efficiency. (Statistics)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: だが、調べたデータによると、そのような傾向も見られる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: But, according to the research data, trends like that can also be observed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 年月が経つとともにこの傾向が見られるようになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As the years passed, this trend became visible.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ハイエンドスマホの需要は最近ますます低下の傾向にある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The demand for high-end smartphones has been in a declining trend recently.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 健康問題の数量は老化とともに増加する傾向がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The amount of health problems (that arise) has the tendency to increase with aging.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 次に、インフレが加速すると同時に物価も増加する傾向がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Then, while inflation accelerates, prices of commodities also have the tendency to increase.

Name: ～に値(あたい)する
Meaning: Be worthy of, Deserving of, Amounts to
About: に値(あたい)する is a phrase that means something 'deserves' something or 'is worthy' of something. It is made up of the particle に and the する verb 値(あたい)する. Grammatically, に値(あたい)する will come directly after nouns or verbs in their dictionary form. The thing marked by に will be the thing that is 'worthy'. The negative form, に値(あたい)しない, can also be used. As expected, に値(あたい)しない means something 'is not worthy' or 'does not deserve' something.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その手法は詐欺に値するから、見直したほうがいいと思いますよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That method is worthy of being considered as a scam, so I think you should reconsider.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは読むに値する論文だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This paper is worth reading.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の行動は尊敬に値しない。人として当たり前なことをしたまでだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: His actions are not worthy of respect. He simply did what any normal person would do.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの舞台は大根役者の集まりなので、見るに値しない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That play is a gathering of bad actors, so it is not worth watching.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本の不動産の価値は滅多に上がらない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The value of real estate in Japan rarely rises.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 商品に値札をつけるのを忘れた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I forgot to put a price tag on a product.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 村田さんの作品に値をつけるのはとても難しいと言われている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is said that it is hard to put worth on Murata-san’s works.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼のこれまでの努力は、間違いなく高い評価に値するものであり、私たちはその功績を正当に認めるべきだと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: His efforts until now are unmistakably worthy of high praise, and I believe that we should duly recognize his achievements.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今年１年の成績に基づいて、あなたがプロレベルに値するかどうかを検討します。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Based on this year’s performance, we will consider if you are worthy of being professional level.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の行動は、尊敬に値する。
Questions.EnglishHTML: His actions are worthy of respect.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたは、総理に値する人間です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You are a person worthy of being prime minister.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女の論文は、十分に出版に値する内容だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Her thesis has sufficient content that is worthy of publication.

Name: ～てしょうがない
Meaning: Extremely, Very, Really, It can't be helped
About: てしょうがない, is a common colloquial expression used when '(A) cannot be helped', or something is 'extremely (A)'. This structure is simply an abbreviated version of 仕様(しよう), a noun meaning 'way' or 'method', as しょう is easier to say than しよう. Literally, the meaning is close to 'it's (A), and nothing can be done about it'. Generally, this just implies that the extent of (A) is so high that it cannot be overlooked, or cannot be avoided. This structure may be seen following the て-form of verbs, い-Adjectives, of the で-from of な-Adjectives. Alternatively, 仕方(しかた)がない may be used, but there is an extremely small difference between these two structures, with the noun 仕方(しかた) also meaning 'way' or 'method'. Traditionally, 仕方(しかた)がない is perceived to be slightly more polite, so may be more likely to be found in literature.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語が上手になりたくてしょうがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't help but want to become good at Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部屋が暑くてしょうがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My room is extremely hot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: スイーツが好きでしょうがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I love sweets so much that it can't be helped.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は今妊娠をしているが、寿司を食べたくて仕方がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although I am pregnant right now, I really want to eat sushi.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 眠くて仕方がなかったので、少しだけ昼寝をしました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I was extremely sleepy, I took a small nap.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この古いパソコンは不便で仕方がないから捨てることにします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since this old computer is extremely useless, I will throw it away.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつも同じものを忘れてしょうがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't help but always forget the same thing (again and again).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ゲームがしたくてしょうがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to play video games so bad it can't be helped.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 楽しくてしょうがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Extremely fun.
(So fun it can't be helped)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの望遠鏡が欲しくてしょうがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
I really want that telescope.
(I want that telescope so much that it can't be helped)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 包帯をしているから、痒くてしょうがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Because it is bandaged, it is extremely itchy.
(Because I am wearing a bandage, it itches so much that it can't be helped)

Name: だけましだ
Meaning: At least, It's better than..., One should feel grateful for
About: だけましだ is a set phrase indicating that 'at least (A)', or that 'one should feel grateful for (A)'. This expression is often used in cases where the overall situation is negative, but it is still better than the alternative. This structure is a combination of the particle だけ 'only', and the な-Adjective 増(ま)し, meaning 'better', or 'preferable'. Originally, まし is just the conjunctive form of 増(ま)す, an う-Verb meaning to grow or increase (like 増(ふ)える). Due to this, the literal meaning is 'even just (A) is a plus, compared to what could have occured'. だけましだ will be used primarily after verbs, い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives followed by な. In the vast majority of cases, まし will simply be written in hiragana, or even katakana as マシ. The katakana version often further emphasizes that one should be grateful for (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 天気はあまり良くないが、久しぶりに旅行に来れただけましだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although the weather isn't the best, I should be grateful that I am able to travel for the first time in a long time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このアパートはボロボロだけど、職場に近いだけましだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This apartment is a wreck, but at least it is close to my work place.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 味覚はないかもしれないが、元気なだけましだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although I can't taste, at least I am feeling well.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日はいつもより寒いけど、風が吹いていないだけまだましだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is colder than usual today, but at least it's not windy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ご馳走とは言えないが、食べるものがあるだけましだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't say that I feasted, but at least I had something to eat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 古い校舎だが、冷房があるだけましだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The school building is old, but at least it has air conditioning.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あんな大事故が起きたのだから、命があるだけましだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since such a big accident occured, you should be grateful that you are still alive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 泥棒に入られたが、金庫が無事なだけましだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A robber broke in, but I should be grateful that the safe is intact.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 上手な部員はいなくても、部に後輩がいるだけましです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if there are no skilled staff, there are at least some kouhai in the department.

Name: 幸(さいわ)いなことに
Meaning: Luckily, Fortunately
About: 幸(さいわ)いなことに, or simply 幸(さいわ)い is a set phrase in Japanese for indicating that 'luckily (A)', or 'fortunately (A)'. This use directly reflects the meaning of the な-Adjective 幸(さいわ)い as 'blessedness', or 'luck'. In most cases, 幸(さいわ)いなことに will appear at the beginning of sentences, before going on to explain exactly what was 'lucky'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 幸い、ライフジャケットを着ていたので溺れずに済んだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Fortunately, I had my life jacket on so I did not drown.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 幸い、留学する前に大親友に会う事ができました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Luckily, I was able to meet my best friend before going abroad.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 幸いなことに、おじいちゃんの手術は成功しました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Fortunately, my grandpa's surgery was a success.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 幸いなことに、優しい人に道を教えてもらったので、終電を逃すことなく家に帰る事ができました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Fortunately, a kind person showed me the way and I was able to get home without missing the last train.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 嬉しいことに、小さい頃からずっと行きたかった大学に入れる事ができた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To my delight, I was able to get into the university I had always wanted to go to since I was a little.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 悲しいことに、おばあちゃんから貰ったネックレスを無くしてしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sadly, I lost a necklace that my grandmother gave me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 幸いなことに遊ぶ時間が結構ある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Fortunately, I have quite a lot of time to enjoy myself.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 幸いなことに、船上に医者がいた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Luckily, there was a doctor on board the ship.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 幸いなことに人を集めることができました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Luckily, I was able to gather people.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は幸い、エアバッグのおかげで怪我をせずに済んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Luckily for him, thanks to the airbag, he got away without injury.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 幸いなことに元気な赤ちゃんが生まれました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Fortunately, a healthy baby was born.

Name: 様(よう)では
Meaning: If, If it is true that
About: ようでは is a combination of the auxiliary verb 様(よう) 'manner', or 'seeming', and では, a conjunction that is frequently used as an abbreviation of それなら in expressing 'if'. Due to this, ようでは itself often has the meaning of 'if', with extra focus on the fact that (A) is something unconfirmed, or only being guessed at. This may be translated as 'if it is the case that (A)', or 'if that which seems to be (A) is true'. In most cases, ようでは will be used to make an evaluation that if (A) is true, then some particular negative result will arise from it. ようでは will primarily appear after verbs in any of their standard forms. ようでは puts extra focus on the appearance or condition of (A), based on what is observable by the speaker. In this way, it is often the speaker's subjective (negative) opinion about what they perceive to be true.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな毎日同じミスをするようでは、いつまで経っても店長にはなれませんよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you keep making the same mistake everyday, you will never be able to become a manager.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これらの文法が分からないようでは、Ｎ２に合格することはできません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you do not understand these grammars, you will not be able to pass N2.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これぐらいの高さで怖がっているようでは消防士にはなれませんよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You can't become a firefighter if you're afraid of heights like this.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そこまで甘やかすようでは、ろくな大人にならないですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you are spoiled to that extent, you can't become a decent adult. (...it appears that...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんなに日時を間違えるようでは、仕事なんてできないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you can make these kinds of mistakes about the time and date, you can't do your job. (...it appears that...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんな問題も解けないようでは、次のテストが思いやられる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you can't solve a problem like this, I am worried about your next test. (...it appears that...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人の成功を羨んでいるようでは、自分の成功にはつながらない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you envy other people's achievements, it won't lead to your own achievements. (...it appears that...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強の日課を守れないようでは、試験に受からないと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you can't keep up with your daily study routine, I don't think you can pass the test. (...it appears that...)

Name: 流石(さすが)
Meaning: as one would expect, only natural, that is just like..., even
About: さすが, also often appearing in the kanji form 流石(さすが), is an adverb that indicates the speaker's feeling of being impressed that something has lived up to its reputation, or what was expected of it. In English, this comes across as 'as expected of (A)', or 'that is just like (A)'. As 流石(さすが) is an adverb, it may appear at the beginning of phrases (either with or without に), or directly preceded a noun when の is used.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: すごい！さすが先輩！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Wow! That's what I would expect from you senpai!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 流石に今日は雨が降りすぎだろ...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As one would expect, it is raining way too much today.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さすがの君でもこの問題は難しいだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even for someone like you, this problem is difficult, isn't it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: さすが田中くん！発注ミスの天才だね！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As expected, Tanaka-kun! You are a genius at making order errors!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いいカーブだ。流石ダルビッシュ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: What a nice curveball. That's just like Darvish.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 流石に食いすぎたな。椅子から立てない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As expected, I ate too much. I can't get up from a chair.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんなおめでたい席に、流石にあの格好はない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As one would expect, that is not suitable for this highly auspicious seat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一流のオーケストラの演奏は流石ですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The performance was as would be expected from a first rate orchestra.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 流石に落し物が多すぎる。注意しないと。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As one would expect, you lose too many things. You need to be careful.

Name: ことは〜が
Meaning: It is true...but, although, but
About: ことは～が is a set expression which indicates that 'while something is (A), also (B)'. In English, this is usually interpreted as '(A) is true, but (B)', or 'although (A), (B)'. When this grammar structure is used, the same word will be repeated before both ことは and が (or けど). Due to this, the literal translation is similar to 'that which is (A) is (A), but (B)'.
