This simply emphasizes that the speaker recognizes (A) as being true, but would like to express information that is contrary to that. ことは～が can appear with any type of word, but だ will need to be used following nouns before が, while な, である, だった or ではない tends to follow な-Adjectives. In most cases, ことは～が expresses that the base fact of (A) is true, but the speaker has some sort of opinion or impression that is in opposition to that fact.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 漢字は読めることは読めるが、簡単な漢字しか読めないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is true that I can read kanji, but I can only read easy ones.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しい家は広いことは広いけど、家具が多いから狭く見える。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is true that my new house is spacious, but because there is a lot of furniture, it looks small.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このスマホは便利であることは便利であるけど、本体がデカすぎて片手では操作できない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is true that this smartphone is useful, but because it is big, I can't use it with just one hand.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここは道路なことは道路だけど、狭すぎて車が通れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is true that this road is a road, but it is too narrow that a car can't pass through.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パターンがあることはあるが、なかなか解読できません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is true that there are patterns, but I can't easily decode them.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 雨に濡れたことは濡れたが、大したことはなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is true that it got soaked by the rain, but it wasn't a big deal.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 熱が出たことは出たが、インフルエンザではありませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is true that I had a fever, but it wasn't the flu.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 締切を延ばせたことは延ばせたが、余裕ないですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is true that the deadline was extended, but it will still be tight.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ボルトは外れることは外れたが、これ以上分解できない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is true that the bolts were able to be removed, but it cannot be dismantled any further.

Name: 更(さら)に
Meaning: Even more or further, Again, More and more
About: 更(さら)に is word that is often used adverbially in Japanese to convey the meaning of 'more and more', 'even more than (A)', or 'again'. This use is an extension of the base meaning that the kanji 更(さら) has in indicating that something is 'approaching change'. Because of this, the expression used following 更(さら)に will always be something that is either further along than the initial statement either in regard to time, quantity, or volume. Taking this into consideration, 'in addition to (A)' may also be used as a fairly standard translation. As さらに is used adverbially, it often appears at the beginning of part (B) of a sentence, after the 'base' information has already been indicated.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電気代がさらに高くなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The electricity bill has become even more expensive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 刺身には刺身専用の醤油をかけると、さらに美味しくなります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sashimi tastes even better when served with soy sauce specially designed for sashimi.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パソコンにウイルス対策ソフトを入れたら、パソコンが更に遅くなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I installed antivirus software on my computer, my computer became even slower.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 病院に行き始めてから彼は更に元気になった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ever since he started going to the hospital, he has gotten even better.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事をクビになって更に生活が苦しくなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My life became even more difficult after being fired.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 税金がさらに高くなった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Taxes got higher again. (more and more)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: さらに気を付けてもらわないと困ります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There will be trouble if you aren't more careful. (more and more)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: さらに給与が上がり、とても助かります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My salary has gone up even more and that is very helpful. (more and more)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: さらに乾燥がひどくなり、保湿するのが大変だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The dry air has become even more terrible and moisturizing is difficult. (more and more)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 国家からの融資でさらにグラフェンの研究を進める。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Financing from the state will push the graphene research further. (more and more)

Name: 精々(せいぜい)
Meaning: (At) most , (At) best, No more than, Barely
About: 精々(せいぜい) 'at the limit' is an adverb used to convey that something is 'at the most (A)', or 'at best (A)'. This just indicates that the point that (A) has reached cannot be progressed beyond, due to having already reached some physical or metaphorical barrier. This can also often come across as 'no more than (A)', especially in cases where no actual barrier exists, but the speaker cannot imagine that anything higher (or lower) than (A) is possible. As 精々(せいぜい) is an adverb, it often appears at the beginning of sentence, or at the beginning of the second clause of a sentence, before the thing that is thought to be at its maximum is described.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このバッグはせいぜい千円くらいだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This bag probably costs 1000 yen at most.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: せいぜい３ヶ月は働いてもらわないと困ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You need to work for 3 months at the most.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が作れる料理はせいぜいこんなもんです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is at best what I can cook.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は今働いているから、勉強できても一日に精々一時間ぐらいしか勉強ができない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I am working now, even if I could study, I can only study 1 hour a day at most.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「３８歳だって？精々３０くらいなものだと思っていたよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: '38 years old you say? I thought he was around 30 at most!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「電車が来ないうちに観光出来るのは精々４時間ぐらい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Before the train comes, we can do sightseeing for four hours at most.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 証人：「加害者はたぶん精々３０歳ぐらいでしょ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Witness: 'The assailant is about 30 years old at most.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 凄く怒ったファン：「ダーデンは精々二流のコーチだぞ！子供でさえもっと上手くコーチングできるぞ!」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Extremely angry fan: 'Durden is a second-rate coach at best! Even a child can coach better than him!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「この車を買うのに彼が支払ったのは精々３万ドルだと思う。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I think that in order to buy that car he spent 30 grand at most.'

Name: 僅(わず)かに
Meaning: Only, Slightly, A little, Barely, Merely
About: 僅(わず)か is a な-Adjective in Japanese that is often used adverbially at the beginning of sentences in order to indicate an excessively small amount of something. 僅(わず)か itself may be translated as 'trifling', or 'meager', with the adverbial variant being interpreted as 'merely', 'barely', or 'slightly'. As an adverb, 僅(わず)か will appear as 僅(わず)かに. Due to 僅(わず)か highlighting an extremely small amount of something, it is often used when the speaker is trying to be modest in indicating that something is nothing more than a trifling amount, such as the difference between their and another's opinions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この建物は真下からみると、わずかに傾いているように見える。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This building appears to tilt slightly when viewed from directly below.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 隣の人のテレビの音がわずかに聞こえる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can slightly hear the sound of my neighbor's TV.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 建物と建物の間から富士山がわずかに見えた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Mt. Fuji was slightly visible between the buildings.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 始めた頃に比べると、僅かに上手になった感じがします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Compared to when I started, I feel I am only slightly better.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの提案に賛成した議員はほんの僅かだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Only a small number of assembly members agreed to that suggestion.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼に残された時間は残り僅かだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He had very little time left.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女とは僅かに意見が違う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (My) opinion differs slightly from her's.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ＬＩＮＵＸのインタフェイスはＷＩＮＤＯＷＳのと僅かに異なる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Linux's interface slightly differs from Windows'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 似ているけど、僅かに形が違うような気がした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They look similar, but I had a feeling that their shapes were slightly different.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僅かに毛が生えてきた。育毛に成功したのかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My hair is coming in slightly. My hair restoration might just be working.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 校長先生の怒鳴り声が僅かに聞こえる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I could hear the angry voice of the principal just barely.

Name: 及(およ)び
Meaning: And, As well as
About: 及(およ)び is a word that functions as a conjunction meaning 'and' or 'as well as', but is originally the conjunctive form of 及(およ)ぶ, an う-Verb meaning 'to reach (A)', or 'to extend to (A)'. Although it is frequently translated simply as 'and', 及(およ)び is a grammar pattern that more literally reflects the meaning of the base verb 'to extend to (A)'. Being a conjunction, 及(およ)び will primarily appear at the beginning of a second clause of a sentence, or directly following a noun that something else is 'in addition to'. As 及(およ)び is considered a formal structure, it will primarily appear in documents, articles, and notifications.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 免許証及び印鑑を持ってきてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please bring your driver's license and seal.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 学校説明会に参加されたい方、及び体験入学をされたい方は８時から５時の間にこちらの電話番号までお電話をください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you would like to participate in a school information session and enroll in a trial lesson, please call this number between 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夕食及び朝食は別料金になります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Dinner and breakfast are charged separately.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 帽子及びメガネは外してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hats and glasses must be removed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 当店の定休日は月曜日及び水曜日となっています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We are closed on Mondays as well as Wednesdays.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 布団及び枕等はございます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are things like futons and pillows.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 指輪及びネックレス等は外してください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please remove things like rings and necklaces.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 受付及び入館は８時からです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Reception and entry begins at 8.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 手帳及び日記等を見せてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please show me things like your notebook and your diary.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 旅館及びホテルへの連絡はご遠慮ください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Please refrain from contacting the Ryokan as well as the hotel.

Name: 忽(たちま)ち
Meaning: Immediately, Quickly, Suddenly, In a moment or flash
About: たちまち is an adverb in that is used to convey the feeling of something happening 'suddenly', or 'in a flash'. The primary nuance with たちまち compared to other similar structures is that たちまち indicates that something happened spontaneously, and was not able to be controlled. In many cases, たちまち will indicate something entering a new, ongoing state, or something being completed. たちまち will often appear directly before the verb phrase that it is describing as being the new state.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのレコード会社に所属すると、アーティストたちはたちまち有名になる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Artists who belong to that record company quickly become famous.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私と田中さんはたちまち仲良くなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san and I immediately became friends.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冷蔵庫に入れておいたシナモンロールはたちまち妻の胃袋へと消えた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The cinnamon rolls I had put in the fridge quickly disappeared into my wife's stomach.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 少し油断したら、ライバルに忽ち追い越された。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (I) was only slightly negligent, but (my) rival immediately overtook me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小さな村で噂が忽ち広がるのは当然だよ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's only natural that rumors would spread in a flash in small villages!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うちの庭を掘ったら、忽ち温泉が出てきて驚いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When I dug up my yard, an onsen suddenly sprung up and I was surprised.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うちの犬は郵便配達員を見ると忽ちフェンスにそって走り始めるのだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My dog starts to run along the fence immediately when he sees a postman.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あんなに仲が良かったのに、あの事件のせいで忽ち解散だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though they got along that well, because of that one incident they immediately broke up.

Name: いきなり
Meaning: For no reason, Suddenly, All of a sudden
About: いきなり, a word appearing almost exclusively in hiragana, is an adverb that conveys the meaning of 'suddenly', 'all of a sudden', or 'for no reason'. いきなり indicates when something happens abruptly, and without any prior warning. As いきなり is an adverb, it will primarily appear at the beginning of sentences, or directly before the verb that it is describing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いきなり電話してごめん。ちょっと相談したい事があるんだけど今時間大丈夫？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sorry for calling you suddenly. I need to talk to you about something, but is now a good time for you?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いきなり雨が降ってきたからびしょびしょだよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It suddenly started raining and I'm drenched.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ペットのワンちゃんがいきなり吠え出したからびっくりして起きた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was startled awake when my pet dog suddenly started barking.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 行き成りの展開に驚きを隠せない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't hide my surprise at the sudden development.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 行き成り電波が切れてしまうのは困る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Suddenly losing phone service gets on my nerves.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そんな行き成り停車したら危ないですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Abruptly stopping like that is dangerous!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 行き成り難問に突き当たってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I suddenly, and unfortunately, ran into a hard problem.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 弟は、行き成り手づかみでご飯を食べ始めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My younger brother suddenly started eating rice with his hands for no reason.

Name: といった
Meaning: Such as, Like, So much as
About: といった is a fairly casual expression which indicates lists in the same way as structures like などの, or のような. Stemming from と, and the past-tense form of the う-Verb 言(い)う, といった is often translated as '(B) such as (A)', or '(B) like (A)'. といった will always be followed directly by a noun expressing the general group that (B) belongs to, with the literal translation being similar to '(B) that can be called (A)'. といった will appear with nouns both in (A) and (B). As can be seen in the last two examples above, constructions such as や and とか may be used if there is more than one (B) that fits in the category of (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の父は、ゲートボールといったスポーツが好きだそうです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Apparently my father likes sports such as gateball.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたの国ではおはぎといった和菓子は売られていますか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are Japanese sweets such as ohagi sold in your country?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 旦那は洗濯や料理といった家事は一切しません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My husband does not do any household chores such as laundry or cooking.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は生姜とかパクチーといった香味野菜を使った料理が苦手です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am not a fan of food that uses pot-herbs such as ginger and cilantro.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勝敗といったものにこだわるのはやめよう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let's stop fussing over things such as winning or losing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 蕎麦といった麺類があまり好きではありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't really like noodles such as soba.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 相撲といった日本の文化に興味がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have interest in Japanese culture such as sumo.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 宣伝といったものに振り回されてはいけません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You must not be manipulated by things such as advertisements.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これといった理由もないのに約束を破ってはいけない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since you don't even have so much as a reason you cannot break your promise.

Name: を込(こ)めて
Meaning: Full of, Filled with, With ～
About: をこめて, or を込(こ)めて when appearing in its kanji form, is a phrase that expresses when something is 'full of (A)', or 'filled with (A)'. The structure is comprised of を, and the て-form of the る-Verb 込(こ)める, which means 'to pack into', or 'to load with'. In this way, the literal meaning is fairly consistent with the standard English translations. をこめて will appear directly after the noun expressing the particular feeling or emotion being discussed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 感謝の気持ちを込めて、１年間お世話になった先生に花束をあげた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Full of the feeling of gratitude, I gave a bouquet of flowers to a teacher who has taken care of me for the past year.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夫は毎晩、愛を込めて晩御飯を作ってくれる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My husband cooks dinner filled with love every night.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 歌うのが下手でも、心を込めて歌えば上手に聞こえる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if you are not a good singer, you can sound like a good singer if you sing with all your heart.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 感謝の気持ちを込めて、プレゼントを贈った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Full of the feeling of gratitude, I gave a present. (filled with feelings of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女が愛を込めて作った弁当を食べたい！
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to eat a bento made full of love by my girlfriend. (filled with feelings of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 憧れを込めて伯父さんの背中を見ていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I watched my uncle's back, full of longing. (filled with feelings of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 祈りを込めて書いた詩に涙した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I shed tears at the poem that was written full of prayer. (filled with feelings of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 願いを込めてステージで歌う姿にジーンときた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Seeing them sing on stage, full of hope, gave me the chills. (filled with feelings of)

Name: に加(くわ)えて
Meaning: Not only...but also, In addition, Not to mention
About: にくわえて is a formal grammar pattern in Japanese that is a combination of に, and the て-form of the る-Verb 加(くわ)える 'to add', or 'to append'. Often, this structure will be translated as 'in addition to (A), (B)', or 'not only (A), but also (B). Being that it is a formal phrase, に加(くわ)えて will also often appear in its formal-conjunctive form に加(くわ)え. To use にくわえて, simply place it directly after the noun that you would like to highlight as being the base information, before discussing what exactly is 'in addition' to that base in the following clause. Both the kanji and hiragana forms of this structure are fairly common, so it will be beneficial to remember both.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は暑さに加えて湿度も高くなる恐れがあるので外に出る方は熱中症に気をつけてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today, in addition to the heat, there is a threat of high humidity, so please be careful of heat stroke if you are planning to leave the house.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今学期から文法に加えて漢字も教えることになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Starting this semester, in addition to grammar, I will also be teaching Kanji.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は空手に加えて、剣道もできるそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that he does kendo in addition to karate.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年の母の日には母に花束に加えて心を込めて書いた手紙を渡すつもりだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This Mother's Day, I plan to give my mother a heartfelt letter in addition to a bouquet of flowers.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年になってから電気代に加えてガス料金までもが高くなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This year, in addition to the electricity bill, even the gas bill has increased.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 白髪に加えてシワまで増えてきた。もう年だな。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My gray hair, not to mention my wrinkles, have increased. Boy am I old.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 性能に加えて価格まで負けているようではどうにもならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Nothing can be done about the inferior value, not to mention ability.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の別荘にはテニスコートに加えてサッカーコートまであるんですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: His vacation home not only has a tennis court, but also a soccer pitch.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 内科に加えて外科にもかかることになるなんて思いもしなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I didn't even think I would have to consult a surgeon, not to mention a physician.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 中指に加えて薬指まで骨折していました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In addition to the middle finger, I also broke my ring finger.

Name: 何(なに)から何(なに)まで
Meaning: Everything and anything, From A to Z, From head to toe, Everything
About: 何(なに)から何(なに)まで is a set phrase that may be interpreted in a very similar way to expressions like 'everything from A to Z', 'everything and anything', or 'from head to toe' in English. Being a construction of 何(なに) 'whatever', から 'from', 何(なに) 'whatever', and まで 'until', the literal meaning is similar to 'from whatever to whatever', and just indicates that there is no limit to what is included in a certain category. This expression is often used in a similar way to adverbs, meaning that it will appear at the beginning of a sentence, before describing the situation further. 何(なに)から何(なに)まで is also frequently used in a similar way to 'absolutely everything' in English, and will appear in phrases where the speaker is expressing thanks or gratitude to someone for all that they have done.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 浜崎さんは釣りのことなら何から何まで知っているから、何か分からない事があったら浜崎さんに聞きな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Mr. Hamasaki knows everything and anything about fishing, so if you have any questions, ask him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何から何まですみません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sorry for everything.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: うちの子は勉強にしろ家事にしろ、何から何までいい加減だから困っちゃうわ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My son does everything halfheartedly, whether it's his studies or chores, so I'm frustrated.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何から何までありがとうございました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thank you so much for everything.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この１年間何から何までお世話になり本当にありがとうございました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thank you so much for everything you have done for me over the past year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「本当に何から何まですみません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I am sorry about everything.' (from A to Z/anything and everything)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サポートスタッフ：「このマニュアルには、何から何まで書いてあります。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Support staff: 'Everything is written in the manual.' (from A to Z)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 刑事、容疑者について：「彼の話は何から何までうそだった！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Detective, about suspect: 'His story was all a lie, from A to Z.' (anything and everything)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ライトノベル：「しかし、そのルールは何から何まで当てはまるわけではない。例外もある。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Light novel: 'However, this rule doesn't apply to anything and everything. There are also exceptions.' (from A to Z)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供について、ご近所さんの話：「エレンは何から何まで母親そっくりだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between neighbors about a child: 'Eren resembles his mother from head to toe.' (anything and everything)

Name: は別(べつ)として
Meaning: Apart from, (Setting) aside, Whether or, Except for, Save for
About: は別(べつ)として is a set phrase with the meaning of 'setting aside (A)', 'except for (A)', or 'save for (A)'. This structure combines は, 別(べつ), a noun meaning 'difference', 'separation', or 'distinction', と, and the て-form of する. Due to this combination, the more literal meaning is 'going ahead with (A) as an exception', and just declares that (A) is something that is being completely disregarded before discussing the main point. As は is simply marking the topic in the same way that it usually does, this phrase may be seen after a noun, or any other word that would usually be grouped with は. This frequently includes things like かどうか. It is also fairly common to see the (A) word repeated in both its positive and negated form. This has the nuance of 'whether or not', in the same way as かどうか. Despite this grammar structure being used to essentially remove (A) from what is being discussed, the primary reason for this is that (A) is usually an exception to some particular rule or constant that the speaker wants to highlight.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この家の外観は別として、中は完全にリフォームされているからとても綺麗だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Setting aside the exterior of this house, the inside is very clean because it has been completely remodeled.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ホラーは別として映画なら基本的になんでも好きです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Setting aside horror, I generally like any movie.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 給料がいいかどうかは別として、自分が楽しいと思える仕事がしたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Setting aside whether the pay is good or not, I want a job that I will enjoy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このハンバーガーは体にいいかどうかは別として、とても美味しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Setting aside whether this burger is good for my body or not, it is very tasty.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このお茶は美味しい美味しくないは別として、健康にいいらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I hear this tea is good for your health, whether it tastes good or not.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 試合で優勝するしないは別として、精一杯頑張る事が大切だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether or not you win the match, it is important to do your best.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 見た目は別にして、あそこの料理はとても美味しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Aside from the appearance, the food there is very good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 手伝うべきかどうかは別としてそもそも現場にはいなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Leaving aside whether I should help or not, I wasn't at the scene in the first place.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは別としてもたぶん遅かれ早かれそのトピックに戻ってくるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if we set it aside, that topic will most likely resurface sooner or later.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この子犬はかわいい、かわいくないは別として確かに動物としては随分賢い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Leaving aside whether this puppy is cute or not, certainly, it is extremely smart for an animal.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そのジョークを言うのはいいか悪いかは別として、自分ではとてもおもしろいと思った！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Leaving aside whether saying this joke is good or bad, I thought it was really funny.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 喰われている餌食自身は別として喰っている捕食動物は本当に幸せだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (Setting) aside the prey that is being eaten, the predator enjoying its meal is surely happy.

Name: だけに
Meaning: As might be expected, Because, All the more because, It's only natural
About: だけに is a grammar pattern that is often translated as 'as might be expected of (A)', 'it's only natural due to (A)', or simply 'because of (A)'. Being a combination of だけ 'just', and に 'to', the literal meaning is 'just in that it's (A)', and is similar to the counterpart phrase in English. だけに may be used when highlighting either positive or negative results that came about due to (A), and will appear after verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives that have been followed by な, or nouns. Also, だけに may be used when highlighting that specifically because of (A), (B) is considered a level above what would usually be expected. This can be in terms of difficulty, emotional reaction, volume, or anything else that is quantifiable.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トムさんは日本語を８年勉強しているだけに、日本語がペラペラだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tom has been studying Japanese for 8 years and as one might expect, he is fluent in Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このアパートは東京駅に近いだけに、家賃が高い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This apartment is very close to Tokyo station, and as one might expect, the rent is expensive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このアプリは便利なだけに、どんどんとユーザーが増えてきています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This application is becoming more and more popular just because it is so useful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夏休みであるだけに、海水浴場には人がたくさんいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is summer vacation and as one might expect, there are a lot of people at the beach.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 合格したと思っていただけに、不合格と知った時はとてもショックだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was very shocked when I learned that I had been rejected because I thought I had passed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 普段は優しいだけに、彼女が怒っている姿を見た時はびっくりしました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was surprised to see her angry because she is usually so kind.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は子供の頃からそろばんを習っているだけに、暗算がとてもうまい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just in that he has been learning the abacus since childhood, he is very good at mental math.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この車は最新だけに、椅子のヒーターもあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a brand new car and as one might expect, it comes with heated seats.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 年を取ってきただけに、出来なくなったことが多い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As one might expect with aging, there are a lot of things you can no longer do.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大工だけに、椅子くらいならすぐに作ってくれる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As one might expect from a carpenter, if it is something like a chair, they can quickly make that for you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寿司職人だけに、醤油へのこだわりがすごい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As one might expect from a sushi craftsman, his particularity toward soy sauce is extensive.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スチュワーデスだけに、身長が高く姿勢もいいですね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As one might expect from a stewardess, she is tall and her posture is good.

Name: だけは
Meaning: To do all that one can, As much or many ~ as one could
About: だけは is another one of the many grammar patterns in Japanese that includes the particle だけ, meaning 'just' or 'only'. In this particular structure, だけ pairs with は, and presents a specific verb as the topic to indicate that it is being done 'as much as one can'. The same verb will be repeated both before and after だけは, with the one coming second usually appearing in its past-tense or ている form. Imagining that the target verb was 食(た)べる 'to eat', the literal translation of something like 食(た)べるだけは食(た)べた would be 'I ate just what I could eat'. Because this pattern frequently discusses possibilities, it is also very common for the first verb to be in the potential れる or られる form.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 飲み放題だったから、飲めるだけは飲んだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It was all you could drink, so I drank as much as I could.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: トイレットペーパーを買えるだけは買ったが、置く場所がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bought as much toilet paper as I could afford, but I have nowhere to put it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ピアノのレッスンには通うだけは通っているけど、ピアノにはあまり興味がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go to piano lessons as much as I can, but I am not very interested in piano.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日漢字の勉強をするだけはしているが、上達している感じがしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I do as much as I can to study kanji every day, but I don't feel like I'm making progress.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勉強だけはしたが、全然頭に情報が入ってこなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I studied as much as I could, but I didn't get any information in my head.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩には何回も連絡だけはしているが、全然返事をしてくれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have been trying to contact my senpai as much as I could, but he won't respond at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食べられるだけは食べた。食べ放題だからさ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I ate all that I could. It was an all you can eat after all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このナッツを砕くだけは砕いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I crushed these nuts as much as I could.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 儀式だからやるだけはやっているが、さっぱり意味が分からない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since it is a ceremony, I am doing as much as I can. However, I have no idea what any of it means.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 感想を書くだけは書いてみたが、まだメールで送っていません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wrote out my impressions the best I could, but I still haven't sent it out (via email).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日着たい服を乾かすだけは乾かして家を出た。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I dried the clothes I want to wear today as much as I could and then left the house.

Name: だけあって
Meaning: Is only natural, …Being the case, Because, As might be expected
About: Like だけに, だけあって is a phrase that is used to show that something is 'only natural for (A)', or 'as might be expected of (A)'. This structure includes the particle だけ 'just', or 'only', and the て-form of the う-Verb ある 'to be'. In this way, the more literal meaning may be interpreted as 'just being (A), (B)', and implies that the innate trait or traits of (A) led to the expected result of (B). だけあって will only be used when the expected result is something that is positive in relation to (A). Like most other grammar patterns that begin with だけ, this structure may be used with verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives followed by な, or nouns.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は１０年間日本に住んでいただけあって、日本語を日本人のように話せる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As one might expect, he can speak Japanese like a Japanese person because he lived in Japan for 10 years.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのホテルは高いだけあって、サービスがとてもいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As one might expect, that hotel has great service because it is expensive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 浅草は有名なだけあって、平日でも観光客で賑わっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As might be expected with how popular Asakusa is, it is crowded with tourists even on weekdays.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中先生は習字の先生だけあって、漢字を書くのが上手です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As expected, Tanaka-sensei is good at writing kanji because she is a calligraphy teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 幼い頃からアイススケートを習っていただけあって、将来はオリンピック選手になるでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As expected from someone who has been learning ice skating from a young age, she will probably be an Olympic athlete in the future. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日一生懸命勉強しただけあって、彼は試験に合格するだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As expected, he studied hard everyday, and would probably do well on his exams. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 茶道を習っているだけあって、礼儀が正しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As one might expect, since she is learning tea ceremony, she is polite.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昼寝しただけあって、午後から眠くなることはなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (As might be expected) because I took a nap, I didn't become tired in the afternoon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの二人は仲良しなだけあって、いつも一緒にいるよね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As might be expected with how close those two are, they are always together.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 揚げ物を控えただけあって、私は３キロも痩せた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As might be expected, I avoided eating fried food and I lost three kilograms.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アナウンサーだけあって、早口言葉が得意だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As might be expected from an announcer, tongue twisters are his strong point.

Name: 何(なに)より
Meaning: Be glad, Be relieved, Most, Best, Above all else, More than anything
About: 何(なに)より, or 何(なに)よりも when emphasized, is a common phrase in Japanese that is used when one wants to express that they are 'glad', 'relieved', or that '(A) is more important than anything'. As this structure is simply a combination of the substitute noun 何(なに) 'what', or 'whatever', and the particle より 'than', the closest literal translation is 'more than anything, (A)'. 何(なに)より is primarily used to express positive feelings when the actual situation may have been worse, but (A) is the most important. 何(なに)より, and 何(なに)よりも most often behave adverbially, meaning that they can be used at the beginning of a sentence, or right before the word they are describing. However, they occasionally come directly before a noun when followed by の. As in most cases, も just strengthens the phrase slightly, with no other significant change in nuance.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何より驚いたのは、あの中田くんが医者になったことだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The most surprising thing is that Nakata-kun became a doctor.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中様のお役に立てて何よりです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We are glad to be of service to you, Tanaka-sama.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何よりも大切なのは、何でも諦めずに頑張ってやることだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The most important thing is to not give up and to do your best in anything you do.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 休みの日に妻とドライブに行くのが何よりの楽しみです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I love going on drives with my wife on weekends more than anything.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「ありがとうございます。」
「お役に立てれば、何よりの幸せです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Thank you very much.'
'More than anything it is a blessing to be able to help.' (above all else・more than anything)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達：「互いに助け合うことが何より大事なのよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Friend: 'Helping one another is the most important thing.' (above all else・more than anything)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 久しぶりに挨拶する時：「お元気そうで何よりです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: When greeting someone we haven't seen for a long time: 'I am really glad that you seem to be doing well.' (above all else・more than anything)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「両親にとって自分の子供の健康が何より大切です。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'For parents, there is nothing more important than the health of their children.' (above all else・more than anything)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
らくさん：「あなたにもらった本、わたしの息子がとても気に入っています。」
おのでらさん：「それは何よりです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Raku: 'My child loved the book he received from you.'
Onodera: 'I am really glad.'

Name: 何(なん)と言(い)っても
Meaning: By any account, All the same, No doubt
About: 何(なん)といっても is an expression that is used in almost exactly the same way in Japanese as it is in English, and qualifies that 'no matter what is said, (A)', or 'by any account, (A)'. Being a mix of the substitute noun 何(なん) 'what', or 'whatever', と, the て-form of the う-Verb 言(い)う 'to say', and も, the literal meaning is also 'even whatever one can say (A)'. 何(なん)といっても is used primarily at the beginning of sentences, and frequently highlights something that is a positive aspect of (A). Like many uses of 何(なに), the pronunciation change to なん is simply for ease of speech. Despite being used mainly in positive situations, 何(なん)といっても may occasionally appear with a negative nuance as well, although this is far less common.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのカフェは何といってもコーヒーとアイスクリームが安いからとても人気がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Without a doubt, they have cheap coffee and ice cream at that cafe, so it is very popular.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は正直者だし、話しやすい。しかし、何といっても誰に対しても優しいからみんなに好かれている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is honest and easy to talk to. But, by any account, he is nice to anyone, so he is well liked by everyone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の日本語の先生は厳しいけど、何といっても日本語を教えるのがものすごく上手だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My Japanese teacher is strict, but she is very good at teaching Japanese without a doubt.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の悪いところは、何といってもすぐに嘘をつくことだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The bad thing about him is, by any account, that he is quick to lie.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の長所は、何といっても朗らかなところだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: His strong point is, by any account, his cheerfulness.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この地域の見所は、何といっても紅葉だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The highlight of this area is no doubt the fall colors.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このマンションのセールスポイントは、何といっても駅から近いことです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: By any account, this apartment's selling point is that it is close to the station.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの牧場のおすすめは、何といっても自家製のアイスクリームだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My recommendation for that farm, is no doubt, their home-made ice cream.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うちの会社のいいところは、何といってもボーナスがたくさんもらえることです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A good point about our company is, by any account, that we get lots of bonuses.

Name: か何(なに)か
Meaning: Or something, Or something like that
About: か何(なに)か is a structure in Japanese used for expressing uncertainty about a specific thing. Being a construction of か, the substitute noun 何(なに), and か, the common translations of 'or something', and 'or something like (A)' are quite close to the more literal meaning which is just '(A), or whatever it is'. か何(なに)か will follow directly after the noun that it is describing as being something uncertain. か何(なに)か will also often be used in questions, or when offering someone something. This is primarily when more than (A) is available as a choice, but the speaker isn't specifying a list just yet. In these situations, (A) just indicates a general category to which 'or something else' would be a part of.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: すみません、お茶か何かありませんか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Excuse me, do you have tea or something?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お巡りさん！あそこにナイフか何かを持った怪しい人がいました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Officer! There was a suspicious person over there holding a knife or something.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何でもいいんで、水か何かをください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please give me water or something. Anything would be fine.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 紅茶か何か飲みませんか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you want to drink tea or something?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 学校か何かに通ってるみたいだけど。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He seems to go to school or something.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「仕事でいやなことがあったか何か？機嫌が悪そうね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Did something happen at work or something? You seem to be in a bad mood.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
バーテンダーのひとみさん：「お飲み物はいかが？」
顧客のにったさん：「ビールか何かがほしいな。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Hitomi, the bartender: 'How about a drink?'.
Nitta, the customer: 'I'd like a beer or something'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
奥さん：「コーヒーか何か飲みませんか？」
お客さん：「結構です。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Wife: 'Would you like coffee or something to drink?'
Guest: 'No, I'm fine.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 警察官：「泥棒はバールか何かを使って、窓を開けたと思います。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Policeman: 'I think that the thief opened the window using a crowbar or something.'

Name: ～てならない
Meaning: Very, Extremely, Can't help but do
About: てならない is a construction made up of the て-form of a verb or adjective (で for な-Adjectives), and the negated form of the う-Verb なる, 'to become'. This expression describes the word that is attached to it as being 'extremely (A)', or that one 'can't help but do (A)'. In most cases, てならない will be used when (A) is something that occurs naturally, such as feelings. Due to this, a more literal translation is close to 'to not be able to move on from (A)'. In this way, it just indicates that (A) is so intense that the person affected by it cannot do anything about it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日は徹夜して勉強してたから、眠くてならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was up all night studying yesterday, so I'm extremely sleepy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 愛知県の夏は暑くてならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Summer in Aichi prefecture is extremely hot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここ五年間娘と連絡がつかないから、心配でならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't help but to feel worried because I haven't heard from my daughter in 5 years.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はいつも僕に嘘をつくからむかついてならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't help but be extremely mad at her because she lies to me all the time. (Continuing feeling, natural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この漫画はつまらなくてならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This manga is extremely boring. (Momentary feeling, unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 詐欺にあった気がしてならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't help but feel it was a scam.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あんなコレクションは無駄に思えてならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot help but think that that collection is worthless.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 去年あなたと見た紅葉が思い出されてならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't help but remember the fall colors I saw with you last year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この毛皮は暑くてならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This fur is extremely warm. (I can't help but feel...)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日の見学が楽しみでならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't help but look forward to tomorrow's field trip.

Name: のみならず
Meaning: Not only...but, Not just...but, What is more
About: のみならず is a structure consisting of のみ, the literary particle equivalent of だけ meaning 'just' or 'only', the negative stem-form of the う-Verb なる 'to be', and the literary auxiliary verb ず, which connects with verbs in the same way, and carries the same meaning as ない. This expression indicates that something is 'not just (A), but also (B)', or 'not only (A), but (B) too'. のみ connects to words in the same way as だけ, so this pattern will be seen following Verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives, or nouns. Occasionally, のみならず may function as a conjunction, appearing at the beginning of a new sentence. In these cases, the meaning is the same, but usually translates closer to 'what's more', 'furthermore', or 'moreover'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日は仕事に遅刻したのみならず、帰りの終電も逃してしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Today I was not only late for work, but also missed the last train home.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本の夏は暑いのみならず湿気が高いから熱中症になりやすい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Japanese summers are not only hot, but also humid, making it easy to suffer heat stroke.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのパソコンは便利のみならず、安いので他のと比べてたくさん売れています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That computer is not only convenient but also inexpensive, so it sells a lot more compared to the others.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この漫画は子供のみならず大人の間でも人気があります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This manga is popular not only among children, but also among adults.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんは私の先輩だ。のみならず、命の恩人でもある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san is my senpai. Furthermore, he is the person that saved my life.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高橋さんはサッカーの専門家だ。のみならず野球にも詳しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takahashi-san is an expert on soccer. Moreover, he is also very knowledgeable about baseball.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 炭素繊維は極めて丈夫であるのみならず非常に軽いらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Apparently, carbon fiber is not only extremely durable, but also very light.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この大統領候補は、豊富な知識があるのみならず経験の深い人でもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This presidential nominee is not only a person with abundant knowledge, but also is a person with vast experience.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 現代人は健康のために健康食品を食べるのみならず、運動もするべきである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Modern people should not only eat healthy food for the sake of their health, but they should also exercise.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は年が経つに伴って英語のみならず中国語も流麗に話せるようになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As he grew older, he became able to speak fluently not only in English, but also in Chinese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 発光ダイオードは蛍光灯よりずっと安いのみならず環境への影響も細小である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Light emitting diodes are not only much cheaper than fluorescent lights, but also their impact on the environment is miniscule.

Name: それなのに
Meaning: And yet, Despite this
About: Being a combination of the substitute noun それ, な, and のに, the particle meaning 'although' or 'despite', それなのに acts as a conjunction meaning 'and yet', or 'despite that', and simply refers back to the previous statement made, when the following statement is in contradiction to it. Due to its use as a conjunction, それなのに will primarily appear at the beginning of a new sentence. Being that the (B) sentence is in contradiction to the (A) sentence, それなのに will often indicate something that is unexpected, or was somehow unpredictable based on (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 妻は今、風邪をひいて寝込んでいる。それなのに、いきなり動物園に行きたいと言ってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My wife is currently in bed with a cold. And yet, she suddenly told me that she wants to go to the zoo.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は毎日３時間日本語の勉強をしている。それなのに全然上達している感じがしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I study Japanese for three hours every day. And yet I don't feel like I'm improving at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新品を買った。それなのにもう壊れた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I bought it brand new. Despite this, it is already broken.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 早起きするために早く寝た。それなのに寝坊した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In order to wake up early, I went to bed early. And yet, I overslept.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アンテナを新しくした。それなのにテレビの映りが悪い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I got a new antenna. Despite this, the quality of the TV picture is bad.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日は遠足だ。それなのに夜更かししている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tomorrow I have an outing. Despite this I am staying up late.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は努力していると思う。それなのにうまくいかないのか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think I am putting in effort and yet, why isn't it going well?

Name: いわゆる
Meaning: What is called, So-called, Generally known
About: いわゆる, occasionally seen in its kanji form 所謂(いわゆる), is a word that is used before nouns to indicate that something is 'what is called (A)', 'the so-called (A)', or 'generally known as (A)'. いわゆる is a combination of いわ, a modern variant of いは, the indeterminate form of 言(い)う 'to say', and ゆる, which is the classical literary equivalent of the auxiliary verb れる, the displacement verb indicator in its attributive form. In this way, the literal meaning of 'what is said to be (A)' is carried over into the English translations.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ハンバーガーやフライドポテトはいわゆるジャンクフードだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hamburgers and French fries are so-called junk food.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それはいわゆる陰謀論というものですね？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is what is called a conspiracy theory, right?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはいわゆる和製英語というものです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is what is called a Japan-made pseudo-English word.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは所謂神話というやつです。信用してはいけません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That’s what you’d call a myth. You shouldn’t believe it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは所謂宣伝ですので、ご理解ください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since this is a so-called advertisement, please understand.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは所謂葬式ではありませんので、悲しまないでください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is not what you would call a funeral, so do not be sad.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは所謂総理案件というやつでは？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Isn't this what is called a matter related to the prime minister?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 所謂送料ですが、無料でやらせてもらっています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is generally known as (having) postage, but for you there is no charge.

Name: に過(す)ぎない
Meaning: No more than, Just, Merely
About: にすぎない is a common structure in Japanese used for indicating that something is 'no more than (A)', or 'merely (A)'. This expression is constructed from に, and the negated form of the る-Verb 過(す)ぎる, meaning 'to exceed', or 'to be more than'. Due to this, the literal translation of 'to not be more than (A)' reflects the English interpretations closely. にすぎない is slightly formal, but is heard fairly often in day-to-day speech as well. This grammar pattern may be used after verbs in any of their standard forms, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives, or nouns. にすぎない is often seen paired with structures that will emphasize the phrase even further, such as ただ 'merely' or だけ 'just'. In the case of だけ, it will come between the target word and にすぎない. Also, standard conjugation rules will need to be remembered, such as adding な after a な-Adjective before だけ.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はお金が欲しかったから、あなたを助けたにすぎない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I helped you just because I wanted money.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんだけ勉強していても、ちゃんと集中して勉強をしないと時間を無駄にしているにすぎない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how much you study, if you don't focus on your studies properly, you are just wasting your time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの建物は古いだけにすぎない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That building is nothing more than old.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんはハンサムなだけにすぎない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san is nothing more than handsome.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 藤田さん、君は子供にすぎない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Fujita-san, you are nothing more than a child.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この納豆はただくさいだけにすぎない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This natto just smells.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田舎はただ不便なだけにすぎない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The countryside is nothing more than inconvenient.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは氷山の一角にすぎないとおもう...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think that this is just the tip of the iceberg…

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君は学生にすぎない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You are nothing more than a student.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 行動しなかったら、口だけにすぎない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you don't act, then that is nothing more than talk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 運が悪いだけにすぎない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is just bad luck. (nothing more than)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 利害関係があるから、親切にしているにすぎない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since I have an interest/stake in it, I am merely being kind. (nothing more than)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「いつか飲みましょう」って言ったけど、あれは社交辞令にすぎない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I said, 'Let's drink sometime,' but that is no more than social etiquette.

Name: も～ば～も
Meaning: …And…, Both ... and ..., ... And ... as well
About: も～ば～も is a construction in Japanese which presents aspects of something to which both (A) and (B) are true. も will be connected to a noun, before the hypothetical marking particle ば will appear following a verb, い-Adjective, な-Adjective, or noun. In the case of nouns and な-Adjectives, なら or ならば will be used. In this way, も～ば～も just highlights that 'If (A) is true, then so is (B)'. This usually just emphasizes that (A) and (B) are things that go together hand-in-hand, with one trait or characteristic always existing if the other does. Standard translations include 'both (A) and (B) are (C)', or 'the trait of (C), is in (A) and (B) as well'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お父さんはイタリア語も出来れば、スペイン語も話せる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My father can speak Italian and Spanish.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本の冬は湿度も低ければ、温度も低いから外で火を使う時は気をつけないといけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Winter in Japan is cold and dry, so you have to be careful when using fire outside.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このギターの音も好きなら柄も好きなので、一生手放したくありません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like the sound and the design of this guitar, so I never want to let it go.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: マルチ商法の話を聞くたびに、騙す方も騙す方なら、騙される方も騙される方だといつも思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whenever I hear about pyramid schemes, I always think that if the scammers are scammers, then the scammed are scammed. (I always think that the scammers and the scammed are both at fault.)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの居酒屋のスタッフの態度もよければ、値段も高いから人気がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The attitude of the staff at that izakaya is good and it is expensive, which is why they are so popular. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は地位もなければお金もない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She has neither status nor money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人は、実力もあれば、努力もする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person has capabilities and puts forth effort.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は撮影もできれば、ナレーションもできる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He can do photography and also narration.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「うまくいっている」という実感もなければ、兆候もない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is not any feeling of 'it is going well,' nor is there any indication.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 総理大臣は、経済も見直せれば、人権問題も解決できます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The Prime Minister can reform the economy and resolve human rights issues.

Name: でしかない
Meaning: Merely, Nothing but, No more than
About: でしかない is a construction comprised of the conjunctive form of だ, で, the particle しか, and the い-Adjective, ない. Like all other しか based structures, it is used to indicate that the target word is 'no more than (A)', or 'merely (A)'. The primary difference with でしかない compared to other similar grammar patterns is that it will only appear directly after nouns. Although でしかない can be used with either a positive or negative nuance, it tends to be seen more frequently with a slightly negative nuance in relation to (A), indicating that it has no value or significant meaning beyond (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは言い訳でしかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is nothing but an excuse.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩は愛のムチだと言っているが、暴言でしかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My senpai says that he is saying this out of love, but it's nothing more than abusive language.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子にとっては宝物かもしれないが、私にとってはゴミでしかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: To my son, it is something precious, but to me it is nothing but garbage.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人は見栄の塊でしかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person is nothing but the embodiment of vanity.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 聞こえはいいが、安易な言い訳でしかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That sounds good, however it is merely a simple excuse.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「訓練だ」と言っているが、あんなの意地悪でしかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They are saying it is 'discipline', but it is merely bullying.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女から秘密を教えてもらったが、ウソでしかなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She shared some secrets with me, but they were nothing more than lies.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アイデアは悪くないが、机上の空論でしかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The idea is not bad, but it is merely academic gossip.

Name: ～て堪(たま)らない
Meaning: Can't help but want to, Very, Extremely
About: てたまらない is made up of the conjunction particle て, and the negated form of the う-Verb 堪(たま)る meaning 'to bear', 'to endure', or 'to tolerate'. Common translations include 'to not be able to help wanting to (A)', or 'extremely (A)'. The primary difference between both meanings is that the 'can't help but want to (A)' nuance is seen attached to verbs conjugated with たい, while the 'extremely (A)' nuance is seen conjugated with both い and な-Adjectives. In both of these situations, the more literal interpretation is 'to be unbearably (A)'. As always, で will replace て when な-Adjectives are used.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来月公開される映画が見たくてたまらない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't help but want to watch the movie that is going to be released next month.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日は３時間しか寝てないから、眠たくてたまらない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I only slept for 3 hours last night, so I'm extremely sleepy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 娘をお使いに行かせたが、ちゃんと一人で行って帰ってこれるかが心配でたまらない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I sent my daughter on an errand, but I'm extremely worried about whether she would be able to go and come back by herself.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サイレンの音がうるさくてたまらない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The sound of the siren is extremely loud. (I can't stand it)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 蚊に刺されてかゆくてたまらない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was bitten by a mosquito and it is extremely itchy. (I can't stand it・I can't help but itch)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自分の子供のことが心配でたまらない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am extremely worried about my own kids.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暑くてたまらない。だからクーラーをつけた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is extremely hot. So, I turned on the air conditioner. (I can't stand it・I can't help but be hot)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのコーラスグループのコンサートが見たくてたまらない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't help but want to see that chorus group's concert.

Name: にせよ
Meaning: Even if, Even though, No matter, Whether… or
About: にせよ, and にしろ are two phrases that are often translated as 'even if (A)', or 'no matter if (A)'. This structure is a combination of に, and either of the imperative forms of する; せよ, or しろ. せよ tends to be more common in written material, while しろ is more common in speech. Despite the English translations, this particular use of the imperative form of する translates more accurately to 'so it's (A), who cares!', as the speaker is just strongly stating that the actual condition of (A) is unimportant in relation to what they actually want to say. にせよ and にしろ can appear following verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives or nouns in any of their standard forms. As this structure is fairly direct, in most cases it will be used as a way to emphasize that regardless of what the case is for (A), (B) is still true, or is the more important matter to consider.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 飲み会に参加しないにせよ、参加費は明日までに持ってきてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if you are not going to attend the drinking party, please bring your entrance fee by tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 怖いにしろ、私の仕事なのでやらなくてはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though it scares me, I have to do it because it's my job.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんなに不便であるにせよ、私は自然が豊かな田舎に住みたいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if it would be very inconvenient, I would prefer to live in the countryside where nature is abundant.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は相手が子供にしろ、一切手加減はしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person does not take it easy at all, even if the opponent is a child.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 違いがあるにせよ、わずかな差だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if there is a difference, it is minimal.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは難しいにしろ、するしかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though it is hard, I have no choice but to do it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 飲まないにしろ、居酒屋に行こう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if we don't drink, let's go to an Izakaya.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いずれにせよ、この決定は変わりません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At any rate, this decision will stand.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それが上司の命令にせよ、わたしは従えません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if that is an order from the boss, I will not follow it.

Name: 何(なに)しろ
Meaning: No wonder, After all, In fact, Because, At any rate
About: Although a combination of the substitute noun 何(なに) and the imperative form of する, しろ, 何(なに)しろ is often considered to be a singular adverb that carries the meaning of 'no wonder', or 'after all'. A more literal translation would be something like 'whatever the case, (A)', and just expresses that in any circumstance, only one conclusion can accurately be drawn in regard to (A). 何(なに)しろ will frequently appear at the beginning of a sentence, or at the start of the second clause. 何(なに)しろ will regularly be seen partnered with statements including words like から or ので, in order to emphasize an explanation or reason as to why (A) is the way it is.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何しろ彼はまだ始めたばかりなので大目に見てやってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After all, he is new, so please cut him some slack.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はできて当たり前だよ。何しろ彼はプロなんだから。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's no wonder he can do it. After all, he is a professional.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何しろ今日は普段より暑かったからクタクタだよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After all, it was hotter than usual today, so I'm exhausted.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何しろこの商品は不便すぎるので、どれだけ値下げをしても売れないでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After all, this product is too inconvenient and will not sell no matter how low the price goes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何しろ暑いからね。食欲も出ないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because it is so hot. It's no wonder that I have lost my appetite.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何しろ期限が迫っている。急いでくれないか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At any rate, the deadline is drawing near. Won't you hurry up?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何しろ基礎ができていないから、彼に数学を教えるのは大変だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At any rate, since his math foundation is not up to par, it is difficult to teach him math.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あそこの会社は何しろ規律が厳しい。あれじゃあまるで軍隊だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At any rate, that company has strict rules. It is pretty much the equivalent of being in the military.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの社長は何しろ強引だから、それで会社を辞めた人もたくさんいます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At any rate, that CEO is overbearing, so therefore, the company has a lot of people quitting.

Name: にしろ〜にしろ
Meaning: Whether… or
About: にせよ, and にしろ are two phrases that are often translated as 'even if (A)', or 'no matter if (A)'. This structure is a combination of に, and either of the imperative forms of する; せよ, or しろ. せよ tends to be more common in written material, while しろ is more common in speech. Despite the English translations, this particular use of the imperative form of する translates more accurately to 'so it's (A), who cares!', as the speaker is just strongly stating that the actual condition of (A) is unimportant in the overall sentence. When repeated, にせよ～にせよ illustrates that regardless of either '(A) or (B), (C) is still true'. In many cases, (A) and (B) will only be a small sample of possibilities, with the actual meaning being 'in (A), (B), or any similar situation at all, (C) is still true'. にせよ and にしろ may appear following verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives or nouns in any of their standard forms.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このイベントに参加するにせよしないにせよ、私に連絡をください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether or not you plan to attend this event, please contact me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 給料が多いにしろ少ないにしろ、給料をもらっている以上ちゃんと働かないといけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As long as you are getting paid, you must properly do your job whether you get paid well or not.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 勉強が好きにせよ嫌いにせよ、子供である以上、勉強はしなくてはいけません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether you like studying or not, as long as you are a child, you have to study.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社長にしろアルバイトにしろ、工場内での喫煙は禁止されている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether you are the president or a part-time worker, smoking is prohibited in the factory.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このレストランは、料理にせよ接客態度にしろ、全てが最悪だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Everything about this restaurant, whether it be the food or the customer service attitude, is terrible. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 浅い川にしろ深い川にしろ、子供にはライフジャケット着させないといけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether the river is deep or shallow, children must wear life jackets.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 好きにしろ嫌いにしろ、このワクチンは義務づけられている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether you like it or hate it, the vaccine is obligatory.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 公務にしろプライベートにしろ、ルールはちゃんと守ってください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether it is public or private, please properly obey the rules.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 古典にしろ新作にしろ、とにかく彼の落語が好きだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether it is his old stuff or a new, in any case, I like his rakugo.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 言葉遣いにしろ態度にしろ、彼の印象はとにかく悪い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether in speech or attitude, I have a really bad impression of him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寿司にしろ刺身にしろ、とにかく生の魚が好きなんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether it is sushi or sashimi, in any case, I like raw fish.

Name: は兎(と)も角(かく)
Meaning: Setting aside, Apart from
About: はともかく is an expression which makes use of the adverbial-particle は, and the adverb 兎(と)も角(かく) meaning 'to set aside', or 'at any rate'. This structure will be used when the speaker wants to change the topic from (A) to (B), or mention (B) as being something additional on top of (A). はともかく is primarily seen following nouns in their dictionary forms. In many cases, this will be when (A) is something that the speaker thinks is not worth considering, or not worth making an issue out of when (B) is more important.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この料理の見た目はともかく、味はとてもいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Apart from the appearance of this dish, it is very delicious.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家賃が高いか安いかはともかく、東京駅の近くに住みたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Setting aside whether the rent is expensive or cheap, I want to live near Tokyo station.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 給料はともかく、やりがいのある仕事がしたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Setting aside the pay, I want a worthwhile job.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 美人か美人じゃないかはともかく、優しくて料理が上手な人と結婚をしたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to marry someone who is kind and a good cook, whether she is beautiful or not is neither here nor there.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 冗談は兎も角、そろそろビジネスの話だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: All jokes aside, let's get down to business.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 家屋は兎も角としてもだ、せめてアルバムだけでも持って逃げたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Setting aside the house, I at least want to take the album and run.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: カタカナは兎も角、平仮名は読めないと困ります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Apart from katakana, you will be in trouble if you can't read hiragana.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 楽器は兎も角、せめて歌だけでも歌いましょうよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Setting aside instruments, let's at least sing a song.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 関東は兎も角、関西でだけでもいいから売れたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Apart from Kanto, even if it is just Kansai that's fine, I just want to sell it.

Name: ならともかく
Meaning: If it's (A), sure, but (B), Putting aside (A), (B)
About: When なら, the hypothetical form of the auxiliary verb だ is paired with the adverb ともかく 'to set aside', it will often be translated as 'if it is (A), sure, but not in the case of (B)', or more simply 'putting (A) aside, (B)'. This structure usually just indicates that if it were (A), then the result or situation would be different, but because it is not (A), the result or situation is not different (it is as it currently is). なら is often classified as and functions in the same way as an adverbial particle, meaning that it will primarily be appended to the plain form of nouns, verbs, or adjectives. However, ならともかく itself is used mainly after nouns. For more details about ともかく, please see the fun fact on the はともかく lesson page!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺の妹ならともかく、俺はそんなことしねぇ〜よ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it's my little sister, sure, but I would never do such a thing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 丈夫で何回も使えるものならともかく、なんでわざわざ高くて使い捨てみたいなもんを買うんですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it is tough and can be used multiple times, sure, but why would you go out of your way to buy something that is expensive and basically disposable.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新人ならともかく、君みたいなベテランがわからないようじゃ困ったもんだよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I understand if a newbie didn't know, but it is a problem if a long time worker like you didn't know.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 生魚ならともかく、納豆は食べられません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it's raw fish, sure, but I can't eat natto.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夜ならともかく、夏は日中は外に出られない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it's night, sure, but you can't go outside during the day in summer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 赤ん坊ならともかく、子供には叱る事も必要だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it's a baby, sure, but it's necessary to scold kids.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 社長ならともかく、平社員に決定権はありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it's the president, sure, but a rank-and-file staff member has no right to make decisions.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: イケメンならともかく、そうでない人はナンパで成功しないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it's a hottie, sure, but a person that isn't would surely not succeed at picking someone up.

Name: やら〜やら
Meaning: Whether or, Things like, And … so on
About: やら is an adverbial particle in Japanese which expresses lack of determination or limitation in regard to (A). Due to this, it is very similar to other structures like など, and will often translate as '(A) and so on', or '(A) and the like'. やら may appear following verbs in their dictionary form, nouns, い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives. When repeated as (A) やら (B) やら, both (A) and (B) will often be the same type of word, although this is not a limitation when the speaker is expressing various feelings in relation to something. Compared to とか, やら puts more emphasis on the scope of things within the category of (A) and (B), thus making it sound like (A) and (B) are only a small fraction of many different things within a complex pool of various emotions, actions, etc.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎日子供の世話をするやら家事をするやらで忙しいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am busy everyday with things such as taking care of my child and doing house chores.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先週は身体中が痛いやら、体調が悪いやらで大変でした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Last week I had a tough week because my whole body was aching, wasn't feeling well and so on.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのニュースを聞いてから不安やら怒りやら、色々な感情が溢れ出てきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After hearing that news, I was flooded with feelings such as anxiety, anger, and many other emotions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 文法だけではなく漢字やら単語やらも勉強した方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You should study not only grammar but also things such as kanji and vocabulary.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は大学に行くのやら行かないのやらはっきりしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not clear whether she is going to college or not.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの歌手は上手なのやら下手なのやら、私にはさっぱりわかりません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have no idea if that person is a good singer or not.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嬉しいやら恥ずかしいやらで、どんな顔をしていればいいのか、わからなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I didn't know whether I should react with happiness or shyness.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼に褒めてもらうとうれしいやら恥ずかしいやら、とにかく気持ちがよかったわ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When I was praised by him, I don't know whether I felt happiness or shyness. Anyway, it felt great.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 髭やら頭髪やらの身だしなみのチェックが厳しくて困る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Checking personal grooming such as beard and hair and so on, is so strict that I am bothered.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 悪口やら皮肉やら、彼はとにかく口が悪いから、あまり付き合いたくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether it is insults or sarcasm, he has a dirty mouth, so I don't really want to spend time with him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小数やら分数やらの問題を教えて欲しいと言われても、算数が苦手なもので...
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if someone says they want me to teach them about decimals and fractions and such problems, I am no good at math...

Name: しかしながら
Meaning: However, Nevertheless, But
About: When combined with the conjunction しかし 'however', the particle ながら 'while', or 'although' creates a new word which itself is used as a conjunction, or occasionally adverbially. しかしながら is itself often translated as 'however', or 'nevertheless', although it is stronger than しかし by itself. A more literal translation which may carry the strength of this grammar pattern a bit better would be 'while however, (B)', or 'even while true, (B)'. Just like in English, the extension of the phrase in Japanese adds emphasis to the overall meaning. しかしながら will primarily appear at the beginning of a new sentence when referring back to something that has previously been stated, either by the speaker themselves or by another. As しかしながら is primarily used as an emphasized version of しかし, which itself is formal, しかしながら will primarily be seen in literature, or in formal spoken language.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本は安全な国だと言われている。しかしながら１００％安全というわけでもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Japan is said to be a safe country. However, it is not 100% safe.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 精一杯頑張れば夢が叶うと言われている。しかしながら、人生はそう甘くない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is said that if you work as hard as you can, your dreams will come true. However, life is not so easy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そのアイデアはいいと思います。しかしながら、我々の予算だとそのプランを実行することはできないでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think the idea is good. However, our budget will not allow us to implement that plan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「多くの喫煙者は喫煙が癌の原因の一つであることを知っている。しかしながら、気にせずに未だタバコを吸い続けている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'Many smokers know that smoking is one of the causes of cancer. However, they don't care and continue to smoke.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ある電気自動車は自動的に運転することができる。しかしながら運転者はまだハンドルの上に手を置く必要がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Certain electric cars can steer automatically. However, the driver still has to keep their hands on the steering wheel.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: オンラインの安全性の記事：「オンラインショッピングは安全だと考えられている。しかしながら詐欺に遭う可能性が０であるわけではない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article about online safety: 'Online shopping is considered safe. However, it doesn't mean that the likelihood of falling victim to a scam is 0.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「オゾンホールの問題は９０年代には解決できるとは思われていなかった。しかしながら、国際協力により、オゾン層は２００５年ごろから回復が進んでいる。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'The ozone hole problem didn't seem solvable in the 90s. However, thanks to international cooperation, the ozone layer has been recovering since around 2005.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アニメーション評価：「『ジェイクとビーモ』というアニメーションは子供向けである。しかしながら、子供たちだけでなく大人向きでもある。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Animation review: 'The animated cartoon "Jake and Beemo" is targeted at children. However, it is suitable not only for children, but for adults as well.'

Name: 事(こと)にはならない
Meaning: Just because… doesn't mean…
About: ことにはならない is an expression which is often seen at the end of sentences when the speaker wants to emphasize that something said earlier is not necessarily the case. Often, structures like ても 'even if' or からといって 'just because' will appear in the first half of the sentence, before ことにはならない will simply highlight that 'it will not be that (B)'. As a grouping, the whole expression is often interpreted as 'just because (A), it doesn't mean that (B)'. ことにはならない is a construction of こと, に, は, and the negated form of the う-Verb なる 'to become'. In this way, the literal meaning is that 'just because of (A), (B) is not something that will come about'. Although not required, the (B) expression may be emphasized even further by the inclusion of という before ことにはならない.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: みんなが簡単にできたからと言って、君にも簡単にできるということにはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because it was easy for everyone else doesn't mean it will be easy for you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いくら上司でも、仕事を全部部下たちに押し付けてもいいことにはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because you are the boss doesn't mean that you can force all your work onto your subordinates.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ５分ノートを見直しただけでは、勉強したことにはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because you reviewed your notes for five minutes doesn't mean that you have studied.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 殴られたからと言って、殴り返してもいいということにはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because someone hits you doesn't mean it's okay to hit back.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 錆びているからといって、ガラクタだということにはならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just because it is rusty doesn't mean it is junk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サンプルだからといって、乱暴に扱ってもいいということにはならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just because it is a sample doesn't mean that it is okay to handle it carelessly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 祝日だからといって、いつまで寝ていてもいいということにはならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just because it is a holiday doesn't mean it is okay to sleep until anytime you please.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 実力があるからといって、威張ってもいいということにはならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just because you have some real ability doesn't mean it is okay to be proud/boastful about it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ジャーナリストだからといって、事実を何でも公表してもいいということにはならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Just because you are a journalist doesn't mean it is okay to publicize any fact you like.

Name: だけのことはある
Meaning: No wonder, Not surprising that, As expected
About: だけのことはある is a grammar structure consisting of the particle だけ, の, こと, は, and the う-Verb ある. It is used when indicating that something about (A) is 'as expected', or 'not surprising'. As a literal translation, it can be thought that the meaning is close to 'just in that it is (A), (B)', and expresses that simply because (A) is (A), (B) is to be expected. だけのことはある will often appear with other words that add emphasis to the expectation of (A), such as さすが, やはり, or やっぱり. This grammar pattern may be seen following verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives or nouns. な will be required after な-Adjectives. In the case of nouns and な-Adjectives, it is also possible to see だっただけのことはある when highlighting that some particular result is not surprising.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 娘が空手の大会で優勝した。さすがに一年間毎日稽古に行っていただけのことはある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My daughter won a karate competition. As expected, she has been going to practice every day for a year.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中くんは体力もあるし動きもテキパキしている。やっぱり若いだけのことはあるな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As expected from someone as young as Tanaka-kun, he is physically strong and moves quickly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのホテルのサービスはとても良かったし、朝食と夕食もものすごく美味しかった。やっぱり有名なだけのことはある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The service at that hotel was very good and the breakfast and dinner were extremely delicious. As expected from how famous that place is.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高橋先生が書く漢字はものすごく綺麗だ。さすが習字の先生だけのことはある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takahashi-sensei's kanji writing is extremely beautiful. As expected from a calligraphy teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの政治家はとても信頼されている。さすが昔から正直だっただけのことはある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As expected from a politician that has been honest for years, he is very trusted.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 鈴木さんは６０歳なのにムキムキだ。昔ボクサーだっただけのことはある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As expected from someone who used to be a boxer, Suzuki-san is very muscular even though he is 60 years old.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 娘は試験に合格できなかった。馬鹿なだけのことはある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As expected from an idiot, my daughter failed the exam. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: かなりの実力だ。誘いを蹴っただけのことはある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (He) is quite competent. As expected from refusing temptation.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: すごいことを思いついた。苦心しただけのことはある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I hit upon something great. As expected from the hard work I did.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仕上がりが完璧だ。彼にお願いしただけのことはある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The finished product is perfect. As expected having made the request to him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 利益が上がってきた。経費を削っただけのことはある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Profits have begun to rise. As expected from cutting down on expenses.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いい芝居だった。一生懸命稽古しただけのことはある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was a good play. As expected from the practicing with all of one's heart.

Name: ～ては成(な)らない
Meaning: Must not, Cannot, Should not
About: Although なくてはならない 'must do' is introduced to many learners early on, てはならない by itself carries the meaning of 'must not do', or 'cannot do'. This structure is a combination of the conjunction particle て, は, and the negated form of the う-Verb なる. Despite this ならない by itself is often considered a standalone word which may indicate that something is 'not possible', 'not permitted', or 'cannot be helped', depending on what type of word it is following. When following verbs and ては, ならない can only mean 'cannot', or 'must not'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この池では泳いではならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must not swim in this lake.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お酒を飲んで運転してはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must not drink and drive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 妊娠している間はタバコを吸ってはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must not smoke while you are pregnant.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんなことで泣いていてはだめだ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You shouldn't cry over something like this.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 会議中に携帯を使ってはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must not use your cellphone during the meeting.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここから先は関係者以外、入ってはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must not enter from this point forward if you are not an authorized personnel.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: くれぐれもこの戸を開けてはならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You must not repeatedly open this door.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 十代はお酒を飲んではならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Teenagers must not drink any alcohol.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 市民病院ではタバコを吸ってはならない。
