Questions.EnglishHTML: You must not smoke in the municipal hospital.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 安易に規律を破ってはならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You must not simply break rules.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何事も限度を超えてはならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You must not push the limits of anything and everything.

Name: ～ては居(い)られない
Meaning: Can't afford to, Unable to
About: てはいられない is a grammar pattern which consists of the conjunction-particle て, は, and the negated-potential form of the る-Verb いる 'to be'. Common translations include 'to be unable to (A)', and 'cannot afford to (A)'. The literal meaning of 'to not be able to be with (A)' just reflects the impossibility of the word that this structure is attached to. This structure is almost exclusively seen with verbs, but may occasionally be seen with い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives or nouns as well. The verb that てはいられない is connected to is often considered to be something that cannot continue on due to either some time-based or feeling-based limitation. In this way, it regularly has the nuance of '(A) cannot continue due to (B)', with the reason of (B) mentioned in another part of the sentence. When appearing with い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives or nouns, the nuance will change slightly, and simply reflects the meaning of いられない itself in conveying that (A) 'cannot be', or is 'impossible' in some way. As always, ては will be replaced by では in the case of nouns and な-Adjectives.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日までに提出しないといけないレポートがあるから、遊んではいられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have an essay I need to submit by tomorrow, so I can't afford to hangout.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あと３０分で家を出ないといけないので、のんびりご飯を食べてはいられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have to leave the house in 30 minutes, so I am unable to relax and eat my food.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 午後までに終わらせるように先輩に頼まれたから、休んではいられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My senpai asked me to finish by this afternoon, so I can't afford to take a break.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 次の大会で勝つには、こんな遅くてはいられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We can't afford to be this slow if we want to win the next tournament.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お父さんもいつまでも元気ではいられないんだから、そろそろ健康に気をつけな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Dad, you can't stay healthy forever, so you should start taking better care of yourself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もうこんな会社の社員ではいられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can no longer be an employee of this company.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 時間がない。下書きしては居られない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no time. I can't afford to make a rough draft.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は実績を上げています。負けては居られません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is achieving results. He can't afford to lose.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 寒すぎて写生してはいられません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is too cold. I am unable to do drawings from nature.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう働くしかない。受験しては居られない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have no choice but to work. I can't afford to take an exam.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんなひどい商品、宣伝しては居られません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Such a terrible product, we can't afford to advertise it.

Name: 陸(ろく)に～ない
Meaning: Not well or properly, Not much or enough, Barely, Hardly
About: When the adverb 陸(ろく)に 'satisfactorily' appears in ない sentences, it indicates that (A) is 'not satisfactory', 'not enough', or 'not being done properly'. This grammar pattern appears at the beginning of phrases, before the (B) part of the sentence will include a ない word, often a verb in its potential form. While ろくに will often appear in the kanji form, it is also common to see this structure in hiragana alone. Alternatively, 碌(ろく)に may also sometimes be seen, but this particular kanji is ateji (a kanji used purely for its pronunciation, not its meaning). This particular grammar point often has the nuance of something that is being done without sufficient effort, or is half-baked.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子は英語をろくに話せないのに、アメリカにひとりで行くそうだ。大丈夫かな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Apparently my son is going to the States, even though he can barely speak English. I hope he will be okay.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人はろくに仕事も出来ないのに、偉そうな態度をとるから会社中で嫌われている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is disliked by everyone in the company because he has an arrogant attitude even though he can barely do his job.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事が忙しすぎて、ここ最近、ろくに友達にも会えてない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I am so busy, I barely have time to see my friends.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 近所のワンちゃんが朝までずっと吠えていたから、昨晩は陸に寝れなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A dog in my neighborhood was barking until this morning so I barely got any sleep.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 豆なんて碌に食べないのに、うちには豆の缶詰がいっぱいある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have a lot of canned beans at home even though I hardly eat them.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 陸に準備もしていないのに、ショップをオープンさせた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though we had barely prepared, I had them open the shop. (hardly・not well/properly)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はケーキを焼くどころか、シンプルな料理さえ陸にできない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Far from baking a cake, he can't even cook a simple meal properly. (hardly・not well)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 毎日、うちの猫に起こされるせいで陸に寝られない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Every day I am woken up by my cat, so I can't sleep well. (hardly・not properly)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 陸に演技もできないのに、テレビドラマのオファーがきた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can hardly do a stage play, and yet I was offered a part in a television drama. (hardly/barely・not well)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 陸に掃除もしないのに、なぜか洗剤をたくさん持っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though I barely clean, I have tons of detergent for some reason. (hardly・not well/properly)

Name: しかも
Meaning: Moreover, Furthermore
About: しかも is a conjunction in Japanese which is commonly translated as either 'furthermore', or 'moreover'. This is a somewhat formal grammar pattern which indicates that both (A) and (B) exist at the same time, or are in unison. しかも itself focuses on the overall topic, so will be used for giving objective opinions, such as observable facts, rather than personal opinions. As しかも is a conjunction, it may be used between two phrases, or sometimes at the beginning of a second sentence, when referring back to the first. Often, (A) will be considered the 'base' information, while (B) is extra information added on top of (A), or further explaining (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このテレビは画質がめちゃくちゃいい。しかも、受信機がついていないから受信料を払わなくてもいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This TV has a very good resolution, and what's more, it doesn't have a receiver, so you don't have to pay a TV reception fee.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はとても頭がいいし性格もいい。しかも、美人だからもてないわけがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She is very smart and has a great personality. Moreover, she is beautiful, so there is no way that she is not popular.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの店は古いし汚い。しかも品揃えもよくないから、そのうち潰れるだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That store is old and dirty. Moreover, they don't have a good selection of goods, so they will probably go out of business soon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の鼻はとても大きく、しかも曲がっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My nose is big and what's more, it is crooked.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのスーパーの肉は安い。しかも、脂がのっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That supermarket's meat is cheap. Moreover, it is marbled (good quality).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: プレーは一流。しかも、ファンに優しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The play is first rate. Moreover, they are fan friendly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの人は常識を知らない。しかも、厚かましい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That person does not have common sense. Moreover, he is brazen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: しかも、舞台の途中に足が絡んで、転けた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Furthermore, while on stage, he tripped and fell.

Name: ～てでも
Meaning: Even if I have to, By any or all means, No matter what
About: てでも is a combination of the conjunction-particle て, and the prefix adverbial particle でも. Regular interpretations include 'no matter what', or 'even if I have to (A)'. When connected to verbs, てでも just emphasizes that 'even if (A) needs to be done, it will be', and expresses the speaker's strong determination to do something, regardless of what the consequences are, or how difficult it might be. Due to てでも expressing strong will, it will often be seen in sentences that include other phrases that mark desire or intent, such as ほしい, たい, and ようと思(おも)う.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの最新のノートパソコンは高いお金を払ってでも手に入れたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want that laptop, even if I have to pay a lot of money for it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 寒い中並んででもあそこのラーメンを食べてみたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to eat their ramen, even if I have to line up in the cold.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このレポートは徹夜してでも終わらせなければいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I need to finish this essay, even if it means that I need to stay up all night.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんな事をしてでも、海賊王になりたいぞ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter what it takes, I want to become a pirate king!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: グループを解散してでも守りたい秘密がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are secrets I want to protect even if the group must break up.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 争ってでもいいから、あの契約を取ってこい！
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's fine even if you have to fight for it, so go and get that contract!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それはまた改めてでもいいので、必ず持ってきてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since it is fine even if you need to revise it again, please make sure to bring it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 意地悪と思われてでも、説得するしかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if you have to be thought of as malicious, there is no choice but to persuade them.

Name: とも
Meaning: Even if, No matter
About: とも is a particle that can be used either as a sentence-ending particle, conjunction particle, or adverbial particle. Despite this, the meanings are often interchangeable, and it depends mostly on what type of word they are grouped with as to which type of particle it is. Common interpretations of とも in almost any situation are 'even if (A)', or 'no matter if (A)', and it will basically always simply highlight that 'in spite of (A), still (B)'. As a conjunction particle, とも will be paired with any words that are followed by the auxiliary verbs う, or よう, or after い-Adjectives in their conjunctive form. The adverbial particle usage only appears after い-Adjectives in their conjunctive form, and a select number of adverbs. It is recommended not to use this structure after adverbs unless you have already seen it used this way in native material.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 親が何と言おうとも、私は彼と結婚するつもりだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter what my parents say, I intend on marrying him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 魚がどんなに暴れようとも、この糸は絶対に切れません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how violent the fish thrashes around, this line will never break.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 人生がいくら辛くとも、諦めてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how hard life is, you must not give up.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いくら下手であろうとも、毎日練習をしていればそのうち上手になれる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how bad you are at it, if you practice every day, you will eventually get good at it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんなことになろうとも、国家が破産するのはまずありえない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter what (becomes of it) , it is impossible for a country to go bankrupt.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 頂点には届かなくとも、行けるところまで行ってみよう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if we don't reach the summit, let's try to go as far as we can.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんなに生意気になろうとも、わたしの息子であることに変わりはない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter how cheeky he becomes, he's still my son.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰に憎まれようとも、使命を果たさないわけにはいきません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if everyone hates it, it is an obligation we must fulfill.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ため息が出ようとも、仕事はやり遂げなければなりません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if you sigh, you must get some work done.

Name: ない訳(わけ)にはいかない
Meaning: Can't not, No way to avoid
About: As an extension of the grammar pattern 訳(わけ)にはいかない 'can't afford to do (A)', or 'impossible to do (A)', ない訳(わけ)にはいかない creates a double negative which is frequently translated simply as 'can't not (A)', or 'no way to avoid (A)'. As this is a combination of the negated form of a verb, 訳(わけ) 'reason', or 'logic', に, は, and the negated form of 行(い)く, the literal meaning is just 'there's no reason that (A) can't be done', or 'it cannot be so that (A) won't be done'. Compared to other similar structures like なければならない, ないといけない, and various others, ない訳(わけ)にはいかない implies that there are some circumstances as to why (A) cannot be avoided, so will often be used when giving an excuse or reasoning as to why one must do (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いつもお世話になっている先輩の結婚式だから、行きたくなくても行かない訳にはいかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's the wedding of a senior who has always been a great help to me, so even if I didn't want to go, I can't not go.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ダイエット中だからといって、何も食べない訳にはいかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because I am on a diet doesn't mean that I can avoid eating food.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: めんどくさいからと言って、宿題をしない訳にはいかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because it's a hassle doesn't mean that you don't do your homework.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 訳あって、白髪を染めないわけにはいかないんです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For some reason, he cannot avoid dyeing his gray hair.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ベテランの職人でも、トレーニングをしないわけにはいかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even a veteran worker cannot avoid training.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 面倒だからといって、打ち合わせをしないわけにはいかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though it is troublesome, there is no way to avoid having a meeting.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 締切前だからといって、まったく寝ないわけにはいかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if it is just before the deadline, you can't not sleep at all. (no way to avoid)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 慣れたメニューだとはいえ、味見しないわけにはいかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although it is a menu I am used to, there is no way to avoid taste testing.

Name: と言(い)う訳(わけ)ではない
Meaning: It is not that, It doesn't mean that, It is not always the case
About: と言(い)うわけではない is often considered an emphasized version of わけではない in stating that something 'doesn't mean that (A)', '(A) is not always the case', or 'it's not that (A)'. Being that という often presents (A) as a matter for discussion, or an important quotation structure, it will regularly be used to refer back to something that another person has said, in order to clarify that it may not be 100% accurate. というわけではない may be used after any structure that could usually be paired with という, and a more literal translation may be thought of as 'it is not so that (A) can be said'. Although not required, だ will often be seen between nouns and な-Adjectives, and というわけではない. と言(い)うわけではない will regularly be used when the speaker is denying that something said earlier is the reason for something. This could either be a misunderstanding that they themselves want to avoid, or something that the listener asked them to clarify.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本に２年間住んでいたからと言って、日本語を話せるというわけではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because I lived in Japan for two years does not mean I speak Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 数学が嫌いというわけではない、ただ苦手なだけだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not that I don't like math, I'm just not good at it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いつもニコニコしているからって、親切だというわけではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because they are always smiling doesn't mean they are nice.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 離婚というわけではないが、しばらく別居することになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It was not a divorce, but we had to live separately for a while.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ということは、彼女は彼を助けるために、彼を押し倒したという訳だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: So that means that she pushed him in order to save him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼がこの国に入国できないのは、以前この国で犯罪を犯したからというわけだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: So the reason why he cannot enter this country is because he has committed crimes in this country in the past.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 苦情という訳ではなく、提案です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not (that it is) a complaint, it is a suggestion. (not the reason)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 全てのキノコが毒を持っているという訳ではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not the case that all mushrooms are poisonous. (not the reason)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 儀式という訳ではないけど、あれはもはや儀式に近い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's not to say that it's a ritual, but at this point it's close enough to being a ritual. (not the case)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 正式な基準という訳ではないですが、参考にしてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not that it is officially the norm, but please take note. (not the reason)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 警備という訳ではないが、近くにいてもらえるとありがたいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It doesn't mean that (I need) security, but I would be grateful if you stayed near me. (not the reason)

Name: のも尤(もっと)もだ
Meaning: May well, Have or has good reason for, No wonder, … Is only natural
About: のももっともだ is a combination of の, も, the な-Adjective もっとも, meaning 'reasonable', or 'plausible', and the auxiliary verb だ. In many cases, the interpretation will be 'it may well be (A)', 'it's only natural that (A)', or 'there's no wonder that (A)'. However, 尤(もっと)も itself is simply an adjective that affirms that the speaker understands the thought process behind (A), and that it is logical to them, regardless of whether or not they actually agree with it themselves. Due to this, 'it may well be (A)' in English is actually a very close translation of the feeling behind the expression. のももっともだ will appear with verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives, and nouns. In the case of nouns, the の will be dropped, as the noun itself will become the expression being marked as the focus. Due to のももっともだ being used when the speaker is expressing that they understand the underlying reasons behind something, phrases used for explanation such as から or ので will often be seen in the same sentence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなことを彼女に言ったのか？彼女が怒るのももっともだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You said something like that to your girlfriend? She has every right to be angry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はいつも夜遅くまで残業をしているから、いつも眠いのももっともだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He always works late at night, so it's no wonder he's always sleepy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は高校生の頃から毎日日本語を勉強をしてきた。上手なのももっともだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He has studied Japanese every day since high school. It is no wonder he is so good at it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 親の反対ももっともだが、俺はもう俺のやり方でやると決めたから親の意見に合わすつもりはない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My parents have a good reason to object, but I've already decided to do things my way, so I'm not going to conform to my parents' views.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 状況からして、彼らがそう考えたのも尤もだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Given the situation, no wonder they thought so.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの本がいつも貸し出し中なのも尤もだ。大ベストセラーだから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is good reason that that book is always unavailable (for rent). It is a huge best seller.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ＳＮＳの投稿回数を減らしたのも尤もだ。彼女は忙しすぎる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is only natural that number of SNS messages she sends has decreased. She is much too busy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会社の規約を改正するのも尤もだ。あの規約は古すぎる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No wonder the company is revising their code of conduct. Those rules are too old.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 解説者が言っているのも尤もだ。かなり的確な意見だと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is good reason that the commentator is saying (those things). It is quite an appropriate viewpoint.

Name: たって
Meaning: Even if, Even though, No matter how
About: たって is a casual structure that carries the same meaning as 'ても' or 'でも', and can be used with a wide variety of words. Common translations include 'even if (A)', 'even though (A)', or 'no matter how (A)'. In the case of verbs, たって conjugates in the standard way that the た past-tense form usually would. For い-Adjectives, たって attaches to the conjugative く-form. For nouns and な-Adjectives, た will change to だ, and だって will then be used with the stem noun or adjective.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女に謝ったってどうせ許してくれないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if I apologized to her, she wouldn't forgive me anyway.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生に聞いたって、何も教えてくれないからインターネットで調べる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if I ask the teacher, they won't tell me anything, so I am going to look it up on the internet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんなに欲しくたって、万引きをしてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how much you want something, you must not shoplift.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 稽古がどんなに楽しくなくたって、稽古中には欠伸をしてはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how boring the lesson might be, you must not yawn during a lesson.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな簡単な問題馬鹿だってわかるよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even an idiot can figure out a simple problem like this!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達だって喧嘩をすることがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even friends can get into fights.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パーティーにはピザじゃなくたってかまわないよね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if it is not a pizza party, I don't mind.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ブロッコリーが健康に良くたって、もう食べたくない！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if broccoli is good for your health, I still don't want to eat it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんなに押したくたって、この赤いボタンを押してはダメ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter how much you want to press it, you must not press the red button.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 海水浴に行ったって僕は泳げないからつまらない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if I went to the beach, since I can't swim, it would be boring.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たとえ彼がどこにいるか知っているとしたって、それでもお前には教えない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if (we assume that) I did know where he is, I still would not tell you!

Name: に至(いた)るまで
Meaning: (Everything) from...to..., From…up until..., Starting with...ending with...
About: 至(いた)る is an う-Verb which can be roughly translated as 'to attain (A)', or 'to reach the climax of (A)'. This verb is seen in several different grammar structures that all basically highlight that some extreme or unexpected extent is being reached. When paired with に and まで, に至(いた)るまで is often interpreted as 'everything from (A) to (B)'. Comparative statements such as から or より frequently come directly after (A), while に至(いた)るまで will come directly after (B). This marks (B) as the 'extreme' extent. Both (A) and (B) will either be nouns or noun phrases. The 'to reach a climax' meaning of 至(いた)る itself can be used as an indicator that grammar points that use this verb all indicate some kind of exceptionally wide range between (A) and (B). Due to this, 至(いた)るまで can be thought of as simply a strong emphasis of まで by itself, which also marks an extent.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このライトノベルは子供から大人に至るまで、幅広い層で人気がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This light novel is popular with a wide range of audiences, from children to adults.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日は大阪から福岡に至るまで、一日中雨が降るようです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Apparently it is going to be raining all day tomorrow, from Osaka to Fukuoka.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 祖父は成人してから退職に至るまで、ずっと同じ会社で働いてきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My grandfather has worked for the same company, from when he became an adult until retirement.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: にしまさんはバーテンダーから大企業の社長に至るまでいろいろな仕事を歴任した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Nishima-san held various positions, from a bartender to a president of a large company.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日では、ＣＰＵはパソコンから歯ブラシに至るまで、さまざまな装置に見られる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Nowadays, CPUs can be found in various kinds of devices, from computers to toothbrushes, etc.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 総理大臣から一般人に至るまであらゆる市民は法のもとで平等である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: All citizens are equal under the law, from the prime minister to an ordinary person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 航海の初めから事故そのものに至るまでの難破船の航海日誌が見つかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A shipwreck's logbook covering everything from the beginning of the voyage to the accident itself has been found.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アジアでは、箸は昔より現在に至るまで長きに渡って、食べるために使われている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In Asia, chopsticks have been used to eat for a long time, from long ago to the present.

Name: ～たところで
Meaning: Even if ~ cannot or will not, Even though ~ not
About: ～たところで is a grammar construction that combines the simple-past form of a verb, the noun ところ 'place', and the case-marking particle で. As with most other grammar patterns that ところ is seen with, the focus is on the situation of the verb occurring. ～たところで is often translated as 'even if (A), not (B)', or 'even if (A), it won't be (B)'. This 'even if' nuance is created by the fact that ～たところで sentences will never have something in the past tense in the second half of the sentence, despite using the past tense before ところ. This is similar to the English 'even if (A) were to happen, (B) would still not occur'. As can be seen by the examples above, ～たところで will convey things that are counter to what the speaker either wants to, or wishes would happen. Due to this, the (B) half of the sentence will almost always be something unfavorable.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今更勉強を始めたところで、合格はできないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if I were to start studying now, I would not be able to pass.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もう電車は発車してしまったから、急いだところで間に合わないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The train has already left, so even if you hurry, you won't make it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 少し走ったところで、すぐには痩せないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just merely by running, you won't lose weight that quickly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 徹夜で勉強したところで、合格しない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if I studied all night, I would not pass.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「いまごろ車に乗って行ったところで間に合いようがない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if you went by car right now, you would not to be on time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「謝ってみたところで、彼女が許してくれるわけじゃないけど。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Even if I try to apologize, it doesn't mean she will forgive me.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「たとえ失敗してしまったところで、 問題はありません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Even if you fail, there will not be a problem.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私が告白したところで、彼女は応じないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if I confessed my love, she wouldn't respond.

Name: 如(ごと)く
Meaning: Like, Similar to, As if, The same as
About: 如(ごと)し is an classical auxiliary verb in Japanese which has a very similar meaning to its modern equivalent, よう 'manner of'. Just like よう, ごとし (written primarily in hiragana) focuses on the appearance of (A) based on observation. Due to this, ごとし may be translated as 'like (A)', 'similar to (A)', or 'as if it were (A)'. ごとし is the base form of this auxiliary verb, but ごとく (the conjunctive form), and ごとき (the attributive form) will also be seen. As only ごとき is attributive, it may be followed directly by other nouns, while ごとし most often comes at the end of sentences. ごとく acts as an adverb when preceding verbs, but may also be seen before breaks in clauses. Let's look at a few examples of each form. Like よう, ごとし and its variations will follow の when coming after a noun. However, it will follow が when coming after a verb. As ごとし is old-fashioned, it will primarily be encountered in books, rather than in speech.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ことわざ：「 竜に翼を得たる如し。」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Proverb: 'It is as if a dragon had wings.'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 主婦の私には休みなんかはあってなきが如し。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a housewife, it's like I don't have any days off.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高橋先生は鬼の如く怖いと言う噂を聞いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have heard rumors that Mr. Takahashi is as scary as a demon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 生まれてきたばかりの赤ちゃんが天使の如くかわいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The baby that was just born is cute like an angel.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女の如き頭がいい人でも失敗することはあるに決まっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even a smart person like her is bound to make mistakes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 風邪ごときで休んでいる余裕など私にはない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't afford to take a break just because of something like a cold.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女の動きはバレリーナの如し。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Her movements are like those of a ballet dancer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ガンダルフの如き英雄はたんと無い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are not many heroes like Gandalf.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ウサイン・ボルトの如く走る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He runs like Usain Bolt.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サービス業のマネージャーを任されている私にとって、休日などはあってなきが如し。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For me, who has been entrusted as the manager of the service sector, something like days off are virtually nonexistent.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 忍者についての小説：「カツラが疾風の如く庭を駆け巡り、塀を飛び越えていった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A novel about ninja: 'Katsura ran through the garden like a swift wind and jumped over the wall.'

Name: に足(た)る
Meaning: To be worthy of, To be enough, To be sufficient
About: 足(た)る, an う-Verb meaning 'to be sufficient', is often paired with に and either verbs or nouns in order to indicate that something is 'worthy of (A)', or 'enough for (A)'. This is quite a formal grammar structure, so is primarily seen in books, or may be used in speeches. に足(た)る will follow verbs in their dictionary form, or nouns. As 足(た)る itself will always appear in the dictionary form, it must be followed by a second noun which it will be modifying as the thing that is or is not worthy of something.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はこの試合に勝つに足る能力はないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is probably not worthy to win in this competition.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 信頼に足る友達に、家族のことをすべて話した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I told my trustworthy friend everything about my family.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お腹はいっぱいにならなかったものの、満足に足る量だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though I did not get full, it was enough to satisfy me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お腹はいっぱいにならなかったものの、満足するに足る量だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though I did not get full, it was enough to satisfy me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの先生は尊敬に足りない先生だと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think that teacher is not worthy of respect. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの先生は尊敬に足る先生ではないと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think that teacher is not worthy of respect.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「これは多くの人の興味を引くに足るものではない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'This is not enough to interest a lot of people.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 信頼に足る友達に、腕のいい歯医者を紹介してもらった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A skilled dentist has been introduced to me by a trustworthy friend.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 功績から考えると、その専門分野では尊敬に足る研究者だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Judging from his achievements he is a researcher that is worthy of respect in that field.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テスラ・モデルＳは語るに足る電気自動車であり、その技術は世界に認められる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tesla Model S is an electric car that is worthy of being talked about, and its technology is recognized worldwide.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 地検：「捜査を尽くしましたが、起訴するに足る証拠を掴むことができませんでした。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Public Prosecutor's office: 'We thoroughly investigated, however, we were unable to find enough evidence to prosecute.'

Name: 極(きわ)まりない
Meaning: Extreme, Extremely
About: Seen as either 極(きわ)まりない or 極(きわ)まる, this grammar structure makes use of the core meaning of the う-Verb 極(きわ)まる 'to be at the extremity of (A)', and will most often be translated simply as 'extremely (A)'. In most cases, this grammar pattern will appear following words that indicate some kind of negative state or emotion. 極(きわ)まる will be used immediately following な-Adjectives, while 極(きわ)まりない will come after こと when either a な-Adjective or い-Adjective precedes it. In the case of な-Adjectives, it is not a requirement that 極まりない be preceded by なこと, and it is actually more common for it to directly follow the な-Adjective without な.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 傘をさしながら自転車を運転することは危険極まる行動なので、もっと厳しく取り締まるべきだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Riding a bicycle while holding an umbrella is extremely dangerous behavior, so the police should more strictly enforce the law.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 理不尽極まるクレームを言われるたびにノイローゼになりそうになる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every time I get an extremely unreasonable complaint, I feel like I'm going to have a mental breakdown.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この会社ではＦＡＸを使わなくてはいけないので、不便なこと極まりない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since we have to use fax at my company, things are extremely inconvenient.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この展望台から見る景色は美しいこと極まりない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The view from the observatory is extremely beautiful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 目上の人に向かってその口の聞き方はなんだ。失礼極まりないやつだな、お前は。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why are you talking in such a manner to a person that is in a higher position than you? You are an extremely rude person, aren't you?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 犯罪を犯すのは愚劣極まりないことだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is extremely foolish to commit a crime.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 当初、ベジータは残忍極まる人だった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At first, Vegeta used to be an extremely cruel person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 警察官は危険極まりない仕事です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Police officers have an extremely dangerous job.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ひらさわ・すすむさん：「さすがにグレープフルーツはサワー極まる味があるわよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Susumu Hirasawa-san: 'As expected from grapefruit juice, it has an extremely sour taste.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ブログの投稿：「食べながら話すことは、失礼極まりない行為だと考えられている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Blog post: 'Talking while eating is considered to be an extremely rude act.'

Name: といえども
Meaning: Even (if), Although, Even though
About: といえども is a combination of the case-marking particle と, the hypothetical form of 言(い)う, 言(い)え, and the conjunction particle ども, which is used in much the same way as けれども, or ても. Due to this, despite the more literal translation of 'even if one were to say (A)', it is usually translated simply as 'even if (A)', or 'although (A)'. といえども will be seen following nouns, い-Adjectives, or verbs in any of their standard form. といえども may also follow な-Adjectives, but だ will precede といえども in these cases. Despite the nuance being slightly different, といえども can be thought of as a very old-fashioned way of saying といっても. Due to といえども being old-fashioned, it is often used for emphasis and will frequently be paired with expressions like いくら, いかに, どんなに, etc.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いくらお金に困っているといえども、闇金には絶対手を出さないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if I was really troubled about money, there is no way I would turn to a loan shark.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 前は一回で成功したといえども、毎回一回で成功できる訳ではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though we were able to succeed before on our first try, that doesn't mean that we can succeed in one try every time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女がどれだけ優しいといえども、そんなことばかりやってたら別れられるぞ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though she is super nice, if you keep doing such things she is going to break up with you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たとえ犯罪者といえども、動物みたいに扱ってはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if they are criminals, you must not treat them like animals.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運転が上手だといえども、シートベルトは必ず着用しなくてはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if you are good at driving, you must wear a seatbelt.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いくら有名だといえども、なんでも好き勝手やっていいと言うことではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if you are famous, it doesn't mean that you can just do whatever you wish.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ヒジカタが恐るべしと雖も、スギモトの敵ではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though Hijikata is incredible, he is no match for Sugimoto.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 手術中は一瞬と雖気が抜けない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: During an operation you cannot lose focus, not even for a second.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たとえ囚人と雖もときどき刑務所を出ることができる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even a prisoner can leave prison from time to time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 雨天と雖も、ゴミ拾いのボランティアをしないわけにはいかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if it is rainy weather, there is no way that I can not volunteer for the litter clean up.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 王様と雖も、法律を犯すことは出来ません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although he is the king, he cannot break the law.

Name: を以(もっ)て
Meaning: By means of, With, By, Via, In view of
About: をもって is a formal grammar pattern stemming from the meaning of its kanji counterpart 以(もっ)て 'by means of'. It is used in a similar way to the case-marking particle で, and will be translated as 'with (A)', 'by (A)', 'via (A)', or 'by means of (A)'. As this structure is preceded by the particle を, it will only be used directly following nouns, or noun phrases. Despite being similar to で in meaning, をもって will generally not be used in regard to simple methods of doing something, such as 'traveling by train'. Due to this, the translation of 'by means of' is the most accurate, as it would only be used in situations where the speaker is trying to emphasize the means, like in English. In addition to this, it is not often used with concrete items, such as a fork or a hammer, but instead will appear alongside abstract concepts, like 'with sincerity', or 'with compassion'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 検査の結果は電話をもって連絡させていただきます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The results of the examination will be communicated by telephone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客様の順番になりましたら、アプリをもって通知いたします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When it is your turn, you will be notified via the app.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自分の家族を持ってから、親である大変さを身をもって感じた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: By having my own family, I have learned firsthand how difficult being a parent is.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最新の技術をもってすれば、運転を完全に自動化することは可能だと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: With recent technologies, I think it will be possible to fully automate driving.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 君みたいな忍耐をもってすれば、どんなことでも乗り越えられるだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: With your perseverance, you will probably be able to overcome anything.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 以上、本状を以って辞表と致します。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Moreover, I resign by means of this document.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 当選は賞品の発送を以て発表に代えさせていただきます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The winner will be notified by means of the shipment of the prize. (Literally - The announcement of the winner will be replaced with the shipment of the prize)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ライトノベル：「どうしてヒメジの料理がみんなに避けられるか、身を以て知ったばかりだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Light novel: 'I just learned with my own body why everybody avoids Himeji's cooking.' (by means of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんは多数決を以て労働組合の代表として選出されました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san has been elected as a labor union representative with a majority vote. (by means of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 採用担当者：「面接の結果は電話を以てご連絡いたします。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Recruiter: 'The results of the interview will be communicated to you by phone.' (by means of・in view of)

Name: 嫌(きら)いがある
Meaning: Have a tendency to, Tend to, Be slightly~
About: 嫌(きら)いがある is a combination of the noun きらい 'a dislike', the case-marking particle が, and the う-Verb ある 'to be'. It is used to indicate the presence of negative tendencies or habits, and may be translated as 'to have a tendency to (A)', or 'to be prone to (A)'. This structure will be seen following the dictionary form of verbs, verbs negated with ない, or after nouns ending with の. As a more literal translation, 嫌(きら)いがある can be thought of as 'having the displeasure of (A)', with the actual 'tendency' merely being implied. Due to 嫌(きら)いがある being quite strong, it is frequently used together with words that will slightly soften the meaning, such as 少(すこ)し 'a little bit', or どうも 'try as one might'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は三日坊主だから、何かを始めてもすぐに辞める嫌いがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since she is a quitter, she tends to quit things as soon as she starts them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は自分の意見を言わない嫌いがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He tends to not share his own opinions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お盆休みの間は浅草に行く観光客の数が上昇する嫌いがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The number of tourists visiting Asakusa tends to rise during Obon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お父さんは少し強い言い方をする嫌いがあるけど、あまり気にしないでね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My father tends to use harsh words, but please don't take it personally.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 斉藤さんはどうも冬になると家に引きこもる嫌いがあるので、今年の冬は斉藤さんとたくさんお出かけに行く予定です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Apparently, Saito-san tends to become a hermit during winter, so I made plans to go out a lot with her this winter.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はなんでもすぐ飽きる嫌いがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have a tendency to get bored easily with everything. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 近頃の親は過保護のきらいがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Parents these days tend to be overprotective.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は彼の気持ちを尊重しないきらいがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She has a tendency to not respect his feelings.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ある人は、民族だけで人の性格を判断してしまうきらいがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A certain person tends to judge a person's nature just by their ethnic group.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お父さんは、困っている人のためには人助けをする。しかし助けてもらった人は、されたことを忘れるきらいがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Father always helps people in need. However, the people who received help tend to forget about it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「高血圧のきらいがあることを除けばほとんど健康だった３４歳の男性はバクテリアの感染により重体に陥った。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'A 34-year-old man, who was mostly healthy, aside for a tendency to have high blood pressure, has fallen seriously ill due to a bacterial infection.'

Name: ならまだしも
Meaning: A is fine...but B is not, If it's ~ then it is ok...but ~ is not, It's different when...but, It's not so bad when...but
About: ならまだしも is a combination of なら 'if', まだ 'still', and the adverbial particle しも, which has the primary purpose of strengthening the word that comes before it. When used, this structure will often be translated as '(A) is fine, but not (B)', or '(A) is fine, but it's different when it's (B)'. ならまだしも is a phrase that usually separates the first and second half of sentences, so will be attached to the end of the (A) phrase, marking the statement that is acceptable. Due to the way that しも alters まだ, a more literal translation of this grammar point can be thought of as 'if it's (A), then of course there's still that, but as for (B)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 暑いだけならまだしも、湿度も高いからどこにも行きたくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it was hot, that would be fine, but because it is also humid, I don't want to go.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 二、三日ならまだしも、二週間なんて待てませんよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it was 2 or three days, we could wait, but 2 weeks? We can't wait that long.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一回だけならまだしも、毎日同じことで怒られて何にも思わないの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it was only once, okay, but don't you feel any sort of way being told the same thing everyday?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今しも家を出ようとしていたところだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was just about to leave the house.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰しも長年使ってきた釣り竿には愛着がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Everyone has an attachment to a fishing rod they have used for many years.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: すみませんが、付き合うぐらいならまだしも、結婚は無理な注文です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am sorry, if it is just going out then it is ok, but marriage is out of the question. (is not okay)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: すごく恥ずかしい！お父さん、ビーチでならまだしも、半裸で外に出るのはやめてほしい！
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is so embarrassing! Papa, if it is a beach, it is ok, but going half naked outside? I want you to stop! (it is not okay)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「ねぇ、歩いて行こうよ。」
「自転車ならまだしも、そんな遠くまで歩いて行くのは無理だよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'C'mon, let's go on foot!'
'If it was on a bicycle, then it would be ok, but it is impossible to go that far on foot!' (is not okay)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 隣人がうちの駐車区域にたまに車を止めるならまだしも、いつも止めているから、いい加減腹が立つよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If my neighbor uses my parking spot from time to time then it's ok, but because he is always parking there, I get pissed. (it is not okay)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ツイート：「自分が感染するだけならまだしも祖父母や親などが病気になってしまうのがとても恐ろしいです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tweet: 'If it is just me becoming infected, then it is ok, but my grandparents or parents becoming ill is really scary.' (is not okay)

Name: までもない
Meaning: There is no need to, Do not have to, It is not necessary to, Needless to
About: までもない is a grammar pattern that consists of the particle まで 'until', the adverbial particle も, and ない 'there is not'. This structure will primarily be seen with a translation similar to 'there is no need to (A)', or 'it is not necessary to (A)'. However, a more literal translation of 'it is not so far as to (A)' is also completely acceptable, and still carries the correct nuance. までもない will be used following verbs in their dictionary form, and may or may not have a part (B) explaining why (A) is not necessary. As can be assumed by the use of まで, the primary nuance of までもない is that while there may be some sort of slight issue or problem, the speaker does not consider it as being something that has reached a point that is worth being concerned about. It may also indicate that because something is obvious, it does not need to be confirmed, etc.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 痛いけど、指は全部ちゃんと動くから病院に行くまでもないと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although it hurts, all my fingers move properly so there is no need to go to the hospital.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子を見て、何か悪いことをしたと分かった。聞くまでもなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I could tell that my son did something bad by just looking at him. It was not necessary for me to ask anything.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人ならなんとかしてくれるよ。心配するまでもないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Knowing that person, they would probably do something about it. There is no need to worry.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 言うまでもなく、不法投棄で近所の人が迷惑しています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying that illegal disposal of garbage is causing troubles to the people in this neighborhood.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「今さら訂正するまでもなく、明らかに間違っている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'There is no need to correct it, it is clearly wrong.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生は、すでに全て解説したので聞くまでもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no need to ask questions because the teacher has already explained everything.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これはただの打撲で骨にヒビが入っているわけではないので病院に行くまでもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since this was just a body-blow, and it is not the case that there is a fracture to the bone, there is no need to go to the hospital.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あのね......そんごくうはクリリンなんかとは比べるまでもなく、それどころかベジータよりもずっと強いんだから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Hey, there is no need to compare Goku to someone like Krillin, because he is far stronger than Vegeta.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この試験の難しさから考えると、試験の結果発表は見るまでもなく明らかだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Judging from this exam's difficulty, the results are clear without the need to see them.

Name: となると
Meaning: When, If, Once, As
About: となると is a strong expression in Japanese that focuses on highlighting that once some relatively high threshold is reached, (B) will occur. While となると may be seen in several different forms, the base structure is a combination of the particle と, the う-Verb なる 'to become', and the particle と repeated in its use of highlighting a certain outcome. Standard translations are 'once (A), (B)', and 'when (A), (B)'. A more literal translation can be thought of as 'once (A) happens, it is sure to follow that (B)'. The other forms that となると may be seen in are ともなると, となれば, and ともなれば. The primary difference being that も adds slight emphasis. While ば and と do have slightly different nuances by default, in terms of this specific grammar point, they are used completely interchangeably. となると may be seen following nouns, or verbs in any of their standard form. も may also be used following the subject of ともなると sentences, and simply places emphasis on that subject.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたも行くともなると、席が足りないので、車３台ではなく４台で行くことにしましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are also coming, there will not be enough seats, so let's take 4 cars instead of 3.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 会社のウェブページを作成するともなれば、優秀なプログラマーが必要になるだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We would probably need good programmers, once we start working on the company website.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ゴールデンウィークともなると、遊園地などは混む。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Amusement parks get crowded once Golden week starts.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社会人ともなれば、色々な社会的ルールを守らなければいけなくなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Once you become a member of society, there are various societal rules that you need to start following.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんなつまらない観光地も、週末ともなると観光客で賑わう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When the weekend starts, even the most boring tourist attractions are crowded.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ５０代となると体が思うように動かなくなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Once you turn 50, your body stops working like how you want it to. (Unavoidable due to age)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ５０代になると体が思うように動かなくなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Once you turn 50, your body stops working like how you want it to. (Simply stating that once you turn 50, your body won't be the same as it was before)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大人ともなると、幼馴染との友情は弱くなりつつあるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once you become an adult, the bond with childhood friends gets weaker and weaker.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: チームリーダーに就任するともなると、自分の仕事に限らずチームメンバーの仕事に責任があるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once you become a team leader, you will be responsible not only for your own but also for the work of team members.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 普段は貪欲ではない人でも、莫大な金額ともなると貪欲になるかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even people who are generally not greedy might become greedy when it comes to huge amounts of money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この辺りでは１１月ともなると中々寒さも厳しくなってくるため、これからの時期はヒートテックが必須だろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once it becomes winter around here, since the cold becomes quite harsh, it's probably necessary to buy some thermal clothing as of now.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここは普通の漁村だが、夏休みともなると大勢の客が来て、賑やかになります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is an ordinary fishing village, but when the summer vacation starts, a large number of visitors come and it becomes lively.

Name: を良(い)い事(こと)に
Meaning: To take advantage of
About: を良(い)いことに is an expression in Japanese that may be translated as 'to take advantage of (A)', and generally refers to someone that is using (A) as a good opportunity to do something that is either immoral, or irresponsible. This construction is a combination of を, the い-Adjective 良(い)い 'good', the noun こと 'thing', and the particle に. A more literal translation can be thought of as 'making good of (A), (B)', although the nuance is exactly the same as 'to take advantage of (A)' in English. を良(い)いことに will be seen following verbs, nouns, い-Adjectives and な-Adjectives, but will be preceded by either の or なの in all cases, based on standard conjugation rules for の. It is also quite common to see して attached to the end of を良(い)いことに without any significant change in either meaning or strength.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 顔が見えないのを良いことにひどいことを書き込む人は最低だと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think that people who write terrible things on the internet, taking advantage of anonymity, are the worst.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼が優しいのを良いことに、クラスメイトたちは彼をいじめた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Taking advantage of his niceness, his classmates bullied him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は美人であるのを良いことに、色々な男からお金を騙し取った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Taking advantage of her great looks, she swindled many men out of their money.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 休みなのを良いことに、友達と一日中ゲームをした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Taking advantage of my day off, I played video games all day with my friend.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生の耳が遠いのをいいことにして、授業中に友達と話していた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Taking advantage of my teacher being hard of hearing, I was talking with my friends during class.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は私が稼いでいるのを良い事に、遊んでばかりいます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Taking advantage of that I am turning a profit; he is doing nothing but having fun.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生の目が悪いのを良い事に試験中にカンニングしていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Taking advantage of the teacher's bad sight, I cheated during the exam.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私はお母さんが忘れっぽいのを良い事に、責任から逃れようとした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Taking advantage of that my mom is forgetful, I tried to evade taking responsibility.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は新入社員なのを良い事に、仕事が出来ないふりをしている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Taking advantage of that she is a new recruit; she is pretending that she doesn’t know how to do the work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 敵が罠にはまったのを良い事に、全力で総攻撃をしかけた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Taking advantage of the enemy being trapped, he launched an all-out attack.

Name: 如何(いかん)
Meaning: Depending on
About: いかん is a grammar structure that has evolved as an abbreviation of 如何(いか)に, an adverb meaning 'in what way'. In almost all circumstances, it can be translated directly as 'depending on', and will be followed by either the auxiliary verb だ at the end of sentences, or the conjunctive form of だ, で, when used in the middle of a sentence. いかん will follow nouns, and may or may not be preceded by の. Occasionally, いかん will be followed by によって. This may seem like repetition for no particular reason, but in most cases it will just strengthen the original meaning of 'depending on', and can be literally translated as 'depending on what way (A) is oriented, (B)'. いかん itself is used in a very similar way to 次第(しだい) 'upon (A)', or 'depending on (A)', and more often than not implies that the degree of (A) will be the factor that determines the overall result. Due to this, it will often be followed by subclauses that use verbs of decision making such as 決(き)まる.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 嵐の状況のいかんで、来週のイベントが中止されるかされないかが決まる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether or not next week's event will be canceled will depend on the status of the storm.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 前回の試験の結果いかんでどの大学に入れるかが決まる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Which college I can get into will depend on the result of my last exam.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 東大に入学できるかは、君たちの努力のいかんだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether or not you guys can get into Tokyo University would depend on your efforts.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来月昇進できるかは自分の業績いかんだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether I get a promotion next month depends on my performance.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 実験の結果いかんによっては、最初からやり直さないといけなくなる可能性もあります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Depending on the results of the experiment, we may have to start over from the beginning.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 入学試験の成績如何で、私の将来が決まる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Depending on the exam results, my future will be decided.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 中東情勢如何では石油価格が急上昇しかねない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The oil prices might surge depending on political tension in the Middle East.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 衝突事故ならば傷の状態如何によっては入院する場合もありうる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In the case of an accident, depending on the severity of the wound, hospitalization is also possible.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「応募者の採用・不採用は書類選考の結果如何です。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'The acceptance or rejection of the applicants depends on the results of the document screening.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 相手の対応如何では、今回の件を裁判沙汰にしようと思っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Depending on what way the other party responds, I am thinking that today's incident shall be a matter for the courts.

Name: ～るまでだ
Meaning: Just, Merely, Simply, Only
About: までだ, and までのことだ are structures that are usually translated as 'merely (B)', or 'simply (B)'. However, they are almost always used in somewhat hypothetical sentences, and translate much closer to 'one can only but (B)'. This nuance indicates a sense of resignation, or understanding on the part of the speaker that they personally have no options beyond (B). This grammar pattern will be used following verbs in their dictionary form, and will often come at the end of a sentence that uses なら in the first clause. In this way, it will mean 'if (A), then (B) is all that can be done'. (A) will almost always be a negative situation. Examining the standard meaning of the particle まで as signifying an extent, it can be seen that this meaning is kept in までだ, with the speaker expressing that (B) is the extent of what is possible given the negative circumstances brought about by (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰にも教えてもらえないなら、ネットで調べてみるまでだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If no one is going to teach me, I will just search it online.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もし失敗したのなら、もう一回挑戦するまでだ。失敗しても諦めないことが大切だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you made a mistake, you just have to try again. It is important to not give up even if you fail.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 誰も迎えにきてくれないのなら、電車で帰るまでのことだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If no one is going to come pick me up, I will simply go home by train.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この会社に入社できなかったら、別の会社を探すまでのことです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I can't join this company, I will simply look for a different one.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「問題が起きても、解決するまでだよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'If a problem arises, I will just solve it.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もしＪＬＰＴに落ちたら、もう一度試してみるまでのことだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I fail the JLPT, I will simply try it once again.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電車に乗り遅れたら、次のを待つまでのことだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I miss the train, I will simply wait for the next one.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夫婦の話：「やめなくちゃならないというなら、やめるまでのことだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A conversation between a couple: 'If you say I have to quit, then I will simply quit.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 祖国で就職できなかったら、外国へ移住することになるまでだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I can't find work in my motherland, I will simply move abroad.

Name: にあって
Meaning: At, In the (place or situation), Under ~ conditions or circumstances, During, Suited to
About: にあって is a fairly formal grammar construction used in Japanese in the same way as its component parts. The particle に indicates a location, while あって is the て-form of the う-Verb ある 'to be'. As such, にあって can be and is often translated simply as 'in the situation of (A)', or 'under the conditions of (A)'. にあって will be used after a noun marking the condition, before the second clause will then go on to explain something remarkable or noteworthy about that situation or circumstance. Occasionally, にあって will be followed by も. This slightly alters the meaning and indicates that despite being in the noteworthy situation of (A), (B) is not being affected in the way that one would expect.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は校長先生という立場にあって、いつも生徒たちのために一生懸命働いている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In the position of a principal, she is always working hard for the students.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: インフルエンザが流行っているという状況にあって、外にいる人はみんなマスクをしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In a situation where the flu is spreading, everyone outside is wearing masks.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 緊急事態宣言にあって、県を跨ぐ移動が制限された。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Under the state of emergency, movements across prefectures were restricted.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 緊急時にあっても、常に冷静を保つようにしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even under emergencies, please stay calm at all times.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな厳しい状況にあっても、諦めずに営業を続けていたから彼は儲けることができた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even under difficult circumstances like this, they were able to make a profit because they kept running their business without giving up.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 好況にあっても破産を申請している企業がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even during a boom, there are companies applying for bankruptcy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 危険な非常時にあっては、安全確保が第一だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Under emergency conditions, ensuring safety is the most important.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このような状況下にあって、医療機関へのアクセスは限定されているかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Under conditions like this, access to the medical institutions might be limited.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ＣＥＯのスピーチ：「混乱期にあっても心配せずに将来を見据えます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: CEO's speech: 'Even in this chaotic time, without fear, we look into the future.' (under...circumstances)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 歴史の教科書：「総理大臣という立場にあって、言論の自由のみならず動物の権利も提唱した。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
History textbook: 'In the position of Prime Minister, she advocated not only for the freedom of speech but also for animal rights.'
(under...circumstances)

Name: を余儀(よぎ)なくされる
Meaning: To be forced to do something
About: を余儀(よぎ)なくされる is a formal grammar pattern in Japanese that is usually translated as 'to be forced to (A)'. Its component parts are the adverbial particle を, the noun 余儀(よぎ) 'another method', the conjunctive form of the い-Adjective ない, なく, and the passive form of する, される. In this way, it literally means 'to not be given another way than to (A)'. を余儀(よぎ)なくされる will be seen following an (A) noun, where (A) is the thing that is unavoidable. In most cases, the subject of sentences that use を余儀(よぎ)なくされる will be a person, or something that is representative of people, such as a company. However, there are exceptions to this.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パーク内での迷惑行為が悪化し始めたため、人気撮影スポットの封鎖を余儀なくされた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to the worsening nuisance caused by guests in the park, they were forced to close off the popular photo spot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 飲食店はコロナの影響で、営業の自粛を余儀なくされた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Restaurants were forced to refrain from continuing business due to Covid.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近大きな地震があったため、この地域の人たちは避難所での生活を余儀なくされた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to a recent major earthquake, people in the area were forced to live in shelters.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 景気悪化のため、会社は閉鎖を余儀なくされた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Due to the economic downturn, the company has been forced to close down.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 津波が接近したため、野外コンサートは中止を余儀なくされた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because of the approaching tsunami, outdoor concerts were forced to be canceled.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 少子化により学生が減れば、多くの学校は閉校を余儀なくされるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If the number of students decreases due to declining birth rates, many schools will be forced to close down.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 国民による反発が強まったために、政府は補助金の配布を余儀なくされました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because of the intensified backlash from citizens, the government was forced to distribute relief subsidies.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 津波によって家を流されてしまった被災者達は、避難所での生活を余儀なくされた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As for the natural disaster victims whose homes were washed away as a result of the tsunami, they were forced to go about their daily lives at the evacuation site.

Name: とは
Meaning: That..., (Surprised) that..., (Never expected) that..., (Shocked) that...
About: とは is an emphatic structure that is regularly seen at the end of sentences, and will imply that the statement before it is shocking, appalling, or unexpected. In English, it translates very similarly as 'to think that (A)' in that it expresses a strong emotional response without expressly saying what that exact response is. とは is a combination of the case-marking particle と in its quotation use, and the adverbial particle は. In this way, it is just marking the whole statement of (A) as what is being highlighted as the topic, without actually stating anything else about it. とは may sometimes be seen following など or similar structures, and in these cases will just imply that 'something like (A)' is what is shocking.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まさかこんな場所でなつみちゃんに会うとは！元気にしてた？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I would have never expected to see you at a place like this! How have you been?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな安く家が買えるとは思わなかったよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I did not think that I would have been able to buy a house this cheap.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 君があんなに速く走れるとは...なんで今まで黙っていたんだい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I had no idea that you could run that fast… Why did you keep this from us?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな簡単なことで失敗するなどとは思っていなかったが、あいつに任せた俺が悪い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was not expecting him to fail at something so simple, but it was my fault for leaving it to him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まさか彼が私の知らないところでそんなひどいことを言っていたなどとは...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I had no idea that he was saying such horrible things behind my back…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高橋さんがもう結婚していたとは驚いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was surprised to hear that Mr. Takahashi was already married.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんなところでキアヌ・リーブスに出会ったとはねぇ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: I (never expected) that I would come across Keanu Reeves in a place like this!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「一戸建てに住むってこれほどまでに大変だったとは驚きだよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I'm shocked that living in a single family home would be this hard!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まさか二ヶ月で１０キロも痩せるとは！このダイエットは効果的だ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: I (never expected) that I would lose 10kg in two months! This diet is super effective!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: メアリーさんとたけしさんが去年もう一度新婚旅行に行ったとは驚いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was surprised that Mary-san and Takeshi-san went on another honeymoon last year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 病弱で内気だった田中さんがボクシングチャンピオンになるとは夢にも思わなかったよ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: I would never have even dreamed that sickly and reserved Tanaka-san would become a boxing champion. (never expected)

Name: じゃあるまいし
Meaning: You are not ~ so..., it isn't ~ so...
About: じゃ or ではあるまいし is an expression which can be translated in a similar way to 'it is not (A), so it is not (B)', or 'you are not (A), so you can't (B)', and is often used for criticism of something acting in a way that is not befitting of it. まい is an auxiliary verb which highlights negative-volitional statements. This means that it has a similar meaning to ないだろう. Due to this, the combination of では, the う-Verb ある 'to be', まい 'not as if', and し, the particle that highlights reasons, all combine to have a literal meaning of 'it is not as if it's (A), so therefore (B)'. じゃあるまいし will be used after nouns, or phrases that have been nominalized with something like の. The statement that follows じゃあるまいし will state the speaker's opinion in relation to (A), and will almost always be negative.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 親に止められているのではあるまいし、好きに自分が行きたいところに行けばいいんじゃないの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are not being stopped by your parents, so why don't you just go wherever you want to?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 減るわけではあるまいし、少しぐらい貸してくれてもいいじゃん。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not like it's going to decrease, so why don't you just let me borrow it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もう子供じゃあるまいし、行動する前に少しでも考えたらどうなの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You aren't a child anymore, so why don't you think a little before taking action.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 減るもんじゃあるまいし車を貸してくれ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You are not going to lose out or anything, so lend me your car, man.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供じゃあるまいしお菓子を見つけた途端に全部食べるな！
Questions.EnglishHTML: You are not a child, so don't instantly eat every sweet you stumble upon!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アニメじゃあるまいし、かわいい女の子は急に空から落ちてこない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is not an anime, so a cute girl won't suddenly fall out of the sky!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田中さん！新入社員でもあるまいし！そんな簡単なミスはすべきじゃないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tanaka-san! You are not a new employee, so you should not make such simple mistakes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お父さん、結婚するわけじゃあるまいし、ただの学校のパーティーだよ。泣かないで。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Papa, I am not getting married. It is just a school party, so please don't cry!

Name: ～てからと言(い)うもの
Meaning: After, Since, Ever since then
About: てからというもの is an extension of the grammar point てから meaning 'after (A)', and partners と言(い)う 'that which is' with もの 'thing'. It is often translated as 'ever since (A)', and will always express a new state of (B) that has been ongoing since (A). Although the literal translation is 'with that which was from (A)', the fact that (B) is ongoing is simply implied. As with てから, this structure will be seen following verbs in their て-form. Although not quite as common, からというもの may be seen following それ, when それ is at the beginning of a new sentence. In these cases, それ will linked to what was stated in the previous sentence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この会社に入社してからというもの、日付が変わる前に家に帰ったことがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ever since I joined this company, I have not been home before the clock ticks over midnight.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事に行く前に散歩に行くようにしてからというもの、どんどん体重が減ってきたのでこれからも散歩を続けようと思っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ever since I started to go on walks before work, I have been steadily losing weight, so I am thinking of continuing to go on walks.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ファイナルデスティネーションという映画を見てからというもの、木材を運んだトラックの後ろを走るのを避けるようになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ever since watching the movie 'Final Destination', I have been avoiding driving behind trucks carrying lumber.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は社長にみんなの前でものすごく怒られた。それからというもの彼は別人になったかのように性格が変わった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He was yelled at in front of everyone by the boss. Ever since that event, he became a different person.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先月彼女が痴漢にあった。それからというもの、満員電車を避けるようになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She was groped last month. Ever since then, she has been avoiding packed trains.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 赤ちゃんが生まれてからというもの、もっと本気で働くようになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Ever since the baby was born, I have come to take my job more seriously.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あやうく溺れかけてからというもの、泳ぎ方を習い始めました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Ever since I almost drowned, I started learning how to swim.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ツイート：「娘が生まれてからというもの、一日たりともろくに眠れていない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tweet: 'Ever since my daughter was born, I haven't been able to get a good night's sleep one single day.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スペースＸのファルコンヘビーの離陸を観てからというもの、宇宙が頭から離れない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Ever since watching the launch of SpaceX's falcon heavy, I cannot stop thinking about space.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 親友が鬱で自殺してからというもの、心理学を勉強してカウンセラーになりたいとずっと夢見ている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since my best friend commited suicide due to depression, I have constantly been studying psychology, and had the dream of wanting to become a counselor.

Name: 傍(かたわ)ら
Meaning: While, Besides, In addition to
About: 傍(かたわ)ら, seen primarily in hiragana, is a noun in Japanese that means 'bystander', in regard to something that is alongside or in the same place as the main focus. As a grammatical structure, it will be translated as 'while (A)', 'in addition to (A)', or 'besides (A)'. かたわら may come after nouns followed by の, or after the dictionary form of verbs. Something that can be remembered from the 'bystander' meaning of this word is that かたわら will always come after the primary action or state of (A), while (B) is considered to just be there incidentally to (A), or as being done secondarily to it. This usually takes the form of something like a side job or a hobby.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は飲食店を経営しているかたわら、鳶職人としても働いている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Besides running a restaurant, he also works as a steeplejack.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: グレッググラフィンは大学の教授をしているかたわら、歌手として活動している。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In addition to being a college professor, Greg Graffin is also active as a singer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の妹は本業のかたわら、英会話教室で英語を教えている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My sister teaches English at an English conversation class in addition to her day job.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 妻は子育てのかたわら、近所の子供達にそろばんを教えている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My wife teaches abacus to kids in the neighborhood in addition to raising our children.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 本業の傍らバイトなどの副業をしている多数の人々がいる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Besides working their main jobs, there are many people that also work part-time jobs on the side.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は大学で教える傍ら、家でも個人指導をしている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Besides teaching at university, she gives private lessons at home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: さらに大学での国語の教授をしている傍ら、漫画家として活躍している。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Moreover, besides holding the position of a Japanese professor at the university, he is also active as a manga artist.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ブルースは、昼は財閥を経営する傍ら、夜はバーマンとして危険地域を見回っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: During the daytime, Bruce manages his family corporation, while at night he patrols dangerous areas as BARMAN.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いくつかの国では、女性は仕事の傍ら、苦労をいとわず子供を育てている。立派なことだと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In some countries, women work in addition to raising their children, not minding the hardships. I think that is quite praiseworthy.

Name: を皮切(かわき)りに
Meaning: Beginning of, Starting with
About: を皮切(かわき)りに is a grammar structure that will be utilized with nouns in order to show the starting point for something, from which it then expanded, or something kept happening after. In most cases, を皮切(かわき)りに will just be translated as 'starting with (A)', or 'beginning with (A)'. This structure is a combination of the adverbial particle を, the noun 皮切(かわき)り 'beginning' or 'outset', and the case-marking particle に. It will appear after nouns or phrases that have been nominalized, before going on to explain how something continued to expand afterwards. In place of に by itself, にして and として are also standard variations of the same grammar pattern.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 藤田先輩がやめたのを皮切りに、他の人たちもどんどんやめていった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Starting with Fujita senpai quitting, others quit in quick succession.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの俳優はテレビ東京に出演したのを皮切りに、色々な局に出演することになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That actor started by appearing on TV Tokyo and then went on to appear on various stations.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 佐々木さんの発言を皮切りに、賛成する人が出てきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Starting with Sasaki-san's comment, some people began to agree with him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: クラスメイトの高橋さんを皮切りに、クラスみんな風邪になってしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Starting with Takahashi-san, my classmate, everyone in my class caught a cold.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女が社長に文句を言ったのを皮切りにして、みんな社長に文句を言い始めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Starting with her making a complaint to the boss, everyone started to make complaints to the boss.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのグループは名古屋を皮切りとして、全国でライブを行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Starting with Nagoya, that group performed throughout the country.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 店の移転を皮切りとして、売上げがどんどんと上がっています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Starting with the shop relocation, sales are rapidly increasing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それを皮切りとして、コンビニは相次いで出店し始めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Starting with that, convenience stores started opening one after the other.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 俳優の伝記：「『Ｙ-ＭＥＮ』に出演したのを皮切りにして、多数出演。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Actor's biography: 'Starting with his appearance in Y-MEN he appeared in numerous performances.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 皆川さんが監督として選ばれたのを皮切りにして、うちのチームは次々とスポーツの成功を掴んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Starting with Minagawa-san being chosen as our trainer, our team continued to be successful.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「レオナルド・ディカプリオはタイタニックの主人公になったのを皮切りにしてスターへの道を歩み始め、大ヒット映画に出演している。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Starting with his leading role in Titanic, Leonardo DiCaprio embarked on the road to stardom and has appeared in many hit movies.'

Name: に至(いた)っては
Meaning: When it comes to, As for, In particular, What is worse or more
About: に至(いた)っては is an expression which presents the most extreme example for something from within a specific category. Due to this, it will usually be translated as 'when it comes to (A), (B)', 'in particular to (A) is (B)', or 'with (A) as the most extreme example, (B)'. This is a combination of the case-marking particle に, the て-form of the る-Verb 至(いた)る 'to climax', or 'to culminate in', and the adverbial particle は in its standard role of presenting a topic. In this way, the literal meaning of 'culminating within (A) is (B)' is quite close to the nuance of the English translations. に至(いた)っては will appear following nouns, or nominalized phrases.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の家族は全員機械音痴です。母に至ってはインターネットさえ使えないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My whole family is mechanically illiterate. What's more, my mother can't even use the internet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近ここにいる社員みんなのやる気がない。藤田さんに至ってはパソコンもつけていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, employees here are unmotivated. As for Fujita-san, their computer isn't even turned on.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 漢字テストは４９点だった。リスニングに至っては２０点だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My kanji test's score was 49. What's worse is that my listening score was 20.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あそこのお宅の次男は留年するらしいですよ。長男に至っては学年トップだったらしいですよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that the second son of the family over there flunked. As for their eldest son, I heard that he was at the top of his grade. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 父親はパソコンならともかくスマートフォンに至ってはまるでお手上げらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My father isn't too bad if it is a PC, but when it comes to smartphones he seems to have given up.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ２０〇〇年は非常に乾燥していた。４月に至っては２回しか降らなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The year 20XX was a very dry one. April in particular, as it rained only twice.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 最近の子供は、かろうじてＣＤは知っているが、フロッピーに至っては全く知らない場合が珍しくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Children these days barely know CDs, but when it comes to floppy disks, it is not unusual if they know nothing at all about them.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 一人暮らしをしている息子の生活は荒れているようです。食生活に至っては、毎日カップラーメンを食べていると聞きました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It appears as though my son's independent lifestyle is tumultuous. When it comes to his eating habits, I heard that he has been eating cup-ramen every day.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の家族はみんな方向音痴です。母に至ってはナビゲーションアプリを使っても道に迷ってしまいます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As for my family, everybody has no sense of direction. What's more, mom gets lost even if she uses a navigation app.

Name: なり
Meaning: As soon as, The moment, When
About: なり is an old-fashioned particle in Japanese that has several different uses. One of those uses is to convey the meaning of 'as soon as (A), (B)', or 'the moment of (A), (B)'. This structure will follow the dictionary form of verbs and is classified as a conjunction particle. (B) is usually something that is surprising, and brought about by a strong sense of will or emotion. Additionally, なり is almost always used in relation to other people, rather than oneself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子が家に上がるなりトイレへと駆け込んだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My son ran to the toilet as soon as he entered the house.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ママ友が私の家に入るなり、冷蔵庫の中を物色し始めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As soon as my mom-friend came into my house, she started to go through my refrigerator.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は机に座るなりすぐスマホをいじり始めたから注意した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I warned him because he started playing on his phone as soon as he sat down.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 父が出張から帰るなり母は泣きだした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The moment father returned home from a business trip, mother started crying.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はジョークを聞くなり笑い出してしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As soon as she heard the joke, she bursted out laughing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うちの奥さんは毎日起きるなりスマホで電子メールを見ている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As soon as my wife wakes up, she checks mail on her smartphone.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 踊りを止めるなり、彼女が急にキスしてくれたんだ。気持ちいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As soon as I stopped dancing, she suddenly kissed me. I feel great.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 実家のお母さんからの電報が来るなり、山田さんは青ざめた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As soon as the telegram from his mother came, Yamada became pale.

Name: とも無(な)く
Meaning: Absentmindedly, Mindlessly, Unconsciously, Without paying attention
About: ともなく and ともなしに are structures used to indicate that (A) was being done absentmindedly when (B) happened. It will be translated as 'unconsciously (A) when (B)', or 'without paying attention to (A), (B)'. This pattern is a combination of the case-marking particle と, the adverbial particle も, and the conjunctive form of the い-Adjective ない. It will be seen after the dictionary form of verbs, and can be thought of as literally meaning something similar to 'even while not intending to (B), while (A), (B)'. ともなしに is similar, but pairs the noun なし 'without' with に, instead of using the conjugative form of ない. ともなく and ともなしに will often be seen in sentences that use たら. This puts emphasis on the specific time that something happened while performing another action absentmindedly. Despite translating this way, the action that precedes ともなく itself will be intentional, but the thing that comes about as a result of performing that action will not be what the doer was aiming to achieve.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日テレビを見るともなく見ていたら、急にお母さんが出てきたから驚いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I was absentmindedly watching TV yesterday, I was surprised when my mother suddenly appeared.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 話を聞くともなく、先生と黒板の方向をぼーっと見ていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I listened absentmindedly while staring towards the direction of my teacher and the blackboard.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 飲み会で上司の話を聞くともなしに聞いていたら、「お前はどう思う」と聞かれたから適当に返事した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I was at a drinking party and was absentmindedly listening to my boss, he asked what I thought, so I gave him a random response.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 暇だったから近所を歩くともなしに歩いていたら、高校の同級生にばったりあった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I was mindlessly walking in my neighborhood because I had nothing to do, I met my classmate from high school.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この曲は行きつけのバーでいつも流れているため、覚えるともなく覚えてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since this song is always playing at my favorite bar, I unconsciously memorized it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 隣人の窓を見るとも無く見ると、驚いたことに裸の人がいた。
