Questions.EnglishHTML: I looked at my neighbor's window without paying attention, and, to my surprise, there was a naked person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勝者の発表を聞くとも無く聞いていたら、なんと私の名前が挙がっていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I listened absentmindedly to the announcements of the winners, when, to my disbelief, my name came up.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ノベル：「彼は夜遅くテレビを見るとも無く見ているうちにいつのまにか寝入ってしまったようだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'It seems that he fell asleep while he was mindlessly watching TV late at night.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昨日、考えるとも無く考えているところに、スズメバチにひどく刺されて「痛っ！」思わず叫んでしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Yesterday, when I was thinking about nothing in particular, I was badly stung by a wasp, and without thinking shouted: 'Ouch!' (mindlessly)

Name: 塗(まみ)れ
Meaning: Stained, Covered in, Smeared, Dirty with, Soaked in
About: まみれ, seen primarily in hiragana only, is a grammar pattern that indicates being 'completely covered in (A)', 'smeared all over with (A)', or 'stained with (A)'. It will follow nouns, and may appear as まみれの when linked directly to a second noun that まみれ is modifying. In the vast majority of cases, まみれ will be used in regard to something that is negative, or can be perceived negatively even if it is not physical, like debt or desires. Examples of physically negative things include but are not limited to blood, mud, oil, etc.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お母さん：「服泥まみれじゃん！どうしたの？！」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Mother: 'You are covered in mud! What happened?!'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家に帰ったら犬が血まみれになっていたと思ったら、どうやらいちごジャムを食べて寝たみたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I got home, I thought my dog was covered in blood, but it seems like he ate some jam and fell asleep.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんな借金塗れの男とは付き合わない方がいいよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't think you should date a guy like that, who is drowning in debt!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ストップ！そんな泥まみれの服を洗濯機に入れないで！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Stop! Don't put clothes covered in mud in the washing machine!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 床は泥塗れになった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The floor became covered in mud.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供は泥塗れのまま遊んでいる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Children are playing while covered in mud.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 頭から汗塗れになって、走っている選手はすごいと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think that players running with their heads covered in sweat are amazing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 仕事で油塗れになったら、家に帰ってからシャワーを浴びると気持ちがいいよね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After getting soaked in oil at work, there's nothing better than having a shower after coming back home, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生の田中さんは氷で滑って雪の塊で転び、雪塗れになってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mr. Tanaka slipped on ice and fell on a lump of snow. He was completely covered in snow.

Name: う・よう + が～まいが
Meaning: Even if, No matter what, Whether or not, [Emphatic], Volitional + が
About: When both the positive and negative volitional auxiliary verbs are combined with a verb in Japanese, it has the nuance of 'whether or not (A)', the result will be (B)'. This is quite emphatic, and has a literal meaning similar to 'say it does (A) or say it doesn't (A), it will still be (B)'. As a reminder, the positive auxiliary verbs of volition are either う or よう, depending on what they are being connected to, while the negative auxiliary verb of volition is まい. Either the case marking particle が or と will appear after both the positive and the negative, with が being slightly more common. While this structure is primarily seen after verbs, it is important to remember that other auxiliary verbs such as だ can be conjugated in the same way, as can い-Adjectives with the less common かろう structure. This means that nouns, な-Adjectives and い-Adjectives can also appear using a similar grammar pattern. However, because the negative volitional まい cannot pair with these structures, an antonym will usually appear with them instead, with both words using the う or よう positive volitional. Based primarily on the use of volitionals, this grammar pattern will often indicate the speaker's strong will or opinion that will not change regardless of (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 忘年会に出席しようが出席するまいが、会費はみんなからもらっています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether you attend the year-end party or not, we will collect the admissions fee from everyone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 雨が降ろうが降るまいが、明日は絶対に釣りに行くと決めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether it rains or not, I have decided to go fishing tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 楽しかろうが楽しくなかろうが、学校は子供の仕事だから学校には行かなくてはだめだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether it is fun or not, school is a child's job, so you must go to school.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 安全だろうが安全でなかろうが、２メートル以上の場所に上がる場合は安全帯を必ず装着してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether it is safe or not, always wear a safety belt when you climb to a place higher than 2 meters.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犬であろうが猫であろうが、どちらにしても動物なので軽い気持ちで買ってはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether it is a dog or a cat, they are both animals, so they must not be bought on a whim.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何年がかかろうと、ドラゴンボールを見つけるつもりだ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if it takes many years, I intend to find the dragon balls!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人が何と言おうが、ずっとあなたを愛しています！
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter what people say, I will always love you!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 商品は上質であろうが悪質であろうが、よく売れるものはよく売れる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether the product is of good quality or low quality, if it sells well, it sells well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達が生きていようが生きていまいが、私は彼らのために歌い続ける。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether my friends are alive or not, I will still sing songs for them.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 生徒が授業に出席しようが出席するまいが、私はきちんと授業を進めていく。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether or not students attend, I will proceed with my lecture as planned.

Name: からする
Meaning: About, Or more, Over, Starts at
About: からする is a slightly formal grammar pattern in Japanese that appears after some kind of number or counter in order to indicate a minimum from which an estimation is being made. It will generally be translated as 'about (A)', '(A) or more', or 'starting at (A)'. This structure is a combination of the case-marking particle から, and the special verb する. It has quite a literal meaning in that a number is 'going from (A)', where (A) is the start point and the speaker doesn't know the exact amount. In addition to からする, からの may be used with the same meaning. However, unlike する, because の must attach directly to a second noun, からの is a bit more limited in the way it will be used.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その靴買ったの？それって１５万からするやつでしょ？やばいね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You bought those shoes? Those are the ones that cost 150,000 yen or more, aren't they? That's nuts.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この辺だと家賃は１５万からする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Around here, rent costs 150,000 yen or more.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 父から三百万円からする時計をもらった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I received a watch that costs 3,000,000 yen or more from my father.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この商品を製造するには、１億からのお金がかかる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In order to manufacture this product, it will cost 100 million yen or more.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日の大地震で十人からの人が行方不明になった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: 10 or more people have gone missing due to the big earthquake that happened yesterday.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １０５円からするライトを買ったらすぐ壊れた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I bought a light that went from 105 yen, it broke immediately. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕には１００万円からの腕時計を買う余裕はない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't have the surplus to buy a watch that goes from 1 million yen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スタジアムに１０万人からの人が集まったそうだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that over 100,000 people gathered at the stadium.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この辺りはとても高いよ。家賃は１０万円からする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This neighborhood is awfully expensive. The rent is around 100,000 yen or more.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ビルさんは彼女に２００万ドルからする車を買ってあげたらしいわ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that Bill gave his girlfriend a car that is worth over 2 million dollars.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アーノルドさんはもう７２歳なのに１００キロからのダンベルを持ち上げられるよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mr. Arnold can lift over 100 kg of dumbbells even though he is 72!

Name: にして ①
Meaning: At, Over, In, Only (after, when, or because)
About: When the case-marking particle に is combined with the て-form of する, it often carries the meaning of 'at (A)', 'over (A)', or 'only when (A)'. This nuance is used when (A) is something that is a fairly high level, or some point that would be considered a prime example for any given topic. にして may appear following counters, or standard nouns. While にして marks (A) as some particular exemplar, what follows may either be something that is or is not considered befitting of that example. In this way, (B) generally describes something that either does or does not fulfill the expectations of (A), and perhaps why. It is common to see にして followed by grammar patterns such as ようやく 'finally', or 初(はじ)めて 'only when'. These function to emphasize にして even further as being a point from which something is achieved or attained.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ３０歳にして初めて海外旅行に行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At the age of 30, I traveled abroad for the first time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 五回目にしてやっと資格を取ることができた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was finally able to get my qualification only after my fifth try.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犯人たちは道を曲がって、一瞬にして暗闇の中へと消えた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The perpetrators turned off the road and disappeared into the darkness in an instant.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ５０歳にしてようやく、イタリアに住んでいる従兄弟の家に行くことができた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At age 50, I was finally able to visit my cousin who lives in Italy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 母は６０歳にして初めて、コンサートに行ったらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My mother went to a concert for the first time at the age of 60.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はバブルがはじけたことにより一夜にして破産者となった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Due to the bubble burst, he went bankrupt overnight. (only (after/when/because))

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 釈迦は２９歳にして初めて、宮殿を出た。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Buddha left the palace for the first time at the age of 29. (only (after/when/because))

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは西尾維新のような文豪にして初めて書ける名著だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a masterpiece that could only be written when a literary giant like Nishio Ishin did it for the first time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ふうかはあきつき氏夫妻の結婚２０年目にして初めて授かった長女だった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Fuuka was the first daughter that the Akitsuki couple was blessed with in the 20th year of their marriage. (only (after/when/because))

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 宝くじに当たって一夜にして大金持ちになった彼が、お金の価値を理解する事は無いでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Having won the lottery and becoming incredibly rich overnight, he cannot understand the value of money, can he?

Name: ものを
Meaning: But, Although, If only, I wish I had
About: ものを is a grammar point that functions in a similar way to のに in that it will express that (A) is something that was desired, despite (B) being the actual result. However, it is primarily used when the speaker is trying to convey their displeasure at the result of (B), due to (A) being something that by all means should have happened. ものを will be translated as 'if only (A)', or '(A), but (B)'. Despite being a construction of もの and the adverbial particle を, ものを is often considered as a standalone conjunction particle. It can be seen following verbs or い-Adjectives in their standard form, or な-Adjectives followed by な. As can be seen in the above examples, ものを is almost always preceded by hypothetical structures such as ば at some point leading up to its use.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もっと早くに歯医者に行けば歯を抜かずに済んだものを...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you went to the dentist earlier, they wouldn't have had to remove your tooth, but…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 目を合わせなかったら止められなかったものを、なんで警察なんかと目を合わせちゃうんだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If only you didn't make eye contact with the police, we wouldn't have been stopped, so why did you have to go and make eye contact with them?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アレルギーなどがあったなら、さきに言ってくれればいいものを...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you had an allergy, you should have let me know beforehand, but…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 「手伝って」って言えばいいものを、一人でやるからこう言う目に遭うんだよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you have just asked for help, but because you did it alone, it ended up like this.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: みんなでやれば簡単なものを...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would have been easy if we all worked on it together, but…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 道具を使えば楽なものを、わざわざ自分の力でやろうとするから怪我をするんだよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would have been easier if you used tools, but because you went out of your way to try it without any tools, you ended up getting hurt.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 素直に認めていればいいものを...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I should have just been honest, but… (I should have just been honest, but instead I continued to lie)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 政治ポスター： 「日本を前へ。」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Political poster: Japan forward. (Verb omitted but obvious from context, the positive improvement of Japan)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「嫌いなものがあったなら、そう言ってくれればいいものを...」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'If there was something you didn't like, you should have said so, but…'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 父は息子に言う：「ＲＩＮＥでメッセージをしてくれたら迎えに行ってあげたもんを...」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Father speaking to his son: 'If you had messaged me on Rine, I would have picked you up, but… (you didn't).'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 犯罪コメディ映画、トニー：「まったく、ボリス、おとなしく死んでおればいいものを...」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Crime comedy movie, Tony: 'Dear God, Boris, it would have been good if you had just shut up and died, but…'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「もっと早くタバコをやめれば健康問題なしに済んだものを、手遅れになってしまった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'If I had quit smoking much earlier I would have ended up without any health problems, but now it is too late.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「彼が君に謝ったのなら許すべきものを、子供じゃあるまいし、無視するなんてひどすぎるよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'You are not a child! If he is apologizing, you should forgive him, but ignoring him is too cruel!'

Name: であれ
Meaning: Even if, Even, No matter
About: Functioning as an extension of である, the formal copula that is a combination of the conjunctive form of the auxiliary verb だ, and the う-Verb ある, であれ or であろうと will be used in order to express strong will or conviction. あれ is simply the imperative form of ある, while あろうと is the positive volitional form combined with the case-marking particle と. Both structures are usually translated as 'even if (A), (B)', or 'no matter if (A), (B)'. Despite this, the more literal meaning of each is closer to 'so it's (A), (B) still won't be affected'. This just emphasizes the fact that (A) is of no relation to the result, like saying 'so what if it is' in English. Both であれ and であろうと will primarily attach to nouns in sentences that express some kind of question or assumption through words like どんな or たとえ. As both であれ and であろうと use structures that indicate strong will, these grammar patterns will frequently be used in sentences where the speaker is expressing their opinions or resolutions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供であれ、法律は守らなくてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if you are a child, you still need to obey the law.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 理由が何であれ、家族や友達を裏切るのはよくないと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter the reason, I don't think it is right to betray your family and friends.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いくらあなたが年上であろうと、ここでは一応私が先輩なので私の言うことに従ってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how much older you are, I am your superior here so please do as I say.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 上司からのメール：「インフルエンザであろうと、会社には来てください。」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Email from one's boss: 'Even if you have the flu, please come to work.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰であれ全ての人々は同様に死ぬ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter who you are, all people die similarly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「どのような状況であれ、逃げることは許されない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'No matter the circumstances, running away is unforgivable.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 何であれ、両親にとっては我が子はいつも愛する我が子。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter what, from a parent's point of view, their child is always their beloved child.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たとえ小さなものであれ検察官は賄賂を受け取るわけにはいかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if it is just a small thing, the public prosecutor must not accept a bribe.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: たとえ氷のように純粋であれ、世界の悪からは免れられないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even if one is as pure as ice, it seems that one cannot avoid the evil of the world.

Name: を措(お)いて他(ほか)に〜ない
Meaning: No...but, Nothing else but, None other than
About: を措(お)いて is a grammar pattern that expresses something similar to 'none other than (A)', or 'nothing else but (A)'. を措(お)いて is a combination of the adverbial particle を, and the て-form of the う-Verb 措(お)く 'to set aside'. In this way, the literal meaning is similar to English phrases like 'setting aside (A), (B)', where (B) will be a broad statement about something that cannot be fulfilled by anything but (A). を措(お)いて will follow nouns or noun phrases, and frequently have 他(ほか)にない directly after it, emphasizing the point that 'there is no other'. を措(お)いて tends to only be used when the speaker positively evaluates (A), and is giving it praise in saying that nothing else can compare to it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんなに人類学に詳しい人は高橋教授をおいてほかにいない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No one knows anthropology better than Professor Takahashi.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最初のライブは、大阪をおいてほかにない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The first concert will be held in none other than Osaka.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語の文法を習いたいなら、文プロをおいてほかにない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you want to learn Japanese grammar, there is none other than Bunpro.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 長年付き合ってきたパートナーに別れを切り出すのなら明日をおいて他にはない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you're going to broach the subject of breaking up with a long-time partner, there's nothing like tomorrow. (no choice but)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 我が子の世話を安心して任せられるのは、実の両親と妻をおいて他にはいません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When it comes to entrusting the care of my child with peace of mind, there's none other than my parents and my wife.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう今年で四十歳になる事だし、結婚を本気で考えているのなら次の機会をおいて他にはないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since you're already going to be 40 years old this year, if you're going to seriously think about marriage, then the next chance is all there is, right? (nothing but)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語の勉強を始めたばかりの初心者の方におすすめするアプリを一つあげるとするなら、「文プロ」を措いて他にありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I were to mention an app that I would recommend for beginners that have just started learning Japanese then it would be none other than 'Bunpro.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 探偵は容疑者に言う：「とぼけないでください。これほど事件について知っているのは犯人自身を措いて他にいないでしょう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Detective speaking to the suspect: 'Don't play dumb. No one but the murderer himself knows this much about the murder.'

Name: をもって
Meaning: As of, With, Effective from
About: When used with time related expressions, the structure をもって is often translated as 'as of (A)', or 'effective from (A)'. This grammar pattern is a construction of the adverbial particle を, and もって 'by means of'. をもって will be used after nouns that indicate a time, or an event that happens at a specific time. As is frequently seen in polite speech or in official notifications, をもって may sometimes be read as をもちまして. Alternatively, the small っ (called a 促音(そくおん)) may occasionally be dropped. This results in をもて.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このゲームのオンラインサービスは２０２３年８月１０日をもって終了することに決定しました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It has been decided that the online service for this game will end as of August 10, 2023.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 本日をもって、受付を終了いたします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As of today, we will no longer be accepting applications.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今回のツアーをもって、解散することになりました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We have decided to disband as of this tour.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いつもご来店ありがとうございます。この店舗は本日をもちまして閉店いたします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thank you for always visiting our shops. As of the day of writing, this store location will be closed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 父は４月２日をもて、４０年間勤めていた会社をやめることにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As of April 2nd, my father decided to quit the company he had worked for for 40 years.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ２０２３年７月２７日をもって、人気映画の続編が公開されます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The sequel to the popular film will be released on July 27, 2023. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 以上をもちまして、私のスピーチは終わりとさせて頂きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'With this, I would like to conclude my speech.' (effective from)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会議、問いかけに答えた後：「これをもちまして質疑応答を終わります。ありがとうございます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: The conference, after answering a question: 'With this, I will end the question-answer session. Thank you very much.' (effective from)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 辞令：「一条蛍殿。令和２年５月１日をもって経理部第５課勤務を命ずる。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Appointment notice: 'Ichijou Hotaru, we appoint you to a position in the fifth section of the accounting department, effective (from) May 1st, 2020.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誠に勝手ながら「可愛い店」は本日をもちまして閉店いたします。長きに渡りご愛顧、誠にありがとうございました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We regret to inform you that 'KawaiiMise' will close as of today. We are truly thankful for the long-lasting patronage. (effective from)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 司会：「以上をもちまして、２０２１年度の運動会を閉会致します。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Master of ceremonies: 'With this, I will bring a close to the 2021 sports carnival.'

Name: とは言(い)え
Meaning: Though, Although (I admit that), Be that as it may, Nonetheless
About: とは言(い)え is one of the standard grammar patterns in Japanese that makes use of the imperative form in order to strongly state a point. It will often be translated as 'although (A), (B) will not change', or 'be that as it may, (B)'. Literally, it is just making use of the case-marking particle と in addition to the adverbial particle は to present (A) as a quote that the speaker acknowledges, but may not actually accept. As this structure begins with と, it may be used at the end of any standard statement. In most situations, the way that とはいえ will be used is like the English 'say that it is (A), that still doesn't change (B)'. (A) will generally be something that is true, or true as far as the speaker knows.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この事件の犯人が分かったとはいえ、犯人はまだ捕まっていないからまだ油断はできない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although the culprit in this case is known, we can't let our guard down yet because the culprit has not been caught yet.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このパソコンは新しいといえ、今持っているパソコンより性能がいいと言うわけではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although this computer is new, it does not mean that it has better features than the computer that I already own.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この国は安全だといえ、日本ではないので子供から目を離さないようにしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although this country is safe, it is not Japan, so please keep an eye on your child.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本人とはいえ、スペインで育ったから日本語があまり話せない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although I am Japanese, I grew up in Spain so I can't speak much Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 馬は肉を食べることができる。とは言え、普通は食べない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Horses are perfectly capable of eating meat. Having said that, they generally do not eat it. (be that as it may)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 犯人は逮捕されたとは言え有罪と宣告されるまで時間がかかるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although (I admit that) the criminal has been caught, it will be some time before they are declared guilty. (be that as it may)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は社長とは言え名前ばかりだ。権限は取締役会にある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although he is admittedly the company president, it is in name only. It is the board of directors that holds the power. (be that as it may)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今では、パンデミックの進行状況は遅いとは言え、まだ安心するわけにはいかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although (I admit that) the progress of the pandemic is slow, we cannot afford to feel at ease just yet. (be that as it may)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女があなたにとって実の母親であるとは言え、礼儀を欠くべきではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although she is, for you, your real mother, you should not lack manners.

Name: ならでは
Meaning: Unique to, Only, Impossible if not, Expected only of
About: ならでは is a construction which indicates that something is 'unique to (A)', or 'impossible if not (A)'. While ならでは is usually considered as its own standalone word, it is actually just a combination of the negative-conjunctive form of the the classical copula なり, ならで, with the addition of the adverbial particle は. ならでは will follow nouns, and the sentence will then usually go on to say what the thing is that is unique to (A). As seen in the above examples, ならでは will only be used when something is being evaluated positively. As a result of this, it is very common to see in advertising and slogans.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 味噌カツは名古屋ならではの食べ物です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Misokatsu is a food unique to Nagoya.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アメリカならではの観光地といったらどこを連想しますか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Where do you think is a tourist attraction that is unique to the States?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この祭りはこの地域ならではの祭りです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This festival is unique to this area.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな綺麗な作品を作れるのは、藤田さんならではだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Only you, Fujita-san, can create such an amazing piece.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車なしで生活できるのは都会ならではだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Only in the city can one live without a car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このクリーミーで且つ重くない絶品のカルボナーラは地元の名店ならではだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This exquisite, creamy, and moreover light carbonara is expected only of a famous shop in our region.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食品広告：「おばあさんの手作りならではなかなか出せない味だ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Food product advertisement: 'Unique flavor that can only be found in grandma's homemade cooking.' (unique to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 求人のサイト、求人情報：「小さいカフェならではの良さが溢れています。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Job search website, job information: 'The charm unique to a small cafe is overflowing.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 広告ポスター：「沖縄ならではの、普段は見られない透明度の高い青い海は必見だ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A poster ad: 'The extremely clear blue waters that can usually only be seen in Okinawa are a must-see.' (unique to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 求人のサイト、店員コメント：「こうした社風の良さは当社ならではだと思います。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Job search website, employee comment: 'I think that the good quality of our corporate culture is unique to this company.'

Name: すら
Meaning: Even
About: すら is an adverbial particle in Japanese that basically translates as 'even'. The primary difference between it and も is that すら tends to present far more extreme examples to which a specific rule applies, and therefore also applies to all other less extreme examples. In most cases すら will be used with a negative nuance. As すら is an adverbial particle, it will be seen directly after nouns, or nouns followed by case-marking particles. すら may also be followed by も in order to emphasize the point even further.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 鉛筆すら持ってきてないの？本当にやる気あるの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You didn't even bring a pencil? Do you actually want to do this?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供ですらできることをできないのか。お前よくここまで生きてこれたな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You can't do what even a child can do. How have you managed to live this long?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼にすら話してないのに、親と話すわけがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I haven't even talked to my boyfriend about it, there is no way I'm telling my parents.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ガラケーすらも使えないのに、パソコンが使えるわけないじゃん。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't even use a flip phone, there is no way I can use a computer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そこさえ乗り越えれば、あとは楽になるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you can overcome that, everything will be a breeze.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなことさえ乗り越えることができないのなら、この先何もできませんよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you can't even overcome something so simple, you won't be able to do anything beyond this point.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: マンガの迷った主人公：「何日たったのかすら...」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A lost manga protagonist: 'I don't even (know) how many days have passed…'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 南極大陸では夏ですら気温が０度以下である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In Antarctica, temperatures are below zero even in summer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「カラスは道具を使用する能力を示したことすらあります。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'Crows have even demonstrated the ability to use tools.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ノベル、語り手：「負傷により、走るどころかベッドから立ち上がることすらもできない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A novel, narrator: 'Due to her injuries, let alone running, she can't even stand up out of bed.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ノベル、語り手：「友達どころか家族にすら説明せずに旅に出た。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A novel, narrator: 'Without even explaining to his family, let alone friends he embarked on a journey.'

Name: あっての
Meaning: Exist only because of or due to, Owe everything to
About: あっての is a pattern which emphasizes that (B) is something that only exists because of (A). It will often be translated as '(B) owes everything to (A)', or '(B) existing is only due to (A)'. This structure is a combination of the う-Verb ある 'to be' in its て-form, and the case-marking particle の. あっての will be preceded and followed directly by nouns, where the first noun is (A), and the second noun is (B). あっての will primarily be used when (B) is something that benefits positively from (A), and therefore is showing or should show some kind of gratitude toward it. Occasionally, the case-marking particle が will come between the (A) noun and あっての. However, it is often omitted.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客様あっての仕事だと思うのですが、理不尽なクレームを言われるとちょっとイラっときます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My job only exists because of the customers, but I get a little annoyed when people make unreasonable complaints.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今回は皆様の努力あっての結果です。皆様本当にありがとうございました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This time, the results are because of your efforts. Thank you very much.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はお金がなかったら愛もない、お金があっての幸せだと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think that love exists only because of money, and without money there is no love.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼が大学をやめるのは、何か理由があってのことだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I guess he is dropping out of university only because some sort of reason exists.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「あなたあってのわたしです。あなたがいなければ私の人生は無意味ですよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I can only exist because of you. My life would be meaningless without you.' (owe everything to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 支配人、社員に：「ゲストあっての遊園地だということを忘れてはいけません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Manager to employees: 'You must not forget that the amusement park exists only because of the customers.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 恋愛は相手あってのことだから一人だけでは無理だ...と思っていませんか？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Love only exists because you have a partner, so it is impossible to love when you are alone… don't you think? (owe everything to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 部員あってのクラブ活動なんだから、部員に対してもっと優しくするべきだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since club activities exist only because of our club members, we must be nicer to them.

Name: ～たまで + だ
Meaning: Just, Merely, Simply, Only
About: In comparison to ～るまでだ, the grammar pattern expressing that 'one can only but (A)', ～たまでだ works in a similar way, with the past tense of the verb indicating that 'doing (A) was all it was'. This emphasis is usually translated as 'I simply (A)', or 'I only (A)', with nuance on the action not being something especially big. Like ～るまでだ, ～たまでだ may be replaced with ～たまでのことだ, depending on what the speaker is trying to emphasize. As this structure emphasizes that (A) is not a big deal, it will often be used in order to modestly highlight that one only did the bare minimum, and therefore praising them is unnecessary.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なんで俺が悪者扱いされないといけないんだ？俺はただ自分の意見を言ったまでだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why do I have to get blamed for this? I only expressed my opinions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お婆さんが困った顔をしていたから、助けたまでだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I just helped because the old lady looked like she needed help.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近学校にも行かないし部屋からも出ないから、聞いたまでのことだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I merely asked because recently, you haven't left your room and haven't gone to school.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなお礼とかはやめてください、人として当たり前のことをしたまでです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please, don't thank me. I just did something expected as a human.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は私が困っていたから、助けてくれたまでだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Because I looked like I was in need, he merely helped me. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なんで怒っているの？私の意見を言ったまでのことだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Why are you angry? I merely stated my opinion.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「助けてくれてありがとうございます！」
Ｂ：「いや、当然のことをしたまでのことです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'Thank you very much for helping me!'
B: 'Not at all. It was just the obvious thing.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「わぁ、日本語上手だね！」
Ｂ：「ただ趣味で勉強してたまでのことで、まだまだだけどね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'Wow, your Japanese is good!'
B: 'I was merely learning it as a hobby. I still have a ways to go.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕はただ伝言を頼まれたから伝えたまでで、それは僕の考えではないからね！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since I was just requested to have a word with you, that's merely all I did, it's not like they were my thoughts.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 真実を話したまでのことなのに、なぜかクラスメイトから嘘つきと言われてしまいました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When I just told the truth, I was accused by my classmate of being a liar for some reason.

Name: を経(へ)て
Meaning: Via, Through, After (experience at job, university, etc.), Pass through
About: を経(へ)て is a fairly formal grammar point used when highlighting a passage of time, or an event that took a certain amount of time. 経(へ)る itself is a る-Verb that means 'to elapse' or 'to pass' in terms of time. The difference between it and 過(す)ぎる 'to pass time' is that 過(す)ぎる focuses on having reached the end point, while 経(へ)る focuses on what was happening for the whole period leading up to that end point. Because of this, を経(へ)て can also be translated as 'having undergone (A)', due to the emphasis being on the preceding action. を経(へ)て will directly follow nouns, and the rest of the sentence usually then goes on to describe the significance of that passage of time or experience, or what happened as a result. As it is a formal structure, を経(へ)て is often seen in biographies, introductions, and similar media.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私たちは２０１９年に出会って、約２年間の交際を経て結婚しました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We met in 2019, and married after going through two years of dating.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本への留学を経て、日本の文化などを学ぶことができました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Through my study in Japan, I was able to learn about Japanese culture and other aspects of the country.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 人は色々な経験を経て、成長していく。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: People grow through various experiences.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ベルリンからローマを経てブエノスアイレスに向かいます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From Berlin, via Rome, to Buenos Aires. (through)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 数世代を経てもなお争議が続いている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even after several generations, the dispute still continues. (through・via・experience)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ちとげとらくは、約１０年の交際を経て結婚した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chitoge and Raku finally married after going through about ten years of dating. (through・via・experience)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 略歴：「早稲田大学理学部卒業後Ｇｏｏｇｌｅ勤務を経て２０２〇年独立。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Short bio: 'Graduated from the department of science, Waseda University. After (having the experience of) working at Google, he started his own business in 202X.' (through・via)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新聞：「今後必要な手続きを経て、鉱山買収は完了します。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Newspaper: 'After going through all of the necessary procedures, the mine acquisition will be complete.' (through・via・experience)

Name: ながら + に
Meaning: While being, Born (with), Traditional (old-fashioned, as it was long ago), As always, While crying or in tears, (Burned) alive
About: When combined with the case-marking particle に, ながら 'while' as a suffix will indicate that something remains in the state of (A), while also having or doing (B). This can be translated as 'while being (A), (B)', or '(A) as always (B)'. ながらに will be seen following nouns, or verbs in their stem form. Additionally, して may be added to the end of に, without any change to the nuance. ながらに is a structure that has many potential translations in English, but the key point to remember is that (B) is something that is being highlighted as happening or existing in same state as (A) in an unchanged state. This doesn't necessarily mean at the same time. For example, in the case of 生(う)まれながらに, it can be translated as '(B) has existed since birth', but what it really means is that 'while being in the state of (A), (B) is still there'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自由権は人が生まれながらに持っている権利の一つだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Freedom is one of the rights that people are born with.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家に居ながらにして仕事ができるから、職場までわざわざ行かなくても良くなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can work while being home, so I don't have to go all the way to my workplace anymore.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は涙ながらに彼を見送った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She sent him off while crying.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供ながらにして、なんで親がいつも喧嘩をしていたかは理解していた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even as a child, I understood why my parents were always fighting.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 生きながら焼かれるところだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She was almost burned alive. (while alive)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつもながらあなたたちと話すのは楽しいですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is a pleasure to talk with you, as always.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コナンは生まれながらのすぐれた名探偵だそうだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They say that Conan is a great detective by nature. (by birth).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テレワークというのは家に居ながら働くということだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Telework means to work while being at home.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コウタはカエデからの手紙を手に取りつつ、涙ながらに喜んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While crying with joy, Kouta held the letter from Kaede in his hands. (in tears)

Name: ～たなり
Meaning: While... ~ing, Remaining, Not or ever since, Keep or leave
About: When following the た, past-tense form of a verb, the conjunction particle なり 'shape' indicates something existing in an ongoing state, similar to まま. This may be translated as 'while (A)', or 'remaining (A)'. Due to ～たなり sentences usually describing something happening while in the state of (A), it will often be followed directly by a comma, or by the conjunctive form of the auxiliary verb だ, で. After this, the (B) phrase will then describe what is happening during (A). ～たなり will primarily be used to express an undesirable state continuing despite (A) having happened, although this is not a strict rule. As ～たなり indicates that (A) is something that is continuing to stay in the same state, it will often have the nuance of 'ever since (A)' in situations where a significant amount of time has passed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 弟は彼女に振られて部屋に入ったなり、全然部屋から出てこなくなってしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ever since my brother locked himself in his room after his girlfriend broke up with him, he hasn't come out of his room at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 父が釣りにいったなりまだ帰ってこない、大丈夫かな...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My father hasn't come back home since he went out fishing. I wonder if he is okay…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 兄は上京したなり、帰ってこない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My older brother hasn't come back, ever since he moved to Tokyo.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は腰かけたなりじっと考えていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While remaining seated, he has been pondering intently.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 町を離れたなり消息は途絶えた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We haven't heard from her ever since she left the city.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ３年前に涙ながらに家出したなり、帰ってこない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She ran away three years ago in tears, and hasn't come back (ever) since.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: レース後、草の上に横になったなり、泣き続けた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After the race, he cried while lying down on the grass.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 宿泊客の一人がドアを開けたなりにしてあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: One of the hotel guests left the doors open.

Name: の極(きわ)み
Meaning: Ultimate, Extreme, Utter, Epitome, Peak
About: When paired with a noun followed by the case-marking particle の, 極(きわ)み 'extremity' will indicate something that is 'the ultimate (A)', 'the extreme (A)', or 'the epitome of (A)'. This may be used in either positive or negative sentences. As 極(きわ)み itself is a noun, it will often be followed by the auxiliary verb だ, or the conjunctive form で when going on to describe something that is as a result of (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あと５分待って居れば私が大好きなアイドルに会えていたとは...痛恨の極みだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If only I had waited five more minutes, I would have met my favorite idol... It's the peak of despair.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今までこんなに良くしてくれて、感激の極みです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am beyond thrilled that you have been so good to me so far.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 有給は取るなとか鬼畜の極みだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Telling us to not take paid time off? That's the epitome of being evil.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんな景色がいいところで、こんな美味しい料理を食べられるなんて、なんて贅沢の極みだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's the ultimate luxury to be able to eat such delicious food in such a scenic place.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この曲の歌詞は感動の極みで、聞くたびに涙が溢れ出てくる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The lyrics of this song are the peak of emotion and bring tears to my eyes every time I listen to it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: タイトル：「シンプルの極み！絶品『ハンバーグ』の作り方」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Title: 'The epitome of simplicity! The recipe for a perfect Hamburg steak.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 地震によってビルに閉じ込められた人々は混乱の極みにあった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The people trapped in the building due to the earthquake were in extreme (utter) turmoil.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「ダイモス王はこの報道を聞いて、驚きの極みに達しました。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'Hearing the news, the King Daimos reached the very peak of surprise.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 目上の人にはじめて出会う時：「お目に掛かることができ、光栄の極みです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: When meeting a superior for the first time: 'It is an extreme honor to be able to meet you.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 釈迦様は当初贅沢の極みを尽くした生活をしていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At first, Buddha lived an utterly luxurious life.

Name: にして + 見(み)れば
Meaning: For (A), In the case of (A), From (A)'s point of view, In the eyes of (A)
About: にしてみれば, usually written completely in hiragana, is an expression used when the speaker is making a hypothetical statement about how something may appear from the point of view of another. It will often be translated as 'from the point of view of (A), (B)', 'in the case of (A), (B)', or simply 'for (A), (B)'. Literally, the meaning is 'assuming that I was (A) and then looking from there, (B)'. にしてみれば will appear after nouns that represent a person, or organizations representative of people. It is a combination of the case-marking particle に, the て-form of する, and the hypothetical form of 見(み)る, 見(み)れば. As にしてみれば will exclusively follow words that indicate a person or a group of people, the (B) part of the phrase will usually discuss how the speaker assumes that they would feel given the situation. Because of this assumption, these sentences often finish with だろう, でしょう, かもしれない, and other similar structures.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 上級者には簡単かもしれないが、初心者にしてみればかなり難しいと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For someone who is experienced it may be easy, but for someone new, I think it would be difficult.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本人の私にしてみれば、日本語は簡単だけど英語は難しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a Japanese person, Japanese is easy, but English is hard.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アニメをあまり知らない人にしてみれば、ポケモンもデジモンも同じアニメだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the point of view of someone who doesn't watch anime, Pokemon and Digimon are the same anime.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ハリーにしてみれば、優しくしてもらうなど、初めての経験だった。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
For Harry, it was the first time he had ever been treated kindly.
(From the perspective of Harry)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 傍から見ればただの安っぽいペンダントだろうが、ラクにしてみれば貴重な思い出の品になっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
It might appear to be a mere cheap pendant from the side, but for Raku, it has become a precious memento.
(From the perspective of Raku)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大人には非常に簡単だが、小さな子供にしてみればかなり困難なことかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
For an adult, it is very simple, but for a small child, it might be quite hard.
(From the perspective of a small child)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私たちにとっては危険すぎるようにみえる彼の生活は、彼自身にしてみればごく普通のことなのでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML:
His life that seems too dangerous to us, is likely quite ordinary for him.
(From his perspective)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
友達１は失敗した友達２を励ます、友達１：「たいしたことじゃありませんよ。」
友達２：「いや、わたしにしてみたら、たいしたことなんだよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Friend 1 reassuring Friend 2 who has made a mistake, Friend 1: 'Come on, it's not a big deal!'
Friend 2: 'No, this is a big deal FOR me!'
(From my perspective)

Name: だの
Meaning: Things like, And so on, Or something, And whatnot
About: Although originally a combination of the auxiliary verb だ, and the case-marking particle の, だの is considered to be a standalone adverbial particle in modern Japanese that is used in the same way as structures like など and とか in presenting examples. Due to this, it will often be translated as 'and things like (A)', or '(A) and whatnot'. だの will only be used when at least two examples are given, with each of those examples being followed by だの. Usually, these two things are either opposites of each other, or two things that share the same negative trait. だの may appear after verbs, い-Adjectives, nouns, or quotations.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は仕事はやめるだの家事を手伝わないだの、本当に自分以外のことは何も考えていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He does things such as quit work, and not help with chores and so on. He really does not think about anyone other than himself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この建物は汚いだの危ないだのと近所の人に言われていたので解体されるらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The neighbor has been saying that this building is dirty, dangerous and what not so apparently it is going to get demolished.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 揚げ物だのコンビニ弁当だのばかり食べてると、また健康診断の時に先生に怒られるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you only eat things like fried food, convenience store food and what not, you are going to get told off by your doctor again at the next check-up.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 妻は大嫌いだの嫌いだのと毎日言ってくるから悲しくなってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My wife tells me that she hates me and dislikes me and what not everyday so I am starting to feel sad.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は「嫌」だの「大変」だの、何かをやる前から弱音を吐くから、一緒にいるとこっちまで仕事をしたくなくなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He only says things like 'No' and 'impossible' even before trying anything, so it even makes me not want to work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなに好きだの嫌いだのと言うんだったら明日から自分でご飯作りな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are going to say things like 'I like this', 'I don't like this', and things like that, why don't you start making your own food starting tomorrow? (Opposite ends of a spectrum)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの新入社員はつらいだの面倒だのの理由で会社を入社して二週間でやめた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That newbie said things like 'this is too much', and 'this is a pain' and gave a reason similar to that and ended up quitting after 2 weeks of working with us. (Both negative)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ヒナは「臭い」だの「まずい」だのと文句ばかりを言っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Hina only complains that 'it smells' or 'it's awful' and so on.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ラーメンやカレーが嫌いな人：「ラーメンだのカレーだのが好きなやつは味のわからんやつだよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A person that hates ramen and curry: 'People who like things like ramen, curry, and so on are people who don't understand what taste is.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 妹にいつもこれが欲しいだのそれが欲しいだのとうるさくせがまれて困る。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'm annoyed because my persistent younger sister is always badgering me with things like 'I want this' or 'I want that' and so on.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はゲームに負けるといつも「回線が悪い」だの「敵がチート」だのと言い訳ばかり言う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Every time he loses a game, he just gives excuses things like 'there's a bad connection' or 'the other players are cheating' and whatnot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 娘はお腹が痛いだの頭が痛いだのよく仮病を使うので、あまり信用出来ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since my daughter often feigns illness with a sore stomach or a headache or whatnot, I cannot really trust her.

Name: 飽(あ)くまでも
Meaning: To the (bitter) end, Stubbornly, Persistently
About: 飽(あ)く is the old-fashioned and somewhat poetic version of 飽(あ)きる the る-Verb meaning 'to tire of (A)', or 'to get sick of (A)'. When used in conjunction with the adverbial particles まで 'until', and も 'even', 飽(あ)くまでも will imply that (A) is being done 'persistently', 'stubbornly', or 'to the bitter end'. The more literal translation of 'to continue (A) even to the point of getting tired of it' fits these interpretations quite well. 飽(あ)くまでも will often come at the beginning of sentences before going on to describe that thing that is being done persistently. も is not required, and 飽(あ)くまで may sometimes be seen without it. However, as the phrase is quite strong, it is far more common for も to be included to highlight the emphasis. Due to the persistence that the verb 飽(あ)く itself can highlight, it will often be seen together in sentences that include words like つもり 'intention', to show that someone intends to do something regardless of the consequences. Despite 飽(あ)くまで being a combination of 飽(あ)く and まで, it will appear in most dictionaries as a standalone adverb in modern Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 容疑者はあくまでも自分がしたことを認めようとしませんでした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The suspect stubbornly refused to admit what he had done.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私たちはあくまでもあなたのお子さんを見つけるつもりです！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We intend to look for your child until we can find them!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はあくまでも子供たちには秘密にしておこうと思っていたが、これ以上子供たちには嘘をついていられないと思い、子供たちに全てを話した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She thought that she would have kept it a secret from her kids till the bitter end, but she couldn't lie to her children any longer, so she told them everything.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犯人のことなら私にお任せください！あくまで彼を捕まえるまで探し続けるつもりです！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Leave it up to me to find the culprit! I intend to look for them until I catch them!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 飽くまでも、不正に立ち向かおうとします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will fight against injustice to the end.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 飽くまでもやると言うなら、私は止めません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you (stubbornly) insist on doing this, I won't stop you. (to the end)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 困難に対してあくまでも抵抗した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He persistently opposed all difficulties.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 被告は飽くまでも無罪を主張するつもりらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have heard that the defendant insists on claiming his innocence until the bitter end.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は政治的圧力にも関わらずその新税に飽くまで反対した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite political pressure, she opposed the new tax to the bitter end.

Name: べく
Meaning: For the purpose of, In order to, To ensure
About: As the conjunctive form of the classical auxiliary verb べし, べく will be attached to the dictionary form of verbs in order to convey the purpose of an action. This will be translated as 'for the purpose of (A), (B)', 'in order to (A), (B)', or 'to ensure that (A), (B)'. べく itself will only attach to verbs that can be done intentionally, with some purpose in mind. The (B) part of べく sentences will also indicate an intentional action that will be performed in order to reach the goal of (A). When combining する with べく, due to べく being a classical auxiliary verb, it will attach to the classical stem of する, す. However, in modern Japanese it is fairly common to see both すべく and するべく, with both forms being considered correct. べく itself is a very formal structure in modern Japanese, so will rarely be used in standard speech.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 地域の高齢者の安全を守るべく、交番が設置されました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In order to ensure the safety of the elderly in the community, a police box has been set.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子は医者になるべく、ここ３年間ほぼ寝ずに毎日勉強をしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In order to become a doctor, he has been studying these past 3 years without much sleep.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここでの交通事故を防止すべく、ガードレールなどの設備を設置することになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In order to prevent car accidents here, things such as guardrails are to be installed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 次の大会で優勝するべく、彼らは毎日朝から夜まで練習をするようにしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They try to practice every day from morning to night in order to win the next competition.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は研修医となるべく、５年以上医科大学で修練しました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In order to become a medical intern, he studied at a medical college for five years.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コーポレートサイト：「クライアントのニーズに応える可く、我が社は世界で初めて、ＡＩカスタマーサポートを生み出しました。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Corporate site: 'In order to meet our customers' needs, our company has developed the world's first AI customer support.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大学ウェブサイト：「ＩＺＵ科学技術大学では、予定通り秋期講座を開講す可く、鋭意準備を進めてまいりました。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: University website: 'We, at the IZU university of science and technology, have been making preparations in order to launch lectures for the Fall Term as planned.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 伝記：「ホテル業界での有力者としての地位を固める可く、海外でもホテルを購入しようとしたが、拒否されてしまった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Biography: 'In order to cement his influential position in the hotel world, he also attempted to buy hotels abroad, but he was refused.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「ＢｉｇＳｏｆｔで培った経験を最大限に生かす可く、 会社を立ち上げて独立することに決めました。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'In order to make the best possible use of the experience she gained at BigSoft, she decided to become independent by launching her own company.'

Name: ところを
Meaning: When, While, In spite of (the circumstances), Regardless of (the circumstances)
About: Being a combination of the noun ところ 'place' or 'situation', and the adverbial particle を, ところを is a grammar construction that will be used in order to express 2 primary meanings. The first is 'in spite of (A)', or 'regardless of (A)'. This nuance of ところ will be that the speaker is politely acknowledging the situation that someone else is in, and apologizing for interrupting them in that moment. ところを may come after any structure that could pair with a noun. This means verbs in their standard forms, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives followed by な, or nouns followed by の. The second meaning that ところを is often used for will simply be 'when (A)', or 'at the time of (A)', with a focus on being a situation in which the action of (A) is interrupted by (B). This may have either a positive or negative nuance. This use of ところを will appear exclusively after verbs in any of their standard forms. The を itself may be omitted when used to express either of these meanings.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩、休んでいるところを申し訳ないんですけど、エクセルの使い方を教えてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Senpai, I'm sorry to bother you while you are on vacation, but could you please teach me how to use Excel?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お忙しいところをすみませんが、相談したいことがあるので少しだけお時間よろしいですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am sorry to bother you while you are busy, but I want some advice. May I have some of your time?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ご多忙なところをご対応いただきありがとうございました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Thank you for taking time out in spite of you being busy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お急ぎのところを恐縮ですが、何時ぐらいに向こうに着くか教えてもらってもよろしいでしょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm sorry to bother you when you are in a hurry, but may I ask what time you expect to arrive over there?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 警察に逃げるところを目撃された。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was seen by the police while I was fleeing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 母に悪戯をしているところを見られてしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My mother caught me while I was playing a prank.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は強盗をしていたところを周りの人に目撃されていたので、どこにも逃げられなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since he was seen when he was robbing the store, he had nowhere to run.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生からの返信のお礼を言う：「お忙しいところ、ご返信ありがとうございます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Expressing gratitude to a teacher for their reply: 'In spite of being busy, thank you for your reply.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 目上の人に尋ねる：「お急ぎのところ恐縮ですが、このプロジェクトについてのご意見をお聞かせ願えませんか。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Asking a superior: 'I hate to trouble you when you are in such a hurry, but could you let me hear your opinion about this project?' (in spite of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: メール：「ご病気中のところ恐れ入りますが、田中先生の携帯の番号を教えていただけますでしょうか。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Email: 'I am awfully sorry to trouble you when you are ill, but could you tell me Mr. Tanaka's cell number?' (in spite of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 駅の放送：「この電車は、三分遅れて到着いたします。お急ぎのところ、ご迷惑をおかけいたします。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Station announcement: 'This train will arrive three minutes late. We apologize for the inconvenience while you are in a rush.' (in spite of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会議での冒頭の挨拶：「皆様、本日はご多忙のところお越しいただき、ありがとうございます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Greetings on the outset of a conference: 'Ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for coming today despite being so busy.' (in spite of)

Name: からある
Meaning: As much as, As many as, At least
About: Like からする, a structure showing that something 'goes from (A)', からある works in a similar way, but simply shows that something 'exists from (A)'. This grammar pattern will be used when making an estimation where the minimum is being guessed. からある is a combination of the case-marking particle から 'from', and the う-Verb ある 'to be'. からある will appear after numbers and counters. からある has a tendency to appear most frequently when describing things that are thought to be static, such as distances, sizes, or weights.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: おじいちゃんは８０歳なのに６０キロからあるダンベルを持ち上げることができる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though my grandpa is 80 years old, he is able to lift dumbbells that weigh as much as 60 kilos.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 中学生の頃から好きなバンドのコンサートチケットを買おうとしたら、５０００枚からあるチケットがすぐに売り切れていて、買うことができなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I tried to buy concert tickets for a band that I have liked since middle school, I couldn't because as many as 5000 tickets were sold out instantly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は小柄であるにも関わらず、７０キロからある冷蔵庫を一人で持ち上げることができる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although he is smaller in stature, he can lift refrigerators that weigh as much as 70 kilos, all by himself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この会社には正社員が３０００人からいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are as many as 3000 full time workers in this company.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのコンサートには一万人からの人数がいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are as many as 10,000 people at that concert.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １００匹からいるネズミをどうやって退治するのか！
Questions.EnglishHTML: How do you get rid of as many as 100 mice!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「富士山はここから２００キロからあるのに、よく見えます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Mt. Fuji is as many as 200 kilometers from here, and yet it is quite visible.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 名探偵ゴナン：「犯人は少なくとも３人からいます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: The great detective Gonan: 'There are, at the very least, as many as three culprits.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: オーストラリアの大火事で１０億匹からいる動物が焼死した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As many as one billion animals perished in the Australian fires.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 狼は、人間には聞こえない音が聞こえる。また、体重が８０キロからある個体もある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Wolves can hear sounds that are inaudible to humans. Also, some specimens weigh as much as 80 kilograms.

Name: にして ②
Meaning: To be ~ and ~, To be ~ as well as ~, Both ~ and ~
About: Occasionally, the combination of the case-marking particle に 'in', and the て-form of the special verb する, して will be considered as a compound particle. While this does not change the way it will be used, it puts more emphasis on the 'going from that (A), (B)' nuance of にして. This will be translated as '(A) as well as (B)', 'both (A) and (B)', or 'to be (A) and (B)'. This use of にして will appear following either nouns or な-Adjectives. Some set expressions like 幸(さいわ)いにして and 不幸(ふこう)にして also exist. These can be interpreted as 'fortunately' and 'unfortunately' respectively.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この足場は安全にしてかつ組み立てるのが簡単だから、注文が殺到している。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Orders for this scaffolding have been pouring in because it is both safe and easy to assemble.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は大学の教授にして会社の経営者でもある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She is both a university professor and a CEO.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 携帯を駅で落としてしまったが、幸いにして交番に届いていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I accidentally lost my phone at the station, but fortunately it was delivered to the police station.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は不幸にして、幼い頃に両親を亡くした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Unfortunately, he lost his parents when he was younger.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 紺碧にして美しい海である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The sea is both beautiful and a deep blue.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: シンプルにしてかつパワフルなアプリである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a simple and moreover a powerful app.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 牛は優美、温和にして頭が冴えている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Cows are graceful, gentle, and smart.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 山田先生は有名な教授にして尊敬されている弁護士でもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Dr. Yamada is both a famous professor and a respected lawyer too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田中総理大臣は稀代の政治家にして同時に偉大な父でもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Prime minister Tanaka is both an extraordinary politician and, at the same time, a great father.

Name: つ (Conjunctive)
Meaning: two contrasting actions
About: つ is a conjunction particle in Japanese that is used in constructions where it will appear twice, highlighting contrasting verbs. This つ～つ structure is often translated as 'to be doing (A) and (B) over and over', where the actions are happening repeatedly one after the other. つ will connect to the conjunctive form of verbs, with (A) and (B) generally appearing in direct sequence. Additionally, it is also quite common to see the same verb being repeated in both places. When this happens, the (A) verb will be in the standard form, while the (B) verb will be in the passive form. This just translates as 'to do (A) and to have (A) done to oneself'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しく発売されたゲーム機を買おうか悩みながら、お店の前を行きつ戻りつした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I walked back and forth in front of the store, wondering if I should buy the newly released game console.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 川で脱げた靴が浮きつ沈みつ流れていった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My shoe that came off in the river was bobbing up and down as it floated away.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 僕たちは持ちつ持たれつの関係で、保育園の頃から今に至るまでお互い助け合ってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We have always been in a give and take relationship, helping each other from the time we were in nursery school until now.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コンサート会場には大勢の人が集まっていて、ゲートが開かれても押しつ押されつで全然会場に入れなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There were so many people gathered at the concert venue that even when the gate was opened, I could not enter the venue at all because of the pushing and shoving.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アリとアリマキは持ちつ持たれつの関係にある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Ants and aphids have a give-and-take relationship.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 押しつ押されつしてなんとかそこに着くことができた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I managed to get there somehow by pushing and being pushed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はドアの前をしばらく不安げに行きつ戻りつしていたすえに入ることにした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: After some time, he finally decided to go inside after nervously going back and forth in front of the door.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 老人は小枝の浮きつ沈みつを眺めながら、海の匂いを楽しんだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The old man enjoyed the smell of the sea while watching the sinking and rising (bobbing) twig.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 藤原拓海、須藤京一など、多くの有名なドライバーが抜きつ抜かれつのレースを繰り広げた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Takumi Fujiwara, Kyoichi Sudo, and many other famous drivers put on a neck and neck race. (back and forth)

Name: 飽(あ)くまで
Meaning: Just, Only, Merely, Strictly
About: 飽(あ)く is the old-fashioned and somewhat poetic version of 飽(あ)きる the る-Verb meaning 'to tire of (A)', or 'to get sick of (A)'. When used in conjunction with the adverbial particles まで 'until', 飽(あ)くまで can imply that (A) is 'just', 'only', or 'strictly' something. The more literal translation of 'to continue (A) to the point of getting tired of it' fits these interpretations quite well, implying that (A) will never deviate from what is being described about it. This use of 飽(あ)くまで often appears at the beginning of a phrase, and functions adverbially. The adverbial particle も 'even' may be added for extra emphasis, but it is not required. In many cases, 飽(あ)くまで will be used in polite sentences when the speaker is expressing their own opinion. In these cases, the nuance of 'this is merely my opinion' is conveying to the listener that the speaker realizes that what they are saying is not the only viewpoint. This way of highlighting opinions is often combined with structures like けど, or が when the speaker wants to soften their statement before offering what they think a solution might be.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はあくまでも新人なので優しく接してあげてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is merely a newbie, so please treat him kindly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それはあくまで可能性に過ぎないからなんの役にも立たない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is merely a possibility, so it doesn't help.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はあくまでも素人に過ぎませんが、設計にミスがあると思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am just an amateur, but I think that there is a mistake in the design.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはあくまで私の意見なので参考にしないでくださいね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is just my opinion, so please don't refer to it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 飽くまでもここだけの話ですが、課長は部下と付き合っているそうですよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is strictly a conversation between us, but I heard that the section manager is dating a subordinate.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「私は飽くまでも素人に過ぎませんが、計算に誤りがあると思います。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I am just an amateur, but I think there is an error in the calculation.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今回の件の決定権は飽くまでもあなたにあるので、自分でよく考えて下さいね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is strictly a matter that you have the right to decide, so please consider it carefully yourself.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 調査結果とは飽くまでも一つのデータに過ぎないので、そればかり気にするのも良くありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since the result of this investigation is just nothing more than one set of data, paying heed only to that is not good.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先ほどの件は飽くまでも私と君の二人だけの秘密という事でよろしくお願いしますね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I would request that the matter from earlier remain a secret strictly between you and I.

Name: であれ〜であれ
Meaning: Whether or, Or, No matter which, In either case
About: Functioning as an extension of である, the formal copula that is a combination of the conjunctive form of the auxiliary verb だ, and the う-Verb ある, であれ or であろうと will be used in order to express strong will or conviction. あれ is simply the imperative form of ある, while あろうと is the positive volitional form combined with the case marking particle と. Both structures are usually translated as 'even if (A), (B)', or 'no matter if (A), (B)'. Despite this, the more literal meaning of each is closer to 'so it's (A), (B) still won't be affected'. This just emphasizes the fact that (A) is of no relation to the result, like saying 'so what if it is' in English. When used consecutively, であれ shows that regardless of whether something is (A) or (B), the result of (C), will not change. Both であれ and であろうと will primarily attach to nouns in sentences that express some kind of question or assumption through words like どんな or たとえ.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供であれ大人であれ、入場料は４０００円です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether you are a child or an adult, the entrance fee is 4000 yen.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本製であれベトナム製であれ同じ機械でできてるから質に変わりはない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether it is made in Japan or Vietnam, it is made with the same machine, so there is no difference in the quality.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 正社員であろうとアルバイトであろうと、客には関係がない話だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether someone is a full time worker or a part time worker doesn't matter to a customer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 未経験者であろうとベテランであろうと、この現場に入るにはこの講習を受けなくてはいけないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether you are inexperienced or experienced, you must take this course to enter this work site.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 近代美術であれ伝統芸能であれ、芸術は芸術だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether it is modern art or traditional art, art is art.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遺伝情報とは、人間であれバナナであれ、すべて同じようにＤＮＡに組み込まれているものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether it is in a human or in a banana, genetic information is something that is similarly encoded in DNA.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人は無病息災であれ、病気であれ、常に健康に注意が必要です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether someone is healthy or ill, they should take care of their health.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 本ウェブサイト、故意に、オンラインであれオフラインであれ、ユーザからの個人情報を収集しません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether online or offline, this website does not knowingly collect personal information from users.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強であれスポーツであれ何であれ、結果は注いできた努力次第である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether it is studying, sports, or whatever, results depend on the effort one has put in.

Name: たら最後(さいご)
Meaning: Once, Now that, As soon as
About: たら最後(さいご) and たが最後(さいご) are grammar structures that both share the meaning of 'once (A), definitely (B)'. (B) will always be something negative that is thought to inevitably occur once the action of (A) happens. These expressions may be translated as 'once (A), (B)', 'now that (A), (B)', or 'as soon as (A), (B)'. Both たら and が are being used as conjunction particles. たら carries its usual meaning of 'if' or 'when', while が has the meaning of 'however', or 'but'. This means that たが最後(さいご) means '(A), but it will end up as (B)', while たら最後(さいご) means 'when (A), it will end up as (B)'. Although this nuance is slightly different, they are used completely interchangeably. Because 最後(さいご) is primarily seen before the comma in these types of sentences, it can be easy to think that it is connected to the が or たら. However, it is actually more correctly connected logically to the (B) half of the sentence, and states that the 'final state' will end up being that way.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 恋愛だけではなく、友達の間でも信頼を失ったが最後、取り戻すにはかなりの時間がかかる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Once you lose trust, not only in love, but also among friends, it takes a long time to regain it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その会社と契約をしたが最後、解約するのがものすごくめんどくさい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Once you have signed a contract with that company, it is a huge hassle to cancel.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの蛇に噛まれたら最後、体が麻痺するらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that once you get bitten by that snake, your body becomes paralyzed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんが話し始めたら最後、口が疲れるまでずっと話し続ける。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Once Tanaka-san starts talking, he won't stop until his mouth gets tired.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人に政治についての意見を求めたら最後だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's the end once you ask him for his political opinions. (He won't stop talking after that)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生が注意しなくなったら最後だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's the end once your teacher stops giving you advice. (Because it means that they have given up on you)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の彼氏はゲームをいったんやり始めたら最後、どうしても深夜までやめられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once my boyfriend starts playing a game, he can't stop until late at night no matter what.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説のカスタマーレビュー：「綺麗な話です。読みはじめたら最後、涙がとまりません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Customer review of a book: 'What a beautiful story. Once I started reading, I couldn't stop crying.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 口を開いたら最後、自分の意志では止められなくて何時間も喋り続けてしまう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once she opens her mouth, she will keep on talking for hours with no intention of stopping.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達との話：「うちの犬ったらいったん食べ物を見つけたら最後、いっぺんに食べてしまう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between friends: 'Once our dog spots food, it eats everything at once.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その民族が住む島には行ったら最後、生きて帰れる可能性は無いだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Once one goes to the island that that tribe lives on, there is no possibility of returning alive, right?

Name: 如何(いか)なる
Meaning: What kind of, No matter what kind of, No … (with a negative verb), Any... (with a negative verb)
About: 如何(いか)なる is a combination of 如何(いか), and なる. なる being derived from the classical auxiliary verb なり 'to be'. 如何(いか) is never used as a word by itself, and will always be attached to something else when it has the reading of いか. However, its meaning is the same as the modern どう 'how'. Because of this, いかなる is interchangeable with どんな 'what kind of', with the exception that it is primarily used only in books and formal writing. いかなる is classified as being attributive, meaning that it will appear directly before a noun, or modify a noun somewhere within the same clause. Just like どんな, when に is added to いかなる, a negative statement will usually follow. This translates as 'no matter how much (A)', or 'no matter what kind of (A)'. However, に will not directly follow いかなる like it does with どんな. Instead, it will appear later in the sentence before the verb. Occasionally, いかな may also be used, but this is far less common.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いかなることがあっても、決して手を離してはいけません。わかりましたか？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter what happens, you must not let go. Do you understand?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私たちはいかなる時にも出動できるように、常に訓練しています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We are constantly training to be ready to dispatch at any moment.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼らはいかなる要求にも応じなければならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They must comply with any request, no matter what it is.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いかなる状況に置かれても、諦めずに突き進むことを忘れないでください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Remember, no matter what situation you find yourself in, do not give up and keep pushing forward.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼らは結婚してから長いから、いかなる困難にあっても、二人で乗り越えられる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They've been married long enough that no matter what challenges they face, they can overcome them together.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いかな状況にも耐え得る人になりたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to be a person who can withstand any situation.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 論文：「亀とは如何なる魚なのか？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Essay: 'What kind of fish is a turtle?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: Ｋａｐｐａｚｏｎグループは如何なる理由であろうとも、Ｋａｐｐａｚｏｎネットショップから如何なる製品も削除する権利を保有しています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Kappazon Group reserves the right to remove any product from the Kappazon online store, no matter the reason.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: シヌラ電気動力株式会社は如何なる第三者にも顧客情報を販売、配布いたしません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The Shinura Electric Power Company does not sell or disclose any data to third parties (no matter what).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 如何なる方ともログイン情報またはパスワードの共有はお控え願います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We request that you refrain from sharing login or password information with anyone (no matter who).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パイロットは如何なる事態になろうとも、適切に対処せねばならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A pilot has to react accordingly no matter what the situation might become.

Name: なりに
Meaning: In one's own way, Of someone's own, Do one's best in one's own way, As much as one can
About: When used as a noun, なり often presents an example group from which something exhibits traits of, regardless of whether that group is actually a good example of the trait being described. This use can be translated as 'for (A) in the way of (B) to do (C)'. Or more simply, 'to do its best in its own way', or 'to do as much as one can'. This use stems from 形(なり), meaning 'shape' or 'pattern', and can be thought of as meaning 'in the pattern of'. In these sentences, (A) will be a specific example from within a group, (B) will be representative of the whole group, and (C) will be the trait or behavior in question related to (B). Either of the case marking particles に or の will come after なり, depending on whether なり is linked directly to a noun, or is being used adverbially. なりに and なりの may follow almost any word in its plain form, with the word it follows being the group or quality that is being represented. This use of なり is considered a neologism, which is a pre-existing word that has been adapted to have a new meaning or nuance. When used this way, なり will almost always express that (A) is not doing something adequately or as desired, but is doing the best it can based on the 'pattern' or 'mold' that it comes from.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自由時間が増えたら、増えたなりに有効に使いたい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If I get more free time, I would like to use all that free time as much as I could.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 広い部屋は広いなりのデメリットがあります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Large rooms have their own disadvantages.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は仕事が下手なりに、他の社員のモチベーションをあげてくれたりしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For all of his lack of skill, he does his best to motivate other workers.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自分なりに頑張ってみたが、やっぱりダメだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I tried my best in my own way, but it was still not enough.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は下手なりに頑張ってラブレターを書いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For all of his lack of skill, he did the best that he could (in his own way) to write a love letter.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こまりちゃんは小さいなりに両親の農家を手伝っていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For all of her small size, Komari-chan did as much as she could to help on her parent's farm. (as much as one can)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会計士は会計士なりに頑張って全ての手段を尽くしましたが、解決策を見つけられませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The accountants have done their best to leave no stone unturned, but they could not find a solution. (as much as one can)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「その問い合わせに対する私なりの回答をご紹介いたします。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I would like to present my own answer to that query.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕なりにベストを尽くしましたが、搬送されてきた患者を救うことが出来ませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I exhausted my efforts as best as I could, but I was unable to save the patient that was transported to the hospital.

Name: れる・られる + ままに
Meaning: Do as (one is told or ordered…), In accordance with, In compliance with, Just like
About: When paired with まま, a noun meaning 'in the state of', and the case marking particle に, the auxiliary verbs れる and られる indicate something being done 'as one is told', or 'as ordered'. Because of this, れる and られる will almost always be paired with verbs that indicate some kind of communication. As these structures are in the passive, the literal translation is close to 'to do (B) in the state that (A) was done to me'. The (B) part will come directly after ままに and simply states how someone is going to react in compliance with (A). The conjunction particle が may appear between られる and ままに, but this is not common in modern Japanese. Although it does carry the meaning of 'but', the focus is more on expressing that the (A) is not being resisted or argued with when doing (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は先輩に言われるままにしただけですよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I only did things as I was told by senpai.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本では上司に命じられるままに仕事をしている人が多い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In Japan, many people work as ordered by their bosses.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 警察に聞かれるままに、仲間の名前を教えた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I gave the names of my accomplices to the police as they asked me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 婚活アプリで出会った人に言われるがままに、ギフトカードを買ってしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I did as I was told by someone I met on a dating app and bought a gift card.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生に教えられたままに漢字を書いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wrote kanji characters as my teacher taught me. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 聞かれるままに、彼女の住んでいる場所を教えた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I told him where she lives, just like I was asked.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 強盗に要求されるまま、金をわたした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I handed over the money as demanded by the robber.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ガイドに案内されるまま、私たちはパリ市内を観光した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We explored the city of Paris as guided by the guide.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生に教えられるままに、生徒はその発音を繰り返した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The students repeated the pronunciation just like they were taught by the teacher.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夫は娘にせがまれるままに何でも買い与えてしまう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In compliance with the pestering from our daughter, my husband will unfortunately buy her any gifts.

Name: に纏(まつ)わる
Meaning: Surrounding, Related or relating to, Associated with, Connected to
About: Making use of the う-Verb まつわる 'to coil around', にまつわる is a formal grammar pattern that follows nouns and expresses that something broadly discusses the topic of (A). It is usually translated as 'surrounding (A)', 'associated with (A)', or 'connected to (A)'. In most cases, まつわる will be both preceded and followed by a noun, with the preceding noun being the topic, and the following noun being the thing that is dealing with that topic. まつわる itself is primarily seen when (B) is some sort of information or explanation related to (A).
