Because of this, 話(はなし) 'tale', 物語(ものがたり) 'story', 伝説(でんせつ) 'legend', 神話(しんわ) 'myth', and similar words will often appear as (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 僕が小さい頃は、おじいちゃんにこの地域にまつわる怖い話をよくしてもらってた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I was little, my grandfather used to tell me scary stories connected to this area.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この監督の映画は戦争にまつわる映画が多い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Many of this director's films are related to war.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はこの神社にまつわる神話には詳しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is familiar with the myths connected to this shrine.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この神社に纏わる伝説や神話は数えきれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are more legends connected to this shrine than one can count.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この物語は「とある魔術の禁書目録」に纏わるものである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This is a story surrounding "A Certain Magical Index".

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ブログ記事：「猫に纏わる英語の慣用表現６選。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Blog post title: 'A selection of 6 English idioms related to cats.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 楊貴妃には美貌に纏わる漢詩が数多く残されている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is quite a bit of remaining poetry relating to Yang Guifei's beauty.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アクア女神に纏わる神話はこの町に代々伝えられている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A myth surrounding the goddess Aqua has been passed down in this town for generations.

Name: たるに
Meaning: To be (in a position of), As a, For
About: たるに is a structure that indicates something that 'is (A)' in the same way as である, and will often be translated as '(B) in the position of (A)', or '(B) as an (A)'. たるに itself as a combination of たる, which is the attributive form of classical auxiliary verb たり, and the case marking particle に. たるに will appear after a noun marking some sort of position, with a statement about that position following after. It may be used either positively or negatively. たるに is not as common as たるもの, which is a combination of たる and the noun 者(もの), used to identify people. In these cases, (A) たる者(もの) will specifically mean 'a person in the position of (A)', and generally describes what is appropriate of that position. This use may be translated as 'for' or 'as'. Although this structure means 'to be' in the same way as である, the emphasis is far more on qualifications or expectations related to that position. Due to this, たる will not be used when simply stating that '(B) is (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの選手に負けるぐらいなら、うちのチームの一員たるにふさわしくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you aren't good enough to defeat that opponent, you are not suitable to be (in the position) a member of our team.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたは従業員たるに相応しい対応ができたと思っているのかい？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Do you think that you were able to deal with that as an employee?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生たる者、生徒の将来を優先するべきだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As teachers, we should put the future of our students first.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 警察たる者、国民の平和を守るべきだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As police, you should protect the peace of the people.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: なんと言っても教師たる者は、情熱が必要なのである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Above all, to be (in the position of) a teacher, a person must be passionate.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 学生たる者は、アルバイトに感けすぎて学業を疎かにしてはならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A (person that is in the position of a) student must not get too preoccupied with a part-time job and neglect their studies.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「需要と供給の関係を理解できない彼には総理大臣たる資格がない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: He who cannot comprehend the relationship between supply and demand is not qualified to be (in the position of) a prime minister.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 職人たるもの、 最新の専門分野の発達についていかなければならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A (person that is in the position of a) professional must follow the latest developments in their field.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 教師たる者、生徒一人一人に真摯に向き合うべきである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To be (in the position of) a teacher, one ought to confront each and every student earnestly.

Name: なら〜で
Meaning: If ~ should, Before ~ should
About: なら〜で is a structure which appears in situations where the same word will repeat twice, followed by some sort of opinion in regard to it. It can be translated as 'if (A), you should (B)', or 'before (A), you should (B)'. In many cases it will be used to exhibit the speaker's dissatisfaction about something. なら〜で may follow verbs in their standard forms, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives or nouns. Both なら and で are functioning as conjunction particles in this grammar pattern.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事するならするでちゃんとしろ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are going to work, you should do it properly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 欲しいなら欲しいで始めっから言ってくれればよかったのに！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you wanted it, you should have told me so!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 嫌なら嫌でやめればいい。嫌々やっていても誰のためにもならないでしょ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you don't like it, you should quit. Continuing something you don't want to do does not benefit anyone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 休むなら休むでちゃんと休んでください。仕事のことはわたしたちに任せてもらって全然いいんで。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are going to take a break, please take a break. You can leave work to us, so no need to worry about that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 上司：「塗るなら塗るでもっと丁寧に仕上げなさい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Boss: 'If you are going to paint, then (you should) be more careful.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: イライラした妻、ダラダラ食べる夫に：「食べるなら食べるで、きちんと食べなさい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Irritated wife to her husband who is sluggishly eating: 'If you are going to eat, you should do it properly!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
娘：「もう空港で１時間も待ってるよ。」
母：「もう待っているなら待っているでもっと早くケータイを鳴らしてくれたらよかったのに・・・」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Daughter: 'I have already been waiting at the airport for an hour!'
Mother: 'If you were already waiting, then you should have called me sooner…'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
彼女：「実はお腹が痛いの...」
彼氏：「お腹が痛いなら痛いで、ベッドで寝た方がいいよ。あとは俺に任せてね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Girlfriend: 'To be honest, my stomach hurts...'
Boyfriend: 'If your stomach hurts then you should lie in bed. Leave the rest to me, ok?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「勝手にジュースを飲むなら飲むで、正直に言ってたらそんなに怒られなかったのに。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'If you drink juice without asking, you should be honest about it. I would not have gotten so angry (if you told the truth).'

Name: をものともせず
Meaning: Making nothing of, Ignoring, In defiance of, Regardless of, Disregarding
About: をものともせず is a combination of the adverbial particle を, the noun 物(もの) 'thing', the particle とも 'even as', and the negative form of する paired with classical auxiliary verb ず, せず. The common translations of 'to make nothing of (A)', or 'in defiance of (A)' are quite close to the more literal translation of 'without making (A) a thing'. As を must follow a noun, this expression may only be used after nouns, or nominated phrases. をものともせず will often follow negative words which are being praised as something that a person was not affected by 'did not make a thing of' in their response to it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 谷口選手は足が震えているのをものともせず、レースを完走した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Taniguchi completed the race, regardless of his shaky legs.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼らは外が暑いのをものともせず、一日中街頭募金活動をした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of it being hot outside, they spent all day on the streets fundraising.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は危険なのをものともせずに、子供たちを助けに行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She went to help the children, ignoring the danger.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は手首の怪我をものともせずに試合で優勝した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He won the match despite his wrist injury.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は嵐をものともせず海にドライブに行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ignoring the storm, I went for a drive to the beach. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 上司の反対をものともせず提案を押し通した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Making nothing of the objection of their superiors, they insisted on the proposal.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 厳しい経済状況をものともせず、アンブレラ社の株は急騰した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of the tough economic situation, Umbrella Corporation stocks shot up.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 清瀬灰二選手は肺がはげしくあえぐのをものともせずに、最後まで頑張って勝利した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Haiji Kiyose, ignoring his lungs desperately gasping for air, pressed on and managed to be victorious.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は政敵からの揶揄をものともせず選挙を戦い抜き、大統領の座を勝ち取った。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Disregarding the mockery from her political opponents, she fought to the bitter end and won the presidential seat.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ダンディーさんは、体長３メートルほどもある大蛇の攻撃をものともせず、器用に捕まえ、素手で殺したと言う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of its attacks, they say that Mr. Dundee skillfully caught and killed a snake nearly 3 meters in length with his bare hands.

Name: には当(あ)たらない
Meaning: No need to/for, Cannot, Not worth it to, Not suitable
About: には当(あ)たらない is a somewhat formal pattern used in Japanese for indicating that something is 'not worth (A)', or that there is 'no need to (A)'. This is a combination of the case marking particle に, the adverbial particle は, and the negative form of the う-Verb 当(あ)たる 'to strike', or 'to be on the mark', 当(あ)たらない. Due to this, the literal meaning can be thought of as 'it's not on the mark to (A)'. には当(あ)たらない will appear directly after verbs in their dictionary form, or する verbs either with or without the する. Additionally, the は may occasionally be omitted, without any change in meaning. Rather than implying that something is 'way off', には当(あ)たらない most often simply highlights that a particular situation is not to the extent where (A) would be appropriate. (A) itself is regularly a verb that relates to reactions or feelings. Some examples include 驚(おどろ)く 'to be surprised', 非難(ひなん) 'to reproach', 称賛(しょうさん) 'to admire', 感心(かんしん) 'to be impressed', 喜(よろこ)ぶ 'to rejoice', and other similar words.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼がまた彼女に振られたの。まあ、あいつは自分のことしか考えていないから驚くには当たらない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He was dumped by his girlfriend again? Well, that's not surprising because that guy only ever thinks of himself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 人として当たり前のことをやったまでです、感謝するには当たらないですよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I just did what any normal person would do, so no need to thank me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人がやったことは人間としては最低だけど犯罪には当たらないから何もできない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What that person did was despicable, but not suitable to be a crime, so we cannot do anything about it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのバンドが新しくリリースした曲は歌詞もメロディーも微妙だから聴くに当たらないらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They say that the newly released song by that band is not worth listening to because the lyrics and melodies are too subtle.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「珍しいことではありません。称賛には当たりません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'It is not uncommon. No need for praise.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつもよりテストの点が５点低かったからって、そんなに落ち込むには当たらないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There's no need to get so depressed just because you got 5 marks less than usual on your test.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「結核は予防接種を受けた健康な人なら、心配するには当たらない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Tuberculosis is not something you need to worry about if the person in question is vaccinated and healthy.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 娘がまだ帰ってきてないけど心配には当たりません。だって、いつも飲み歩いているから…。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My daughter still hasn't come home, but there is no need to worry. It's because she always goes bar-hopping.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 少しミスをしたからって新入社員を非難には当たらないよ。誰だってミスはするんだから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not worth reproaching the new employee. Just because they made a small error, since everyone makes mistakes.

Name: ものと思(おも)う
Meaning: Think that, Believe that, Expect that, Have confidence that, Absolutely
About: 物(もの)と思(おも)う is made up of the noun 物(もの) 'thing', the case marking particle と, and the う-Verb 思(おも)う 'to think'. Regular translations include 'to believe that (A)', or 'to have confidence that (A)'. In a broader sense, this grammar pattern is just making use of one of the meanings of 物(もの) as being something abstract that the speaker can reliably determine has all of the qualities of something concrete. As もの is a noun, this pattern may follow any word in its attributive form. When 思(おも)う appears in the past tense, the most common translation is 'as I had believed was true of (A)', or 'I was under the impression that (A)'. Although this grammar construction is slightly formal, it may occasionally be heard in daily speech.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人はなんでもできると自信ありげに言っていたんで、仕事ができるものと思っていたが全然だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He said confidently that he could do anything, so I expected him to be capable of doing the job, but he was not at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夫の部屋からものすごいキーボードの音が聞こえたから、忙しいものと思っていたがただゲームをしていただけだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard my husband typing on his keyboard, so I was confident that he was busy, but he was just gaming.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 結婚は幸せなものと思う人は多いだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Many people believe that marriage is a happy thing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本で最も寒い月は１２月であるものと思っている人が多いが、実は２月だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Many people think that the coldest month in Japan is December, but actually it is February.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 外国人観光客は日本語が話せないものと思っていたが、実際そうでもなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was under the impression that foreign tourists could not speak Japanese, but this was not the case.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: セールスマンはクライアントに：「この商品の品質でご満足いただけるものと思います。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Salesman to a client: 'I am confident that you will be satisfied with the quality of the product.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「可児江さんを支配人にすれば、このテーマパークは必ず成功するものと思います。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I think that if we make Mr. Kanie the manager, the theme park will surely be successful.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
よしの：「ウサギは卵を産まないわ...」
しどう：「でも、実際には多くの人がそんな風に思うもんと思うよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Yoshino: 'Bunnies do not lay eggs…'
Shidou: 'But I think that a lot of people think that they do.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 社員が上司に話す：「宅配便が今日、約束通りに来るものと思っていますが、念の為に電話をかけてみます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Employee talks to the boss: 'I think that the courier will come today as promised, but I will call him and see just to be safe.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 財務大臣：「この問題について、政府と産業界との連携はやがて成果に結びつくものと思います。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Minister of Finance: 'About this matter, I expect that the cooperation of the government and the industry will eventually bear fruit.'

Name: を踏(ふ)まえて
Meaning: Based on, Considering, Keeping in mind, Taking into account, Therefore
About: 踏(ふ)まえる is a る-Verb that means 'to tread firmly', but is often used figuratively in regard to taking things into account. Because of this, the combination of the adverbial particle を, and 踏(ふ)まえる in its て-form can frequently be translated as 'considering (A)', or 'keeping (A) in mind'. を踏(ふ)まえて is primarily used in formal situations where (B) is an action being undertaken with (A) as the premise. As this structure begins with を, it will need to follow a noun. In this grammar pattern, the literal meaning of を踏(ふ)まえて as 'being firmly planted' can be used equally as naturally, so long as its figurative nature is kept in mind.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客様の意見を踏まえて、色々と機能を追加するつもりです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We intend to add various features based on customer feedback.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先週の反省を踏まえて、今週は別のやり方でやってみようと思っています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Based on my reflections from last week, I am going to try a different approach this week.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 前回の失敗を踏まえて、今回はもう少し気をつけて挑戦してみる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Based on my last failure, I will try to be a little more careful this time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アンケートの結果を踏まえて、お客様に喜んでいただけるアイディアをどんどん提案してください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Being firmly planted on the results of the survey, please keep throwing in ideas that you would think would please our customers.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会社のサイト：「国際的な基準を踏まえた新製品開発に懸命に取り組んでいます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Website of a company: 'We work earnestly to develop our products with international standards in mind. (while keeping in mind)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「我々のアウトソーシング分野で１０年以上の経験を踏まえた提案である。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'It is a suggestion based on ten years of experience in the outsourcing field.' (while keeping in mind)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 前回の反省を踏まえて今回のテストに挑んだのに、結果は前回よりも悪かった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite going up against this test taking into account my reflection upon the last test, my result was actually even worse than last time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お客様の意見を踏まえて、当ホテルのチェックアウトの時間を一時間遅くしました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Keeping in mind customer opinions, the checkout time at this hotel was made one hour later.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼の家庭環境が複雑である事を踏まえて、破格の値段で社員用の寮を貸し出す事にしました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Based on the fact that his household environment was complicated, he was loaned an employee dormitory room at an unprecedented price.

Name: 故(ゆえ)に
Meaning: Because, The reason is, Due to, Therefore, So
About: When the noun 故(ゆえ) 'consequence' is paired with the case marking particle に, it will be used in formal situations to highlight reasons. This may be interpreted as 'because of (A)', 'due to (A)', or 'the reason is (A)'. However, 'consequently to (A)', or 'as a consequence of (A)' are also completely acceptable translations that may help to differentiate ゆえに from less formal structures. As ゆえ itself is a noun, regular grammar rules such as being preceded by の will occasionally be observed when following another noun. Despite this, noun + の + 故(ゆえ) is actually quite uncommon in modern Japanese, and the の will usually just be omitted. In other cases, ゆえに will simply attach to the standard form of words. ゆえに may also appear at the beginning of new sentences. When this happens, it expresses 'as a result of (A)', where (A) is the entire previous sentence. The に will need to be replaced with の when ゆえ is being connected to another noun and therefore modifying it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お巡りさんたちが夜も眠らずにパトロールしているが故に、夜でも安心して散歩できる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to the police officers patrolling the area at night without sleep, it makes it safe for us to go on walks at night.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私のおじいちゃんは目が悪いが故に、運転免許証を返納した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My grandpa had to give up his driver's license because of his bad eyesight.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の接客は丁寧な故に、お客さんからの評判がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: His customer service is courteous and therefore well received by his customers.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本ではまだ女性のゆえに差別されることがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In Japan, women are still discriminated against because of their gender.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの国では高齢化が深刻な問題になってきている。ゆえに、海外から若者を呼び込み始めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Aging is becoming a serious problem in that country. Due to that, they have started to attract young people from abroad.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 若さゆえの過ちであったとしても必ず許さなければならないということでもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just because something was done due to a young age, doesn't mean that it should be forgiven.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ラテン語のフレーズ：「不合理故にわれ信ず 」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Latin phrase: 'I believe just because it is absurd.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 手紙：「季節の変わり目故、くれぐれもご自愛くださいませ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Letter: 'Since the seasons are changing, please take good care of yourself.' (due to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「ベンジャミンの若さ故の自信過剰も無知もミセス・ロビンソンの目からすれば、可愛らしい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'From the perspective of Mrs. Robinson, Benjamin's overconfidence and naivety, due to his youthfulness, is charming.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: Ａ⇒Ｂ、Ｂ⇒Ｃ故にＡ⇒Ｃ (Ａが真ならばＢも真、Ｂが真ならばＣも真。故にＡが真ならばＣも真である）
Questions.EnglishHTML: A⇒B、B⇒C therefore A⇒C (If A, then B, if B then C. Therefore if A, then C)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ファンタジー小説：「 ドワーフ族が滅んだのは富に対する飽くなき欲望故であった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Fantasy novel: 'The reason for the dwarves' undoing was their untiring desire for wealth.'

Name: と言(い)う
Meaning: Every single, Each and every, Emphasis, Everything that could be called
About: One of the uses of the extremely common という structure in Japanese is the pairing of identical nouns in order to convey the meaning of 'every single (A)'. In many cases, this expression will simply be used for emphasis, but the literal meaning is 'every (B) that could be called an (A)'. という will be used between the same noun repeating itself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 空き家に入ったら床という床が全てゴミに覆われていたのでびっくりした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I entered the vacant house, I was surprised because the entire floor was covered in garbage.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この街の電柱という電柱に広告の張り紙が沢山貼られてあったので、街の人たちが張り紙を全て撤去した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There were so many advertising posters on every single telephone pole in this city that the people of the city removed all the posters.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 世界各国の偉い人たちが来るということで、サミットの近くの道という道は閉鎖されている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Every single road near the summit was closed due to the fact that important people from all over the world are coming.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日という今日は絶対あいつを許さない！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will not forgive him today of all days!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今度という今度は優勝してみせる！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will win THIS TIME!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「今日という今日は許さん。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I absolutely will not allow it TODAY.' (emphasis)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 政治家という政治家はみんな口ばっかりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Every single politician is nothing but talk.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それを聞いて、人という人が一斉に頷いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Every single person nodded in unison when they heard that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 山々に生えた木という木は地すべりのため根こそぎ倒れていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Every single tree that was growing on the mountain collapsed due to the landslide.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 名古屋に生まれて名古屋で育った。だから、町中の道という道、家という家を、すっかり知っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: (They were) born and raised in Nagoya. Therefore, (they) know every single street and each and every house in the city.

Name: に止(とど)まらず
Meaning: Not limited to, Not only...but also, Not stopping at
About: にとどまらず is a formal structure that pairs the case marking particle に, the う-Verb 止(とど)まる 'to remain', or 'to be limited to', and the classical auxiliary verb ず 'not'. にとどまらず is generally translated as 'not limited to (A)', or 'not stopping at (A)', and follows words indicating an extent, before going on to explain how something spreads beyond (A). にとどまらず will be seen following either nouns, or verbs in their dictionary form. This expression may be used to highlight either positive or negative effects.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は会社の経費を管理するにとどまらず、社員の給料も管理している。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He not only manages the company's expenses, but also the salaries of its employees.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生は授業を行うにとどまらず、部活の指導などもしなくてはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Teachers must not only teach classes, but also supervise club activities.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 寿司は日本にとどまらず、世界中で人気がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Sushi is popular not only in Japan but all over the world.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この漫画は子供にとどまらず、大人の間でも話題になっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This manga is not limited to children, but has become a topic of conversation among adults as well.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このコンサートのチケットにとどまらず、限定グッズなども高かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not only were tickets to this concert expensive, but also limited edition merchandise. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 共感は人間にとどまらず、動物にも見られるものである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Compassion is not only limited to humans but is something that can also be observed in animals.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先日の悪夢が夢にとどまらず、まさか現実になってしまうとは…。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is unbelievable that yesterday's nightmare was not only a dream, but would actually happen in reality…

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ボックスステーション７、日本国内にとどまらず、海外でも普及しています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Boxstation7 is not only popular in Japan, but also abroad.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語の学習によって語学力にとどまらず、日本風の考え方も身に着ける。
Questions.EnglishHTML: By studying Japanese, one does not only acquire linguistic ability but also a Japanese way of thinking.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会社ウェブサイト：「当社は製品を販売するにとどまらず、その商品の設計もいたします。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Company website: 'Our company is not only selling products but also designing them.'

Name: と思(おも)いきや
Meaning: Thought...but, When...thought that...but, Despite having thought...
About: と思(おも)いきや is an expression used in Japanese for indicating that something is not as one had thought, and will often be translated as 'despite having thought (A), (B)', or 'when I thought that (A), it was actually (B)'. と思(おも)いきや is a combination of the case marking particle と, the conjunctive form of the う-Verb 思(おも)う, 思(おも)い, the classical auxiliary verb き, which indicates past tense, and the classical binding (adverbial) particle や, which marks actual or rhetorical questions in the same way as か. Due to this, a more literal translation is 'I thought it had (A), but I guess (B)'. Despite the origin of the phrase, in modern Japanese と思(おも)いきや is just thought of as an emphatic structure that highlights the speaker's surprise in relation to something not being as they had expected. と思(おも)いきや may follow any word in its standard form. The particle か may appear before と思(おも)いきや, but this just further emphasizes the same rhetorical question, as や itself has the same role.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日も残業するかと思いきや、４時になったと同時に上司が「みんな、毎日お疲れさん、今日は早めに帰って、ゆっくりしてくれ」と言ってくれたから定時前に帰ることができた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I thought I would have to work overtime again today, but as soon as it hit 4:00, my boss said, 'Hey guys, thanks for working hard every day, go home early today and relax,' so I was able to leave before the regular time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 木村くんのピアノの先生は優しいと思いきや、見学してみたらめちゃくちゃ怖くて厳しいということが分かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I thought that Kimura-kun's piano teacher was nice, but when I went to observe the class, I found out that she is very scary and strict.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 家を建てるのは簡単かと思いきや、建てる前に色々土地の調査など測量などをしないといけなかったから思っていたより面倒だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I thought building a house would be easy, but it was more trouble than I expected because I had to do things such as survey and inspect the land before building.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女たちは姉妹だと思いきや、親子だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I thought that they were sisters, but they were mother and daughter.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は日本に１０年も住んでいるもんだから日本語をペラペラに話せると思いきや、少しも話せない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He had lived in Japan for 10 years, so I thought that he could speak Japanese fluently, but he can't speak a word of it. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いよいよ晴れるだろうと思いきや、たちまち雨が降り出してしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I thought that the weather would finally clear up, but it suddenly started raining.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「やっぱり、今度も失敗したか...」と思いきや、見事合格だった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite having thought, 'As expected, I failed again,' I passed with flying colors.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うたげさんが小さいから同級生と思いきや、驚くことに先生だった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because she was small (like me), I thought Utage-san was (my) classmate, but, to my surprise, she was (my) teacher.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 納豆はまずそうに見えるから、間違いなくまずいと思いきや、実際は、そうではなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I thought for sure that natto would be gross since it looks unappetizing, but that was not the case.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 娘は部屋がとても静かだからきっと寝ていると思いきや、意外にも勉強していた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I thought that my daughter was sleeping because it was very quiet, but to my surprise she was studying.

Name: どうにも
Meaning: Cannot, There is no way one can, Nothing one can do, Cannot possibly not by any means, Cannot do no matter how hard one tries, Nothing will come out, It is meaningless to
About: どうにも is an expression that is often paired with negative structures such as できない 'cannot', ならない 'won't happen', or ようがない 'no way'. It is a combination of the adverb どう 'how', the case marking particle に, and the adverbial particle も, and may be translated as 'even however (A), still not (B)'. The whole structure itself is usually interpreted simply as 'it is meaningless to (A)', 'there's nothing one can do about (A)', or nothing will come of (A)'. どうにも will primarily be seen either at the start or end of sentences, after or before going on to explain a situation which seems impossible due to some specific reason. This grammar pattern emphasizes the speaker's feelings of resignation, frustration, or regret in relation to something that is out of their control. Due to this, it often highlights the actions of someone other than the speaker. Occasionally, どうにも is further emphasized by the addition of こうにも.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今更頑張ってもどうにもならないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if you try your best now, nothing will come out of it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなこと急に言われても、どうにもできないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Nothing could be done, even if you suddenly tell me that.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自分で読むだけじゃどうにも理解できないので、先生に聞くことにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I couldn't manage to understand it just by reading it myself, so I decided to ask my teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなことを言われてもどうにもこうにもなりません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter what you say, nothing will come out of it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 説明してあげたいけど、どうにもこうにも説明できない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I would love to explain it for you, but there is no way I can explain it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あたしがいなきゃどうにもならないでしょ？
Questions.EnglishHTML: It seems that there is nothing you can do if I am not around?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達との話：「後悔したってもうどうにもなんない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat with a friend: 'Even if you regret it, nothing can be done now.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうにもできない事態に陥ったので手を借りるしかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I got trapped in a situation about which nothing could be done so I have no choice but to ask for help.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は人の言うことを聞かないからアドバイスしたところでどうにもならないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She doesn't listen to what people say, so even if you give her advice, nothing will come out of it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「都心に向かう電車の中は、人でいっぱい。どうにも身動きしようがない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Trains heading downtown are packed with people. There is no way for one to move.'

Name: ことだし
Meaning: (And) so, Because, Since
About: ことだし is a combination of the noun こと 'thing', the auxiliary verb だ, and the conjunction particle し, used for listing reasons. The whole structure itself often translates simply as 'because (A)', or 'since (A)', but places extra emphasis on there being other reasons besides what the speaker has specified. This structure may appear after any word in its attributive form, or after a noun that has been followed with の. Just like with its standard use in creating lists, し is being used in this grammar point to show that (A) is not exclusive. The way this comes across is that 'while there are other reasons, (A) is good enough to (B)'. (B) is usually some suggestion, invitation, or expression of determination.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: せっかく君のお父さんとお母さんが来ることだし、どっかいい焼肉屋さんにでも行こう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since your father and mother are coming all the way (to see us), let's go to a nice yakiniku restaurant.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 天気もいいことだし、みんなで公園にでも行きましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since the weather is nice, let's all go to the park together.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼が勤めている会社は有名なことだし、給料もいいんだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since the company he works for is famous, his salary must be good.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼のことだし、また遅れてくるんじゃないの。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Knowing him, I bet that he will come late as usual.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 飛行機代も安いことだし天気もいいから沖縄に行こうよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since plane tickets are cheap and the weather is nice, let's go to Okinawa.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 割引クーポンもあることだし、明日映画を一緒に観に行かない？
Questions.EnglishHTML: I also have discount coupons, so why don't we go watch a movie together tomorrow?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう夜も更けてくることだし、今日のパーティはこれでお開きにしよう！
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's getting late, so let's call it a night with this!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 風邪を引いていることだし、今日くらいは何もしないでゆっくり休んだら？
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since you have caught a cold, at least for today, how about you rest without doing anything?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女のことだし、きっと次の試合には勝つとわたしは信じているよ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Knowing her, I am convinced that she will surely win the next match.

Name: がん～
Meaning: Totally, Seriously, Completely, Furiously, Majorly
About: ガン見(み) is a noun that acts as a する-Verb in order to convey that someone is looking at something with fixation. Originally, it is a colloquial abbreviation of ガンガン見(み)る, with ガンガン being an onomatopoeic expression that can be interpreted as 'furiously', or 'vigorously' in certain contexts. ガン can be attached the the stem form of certain verbs to create new する-Verbs, or attached to certain pre-existing する-Verbs. As you are exposed to Japanese more and more, seeing certain onomatopoeia structures shortened like this will be quite common, and many of them are only used in some specific phrases. In this case ガン is not usually attached to other words, and words like ガン見(み) are considered a standalone expressions. Due to this, it will be important to look up similar expressions on a case-by-case basis in order to determine if the onomatopoeic part is acting as a prefix, or is just a set phrase.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電車の中で転んで、周りの人たちにガン見されたときは恥ずかしさのあまり、泣いてしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I fell while on the train and everyone majorly stared at me, I cried from embarrassment.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 両親の電話をガン無視していたら家まで来られた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I completely ignored my parents' phone calls, they came to my house.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日も先輩にガン切れされたよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was majorly scolded by my senpai again today.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昨日の帰りが遅くなった理由を、妻にガン詰めされた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My wife completely hounded me about why I came home late yesterday.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の娘がいじめられていたなんて、もう学校にガン切れしに行くしかない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You’re saying my daughter has been bullied? There’s nothing left for it but to go absolutely ballistic at the school.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あれだけ彼に会えることを楽しみにしていたのだから、彼女がガン萎えするのも無理はないと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since she had been looking forward to seeing him that much, it’s understandable that she’s totally down.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 犬が主人公の映画を見たら、過去に飼っていた愛犬とその犬を重ねてしまって、ガン泣きした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When I watched a movie that had a dog as a main character, I imagined my old dog in its place and completely bawled my eyes out.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ちょっとした冗談のつもりだったのに、彼女にとっては地雷だったみたいで、いきなりガン切れされた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though I’d meant it as a little joke, apparently it was a crazy sensitive topic for her and she furiously snapped at me.

Name: か否(いな)か
Meaning: Whether or not
About: 否(いな)  'no' is an interjection in Japanese that is primarily paired with the adverbial particle か 'or' when stating 'whether or not (A)'. The literal meaning is just '(A) or no'. This is a very formal expression that will mainly be seen in writing. か否(いな)か may appear after almost any word in their standard forms. This structure is often paired with words like べき 'ought to', を問(と)わず 'without questioning', にかかわらず 'regardless of', and will be used to make determinations about the suitability of something based on a specific situation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この授業を楽しむか否かは自分次第だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether you enjoy this class or not is up to you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 怖いか否かは別として、この映画はとても面白かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Putting aside whether this movie was scary or not, it was really enjoyable.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人が貧乏であるか否かは私たちには関係のないことです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether that person is poor or not is none of our business.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人がこの子の父親か否か、ＤＮＡ検査をしなくてはわからない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We will never know if that man is the father of this child or not without a DNA test.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自分の人生に満足できるか否か、それはあなたの頑張り次第である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether you are satisfied or not with your own life is a result of your effort.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今の会社を辞めて転職するか否か、もう少し悩む事にしよう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether I will resign from my current company and get a new job or not, I'll ponder on it a bit more.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: イベントのサイト：「参加資格： 登録ユーザーであるか否かを問わず、どなたでもご参加可能」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Event website: 'Entry qualifications: Regardless of whether you are a registered user or not, anyone can participate.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事のタイトル：「プロゲーマーは真のスポーツ選手か否か。ｅスポーツ業界が直面するビザの問題」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article title: 'Are pro gamers real athletes or not? The visa problem that eSports faces.' (whether or not)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サイト、クッキーファイルについて：「利用者はそのクッキーを受け入れるか否かを決めることができますし、また、全部のクッキーを削除することもできます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Website, about cookie files: 'Users can decide whether or not they accept cookies. Users are also able to delete all accepted cookies anytime.'

Name: たら〜で
Meaning: Even if, If
About: たら〜で is an expression that appears with repeating words, and may be used either positively or negatively in order to show that 'if (A), then with (A), (B)'. It is often simply translated as 'even if (A), (B)'. たら〜で may use either the conjunction particle たら or ば when paired with verbs or い-Adjectives, but will use なら when paired with な-Adjectives. In たら〜で constructions, it is important to remember that the nuance will change depending on the first half of the sentence. Basically, the most common interpretations are as follows. In the good situation of (A), the problem of (B) will arise. In the problematic situation of (A), (B) can still be done. So in either case, it can be seen that (B) will be something that is contradictory to (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ニートになったらなったで大変だと思うよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if you become a NEET, I think it would still be tough.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日雨が降れば降ったでなんとかすればいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it rains tomorrow, we can do something about it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大きい方が荷物とかいっぱい積めるけど、大きかったら大きいでデメリットがある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The bigger the car, the more luggage it can carry, but if the car is big, there are many disadvantages.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 力がなくてもできる仕事は沢山あるから、弱ければ弱いでいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are plenty of jobs that can be done even if you are weak.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 嫌なら嫌で大丈夫！田中くんに頼むこともできるし。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you hate it that's fine! Since you could also just request Tanaka-kun to do it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 難しい文法を見ると怯んでしまうけど、簡単なら簡単でやりがいはない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's daunting to see difficult grammar, but if it's easy then it's not worth doing. (This grammar point's meaning)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 辞めるなら辞めるでいいけど、後からやっぱりやめなければよかったとかって言わないでね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you want to quit, then go ahead and quit, but don't say later that you wish you hadn't quit after all. (The other なら～で meaning)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「もし失敗したら失敗したで、また最初からやり直そうと思う。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Even if I fail, I will do it again from the beginning.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「結婚したい。」
「結婚したらしたで大変だよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'I want to marry…'
'Even if you get married, it's (still) tough.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「また子供になりたいな。」
「けど、子供になったらなったで子供なりの苦労があるよ」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'I want to be a child again…'
'But, children have problems of their own even if you become (are) one.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「金は沢山あったらあったで悩みも増えるものだよ。」
「それはそうだけど、でも、なかったらないで困るでしょ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Even if you have a lot of money, problems will also multiply.'
'That might be right, but even if you don't have any, then it's (still) troublesome.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「スーパーとかで高い棚に手が届けばいいんだけど、背が低ければ低いで、なんとかなるはずだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'It'd be nice if I could reach the high shelves in the supermarket and such, but I should be able to manage one way or the other even if I'm short.'

Name: べくして
Meaning: As expected, Meant to, Supposed to, Destined to, Sure to
About: べくして is a combination of the conjunctive form of the classical auxiliary verb べし, べく, and the conjunctive particle して, which shows a situation from which a logical determination can be made, or will be a natural course of action. べく itself indicates the word that it is attached to as a 'purpose' or 'end goal'. べくして is often translated simply as 'as expected of (A), (B)', or 'as was supposed to (A), (B)'. (A) and (B) will be the same verb repeated. The literal meaning of 'as determined with the purpose of (A)' may also be used if it helps to remember the nuance. This expression is quite formal, so will rarely be heard in daily speech.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女らはここ２年間毎日文句を言わずにトレーニングしてきたから、大会で勝つべくして勝ったんだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: These girls have trained every day for the last two years without complaint, so as expected they won the competition.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 役所には何回もここに止まれの標識を設置するように訴えたが対応してくれなかったので、この事故は起こるべくして起こった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We have asked the city office multiple times to install a stop sign here, but they never listened to us, so this accident was expected.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近、彼女とは出会うべくして出会ったと感じることが多い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, I have been feeling that we were destined to meet.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: タイトル：「俺の青春ラブコメはまちがいになるべくしてなった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Title: 'As expected, my romantic youth comedy was a blunder.' (meant to・supposed to・destined to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 壊れた一時停止標識を放置した結果、起こるべくして起こった交通事故だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As expected, the result of neglecting a broken stop sign was a traffic accident. (meant to・supposed to・destined to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「これらの二人は、専門分野も年齢も共に近いゆえに出会うべくして出会ったと言えるだろう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: As expected, one can say that these two met because they both shared fields of expertise and were close in age. (meant to・supposed to・destined to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 不景気か否かにかかわらず、高品質で適正価格の商品は売れるべくして売れている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether there is a recession or not, products of good quality and reasonable price are sure to sell. (meant to・supposed to・expected to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 好景気が遅かれ早かれ終わるのは経済学者にとって当然のことであったし、そうなるべくしてなった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To the economists, it was only natural that prosperity will end sooner or later, and, as expected, that's what happened. (meant to・supposed to・destined to)

Name: ままに (As Desired)
Meaning: As (one likes, feels or pleases), Spur of the moment, Wherever one fancies, Spontaneously, On a whim
About: Unlike the ままに that is partnered with passive structures like れる and られる 'to do as one is told', when paired with verbs in their standard forms, ままに means 'to do (A) as one wishes', or 'to do (A) on a whim'. ままに is a combination of the noun まま 'as is', and the case marking particle に. ままに will follow verbs in their dictionary form. In many cases, this use of ままに indicates that the speaker or doer is letting the action of (A) happen in whatever way is most natural, and is not making any particular effort to control the outcome. Due to this, there are only a limited number of verbs that are commonly used with ままに, and it is best not to attempt to use combinations that you have not come across before. Some standard sequences are 気(き)の向(む)くままに 'in whatever way my attention is inclined', 思(おも)うままに 'in whatever way I think up', 思(おも)いつくままに 'in whatever way I come up with', 足(あし)の向(む)くままに 'in whatever direction my feet are pointed', 赴(おもむ)くままに 'in whatever way it proceeds', 欲(ほっ)するままに 'in whatever way is desired', and 風(かぜ)の吹(ふ)くままに 'in whatever way the wind blows'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはもうあなたのものだから、自分が思うままに使えばいいよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is yours now, so you can use it as you see fit.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 僕はしばらくの間一人で、足の向くままに旅をする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will be alone for a while, traveling wherever my feet take me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 文法とかは気にしなくていい！ただ思いつくままに書いてくれればいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no need to worry about grammar! Just write whatever comes to mind.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 足の向くままにバイクで駆けていたら公園に行き着いてしまったのだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was biking where my feet took me and ended up in a park.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 抽象画家は深く考えずに形や色を気の向くままに選ぶ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Abstract painters choose shapes and colors as they please, without thinking deeply about them.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「ジラヤさんはどこ？」
Ｂ：「わからん。どこかに行ったんだ。」
Ａ：「相変わらず、風の吹くまま、赴くなぁ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'Where is Jiraya?'
B: 'Dunno. He went somewhere.'
A: 'As always, he goes wherever the wind takes him.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
ふぶき：「そのあと、どうするつもり？」
さいたま：「ただ心の欲するまま、自由に生きる。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Fubuki: 'What are you going to do after that?'
Saitama: 'I will simply live freely, as I desire.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: モーガンさん、クリスチャンさんに：「あなたのものですから気兼ねなく自分の思うままに扱ってもいいです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mr. Morgan to Mr. Christian: 'It belongs to you, so feel free to handle it as you please.'

Name: かれ〜かれ
Meaning: Or, Either or
About: かれ～かれ is a grammar pattern that pairs with opposite い-Adjectives in Japanese to convey that 'whether (A) or (B), the result will be the same'. It is usually translated as 'or', or 'either (A) or (B)'. Originally, this structure was a contraction of the conjunctive stem of い-Adjectives, く, and the imperative form of the う-Verb ある 'to be', あれ. い-Adjectives do not have their own imperative form, so くあれ and then the abbreviation かれ evolved to fill this role. As it is imperative, the literal meaning is simply 'be it (A) or (B)', and is a declaration. かれ～かれ will attach to the stem of 2 adjectives that are antonyms, before going on to explain how the result remains the same regardless. かれ～かれ is used with a very limited set of adjectives, so it is best not to use it with words that you have not come across previously.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんな人でも多かれ少なかれ悩みを抱えて生きている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether it be to a higher or lesser extent, everyone lives burdened by troubles.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 暑かれ寒かれ、脱水症状は起こりうるので水分補給はこまめにしてください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Dehydration can occur in hot or cold weather, so please hydrate frequently.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遅かれ早かれ提出させないといけないのであるならば、早めに提出した方がいいと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it has to be submitted sooner or later, I think it is better to submit it as soon as possible.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この発明は、良かれ悪しかれたくさんの人に影響を与えるだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This invention will affect a lot of people, for better or worse.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「こんなにタバコを吸い続けては遅かれ早かれ病気になるだろう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'If you keep on smoking like this, sooner or later you will get sick.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この発見はよかれあしかれ、大きな変化をもたらすだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For better or worse, this discovery will bring great change.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 好奇心は多かれすくなかれ誰もが持っているものだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Curiosity is something that everybody has, to a greater or lesser extent.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遅かれはやかれ有人火星探査の時代はやってくるはずだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am sure that sooner or later, the era of manned missions to Mars will come.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: よかれあしかれ、確かに社会がキャッシュレス化する傾向が続いている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For better or worse, the trend of society turning cashless continues.

Name: ～に〜ない
Meaning: Cannot even...if wants, Would like to...but cannot, Wants to...but cannot
About: に～ない is a construction which appears with repeating verbs in Japanese to indicate that one 'cannot (A) even if they want to', or 'due to some circumstances, can't (A)'. the case marking particle に will appear after a verb in its dictionary form, before the potential form of the same verb will be negated with ない. In this way, the more literal meaning is 'for (A), (A) is not possible'. It will be important to keep in mind that する does not have a potential form, so できない will be used in the latter half of this expression when paired with する verbs. Additionally, ない may sometimes be replaced with other structures that convey negation, such as ず.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 生徒が言った冗談は面白かったが内容が下品だったので笑うに笑えなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The joke the student told was funny, but it was inappropriate so I could not laugh even if I wanted to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 本当は時間はあんまりなかったが、先輩に頼まれたから断るに断れなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I actually didn't really have too much time, but since my senpai asked me I couldn't refuse even if I wanted to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子には明日までに滑り台を作ってあげると約束してしまったので、どんな忙しくても引くに引けない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I promised my son that I would build him a slide by tomorrow, so I can't back out no matter how busy I am.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近は色々と悩み事が多くて、集中するにできない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A lot has been on my mind recently that I haven't been able to concentrate even if I wanted to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子が一晩中泣いていて寝るに寝れず徹夜をしてしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My son cried all night and because of that I couldn't sleep even if I wanted to and stayed up all night.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日の練習で足の怪我をしてしまったので歩こうにも歩けない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I couldn't walk even if I wanted to because I injured my foot in yesterday's practice.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今の仕事を辞めようと思っているが、次のところが見つからないから今の仕事を辞めようにも辞められない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm thinking of quitting my current job, but I can't find another one, so I couldn't quit my current job even if I wanted to.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 親友から土下座をしながら頼まれては、断るに断れません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Being requested something while my friend is on their hands and knees, I cannot refuse even if I want to.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 逃げるに逃げられない状況から救ってくれたのは、いつもは厳しい先輩だった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The one who saved me from a situation that I wanted to escape from but could not, was my senpai who is always strict.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嫌われている上司が見事に転んでしまった。従業員が笑うに笑えない、という顔をしてた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The boss that everyone hates had a spectacular fall. The employees' faces looked as though they wanted to laugh but were unable to.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「彼はどうして学校に戻ろうとしないのかな？」
「何があったか知らないけど、言うに言えない事情があるのかな。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Why is he not willing to go back to school?'
'I'm not sure if something happened or not, but maybe he is in a situation where he cannot talk about it (even though he may want to).'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「彼女が断れば殺すと言って突然断るに断れない状態になった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'She said, 'If you refuse, I will kill you,' so the situation suddenly turned into one where I couldn't refuse even if I wanted.'

Name: なくしては
Meaning: Without, If not for
About: なくしては is a hypothetical expression that indicates that 'if not for (A), then not (B)'. It may appear as either なしには, なしでは, or なくしては, with little variation in meaning. It is a combination of the conjunctive form of the い-Adjective ない, なく, the conjunction particle して, which highlights the word before it as a condition from which a determination can be made, and the adverbial particle は. As the second part of なくしては sentences will also be negative, we can see the more literal meaning of 'from the lack of (A), a lack of (B) can be determined'. This 'determination' comes across quite strongly, and may be interpreted as '(B) is impossible without (A)'. なくしては will appear after either nouns, or phrases that have been nominalized with こと. As mentioned previously, なしには and なしでは may also be seen. These are just the noun 無(な)し 'without', paired with either of the particle combinations には or では. なくしては is the most formal of the three. The (B) part of なくしては sentences will almost always be some state of completion or desirable outcome that cannot be achieved without (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は彼女なくしては生きていけないと思います。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't think that I can live without her.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 努力なくしては、日本語は上達しません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Without hard work, your Japanese won't improve.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 失敗することなくしては、成功できないと言われているが本当なのだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is said that, without failure you cannot succeed, but I wonder if that is true.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 相手の気持ちを考えることなくしては、友情は続かない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Friendship cannot last without considering the feelings of the other person.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この国ではエアコンなしには夏を乗り越えられません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In this country you cannot survive summer without air conditioning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたなしでは生きていけません！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't live without you!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 名言：「努力なくして成功なし。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Wise saying: 'There is no success without hard work.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 愛なくしては生きられないというが、それが苦痛になることもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They say that one cannot live without love, but sometimes it becomes a significant burden.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トランジスタの開発なくして、現在の世界は成立しえない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The world we know today is not possible without the development of transistors.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「ノーベル賞受賞はノーベル委員会に是認されることなくしては、ありえないことであろう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Receiving the Nobel prize is impossible without the approval of the Nobel Committee.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スピーチ、ＣＥＯ：「消費者の皆様との協力なくしてはこの商品開発は不可能であります。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Speech, CEO: 'The development of this product is impossible without the cooperation of all of our consumers.'

Name: のなんのって
Meaning: So much that, Extremely, Very
About: のなんのって is a casual phrase that is used in spoken Japanese to indicate that the word before it is 'excessively (A)', or 'extremely (A)'. This structure consists of the case marking particle の, the pre-noun adjectival 何(なん)の 'what kind of', and って, an abbreviation of という 'to say'. The literal meaning of 'and to say it's (A) or something' just indicates that something is so (A) that if it is not that then the speaker doesn't know what to call it. This structure will be seen after い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives followed by な, and verbs. のなんのって itself is a more condensed variation of ～の～ないのって, which has the same meaning, but has (A) appear in both the positive and negative for 'to say it's (A) or not (A), (B)', where (B) will usually be a phrase explaining the extent of (A). Occasionally (B) will be left unsaid, as ～の～ないのって itself is always used to mean 'extremely (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんな痩せているのにあの量一人で食べちゃうなんて、びっくりしたのなんのって。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was extremely surprised that such a skinny guy could eat that amount of food all by himself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 名古屋の夏は暑いのなんのって、外に出た瞬間シャツが汗でびっしょりになるんだよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is so hot in Nagoya in the summer that the moment you step outside, your shirt will be drenched in sweat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの建物は丈夫なのなんのって、去年あった震度７の地震までも耐えたんだよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That building is so sturdy that it even withstood last year's earthquake that measured 7 on the Japanese seismic scale.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は食べるの食べないのって、三十分で三キロも肉を一人で食べた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He eats so much that he ate 3 kg of meat in 30 minutes all by himself.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのジェットコースターは大人でも失神するほど怖いの怖くないのって。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That rollercoaster is so scary that even an adult would pass out.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お母さんが「勉強しろ」ってうるさいのなんのって、もう家に帰りたくないよ…。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My mom is extremely annoying with comments like 'study!', and I don't want to go home anymore.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの旅館の女将さんは愛想が悪いのなんのって、もう二度と行くもんか！
Questions.EnglishHTML: That ryokan's proprietress' amiability was so bad that there is no way I would ever go there again!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ジャングルの中でワニと出くわした時は焦ったのなんのって、もう死ぬかと思ったよ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was extremely startled when I happened upon a crocodile in the jungle that I thought I was going to die!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 東京の夏は蒸し暑いのなんのって、少し歩いただけで気持ち悪くなるくらいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Tokyo's summer is extremely humid, so much so that it feels gross even if you just walked around a little bit.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夫の実家は広いのなんのって、庭には沢山の木が植えられていてプールもあるんだよ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: My husband's family home is extremely spacious. There are lots of trees planted in the garden, and even a pool!

Name: にかかっている
Meaning: To depend on
About: にかかっている is a structure that may be translated as 'to depend on (A)', or 'to rest on (A)'. It is a combination of the case marking particle に, and the ている continuous form of 懸(か)かる 'to depend'. Although にかかっている may attach to nouns, it is also frequently seen following set structures such as かどうか 'whether or not', and か否(いな)か 'yes or no'. The に in にかかっている may sometimes be replaced with the adverb 如何(いかん)に 'how', 'in what way', or 'to what extent. In these situations, the meaning stays relatively the same, but will extend to 'depending on the way in which (A)', or 'depending on to what extent (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来月旅行に行けるかは、部長が僕に休みをくれるかにかかっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether I can go on the trip next month depends on whether my boss will give me time off.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 地球の未来は若者にかかっているから、若者を教育しなくてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We must educate the youth because the future of this earth depends on them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自分で立ち上げた会社が成功するかどうかは自分の努力にかかっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether your company will succeed or not depends on your own efforts.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この商品の売れ行きはマーケティングが成功するかどうか如何にかかっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The sales of this product will depend on the success of the marketing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: みなさんが合格できるかできないかは、皆さんが努力するかどうか如何にかかっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Whether or not you will be able to pass the exam depends on how hard you are going to work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ほむら：「すべてが一人の少女の選択にかかっている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Homura: 'Everything depends on one girl's choice.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コーチ：「勝つも負けるも我々の協力にかかっているから頑張ろう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Coach: 'Whether we win or lose depends on our cooperation, so let's do our best!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日予定通りにピクニックに行けるかどうかは明日の天気にかかっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Whether we can go on a picnic tomorrow as planned depends on tomorrow's weather.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 成功するかどうかは才能よりむしろどれだけ頑張るかにかかっていると言えるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'It is fair to say that whether or not one succeeds depends on how hard one can work rather than one's ability.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「帝国の運命はターニャの作戦が成功するか否かにかかっている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'The fate of the empire depends on whether Tanya's strategy succeeds or not.'

Name: ～て止(や)まない
Meaning: Never cease to, Always, Sincerely, Greatly, From the bottom of one's heart
About: ～てやまない is a formal construction that combines the て-form of a verb with the negative form of the う-Verb 止(や)む 'to cease', or 'to desist'. The literal meaning of 'to not stop (A)', or 'to not desist (A)' is often translated as 'to always (A)', or 'to (A) from the bottom of one's heart'. It is an expression that is used exclusively in relation to feelings and emotions. Common words that may be partnered with やまない include 愛(あい) 'love', 敬愛(けいあい) 'love and respect', 願(ねが)う 'to wish for', 祈(いの)る 'to hope for', 望(のぞ)む 'to have ambitions for', 希望(きぼう) 'wish', 期待(きたい) 'anticipation', 尊敬(そんけい) 'respect', 信(しん)じる 'to trust', and several more. Either positive or negative emotions may be used.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が愛してやまない犬が急に体を壊したから心配でしょうがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The dog that I love from the bottom of my heart got sick suddenly, so I am worried.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんなことを親にさせてしまって後悔してやまない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I never cease to regret letting my parents do that for me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １日も早く普通の生活に戻れる様に祈ってやみません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will never cease to pray for them to be able to return to their normal lives as soon as possible.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 上司に子供や妻のことを悪く言われて、腹が立ってやまない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was sincerely mad at my boss for saying such things about my wife and kids. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 献辞：「愛してやまない妻と息子へ」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Dedication: 'To my wife and son, whom I will always love.' (never cease to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スピーチ：「飢餓がこの世界から駆逐されることを、祈ってやみません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Speech: 'I will never cease to pray for the eradication of hunger and starvation from this world.' (always・deeply・sincerely)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「彼は人を惹きつけてやまない何かを持っていると言えるだろう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'One could say that he has something that greatly fascinates people.' (never cease to)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうして科学的な証拠もないのに幽霊を信じてやまない人がこんなに沢山いるのかな…。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I wonder why there are lots of people that never cease to believe in ghosts, despite there being no scientific evidence.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 賛辞：「友達としても人としても心の中に生涯存在する尊敬してやまない人でした。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Eulogy: 'She was a person I greatly respected throughout my life both as a friend and as a human being.' (never cease to)

Name: くらいなら
Meaning: Would rather...than, Rather than, Better off
About: くらいなら will often be translated as 'would rather (B) than (A)', or 'better off (B) than (A)'. It is a grammar pattern that combines the adverbial particle usages of くらい 'about' and なら 'if' to imply that 'if it gets to the extent of (A), then (B)', where (B) will be something that is preferable. くらいなら will be used directly following verbs in their dictionary forms. As this structure emphasizes (A) as being something that is undesirable, (B) will often contain statements that offer a solution, suggestion, or opinion, such as ほうがいい 'would be better to', ほうがましだ 'would be less bad', なさい 'do!'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの地域に引っ越すくらいなら、死んだ方がマシだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I would rather die, than move to that neighborhood.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの先輩の下で働くぐらいなら、一人で働いた方がいいと思うよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think you would be better off working alone, than working under that senpai.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 何十万もかけて直すくらいなら、もう少し出して新しい車を買った方がいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I would rather buy a new car that is a little expensive than pay thousands of dollars to fix this car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: え、前使ってたパソコン捨てちゃったの？捨てるくらいなら俺が買ったのに。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What… You threw away the computer you were using? I would have bought it from you rather than you throw it away.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんな奴に頼むぐらいなら、自分でやればよかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I should have done it myself, rather than asking a person like that to do it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「やらずに後悔するくらいなら、いっそやってみなさいよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Rather than regret not doing it, try it!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「 こんなクソゲームを買うくらいならお金をドブに捨てたほうがよかった・・・」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I would have been better off throwing money away than buying this gosh darn game…'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「その仕事は絶対に嫌だ。それに戻るくらいなら死んだほうがましだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I really hate that job. I would rather die than go back.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「小さなことに目くじらを立てる人と一緒に生活するくらいならホームレスになったほうがましだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I would rather become homeless than live together with a person who nitpicks every little thing I do.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「愛Ｐｈｏｎｅの画面の修理は３万円からするよ。どうしようかな？」
Ｂ：「とっても高いよね！修理するくらいなら新しいのを買っちゃった方がいいかなあ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'My aiPhone screen repair cost starts at about 30000 yen! What should I do?'
B: 'Wha, that's super expensive! You would be better off buying a new one rather than repairing it.'

Name: ってば
Meaning: I said...!, I told you...!, !
About: ってば and ったら are often used in casual Japanese to insist the speaker's own viewpoint or opinion about something. The structures are frequently translated as 'I said (A)!', or 'I told you (A)!'. ってば and ったら are contractions of といえば 'if it were said', and といったら 'if it were said' respectively. In these cases, the literal meaning is very similar to the English 'didn't I say (A)!?' when used sarcastically or aggressively. Either ってば or ったら may follow just about any word, but will require a だ to precede them when coming after nouns or な-Adjectives.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 分かったってば！何回も言われると本当むかつくからちょっと黙ってて。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I said I got it! You telling me the same thing (repeatedly) is getting on my nerves so can you please be quiet for a little bit?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 痛いったら！なんでずっと痛いって言ってるのに何回も何回もフォークでつついてくるの？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I said that hurts! Why do you keep poking me with a fork even when I say that it hurts?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 嫌いだってば！あんな奴なんて大嫌いだ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I said I don't like them! I don't like such people!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: だから、俺は大人だったら！背が低いからってひどいぞ本当に。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For the last time, I said that I am an adult. It is kind of mean to say such things just because I am short.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 金太郎ってば、またエアコンつけっぱなしで家出てったよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That darn Kintaro, he went out with his AC still running.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたったら本当におっちょこちょいね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Oh you, you are such a clutz aren't you.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
親：「もっとお姉ちゃんを見習いなさい！」
子供：「見習いたくないったら！」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Parent: 'You need to better follow your sister's example!
Child: 'I said I don't wanna!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
親：「宿題やりなさいよ！」
イライラした子供：「今からやるったら！」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Parent: 'Do your homework!'
Irritated child: 'I said I'm gonna do it!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 配偶者１がケーキを食べようとしている配偶者２に「ケーキを夕食の前に食べちゃダメったら！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Spouse to spouse that is about to eat cake: 'I told you not to eat cake before dinner!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
友達１：「俺と一緒バンジージャンプ、やってみない？」
友達２：「興味ないんだ。」
友達１：「本当に？」
友達２：「やだってば、もう！」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Friend1: 'Won't you go bungee jumping together with me?'
Friend2: 'Not interested.'
Friend1: 'Are you sure?'
Friend2: 'I said no, Jeez!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
父：「宿題やったのか？」
息子：「やったよ〜。」
父：「ふむ…本当か？」
息子：「本当だってば！」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Dad: 'Have you done your homework?'
Son: 'Done.'
Dad: 'Hmmm, is that true?'
Son: 'I said it's true!'

Name: ずとも
Meaning: Even if not, Without, Don't have to
About: When combined with the classical auxiliary verb ず (used for negation), the conjunction particle とも 'even if' implies that regardless of the hypothetical situation of (A), (B) still applies. This often translates as 'even if not (A), (B)', or 'don't have to (A) to (B)'. ずとも will appear attached to the ない-stem of verbs. When the speaker wants to express 'not being (A)' rather than 'not doing (A)', ならずとも will follow a noun. This is simply the negated form of the う-Verb なる 'to become'. Although ずとも is a formal expression, it may occasionally be used sarcastically. Additionally, it is common for ずとも to be followed by 良(よ)い. This can be interpreted as 'okay even if not (A)'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昔は練習せずとも新しい曲を完璧に弾けたのに、今となってはどんだけ練習しても上手く弾けないんだよな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I used to be able to play new music without any practice, but now I can't play well no matter how much I practice.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたが今ものすごく落ち込んでいるということは聞かずともわかりますよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can tell that you are very upset without even asking.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本に留学せずとも、日本語を習得する方法はあるが、日本に行って勉強する方が楽しそうだから私は日本に留学したいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I know that there are ways to study Japanese without studying abroad in Japan, but I am going to Japan because it seems fun to study there.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 専門家ならずとも、彼は政治について色々と知っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though he is not an expert, he knows alot about politics.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 親ならずとも子育てが大変だということは見てわかるはずだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You don't have to be a parent to see that parenting is hard work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来週の試合の相手はあの弱いチームだから、そんなに練習せずとも良いだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Next week's game is against that weak team, so we won't have to practice so much.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「植物は動物ならずともある種の知覚表示をしている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'Even if plants are not animals, in a way, they display perception.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ゲーム評論：「ＲＰＧゲームファンならずとも、ウィッチャー ３に興味をひかれずにはいられません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Game review: 'Even if I am not an RPG fan, I cannot help but be captivated by Witcher 3.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「アメリカ人とイギリス人は他の言語を学ばずとも生きられる言語環境に居ます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'Americans and Brits are in a language environment where they can live without learning other languages.' (even if they do not learn)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 時代小説、瀕死の親：「わたしの身の心配などせずとも良い。我が娘よ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A historical novel, dying parent: 'You don't have to worry about me. My dear daughter.' (without・even if)

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
妹：「でも、どうやってわかった？」
兄：「家族だから言わずともわかる。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Younger sister: 'But, how did you know?'
Older brother: 'We are a family, so I understand you even if you don't say anything.'

Name: とあって
Meaning: Since...(it is no wonder that), Because...(it is no wonder that), Due to...(it is no wonder that)
About: とあって is a formal grammar expression that combines the case marking particle と with the て-form of ある 'to be'. It is used to present an unusual situation from which an obvious result will or has occurred. It is often translated as 'since (A), it is no wonder that (B)', or 'because of (A), it's natural that (B)'. とあって is usually seen following almost any word in their standard forms, but な-Adjectives will require a だ to come between them and とあって. This construction can be thought of as similar to として 'as', but with focus more on 'what (A) is or is viewed as', emphasized through ある, rather than 'how (A) conducts itself or is conducted', emphasized through する.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのグループの卒業ライブが行われるとあって、この会場は大勢のファンで溢れている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since a farewell concert of that group is about to take place, this venue is filled with a large number of fans.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 北海道は夏の間でも涼しいとあって、冬の間だけでなく夏にも多くの観光客が訪れるらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard that Hokkaido attracts many tourists not only during winter, but also summer since it is cool there even during the summer months.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの街は便利だとあって、土地の値段が高い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since that city is convenient, the price of land is expensive.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お盆の最終日とあって、高速道路だけでなく、下道もものすごく混んでいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Both the toll free road and the expressway are extremely crowded since it is the last day of Obon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はハンサムとあって、友達が作りやすい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I am handsome, it is easy to make friends. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いつもより講演の参加者が多いとあって、発表者はいつも以上にソワソワしています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since many people attended the lecture, it is no wonder that the speakers are uneasy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ニュースサイト：「日本で初上映とあって、大人から子どもまで多くの人が集まりました。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: News: 'Since it premiered in Japan, (it is no wonder that) many people of all ages gathered.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「この都市で唯一のイタリアンが食べれるレストランとあって、自然と大人気になった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'Since it is the only restaurant in this city where one can eat Italian cuisine, (it is no wonder that) it naturally became very popular.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日はスーパーの特売日とあって、開店する三十分も前から長蛇の列が出来ています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because today is a special sale at the supermarket, it is no wonder that there is already a long line 30 minutes before the store opens.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ニュースサイト：「 気軽に鹿などの野生動物が撮影できるとあって、大変人気の撮影スポットの一つになっています。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: News site: 'Since one can easily photograph wild animals such as deer, (it is no wonder that) it has become one of the most popular photography spots.'

Name: でもなんでもない
Meaning: Not at all, By no means, Definitely not, Nothing like that, Not really
About: でもなんでもない is a structure seen after nouns or な-Adjectives in Japanese to indicate that something is 'definitely not (A)', or 'not (A) at all'. This is a combination of the adverbial particle でも 'even', the adverb 何(なん)でも 'whatever' or 'anything at all', and the い-Adjective ない 'not'. Due to this, the literal translation of 'not even (A) or anything of the sort' reflects the desired nuance. でもなんでもない may be used either positively or negatively. When being used positively, it often has the translation of '(A) is no big deal'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺はファンでもなんでもないよ、ただあの人が作曲した曲を聞くのが好きなだけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am not a fan by any means. I just like listening to the music he produces.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あっ、あの人ですか？友達でもなんでもないですよ、なんかさっき急に話しかけてきたので話していただけです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Oh, that person? They are not my friend at all. They just came up to me and started talking to me so I was just talking to them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 迷惑でもなんでもないですよ、ゆっくりしていってください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's not bothersome at all. Please take your time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 好きでもなんでもない人からそんなこと言われても全然嬉しくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm not at all happy to hear such a thing from someone I don't like or anything.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あいつとは別れたけど、ひどい奴だったから、悲しくもなんでもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I broke up with him, but since he was such an awful person, I am not sad or anything.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これ重くもなんでもないじゃん。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This isn't heavy at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「これは偶然でもなんでもないんです、起こるべくして起こったんです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'It is not a coincidence at all. It was sure to happen.' (definitely not)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 好きでもなんでもないクラスメイトと付き合っているという噂を流されてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Unfortunately, a rumor that I was dating a classmate that I definitely do not like started going around.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼氏が誕生日でもクリスマスでもなんでもないのにペアのネックレスをプレゼントしてくれました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Despite it not being anything like my birthday or Christmas, my boyfriend gave me a couple's necklace.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「彼は‎全然天才でもなんでもない。人並み以上の努力をしているから、あれだけの結果を残せるんだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'He is not a genius by any means. He can achieve so much because he is putting in more work than anyone else.' (definitely not・not at all)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 結婚式の前日に私の婚約者と寝るなんて…あんなやつ、家族でもなんでもないわ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That they slept with my fiance on the day before the wedding… That person, they are not my family at all.

Name: 包(ぐる)みで
Meaning: Whole, -wide, Across the, Entire, All of, With … altogether
About: When following nouns, the suffix ぐるみ 'including (A)', 'all over (A)', or '(A) wide' is used to express that something encompasses absolutely all of (A). ぐるみ stem from the う-Verb 包(くる)む, meaning 'to wrap', or 'to encompass'. In many cases, the case marking particle で will follow ぐるみ to mark 'with', but の may also be seen when preceding a second noun. ぐるみ is most frequently seen following words that specify a whole 'group' or 'span' to which the topic of the sentence is only one part of. This could be one member of a family, one home within a neighborhood, one student within a school, or any other number of things that share a clearly identifiable link. Despite this, the primary nuance will always be that the group itself shares a common trait, rather than focusing on any individual part.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎年家族ぐるみで初詣に行きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go to Hatsumode with my entire family every year.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 会社ぐるみで違法な取引をしていたので、社員全員逮捕された。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: All the employees were arrested because the entire company was doing illegal business.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼とは家族ぐるみの付き合いです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Our family is friends with him and his whole family. (He is a family friend)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 街ぐるみの治安をよくするために、町内会の人たちが毎晩パトロールをしています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In order to improve the security of the entire town, people from the neighborhood association patrol the area every night.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「ともさんとは家族ぐるみの付き合いです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Our family is acquaintances with Tomo and her entire family.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「長年、家族ぐるみで親しくしている友達だよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Our entire families were close friends for many years.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 組織ぐるみで違法な売春宿を見逃していたと知り、組織全体に深く失望した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Knowing that the entire organization had turned a blind eye to illegal brothels, I was deeply disappointed in the whole thing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 学校ぐるみでイジメを隠蔽しようとした結果、社会からさらなる批判を浴びる事になった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As a result of the whole school trying to conceal the bullying, the shower of criticism from the public grew even worse.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 国家ぐるみのドーピングがばれ、その国の選手の大会への出場は禁止されました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: With the uncovering of nation-wide doping, that country's athletes were banned from competing in events.

Name: そばから
Meaning: As soon as, Right after, Even if … still
About: そばから is a combination of the noun 側(そば) 'side', and the case marking particle から 'from'. It illustrates something that happens immediately upon (A), and can be translated as 'as soon as (A), (B)', or 'right after (A), (B)'. (B) is usually something that is considered annoying, unfavorable, or somehow nullifies (A) by the speaker, but there are exceptions. If the more literal translation of 'from right beside (A), (B)' helps to remember the nuance of (B) happening straight away, then that may be a helpful way to memorize this construction. そばから will follow verbs in either their dictionary or past-tense forms. Regardless of whether the dictionary or the past-tense form of a verb is used, as そばから means 'right after (A)', the meaning will not change at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は約束をするそばからすぐ約束を破る。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She breaks her promises as soon as she makes them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は注意するそばから失敗をするから、私のいうことは聞いていないんだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I guess he doesn't listen to me because he makes mistakes as soon as I warn him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パソコンを直したそばからまた壊れてしまうから困っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm having trouble with my computer because it breaks down just as soon as I fix it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 早く読みすぎると読んだそばから忘れるから、もっとゆっくり読む様にしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I try to read more slowly, because if I read too quickly, I forget as soon as I read it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 車の洗車を終えるそばから、雨が降ってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It started to rain as soon as I was about to finish washing my car.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自転車は直したそばから壊れてしまう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My bike breaks as soon as I repair it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたって人は、「やるな」と言ったそばからやるんだから。
Questions.EnglishHTML: People like you are just… As soon as I told you not to do it, you still do it…

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 教わったそばから同じ間違いをおかした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I made the same mistake as soon as I learned of it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ケーキが熱いから触らないように言ったそばから こいつは～。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As soon as I told him not to touch the cake because it was hot, this guy...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新人育成がつらい。彼らは言ったそばからどんどん忘れてしまう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's hard to train new employees. As soon as I tell them something, they immediately forget it.

Name: 訳(わけ)あり(訳(わけ)あって)
Meaning: ～ with reasons, Due to reasons, Defective, Problematic, Unique
About: 訳(わけ)あり is a phrase that is often used before nouns to express that there is a reason for something being a certain way. The reason is normally complicated or something that the speaker does not want to or cannot explain. 訳(わけ)あり is literally made up of 訳(わけ), 'reason' or 'cause', and the continuative form (連用形(れんようけい)) of ある.  訳(わけ)あり will often be connected to nouns with の but sometimes it will be used like a な-adjective and be connected with な. 訳(わけ)あり can also seen directly before some words, without な or の, however these are normally considered to be fixed expressions. This is often a way to euphemistically avoid giving negative descriptions of things.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 訳ありの商品は普通よりかなり安いことが多いから、いらなくてもつい買っちゃう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Products with a reason are way cheaper than usual, so I tend to buy them even if I don’t need them. (Defective products are way cheaper than usual, so I tend to buy them even if I don’t need them.)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近なんでこのあたりが「訳ありの地域」って言われてるかわかってきた気がする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, I feel like I have a better grasp on why this area is known as the ‘Region with a reason’. (Recently, I feel like I have a better grasp on why this area is known as the ‘Defective Region’)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この会社ってなんかみんな訳ありな人だよね。
