AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Everyone in this company is a person with a reason. (Everyone in this company has a colorful background)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この車は訳ありな車だから、買ってすぐ壊れても修理代はすべてこっちもち。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This car has a reason, so even if it breaks immediately after purchase, I have to pay out of pocket if anything happens to it. (This car is defective/has been in an accident, so even if it breaks immediately after purchase, I have to pay out of pocket if anything happens to it)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 訳あり商品は欠陥があっても、安いからすぐ売れることが多い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if a defective product has defects, they sell fast because they are cheap.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が住んでいるところは訳あり物件だから、東京駅から徒歩４分で２ＬＤＫだけど家賃が５万なんだよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The place that I am staying at is a place with reason, so the rent is only 50,000 even though it is a 2LDK that is a 4 minute walk from Tokyo station. (The place that I am staying at is a stigmatized property, so the rent is only 50,000 even though it is a 2LDK that is a 4 minute walk from Tokyo station.)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 訳あって、明日から数日間出勤できません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to reasons, I will not be able to come into work for a few days starting tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 色々と訳ありで、来年から日本で生活することが決まりました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to many reasons, I will be living in Japan starting next year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 訳ありだのなんのって、つべこべうるさいんだよ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Can you shut up with your endless complaints about there being issues!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 数量限定の訳ありアウトレット品ですので、お早めにどうぞ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are a limited number of outlet items with minor issues, so help yourself soon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私たちは、訳あり夫婦で有名だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We’re famous as a couple with a complicated past.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 訳あって、明日から海外に行きます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Due to reasons, I’m going abroad from tomorrow.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「実は今日デートに行けなかったの、ちょっと訳ありでね……ごめん。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: ‘Actually, I couldn’t go on the date today. It’s just have my reasons, sorry.’

Name: に至(いた)って
Meaning: When it came to, Only when, Only after, Go as far as
About: Just like in other grammar points that include the う-Verb 至(いた)る 'to result in', or 'to reach a climax', に至(いた)って will indicate (A) as an extreme extent from which (B) results. The case marking particle に will mark either a verb or noun as the extent that 至(いた)る is signifying as being extreme. Common translations include 'only when (A), did (B)', and 'going as far as to (A), (B)'. The extreme extent that に至(いた)って implies will often be the result of something that has been left far too long in a certain state. Due to this, に至(いた)って is often used in relation to criticism of a lack of action. As with many other grammar structures that use verbs, occasionally the formal conjunctive 至(いた)り will replace the standard て-form 至(いた)って.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩に注意されるに至って、どれだけ俺が自分勝手だったかが分かった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It wasn't until I was warned by a senior colleague that I realized how selfish I had been.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 工場で大きな事故が発生するに至って安全大会を実施する様では、この工場では事故が起こり続けます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If a safety meeting is held only after a major accident occurs at the plant, accidents will continue to occur at this plant.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 糖尿病に至って、食生活に気をつける様になった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Only when I got diabetes, I started to watch what I ate.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この年に至って会社を立ち上げるなんて、自分でもびっくりだよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Deciding to start a company only after reaching such an age, even I am surprised.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 過労で意識を失うに至って、ようやく働きすぎたことがわかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only when I collapsed due to overwork, did I finally realize that I worked too hard.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の祖父は肺不全に至って、いよいよタバコを止めざるをえないことを認めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only when his lungs failed, did my grandfather finally accept that he has no choice but to stop smoking.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 手に負えなくなったこの段階に至ってようやく緊急事態を宣言しました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only at this point, when things got out of hand, (did the government) finally declare a state of emergency.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 訴えられる事が決まるに至ってようやく、彼は自分が何をしたか気づいたようだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Only when the accusation was determined did he realize what he had done.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「何千ものバナナの木が枯れるに至って、バナナ産業は初めてパナマ病の深刻さに気が付いた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'Only when thousands of banana trees died, did the banana industry realize the seriousness of the Panama disease for the first time.'

Name: だに + しない
Meaning: Not even, Not at all, Never could have
About: だに is an adverbial particle that shares a similar meaning to さえ and すら 'even', but is more commonly found in classical literature. It will be paired with negative structures and presents 'minimum' or 'light' examples to which (A) does not apply, and therefore obviously also does not apply to anything greater than (A). It will be translated as 'not even (A), so not (B)', or 'not (B) at all'. だに will be seen following nouns or noun-phrases. Although だに often appears when the (B) part of a sentence is negative, だに itself is not limited to being used this way. When following verbs, and the (B) phrase is not negative, だに simply means 'just'. It is best to keep this in mind, as the core meaning of this adverbial particle will always be to mark the word or phrase before it as an extremely small amount or lower limit.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: アメリカでこんな大きい地震が来るとは誰も予想だにしなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No one could have expected such a big earthquake to happen in the United States.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼が彼女と別れるなんて想像だにしなかったよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I would have never imagined he would leave her.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まさかこの年になって子供を授かるなんて思いだにしていなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I would have never thought I would have a child at this age.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: そのカメレオンは外敵から身を隠すために微動だにしていません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In order to hide itself from predators, that chameleon does not even slightly quiver.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アニメのプロローグ、語り手：「あのとき、俺はあんな悲劇が待ち受けていたなんて、夢にだに思わなかった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Anime prologue, narrator: 'Back then, I couldn't have even dreamed that such a tragedy lay ahead.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「彼女はソファーに座ったままで、まるで本物の人形のように微動だにしない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'She remained seated on the sofa, just like a doll, not even moving an inch.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「ビットコインがこれほどになるとは２００９年始めには誰も予想だにしなかった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'No one could have even predicted in early 2009 that bitcoin would come this far.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「彼が心の中にこんな暗闇を抱えていたなど、勇者は夢想だにしなかった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'The hero couldn't have even dreamed that he was carrying such darkness in his heart.'

Name: がてら
Meaning: On the occasion of, While … as well, While …  (one is) at it, During, Along the way
About: がてら is a neologism that is used in the same way as an adverbial particle in modern Japanese, and will connect to the conjunctive form of verbs, and to nouns. It is similar to ながら in that it will be translated as 'while (A), (B)', 'during (A), (B)', or 'on the occasion of (A)'. When (A) is a noun, it will almost always be a noun that signifies some sort of physical movement. Unlike ながら, がてら focuses more on (A) being a good opportunity which can be utilized or taken advantage of in order to do (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 弟を駅から迎えがてらに、今夜の夕飯の買い物をしに行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will go grocery shopping for tonight's dinner on my way to pick up my brother as well.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 友達の家に行きがてら、近くの神社にお参りに行った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While going to my friend's house, I went to pray at the shrine nearby as well.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ワンちゃんの散歩がてらに、ペットショップにいってくる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While taking my dog on a walk, I am going to go to the pet store as well.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運動がてらに会社まで自転車で行くことにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the occasion of exercising, I decided to ride the bicycle to work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「帰りがてら手紙出してくるね。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'll post the letter on my way home as well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「イノシシの散歩がてら、ちょっとコンビニまで行ってきます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'While taking a walk with my pet wild boar, I will go to the convenience store as well.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「お花見がてら、公園を散歩しよう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Let's take a walk in the park while viewing the cherry blossoms as well.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 回顧録：「ヒースロー空港への移動がてら、観光スポットを訪れた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Memoir: 'I visited some tourist attractions on my way to Heathrow Airport as well.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 友達との話：「じゃあ買い物がてら、紅葉を見に行かないか？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Chat between friends: 'So, why don't we view the autumn leaves while shopping as well?'

Name: んが為(ため)に
Meaning: In order to, To, For the purpose of
About: んがため is a grammar pattern used when indicating that something is being done 'for the purpose of (A)', or 'with (A) as the goal'. ん comes from an abbreviation of む, which is a classical auxiliary verb used to show intent or strong will in the same way as う and よう in modern Japanese. ん is then followed by が, and the noun ため 'sake', or 'purpose'. ん connects to the indeterminate form of verbs (ない stem). Either の or に will usually come after んがため, depending on whether it is followed directly by a noun, or a statement linking to a verb. The meaning of む is kept in ん, as this grammar structure will imply the speaker's will to achieve the goal of (A). As む expresses intent, the verb that ん is attached to must be something that can be controlled by the speaker.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は若い頃からお金を貯めんがために、色々と我慢してきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In order to save up money, he has sacrificed a lot since he was young.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の両親たちは私たちの夢を叶えんがために、毎日休まずに仕事をしてきました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In order to fulfill our dreams, my parents have worked everyday without any rest.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんなことはしたくないが大会で勝たんがためのことだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't want to do such a thing, but will in order to win this competition.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 売れ残りの商品を売らんがための作戦を考えたが何も思いつかなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I tried to come up with a strategy in order to sell the unsold goods, but came up with nothing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は自分の作戦を成功させんがために、友達を裏切った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She betrayed her friends in order to make her plans work.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ソクラテス：「生きんがために食え、食わんがために生きるな」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Socrates: 'Thou shouldst eat to live; not live to eat.' (for the purpose of)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「力の指輪を得んがための戦争が始まった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'The war for the purpose of acquiring the ring of power has begun.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 溺れている子供を助けんがために川に飛び込んだ人が亡くなってしまったそうです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I heard that the person who dove into the river to save the drowning child unfortunately passed away.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕はこの世に何かを為さんがために生まれてきたはずだが、それが何かはまだ分からない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was bound to be born into this world for the purpose of achieving something, but I still do not know just what that is.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「その会社は不良品を売らんがために、高齢者の弱みにつけ込んだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'That company took advantage of the elderly in order to sell defective products.'

Name: いかん〜ず
Meaning: Regardless of (whatever … is), Irrespective of (whatever … is)
About: When the noun いかん 'how', or 'what' is paired with a verb negated with the classical auxiliary verb ず, it will commonly be translated as 'regardless of (A), (B)', or 'irrespective of (A), (B)'. The verbs used for this construction are restricted to 関(かか)わらず 'without relation', によらず 'without approaching', and を問(と)わず 'without questioning. いかん〜ず comes after a noun followed by the case marking particle の. いかん〜ず is a formal grammar pattern that is used primarily to express that (B) will not be affected by (A), even if it is something that would usually be expected. Because of this, 'without taking (A) into account' is another fairly accurate translation of the nuance.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 天候のいかんに関わらず、明日のコンサートは予定通りに開催されます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of the weather, the concert tomorrow will be held as scheduled.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 予約日の２４時間前であれば、理由のいかんによらず、キャンセル料を取られずにキャンセルをすることができます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Cancellations may be made 24 hours prior to the appointment date, regardless of the reason without incurring a cancellation fee.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 未経験者や経験者のいかんを問わず、ここで働く前には新規研修を受けてもらいます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether you are experienced or not, we require everyone to undergo training before working here.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 結果如何を問わず、この学校では努力をした生徒を褒めるようにしています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of results, this school makes sure to praise students that put in effort.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テストの形式如何を問わず自分の力を最大限出せるように勉強しよう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Irrespective of the test format, I shall study in order to put forward my absolute best performance.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これまでの経歴如何を問わず、我が社は多様な人材を受け入れる方針だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of your career history thus far, our company has a policy of accepting a range of talented individuals.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 僕は勝敗如何を問わず、全力でプレーした息子を褒め称えるつもりです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Irrespective of winning or losing, I intend to sing the praises of my son, who played with all of his might.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 発信する内容の如何を問わず、私たちは自由に発言する権利を与えられるべきだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of the transmission contents, we ought to be given the right to voice things freely.

Name: う・よう + にも～ない
Meaning: Cannot... even if one wants or tries, Would like but cannot, Wants or tries but cannot
About: When combined with either of the auxiliary verbs of volition, う or よう, にも～ない conveys that 'despite wanting to (A), it can't be done'. There are usually some circumstances as to why (A) cannot be done that are beyond the control of the speaker. The same verb will be repeated in both the volitional form and the negated potential form. This means that the literal meaning of this grammar pattern is 'Even if I went to (A), I can't (A)'. This 'went to' implies the 'attempt' or 'will' on behalf of the speaker.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もう夜遅いから電車もバスも走ってないし、全然タクシーも通らないし、帰ろうにも帰れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since it is late at night, there aren't any trains or buses, and I haven't seen a taxi, so I can't go home even if I wanted to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 色々と仕事のことで悩んでいるから、毎晩寝ようにも寝れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't sleep even if I wanted to because I am worried about a lot of things regarding work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日出てきた釣竿を買いたいけど、高いから買おうにも買えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I want to buy the new fishing rod that came out yesterday, but since it is expensive, I can't buy it even if I wanted to.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 行きたくないけど、先輩に誘われたら断るに断れない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't want to go, but since my senpai invited me, I can't say no even if I wanted to. (Mental reason)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 携帯を無くしてしまったから、上司に連絡しようにもできない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I lost my phone, I can't call my boss even if I wanted to. (Physical reason)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 亡き妻の笑顔は忘れようにも忘れられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot forget the smile of my late wife, even if I try to.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: プロジェクトについて心配するあまり、寝ようにも寝られない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am so worried about the project that I cannot sleep even if I try.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 車がないのなら、運転しようにも運転できないでしょう？
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you don’t have a car, you couldn’t drive even if you wanted to, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 風邪をひいて喉が痛すぎて、返事をしようにも出来ません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I caught a cold, and my throat hurts so much, so I can’t reply even if try to.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テーマパークには行きたいですが、骨折をしていて歩こうにも歩けないのです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I want to go to a theme park, but I broke a bone and can’t walk even if I try to.

Name: く + もなんともない
Meaning: Not... or anything, Not at all, Not, By no means, Definitely not, Nothing like that
About: When paired with the conjunctive form of い-Adjectives, く, もなんともない is often translated as 'not (A) or anything', or 'definitely not (A)'. This is a combination of the adverbial particle も and the adverb 何(なん)ともない 'doesn't amount to anything'. なんともない is often grouped with other negative structures in order to show that the thing it is linked to is not a large amount or considerable extent. In many cases, 何(なん)ともない illustrates that the extent of the thing that it follows is not sufficient to cause a problem. Because of this ～くもなんともない will often be used in sentences where (A) is something that could potentially be an issue, but the speaker is expressing that it has not reached that point, or does not go that far. Because of this, ～くもなんともない is frequently used with adjectives that describe sensations or emotions.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まだまだだな、お前のパンチを喰らっても痒くもなんともないぞ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You still have a long way to go. Even after getting punched by you, it doesn't even itch.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここで売ってるもんは全て珍しいとかって言ってるけど、実は珍しくもなんともないんだよ。他の店に行くと五千円以下で売ってるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They are saying that everything they are selling is rare, but actually they are not rare at all. If you go to other stores, you can see that they sell them for under 5 thousand yen.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ホラー映画にしたら怖くもなんともない、むしろちょっとコメディーっぽいかも。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As a horror movie, this is not scary at all. Matter of fact, it's more like a comedy movie.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はジェットコースターとかが苦手だから遊園地に行きたくもなんともない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I dislike roller coasters, I don't want to go to amusement parks at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼のことは聞きたくもなんともない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't want to hear about him at all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「噂なんて全然知りたくもなんともないけど。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I don't want to know any rumors at all.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「もうやめない？その話。面白くもなんともないから！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Won't you stop (talking about) that topic? Because it is not interesting at all!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この料理は美味しくもなんともないから、感想は何もない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This food is not delicious or anything at all, so I don’t have any impressions.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 悲しくもなんともないのに急に涙が出てきて混乱しています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am confused because, despite not being sad or anything like that, tears suddenly started pouring out.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 見たくもなんともないテレビ番組を見たら、予想通りつまらなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When I watched a TV show that I by no means wanted to watch, it was boring just I had predicted.

Name: (Verb) + だに
Meaning: Just, Even just, Even merely
About: As mentioned in our だに＋しない grammar point, だに is an adverbial particle that shares a similar meaning to さえ and すら 'even', but is more commonly found in classical literature. It presents (A) as 'minimum' or 'light' examples, and therefore implies that anything greater than (A) would be more than can be handled, imagined, etc. In this use, it is often translated as 'just (A)', or 'merely (A)'. だに will appear directly following verbs in their dictionary form. This is a formal structure, and will be seen far more often in literature than it will be spoken. Despite this, it is actually quite common in anime and manga when characters are being dramatic. As (A) presents a 'minimum', it will often be a word which expresses something that depicts the difference between reality and fantasy. For example, if (A) was 想像(そうぞう)するだに 'even in my imagination'. The 'minimum' is the imagination, for which the opposite end of the spectrum would be 'in reality'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんな地獄みたいな職場にまた明日も行かないとって考えるだに気が重くなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even just the thought of having to go back to that hellish workplace again tomorrow makes me feel depressed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼のことを思い出すだに、悲しくなります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Just remembering about him makes me sad.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 部長からもらった仕事の量を見るだに、やる気が失せる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I lose all motivation by just looking at the amount of work my boss gave me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「人間にとってはダニを食べるのは考えるだにおぞましい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'For a human being, just thinking about eating ticks is repulsive.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「クトゥルフは見るだに正気を失ってしまうほどたいへん恐ろしい化物であるらしい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'It is said that Cthulhu is a monster so awfully scary that one goes mad just by seeing it.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「その映画のワンシーンを思い出すだに、胸が痛くなります。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'Just recalling that movie scene breaks my heart.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「ただ、その事故の話を聞くだに古傷が疼く。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'Just hearing a conversation about that accident makes my old wound throb with pain.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「太陽の中心の温度は想像するだに恐ろしい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'Just imagining the temperature at the center of the sun is terrifying.'

Name: ～なり～なり
Meaning: Or, Either or
About: When the classical adverbial particle なり is used in lists, it expresses that each item within that list is a possibility, but that one particular thing will be or needs to be chosen. This use of なり will indicate that either (A) or (B) is fine, but anything else that falls within that same category is probably fine too. Due to this, it is non-exhaustive. なり is a fairly polite construction and will appear after either verbs in their dictionary forms, or nouns that may or may not be followed by another particle. This is in cases where that particle is giving important information involved in the 'choice'. An example of this would be に for marking a location. As with all adverbial particles, なり cannot follow either が or を.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もうちょっと待機しないといけなさそうだから、タバコを吸うなり弁当食べるなりして待ってな。準備ができたら呼ぶからゆっくりしてな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems like we have to wait a little longer, so why don't you go smoke some cigarettes or eat your lunch and wait. Once everything is ready, I'll let you know so take your time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうぞ受け取ってください。いらないなら売るなり捨てるなりしてもらっても結構ですので。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Please take this. If you don't want it you can sell it or throw it away.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 遅れるなら電話なりメールなりするのが社会人としての常識じゃないのか？！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Isn't it common sense as a member of society to call or text if you are going to be late?!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なんでお前はいつもそう一人でなんでも解決しようとするんだ？俺になり高橋になり相談してくれればいいのに！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Why do you always try to solve everything on your own? You should come talk to me or Takahashi!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ヨーロッパなら、フランスなりイタリアなり、料理が美味しいところに行きたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it’s Europe, whether it’s France or Italy, I want to go to a place with delicious food.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 完璧な人はいない。大なり小なり欠点はあるものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Nobody is perfect. To either a greater or lesser extent, we all have faults.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ご飯にするなり運動するなり好きにすればいいけど、早く寝なさいよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Do whatever you want whether it is eating or doing exercise, but please go to sleep early.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女が彼氏に：「電話なり何なりで、早く連絡しなさいよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Girlfriend to boyfriend: 'Contact me as soon as possible, by phone or something.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お母さん：「私じゃなくて、お姉ちゃんなりお兄ちゃんなりに質問して！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mother: ‘Rather than me, ask your sister or brother!’

Name: ないでもない
Meaning: Kind of, Might, Slightly, It’s not (impossible) that, Somewhat, In some respects
About: ないでもない, and なくもない are structures that have the literal meaning of 'to not not be (A)', and are used to express that something is 'a little (A)', or 'kinda (A)'. These structures are used primarily when the speaker can neither confirm or deny (A), but may also be used simply when not wanting to directly disagree with something that another person has said. Both ないでもない and なくもない may be used after either the negated form of verbs, or nouns followed by the case marking particle が. ないでもない and なくもない are completely interchangeable, with the primary difference simply being that なくもない is less frequently used. Additionally,  ないものでもない may also be seen, but just like なくもない, it is far less common.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あいつが悪いとは思わないでもないけど、お前にも少しは非があると思うよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I kind of think he is in the wrong, but I think you are a little at fault too.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まあ、そう言われてみれば鳥に見えなくもないけど...
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well, when you put it like that, it kind of looks like a bird…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女が謝ってきたら、彼女がしたことを許す気がないでもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If she comes apologizing, I might forgive her for what she's done.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ピアノを弾くのは好きだが、ピアノのレッスンをやめようと思うことがなくもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like to play the piano, but there are times when I kind of think about quitting piano lessons.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あなたの考えが分からないものでもないけど、そういうことはあまり口に出さないほうがいいと思うよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I kind of understand your opinion, but I don't think you should say things like that out loud.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あなたの考えが分からないでもないけど、反対するね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I kind of understand what you’re thinking, but I object.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パクチーは食べられないでもないけどさ、食べるとウッてなるんだよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It’s not that I can’t eat coriander, but if I eat it, I feel like I am gonna hurl.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この洋服、着られないでもないけど、やっぱりキツイなぁ〜。
Questions.EnglishHTML: These clothes, it’s not that I can’t wear them, but they really are tight.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: トイレに行きたい気がしないでもないけど、まだ並ばなくてもいいかな…。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I kind of feel like going to the toilet, but it’s probably fine if we don’t line up yet...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このブランドのあのバッグは１０万円？！買えないでもないけど、勇気が出ないなぁ〜。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That bag from this brand is $1,000?! It’s not that I can’t buy it, but I can’t muster up the courage to get it.

Name: もさることながら
Meaning: It is a fact that, But, Even more than, It goes without saying, Not only but also,
About: もさることながら is a construction in Japanese that is often translated as 'it goes without saying that (A), but (B)', or 'not only (A), but (B) too'. This expression is a combination of the adverbial particle も, the pre-noun adjectival さる 'particular', or 'certain', the noun 事(こと) 'thing', and the conjunction particle ながら 'while'. Due to this, the more literal translation is simply 'while (A) is also of particular merit, (B)'. This literal translation will be helpful to remember, as もさることながら will always present (A) as important, but (B) as even more important than that. もさることながら will be attached to the end of nouns and noun phrases. As (B) is being emphasized in sentences that use this grammar structure, it is common to see other expressions of emphasis combined with もさることながら. Some examples include さらに 'additionally', なにより 'more than anything', and 以上(いじょう) 'above that'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのブランドが出す商品もさることながら、マーケティングも素晴らしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is a fact that the products that the brand produces are amazing, but also how they market them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このパソコンは機能もさることながら、デザインもいい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is a fact that the features of this computer are good, but so is the design.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語を勉強するにおいて漢字もさることながら、文法も勉強しなくてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When it comes to studying Japanese, it is a fact that you need to study not only kanji, but also grammar too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: モナ・リザは美しい画もさることながら、やはり目を引くのは神秘的な微笑である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is a fact that Mona Lisa is a beautiful painting, but it is the mysterious smile that attracts the attention after all.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日頃の心がけもさることながら、今回は運が味方してくれたようだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even more than my usual efforts, it would seem luck was on my side this time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 見た目もさることながら性格も素晴らしい彼がモテるのは当然のことです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It’s only natural that he’s popular, given that not only his appearance but also his personality is wonderful.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 歌詞もさることながらメロディーもいいのだから、この曲はやっぱり最高だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even more than the lyrics, since the melody is good too, this song is really the best.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 美味しさもさることながら見た目も凄いこのフレンチレストランは、大人気です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: While it is a fact that the food is delicious, since the look of this French restaurant is awesome too, it’s super popular.

Name: ものと思(おも)っていた
Meaning: Was under the impression that, (Always) the thought used to think
About: 物(もの)と思(おも)う is made up of the noun 物(もの) 'thing', the case marking particle と, and the う-Verb 思(おも)う 'to think'. Regular translations include 'to believe that (A)', or 'to have confidence that (A)'. In a broader sense, this grammar pattern is just making use of one of the meanings of 物(もの) as being something abstract that the speaker can reliably determine has all of the qualities of something concrete. When 思(おも)う appears in the past tense as ものと思(おも)っていた, the most common translation is 'as I had believed was true of (A)', or 'I was under the impression that (A)'. As もの is a noun, this pattern may follow any word in its attributive form. As ものと思(おも)っていた highlights an impression of something that was true, contradictory statements will often appear in part (B) of the sentence following structures like が or けど.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: え...まだ晩御飯食べてないの？てっきり帰りに食べてくるものと思っていたから、あなたの分は作ってないですよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What… You haven't eaten dinner yet? I was totally under the impression that you were going to grab something on the way back home, so I did not make anything for you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の母は猫が好きではないものと思っていたが、聞いてみたらただ猫アレルギーがあるそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was under the impression that my mother did not like cats, but after asking her, I found out that it's just that she is allergic to them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ゲートボールは老人しかやらないものと思っていたが、最近は若者の間で流行っているらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was under the impression that gateball was something only old people played, but it seems to be popular among young people these days.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: てっきり漢字を学ぶのは退屈なものと思っていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was under the impression that learning kanji would be boring. (But it is not)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 犬は怖いものと思っていたけど、飼ってみたら思ったより優しかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was under the impression that dogs were scary, but after I tried taking care of one, they turned out to be more gentle than I had thought.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お母さんに怒られるものと思っていたが怒られず、拍子抜けした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was under the impression that my mum was angry, but she wasn’t angry, so it was an anticlimax.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供の頃、森の中で迷った。てっきりこのまま死ぬものと思っていた。（が救われた）
Questions.EnglishHTML: When I was a child, I lost my way in the forest. I was under the impression that I would die like this. (But I was saved)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 面接に合格するものと思っていたが不合格となり、愕然としている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I was under the impression that I had passed the interview, but since I failed I am astounded.

Name: でなくてなんだろう
Meaning: If … is not … then what is?
About: でなくてなんだろう is a formal pattern that appears following nouns that the speaker is certain is something which is true. It can be translated as 'if it's not (A), then what is it?'. でなくてなんだろう is a combination of the conjunctive form of the auxiliary verb だ, で, the conjunctive form of the い-Adjective ない, なくて, the prefix なん 'what', and the volitional form of だ, だろう. As can be seen, the literal and common translations are quite similar. Occasionally でなくてなんだろう will be followed by the sentence-ending particle か. This just emphasizes the point further, without changing the nuance. In most cases, でなくてなんだろう will be used to ask a rhetorical question, or to strongly assert the speaker's own opinion about something.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの子が新しいってだけでいじめられている。あれはパワハラでなくてなんだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She is getting bullied just because she is new. If that is not power harassment, then what is?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺はこんなに夜遅くまでタダ働きをしている。俺は社畜でなくてなんだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am working late for free. If I am not a corporate slave, then what is?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の家だけ浸水しなかった。これが奇跡でなくてなんだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My house was the only one that did not get submerged. If this is not a miracle, then what is?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 説明欄には新品だと書いてあったのに届いた商品は傷だらけだった。これは詐欺でなくてなんだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In the description, it was written that it was brand new, but the product that arrived was covered in scratches. If this is not a scam, then what is?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 注射を打った後にすぐ亡くなった…これがワクチンのせいでなくてなんだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: They died straight after they got a shot... If this isn’t the vaccine’s fault, then what is it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 勉強しなかったのにテストで１００点をとるとは！天才でなくてなんだろう！
Questions.EnglishHTML: To think that despite not studying you got 100 points on the test! If that’s not genius, then what is?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まさか扉が勝手に開くとは…これが心霊現象でなくてなんだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To think that the door would open by itself... If this isn’t a psychic phenomenon, then what is?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ずっと一緒に寄り添いたいと思うこの気持ちが愛でなくてなんだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If this feeling of always wanting to snuggle up close together isn’t love, then what is it?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 頼れる家族がいて仲のいい友達がいて愛する恋人がいて…これが幸せでなくてなんだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Having a reliable family, close friends, and a partner that you love... If this isn’t happiness, then what is?

Name: はさておき
Meaning: (Leaving or putting) aside, Apart
About: はさておき is an expression which is often translated as 'leaving aside (A)', or 'apart from (A)'. It is a combination of the adverbial particle は, the conjunction さて 'now' (moving on to a new thing), and the conjunctive form of 置(お)く 'to place', or 'to leave', 置(お)き. The more literal 'now putting aside (A)' may also be used. This structure will be used when (A) is a topic that the speaker would like to move away from, in order to discuss something more important. はさておき will primarily directly follow nouns. However, it is also common to see はさておき following a phrase that ends with かどうか. This can be translated as 'disregarding whether it is (A) or not, (B)', and will imply that (B) is a more appropriate topic, so (A) should be moved on from.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: みんなの感想はさておき、私は美味しいと思ったよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Aside from everyone else's opinions, I thought that it was delicious.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなことはさておき、仕事をちゃちゃっと終わらせて早く帰りましょうよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That aside, let's quickly finish work and go home.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語に自信があるかどうかはさておき、一人で行ったことのない国へ行くのには勇気がいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether I am confident in Japanese or not, going to a country you haven't been to alone takes some courage.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女がいるかいないかはさておき、普段から清潔にしていたほうがいいと思うよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Regardless of whether you have a girlfriend or not, you should be hygienic.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冗談はさておき、そろそろ会議を始めよう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Jokes aside, let's start the meeting soon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それはさておき、会議の本題に移りましょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Putting that aside, let’s move to the main topic of the conference.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 冗談はさておき、そろそろ真面目にミーティングをしないと。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Jokes aside, we better get this meeting underway seriously.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この映画は内容はさておき、映像のクオリティは最高でした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Putting aside the content of this movie, the quality of the picture is superb.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 品質はさておき、この商品のデザインはどこよりも優れています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Putting aside the quality, the design of this product is better than anywhere else.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 目が悪いことはさておき、それ以外は僕の体は完璧だと言ってもいい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Apart from that my eyes are bad; you could say that the rest of my body is perfect.

Name: 折(おり)には
Meaning: When, Occasion, Opportunity, Time
About: When the noun 折(おり) 'fold' or 'pleat' is used adverbially with the case marking particle に, it indicates a time which may be used as an opportunity to do something. It is often translated as 'on the occasion of (A)', or 'when the chance of (A) comes up'. It is an expression that is primarily used as a formal, positive alternative for 時(とき)に, but there are times that it may indicate something negative. 折(おり)に may be seen after any structure that could connect to a noun, but will primarily appear after verbs in their standard forms, or nouns followed by の. Additionally, 折(おり)に may occasionally appear as 折(おり)には, but the additional は is often omitted. In most cases, 折(おり)に will be used to indicate things that happen 'from time to time', rather than one off events.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こちらの旅館にいらっしゃる折には、事前の予約をお願いいたします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the occasion that you visit our ryokan, please make a reservation in advance.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今度お会いした折に、旅行へ行った時のお土産をお渡しします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When the chance comes up that we meet again soon, I'll give you the present that I got when I went on a trip.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 卒業の折に担任の先生に手紙を渡そうと思っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the opportunity of my graduation, I am thinking that I'd like to give a letter to the teacher that was looking after me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: メール、本社の上司に：「お暇な折にぜひ我が支店にお越しください。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: E-mail to a superior from the head office: 'Please, make sure to come to our branch when you are free.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 手紙：「新春のお支度にお忙しい折から、風邪などひかれぬようご自愛下さい。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Letter: 'Please take care not to catch a cold at this busy time of preparations for a new year.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お近くにいらっしゃる折には、ぜひうちにご飯を食べに来てください！
Questions.EnglishHTML: On the chance that you will be close by, you’re certainly welcome to come to my place to eat!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 宴会をする折には、ぜひうちの居酒屋をご利用くださいませ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: On the occasion of having a banquet gathering, you’re certainly welcome to make use of our izakaya.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: オーストラリアへ来る折には、ぜひカンガルーのお肉を食べてみてください。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At the opportunity of coming to Australia, certainly try eating kangaroo meat.

Name: とばかりに
Meaning: As if (to say), Seeming that
About: とばかり is a construction that is often used to show that something is being done 'as if to say (A)', or 'seeming that (A)'. It is a combination of the case-marking particle と in its 'quotation' use, and the adverbial particle ばかり, exhibiting that something is 'basically exactly as described'. Due to this, とばかり simply indicates that while (A) is as described, it is not literally the case. とばかり can appear after almost any word, as the と is creating a quote. に will often follow ばかり when the sentence is going on to describe what is actually happening. とばかりに is an abbreviation of と言(い)わんばかり 'to only just not be at the point where (A) is said', which itself will still be seen quite often. In this case, 言(い)わん is an abbreviation of 言(い)わぬ, making use of the classical auxiliary verb ぬ used for negation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 中田選手のバランスが崩れたので、斉藤選手はチャンスとばかりに中田選手の太ももを蹴った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since Nakata's balance was disrupted, Saito, seeing it as a chance, kicked Nakata's thigh.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: うちのわんちゃんが「待ってました」とばかりに尻尾を振って友達に飛びついた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Our dog wagged his tail and jumped onto my friend as if to say 'I have been waiting'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生が「俺の話聞いてるか」とばかりに生徒たちを睨みつけた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The teacher stared at the students as if to say 'Are you listening to me'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 早くしろと言わんばかりに上司が何回も「まだ？」って聞いてきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My boss repeatedly asked me, 'Are you done?' as if to say 'hurry up'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: つまらないと言わんばかりの顔でみられたから、話すのをやめた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: They were looking at me as if they were bored, so I stopped talking.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ランナーが通り、ここぞとばかりに声援を送りました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The runner passed, and as if to say ‘Now’s the time!’, I let out a cheer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「おまえも黙れ」とばかりに手でテーブルを叩いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: She slammed the table with her hand as if to say 'Silence!'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 盗賊たちが待っていたとばかりに通行人を止めたのです！
Questions.EnglishHTML: As if they had been waiting, the robbers stopped the passersby!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 桜は、今この時を待っていたとばかりに花びらを広げています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Seeming that they had been waiting for this time right now, the petals of the cherry blossoms spread.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 社長に呆れたとばかりにため息をつかれて、クビを覚悟しました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Being sighed at by the president as if to say he was exasperated, I readied myself to be fired.

Name: わ〜わ
Meaning: ~and ~and, Keep ~ing, One after another, So much, So many, One after the other
About: わ is an adverbial particle that is commonly used in cases of stress of emphasis in Japanese. When appearing after the dictionary form of a verb that is being repeated, it highlights a large amount, something happening successively, or more and more. It will often be translated as 'more and more (A)', '(A) keeps on happening', or 'so much (A)'. わ～わ may be used either positively or negatively. To use this structure, simply place わ after the verb, and then repeat the same verb with a second わ. わ～わ primarily emphasizes the speaker's surprise in regard to the amount or extent of (A). This structure is predominantly used by men, but it may also sometimes be used by women. However, there are several different variations of わ depending on where they appear in sentences, each of which have gender usage tendencies that will need to be learned. In many cases where a する verb is being used with わ～わ, the second instance of the action will be omitted, with する appearing by itself. For example, instead of 勉強(べんきょう)するわ勉強(べんきょう)するわ, 勉強(べんきょう)するわするわ would be used.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もう、昨日子供達が喧嘩して泣くわ泣くわで大変だったんだから。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Oh my god, it was so hectic yesterday because the kids got into a fight and cried so much.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 空き家を買ったのはいいけど、家中にはゴキブリがいるわいるわ。多分自分じゃ何もできないから業者に頼むしかなさそう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bought a vacant house, and that's exciting, but there are so many cockroaches all over the house. I probably won't be able to do anything myself, so I will have to call someone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の息子なんて、部活を始めてからというもの食べるわ食べるわ、食費が心配だよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ever since my son has started after school activities, he eats so much that I am worried about the cost of food.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの子は医者になりたいって決めてから、毎日勉強するわするわ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ever since he has decided that he wants to be a doctor, he studies a lot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「病院に入院してた時、いろいろ検査したらまあ、出るわ出るわ…（思った以上のことが指摘された）。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'When I was in the hospital, they did various tests and, well, they just kept coming up...' （the results that were worse than expected）

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「新婚旅行から戻ったらメールボックスには郵便物があるわあるわ、つかえてしまって引っ張ることができなかった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'When we got back from our honeymoon, there was so much mail in the mailbox that it was stuck and I couldn't pull it out.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「子供が転んで泣くわ泣くわ。なだめるの大変だった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Our child fell and cried so much that it was hard to calm her down.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「先輩は面白いのなんのって喋ると笑うわ笑うわ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Senpai is so funny, that I laugh so much whenever he talks.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「ちょっとからかっただけで、あいつ怒るわ怒るわ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'He gets so angry just by teasing him a bit.'

Name: なりとも
Meaning: Even (a little), At least
About: なりとも is a classical Japanese expression which is used to show a minimal degree of something, often with a nuance of concession. It is commonly translated as 'at least' or 'even', and is typically used in very polite or formal speech. Grammatically, なりとも will come directly after a noun. なりとも can carry a humble, and sometimes even pleading, tone. It is often used when making requests. Because なりとも is slightly old-fashioned and stiff in tone, it will not often be used in daily conversation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 多少なりとも毎日勉強することはいいことだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if it is a little, it is a good thing to study everyday.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このようなことは一度なりともやったことはないですが、頑張ってみます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We have never done something like this, not even once, but we will try our best.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このおむつ交換ステーションのご利用の場合、お子様から一時なりともお目を離さずご利用ください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When using this diaper changing station, please do not leave your child unattended for even a moment.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 急いでいるのは承知ですが、熱中症で倒れそうなので、わずかなりとも休憩をいただいてもよろしいですか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I know you are in a hurry, but may I have a short break as I feel like I am going to collapse from heat stroke?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩今鹿児島にいるんですか？時間があったら、一目なりとも会いたいです！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Senpai, you are in Kagoshima right now? If you have time I’d like to see you, even for a short time!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 母さんに一目なりとも会いたいから、夕方そっち行くね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Hey mom, I wanna see you even if it’s brief, so I’m gonna head there this afternoon.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君に迷惑をかけるぐらいなら、自分なりともできることを全部やってみるよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it is to the extent that it is causing you bother then I will try and do what I can in at least my own way.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 近くまで来たなら、声なりともかけてくれてよかったのに。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you came so close, I wish you would have at least called out to me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ご意見なりともいただければ幸いです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I would be happy to receive at least some feedback.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 詳細は後日でも構いませんが、現段階での決定事項なりとも先に教えていただけると助かります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It’s no problem if the details come at a later date, but at this point it would be helpful if you could share at least the decisions with me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 遅かれ早かれ、誰かなりとも真実に気づくときが来るだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Sooner or later, at least someone will come to realize the truth.

Name: に至(いた)っても
Meaning: Even when
About: In contrast to に至(いた)っては, which presents the most extreme examples for something from within a specific category. に至(いた)っても will present the same extreme example from which some result will not occur. This is due to the adverbial particle も 'even' replacing は. に至(いた)っても may be translated as 'even if it came to (A), (B)', 'even when (A), (B)'. (B) will often be negative, thus highlighting that even the extreme (A) couldn't affect (B). This is a combination of the case-marking particle に, the て-form of the る-Verb 至(いた)る 'to climax', or 'to culminate in', and the adverbial particle も. に至(いた)っても will appear following nouns, or verbs in their dictionary form. に至(いた)っても will often be used when the speaker laments or regrets that despite reaching the point of (A), (B) is something that will still not, or did not change. However, it may occasionally be used positively, especially when the speaker is expressing their determination.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの事故に巻き込まれてから２年経つに至っても、相手は謝罪すらもしてこない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even now, 2 years since I have been involved in an accident, and the other party has not even apologized.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社会人になるに至っても、まだ自分が子供だと思っている人は少なくないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even as people become a functioning member of society, there are probably a lot of people that think they are still kids.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼と別れて３年経った現在に至っても、男の人を信用することができない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even now, 3 years after I broke up with him, I still have a hard time trusting men.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この会議は朝方に至っても、続きそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This meeting seems like it is going to continue, even if it becomes morning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これは俺が決めたことだから、どんな結果に至っても、絶対に後悔しない！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This is something I have decided on, so I will not regret the result even if it's bad.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は病院に来るに至っても、まだ治療をすることを拒否していた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even now when he will come to the hospital, he was still refusing getting medical treatment.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 就業時間を過ぎるに至っても、この会議は終わりそうにありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even now when work hours will pass, this meeting is showing no signs of ending.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 結婚するに至っても、完全にお互いを理解し合えないカップルが多い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Many couples can't understand each other completely even when they are about to get married.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「だが、事ここに至っても、まだ謝ることを拒否するほど頑固である」。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'However, even when things have come to this, he is still obstinate to the point that he refuses to apologize.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事：「首相は政府の腐敗を暴露されるに至っても、まだ詳細情報を隠し通そうとしていた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'Even when the corruption of the government was exposed, the prime minister still tried to hide the details.'

Name: を兼(か)ねて
Meaning: And also, Also (partly) to, Also (partly) for (the purpose of), At the same time, To double as, When … also, While … as well, And as
About: を兼(か)ねて is a grammar pattern that makes use of the standard meaning of the る-Verb 兼(か)ねる 'to stretch across to', or 'to do concurrently'. The adverbial particle を will mark a noun which will be considered the secondary event or state, while 兼(か)ねて will be followed by the primary event or state that will be done concurrently with (A). This is often translated as 'to (A) at the same time as (B)', 'to double as (A)', or 'to (A) also partly for the purpose of (B)'. を兼(か)ねて often highlights (B) as the primary goal, where (A) is something that acts to support it, makes sense to be done together, or just gives the speaker a good excuse to do (B). In order to remember that (A) is actually the secondary goal in this structure, using the literal translation of 'while extending across to (A), (B)' may help. In the case of multiple goals existing, the case-marking particle と will be used for listing of nouns.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: おばあちゃんはボケ防止を兼ねて、毎日クロスワードパズルをしています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My grandma does crossword puzzles also partly to prevent dementia.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本語の勉強を兼ねて、英語の字幕なしで日本の映画をみています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I watch Japanese movies without subtitles also partly to learn Japanese.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ダイエットを兼ねて、毎朝ランニングしています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I run everyday also partly to lose weight.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運動不足とストレス発散を兼ねて、キックボクシングジムに通っている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go to a kickboxing gym also partly to relieve stress and to get exercise.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 体調管理と節約を兼ねて、寝る時はエアコンを使わないようにしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I sleep, I try not to use the air conditioner also partly for my health and to save money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ダイエットを兼ねて、スポーツジムに通っています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I go to the gym also (partly) to lose weight.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語の勉強を兼ねて、日本のゲームをしています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I play Japanese games also (partly) to learn the language.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: リスニングの練習を兼ねて、日本語の曲を聞くことにしています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Doubling as listening practice, I decided to listen to Japanese songs.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 散歩を兼ねて隣町まで歩いて買い物に行きました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I walked to the neighboring town to do some shopping and (partly) for a stroll as well.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小遣い稼ぎを兼ねて趣味で同人誌を描いている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I draw doujinshi as a hobby and also (partly) for extra money.

Name: ないものだろうか
Meaning: (Why) can’t, Isn’t there, Wish that, If only
About: When paired with negative expressions, the noun 物(もの) and either the sentence-ending particle か or a combination of だろう and か will indicate that the speaker wishes (A) were possible, but for some reason it is beyond their immediate capacity. This structure may be translated as 'if only (A)', or 'isn't there a way to (A)', but the literal translation is closer to 'I wonder if it really is a thing that can't (A)'. This grammar pattern will primarily be seen attached to the negated form of verbs, but may also be used in reference to nouns when the ない is being used to indicate a lack of existence of (A), rather than a lack of ability to do (A). As can be seen in these examples, the polite でしょう may replace だろう. Additionally, similar structures such as かな or かしら may replace だろうか or でしょうか in more casual conversations.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これはもっとシンプルにできないものか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Can't this be made to be more simple?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こっちから言わないとやって貰えないものだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Can't you do it for me without me telling you to?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 難しいのはわかっているんですが、佐々木さんの腕でなんとかできないものでしょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am aware that it is difficult, but can't something not be done with your skills?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事をもう少し楽にする方法はないものか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Is there no way to make work a little easier?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もっと楽にお金を稼げる仕事はないものだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder if there are any jobs where I can earn money easier.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これよりもっと燃費がいい車はないものでしょうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Are there no cars that have better mileage than this one?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ダイエットのモチベーションがもっと上がらないものだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is there no way to raise my motivation more for my diet?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電気自動車の値段はもう少し安くできないものだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Can't electric cars's price be a bit lower?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日傘はもっと畳みやすく、そして風に強くならないものだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Is there no way to make a sun umbrella that is more easily collapsible and strong against the wind?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人間は食べ物を食べなくても生きるようにならないものだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If only humans could become able to live without eating food.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ブログ：「詐欺まがいなオンラインショップのことはどうにかならないものだろうか。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Blog: 'Can't something be done about the fraudulent online shops?'

Name: ～て見(み)せる
Meaning: I will definitely, I will certainly, Just watch, Whatever it takes, I swear, for sure
About: て見(み)せる, primarily written in hiragana, is an emphatic structure that indicates that the speaker is going to do (A) in a way that it is clear to the listener. This can be translated as 'I will definitely (A)', or 'I swear I will (A)', but the literal translation of 'I will show you that I'll do (A)' also makes the point clear. To use てみせる, simply alter the verb preceding it into its て-form. Due to みせる requiring a target for who the speaker is showing, this grammar pattern will only be used when there is either directly someone that will be shown (A), or when the speaker is talking about showing someone (A) that does not happen to be there at the moment either physically or temporally. It will not be used when simply strongly stating that you will do (A), unless who sees that (A) is important. In a sentence like this, where the person being shown is not obvious, it will come across as 'I'll show everyone'. As て見(み)せる literally just means to 'show (A)', it will often be used without any special emphasis. Whether it is being used emphatically or not will usually be obvious from the overall context of the sentence.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前のために、次の試合では勝ってみせる！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will definitely win the next competition for you!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来週のテストで合格してみせる！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will definitely pass the test next week!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 足が痛いけど、完走してみせる！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My legs hurt, but I am definitely going to finish the race!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「何があっても、必ずファンの期待に応えて見せます！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'No matter what happens, I will definitely live up to my fans' expectations!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ピアニスト：「この曲を明日までに弾きこなしてみせる！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Pianist: ‘I will definitely be able to play this song well by tomorrow!’

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「今年こそ、必ず運転免許を取って見せるよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I will definitely get a drivers license this year!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「どんな手を使ってでも、絶対、成功して見せる！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I will definitely win, no matter what it takes!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 妻を喜ばせるような美味しい料理を作ってみせる！
Questions.EnglishHTML: I will make delicious food that my wife will be thankful for, just watch!

Name: 相(あい)まって
Meaning: Combined with, Coupled with, Together with
About: 相(あい)まって is a structure used for showing that (A) and (B) are things that will perform some sort of synergistic task in order to achieve the result of (C). In many cases, either (A) or (B) alone could achieve (C), but their combined action will bring about a better result. This structure is a combination of 相(あい), 'mutual', or 'reciprocal', and the て-form of the う-Verb 俟(ま)つ 'to wait on'. In this pattern, both (A) and (B) will often come before 相(あい)まって, with either of the case-marking particles と or が being used after the nouns. Common translations include '(A) combined with (B) will (C)', or 'coupled together with (A), (B) will (C)'. As for a literal translation, 'mutually depending on each other, (C)' is fairly close to the exact nuance. See the fun-fact for more about this.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの古い屋敷は霧と相まって不気味な雰囲気を出しています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That old mansion, combined with the fog, creates an eerie atmosphere.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ツイッターでの流行と相まって、この漫画は若者の間ではすごく人気だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Combined with its popularity on Twitter, this manga is very popular among young people.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このステーキはシェフ特製のソースが相まって、とても美味しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This steak is very tasty, coupled with the chef's special sauce.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: クライアントのアイデアと私たちの努力が相まって、とてもいいイベントを開催することができた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The client's ideas, combined with our efforts, resulted in us being able to host a very good event.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 感動的なシーンとＢＧＭが相まって、泣かずにはいられませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The moving scene coupled with the background music made it impossible not to cry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 腹痛と頭痛が相まって、まるで生きている心地がしませんでした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Stomach pain combined with a headache made it completely uncomfortable just to live.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「夕暮れが虹と相まって空をある種のキャンディーのように見せた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'Twilight combined with a rainbow made the sky look like some sort of candy.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 気温の高さと湿度の高さが相まって、日本の夏は地獄みたいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The air temperature combined with the humidity in Japan makes summer like hell.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 値段の安さと質の良さが相まって、この商品は売れに売れている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The cheap price together with the good quality of this product is making it sell one after the other.

Name: に足(た)りない
Meaning: To not be worthy, To not be enough, To not be sufficient, To lack
About: に足(た)りない is a grammar expression appearing after the dictionary form of verbs used to indicate that something is 'not worth (A)', or 'not sufficient for (A)'. It comes from a combination of the case-marking particle に, and the る-Verb 足(た)りる 'to be sufficient', or 'to be enough'. This structure is formal, so will mostly be used in literature or formal speech settings. While に足(た)りない may be similar to another grammar point, に足(た)る, in that they are conversely pointing out the worth, or lack of worth of something, they are actually different verbs. 足(た)る is an う-Verb, and is often used more in literature, or in western Japan. This means that the negative form of 足(た)る is 足(た)らない, not 足(た)りない.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は陰謀論者だから、あの人のいうことは信じるに足りない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is a conspiracy theorist so nothing he says is worth believing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人は自分を良くみせるためだったら、すぐに自分の失敗を人のせいにするから、彼は信頼するに足りない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He will blame others for his own mistakes, just to make himself look good, so he is not worth trusting.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ブランド物のバッグをリサイクルショップに売りに行ったけど、買取の金額が売るに足りない金額だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I went to sell a designer brand bag to a secondhand store, but the purchase price was not enough for me to sell it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 周りから見ると取るに足りない、ただのゴミだが、私にとっては大切なコレクションの一部だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: From the perspective of the people around me, it's nothing but a worthless piece of garbage, but to me they are an important part of my collection.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この部品は取るに足らない物のように見えるかもしれないが、これが壊れたら、この機械は動かなくなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This component may seem insignificant, but if it breaks, this machine will stop working.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ロジャー・キントの言葉は一つとして信じるに足りないことだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not even one word of Roger Kint is worth believing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんな稚拙な感想文なんて、発表するに足りないですよ…。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Such a crude opinion piece is not worthy of publishing, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自慢するに足りないテストの点数で、しょんぼりとしている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am feeling dejected because of a test score that is not worthy of being proud about.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは因果応報というやつだから、彼女には同情するに足りません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because this is what you'd call karma, it is not worth sympathizing with her.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 信じるに足りないデタラメを信じてしまうような人が心配でならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can’t help worry about the type of person that trusts rubbish that is not worthy of trusting.

Name: べからず
Meaning: Do not, Must not, Should not, Cannot (べからざる)
About: べからず, and べからざる are two formal expressions used to convey the meaning of 'must not (A)', or 'ought not to (A)'. It is a combination of the helper-conjugation form of the auxiliary verb べし, べから, and the classical auxiliary verb ず 'not'. ざる itself is just the helper-conjugation form of ず, meaning that the nuance remains exactly the same. In this way, we can see that the literal meaning of 'ought not (A)' exhibits some sort of moral or logical obligation, as is true for all uses of べき derived patterns. べからず and べからざる will be seen following verbs in their dictionary forms. べからざる will be followed by a noun, indicating that the noun is being modified by the phrase. In modern Japanese, the meanings of both of these grammar patterns have shifted slightly from 'obligation', to simply having a strong nuance of 'don't (A)'. In addition to this, they will almost only ever be used on signs or notices.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ことわざ：「初心忘れるべからず。」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Proverb: 'Do not forget beginner's humility.'

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この施設内ではスケートボードなどのことをするべからず。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must not skateboard or anything similar in this facility.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 配達員を装って玄関のドアを開けさせるのは、許すべからざる行為だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Making someone open the door, by pretending to be a delivery person is an act that is not to be forgiven.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 吸うべからざる場所でタバコを吸っているのを見られたら、１０００円払うことになります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you are seen smoking in an area where you must not smoke, you will end up having to pay 1000 yen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 空気は生きるに欠くべからざるものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Air is essential to life. (Must not lack air)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ちゃんと稼いでいない人はご馳走など食うべからず。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Those who are not sufficiently earning should not eat treated food.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 池の鯉に餌をあげるべからず！鯉が増え過ぎてしまいます！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Do not feed the koi in the pond! They will multiply too much!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 公園の看板：「芝生にゴミ捨てるべからず」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A signboard at the park: 'Do not dump rubbish on the lawn'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ブログ記事：「英語で上手にフォーマルな手紙を書くための『べし・べからず』集」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Blog post: 'Dos and Don'ts for writing a formal letter in English skillfully.'

Name: んばかりに
Meaning: As if, As if it were about to, About to
About: Like とばかりに, んばかりに is a construction that is often used to show that something is being done 'as if it were (A)', or 'seeming that it will (A)'. It is thought to be a combination of ん, an abbreviation of む, the classical auxiliary verb used to show intent or strong will in the same way as う and よう, and the adverbial particle ばかり, exhibiting that something is 'basically exactly as described'. As a result, んばかり simply indicates the volitional form of (A) as appearing to be about to happen. んばかりに will appear linked to the indeterminate form of verbs (ない stem), and then followed by a statement that is being modified by the に. If んばかり will modify a noun instead, の will replace に.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 台風の風で、隣の空き家が崩れんばかりにギシギシ音を立てていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The vacant house next door was making creaking sounds as if it were to collapse because of the winds caused by the typhoon.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先生は「こっちを見ろ」って言わんばかりに、机を叩いた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The teacher slammed his desk as if to say, 'look this way'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このコンサート会場は溢れんばかりのファンで埋め尽くされている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The concert venue was filled, as if it was about to overflow with fans.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼が交通事故で亡くなったってことを聞いて、私は胸が張り裂けんばかりの気持ちになって、その場から動くことができなくなった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I heard that he had died in a car accident, I felt as if my heart was about to tear apart (heartbroken), and I could not move.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「割れんばかりの拍手に部屋は満たされた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'As if it were about to shatter, the room filled with thunderous applause.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 溢れんばかりのこの気持ちを、どうやったら伝えられるのでしょうか…。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This feeling that is about to overflow, just how do I convey it I wonder...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このトリックアートを見ていたら、今にも目が回らんばかりにフラフラしてきた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When I looked at this trick art, I felt lightheaded as if I were about to faint at this very moment.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 泣かんばかりに口をギュッと閉じている息子が、愛おしくてしかたがありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: How dear he looks, my son who has his mouth clenched as if he is about to cry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 殴りかからんばかりに体をワナワナと震わせている彼からソッと距離をおいた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I distance myself from him, whose body was trembling as if he was about to throw a punch.

Name: に則(のっと)って
Meaning: According to, In accordance with, Based on, In line with
About: に則(のっと)って is a formal expression used when something is being done 'according to (A)', or 'in line with (A)'. This is usually some basis, foundation, or standard which has a long running history. The case-marking particle に is being combined with the て-form of the う-Verb 則(のっと)る 'to follow along with' in this grammar pattern. Based on this, the literal meaning is just that (B) is something that follows along with (A). While several forms may be seen, the most common are a noun followed by にのっとって, or a noun followed by にのっとった which will then modify a second noun. Both the kanji form and the plain hiragana form are quite common, so it will be helpful to remember both. As (A) is generally considered to be something that has some kind of foundation. It will mostly represent a thing that has some kind of inception point from which point little, if anything, changed. Some examples are laws, traditions, standards, codes of conduct, etc.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どの国に行こうと、その国の法律に則って、生活しなくてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter what country you go to, you must live according to the laws of that country.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 芸能事務所の規則に則って、事務所に内緒で交際を始めたアイドルがクビになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In accordance with the rules of the production company, the idol that began to date without notifying the company got fired.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は無宗教なので、宗教にのっとった式はあげたくないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am not religious, so I do not want to have a ceremony based on religion.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: たとえ国のガイドラインにのっとった方法で物事を進めても、批判の声を上げる人は出てくる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if things are done in accordance with national guidelines, there will still be those who will voice criticism.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 全ての犯罪者は、法に則って裁かれるべきである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: All criminals should be tried in accordance with the law.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 伝統に則って、和装で結婚式を行いました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In accordance with tradition, the wedding ceremony was conducted in traditional Japanese attire.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先例に則って全てのことをしていては、改革などできない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If everything is always done in accordance with the initial steps, a reformation cannot happen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: もう古いやり方に則って全てのことを行うのはやめようではないか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Isn’t conducting everything based on the old way something that we should stop already?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 原則に則って、規則を破った社員は解雇されることとなりました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The staff member was fired, having broken a regulation in line with the precedence.

Name: (Adjective) + 限(かぎ)りだ
Meaning: Extremely, Really, Very, As ... as one can be
About: 限(かぎ)りだ is a structure that follows adjectives in order to indicate that something is 'extremely (A)', or 'as (A) as can be'. This grammar pattern is simply a mix of the noun 限(かぎ)り, 'limit', and the auxiliary verb だ, or です in the case of a polite sentence. Therefore, the literal meaning is just that something is 'the limit of (A)', where (A) is some describable feature. 限(かぎ)りだ will follow adjectives in their standard forms. 限(かぎ)りだ is a fairly formal grammar point that simply aims to highlight the intensity of traits as perceived by the speaker. As this perception is something coming from the speaker, the adjective itself will often be an emotion that the speaker themselves is experiencing, rather than a direct quality of the object, such as its color or shape. Some examples of this are as follows. 嬉(うれ)しい - The feeling of happiness, as experienced by the speaker. 頼(たの)もしい - The feeling of reliability, as experienced by the speaker. 羨(うらや)ましい - The feeling of jealousy, as experienced by the speaker. 寂(さみ)しい - The feeling of loneliness, as experienced by the speaker. 恥(は)ずかしい - The feeling of embarrassment, as experienced by the speaker. 心強(こころづよ)い - The feeling of reassurance, as experienced by the speaker. As can be seen in all of the examples. The intensity of the adjective is something that will change depending on one speaker to the next, rather than something that the target is doing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私のためにこんな素晴らしい送別会を開いてくれるなんて、嬉しい限りです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am very happy that you threw such an amazing farewell party for me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 宝くじで一等が当たったなんて、羨ましい限りだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Something like winning first place in a lottery is very enviable.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 一分遅れただけで不合格にされるなんて、残念な限りだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It's very disappointing that I failed just by being a minute late.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 同僚にあんなことを言われて、不快な限りです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm very offended that my colleague said something like that to me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: まあ、お子さんが結婚したの？羨ましい限りだわ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Oh, your child got married? I am as jealous as one could be!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コスタリカ旅行の抽選に当たったなんて、うらやましい限りだよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Something like winning a Costa Rica trip on the lottery is very enviable.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 狼人間が僕の味方なんて、心強い限りです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Something like having a werewolf as an ally is extremely reassuring.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 信頼していた子供に裏切られて、悲しい限りです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I am extremely sad, having been betrayed by the child I trusted.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供を先に亡くすなんて、本当に可哀想な限りだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Something like losing a child before you die, it is as pitiable as can be.

Name: は疎(おろ)か
Meaning: Let alone, Much less, Needless to say, Not to mention, Not only but also
About: は疎(おろ)か is an expression that works similarly to はもちろん 'of course (A), but (B)' in Japanese. 疎(おろ)か itself is a な-Adjective that means 'negligent', or 'alienation'. However, this use of 疎(おろ)か is not seen much in modern Japanese, and the word will mainly be used in set expressions where it doesn't behave exactly as a な-Adjective usually would. Despite this, the meaning of 'alienation', or 'completely removed from' is kept in はおろか, as it simply means 'completely putting aside (A), (B)'. Common translations include 'let alone (A), (B)', and 'it's needless to say that (A), when (B)'. (B) and (A) will usually be things that fall into the same category, where (B) is considered the far more obvious of the two. Due to this obviousness, (B) will often be immediately followed by the adverbial particle さえ. This shows that (B) is the noteworthy minimum extent. Alternatively, さえ may be exchanged with other adverbial particles that fill a similar purpose such a も, すら, or まで. In most cases, は疎(おろ)か sentences tend to have a fairly negative nuance.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は掃除はおろか、料理さえできない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He can't even cook, let alone clean.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はスーパーはおろか、コンビニさえもないど田舎に住んでいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I live in a very rural area where there isn't a convenience store, let alone a supermarket.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 父はパソコンはおろか、スマホさえも使うことができない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My father can't use a smartphone, let alone a computer.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「ルームメイトはオムライスは疎か、おにぎりさえ作れない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'My roommate cannot even make onigiri, let alone omurice.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 掃除機をかけることは疎か、彼はゴミ拾いさえしない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let alone turning on the vacuum cleaner, he won’t even pick up the trash.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パスタは疎かお米さえ食べるのをやめていたら痩せました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Let alone pasta, when I stopped eating even rice, I lost weight.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 貴重品は疎か、身につけていた服まで奪われてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not to mention my valuables, even the clothes off my back were stolen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今月の生活は疎か、今日でさえ生きていけるか分かりません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Much less living this month, I am not really even sure if I can live today.

Name: めく
Meaning: Like, To show signs of,  To have the appearance of, To come to a (state) similar to, Somewhat, An air of,  Feels almost like
About: めく is a fairly unique う-Verb in Japanese in that it will only be used as a suffix. This is due to its meaning of 'to show signs of (A)', or 'to have the appearance of (A)'. It will be attached to nouns that the speaker experiences to be the case. As めく itself is a verb, it may appear in several different conjugation forms depending on how it is describing the rest of the sentence. When connected directly to a second noun, the past-tense form めいた is most common. This 'that the speaker experiences to be the case' part is important, as めく will almost always highlight the speaker's own personal feelings in regard to (A), and how they perceive it. The thing being described as (A) will usually not actually be (A), and the speaker is often aware of this fact.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日までは嘘みたいに暑かったのに、やっと春めいてきた！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It has been hot until yesterday, but it's finally starting to become spring-like!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 冗談めいて言ったが、多分冗談だったということは気づいていないと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I said it like a joke, but I don't think they understood it as a joke.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 皮肉めいたことを言ってしまって、相手が黙り込んでしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I said something which sounded like sarcasm and the other person fell silent.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はなんか謎めいた雰囲気があるよね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She has a somewhat mysterious vibe, doesn't she?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 脅迫めいたメールが役所に届いたそうだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It seems a threatening sounding email was delivered to the city office.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 桜も咲いてすっかり春めいてきました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The cherry blossoms are blooming, and it starting to thoroughly show signs of being spring.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 作り物めいて見えるほど、平穏で美しい景色だった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It was calm and beautiful scenery, to the point of looking man-made.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 色めいた彼女の表情に、思わずドキッとしました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My heart skipped a beat when her expression showed signs of being amorous.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 芝居めいた彼のプレゼンには、あまり魅力を感じません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don’t feel any allure toward his presentation that feels almost like an act.

Name: と言(い)わず
Meaning: Not only A or B but every-; A, B and every-; Not only A or B but all over;  A, B both, whether A or B
About: When used in succession, と言(い)わず indicates that something is not limited to either (A) or (B), but applies to everything in a specific category or group. It may be translated as 'not just (A) or (B), but all', or '(A), (B) and everything else'. It is a combination of the case-marking particle と in its quotation use, the negative stem of 言(い)う, 言(い)わ, and the literary form of the classical auxiliary verb ぬ, ず. The literal translation is simply 'without saying (A), and without saying (B), (C)'. This 'without saying (A)' just means 'without limiting it to (A)'. This structure will follow both an (A) and a (B) noun before going on to explain what applies to everything. It will be important to remember that both (A) and (B) must be some part of a logical group when using this grammar structure, in order for it to sound natural. For example, the hands and the feet are part of the body, the morning and the afternoon are parts of a day, the chorus and the melody are parts of a song, etc. と言(い)わず～と言(い)わず is a fairly formal expression, and will rarely be used in everyday speech.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 旅行から帰ってきたら、タンスと言わず、棚と言わず、家中泥棒に物色されていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When I returned from my trip, the whole house had been ransacked by thieves, not only the wardrobe or the shelves.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は仕事中と言わず、休憩中と言わず、ずっとユーチューブを見ている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is always watching Youtube not only when he is working, but also on his break.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この映画は子供と言わず、大人と言わず、みんなに愛されている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Not only is this movie loved by children, but also by adults.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ご飯中と言わず会話中と言わず携帯を手放さない娘が心配です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not only during food but also during conversations, I am worried about my daughter who can’t put her phone down.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 金庫の中と言わず冷蔵庫の中と言わず、泥棒は全てを盗んでいったらしい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not only the contents of the safe and the fridge, but it seems that the thieves stole and made off with everything.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子供と言わず女性と言わず、いつでも安全に暮らせるようになればいいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not only if you are a child or a woman, but everyone should be able to always live in safety.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 朝と言わず夜と言わずずっとゲームをしていたせいで生活リズムが狂ってしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not only in the mornings or at night, because I was gaming all the time, my lifestyle rhythm has become screwed up.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「街灯は、はるか北の村で、夜と言わず昼と言わずともりつづけた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'The lights in the village far north are lit continuously, not only during day or night (but all the time).'

Name: にも程(ほど)がある
Meaning: There is a limit to, You are too ..., How …!, How … one can be!
About: にも程(ほど)がある is an expression that will often be used fairly critically in order to state that something is too much, based on the speaker's personal opinion. Common translations include 'how (A) can one be', 'there is a limit to (A)', or 'you are too (A)'. Being that it is composed of the case-marking particle に, adverbial particle も, the noun 程(ほど) 'bounds', and がある 'to have', the more literal meaning of 'there are bounds even within (A)' also carries the critical nuance of the more standard translations. This structure may follow almost any word type in their standard forms.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前またぶっ倒れるまで飲み続けたの？飲み過ぎにも程があるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You drank until you blacked out again? There is a limit to drinking too much you know.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あいつからまたメールがきた。また「今夜も泊めて！」だってさ。図々しいにも程があるって。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I got a text from him again. He said, 'Let me crash at your place again!' There is a limit to how shameless one can be.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 敬語使わないのは別として、先輩に向かって「お前」っていうのはどうかと思うよ。失礼にも程がある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Setting aside you not using keigo, I don't think you should say 'you' towards your senpai. There is a limit to how impolite you can be.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そういうことは相手を傷つけるかもしれないから冗談にしないほうがいいよ。冗談にも程がある。
