AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Things like that could hurt the other person's feelings, so you should not joke about that. There are limits to jokes too.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なんだこれは！店出せるほどの美味しさじゃん！うまいにも程があるだろ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: What the heck is this!? This is so good you can open a restaurant! There is a limit to how good it can be!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ん？熊がエイリアンを襲ったって？！嘘をつくにもほどがある！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Huh? A bear attacked an alien? There is a limit to just how much one can lie.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: またギャンブルをしたのか…金を無駄遣いするにもほどがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: You were gambling again? There is a limit to just how much you can pointlessly waste money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ここぞという時に頼りにならないなんて、リーダー失格にもほどがある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Something like not being reliable at just the right moment, there is a limit to just how much you can fail as a leader.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 毎月１０万円もコスメに使うなんて、買いすぎにもほどがあるでしょう！
Questions.EnglishHTML: Using more than 100,000 yen on cosmetics every month, there is a limit to just how much one can over-purchase.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 吐きそうになる料理を作れるとは…料理が下手にもほどがあります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Something like being able to make food that makes you feel like throwing up... There is a limit to just how bad one can be at cooking.

Name: にもまして
Meaning: Even -er than, Even more than, More than anything, More than anybody, More than ever
About: にもまして is a structure used to imply that something has surpassed a certain point, and will be used particularly when that thing was at a consistent level in the past, but has now risen. Common translations include 'more than ever, (B)', or 'even more than (A), (B)'. にもまして is simply a combination of the case-marking particle に, the adverbial particle も 'even', and the て-form of the う-Verb 増(ま)す 'to increase'. The に will be attached to a noun which it is marking as the comparison point from which 増(ま)す indicates an increase or growth. This means that the literal translation is simply 'even increasing from (A), (B)'. This pattern will regularly follow words like 誰(だれ) 'who', 何(なに) 'what', or いつ 'when'. In these cases, (A) is just being expressed as 'anyone', 'anything', or 'ever', rather than something more specific.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年は去年にもまして、湿気が多い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This year is even more humid than last year.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ちゃんと薬を飲んで体を休ませたのに、昨日にもまして腹痛がひどい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I took the proper medication and rested my body, but my stomach ache is even worse than yesterday.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 斎藤くんは誰にもまして仕事を一生懸命やってくれるからものすごく助かっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Saito-kun works harder than anyone else, so he is very helpful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このプロジェクトを成功させることは、何にもまして大切なんだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Succeeding in this project is more important than anything else.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はいつにもまして輝いている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She is shining brighter than ever.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 前にもまして元気になって、ようやく退院した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have gotten even better than before and am finally able to leave the hospital.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大学に合格したという知らせに、誰にもまして父が喜びました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Having been informed about me passing the university entrance exams, my dad was happier than anybody else.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 財布をなくした。それにもまして困ったのは、家の鍵をなくしたことだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I lost my wallet. And even more troubling than that was that I also lost the key to my house.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今年の花火大会は、例年にもまして豪華だったような気がします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have a feeling that this year’s fireworks festival was even more spectacular than the average year.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このホテルの接客は、どこにもまして良いと評判になっている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This hotel has a reputation of having better customer service than anywhere else.

Name: 捲(まく)る
Meaning: Like crazy, Keep doing (without a second thought), Nothing but, On and on, Do … all around, To do a lot of, One after another, All over, Keep, Everything, Constantly, All the time
About: まくる is a verb that is attached to the conjunctive form of other verbs in order to show that (A) is being done over and over, a lot, or with a great amount of vigor. It comes from the verb う-Verb 捲(まく)る 'to roll', or 'to turn', so means 'to do (A) around and again'. Common translations include 'to (A) like crazy', 'to do nothing but (A)', and 'to constantly do (A)'. As mentioned, this structure is attached to the conjunctive form of other verbs. This structure may be used both in positive or negative contexts, and it is quite common for the nuance of まくる to indicate that (A) is being done recklessly, or with abandon. This implies that the speaker isn't thinking about the consequences of doing (A) repeatedly, if any may exist.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日は釣具屋でルアーを買いまくったから、来週までご飯とふりかけで我慢しなきゃいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bought a bunch of lures at the tackle shop yesterday, so I have to put up with eating rice and furikake until next week.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 久しぶりに実家に帰って、母の料理を食べまくってるから少し太ってきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have started to gain some weight because I've been eating so much of my mom's food, ever since I came to visit my family after a long time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日はカラオケで歌いまくったから、声が全然でない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I sang like crazy at the karaoke last night, so I lost my voice.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: しゃっくりが出まくりすぎて苦しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am having a hard time breathing because I am hiccuping like crazy. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: はやせとなおとは狂ったように踊って踊って踊りまくった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Hayase and Naoto danced like crazy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「最近、チョコを食べまくっているからちょっと太った。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I've been eating chocolate like crazy lately, so I've gained some weight.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 締め切りが近いから、原稿を書きまくった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Because the deadline is close, I was writing the draft like crazy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 時間さえあれば走りまくっている彼の足はたくましいです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He, who runs like crazy so long as he has time, has strong legs.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ストレス発散でメイク道具を買いまくったせいで金欠になった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Due to buying makeup goods one after the other to relieve stress, I have no money.

Name: わ〜わで
Meaning: And...so, And...because, Since
About: As mentioned in the わ grammar point, わ is an adverbial particle that is commonly used in cases of stress of emphasis in Japanese. When used after either verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives, or nouns in their standard forms, it generally implies that (A) and (B) are negative factors that have lead to (C), where (C) is either a negative outcome, or a negative opinion. It will often be translated simply as 'with (A) and (B), (C)'. To use this structure, simply place わ after a word, and then repeat the same after a second (different) word. In the case of な-Adjective or nouns, だわ will be used. The case-marking particle で will then follow the second わ, indicating 'with', or 'as a consequence of'. わ～わで, like わ, primarily emphasizes the speaker's surprise in regard to the words that appear before it. However, unlike わ, where the same verb will be repeated in order to highlight an excessive extent, わ～わで simply indicates surprise in terms of irritation or frustration. This structure is predominantly used by men, but it may also sometimes be used by women. However, there are several different variations of わ depending on where they appear in sentences, each of which have gender usage tendencies that will need to be learned. In essence, わ is used in the same way as し～し, where the words that they are being attached to are just being listed as reasons. Additionally, the で may occasionally be omitted.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日はクライアントに怒られるわ、自分の上司に暴言吐かれるわで大変だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I had a bad day yesterday because my client was mad at me and because my boss yelled at me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このアパートはボロいわ狭いわで最悪な物件だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This apartment sucks because it is run-down and small.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しく入ってきた新人はクライアントには無礼だわ、クレーム対応が下手だわで、どこから教育していいかわからない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The newbie that just joined is rude to our clients and bad at handling complaints, so I don't know how I should train him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 携帯を買ってくれたこと自体は嬉しかったんだけと、５年前のモデルだわ画面は割れているわで使い物にならなそうだったから、自分で新しい携帯を買った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am happy that they bought me a phone, but it was a 5 year old model and the screen was broken and didn't look like I would be able to use it, so I went ahead and bought myself a new phone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今年は宝くじには当たるわ、長年付き合っていた彼氏にプロポーズされるわで、幸せなことが沢山あってとても嬉しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am very happy this year because I won the lottery and my boyfriend of many years is going to propose to me. (Positive meaning)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「今朝の通勤時は、急に雨が降ってくるわ傘は壊れるわで大変だった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I had a hard time getting to work this morning because it suddenly started raining and my umbrella broke.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「今日はタンスに小指をぶつけるわ、道でつまずくわで、ついてなかった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I was not lucky today because I hit my little finger on the dresser and tripped on the street.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「朝から犬に吠えられるわ、鳥のウンチが頭に落ちてくるわで…（最低な一日だったわ）。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'The dogs barked at me in the morning and the bird pooped on my head, so... （it was a horrible day.）'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「あのレストラン、料理に虫が入ってるわ、クレームいったら切れられるわで最低だったの。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Speaking of that restaurant, it was the worst since they had bugs in the food, and when I complained about it, I was ignored.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お母さんに怒られるわ先生にも怒られるわ、気分が悪い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Being gotten angry at by my mother and my teacher one after the other, I feel terrible.

Name: どうにか
Meaning: Somehow (or other)
About: どうにか is an adverb which is used when something happens 'somehow or other'. It is often used when the speaker has some reason to believe a desire or goal is unlikely to be achieved, yet somehow in the end the desired outcome still occurs. どうにか is often translated as 'somehow or other' or 'one way or the other'. In some contexts どうにか is also translated as 'barely', emphasizing that effort was put into achieving a result. The result may not be exactly as originally desired, but it has still 'somehow' been managed. どうにか is often paired with the transitive verb する or the intransitive verb なる. どうにかなる means ‘to somehow turn out alright (on its own)’, and implies that things will work out without some specific intervention. どうにかする means ‘to somehow manage to do’, and implies that the method for resolving the situation is uncertain but that by some effort it is possible to solve.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 条件に不安はあったみたいだけど、どうにか説得することができた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It appears that there were concerns about the conditions, but I was somehow able to persuade them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どうにか明日までに解決しなくてはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have to solve this problem one way or another by tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんなどうにか聞こえる声で話されたら何言ってるかわからないよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you talk to me with a voice that I can barely hear, I won’t understand what you are trying to say.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんな落ち込むなって、時間が経てばどうにかなるよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don’t be that upset, things will work out over time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お母さんのこと聞いたぞ。こっちはこっちでどうにかするから、今は家族との時間を大切にしろ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I heard about your mother. We will work things out on our end, so prioritize spending time with your family right now.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日の午後までにどうにか帰れたらいいんだけど・・・。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It’d be nice if I could somehow make it back by this afternoon...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうにかして敵の攻撃を回避しなければ！ このままでは私たちの方が先に滅びてしまう！
Questions.EnglishHTML: We need to somehow avoid the enemy’s attack! At this rate we’ll be destroyed first!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうにかステージの後方まで声を届けてくれないと困るよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It’ll be an issue if you can’t somehow project your voice to the back of the stage.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どうにか明日までに終わらせないと。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have to somehow get this finished by tomorrow

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 雨がどうにか止んでほしいと、心から願っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the bottom of my heart, I wish that it would somehow stop raining.

Name: や否(いな)や
Meaning: As soon as, No sooner than, The minute
About: や否(いな)や, like か否(いな)か, is a grammar pattern that makes use of 否(いな)  'no', an interjection. However, unlike the pairing with the adverbial particle か 'or' when stating 'whether or not (A)', the  pairing of 否(いな) with や in its role as a conjunction particle has the meaning of 'as soon as (A)', or 'no sooner than (A)'. Remembering that や simply highlights the word before it is not being limited to that, the literal meaning of や否(いな)や is 'at a point when neither (A) or not (A) could be determined, (B)'. や否(いな)や will be used after verbs in their dictionary form. や否(いな)や is a formal expression that will generally be used when (B) is something that happens spontaneously, or is surprising.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私が部屋から出てくるのを見るや否や、空き巣が手に持っていたものを私に投げて、逃げていった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As soon as the burglar saw me coming out of the room, he threw everything that was in his hand at me and ran away.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺の顔を見るや否や友達の犬が吠え出した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As soon as he saw my face, my friend's dog started barking.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は席に座るや否や「とりあえず生一つ」といった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He said 'I'll have a beer to start' as soon as he sat down.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は本を開くや、寝た。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He fell asleep as soon as he opened the book.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はあの曲を聴くや、泣き始めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She started to cry as soon as she listened to the song.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 教室に着くや否やランドセルを机に置いた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I put my backpack on the desk as soon as I arrived at the classroom.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １２時を回るや否やすぐに誕生日のメッセージを送ってくれたのは、お母さんだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The person who sent me a birthday message the minute it came around to midnight was my mother.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「彼があくびをするや否や彼女もあくびが出てしまった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'As soon as he has yawned, the girl also yawned.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 記事： 「警察官に気が付くや否や急に走り出した。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Article: 'As soon as he noticed the policeman, he suddenly started to run.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「焼き立てのパンが皿に出てくるや否やすぐに彼の口の中に消えた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'As soon as the freshly baked bread appeared on the plate, it immediately disappeared in his mouth.'

Name: 次第(しだい)です
Meaning: Because the reason is, Therefore, The present situation is like this, This is how (it is), Those are the circumstances, This is why
About: When following a verb in one of its standard forms, 次第(しだい) 'directly following' will be used to express reasons or give explanations. In these cases, it will be followed by either of the auxiliary verbs だ, or です. However, です is far more common, due to this use of 次第(しだい) primarily appearing in polite speech. In this particular use of 次第(しだい), it is similar to 'the eventuation is that (A)', meaning that something ultimately ended up as (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高速で玉突き事故があったので、遅れた次第です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I was late because there was an accident involving several cars on the highway.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来月から、向かいの家に引っ越すことになったので、挨拶しにきた次第です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I came to introduce myself because we will be living in the house across from yours starting next month.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩が提案してくださったプランでは予算オーバーしそうだったので、今クライアントと相談しつつ色々と調整している次第です。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We are now discussing with the client and making various adjustments because the plan proposed by you (senpai) seemed like it was going to go over their budget.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お見舞いに行く：「先生が倒れたと耳にしたため、直ぐにこちらへ伺った次第です。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Enquiring about one’s health: ‘Because I heard that you collapsed, that is why I came to visit you immediately.’

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 先生：「なんで遅れたんだ？」生徒：「電車が遅延していて遅れてしまった次第です。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Teacher: ‘Why are you late?’ Student: ‘The reason is that the train was delayed.’

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 部下が上司に：「吹雪の影響で列車の運行ダイヤが乱れており、出社が遅れた次第です。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Subordinate to boss: 'I arrived late to the office because of the blizzard and the train schedule was disrupted.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 陽子：「どうして日本語の勉強をしているの？」マット：「日本にいずれ住みたいと思って勉強を始めた次第だよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Yoko: ‘Why are you studying Japanese?’ Matt: ‘The reason that I started studying is that I would like to live in Japan at some point.’

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 辞表を提出する：「母国にいる身内が倒れたとの連絡が入ったため帰国する事にした次第です。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Submitting a letter of resignation: ‘Because of receiving news that someone close to me collapsed in my home country, that is the reason why I have decided to return home.’

Name: と言(い)うところ
Meaning: I would say (about), I guess (about), It could be said that, About, At best
About: というところ is a grammar expression that is used when highlighting an approximate number or degree for something. It is a combination of the case-marking particle と, the う-Verb 言(い)う 'to say', and the noun ところ 'place', which often marks situations. Common translations include 'I would say about (A)', 'I guess about (A)'. A more literal translation is 'To be at the point where saying (A) is accurate'. It is most common for this structure to appear following either verbs or nouns, but may also occasionally follow adjectives. Coming primarily at the end of sentences, というところ will often be followed immediately by the auxiliary verb だ or です. Occasionally, という will be replaced by the past-tense form, といった. However, the meaning does not change at all in these cases.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このペースだとこの工事はあと二週間で終わるというところだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At this pace, I would say this construction work will be finished in about two weeks.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どれぐらい辛いって聞かれても...汗が出るぐらい辛いというところかな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You are asking me how spicy it is? I would say spicy enough to make you sweat.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まあ順調は順調だけど、まあまあというところだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well, you could say everything is going smoothly, but it's alright, I guess.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電車で行けば３０分かかるけど、車なら１５分というところです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It would take 30 minutes by train, but I would say it would take 15 minutes by car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: これぐらいの物件だったら５０００万といったところですね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For a property of this size, I would say it would cost something like 50 million.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 徒歩だと１時間といったところです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I would say it would take an hour by walking.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 買取となると、最低で５千円というところです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If we were to buy this from you, I would say we would pay you at least 5 thousand yen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 失敗の原因は、過度な緊張と言うところでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I would say the reason for the failure was probably due to excessive nervousness.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ストレスによる暴飲暴食で体重が増加したと言うところだと思います。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think that I would say that the reason for the weight increase was because of excessive eating and drinking due to stress.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
はなこ：「オリビアの日本語のレベルはどうですか？」
かすみ：「せいぜい平均といったところでしょう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Hanako: 'How are Olivia's Japanese skills?'
Kasumi: 'I would say average at best.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
上司：「頼んでいた仕事はどこまでおわりましたか？」
部下：「７０、８０パーセントというところです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Boss: 'How far have you gotten on the job I asked you to do?'
Subordinate: 'I would say it is about 70-80% done.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
友達１：「スーパーまで行くのにどれくらいかかる？」
友達２：「たぶん２０分といったところだろう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Friend1: 'How long will it take to get to the supermarket?'
Friend2: 'I would say about 20 minutes.'

Name: １～たりとも～ない
Meaning: Not even one, Not a single, No (at all)
About: たりとも is a grammar pattern that is most often used in negative sentences, in order to indicate that (A) is not an exception to something. It will follow either number words, or nouns. Possible translations include 'not even one (A)', and 'not a single (A)'. However, due to たりとも just being a combination of the auxiliary verb たり 'presenting examples', and the conjunction particle とも 'presenting approximate limitations', the literal translation of たりとも is just 'even limited to (A) as an example, not (B)', with the 'not (B)' coming from the negative structure in the second half of the sentence. This is a very formal expression, so will not be used in daily conversation.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: みんなで押し入れようとしたが、一ミリたりとも動かなかったから、ユンボで押し込みました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We all tried to push it in together, but it did not even move a millimeter, so we pushed it in using a backhoe.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 消防士などは一秒たりとも気を抜くことができない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: People like firefighters can't lose focus, even for a second.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は一分たりとも残業をしたくないので毎日定時に帰っています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't want to work overtime even for a minute, so I go home on time every day.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 少したりとも油断をすると、ミスをして命を落とす恐れがあります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you let your guard down even a little, you could make a mistake that could cost you your life.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この洞窟へは２０年前に起きた事故以来、何人たりとも立ち入ることが許されない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since the accident that occurred 20 years ago, no one has been allowed to enter this cave.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人間は酸素なしには１日たりとも生きられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Humans can not live even one day without oxygen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 安全や生命を脅かすものは何人たりとも許されない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not even one person is allowed to threaten life or security.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今日は沢山の仕事があるので、一分たりともぼーっとして過ごすわけにはいきません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have stacks of work to do today, so there’s no way I can zone out for even one minute.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「一瞬たりとも無駄にしないつもりで生きている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'He follows his belief of wasting not even one moment in his life.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 茜雫の死以来１５年経ったが、彼女を忘れたことは一度たりともなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though 15 years have passed since the death of Senna, I have not forgotten her even one time.

Name: といっ + たらない
Meaning: Cannot tell, describe, say or express how, Words cannot express, Too … for words, Extremely
About: といったらない is a casual expression used when something is at a level such that not even (A) is sufficient to describe it. It is usually translated as 'there are no words to express (A)', or 'too (A) for words'. This structure is a combination of the case-marking particle と, the conjunction particle たら 'when', or 'if', and the い-Adjective ない. It may be used in either positive or negative contexts. といったらない, or the shortened form ったらない may appear after adjectives or nouns in their standard forms. The ない in this grammar pattern is commonly thought to be an abbreviation of ありはしない, or ありゃしない, the conjunctive form of the う-Verb ある combined with the case marking particle は, and the negated form of する, しない. In this way, a more literal meaning can be thought of as 'if one were to say (A), it's not possible'.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 隣の人の犬は朝からうるさいといったらない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't describe to you how loud my neighbor's dog is in the morning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子を家で留守番させるのは心配といったらない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't tell you how worried I am to let my son stay at home alone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: プロジェクトを終わらせた後の達成感ったらない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't describe the feeling of accomplishment after finishing a project.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの子の運転は危ないといったらありゃしないから、あの子と出かける時には運転させないようにしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't describe how bad her driving is. I always make sure not to let her drive when we go somewhere.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田舎では車がないとどこにもいけないから、不便といったらありゃしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't describe to you how inconvenient the countryside is. You can't go anywhere without a car.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は私の話を全然聞いてくれない。むかつくといったらありゃしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She does not listen to a word I say. I can't describe to you how annoyed I am.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人の優しさと言ったらありゃしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can't describe how nice he is.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このラーメンの美味しさったらない…。ついつい食べてしまうんだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Words cannot express how delicious this ramen is. I can’t stop eating it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「車のタイヤが盗まれた。本当に腹が立つったらない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'My car tires have been stolen. I can't tell you how angry I am!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「校長と鹿との戦いを見たときの驚きといったらないよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I can't describe my surprise at seeing a fight between the principal and a deer.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: メークした時の星野の変わり様と言ったらなかった。まるで別人のようだった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I couldn't describe how much Hoshino has changed when she put on the makeup. She was like a different person.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 数年が経ったのにまだあの日の日没を覚えている。その景色の美しさと言ったらなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though years have passed, I can still remember the sunset that day. I couldn't describe the beauty of the scene in words.

Name: に照(て)らして
Meaning: In light of, Based on, According to, Referencing, Comparing against, In view of
About: に照(て)らして is an expression based on the standard meaning of the う-Verb 照(て)らす 'to illuminate', and is primarily used comparatively in a similar way to 'in light of' in English. This comparative meaning aims to illustrate (B) from the perspective of (A), and usually refers to situations, level of experience, or something similar. To use this structure, attach the case-marking particle に to the end of a noun, then follow it with 照(て)らして. If a second noun will be modified directly, then 照(て)らした will be used instead. Keep in mind that the に in this structure is marking (A) as the 'doer' of 照(て)らす 'to illuminate', as it is a transitive verb. This means that the structure has a more literal translation of '(B) as reflected by (A)'. This can also be thought of as 'as made clear by (A), (B)', 'as made evident by (A), (B)'. (B) will almost always be a judgment that is logically based on (A).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 母は自分の経験に照らして、こういう時はどうすればいいかをアドバイスしてくれた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My mother advised me what to do in these situations in light of her own experience.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 労働基準法を守らない会社は法律に照らして罰せられるべきだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Companies that do not comply with the labor laws should be punished in accordance with the law.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 経済統計に照らした強盗と窃盗事件に関する犯罪統計。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Crime statistics on burglaries and thefts in light of economic statistics.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犯罪者は刑法に照らして罰せられる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Criminals are punished in accordance with the law.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アルバイトをすることは学校の規則に照らして規則違反になる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Part-time working is a violation in light of school rules.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼女の生活習慣に照らして罪がないことを宣言された。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In light of her everyday life (alibi), she has been declared innocent.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 我々の基準に照らすと、この製品を粗悪品と言う人は少なくない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are quite a few people that would call this product inferior in light of our standards.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 国内の状況に照らすと、国外からの石油の購入は必要である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In light of the domestic situation, purchasing petrol abroad is necessary...

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 社内規程に照らして、作業員の効率性の検証を行う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: To perform the validation of workers' efficiency in accordance with company regulations.

Name: とあれば
Meaning: (Emphatic) if, If it is the case that, As (you wish)
About: とあれば is a grammar pattern in Japanese that is used as an emphatic version of なら 'if'. It will primarily be used in formal situations, or for literary effect, such as in a novel. It may be translated as 'if (A) is the case, then (B)', or 'should (A) be true, then (B)'. This is a combination of the case-marking particle と, and the hypothetical form of the う-Verb ある 'to be', あれば. とあれば will primarily follow nouns, but is occasionally also seen after other structures such as verbs and adjectives when the と is being used as a quotation. (A) is often some special circumstance or condition that leads to the conclusion or assumption of (B), were (A) to be accurate. As this expression is emphatic, (B) will usually indicate something that must be done, or can't be avoided, with structures like しかない, なければならない, ざるを得ない, etc.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: データを復元できるとあれば、いくらでも出します！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it is for recovering my data, I would pay whatever you offer!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 状態がいいとあれば４万円ぐらいで売れると思いますよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it is in good condition, I think you'd be able to sell it for 40,000 yen.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩の指示とあれば従わないわけにはいけないけど、絶対私のやり方の方が効率がいいと思うのに。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is my Senpai's orders so I have to do it, but I swear my way is a lot more efficient.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前の頼みとあればやるしかないだろ。俺に任せろ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it is your wish, I have to do it. Leave it up to me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子のためとあればどれだけでも残業をする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If it is for my son, I will do as much overtime as I have to.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 息子のためとあれば、火の中でも飛び込みます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If it is for my son, I would even dive into a fire.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 市民の願いとあればスーパーヒーローはいつでも出動するんだとか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I hear that the hero would mobilize at any moment if it were the wish of the citizens.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 社員：「そんな会社のトップからの誘いとあれば無視できない」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Company employee: 'If it is an invitation from the head of the company, then it cannot be ignored.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 母はいつも「愛する孫のためとあれば、どんな頼みも聞くわ」と言っています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mom always says, ‘if it is my beloved grandchild, then I would listen to any request’.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「皇帝陛下の命令とあればせざるを得ない！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'If it is his Highness's order, then I will have no choice but to do it.'

Name: さぞ
Meaning: You must be very, How … you must be, I dare to say, I am sure or certain that you must be very
About: さぞ is a fairly formal adverb in Japanese that is used emphatically to highlight that the following statement is something that the speaker understands to be true. This is often in relation to the feelings or situation of another. Common translations include 'you must be very (A)', 'how (A) you must be', or 'I dare say that (A)'. 'I dare to say that (A)' is probably the closest to the literal meaning of さぞ, as the speaker is empathizing with someone else by trying to imagine the situation from their point of view. As さぞ is an adverb, it will usually appear at the beginning of a sentence, modifying the whole phrase that follows. The phrase following さぞ will often finish with だろう or でしょう. This highlights the speaker's opinion about the situation as being limited by their own knowledge.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの一流企業で働いているなら、さぞいいところに住んでいるんでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you work for that prestigious company, you must live in a very nice place.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: おばあさんが急に入院されて、さぞご心配でしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Your grandmother's sudden hospitalization must be very worrisome.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんなニコニコしている斎藤さんは初めて見た。さぞ嬉しい出来事があったんでしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I had never seen Saito-san smiling like that before. He must have had something good happen to him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんなに大切にしていた車を盗まれたなんて、さぞや悔しかっただろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You must have been so frustrated to have such a cherished car stolen.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人が彼の父だなんて、さぞかし驚いただろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He must have been very surprised that that man was his father.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「夜勤の仕事もさぞ大変だろう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: How tough the night shift work must be!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「長旅ご苦労様です。さぞお疲れでしょう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: You went through such a long trip. You must be very tired. (How tired you must be!)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「初めての赤ちゃんのお誕生にさぞ嬉しいことでしょう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: You must be very happy to have your first child. (How happy you must be to have your first child!)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「智子は昇進が見送られて、さぞがっかりしたに違いない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Not getting the promotion, Satoko must be very disappointed. (How disappointed Satoko must be after not getting the promotion!)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 料理好きの旦那さんと結婚されて、さぞ幸せなことでしょう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Getting married to a husband who loves cooking, how happy you must be.

Name: と来(き)たら ①
Meaning: When it comes to, That or this … of mine, That or this darn …, That or this blasted …
About: ときたら is an expression used casually when expressing mild frustration toward (A) in a lighthearted manner. This structure is a combination of the case-marking particle と, and 来(く)る combined with the conjunction particle たら 'if', 来(き)たら. It will often simply be translated as 'that blasted (A)', or 'that damn (A)'. Despite this, the literal meaning is just 'when it comes to (A)'. ときたら will directly follow nouns. This grammar pattern will almost exclusively appear in kana, so memorizing the stem verb it comes from will help to remember the meaning.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: うちの息子ときたら、就職もしないで家でダラダラしている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When it comes to my son, he is not even trying to get a job, and he is just sitting around at home.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: うちの弟ときたら、朝から文句ばかり言ってくるから本当にうざい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This (darn) brother of mine, he always complains to me in the morning, and it is really annoying.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私の上司ときたら、自分が仕事できないくせに少しでもミスをしたらものすごく怒るからみんなから嫌われている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When it comes to my boss, he gets super mad if you make the slightest mistake, even though he is not the best worker, so he is disliked by everyone at work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: うちの犬ときたら、家にお客さんが来るとその人に飛びつくからもっと躾をちゃんとしないといけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When it comes to my dog, when a guest comes to our place, he jumps on them so I need to train him properly. (To be expected)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: カセットテープを使う機会がなくなったため、最近の若者ときたら、カセットプレイヤーが使えない子達が多い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since there is no opportunity to use cassette tapes, when it comes to the younger generation, there are many who do not know how to use cassette players. (Only natural)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「義理の母ときたら私のことをぼやいてばかりよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'That mother-in-law of mine, she always complains about me!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「このプリンターときたら、忙しい時に限って故障するぞ！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'This freaking printer of mine, it breaks only when I am busy.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「娘は真面目に勉強しているのに、息子ときたら・・・（何もやらない）」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Even though my daughter studies very seriously, that son of mine... (Doesn't do anything at all)'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「うちの旦那ときたら、連休中うちでゴロゴロばかりで、子どもの面倒をみてくれないの。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'That husband of mine, he is always loafing around during the holidays and doesn't take care of children!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「隣の人ときたら、毎日、毎日、朝の６時からラジオを聞くからうるさくて眠れない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'That freaking neighbor of mine, every single day he listens to radio from 6 a.m. so loud that I can't sleep.'

Name: びる
Meaning: -like, Looking, Feeling, With an air of, To become
About: びる, like めく, is a verb that is used exclusively as a suffix. It is a る-Verb, and may be translated as '(A) looking', '(A) seeming', or 'behaving like (A)'. びる is quite formal, and will follow a limited set of expressions. びる will appear after nouns, or occasionally the stem form of い-Adjectives. びる indicates that, according to the speaker, something 'gives off the sense of (A)', and is based on visual information. As it is a descriptive verb, びる will change to びた when linked directly to a second noun.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 実家で屋根裏部屋を掃除していたら、古びたアルバムが続々と出てきた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: While cleaning out the attic at my parents' house, I found a series of old-looking albums.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は幼びて見えるけど、実際は33歳らしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She is young-looking, but apparently she is 33 years old.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は大人びて見えるが、まだ社会のことなんて分かってないただの学生だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She is adult-looking, but she is actually just a student that knows nothing about the real world.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この町は田舎びているから好きだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I like this town because it is rural-like.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はどんなに治安が良くても、田舎びた町には住みたくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how safe it is, I don't want to live in a rural-looking town.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なぜ子供は大人びた格好をしたがるのだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I wonder why kids tend to want to dress adult-like.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「くみこは年の割に大人びている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Kumiko feels mature for her age.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「ヴァミリオは大人びて見えるが、純粋で、表情がわかりやすい少女なのだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A novel: 'Vamirio looked mature-like, but she was a pure girl with easy-to-read facial expressions.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: プレミアが付いているせいでこんな古びたレコードが三十万円もするなんて…！
Questions.EnglishHTML: To think that due to it being limited, this kind of old feeling record would go for 300,000 yen...!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「古びた木橋は足を踏み出すたびに不穏な音がした。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: A novel: 'The old-looking wooden bridge was making a disturbing noise with every step.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「そのテレビは本当に古びたものだった。まるで昭和の時代から飛び出したかのようだった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'That TV was really old-fashioned-like. As if it jumped straight out of the Showa era.'

Name: にしたところで
Meaning: Even, Even for, Even from the perspective of, Even in the case of
About: にしたところで or としたところで are two expressions that are used to indicate the hypothetical situation of (A), from within which the result of (B) will not change. These structures primarily express a lack of power over the ultimate result, or a lack of significant difference between (A) and any other potential choice. Translations include 'even in the case of (A), (B)', or 'even for (A), (B)'. These structures combine either of the case-marking particles と or に with the past tense of する, した, the noun ところ, used for marking the situation, and the case marking particle で. It will directly follow nouns or noun-modified phrases. These patterns can be thought of more simply as a combination of にする 'going with (A)' or とする 'as (A)', and the たところで 'even if (A), not (B)' grammar structure that indicates negative outcomes. In casual situations, たところで will occasionally be replaced with たって.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先輩の青木さんにしたところで、上達しなければいけない箇所はある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even our senpai Aoki-san has areas where he can improve.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ノートパソコンにしたところで、Ｗｉ－Ｆｉがないと仕事ができない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even with a laptop, if there is no Wi-Fi I can't work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １時間寝坊をしてしまったのでいくら急いだとしたところで、間に合うわけがない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if I hurry, I am not going to make it because I overslept an hour.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ダイエットを始めたとしたところで、私は三日坊主だから続かないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if I go on a diet, I have a short attention span so I don't think I will be able to continue.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私にしたってそんなことはしたくないけど、上司に言われたからにはするしかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if I don't want to do such a thing, my boss told me to, so I have no choice but to do it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 謝ったとしたって、社長は彼のことを許さないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even if I apologized, he would probably not forgive him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 誰にでも欠点はある。完全な田中さんとしたって同じだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Everyone has faults. It is the case even for the perfect Tanaka.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「え？倒産するか合併するかだって？どちらにしたって、僕にとってはマズイ事だ…。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: ‘Huh? You’re talking about either declaring bankruptcy or merging? Even in either case, for me they’re bad things...’

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ５人の子供のお母さんにしたところで、まだまだ子育てにおいて学ぶことがあるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even in the case of it being a mother of 5, there are probably still plenty of things to learn regarding child rearing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は非常に深刻な状態だ。天才医師のジャックにしたところで何もできない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He is in very serious condition. Even the genius-doctor Jack cannot do anything.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「ありがとう」や「ごめんなさい」という小さな言葉にしたって、聞く側には大きな意味を持ちます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even little words like ‘thank you’ and ‘I’m sorry’ hold a lot of meaning for those on the receiving end.

Name: ばこそ
Meaning: Precisely because, Only because, Because, Due to, Only if
About: ばこそ is used in a similar way to からこそ, indicating that (A) is the precise reason for (B). It will be translated as 'precisely because of (A)', or 'it is only due to (A) that (B)'. This pattern is a combination of the conjunction particle ば, and the adverbial particle こそ, which is being used in a similar way to a sentence ending particle in this case. ばこそ may follow almost any word type that has been adjusted into its hypothetical form. However, it will appear as であればこそ when used after nouns or な-Adjectives. In many cases, (A) will be a reason that is difficult to conceive of as what would lead to (B) under normal circumstances, and therefore requires the speaker to emphasize it with こそ.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 娘の将来を思えばこそ、塾に通わせます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Precisely because I am thinking about my daughter's future, I will make her attend cram school.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 忙しければこそ時間を効率的に使うことができるようになる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Precisely because you are busy, you will be able to use your time more efficiently.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 健康であればこそ、年をとっても楽しい人生を過ごせる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You will be able to enjoy life even if you grow old, precisely because of good health.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 小さな会社であればこそ、優秀な人材が必要だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Precisely because it is a small company, we need the best workers.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 悲しみがあればこそ、喜びもある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Precisely because there is sadness, there is also happiness.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 失敗すればこそ、成長できるのだと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think that it is precisely because of failures that you are able to succeed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本語の勉強は難しければこそ、却ってやりがいを感じるのです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Precisely because studying Japanese is hard, it feels all the more rewarding.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 両親が子どもを叱るのは子どもの幸福を考えればこそだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is precisely because parents think of the well-being of their children that they scold them.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「私たちは友達であればこそ、Ｘさんの計画に反対なんです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Precisely because we are friends, I am against your plan.'

Name: ても差(さ)し支(つか)えない
Meaning: May, Is bit a bother if, Do you mind if, Is it a problem if
About: ても差(さ)し支(つか)えない is a polite expression used in a similar way to てもいい 'may I', or 'do you mind'. This is a combination of ても (or でも when following nouns or な-Adjectives), and the る-Verb 差(さ)し支(つか)える 'to interfere', or 'to hinder' in its negative form, 差(さ)し支(つか)えない. It may be used either for asking for or granting permission. Due to this pattern being polite, ありません will almost always be used in place of ない by itself. The more literal translation is 'it is not a hindrance if (A)'. In cases where permission is being asked for, か will be added to the end of ありません.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここに座ってもらっても差し支えありません。どうぞお座りください。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't mind if you sat there. Please sit down.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お風呂は熱くても差し支えません。むしろ熱い方がありがたいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't mind if the bath is hot. In fact, I like hotter baths.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はまだ初心者です。下手でも差し支えありませんか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am still a beginner. Do you mind if I'm not very good at it?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今週はものすごく忙しいので来週でも差し支えありませんか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm extremely busy this week, so would you mind if we do it next week?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日の大会に差し支えるので、焼肉に行くのは大会の後にしましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since it will interfere with tomorrow's tournament, let's go to the yakiniku after the tournament.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: タバコは健康に差し支えるので、吸わないようにしています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I do not smoke cigarettes because it is hazardous to my health.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「ミーティングは明後日でも差し支えありません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I don't mind if the meeting is the day after tomorrow.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 電車：「ここに座っても差し支えありませんか？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Train: 'Would it bother you if I sit here?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 部下：「今日は定時に帰っても差し支えありませんか？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Subordinate: ‘Is it a problem if I go home at the regular time today?’

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 医者に：「この薬とその薬を一緒に飲んでも差し支えないでしょうか？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: To a doctor: 'May I take that medicine together with this one?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
営業担当者：「明日、お電話差し上げても差し支えございませんか？」
クライアント：「はい、問題ありません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Sales representative: 'Would it bother you if I call you tomorrow?'
Client: 'No problem at all.'

Name: には及(およ)ばない ①
Meaning: There is no need to, It is fine if you don’t, Unnecessary
About: には及(およ)ばない is a polite expression in Japanese used in order to indicate that there is 'no need to (A)', or that '(A) is unnecessary. It is a combination of the case-marking particle に, the adverbial particle は, and the negated form of the う-Verb 及(およ)ぶ 'to reach', 及(およ)ばない. The literal translation is 'it does not extend to (A)'. This phrase will appear after nouns, or verbs in their dictionary form. As this grammar pattern is used in polite speech, the word that it is attached to is often preceded by either お or ご, depending on what type of verb it is.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こちらから以前いただいたアドレスに送るので、こんな遠くまで取りに来ていただくには及びません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am going to send it to the email address you gave us last time, so there is no need to come this far to pick it up.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私たちの方からそちらに書類を持っていくので、こちらまでお越しいただくには及びません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We will bring the documents to you, so there is no need to come here.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ご心配には及びません。これぐらいの怪我なら全然我慢できます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no need to worry. This level of injury is totally bearable.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここに書かれていることは皆さん既にご存じだと思いますので、ご説明には及びませんね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think everyone already knows the contents of this, so there is no need for me to explain.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの有名ラーメン店には及ばないけど、ここのラーメンも結構美味しいと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think the ramen here is also quite good, though not as good as that famous ramen restaurant.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お宅の息子さんには及ばないかもだけど、私の息子も結構上達してきたと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Maybe not as good as your son, but I think my son has also improved a lot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「待って、私も行くよ。」「いえ、それには及びません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Wait, I will go too!'
'No, there is no need for that.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: リモートワークやオンライン会議が主流なのに、わざわざ会議の為にこちらまでお越しいただくには及びません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since remote work and online meetings are now the norm, there's really no need for you to come all the way here just for meetings.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
はいだ：「れつこさんの顔色が悪いね。」
れつこ：「ご心配には及びません。ただちょっと元気がないだけです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Haida: 'Retsuko, you are pale.'
Retsuko: 'No need to worry. I am just a bit tired.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
普通の人：「ありがとうございました。」
偉い人：「いや、礼には及びません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Ordinary person: 'Thank you very much.'
Person in high position: 'No need to thank me.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
小説、バトラー：「気に入ったなら、何か食べるものでもお支度致しましょうか。」
ゲスト：「いいえ、それには及びません。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A novel, butler: 'If you would like I can make something to eat.'
Guest: 'No, there is no need for that.'

Name: に即(そく)して
Meaning: In line with, Based on, In accordance with
About: に即(そく)して is a formal grammar structure which is used to express that something is being done for the purpose of handling a matter in the best possible way. It is a combination of に, and the する-verb 即(そく)する 'in accordance with (A)', ' in line with (A)' in its て-form. Occasionally, に則(そく)して 'in following with' will be used instead. This structure will be used before nouns, or may be used when one noun is directly modifying another. In the case of the latter, に即(そく)した will be used instead of に即(そく)して.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 会社のルールに即して、副業をしてはいけない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In line with the company's rules, you may not work a second job.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの監督はちゃんと事実に即して映画を作るから、映画を見るだけでいろいろなことが学べる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That director makes his films in accordance with the facts, so you can learn a lot just by watching his films.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 法律に則した勤務時間は週４０時間にも関わらず、あの会社は社員に週７０時間働かせている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Work hours in line with the law is 40 hours a week, but that company makes its worker work 70 hours a week.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 外国人であろうと、日本にいる限り、日本の法律に則した罰が与えられます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter if you are a foreigner, as long as you are in Japan, you will be punished in line with Japanese law.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この計画は現実に則していません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This plan does not follow with reality. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 映画は実情に即して制作されたものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The movie was made in line with actual circumstances.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 経済状況に即して課税を調整する必要がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is a need to adjust taxes in line with the economic condition.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 役職に関わらず、ルールに即して平等に罰せられるべきだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regardless of position, punishment ought to be given equally, in line with the rules.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 現実に即して撮られたホラー系のドキュメンタリーほど怖いものはありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is nothing scarier than horror documentaries that are shot based on true events.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ＭｃＲｏｎａｌｄ社とＳＦＣ社との抗争は現地の法律に即して処理される。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The dispute between McRonald and SFC will be handled in line with local law.

Name: ないまでも
Meaning: May not … but (at least), Even though not, Even if not
About: ないまでも is a combination of the negated form of a verb, the case-marking particle まで 'until', and the adverbial particle も 'even'. It will often be translated as 'even though not (A), (B)', or 'it may not be (A), but (B)'. This structure usually presents some form of extreme (A) which has not yet been reached, but the lower extent of (B) cannot be denied. The literal translation is 'even though not reaching (A), (B)'. Depending on the source, this structure may occasionally be used with nouns. In this case, it will need to follow ではない, or the casual じゃない. This grammar pattern will be used in both positive and negative situations. For example, (A) may be the best outcome, where (B) is something just below that which is desirable, or (A) may be the worst outcome, where (B) is just below that, but still quite bad. Often, the (B) phrase will express some kind of wish or demand that the speaker wants to meet with structures like たい, てほしい, てください, たらどう, つもり, といい, etc.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この作品は名作だとは言えないまでも、なかなかいい作品だと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This may not be a masterpiece, but I think that it is a pretty good piece.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 犯罪などは完全になくせないまでも、減らすように頑張るべきだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though it may not be possible to eliminate crime, we should try our best to reduce it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: プロ野球選手にはなれないまでも、プロ野球に関わる仕事をしているので満足している。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though I can't become a professional baseball player, I am satisfied because my job is related to professional baseball.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 毎週ではないまでも、娘に会えるだけ幸せだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm just happy to see my daughter, even if it's not every week.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 好きな仕事ができないから幸せじゃないまでも、生活費に困っていないから文句は言えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Even though I can't do what I love for work, I can't complain because I am not struggling with my bills.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これは不可能ではないまでも、実行するのは困難である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This may not be impossible, but carrying it out is hard.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: クビにはしないまでも、確実にボーナスは減額するつもりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though I may not fire you, I certainly plan on lowering your bonus at least.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: リザ：「大谷は一番ハンサムといわないまでも、かなりカッコいい男だと思うよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Riza: 'I won't say that Ooya is the most handsome, but I think he is quite a cool guy.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 急速充電はバッテリーを直ちに駄目にしないまでも、性能をより速く低下させる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Fast charging may not immediately damage the battery, but it will decrease its performance faster.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 初めてＪＬＰＴ Ｎ１を受験したが、合格できないまでも、せめて８０点は得点できたい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I took the JLPT N1 exam for the first time, I may not pass, but at least I want to get 80 points.

Name: を余所(よそ)に
Meaning: Ignoring, Disregarding, Despite
About: を余所(よそ)に is used to express that (A) is something that effectively has nothing to do with the speaker, or that the speaker is ignoring it in relation to something else. It may be translated as 'ignoring (A)', or 'disregarding (A)'. It is a combination of the adverbial particle を, the noun 余所(よそ) 'other place', and the case-marking particle に. Due to this, its literal meaning is close to 'putting (A) completely aside, (B)'. This structure will follow nouns, or phrases that have been nominalized with の. It is reasonably formal, so will be seen more often in writing. The most common pattern for をよそに to follow is that (A) expresses some overall situation, while (B) indicates an action that is being done without any thought or care given toward those circumstances. Because of this, it is often used critically about actions that are seen as irresponsible.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は親の心配をよそに、毎晩夜遅くまで友達と遊んでいる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ignoring his parent's worries, he hangs out with his friends every night until late at night.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 社長は社員の反対をよそに、仕事の効率を上げるために休憩所を撤去した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ignoring objections from his workers, the president got rid of the break room in order to increase efficiency.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は周囲の視線をよそに、コンビニの店員に暴言を吐き続けていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ignoring the eyes of those around him, he continued to lash out on the convenience store worker.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私は両親の反対をよそに、彼と結婚することにした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ignoring my parents' objections, I decided to marry him.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: メアリーと武は親の反対を余所に一緒になった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Ignoring objections from their parents, Mary and Takeshi got together.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 母の心配を余所に、彼は商船の船員になった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Ignoring his mother's worries, he has become a merchant seaman.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は泣いている子猫を余所に、そのまま猫を置き去りにして行ったのです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Disregarding that it was a crying kitten, he completely abandoned it and went like that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ピーターは周りの忠告を余所に、ＭＭＯＲＰＧゲームばかりすることを存分に楽しんだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Ignoring the advice of those close to him, Peter does nothing but play MMORPG games to his heart's content

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私たちがその衝撃的な言葉の意味をまだ飲み込めてないのを余所に彼女は説明を続けた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Ignoring that we still haven't digested the meaning of her shocking remark, she continued the explanation.

Name: に限(かぎ)ったことではない
Meaning: Not limited to, Not restricted to, Not only
About: に限(かぎ)ったことではない is a fairly emphatic expression that, like several other grammar patterns, makes use of the う-Verb 限(かぎ)る 'to limit'. It is a combination of the case-marking particle に, the past tense of 限(かぎ)る, 限(かぎ)った, the noun こと 'thing', the conjunctive form of the auxiliary verb だ, で, the adverbial particle は, and the い-Adjective, ない. The literal translation is 'it is not something that is limited to (A)', but other common interpretations include 'not only (A), but (B)', or 'not restricted to (A), (B) too'. This structure will be used following nouns, and tends to be reserved for fairly formal situations. This grammar pattern often indicates that (A) is something that is not especially rare, so should not be, or does not require to be treated in any special way.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近の若者は挨拶ができないと言われているが、若者に限ったことではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is said that young people these days can't greet people, but it is not limited to young people.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今日に限ったことではないが、なんか仕事する気にならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not limited to today, but for some reason I don't feel like working.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 文法が難しいのは日本語に限ったことではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Grammar being difficult is not something that is limited to Japanese.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 浮気をするのは男性に限ったことではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Cheating is not something that is limited to men.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 地震が頻繁に起きるのは日本に限ったことではありません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Frequently occuring earthquakes are not something that is limited to Japan.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 不幸が連続して起こるのは自分に限ったことではないと信じている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I believe that successive misfortunes are not something that is limited to me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 子犬にメロメロになるのは女の子に限ったことではない。父もメロメロだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Being infatuated with puppies is not something that is limited to girls. My father is infatuated too.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 松岡さんが宿題を忘れるのは今日に限ったことではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mr. Matsuoka forgetting to do his homework was not limited only to today.

Name: とは比(くら)べものにならない
Meaning: Nothing compared to, Cannot be compared to, Much more, Way better, Above comparison (beyond comparison), Far greater than
About: In order to emphasize that something is far beyond what could possibly be compared to (A), the emphatic phrase とは比(くら)べものにならない will be used. This is a combination of the case-marking particle と, the adverbial particle は, the neologism 比(くら)べもの 'a comparable thing', the case-marking particle に, and the negated form of the う-Verb なる 'to become', ならない. This may seem like a lot, but it is just expressing that '(A) will not be a comparable thing'. This structure will be used before nouns, where that noun is the thing that cannot be compared. This is usually due to quality, quantity, or some other feature that is easily measurable. As this grammar pattern is emphatic, it will indicate that the difference between (A) and (B) is quite large, without specifically expressing the amount. Additionally, like in the final example, we can sometimes see the use of the adverbial particle は a second time before ならない. This just adds further emphasis or highlights contrast.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: Ａ社の作る部品はいいが、Ｂ社の作る部品とは比べ物にならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Parts made by Company A are good, but they are not comparable to the parts made by Company B.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お母さんのスパゲティーとは比べものにならないが、ここのシェフが作るやつはなかなか美味しい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The spaghetti prepared by the chef here is quite good, but it is nothing compared to the spaghetti my mother makes.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 岐阜は寒いが、北海道とは比べものにはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Gifu is cold, but it is nothing compared to Hokkaido.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の絵画など須ノ宮さんのとは比べものにならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My paintings are nothing compared to Sunomiya's.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 日本の地震の多さはオーストラリアとは比べものにならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The amount of Japan’s earthquakes is beyond comparison to Australia.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 光の速さでも、この宇宙の大きさとは比べものにならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even the speed of light is nothing when compared to the size of the universe.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この寿司は悪くはないが良質の寿司とは比べものにならない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This sushi is not bad, but it is nothing compared to good quality sushi.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 北海道は寒いといえどもシベリアとは比べものにならないと思う。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though Hokkaido is cold, I think it is nothing when compared to Siberia.

Name: まじき
Meaning: Unbecoming of, Unworthy of, Not proper for, Should not, Must not, Cannot
About: まじき is the attributive form of まじ, a classical auxiliary verb that has been replaced almost entirely by まい 'must not', 'should not' in modern Japanese. まじ itself has this same meaning of 'must not', and will only be seen in a very limited number of formal expressions. Although slightly different in nuance, まじき is often translated simply as 'not proper for (A)', or 'unbecoming of (A)' in each case. The most common pattern that まじき will be seen in is (A) にあるまじき (B), where the case-marking particle に follows a noun, then is linked to the う-Verb ある, before まじき will connect to a second noun. Occasionally, に will be replaced by として 'as', with the rest of the structure remaining the same. 許(ゆる)すまじき 'must not be forgiven', or simply 'unforgivable' is another pattern that may be seen.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 生徒に手を挙げることは先生にあるまじき行為だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Raising your hand to a student is unbecoming of a teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は飲酒運転という警察官にあるまじき行動をし、クビになった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He was fired for drunk driving, an unbecoming behavior for a police officer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 先日、斉藤首相は総理としてあるまじき発言をし、SNSで炎上している。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently, Prime Minister Saito has been under fire on social media for making comments that are unbecoming of a prime minister.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は医師としてあるまじきミスをしてしまい、医師免許を剥奪された。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He made a mistake that was unbecoming of a physician and was stripped of his medical license.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 煽り運転のような許すまじき行為をした場合、免許は取り消しになります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you commit unforgivable acts such as tailgating, your license will be revoked.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: リヒャルトは王としてあるまじき汚名を着せられ、やがて廃位された。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Richard was tarred with the stigma unbecoming of the position of the king and was eventually dethroned.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 言うまでもないが、公金横領など政治家としてあるまじき行為だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It goes without saying, but something like misappropriation of public funds is an act unbecoming of a statesman.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 妻を下げるような発言をするなんて、夫にあるまじき行為だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Something like saying remarks that bring down his wife, it is behavior that is unbecoming of a husband.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 戦場から離脱することは武士にあるまじき行為と咎められ、罰せられた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Fleeing from the battlefield was condemned as unbecoming of a warrior and punished.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ララティーナは貴族にあるまじき態度で、甘やかされた子供のようなふるまいをした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Lalatina behaved in a manner unbecoming of a noble, like a spoiled child.

Name: の至(いた)り
Meaning: Utmost, Height of, Extreme, Heartiest, Such a, Very, really, Completely, Deeply
About: の至(いた)り is a set, formal expression used to highlight that (A) is the highest level of something, and will often be used positively, although not exclusively. It is a combination of the case-marking particle の, and the noun 至(いた)り 'pinnacle', or 'climax'. Common translations include 'the utmost (A)', or 'the extreme of (A). To use this structure, attach it to the end of a noun, where that noun is the 'limit' for whatever is being expressed. (A) is usually some emotion that can be experienced to a high degree when confronted with certain situations such as 光栄(こうえい) 'honor', 赤面(せきめん) 'embarrassment', 感謝(かんしゃ) 'gratefulness', 恐縮(きょうしゅく) 'obligation', etc.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここ４年間色々と教えていただき、恐縮の至りです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am extremely grateful for the many things you have taught me over the last four years.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このような大切な式に、こんな私を招待してくださったことは光栄の至りです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am extremely honored that you invited me to such an important ceremony.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 色々とアドバイスをしていただいて、感謝の至りです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am extremely grateful for all the advice you have given me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大学生の頃は若気の至りでたくさん悪いことをしてしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I did a lot of bad things when I was in college, due to an extreme moment of youthful indiscretion.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 演説：「特別賞を受賞することになり、光栄の至りです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Speech: 'Receiving the special reward is an extreme honor.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「このような小さな誤りに気づくのに数日もかかるとは、赤面の至りです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I am extremely ashamed that it took a few days to notice such a simple mistake.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 演説：「たいそうな品をいただき、恐縮の至りです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Speech: 'We are extremely grateful for your generous gift.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: インタビュー：「ファンや映画評論家の皆さまから肯定的なレビューをいただき、感激の至りです」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Interview: 'We are extremely moved by the positive reviews we have received from fans and film critics.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 伝記：「若気の至りで、給料の良い仕事を辞めて独立開業した。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Biography: 'Due to an extreme moment of youthful indiscretion, I had quit a well-paid job and started an independent business.'

Name: に恥(は)じない
Meaning: Lives up to, Truly to …’s name, Worthy of, Not dishonor, Not putting to shame, Measure to
About: When showing that something lives up to an expected standard or level of quality, the phrase に恥(は)じない will be used. This is a combination of the case-marking particle に, and the negated form of the る-Verb 恥(は)じる 'to shame'. The literal translation is 'without shaming (A)'. This structure will follow nouns. In many cases, (A) will be a word indicating an aspect of something that has come to be well known. Examples of this are 名(な) name, 名誉(めいよ) 'reputation', etc. As に恥(は)じない has the nuance of 'not shaming (A)', or 'not damaging the reputation of (A)', it will usually only be used in positive contexts, where someone or something is being praised.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの大学のバスケチームは日本一という名に恥じない強さだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That university's basketball team's strength lives up to its name of being the best in Japan.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本代表の名に恥じないよう、ベストを尽くします。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will do my best to live up to the name of a representative of Japan.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 会社の名に恥じないよう、精一杯頑張ります。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will do my best to live up to the name of the company.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: サハラ砂漠の名に恥じない天候だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is a weather that lives up to the name of the Sahara desert.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 店のウェブサイト：「当店は８０年培った信頼と伝統に恥じないサービスをご提供致します。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Shop's website: 'Our shop provides services that live up to the trust and the tradition we have built over 80 years .'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 昇格する演説：「ブランド名に恥じないよう、精一杯努めさせていただきます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Being promoted speech: 'I will work as hard as I can to live up to the brand's name.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ホテルのウェブサイト：「五つ星ホテルの名に恥じないサービスをお客様に提供しております。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Hotel's website: 'We provide a service for our guests that lives up to the name of a five star hotel.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 受賞の演説：「この賞に恥じないよう、これからも最善を尽くすつもりです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Receiving award speech: 'I intend to continue doing my best to live up to this award.'

Name: ずじまい
Meaning: Ended up not, Did not (in the end), Never did
About: ずじまい is a grammar structure that combines the literary form of the classical auxiliary verb ぬ, ず 'not', and the voiced conjunctive form of the う-Verb しまう 'to finish', or 'to bring to a close', じまい. Like しまう, ずじまい will often indicate regret at something ending up a certain way. However, this regret is about '(A) not happening', due to the negation provided by ず. This structure will be used following the indeterminate form of verbs. Common translations include 'to end up not (A)', and 'to not have done (A) in the end'. ずじまい will often be followed by だった or でした, indicating that (A) was not something that turned out happening, despite the wishes or intentions of the doer.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: マウンテンバイクを買ったが、使わずじまいで売ってしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bought a mountain bike, but I ended up selling it without using it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: コンサートのチケットを買ったが、色々とやることがあって行かずじまいだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bought the ticket to the concert, but I had a lot on my plate so I ended up not going.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 日本で使うために電子辞書を持っていったが、持ち運ぶのが面倒だったから結局使わずじまいだった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I brought my electronic dictionary to Japan to use it there, but I ended up not using it because it was a pain to carry it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 好きな子に告白せずじまいで、高校を卒業してしまった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I ended up graduating highschool without confessing my feelings to the girl I liked.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「結局、やらずじまいで新学期になっちゃったよ。」
Ｂ：「なにをやらなかったの？」
Ａ：「夏休みの宿題…」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'I ended up not doing it, and the new school term started.'
B: 'What did you not do?'
A: 'The summer homework...'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「宇崎さんと映画館に行こうと思っていたけど、仕事から手が離せなくて結局行けずじまいだった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I planned to go to the cinema with Uzaki, but I couldn't get away from work, so I ended up not going.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「事故の原因について調べようとしたが、ついにわからずじまいだった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'I tried to investigate the cause of the accident, but I ended up not discovering anything.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「最新の愛Ｐｈｏｎｅを買おうとストアに１０時間並んだのに、自分の番が来る頃には欲しい色がもう売り切れていて結局買えずじまいだった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I stood for 10 hours in line to buy the new 愛Phone, but when my turn came, it turned out that the color I wanted had already sold out, so I ended up not buying it.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「日本語の教科書をたくさん買ったけど、結局使わずじまいだった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I bought lots of Japanese textbooks, but I ended up not using them.'

Name: に言(い)わせると
Meaning: If you ask, In … opinion, According to
About: に言(い)わせれば is a structure that will be attached to nouns, in order to indicate a person or group that is giving a strong opinion. It is usually translated as 'if you ask (A), (B)', or 'according to (A), (B)'. The literal meaning is 'if (A) is allowed to speak, (B)', as this pattern is just a combination of the case-marking particle に, the う-Verb 言(い)う 'to say' followed by the hypothetical form of the auxiliary verb せる, せれ 'to allow to do', and the conjunction particle ば. To use this structure, simply attach it to the end of a noun marking the person or group whose opinion is being given. Other hypothetical structures such as と and たら may also be used, but ば is the most common. Additionally, this pattern may sound self-important, so is best used sparingly, especially when giving your own opinions. Occasionally, から will be used instead of に.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私に言わせれば５キロを２５分で走るのは簡単だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you ask me, running 5km in 25 minutes is easy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私はあのパーソナルトレーナーは厳しすぎると思ったが、彼に言わせれば優しすぎるらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I thought that that personal trainer was too strict, but according to him, he is apparently too nice.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 専門家に言わせれば、もっと早い対応をするべきだったそうです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: According to a specialist, we should have dealt with it earlier.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私から言わせれば、なんでそんなことして許されると思ったのかがわからない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In my opinion, I don't know why they thought they would be forgiven after doing such a thing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私に言わせればあなたが買ったスマホは不良品だよ。もう３回も壊れたんだから！
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you ask me, the smartphone you bought is a defective product. It has fallen apart 3 times already!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ドイツ側に言わせればオーストラリア企業は初めは経済協力に反対していたという。
Questions.EnglishHTML: According to the German side, the Australian companies were opposed to cooperation from the beginning.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 会社の観点からすれば、結果は失敗とみなされるかもしれないが、少なくとも私に言わせれば、完全な失敗というわけではない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: From the company's point of view, the results might be considered a failure, but it does not mean it was a complete failure, at least if you ask me.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 君にとっては面白いのだろうが、私に言わせれば、ただの無礼にしかすぎない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For you it might be funny, but if you ask me, it is just rude.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 武田さんに言わせれば、最近の若者はまったくお年寄りを敬わないとのこと。
Questions.EnglishHTML: According to Mr. Takeda, youth these days do not respect their elders at all.

Name: ずくめ
Meaning: Completely, Entirely, All in, Nothing but, A real streak of, Without exception, Jet
About: Originally stemming from the suffix use of 尽(づ)く 'completely', or 'using solely', and the addition of め, ずくめ came to be preferentially written as hiragana, with ず replacing づ. This structure may be translated as 'completely (A)', 'all in (A)', or 'nothing but (A)'. Generally, it is attached directly to nouns, and expresses that (A) is to such an extent that nothing apart from (A) can be seen, felt, or noticed. In cases where ずくめ will directly modify the following noun, の will come between ずくめ and that noun. Although づくめ may occasionally be seen in older literature, it is mostly considered incorrect kana usage these days. While ずくめ may be used in either positive or negative contexts, it is mainly seen in set expressions, so is best used with combinations that you have already heard or read.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今月も仕事ずくめになりそうだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems like I'm going to be doing nothing but work again this month.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 最近は嫌なことずくめで全然楽しくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I'm not having the best time right now, because nothing but bad things are happening.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は黒ずくめの男たちに誘拐された。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He was kidnapped by men covered in black.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 警察への電話：「もしもし、家の前に黒ずくめの車が何台も止まっているんで今から言う住所まできてもらってもいいですか。」
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Calling the cops: Hello, there are several jet black cars parked in front of my house, so could you please come to the address I'm about to tell you?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 国づくしの偉い人が集まった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Great people from all sorts of countries gathered.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 新聞の見出し：「６月猛暑記録ずくめ」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Newspaper headline: 'June - A Heatwave full of Temperature Records'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 規制は必要であるが規則ずくめで窒息しそうな社会は強圧的ではないだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Regulations are needed, but isn't a society that is about to suffocate with nothing but restrictions overbearing ?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ２０２０年は異例ずくめの大変な年でしたが何とか乗り切りました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: 2020 was a very challenging year full of irregularities, but we somehow got through it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ツイッターの投稿：「朝から晩まで、ごちそうずくめで結婚を祝う。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Twitter post: 'We are celebrating the marriage with nothing but delicacies from morning till night.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 黒ずくめのスーツに身を包んだ男はベンチに座り、逆さに持った新聞を読むふりをしていた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A man dressed in a completely black suit was sitting on a bench and pretending to read a newspaper that was upside down.

Name: には及(およ)ばない ②
Meaning: To be no match (for), To not compare (with), To fall short (of), To not reach, Cannot win with, To be out of reach (for), To not be on par (with)
About: As mentioned in the には及(およ)ばない grammar point lesson as a polite expression, には及(およ)ばない may simply show the extent of something. This is usually when a comparison is being made between two things. This pattern is a combination of the case-marking marking particle に, the adverbial particle は, and the negated form of the う-Verb 及(およ)ぶ 'to reach', 及(およ)ばない. The literal translation is 'it does not extend to (A)'. This nuance of the phrase will appear after nouns. In this comparative use, the structure may also be translated as 'to be no match for (A)', 'to fall short of (A)', 'to not be on par with (A)'. には及(およ)ばない will be used most frequently when (A) is something that is being given extremely high praise. As such, set combinations like (A) の足元(あしもと)には及(およ)ばない 'to not even reach the feet of (A)' will often be seen.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この海は沖縄の海には及ばないが、結構綺麗だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This beach is no match for the beaches in Okinawa, but it is quite beautiful.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの一流レストランの味には及ばないが、かなり似ている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The taste is no match for that top-notch restaurant, but it is very similar.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はものすごくギターが上手いが、布袋寅泰には及ばない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He is very good at playing the guitar, but he is no match for Hotei Tomoyasu.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どれだけ頑張っても、青木先輩の足元には及ばない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how hard I try, I am no match for Aoki senpai.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 言うまでもなく真作には及ばないでしょうが、いい贋作です。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Needless to say, it is no match for the original. Even still, it is a good forgery.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「物理学では、とてもアルバートには及ばない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I am no match for Albert in physics.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 続編は立派なものの、明らかに最初の映画には及ばない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though the sequel is splendid, it is clearly not on par with the first movie.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「はるこの嗅覚は、犬には及ばないが、普通の人間のよりはるかにすぐれている。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'Haruko's sense of smell was no match for a dog's. However, it was far better than an ordinary human's.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「どんなに練習してもさいたま先生の足元には及ばない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'No matter how much I train, I am no match for Saitama-sensei.'

Name: とは言(い)うものの
Meaning: Although, But, Although I say, Although it is said, Having said that
About: とは言(い)うものの is a set expression that may be used after most types of words, it is a combination of と as a case-marking particle, は as an adverbial particle, the う-Verb 言(い)う, and the conjunction particle ものの 'although'. Its literal translation of 'although it is said that (A), (B)' is the same as how it will usually be interpreted in English. When used after either nouns or な-Adjectives, だ will precede とは言(い)うものの. This phrase may also be used at the beginning of sentences when acknowledging a statement that was made, but then pointing out that there is other important information as well. In all cases, the (B) phrase that comes after ものの will be considered the important or defining detail.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: なんでも頑張れば必ずできるようになるとはいうものの、どれだけ頑張ってもできないことはある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although it is said that you will be able to do something if you try your best, there are things that can't be done no matter how much you try.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今働いている会社の給料はいいとはいうものの、お金を使う時間がない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although the pay at my current company is good, I don't have any time to use my money.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: スマホは便利だというものの、使い方がわからないとスマホの便利さをしれきれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although it is said that smartphones are useful, if you don't know how to use them, you can't fully appreciate their usefulness.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は学生だというものの、バイトばかりしていて勉強についていけていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Although he is a student, he is falling behind with his studies because he works a lot.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 数学は時間の無駄だとは言うものの、やはり基本を知る価値だってある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although it is said that math is a waste of time, actually, learning the basics still has its value.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼はホラー作家として知られているとは言うものの、傑作と言えるものは１９８２年に出版された犯罪小説だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although he is known as a horror author, what can be called his masterpiece is actually a crime novel that was published in 1982.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: チェコの「ストラホフ・スタジアム」は「世界最大のスポーツスタジアム」とは言うものの、実際にはスポーツ目的にはほとんど使われていない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although the Czech 'Strahov Stadium' is said to be the 'world's largest sports stadium', in practice it is hardly used for sports purposes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このカフェは人気が高いとは言うものの、実際には知る人ぞ知る所だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although I say that this coffeehouse is popular, actually that's limited to the people that know the place.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: それは「人工知能」とは言うものの、まだ「知能」というよりも「コンピューター」に近いものだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Although that is called 'artificial intelligence', it is still closer to a 'computer' than actual 'intelligence'.

Name: が早(はや)いか
Meaning: As soon as, No sooner than, The instant that, No sooner had
About: が早(はや)いか is an expression in Japanese that groups with verbs, for the purpose of indicating an action which is immediately followed by a second, often unexpected action. It is a combination of the case-marking particle が, the い-Adjective 早(はや)い 'soon', and the adverbial particle か. It is often translated as 'no sooner than (A), (B)', or 'the instant that (A), (B)'.
