The more literal translation, taking into account the use of か, is '(A), or possibly sooner, (B)'. This just illustrates the instantaneousness of the (B) action in that (A) was unable to be determined as actually completed before (B) started. This grammar pattern is formal, and will follow verbs in their dictionary or past tense forms. The verb that comes in the (B) phrase will always be in the past tense. (A) will tend to be actions that happen momentarily, or having a clearly defined finish point. For actions that don't have a clearly defined finish point, 終(お)わる 'to finish' will often be linked to the stem form, in order to specify the end. Additionally, while the (B) action will often be unexpected, it will also usually be volitional, that is to say something done intentionally.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女は彼が書いた手紙を読むが早いか、悲しさのあまりで泣き始めた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As soon as she read the letter from her boyfriend, she started to cry out of sadness.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子は食卓に座るが早いか、並べてあった夕食を吸い込むように食い上げた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As soon as my son sat at the dining table, he ate all the food that was out as if he sucked them up.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 木村くんはアラームが鳴ったが早いか、スヌーズボタンを押した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As soon as the alarm went off, Kimura-kun pressed the snooze button.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 警察官は犯人を見つけたが早いか、犯人に飛びつき手錠をかけた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As soon as the police officer saw the suspect, he jumped onto him and handcuffed him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 雨が止むが早いか、出かけるつもりだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As soon as the rain stops, I am planning to go out. (Unnatural Japanese)

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 俺は毎日家に荷物を置くが早いか、友達の家に行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I go to my friends house as soon as I drop my stuff off at home, everyday. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: お母さんがケーキを焼き上げるが早いか、お父さんが食べ始めた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As soon as mom had baked the cake, dad started eating it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 黒ずくめの男は探偵を見つけたが早いか、疾風のごとく駆け出した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As soon as the man dressed completely in black noticed the detective, he dashed off like the wind.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 夜、幼い魔法使いが窓を開けるが早いか、白フクロウが飛び込んできた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: At night, as soon as the young wizard opened the window, a white owl flew in.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 自動ドアが開くが早いか、まもなく人々は電車に乗り込んだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: As soon as the automatic doors opened, people promptly entered the train.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「田中は目が覚めたが早いかベッドから飛び起きた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'As soon as Tanaka opened his eyes, he jumped out of bed.'

Name: に難(かた)くない
Meaning: Not hard to, Not difficult to, Easy to, Is obvious that
About: にかたくない is a formal grammar pattern that uses a different version of the い-Adjective 難(むずか)しい 'difficult', 難(かた)い, which has the same meaning. This adjective will be used in the negative, in order to indicate that something is 'not difficult'. The case-marking particle に at the beginning is limited to following verbs that indicate thinking or conjecture. This structure will only appear with quite a limited number of verbs, with 想像(そうぞう) 'to imagine', 予想(よそう) 'to predict', 察(さっ)する 'to infer' or 'to sense', 理解(りかい) 'to understand', and 推測(すいそく) 'to guess' making up the majority of them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そう言う叱り方は子供にいい影響を与えないだろうことは想像に難くない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not hard to imagine that scolding children like that would not have a positive effect on the child.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このプロジェクトを中止したら多くの人に迷惑がかかることは予想に難くない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not hard to guess that canceling this project would end up inconveniencing a lot of people.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 子供を亡くした親たちの気持ちは理解に難くない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is not difficult to understand the feelings of parents who have lost their children.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ピラミッドが、古代人に畏敬の念を抱かせたであろうことは、想像に難くない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not hard to imagine the awe that the pyramids likely inspired in the ancients.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 飛行機が墜落すれば乗客に何が起こるかは察するに難くない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not hard to guess what happens to passengers when an airplane crashes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: その日の悲惨な出来事が、大いに影響していただろうことは想像に難くない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not hard to imagine that the tragic events of that day likely affected her greatly.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暴力に満ちているこのゲームが９０年代に論争を巻き起こした理由は理解に難くない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not hard to understand the reason why this game that is filled with violence caused controversy in the '90s.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: バスの運転手がいかに大きな責任を背負っているか、想像に難くない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It is not hard to imagine how much responsibility a bus driver shoulders.

Name: ならいざ知(し)らず
Meaning: Don’t know about it, Maybe it would or might be possible for
About: ならいざ知(し)らず is a grammar expression which combines the hypothetical form of the auxiliary verb だ, なら, the adverb いざ ‘now’, or ‘well then’, and the classically-negated form of the う-Verb 知(し)る, 知(し)らず ‘to not know’. It is often translated as ‘I don’t know about (A), but (B)’, or ‘maybe (A), but (B). This phrase is formal, and usually used to emphasize that, regardless of (A), (B) fits a specific description. ならいざ知(し)らず will follow verbs in their standard forms. Additionally, it may follow either な-Adjectives or nouns that have had their terminal だ replaced with なら. Just like the literal translation of ‘if it’s (A), well then I don’t know’, this structure emphasizes that (A) may or may not be the case, but (B) is definite. However, there is no direct use of ‘but’ in Japanese. This shows that the ‘but’ comes from the simple contrast of (A) being unknown while (B) is known. ならいざ知(し)らず may also be seen following other structures such as い-Adjectives when they have been nominalized with の. This の pattern is also used with verbs, but it is less common than simply attaching ならいざしらず to one of the standard verb forms.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 結婚式かなんかに出席するならいざ知らず、友達の家に行くだけなんだからスーツなんて着ていかなくてもいいんじゃない？
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't know if you're going to a wedding or something, but since you're just going to your friend's house, you probably don't have to wear a suit.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: １５分待つならいざ知らず、いくら友達でも３０分以上待つのは無理だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It may be possible for me to wait for 15 minutes, but I won’t be able to wait more than 30 minutes, no matter how good of a friend they are.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 経験豊富で仕事が上手ならいざ知らず、まだ始めたばかりの子にこの仕事を任せるのはかわいそうすぎますよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don’t know about people that have a lot of experience and are good at their jobs, but I feel bad giving such work to a person that just started.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 平日ならいざ知らず、連休中に遊園地などのようなところに行く人は多いだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't know about weekdays, but I’m sure that there are a lot of people that go to places like amusement parks during holidays.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 新しいのならいざ知らず、前のモデルはよく勝手に電源が落ちたからあまり売れなかったらしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don’t know about the new ones, but the older models didn’t sell well because they would turn off on their own.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 大昔ならいざ知らず、現代では詐欺についてよくテレビやインターネットで話題になっているから、詐欺の手口も年々と進化していってる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don’t know about the past, but nowadays, scams are often talked about on TV and the internet today, so scam tactics are evolving year by year.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 神ならいざ知らず、俺みたいなやつにはああいうことをする奴たちを許すことなどできない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don't know about the gods, but it is very hard for a person like me to forgive people that do things like that.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ６０年前はいざ知らず、今では喫煙する人が減ってきている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I don’t know about 60 years ago, but nowadays, there are less people that smoke.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １万円は社会人ならいざ知らず、小学生にとっては想像を絶する金額だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't know about working adults, but for children, 10 000 yen is an unimaginable amount of money.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １００年前ならいざ知らず、現代のこの国においては情報へのアクセスは容易になっているからそのようなことを誰でも知っているはずだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I don't know about 100 years ago, but in modern times, since access to information is widespread in this country, everybody should know something like that.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「運動は不健康だからしない」と最近よく聞く。プロのスポーツ選手ならいざ知らず、一般の人ならば、運動は有益である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Recently, I often hear that 'exercising is unhealthy, so I don't do it'. I don't know about professional athletes, but for ordinary people exercising is beneficial.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「子供の頃、ここでザリガニを釣ったものだ。」
Ｂ：「昔ならいざ知らず、現代では川が汚染されているから​​無理です。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'When I was a child, I used to catch crayfish here.'
B 'I don't know about how it was in the past, but nowadays the river is polluted, so it's impossible.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「自分一人で衣装を着て楽しむのならいざ知らず、人前にコスプレ姿で出るのは私にとっては不可能に近いです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'It might be possible to wear the costume by myself for fun, but when it comes to going out in public dressed in cosplay, then it's nigh on impossible!

Name: を禁(きん)じ得(え)ない
Meaning: Cannot help feeling, Cannot but, Cannot hold back
About: を禁(きん)じ得(え)ない is a formal grammar pattern used to express that one ‘cannot help feeling (A)’, or ‘cannot hold back from (A)’. It is primarily used connected to words that express emotions, or things that are the result of emotions, such as tears or laughter. This is a combination of the adverbial particle を, the conjunctive form of the る-Verb 禁(きん)じる ‘to prohibit’, and the 得(え)ない pattern which means ‘to not gain’, but is used in a similar way to できない. を禁(きん)じ得(え)ない will be seen following nouns, or occasionally verbs that have been nominalized with の.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 初めて広島にある平和記念資料館に行ったとき、涙をこらえるのを禁じ得なかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I could not hold back my tears when I went to the peace museum in Hiroshima for the first time.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子が生まれたが、いい父親になれるか不安を禁じ得ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have a son, but I can't stop worrying about whether I will be a good father.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 税金を国民のためではなく自分たちのためだけに使う政治家に怒りを禁じ得ない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I cannot help but be outraged at politicians who spend taxpayers' money only on themselves and not on the people.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はあのシーンを見て涙を禁じ得ないようだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems like he was not able to hold back his tears when he saw that scene. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この生徒たちは流暢な日本語でニュースについて議論していたが、彼らは二年前から日本語を勉強し始めたと聞いて、驚きを禁じ得なかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I could not help being surprised, hearing that these students who were discussing the news in fluent Japanese, had started studying it two years ago.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この不況の中、政治家が自分の給与を上げるとの報道を耳にし、怒りを禁じ得ません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot help but feel anger upon hearing the news that the politicians raised their salaries during this time of recession.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 伝記：「戦争がこの地方にもたらした破壊を見て、涙を禁じ得なかった。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Biography: 'I could not hold back tears after seeing the destruction that the war brought upon this area.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 長い年月の後、互いに抱き合った姿に、喜びを禁じ得ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot help but feel joy at seeing those two embracing one another after all these years.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 全てを失った地震の被害者に同情の念を禁じ得ない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I cannot help feeling compassion for the victims of the earthquake, who lost everything.

Name: に託(かこつ)けて
Meaning: In the name of, Using the excuse of, To use as a pretext of, Under the guise or pretense of
About: に託(かこつ)けて is a structure based on the case-marking particle に, and the る-Verb 託(かこつ)ける ‘to consign as’, or ‘to label as’. As this translation doesn’t exhibit the same nuance well in English all the time, it is commonly interpreted as ‘in the name of (A)’, or ‘under the pretense of (A)’. に託(かこつ)けて will be used after nouns, or verbs that have been nominalized with の.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 病院に行くというのに託けて仕事を休んだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I took a day off work under the pretense of going to the hospital.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の家に忘れ物をしたというのに託けて彼のところにもう一度行く。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will go to his place again under the pretense that I left something at his place.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女はいつも何かにかこつけて僕の家に来ようとする。本当にやめてほしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She always tries to come to my place under the pretense of something. I really want her to stop.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 風邪にかこつけて、授業を休んで一日中テレビを見ながらダラダラしていた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Using the pretext of a cold, I skipped class and loafed around and watched TV all day.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 靴ひもを結ぶのに託けて落ちていた財布をこっそりと拾った。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I sneakily picked up the wallet that was on the ground, labeling it as tying my shoelace.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あいつは出張に託けて、また釣りに行っているに違いない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I bet he has gone fishing again, consigning it as a business trip.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「花子ったら部活動に託けて、部室に潜り込んでひとり遊んでばかりいるよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'Speaking of Hanako, she sneaks into the club room under the pretense of club activity and just lazes around.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人（私も含めて）はお菓子が大好きで何かに託けていつも買ってしまうのではないだろうか。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I think that people (myself included) love sweets and will always buy them under some pretext.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
武田：「田中さんったら出張に託けてパリを観光するつもりね。」
田中さん：「いやいや、そんなこと。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Takeda: 'Tanaka-san, you're planning to go sightseeing in Paris using the pretense of a business trip, aren't you?'
Tanaka: 'No no, nothing like that.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「あすかさんと会いたいけどどうしたらいい？」
Ｂ：「プリントを渡すというのに託けて家に行ったらどう？」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'I want to meet with Asuka, but what should I do?'
B: 'How about going to her house under the pretext of intending to give her printouts?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 風邪に託けて、仕事を休んで一日中コーラを飲んだりゲームをしてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Using the pretext of a cold, he took some time off work, drank coke, and played games all day long.

Name: 様(よう)によっては
Meaning: Depending on the way, Depending on how
About: ようによっては is used in Japanese to indicate that the way in which something is done will determine the result. This structure is a combination of the noun 様(よう) ‘manner’, or ‘way’, the case-marking particle に, the て-form of the う-Verb, よる ‘to depend on (A)’, or ‘to be due to (A)’, and the adverbial particle は. The standard translation is ‘depending on the way that (A), (B)’. ようによっては will often highlight results that vary greatly from person to person, or from one method to the other. This grammar pattern will appear after the conjunctive form of verbs.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この映画は見ようによってはコメディーだと感じる人もいるだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Some people may see this movie as a comedy film, depending on how they watch it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ４５分で行けるはずだけど、混みようによっては１時間半かかることもあり得るから明日は少し早く家を出よう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We should be able to get there in 45 minutes, but depending on how congested the road is, it could take an hour and a half, so let’s leave a bit early tomorrow.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: どんなに安全な機械であっても使いようによってはとても危険になることもある。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No matter how safe a machine is, it could become very dangerous depending on how you use it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この絵は見方によっては奇麗な女性かウサギに見える。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Depending on how you look at this picture, it may look like a beautiful lady or a rabbit.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このドレスの色は見ようによっては「青と黒」か「白と金」に見えるかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Depending on how you look at it, the color of this dress may seem like it's 'blue and black' or 'white and gold'.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「結構です」は聞きようによっては肯定にでも否定にでもどちらにでも受け取れる。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Depending on the way you hear it, '結構です' can be taken either as affirmation or denial.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 経済危機は、一見絶望しかないように見えるが、考えようによっては素晴らしい機会とも言えるかもしれない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The economic crisis may seem to be nothing but despair. However, depending on the way you think about it, it might also be called a great opportunity.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 確かに、この大きな目のクモは、見ようによっては可愛いらしいと言えなくもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Needless to say, depending on the way you look at this big-eyed spider, it can kind of be called adorable.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このツイートは読みようによっては皮肉にも取れるだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Depending on the way you read this tweet, you could take it as irony, right!?

Name: べくもない
Meaning: No (doubt or hope), There is no way, It is impossible, Not a hope in hell
About: As mentioned in the several other grammar structures that include べく,  this structure is the conjunctive form of the classical auxiliary verb べし ‘shall’. It will be attached to the dictionary form of verbs in order to convey the purpose, necessity, or likelihood of an action. When combined with the adverbial particle も, and the い-Adjective ない, it is often translated as ‘it is impossible to (A)’, or ‘there is no way to (A)’. べくもない is a pattern that usually appears with verbs highlighting the thinking or emotions of the speaker, and how that action is impossible or inconceivable for them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自分が作ったパスタはあの有名シェフが作るパスタと比べるべくもないが、結構おいしいと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is impossible to compare the pasta I made with the one made by that famous chef, but I think mine is quite tasty.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの顔を見てみろ、あいつが彼を殺したという事は疑うべくもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Look at that face, there is no doubt that they are the one that killed him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私自身が先生になるまでは、先生の大変さなど知るべくもなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Until I became a teacher myself, I could never have known how hard it is to be a teacher.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの中古車販売店が詐欺まがいなことをやっていたということは、否定するべくもない事実だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no doubt that that used car dealership was doing something that could be considered as a scam.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そんな解決策では問題が解決すべくもない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is no way that we can solve the problem with such a solution.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「戦力差は歴然としているゆえ、まともな勝負は望むべくもない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'Since the difference in strength is clear, there is no hope of a decent match.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: いくら頑張ったところで、絵は写真にはおよぶべくもないのである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter how much one tries, a drawing is no match for a photograph.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 地球温暖化は人間活動と直接関係があるということは疑うべくもない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no doubt that global warming is directly linked to human influence.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「今回、彼は危害を免れたにせよ、そのように運転を続けていては将来は彼に何事が起りかねぬかは、知るべくもない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'Even though he escaped injury this time, there is no way to know what might happen to him in the future if he continues driving like that.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「この真正直な少年に、嘘をつくなど望むべくもない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'There's not a hope in hell that this honest boy would lie.'

Name: と来(き)たら ②
Meaning: For …(is the best), When it comes to, Concerning
About: When used in the more literal sense, ときたら is a grammar pattern that means ‘when it comes to (A)’, or ‘concerning (A)’. It is a combination of the case-marking particle と, and 来(く)る combined with the conjunction particle たら ‘if’, 来(き)たら. This is not to be confused with the alternative translation of ときたら which is ‘that damned (A)’ when used for criticism. ときたら will attach to the end of a phrase marking what the conversation is ‘concerning’, before that topic will then be explained further. In other words, (A) will present the topic, while (B) will indicate the speaker’s first instinctive thoughts about that topic. For the speaker, (A) is usually something that strongly makes them think of (B). However, it may just be that the relationship between (A) and (B) is a thing that the speaker is implying as obvious, or that goes without saying. Due to this, the (B) phrase often begins with やっぱり or やはり ‘sure enough’.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 夏ときたらやっぱりキンキンに冷えたビールですよ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When it comes to summer, as expected, a cold beer is the best!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 寒い日ときたら、鍋でしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: For a cold day, hot pots (is the best), don't you think?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: パワハラときたら大問題になるのは当然でしょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: When it comes to power harassment, of course it is going to become a huge problem.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「田中さんがクビになったと聞いたよ。」
「毎日遅刻ときたらクビになるのは当然でしょ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'I heard Mr. Tanaka got fired.'
'No wonder he would get fired when he was late every day.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ドーナツときたらやっぱり牛乳でしょ！
Questions.EnglishHTML: For donuts, as expected, it's gotta be milk, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テストで毎回０点を取っているときたら、お母さんが怒らないわけがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When you get a zero on every test, there's no way your mother won't get angry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 暑い日ときたら、やっぱり麦茶よね。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For a hot day, as expected, there's nothing like barley tea, right?

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こんなに曇っているときたら、雨が降らないはずがない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When it is so cloudy, it is impossible for it not to rain.

Name: ものとして
Meaning: Assuming, Supposing, (Interpret) as, On the assumption, Regarding, Considering
About: Like many grammar expressions that use もの, this noun will imply that the word or phrase that comes before it is a strong determination. Due to this, when として ‘as (A)’, or ‘in the capacity of (A)’ is added, it presents a situation in which the speaker is determining that (A) is true for the sake of discussion. In English, this may be interpreted as ‘supposing that (A)’, or ‘on the assumption that (A)’. ものとして will primarily be seen after verbs, and nouns followed by な. However, it may also occasionally appear after い-Adjectives.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もう一時間もたつので、出席しないものとして会議を始めましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It’s already been an hour, so let’s assume that they are not attending and start the meeting.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: みんなが参加できるものとして計画を立てましょう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Let’s make a plan on the assumption that everyone would be able to attend.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日のテストは難しいものとして勉強したが、実際に受けてみたら全然余裕だった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I studied for yesterday’s test with the assumption that it was going to be difficult, but when it came to actually taking the test, it was easy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼のアイデアは不可能なものとして、誰も彼のアイデアを取り入れようとしなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: No one even considered implementing his idea on the assumption that it was impossible.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の説明はありえないとして、聞き流されました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: His explanation was seen as impossible, and was dismissed.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼の説明はありえないものとして、聞き流されました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: His explanation was assumed to be something which was impossible, and therefore dismissed. (Slightly more verbose, creating a feeling of stiffness or formality)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: これ以上討議しても進展は見込めないものとして、これをもって会議はお開きとします。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Considering no further progress can be made in the discussion, with this the meeting is closed.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 講師：「ご質問等はありますか？ない場合は理解したものとして今日はここまでです。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Lecturer: 'Do you have any questions? If not, I will assume that you understood, and that will be all for today.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大学のサイト：「先生からの連絡は一度掲示された内容については１週間後、全学生に伝達されたものとして扱います。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: University website: 'Once posted, communications from the teacher will be assumed to have been delivered to all students after one week.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 格闘技においては選手は畳やマットを３回叩くと降参したものとして、試合の決着がつく。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In martial arts, a match will be regarded as forfeited when a fighter strikes the tatami or mat three times.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: しかしながら、市長は、住民の心配事を、ありえないものとして、却下しました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: However, the mayor dismissed the residents' worries, supposing they were improbable.

Name: を前提(ぜんてい)に
Meaning: On the premise of
About: を前提(ぜんてい)に is a pattern that combines the adverbial particle を, the noun 前提(ぜんてい) ‘premise’ or ‘hypothesis’, and the case-marking particle に. It is often translated as ‘on the premise of (A)’, and marks something as the base thought or goal toward which some other (B) action is being taken. This structure will be used following nouns, or verbs that have been nominalized with こと. Alternatively, either にして or として may be used in place of に by itself. This only slightly changes the nuance in the same way that is to be expected of these structures. を前提(ぜんてい)にして will sound more active as ‘toward the premise of (A), (B)’. While を前提(ぜんてい)として sounds more passive as ‘with (A) as the premise (B).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このパソコンは仕事場で使われることを前提に作られているので、ゲームなどには向いていないです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This computer was made on the premise that it would be used in the workplace, so it is not suitable for games.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 娘さんとは結婚を前提にお付き合いをさせていただいています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am dating your daughter on the premise of marriage.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この車はレースをするということを前提に改造されているため公道では運転できません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This car was customized on the premise of racing, so you can’t drive it on public roads.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 名前を出さないということを前提にして、労基に上司のパワハラなどを通報した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: On the premise that they don’t make my name known, I reported to the Labor standards inspection office about my boss harassing me.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このアパートは、一人で住むことを前提として作られているので、キッチンとお風呂場は小さいです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This apartment was built on the premise that only one person will live here, so the kitchen and the bathroom is small.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私たちは、結婚を前提に付き合っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We are dating on the premise of marriage.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 元々、 一人で住むことを前提にこの家を建てたから、時が経ったらちょっと狭くなった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The house was originally built on the premise that I would live there by myself, so it turned out to be a little small over time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 原価見積は、建材の価格が緩やかに上昇することを前提に計算されます。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Cost estimates are calculated on the premise of a slow increase in the price of building materials.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 多くの家庭用ゲーム機を所有している人はゲームが終わったら売ることを前提にそのゲームを買っている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Many console owners purchase games based on the premise that they will sell them after finishing.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 本教科書は、文法に関する知識があることを前提に書かれています。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This textbook was written on the premise that you have an understanding of basic grammar.

Name: ずにはすまない
Meaning: Won't get away without, Won't get off without, Have to, Have no choice but to, Can’t not
About: ずにはすまない is used to indicate that one ‘has no choice but to (A)’, or ‘won’t get away without doing (A)’. It is a formal expression that is a combination of the negative classical auxiliary verb, ず, the case-marking particle に, the adverbial particle は, and the standard negated form of the う-Verb 済(す)む ‘to come to pass’, or ‘to finish’. Due to this, the more literal translation is ‘it will not come to pass that (A) is not done’, with the more natural English interpretations conveying the same feeling. As we can assume by this expression beginning with ず, it will exclusively follow verbs. Just like other instances where ず is used with する, ぜず will be the correct conjugation pattern. The standard (ない) negative form of a verb may also be followed by ではすまない. This has the same meaning as ずにはすまない.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんなに迷惑をかけてしまったんだから、謝らずにはすまないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I caused so much trouble, so I won’t get away without apologizing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 取引先のお偉いさんに飲みに誘われたから、行かずにはすまない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A high-ranking business partner invited me out for a drink, so I have no choice but to go.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 会社の先輩からの電話は出ずにはすまない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have no choice but to answer phone calls from my senpai from work.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やばい、田中君のゲーム機を壊してしまった。これは、弁償せずにはすまないな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Oh shoot, I broke Tanaka-kun’s gaming console. I won't get away without paying him back.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 父が大切にしていた釣竿を折ってしまった。謝らないではすまない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I accidentally broke a fishing rod my father took great care of. I won’t get away without apologizing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 税金は払わないではすまない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: You can’t get away without paying taxes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 重要な会議だから、間に合わないではすまない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's an important meeting, so I won't get away without making it on time.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は相談もなく重要な道具を廃棄した。首にならずにはすまないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He has scrapped an important tool without consultation. He won't get off without being fired.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私は子犬を助けるためとはいえ、無断で車の窓を破った。罰を受けずにはすまないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I broke the window of the car without permission, even though I was trying to save a puppy. I won't get away unpunished.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この深刻な問題は難しいので、上司に話さずにはすまないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I have no choice but to talk to my boss about it, since it is a serious problem.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大人なのだから、知らずではすまないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Since you are an adult, you won't get by without knowing it.

Name: に堪(た)えない
Meaning: Cannot bear to, Cannot stand to, Too much to, Cannot go on doing, Cannot tolerate
About: に堪(た)えない is a construction that will translate as ‘to not be able to bear (A)’, or ‘to not be able to tolerate (A)’. It is a mix of the case-marking particle に, and the negative form of the る-Verb 堪(た)える ‘to tolerate’, 堪(た)えない. In this meaning, に堪(た)えない will be used following verbs. This is in contrast to the に堪(た)えない grammar point that follows nouns, and means ‘to be very (A)’, but is more literally ‘to be so (A) I can’t stand it’. Although 堪(た)える will be used more often than other kanji that have the same reading and similar meanings, this is not always the case. Occasionally 耐(た)える ‘to withstand’ will be used when the emphasis is on the ability to endure (A), while 絶(た)える ‘to discontinue’, or ‘to peter out’ will be used when the emphasis is on not being able to suppress (A). For 絶(た)える, this is especially used in the case of strong feelings.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの映画に出ている役者さんみんなが大根役者だったので、見るに堪えなかったです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since all the actors that were in that movie were bad actors, I couldn’t bear to watch it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんの話はいつも人の悪口ばかり言っているので、聞くに堪えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can’t tolerate listening to Tanaka-san because he is always talking ill about others.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この本には過激な表現がありすぎるので、読むに堪えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There are too many graphic expressions in this book that I can’t bear to read it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 仕事の環境がひどすぎて続けるに耐えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The working conditions are so bad that I cannot bear to continue.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お客さんの所有物を壊してお客さんをだますなんて怒りに絶えない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am extremely outraged that they destroyed their customers’ property and lied to them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この漫画は内容がとてもよく、大人でも読むに堪える。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: This manga is worth reading, even for an adult, because it is well written.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やっと公開するに堪える音楽ができました！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have finally made a song that is worth publishing!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: くりやまさんの歌声は酷すぎて聞くに堪えなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Kuriyama-san's singing voice was so terrible that I couldn't bear to listen.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: このホラー映画には正視に堪えない、すごく残虐なシーンが多い。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In this horror movie, there are so many brutal scenes that I cannot bear to watch it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 最近、新聞で悪いニュースばかりが続いているから読むに堪えない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: With all the bad news in the newspaper lately, I cannot bear to read it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 嘘をついてばかりいる政治家のインタビューはもう聞くに堪えない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't tolerate listening to interviews with politicians who tell nothing but lies.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 中二病のころ撮った写真は恥ずかしすぎて見るに堪えないから消した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The photos I took when I was in my 'look at me' stage were so embarrassing that I couldn't bear to look at them, so I deleted them.

Name: 始末(しまつ)だ
Meaning: Ends up, Finally, In the end, (Unfortunately) As a result, This is what happened, To come about, To wind up
About: 始末(しまつ), a noun meaning ‘settlement’, or ‘end result’ is commonly used in order to indicate a negative sequence of events that has been passed through, causing an equally negative result to come about at the end. It will be translated as ‘to wind up as (A)’, ‘to end up as (A)’, or ‘to come about that (A)’. This expression will be used primarily after verbs in their dictionary form. Due to 始末(しまつ) being used to highlight negative outcomes that are the result of going through a specific event, it will often appear in sentences that also include words like とうとう ‘to come to a head’, 挙(あ)げ句(く) ‘after a long process’, or 結局(けっきょく) ‘in the end’. It may seem redundant to include these phrases, but as 始末(しまつ) has the more literal translation of ‘to culminate in’ (including everything from beginning to end), it is more emphatic, rather than redundant.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんだけダブルチェックをするように言ったのに、この始末だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I told him so many times to double check, but this is the result.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: みんなで祭りに行くつもりだったのに、みんながドタキャンするから、結局一人で行く始末だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We were supposed to go to the festival together, but everyone canceled suddenly, so I ended up going alone.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: その客は店中をぐちゃぐちゃにしたあげく、何も買わないで帰る始末だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: After messing up the whole store, they ended up leaving without buying anything.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 武田さんは小さな声で職場でハラスメントを受けたことを伝えてきて、しまいに大きな声で泣き出す始末だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Takeda-san quietly told me that she was being harassed at work, and wound up crying out loud.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あいつは、自分が起こしたミスなのに、謝るどころか私のせいにする始末だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though it was a mistake that he had made, far from apologizing, he ended up blaming me!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: せっかく友達と海へ行く計画を立てたのに、田中は大事な用があって行けないとか、武田もシフトが入ってたとかで、結局私一人だけで行く始末だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Even though I went out of my way to plan this trip to the beach with friends, Tanaka said that he had something important to do and couldn't go, while Takeda said that he had a shift. So I ended up going all by myself.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
武田：「山田さん、顔色が悪いですけど・・・」
山田：「夜遅くまでゲームをしていたので、おかげでこの始末だ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
Takeda: 'Yamada-san, you don't look so good...'
Yamada : 'I was playing video games until late at night, and this is the result.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田中には二度と仕事は頼まないぞ。納期は守らないし仕上がりも悪かったのに、言い訳ばかりならべて。最後には追加の料金を払えと言い出す始末だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I'll never ask Tanaka to work for me again. He can't meet deadlines, his workmanship is poor, and he only gives excuse after excuse. In the end he told me to pay an additional fee.

Name: ものなら ②
Meaning: If you were to do, If you try to, If … happens, Should there be
About: ものなら is a combination of the noun もの ‘thing’, and the hypothetical form of the auxiliary verb だ, なら ‘if’. Common translations include ‘If you were to (A), (B)’, of ‘if (A) happens, (B)’. In this particular use of ものなら, (A) will be a verb in its volitional form, and (B) will be some sort of negative result that would come about from that. Let’s have a look at a few examples. Keeping in mind that the volitional form can mean to approach an action with reckless abandon, it can be thought of as being similar to the English ‘to go and do (A)’, where the ‘to go and’ just indicates proceeding ahead without carefully considering the outcome.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼女の誕生日を忘れようものなら、一日中機嫌が悪くなる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you were to forget her birthday, she would be in a bad mood all day.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このレポートを出し忘れようものなら、今までの努力が水の泡だ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: All of our efforts would be worth nothing, if I happen to forget to submit this paper.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 以前同じようなことで炎上したから、また似たようなことで炎上しようものならこの業界から干されるに違いない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since we went under fire with something similar before, if we go under fire for something similar again, I am sure we would be sidelined from this industry.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: しのぶさんはとても血を恐れている。万が一、一滴でも血を見ようものなら気絶してしまうはずだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Shinobu is completely terrified of blood. If she were to see even one drop of it by chance, she would faint for sure.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ブラッド・ピットに出逢おうものなら、死んでしまう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If I were to run into Brad Pitt, I would die.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 秘密を打ち明けようものなら、彼女はすぐに他の奴らにしゃべってしまうだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you happen to tell her a secret, she will quickly spill it to others.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 万が一このプロジェクトが失敗しようものなら、我々は終わりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If this project were to fail, we'd be finished.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: うっかり彼のお菓子を食べようものなら、きっと、ものすごく彼にしかられるはずだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you were to go and eat his sweets, you would be scolded for sure.

Name: に引(ひ)き換(か)え
Meaning: In stark contrast, In comparison, On the other hand, While, In sharp contrast
About: に引(ひ)き換(か)え is a grammar pattern that is used for making contrasts between things, and will be translated as ‘in comparison to (A), (B)’, or ‘in stark contrast to (A), (B)’. The literal translation is ‘pulling back and switching away from (A), (B)’. This ‘switching away from’ portion may be used as a reminder of the large size of the difference that this grammar pattern usually indicates. に引(ひ)き換(か)え is a combination of the case-marking particle に, the conjunctive form of the う-Verb 引(ひ)く ‘to pull’, 引(ひ)き, and the conjunctive form of the る-Verb 換(か)える ‘to switch between’, or ‘to interchange’, 換(か)え. に引(ひ)き換(か)え may follow almost any type of word, but will require a の to precede it before い-Adjectives or verbs, and なの to precede it before な-Adjectives. (A) and (B) will always be two opposite ends of some kind of spectrum, where one is considered to be good, while the other is regarded as bad based on the subjective opinion of the speaker. Additionally, それにひきかえ may be used to begin sentences where the comparison is being made to a previous statement.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 周りの人たちはどんどん就職していっているのに引き換え、俺はまだ面接さえしていない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In stark contrast to the people around me, who are getting jobs, I haven’t even gone to an interview.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: うちの娘は頭がいいのに引き換え、うちの長男はゲームばかりして全然勉強をしようともしない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In stark contrast to my daughter, who is smart, all my eldest son wants to do is play videogames and won’t even try to study.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 親戚の全員が裕福なのに引き換え、なぜか私の家族だけが貧乏。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In stark contrast to all my relatives, who are wealthy, my family is poor for some reason.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 去年の夏に引き換え、今年の夏はえげつなく暑い。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In stark contrast to summer last year, summer this year is extremely hot.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 周りの子たちを見てみなさいよ！みんな来年から大学よ！それに引き換え、あんたったら。。。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Look at the kids around you! They are all going to college starting next year! In stark contrast to that you…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今は寒いのに引き換え、昼になったら暖かくなるかもしれない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In stark contrast to it being cold right now, it would probably get warmer at noon. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 母親の友達の息子さんは、弁護士として立派に働いているのにひきかえ、僕は・・・（まだフリーターだ）。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In stark contrast to my mother's friend's son, who is working prominently as a lawyer, I am… (still a permanent part-timer)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 姉は積極的で活発な性格にひきかえ、弟の健太郎はとても無気力だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In stark contrast to the elder sister's lively personality, the younger brother, Kentaro, is very apathetic.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 兄は優秀な成績をおさめている。それにひきかえ妹の方は遊んでばかりだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The elder brother has excellent grades. In stark contrast to that, the younger sister is just mucking around.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 前回のテストにひきかえ今回のテストは難しい。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In stark contrast to the previous test, this one is hard.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 隣の家の猫は痩せていて頭がいいのにひきかえうちの猫はぐうたらしてばかりだなあ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In stark contrast to the neighbor's cat, which is skinny and smart, our cat is just loafing around.

Name: それまでだ
Meaning: If… then it is all in vain, It's done, It is useless, No point, It is a waste, That's it, It is all gone,
About: ばそれまでだ is a hypothetical expression used when one wishes to indicate that ‘if (A) is reached, that’s as far as it will go’. This usually indicates that everything up to that point will unfortunately go to waste. Standard translations include ‘if (A), then it’s all been in vain’, ‘if (A), then all is a waste’, or ‘if (A), then there’s no point. Although verbs combining with the conjunction particle ば is the standard form of this grammar structure. The conjunction particle たら may also occasionally be used. Frequently this grammar structure will be seen in sentences that include ても or でも in the first half, with ばそれまでだ coming closer to the end. This indicates that ‘even if (A), if also (B), then there’s no point’.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このことが外部に漏れればそれまでだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If this information gets leaked, then it’s all in vain.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: やっとここまでたどり着いた。ここでミスを犯せばそれまでだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We finally got to this point. If we make a mistake then it’s all in vain.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: もう少し我慢をしろ！ここで見つかったらそれまでだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Have a little more patience! If they find you here, that's it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼らに訴えられたらそれまでだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If they sue us, that's it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 不可能だと言われればそれまでだ。せめて一回でもいいから試してみよう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: If you say it's impossible, that's the end of the story. Let’s at least give it a try, even if it's just once.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「毎日毎日勉強していてとても疲れてるんだ。大学を中退したい…。」
Ｂ：「でも、もう３年生だよ！あきらめてしまったらそれまでだよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'I'm studying every single day, I am so tired. I want to drop out of college...'
B: 'But you're already in your third year! If you give up then it's all in vain.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: どんなに大きな家でも、誰も住まなければそれまでだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: No matter how big the house is, if no one lives there then it's all in vain.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この内定を受諾することに興味がないだけと言えばそれまでだが、もういちどよく考えて決めたほうがいいだろうな。こんなチャンスは二度とないよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: If you say that you are not interested in accepting this offer then there is no point (in discussing further), but I think you'd better think it over once again and then decide. You won't get a second chance like this.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ダイエットしている友達へ：「頑張って運動しても毎日食べ過ぎたらそれまでだよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: To a friend who is dieting: 'Even if you do your best exercising, if you eat too much every day then it's all in vain.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: スパイ映画：「敵に発見されたらそれまでだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Spy movie: 'If we are discovered then it's all in vain.'

Name: と言(い)おうか
Meaning: How to put it, How shall I put it, How should I put it, Or perhaps, Or maybe, Call it … or
About: と言(い)おうか is an expression that combines the case-marking particle と in its quotation use, the volitional form of the う-Verb 言(い)う, 言(い)おう ‘to say’, and the adverbial particle か used for mid-sentence questions. It may be translated as ‘how to put it’, or ‘perhaps it’s (A), or perhaps it’s (B)’. However, the more literal ‘shall I say it is (A), or shall I say it is (B)’ is also a common interpretation. This expression will be used twice, where both the (A) and the (B) phrase are being questioned by the speaker. As with many other uses of と of a quotation, the preceding word may be almost anything. と言(い)おうか is interchangeable with the more common と言(い)うか, but it is advisable to only use it when specific emphasis needs to be made, or for some type of dramatic effect. In many cases, it will sound unnatural in daily speech. と言(い)おうか will frequently be used with fairly vague or imprecise descriptions, in order to avoid but hint at what the speaker actually wants to say. Often, this will be something negative, and will therefore be omitted.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: また彼女に誕生日を忘れられたんだ。あきれていると言おうか、傷ついたと言おうか、よくわからない。毎年のことだから慣れてきたけど…。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My girlfriend forgot my birthday again. How shall I put it, I don’t know whether I am disappointed or sad. Well, this happens every year so I’m starting to get used to it…

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あいつの運転は荒いと言おうか、危ないと言おうか、とにかくあいつが運転する車には乗りたくない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: How shall I put it, his driving is rough, perhaps dangerous, either way I don't want to get in a car operated by him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 自分の体を使ってお客さんの車を守ろうとするなんて、バカと言おうか、真面目すぎると言おうか分からない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: How shall I put it, I don't know whether to call him stupid or too serious for trying to protect a customer's car with his own body.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はいとこと言おうか、ハトコと言おうか、私もどういう関係かはわからないけど親戚だということはわかっている。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: How shall I put it, I don’t know if he is my cousin or my second cousin. I don’t know how we are related, but I know that we are relatives.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前は努力が足りないと言おうか、才能がないと言おうか…。（俺にはお前がこの仕事に向いていないと思う）
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: How shall I put it, you aren’t trying hard enough, or perhaps you are not talented… (I think that you are not suited for this job)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この前、電車を乗り違えてしまったんだ。僕はそのとき、自分でもこんなドジをして、面白いといおうか、困っているといおうか…とにかく忘れられない思い出になったよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I took the wrong train the other day. I made such a blunder at that time, how shall I put it, it was funny? or perhaps troubling?... Anyway, it turned into an unforgettable memory.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「プチチーズってなんですか。」
Ｂ：「クラッカーといおうか、チーズとのスナックといおうか…（うーん、的確な言葉が思い浮かばないなぁ）」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'What is Puchi cheese?'
B: 'How shall I put it, a cracker, or perhaps a snack with cheese... (well, I can't think of the right word)'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
「彼女は誰ですか？」
「彼の元カノといおうか友達といおうか複雑ですよ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
'Who is she?'
'How shall I put it, his ex-girlfriend, or perhaps his friend, it's complicated.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は穏やかといおうか、のんびりといおうか、何事につけてもゆっくりしている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: How shall I put it, he is calm or perhaps relaxed, he takes his time with everything.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: とうとう一人暮らしを始めたのに、寂しいといおうか嬉しいといおうか、よくわからない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I finally started living alone, and how shall I put it, I don't really know if I am lonely or happy.

Name: ずには措(お)かない
Meaning: Will definitely, Will certainly, Bound to, Not fail to
About: ずにはおかない is a combination of the classical auxiliary verb ず, the case-marking particle に, the adverbial particle は, and the standard negated form of the う-Verb 措(お)く, 措(お)かない, ‘to set aside’, or ‘to leave as is’. It is interpreted as ‘(A) will definitely happen’, or ‘I will not fail to (A)’. This is a formal expression that literally means ‘I cannot leave it as it is with (A) undone’, and therefore indicates strong will to complete the action that is reflected in the standard translations. As this structure begins with ず, it will only be used with verbs. Alternatively, ないでは may replace ず. This will be seen as ないではおかない. However, the meaning will not change at all.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あんなひどいことをした人だから、警察も捕まえずにはおかないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am sure the police will not fail to arrest that person, since they did something so horrible.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: メディアにも取り上げられたから、警察も調査をせずにはおかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since it was covered by the media, the police will certainly investigate.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こんなことをされたのだから、お客さんも訴えないではおかないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since they did such a thing to the customers, they would certainly sue them.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この犬は３０キロになるから、躾に力を入れないではおかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since this dog will become 30kg, I will not fail to train him.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの人のスピーチは聞く人を感動させずにはおかない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That person’s speech will not fail to move the audience.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説、勇者：「どんな手段を用いても、かならず魔王を倒さずにはおかない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'No matter what it takes, I will not fail to defeat the Demon Lord!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「私はきっと彼に同じ手で仕返しをしないではおかない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I won't fail to pay him back in his own coin.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「警察はすべての悪者に必ず罰を与えずにはおかない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'The police will not fail to punish all the wicked people.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「彼はまた私との約束をすっぽかした。絶対に彼に『ごめんなさい』と言わせずにはおかない。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'He skipped our appointment again. I won't fail to get him to say "I'm sorry".'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「探偵は『この残虐行為の責任者を訴追せずにはおかない』と意を決する。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'The detective resolved himself, "I won't fail to bring the person responsible for this atrocity to justice".'

Name: を限(かぎ)りに
Meaning: As of (the end of), (Starting) from, (No longer) after, By (the), Ending with
About: を限(かぎ)りに is a structure that follows nouns in order to express a time for which something that was continuing will finish by. Common interpretations include ‘ending with (A), (B)’, and ‘no longer than (A), (B)’. This grammar pattern makes use of the adverbial particle を, the noun 限(かぎ)り ‘limit’, and the case-marking particle に. を限(かぎ)りに is primarily used for making proclamations or announcements, and is more formal than similar structures like 限(かぎ)りで.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こちらの事情により、明日を限りに店を閉店させていただくことになりました。長年ご利用いただき誠にありがとうございました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Due to personal reasons, we have decided to close the store as of tomorrow. Thank you very much for your patronage over the years.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今月を限りに、海外に引っ越すことになりました。今までいろいろとお世話になりました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: As of this month, I will be moving abroad. Thank you so much for everything.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 来月行われるコンサートを限りにＳＵＭ４１は解散することを決めたそうです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: SUM41 has decided to disband after the concert next month.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 昨日の夜は息子が声を限りに泣いていたから大変だったよ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It was tough last night because my son was crying to the limit of his voice (crying as loud as he could).

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 明日を限りに閉店致します。当店は１９７２年に開業し、４９年にわたり現在の場所で営業してまいりました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: We will close as of tomorrow. This store opened in 1972 and has been operating at our current location for 49 years.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 異動、公務員：「今週限りで、現在の職務から離れることになりました。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Changes in personnel, civil servant: 'I will be leaving my current position as of this week.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 同僚との話：「今月限りで田中さんは退職するつもりって聞いたけど、本当か？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Conversation between coworkers: 'I heard that Tanaka is planning to resign as of this month, but is that true?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 今回を限りに武田先生は人前では演奏しません。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Takeda-sensei will not perform in public as of now.

Name: ては叶(かな)わない
Meaning: It's unbearable when, It'd be unbearable if, I can't stand it when, I couldn’t stand it if
About: In order to convey that something is undesirable, the grammar structure てはかなわない may be used. This combines the conjunction particle て, the adverbial particle は, and the negative form of the う-Verb 叶(かな)う ‘to grant (a wish)’, or ‘to realize (a goal)’. This may be interpreted as ‘it’s unbearable when (A)’, or ‘I can’t stand it when (A)’. However, the literal translation is ‘it’s not a dream come true for (A)’. When used following verbs, the (A) verb is often in the passive. This indicates that the speaker does not like being the target or victim of (A). However, standard verb structures may also be seen. In addition to this, てはかなわない may follow the conjunctive form of い-Adjectives, or appear as ではかなわない when following な-Adjectives.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 明日充電器を忘れてはかなわないから、今のうちに鞄に入れておこう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It’d be unbearable if I forgot my charger tomorrow, so I am going to put it in my bag right now.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こう頭が痛くてはかなわない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It’s unbearable when my head aches like this.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 息子に竿を折られてはかなわないから、手が届かないところに置いておこう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It’d be unbearable if my son breaks my fishing rod, so I am going to put it out of reach.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今繁忙期だしこんな時にやめられてはかなわない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It’d be unbearable if they quit during peak season.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 電車で隣に座っている人がくさくてはかなわない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It is unbearable when the person sitting next to you on the train smells.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: そうあやふやではかなわない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It’s unbearable when you are vague like that.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 漢字とくると彼女にはかなわない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: She is no match for me when it comes to kanji.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: こう寒くてはかなわない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's unbearable when it's cold like this.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 雨に降られてはかなわない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I can't stand getting rained on.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 上の部屋の人がうるさくてはかなわない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's unbearable when the people upstairs are noisy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 話をしている時、非常識なひとに邪魔されてはかなわない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's unbearable when I am interrupted by a thoughtless person when I am speaking.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 毎日こんなに蒸し暑くてはかなわない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: It's unbearable when it is so humid every day like this.

Name: 旁(かたがた)
Meaning: Partly for (the purpose of), In addition to, Along with, By the way, And also to, Incidentally, While
About: 旁(かたがた) is a conjunction that will be seen primarily in hiragana. This word will be translated as ‘in addition to doing (A), (B)’, ‘along with (A), (B)’, or ‘incidentally to (A), (B)’. Both (A) and (B) usually have an equal level of priority, but (B) will have the nuance of ‘while (A), also (B) in passing’. かたがた will attach to the end of a noun that marks (A), while (B) will often, but not always, mark a verb of action. In cases where (A) is a noun that would usually take する, the する will be omitted entirely.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 婚約の報告かたがた、お父様とお母様に会いに行きます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I will go see (my partner’s) father and mother, partly for the purpose of letting them know about our engagement.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 妊娠の報告かたがた、相手の両親の家を訪ねた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I visited my partner’s parents, partly for the purpose of letting them know about the pregnancy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お礼かたがた、そちらにお伺いをしたいと思っています。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I would like to come visit you, partly for the purpose of thanking you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 本棚の整理かたがた、春の大掃除をした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I did some spring cleaning, partly for the purpose of cleaning out my bookshelf. (Unnatural Japanese)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 恩師の訪問：「本日は当時のお礼かたがた、卒業して以来どうしているかをご報告しに訪ねさせていただきました。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Visiting a former teacher: 'Today I visited her to express my gratitude for that time in my life, and also to let her know how I have been doing since I graduated.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ​​挨拶状：「まずは右ご挨拶かたがたお知らせまで。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Greeting card: For now, this is only a notification and also greetings.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 結婚の報告かたがた、妻の兄弟の家を訪ねました。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I visited my wife's sibling's house partly for the purpose of announcing our marriage.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 同じ会社で働く上司へのメール：「ご挨拶かたがた訪問をさせて頂きたいのですが、明日のご都合はいかがでしょうか。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Email to a superior in the same company: 'I would like to pay you a visit to say hello and also other things. How would tomorrow be for you?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ​​同じ会社で働く上司へのメール：「まずはお礼かたがたご挨拶申し上げます。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: ​​Email to a superior in the same company: 'For now, I would like to express my gratitude, and also greetings.'

Name: を余儀(よぎ)なくさせる
Meaning: Force to, To compel, Make unavoidable
About: Like を余儀(よぎ)なくされる, a formal grammar pattern that is usually translated as ‘to be forced to (A)’, を余儀(よぎ)なくさせる has the same base, but uses the causative auxiliary verb させる ‘to make do’, in place of the passive される ‘to have done to one’. Its component parts are the adverbial particle を, the noun 余儀(よぎ) ‘another method’, the conjunctive form of the い-Adjective ない, なく, and the causative form of する, させる. In this way, it literally means ‘to not give another way than to (A)’. を余儀(よぎ)なくさせる will be seen following an (A) noun, where (A) is the thing that is unavoidable. Unlike を余儀(よぎ)なくされる, in most cases the (A) subject of sentences that use を余儀(よぎ)なくさせる will be non-human cause. However, there are exceptions to this.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 外出自粛要請が、飲食店の閉店を余儀なくさせた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The official request to refrain from going out forced many eating establishments to close.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 地元住民からの反対の声が、ショッピングモールの建設の中止を余儀なくさせた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The voices of opposition from the residents, they were forced to cancel the construction of the shopping mall.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運転手の不注意が、入院を余儀なくさせた。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The carelessness of the driver, forced them to get hospitalized.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 地球温暖化が、サンタクロースに北極点から移転することを余儀なくさせた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Global warming forced Santa Claus to relocate away from the North Pole.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パンデミックは店や学校の閉鎖を余儀なくさせた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The pandemic forced stores and schools to close.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大洪水は都市からの撤退を余儀なくさせた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The major flood forced people to withdraw from the city.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ７０年代のエネルギー危機は政府にガソリン以外の代替エネルギーを探すことを余儀なくさせた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The energy crisis of the 1970s forced the government to look for alternative energy sources, other than gasoline.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: バブル崩壊が彼に会社の株式の売却を余儀なくさせた。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The economic bubble burst forced him to sell his shares in the company.

Name: ～てやる
Meaning: Just wait and see, Just you wait, To do a favor, For you, Definitely, For sure
About: The う-Verb やる, occasionally seen in the kanji form 遣(や)る, primarily means ‘to do’, but can also mean ‘to give’ as the casual form of あげる. When attached to the て-form of verbs, it acts as a subsidiary verb. When substituting for あげる, it will often sound patronizing, or that the speaker is doing an action because it is unavoidable, and the person they are doing it for cannot do it themselves. This will be translated as ‘to do for’. In other cases, やる acts more like 見(み)せる ‘to show’, and indicates the speaker’s strong will to perform an action. In these cases, it will be translated as ‘I will do (A), just wait and see’, or ‘I’ll definitely do (A)’. However, in either the place of あげる or みせる, the underlying meaning is just ‘to do’, with emphasis on the doer being the person that is in power over the result of the action due to their superiority.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: いいよいいよ、俺がやってやるからお前は見とけ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Don’t worry about it, I’ll do it for you, so just watch.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 今夜は俺が奢ってやるから、どんどん好きなもん頼めばいいからな。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I’m going to pay for you, so don’t hesitate and order whatever you want.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 絶対綺麗になって見返してやる！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am going to become pretty and prove them wrong, just wait!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: こうなったら勝ってやるしかないだろ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Well, in a situation like this there is no other choice but to win!

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ​​アクション映画のマッチョな主人公：「ぶっころしてやる！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: ​​The macho protagonist in an action movie: 'I'm gonna kill you!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ​​お金がなくて行きたい大学に行けないという状況：「金持ちになってやる！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: ​​The situation of not being able to go to the school one wants to, due to money problems: 'I will get rich, just you wait!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ​​低得点で馬鹿にされた後：「絶対、次のテストでは百点取って、あいつをみかえしてやる。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: ​​After being ridiculed for a low score: 'I will definitely score 100 on the next test and prove I'm better than that dude, just you wait!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「絶対、合格してやる！」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'I will surely pass, just wait and see!'

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
​​Ａ子：「こっちからあっちまで競走しよ！」
​​Ｂ子：「いいよ、かってやる!」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
​​Child A: 'Let's race from here to there!'
​​Child B: 'Okay! I'll win!'

Name: ただ〜のみ
Meaning: Nothing but, Should, Have to, Only, All that remains,
About: ただ～のみ is an expression that is commonly interpreted as ‘(A) is all that is required’, or ‘(A) is all that remains’. It is a combination of the neologism ただ ‘merely’, and the adverbial particle のみ ‘just’ or ‘only’. のみ itself has the same meanings and uses as both だけ and ばかり, but is slightly more formal. Frequently, (A) will be a verb that indicates movement, continuation, or hope. This highlights that one has already done everything that is possible, and all that is left to do is hope for a good result, or that one is already doing all that is necessary, and all that remains is to continue. When する-Verbs are used with this expression, occasionally it will be replaced by ある. This puts more focus on the existence of the action, rather than the action itself. The replacement of する with ある is primarily literary.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 私たちにはもう何もできない。ただ医者を信じて待つのみだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There is nothing we can do anymore. What we can do is nothing but trust the doctor and wait.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 僕にできることはただ祈るのみです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can do nothing but pray.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 将来日本の大手企業に勤めたいので、ただ勉強あるのみだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Since I want to work in a big Japanese company in the future, I have no choice but to study.

Questions.JapaneseHTML:
Ａ：「どうやれば作家になる夢を実現することができるのでしょう？」
Ｂ：「やっぱりなにごとも練習あるのみだな。」
Questions.EnglishHTML:
A: 'How can I achieve my dream of becoming a writer?'
B: 'In the end, It all rests on practice.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「できるだけのことをした。あとは降伏するのみだ。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'We have done all we can. All that remains is to surrender.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 人生には後悔する暇なんてありません。ただ前進あるのみです。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There is no time for something like regrets in life. We have only to move forward.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: テストを受けた後、ただ結果を待つのみだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'After taking the test, all that remains is to wait for the results.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 「このような状況ではただ前に進んで迎えに行くのみであります。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: 'In a situation like this, there is no choice but to keep moving forward.'

Name: ものとする
Meaning: Shall, To assume, To suppose, To consider
About: Like many grammar expressions that use もの, this noun will imply that the word or phrase that comes before it is a strong determination. Due to this, when とする ‘as (A)’, or ‘in the capacity of (A)’ is added, it presents a situation in which the speaker is determining that (A) is true for the sake of discussion. In English, this may be interpreted as ‘supposing that (A)’, or ‘on the assumption that (A)’. ものとする, like ものとして, will primarily be seen after verbs. However, unlike ものとして, ものとする will almost always appear at the end of a sentence, and highlights things that are being taken as facts in legalese, and other forms of contractual writing.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 住民税は世帯主が払うものとする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: The head of the household shall pay the resident’s tax.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 契約者の都合で解約をした場合、契約者に解約金を請求するものとする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In the event that the subscription is canceled due to the subscriber’s personal reasons, a termination fee shall be charged to the subscriber.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ダム建設に対して批判の声が上がったときには、ダム建設を取り下げるものとする。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We shall withdraw from building a dam in the event where people oppose it.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 契約者は、次に掲げる業務を行うものとする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: A contractor shall perform the duties listed below.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 別表第七に定める帳簿は、五年間保存するものとする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The account books provided in attached table 7 shall be retained for five years.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 当該研究は、法令の範囲内で行うものとする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The said research shall be conducted within the limits permitted by laws and regulations.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 延滞金は、納付金に先立つものとする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Penal interest shall be collected prior to the payment.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 契約書は、英語と日本語をもって記載するものとする。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The contract shall be recorded in both English and Japanese.

Name: との
Meaning: That, To
About: との is a compound particle made up of the case-marking particle と in its quotation use, and the case-marking particle の. Effectively, this marks the previous statement as a quote, before の then indicates that the whole statement is an attribute of the following word. In many cases, this will simply be translated as ‘that’, or ‘to’. As always with the quotation use of と, it will appear after almost any word, and may or may not be separated from nouns and な-Adjectives with だ. This expression indicates that the preceding information is information of some type, and will therefore usually be followed by a noun that highlights what type of communication it was. Common examples include 提案(ていあん) ‘proposal’, 知(し)らせ　’notice’, 意向(いこう) ‘inclination’, 依頼(いらい) ‘request’, 見方(みかた) ‘point of view’, 指摘(してき) ‘pointing out’, 報告(ほうこく) ‘report’, etc.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この周辺で誘拐事件が起きたとの放送があったが、犯人の特徴については放送されなかった。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There was an announcement that there was a kidnapping in this area, but the description of the culprit was not mentioned.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この店はほかの店舗に比べてきたないとのクレームが何件も寄せられているがどうなってるんだい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: There was a complaint that this store is dirty compared to the other store, would you mind explaining?

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 本部からこの喫茶店の接客は雑だとの報告を受けました。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: We have received a report from headquarters, saying that the customer service at this cafe is sloppy.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: ここの先生はヤブ医者との噂を最近聞くけど本当なのだろうか。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Recently I have been hearing rumors that he is an unskilled doctor, but I wonder how true that is.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの客はクレーマーだとの指摘を先輩から受けたので、あのお客さんを接客するときはいつもより丁寧に接客するつもりだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: My senpai told me that that customer makes a lot of complaints, so I am planning to be extra polite when interacting with them.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 多くの経済学者は、景気が回復しつつあるとの見方を維持した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Many economists maintain the opinion that business conditions are in the process of recovering.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 政府関係者は電気自動車の普及を推進するとの意向を強調した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The government officials stressed that their intention was to promote the popularization of electric vehicles.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 田中さんは新しい反トラスト法が抜け穴だらけとの意見を表明した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Mr. Tanaka made clear his view that the new antitrust law is full of loopholes.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 探偵の伝記：「２００２年、彼は、南アフリカに連れて行った男性の家出人を探してほしいとの依頼を受けた。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: The biography of a detective: 'In 2002, he received a request to find a runaway man that went to South Africa.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: あの日、 雪崩が発生したとの報告もあったが、けが人が出ているかどうかは確認されていなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: That day there was also a report that an avalanche had occurred, but it was not clear whether any injured people had appeared.

Name: 以前(いぜん)
Meaning: Before, Not even, Before even, Precede, Far from
About: When used as a suffix, the noun 以前(いぜん) ‘preceding’, or ‘prior to’ will indicate that a topic is being brought forward as not even fulfilling the minimum requirements of (A), and therefore is expected to be reached before that minimum. Often, this will come across as ‘before even (A)’ in English, and is used to criticize something that is thoughtless or irresponsible. 以前(いぜん) will appear directly after another nouns, the dictionary form of verbs, い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives. In most cases, 以前(いぜん) will be followed by either the case-marking particle に or の, depending on whether it is being linked to a subsequent verb or noun. The word 以前(いぜん) itself is usually reserved for highlighting larger distances in the past than 前(まえ) ‘before’ by itself, and can therefore simply be thought of as an emphatic version of 前(まえ). This emphasis is often what gives rise to the tone of criticism. As it is stating that ‘way before (A), (B)’, or ‘long before you even think of (A), (B)’.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 人のことを心配する以前に自分の心配をしろ！
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Before worrying about others, worry about yourself!

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは古いか新しいか以前の問題だと思う。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I think that is a problem before worrying about whether it is new or old.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 安全か危険か以前に、それは法律で禁じられているので試すこともできません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Before whether it is safe or dangerous, that is forbidden by law, so you will not even be able to try it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: お前が結婚できないのは顔以前の問題だよ。お前は性格が悪すぎる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Your face is far from the reason you cannot get married. You have a bad personality.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ポイ捨ては法律いぜんの道義的な問題だ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: When it comes to littering, before even the law, it is a moral issue.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 彼は、自分が女の子にモテないのはファッションがださいからだと思ってる。それは事実だけど、それいぜんの問題として、彼は性格に問題がある。
Questions.EnglishHTML: He believes that he is not popular with girls due to his bad fashion sense. While that is true, even before that, he has issues with his personality.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 信じる信じないいぜんにもっと根本的な問題なんだよ。先ずどうにか彼女にこの事を伝えなきゃ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Before whether she believes it or not, there is a more fundamental issue. To start, I must somehow convey this to her.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 食べずに「ブロッコリーが嫌い」という人もいます。好き嫌いいぜんに、食べてみることが大事なのです。食べた上で、好き嫌いはご自由に。
Questions.EnglishHTML: There are even people who say 'I don't like brocolli', without having eaten it. Before being nitpicky, what's important is to try it. Upon eating it, then feel free to be fussy.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: パフォーマンスいぜんの問題で、基本的な機能を実装する必要があります。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Preceding the performance issue, it is necessary to equip it with basic functionality.

Name: ともあろう
Meaning: Of all people, Such,
About: ともあろう is a grammatical structure in Japanese which highlights either the skill or responsibility that a particular person or organization has, and what they are doing despite that, or that contradicts that. It will be interpreted as ‘(A) of all people’, or ‘such as (A)’. Often, ともあろう will be followed by the speaker's opinion about how (A) is being ignorant of what is expected of them. This construction is a combination of the case-marking particle と, the adverbial particle も, and the volitional form of the う-Verb ある, あろう ‘to be’. The literal meaning is ‘even a (B) such as (A), (C)’, with (C) being something unexpected or unwanted. ともあろう will be seen after nouns, and may be followed by the conjunction particle が ‘but’, or a combination of the noun もの and が for further emphasis. もの is primarily used for emphasis, and other words such as 方(かた) ‘individual’, or 人(ひと) ‘person’ may also be used.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 有名な大学の教授ともあろう人が、ろくに敬語も使えないなんておかしい。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Of all people, it is strange that a professor of a famous university cannot even use keigo properly.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 教会の牧師さんともあろうお方が、詐欺で逮捕されるなんてショックすぎる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I am so shocked that the pastor of a church of all people was arrested for fraud.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 警察ともあろうものが違法薬物を使用していたなんて信じられない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I can’t believe that a police officer of all people was using an illegal substance.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 高橋さんともあろうお方がこんな簡単なことができないなんて、珍しいですね。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Takahashi-san, it is so rare that a person such as yourself can’t do something so simple. (Sarcastic)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この田中さんともあろうものがくだらないミスをしてしまった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: For Mr. Tanaka of all people to make such a silly mistake.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 大自然を保護することを呼びかけている国会議員ともあろうものが、砂浜にごみを散らかすとは信じられない。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Of all people, It is unbelievable that a member of the Diet who calls for the protection of nature would litter at the beach.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 乱世の時にこんなふざけた言動があるだろうか。議員ともあろうものが…
Questions.EnglishHTML: A joke like this in such turbulent times? And from a member of parliament of all people…

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 上司が部下坂本に：「君ともあろう優秀な部下がこんなミスをするなんて。なぜあんなことを？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Superior to his subordinate, Sakamoto: 'I cannot believe that of all people, brilliant subordinate such as you would make this kind of mistake. Why did you do such a thing?'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: ファンタジー映画：「 賢いウィザードともあろう者がいつ正気を失った？」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Fantasy movie: 'When did the wise wizard of all people lose all sanity?'

Name: こそすれ〜ない
Meaning: And certainly not, But certainly not, But, Although, Even though
About: Occasionally in Japanese, the adverbial particle こそ will be seen followed by the realis form (sometimes referred to as the perfective form) of verbs. This is a classical verb form that does not have a modern counterpart. However, the hypothetical form has largely replaced the realis form in the manner in conjugates. The verbs that will be seen altered this way are する ‘to do’, なる ‘to become’, and ある ‘to be’. They will respectively become こそすれ, こそなれ, and こそあれ , and are used specifically for emphasis. Common translations include ‘certainly not (B), but (A)’, or ‘even though (B), actually (A)’. The (B) phrase in this grammar point will include a negative statement, and is usually something that the speaker is responding to or correcting about what another person mistakenly thought. こそすれ may attach to either the noun part of する-Verbs, or the conjunctive form of standard verbs. なれ and あれ will be used based on the standard rules of what type of word なる would usually appear with (a noun or adjective), and what type of word ある would usually appear with (a noun).

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: このままだと日本の経済は悪化こそすれ、回復はしないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: At this rate, Japan's economy will continue to worsen, and certainly not recover.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのカードは世界に一枚しかないので値段が上がりこそすれ、下がりはしないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That is the only card that exists in this world, so the price will keep rising, and certainly not decrease.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 運動は健康のためにこそなれ、絶対に損にはならない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Exercise will be beneficial for your health, and you certainly won’t regret it.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: それは損にこそなれ、利益になることはないだろう。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: That would be a loss, and certainly won’t be profitable.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 憎みこそあれ、実際に傷つけようとは思ったこともない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I have felt hatred towards you, but I certainly have never thought of actually hurting you.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼はコミュニケーションの能力こそあれ、仕事は得意ではない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He has skill in communication, but he certainly is not a skilled worker.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 感謝されこそすれ、文句を言われる筋合いはない。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: I should be thanked, you certainly are not in the position to complain.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: セキュリティ事故は増えこそすれ、減りはしないだろう。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The security incidents will only increase, certainly not decrease.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 小説：「だが実際は、剣士の復讐心は火の手を強めこそすれ、決して冷めるどころではなかったのである。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Novel: 'In reality, however, the swordsman's blazing desire for vengeance was intensifying, and certainly not cooling down at all.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 多くの人にとって、その奇妙な現象は驚きこそすれ、恐怖を感じるほどではなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: The strange phenomenon was surprising for many, and certainly not terrifying.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 魔法使いへの恋情は、強めこそすれ弱めるものではなかった。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Her love for the sorcerer strengthened, and certainly didn't weaken.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 感謝こそすれ、憎しみを感じるなんてちゃんちゃらおかしいよ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: I feel gratitude, certainly not something as ridiculous as hatred.

Name: 並(な)み
Meaning: As, On par with, Worthy of
About: 並(な)み is the noun form of the classical verb 並(な)む, which has the same meaning as 並(なら)ぶ, ‘to line up’, or ‘to be in line’. It will be used following nouns, and may be interpreted as ‘on par with (A)’, ‘worthy of (A)’, or ‘as standard for (A)’. However, the literal translation of ‘in line with (A)’ also works just as well in many cases.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あの子のサーブの仕方はプロ並みだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Their serve is on par with pros.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: まだ５月なのに８月並みの暑さだ。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Despite it still being May, it is as hot as August.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 彼は日本語をネイティブ並みに話せるから、彼がいると安心できる。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: He can speak Japanese as well as a native, so I feel at ease when he is around.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: あのような家は並の人には高すぎます。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: A house like that is too expensive for the average person.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 並の大学生がお金を貯めるにはアルバイトだけではなく、節約できるところで節約もしないといけません。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: In order for the average college student to save money, not only do they have to work part-time, but they also have to cut expenses where they can.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: この子供の柔軟さはトカゲ並みのレベルがありそうです。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: It seems that this kid’s flexibility is on par with that of a lizard. (Unnatural Japanese, as the flexibility of a lizard is not something that is either easy to imagine, or common knowledge)

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 私の妻の歌はプロ並みだ。
Questions.EnglishHTML: My wife's singing is on par with pros.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: アトランタの年間日照時間は、ローマ平均並みである。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Atlanta's annual daylight hours are on par with Rome's average.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: チタンは鋼鉄並みの丈夫さだが、はるかに軽量である。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Titanium is as strong as steel, yet much lighter.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: この映画はアカデミー賞並みの功績でした。
Questions.EnglishHTML: This movie was an achievement on par with the level of an academy award.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 統計から推測すると、中国の経済は先進国並みになってきている。
Questions.EnglishHTML: Statistics suggest that China's economy has come to be on par with with that of other developed countries.

Name: に先駆(さきが)けて
Meaning: First, Prior to, Pioneer, Ahead of
About: に先駆(さきが)け, is an expression used after nouns which indicates that something is being done ‘ahead of (A)’, or in a way that ‘paves the way for (A)’. It is a combination of the case-marking particle に, and the conjunctive form of the る-verb 先駆(さきが)ける, meaning ‘to lead the attack’, or ‘to pioneer’. In most cases, 先駆(さきが)け will imply that one person or organization did something first, which then led to everyone else within the same category taking the same course of action. Common translations include ‘prior to (A), (B)’, or ‘ahead of (A), (B)’. Occasionally, the conjunction particle て may be used after the base 先駆(さきが)け form. As this grammar structure often indicates whole bodies that took a similar action after (B), に先駆(さきが)け will usually be seen after words like 世界(せかい) ‘the world’, 全国(ぜんこく) ‘the whole country’, 全市(ぜんし) ‘the whole city’ or ‘every city’, 業界(ぎょうかい) ‘the industry’, 他社(たしゃ) ‘other companies’, or 他(た)◯ ‘or anything’.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 世界に先駆け、あの国は死刑を廃止した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Pioneering for other countries, that country was the first to abolish the death penalty.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: 三重県は全国に先駆け、梅雨入りをした。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Ahead of the rest of the nation, the rainy season kicked off in Mie prefecture.

AboutExamples.JapaneseHTML: Ａ社は他社に先駆けて、自動運転が可能な車を開発した。
AboutExamples.EnglishHTML: Paving the way for other companies, Company A developed a self-driving automobile.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: １７６３年に、プロイセンは他国に先駆けて近代的な義務教育を導入した。
Questions.EnglishHTML: In 1763, paving the way for other countries, Prussia introduced the modern compulsory education.

Questions.JapaneseHTML: コンサートのサイト：「ファンクラブでは、一般発売に先駆けて、チケットの販売を行います。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Concert website: 'The selling of tickets via the fan club will take place prior to offering them to the general public.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 広告：「世界の人々に先駆けて、楽しみながら学ぶ体験型博物館を訪れてみてはいかがでしょう。」
Questions.EnglishHTML: Advertisement: 'How about paving the way for the people of the world and visiting an interactive museum, where you can learn and have fun at the same time.'

Questions.JapaneseHTML: 我が社は他社に先駆けて世界初となる海流発電の実証実験を成功させた。
